webTitle: Brown pep-talk brings families new tax cheer

fields.headline: Brown pep-talk brings families new tax cheer
fields.standfirst:
Chancellor pledges 'generous' tax credit cash-back to lower-income parents
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown yesterday signalled future tax cuts for families as he promised a children's tax credit worth up to 2.5 per cent off the basic rate in the run-up to the election.
fields.byline: by Gaby Hinsliff, chief political correspondent
fields.body:
Gordon Brown yesterday signalled future tax cuts for families as he promised a children's tax credit worth up to 2.5 per cent off the basic rate in the run-up to the election.

In a speech designed to pep up Labour activists ahead of the campaign, the Chancellor said he would offer a more generous than expected £10-a-week tax credit - cash back in the pay packet - targeted at lower-income parents.

But he left the way clear for further generosity in what will be a highly political Budget just before the Government goes to the polls.

Brown's speech will be seen as a response to the aggressive Tory tax-cutting agenda outlined over the last few weeks, attempting to position Labour as the party that can offer the most robustly calculated and wisely targeted cuts. His speech made clear that tax and spending will be the key battleground of the election campaign. Labour's manifesto would be based on a theme of prosperity for all, compared to 'irresponsible' offers of Tory cuts.

'So in future budgets tax cuts will be targeted on the priorities: work, families, savings and investment - helping pensioners such as our pensions credit - and the environment,' he said.

'But we will not go along with irresponsible or indiscriminate cuts that undermine our stability, irresponsible tax promises that risk repeating 1992 - where tax cuts before the election lead to public spending cuts and rises just after.'

His criticisms were rubbished by the Tories however who said that after raising 'stealth taxes' worth up to 10p in the pound it was surprising Brown 'had the gall to start talking about tax cuts'.

'In the last three-and-a-half years they have put taxes up by stealth to the equivalent of almost 10p in the pound, hitting hard-working families hardest,' a Tory spokeswoman said. 'Now, in the final months before the election, they have the gall to start talking about tax cuts. No one will believe Labour's promises second time around.'

Liberal Democrat Treasury spokesman Matthew Taylor said poorest families were paying more under Labour. 'The rich have benefited from tax cuts while pensioners, schools and the health service have gone without,' he said. 'Liberal Democrat priorities are to help poorer families by cutting tax on people with low incomes.'

Privately senior Labour ministers have been worried that complacency among their supporters, who believe the Government has the election in the bag, could cost them dear next spring.

Brown's speech, along with a similar address from Peter Mandelson, expected to warn of the dangers of voters switching off, was designed to galvanise the party into action. Meanwhile, the Tories will tomorrow signal a retreat on plans for housing benefit reform with a plan to save £475m on the welfare bill.

Failing councils who cannot reduce fraud and error in housing benefit would be stripped of their powers to deliver it, with the national Benefits Agency stepping in, Shadow Social Security Secretary David Willetts will say.

Previously the Tories had wanted the entire payment centralised but gave up on that as too draconian.

The changes are viewed as a first step to reforms which could tighten eligibility for the benefit, reducing payments to some claimants.

Cash saved would be added to the Tories' target of saving £8bn on spending to give back in tax cuts.

webTitle: Revealed: Pinochet drug smuggling link

fields.headline: Revealed: Pinochet drug smuggling link
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The Chilean army and secret police have spent almost two decades secretly flooding Europe and the US with massive shipments of cocaine. The trafficking began during the 17-year dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet and continues to this day, a year-long investigation for  The Observer has established.
fields.body:
The Chilean army and secret police have spent almost two decades secretly flooding Europe and the US with massive shipments of cocaine. The trafficking began during the 17-year dictatorship of General Augusto Pinochet and continues to this day, a year-long investigation for The Observer has established.

Twelve tons of the drug, with a street value of several billion pounds, left Chile in 1986 and 1987 alone. The drugs, destined for Europe, have often been flown to Spanish territory by aircraft carrying Chilean-made arms to Iraq and Iran. Distribution to Britain and other European countries has been controlled by secret police stationed in Chilean embassies in Stockholm and Madrid.

The revelations will come as an embarrassment to the Conservative Party, which criticised Pinochet's arrest in London in 1998 and backed his fight to avoid deportation to Spain on charges of murder and torture. The news will be particularly unwelcome to Lord Lamont, the former Chancellor, who was in Santiago last week to deliver a letter of support to the former dictator from Lady Thatcher.

Under Conservative governments, large quantities of British arms were sold to Chile, and British firms such as Royal Ordnance collaborated with the development of Chile's weapons potential.

There can be no doubt that Pinochet, whose power was absolute between the 1973 coup and his surrender in 1990, was a party to trafficking. He declared in October 1981: 'Not a leaf moves in Chile if I don't move it - let that be clear.'

The secret police - originally known as the Dina and from 1977 as the SNI - was staffed by service personnel and helped Pinochet to torture and kill opponents.

The Dina's former director, General Manuel Contreras, declared to the Chilean supreme court in 1998 that he undertook nothing without Pinochet's express permission.

The huge profits from the drug deals went to enrich senior figures in Chile, with some going to finance the Dina/SNI operations.

Pinochet, who is now fighting arrest on kidnapping and murder charges in Santiago, has not clarified how he and his wife, Lucia, had $1,169,308 (around £730,000) in their account in the Riggs Bank in Washington on 1 March 1997. As commander-in-chief of the Chilean army, his annual salary in March 1997 was $16,000 (£10,000).

New evidence of Pinochet's collaboration with Colombian drug dealers, first sketched out last year in this writer's book, Pinochet: The Politics of Torture , has emerged in The Thin White Line , a new book by Rodrigo de Castro, a former international civil servant in Chile, and Juan Gasparini, an Argentine journalist. It quotes US court documents, Chilean police files and depositions by a former US marine involved in the trafficking.

The former marine, Frankell Ivan Baramdyka, was extradited from Chile in May 1993 and convicted in southern California of narcotics offences. He worked for US intelligence in the early Eighties and was encouraged to traffic in drugs on condition that some of the profits went to the Contra terrorists in Nicaragua, who were being supported by President Ronald Reagan.

Baramdyka has revealed how he first made contact with the Chileans in 1984 when, acting for Colombian cocaine producers, he delivered $2m to the Chilean consulate-general in Los Angeles. This was a payment for chemicals needed to make cocaine which had been supplied by the Chilean army.

At the time Pinochet's younger son, Marco Antonio, was on the consulate-general's staff.

After the US authorities raided his home in Los Angeles in 1985, Baramdyka fled to Santiago, where he set up a new trafficking operation. Later that year he was recruited by the Chilean secret police and was soon overseeing the army's drug-export activities. The operations included the dispatch of cocaine on flights taking Chilean arms to Iran or Iraq.

webTitle: Fears grow that IRA murdered Protestant

fields.headline: Fears grow that IRA murdered Protestant
fields.standfirst:
Taxi driver's death and tit-for-tat UDA killing of Catholic pose new threat to peace

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Suspicions are growing that disgruntled Provisional IRA members shot dead a Protestant taxi driver last week, sparking a wave of sectarian shootings and marking a new threat to Gerry Adams's peace strategy.
fields.body:
Suspicions are growing that disgruntled Provisional IRA members shot dead a Protestant taxi driver last week, sparking a wave of sectarian shootings and marking a new threat to Gerry Adams's peace strategy.

The RUC and Republican Socialists believe PIRA members murdered Trevor Kell in north Belfast last Tuesday evening. His death provoked the Ulster Defence Association - which, like the PIRA, is officially on ceasefire - to murder one Catholic and wound another in retaliation.

If the PIRA unit did carry out the Kell killing, it will represent a serious challenge to Adams and the other leader of the republican movement, Martin McGuinness.

The killing means that either there is a fresh split within the PIRA, or that someone in the organisation's leadership sanctioned the murder to thwart moves to extend the arms decommissioning process.

Both dissident republican groupings - the Real IRA and the Continuity IRA - have denied any involvement in the Kell murder.

Initial ballistic reports on the weapon used to kill the taxi driver, who had been lured to a house in the Protestant Ardoyne area, indicate a link with a gun the PIRA fired at two police officers in Co Armagh in June 1997. The PIRA's North Armagh Brigade used that weapon to kill constables John Graham and Derrick Johnston only weeks before its second ceasefire, in July 1997.

The evidence pointing to PIRA involvement in the Kell murder comes only days before Bill Clinton's final visit to Ireland as President. The Irish and British governments had hoped to have a formula in place which could have broken political deadlock in Ulster during the President's trip.

However, Irish government sources indicated last night that there was only a slim chance of a deal being done between the Northern Ireland parties before the presidential jet, Airforce One, touched down in Dublin on Tuesday.

The Kell murder and the subsequent killing of Catholic workman Gary Moore, along with the attempted assassination of a Catholic taxi driver, create further complications in this difficult stage of the peace process.

Sinn Fein's Gerry Kelly still insists that anti-ceasefire loyalist terrorists murdered Kell to try to provoke fellow loyalists to break their ceasefires and thus destabilise the process.

But the RUC's chief constable, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, has blamed Republicans for killing Kell, although he refused to name the organisation responsible.

The Continuity IRA yesterday publicly denied any involvement. A coded statement said its leadership was 'adamant that none of our units were involved'. It added: 'We would not willingly get involved in tit-for-tat sectarian conflict.'

The Real IRA also rejected speculation that its members were behind Tuesday night's murder. In another coded statement, it hinted that mainstream Republicans were responsible for the Kell killing.

A senior RUC officer told The Observer yesterday that the force was 'utterly bewildered' as to the motive of those responsible. 'Whoever did this knew they would draw a response from loyalists and that Catholics would be killed. They must also have been aware that this would happen at such a critical time in the peace process,' the officer said.

webTitle: Ballot chaos as Supreme Court halts recount

fields.headline: Ballot chaos as Supreme Court halts recount
fields.standfirst: Now it's a fight to the bitter death
fields.trailText: America's highest court yesterday intervened dramatically in the increasingly chaotic presidential election when it ordered a halt to the manual recount of votes in Florida.
fields.byline: Ed Vulliamy in New York and Julian Borger in Tallahassee
fields.body:
America's highest court yesterday intervened dramatically in the increasingly chaotic presidential election when it ordered a halt to the manual recount of votes in Florida.

The US Supreme Court appeared to have swung the advantage away from Vice-President Al Gore just hours after tellers had begun recounting the votes that could have given him victory.

The Supreme Court order stopped the recount until fresh hearings on Monday. However, the delay could be decisive for George W. Bush in a race in which time is becoming increasingly critical.

The recount of 'undervotes' - those not registered by machine count - had been set in motion at 9.50am in Leon County's concrete and glass library at Tallahassee.

Republican and Democratic observers, flown in overnight, were sworn in and looked on as a panel of eight judges, working around four white Formica tables, picked up the first ballots from Miami and stared at the now familiar lines of holes, dimples and chads.

This had been the moment Gore was waiting for: the votes include 9,000 cast in Miami. On Friday the Florida Supreme Court, in ordering the recount sought by Gore, had whittled Bush's lead to just 193 votes out of roughly six million cast statewide.

By mid-day yesterday, Gore had gained a net four votes on his rival, based on the first, partial returns from Orange County.

The tally had developed into a frantic race against time, with a deadline imposed by Leon County court - assigned to manage the count - of 2pm today.

Last night's dramatic intervention by the Supreme Court in Washington came after lawyers for Bush lodged an appeal. They also applied to the Federal Court of Appeals in Atlanta.

The Atlanta court had been petitioned to stop the counts before they even began. But the judges allowed it to continue, adding the rider that the new tallies could not be certified unless the US Supreme Court so determined. Later the Washington court halted the count altogether. Friday's decision by the Florida Supreme Court, by 4-3 to order the recount, had been a punch in the windpipe for Bush, who had been due to fly to Washington tomorrow, start naming his Cabinet and meet President Clinton.

The hand count applied to a total of 43,852 votes across Florida - way beyond what Gore's lawyers were asking. But other counties had been making a slower start yesterday - some with logistical problems, others delayed by political reluctance to comply with the order to count, handed down by the Florida Supreme Court.

The logistical nightmare imposed by the deadline emerged as baffled officials across Florida gathered to begin the count. In most places, 'undervotes' - unlike Miami's, which have been separated - are mixed in with hundreds of thousands of others.

The hurdles focused on Duval County, which incorporates the metropolis of Jacksonville - already under the spotlight of controversy after African-American voters accused the all-Republican electoral board of discrimination and mass disenfranchisement.

Duval has to count 4,967 'undervotes', but they are mixed in with 291,000 others, boxed in a vault. The computer software that sorts the votes was flown from Miami early yesterday, to kickstart counting in Duval and elsewhere.

However, a session of the all-Republican Duval board was broadcast on national television, showed officials deliberating with such painstaking reluctance to proceed, it amounted to an effective filibuster.

Bobby Burchfield, a Republican lawyer monitoring the Miami count, argued that there were no clear standards.

'It seems to me fundamental that we should have the right to object,' he said outside the library. But, he promised: 'We're not going to disrupt the proceedings.'

Jenny Backus, a Democratic spokeswoman, cast doubt on the Republicans' motives. 'What we've heard is that they're going to try to slow this down by every means they can.'

The Miami count, however, would be over by the end of yesterday, said Dave Lang, clerk of Leon County courts. As the majority of the disputed ballots were from Democratic precincts in Miami-Dade County, the recount in the library could have pushed Mr Gore into the lead for the first time since election day.

Republicans had kept up their attacks on the process, only allowed to register written challenges ballot by ballot, while Democrats had exuded nervous exhilaration, lest a call from the federal courts came.

webTitle: Letter: Refreshing Becks

fields.headline: Refreshing Becks
fields.trailText: The crux of Andrew Anthony's article on that David Beckham TV programme is that 'where the film inevitably failed was in shedding light on Beckham's interior life such as it is' (Review, last week).
fields.body:
The crux of Andrew Anthony's article on that David Beckham TV programme is that 'where the film inevitably failed was in shedding light on Beckham's interior life such as it is' (Review, last week).

Anthony's own failure is not to recognise that that 'interior life' includes Beckham's love for his wife and kid, something not referred to and something that might just be powerful enough to outweigh all the negative factors so assiduously detailed there.
Frank Desmond
London W6

webTitle: Letter: Market forces

fields.headline: Market forces
fields.body:
Thank you Jay Rayner, for your write-up of the Borough Market and for exposing the threat from Railtrack to our unique area of London (Life, last week). But don't assume that Railtrack's project is a fait accompli . Railtrack may have decided that their new viaducts are the only way to increase their Thameslink services but our community is fighting back and the Department of Environment Transport and the Regions has instructed the public inquiry to consider alternative routings.
Jackie Power
Cathedral Area Residents Association
Camilla McGibbon
Bankside Residents Forum
London SE1

webTitle: Scottish drink driving case makes history

fields.headline: Lost case makes history
fields.standfirst:
A verdict last week against a drink driver who claimed infringement of human rights was a victory for devolution

Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: A verdict last week against a drink driver who claimed infringement of human rights was a victory for devolution.
fields.body:
When Margaret Anderson Brown drove to a 24-hour superstore in Dunfermline at around 2.30am in June last year, two things were waiting to happen. The first was that after being questioned by police she was charged with stealing a bottle of gin and driving while over the limit. The second took a little longer. But last week, though the case went against her, she made legal history.

Five judges from England and Scotland sitting on the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council ruled that when police that night asked her whether she was the driver of the car in question, they did not infringe the European Convention on Human Rights, now enshrined in domestic law.

And the judges used this new judicial machinery to settle promptly an issue that had threatened to bring chaos to the prosecution of drink driving offences throughout the United Kingdom.

With the approach of Christmas their ruling was welcomed by police and road safety organisations. Until last year the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council seemed a relic of empire, dealing largely with cases from the Commonwealth. Much of its most contentious business in recent times has concerned appeals against the death penalty in the Caribbean. It also hears appeals from professionals such as doctors or dentists convicted of misconduct.

But the late Donald Dewar saw the need to make sure that devolution did not produce quixotic results in various parts of the UK. Last year the committee began to emerge as an incipient UK constitutional court to regulate the relationship between Westminster and the new legislative bodies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. So far it has been concerned with cases arising under the convention, by which the Scottish Parliament and Executive have been bound since their inception last year. The convention became part of UK law in October under the Human Rights Act.

Last week the five judges unanimously found that Miss Brown's right to a fair trial under the convention had not been compromised by the question about who was driving the car which the police had asked her under section 172(2)(a) of the Road Traffic Act 1988. They thus rejected the view of the High Court in Scotland that her answer - 'it was me' - was self-incriminating.

Lord Bingham, Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales, said there had to be a fair balance between the general interests of the community - which justified measures against drinking and driving - and the personal rights of the individual.

Although it was, he conceded, a 'slightly odd arrangement', the Privy Council had several advantages. It wasn't part of Westminster and its judges didn't have to be from the House of Lords but could come from a wider pool of senior figures from UK courts.

'It's also possible for the Judicial Committee to move around in a way the House of Lords can't really do. It is in theory possible for the Privy Council to hear cases in Edinburgh, Cardiff or Belfast.'

He continued: 'There's a feeling that, given that we can actually find time to do it, we'd quite like to be able to be seen to be participating in our function more visibly to the public.'

In practice, though, the judges who sat on the Privy Council were mainly judges who sat in the House of Lords. The case of Brown, he said, showed that a definitive judgment could be achieved more quickly than by taking the case through the judicial processes of each country.

'It's a matter of equal concern north and south of the border as to what the position is under human rights if somebody's asked by a police officer to name the driver of the motor car,' he said.

The Privy Council verdict was open to challenge, either in the Court of Appeal in England, the House of Lords or by individual petition to Strasbourg. But he continued: 'I suspect that there will be fairly strong feeling in the Court of Appeal in England, which I can't speak for, not to grant leave to appeal to the House of Lords against their decision in view of the fact that the Privy Council has already reached a decision ... They would have to persuade the appeal committee in the House of Lords that there was still a point left to be argued.'

As for Strasbourg, he said: 'We've yet to find out what the result would be when the Strasbourg court places greater weight on views brought to bear by the judges of the highest level in this country. What we've tried to do is understand the Strasbourg jurisprudence. We believe that the decision in Brown is consistent with the Strasbourg jurisprudence and therefore would survive challenge. But in theory that route is open.'

Early next year the Privy Council will hear a case arising from the conviction at Paisley in June last year of Robert McIntosh for drug trafficking. The prosecutor then applied for an order under the Misuse of Drugs Act confiscating his assets. The High Court in Scotland found that this violated McIntosh's right, under the convention, to a presumption of innocence.

This case, too, said Lord Hope last week, not only involved a matter of concern on both sides of the border but also an issue reserved to Westminster. It had been dealt with in Scotland before England because the devolution legislation took effect before the Human Rights Act. The appeal to the Privy Council would be heard before an appeal could reach the House of Lords from the Court of Appeal.

He continued: 'So again the Scottish position is being used as a test-bed to decide the issue on both sides of the border.'

However, Lord Hope is anxious that the Privy Council should not become involved in pronouncing on Scottish criminal law or criminal practice. Its strength was that it had been able to develop its own system without English influence.

He said: 'I see a great deal of English law as operated in the Caribbean and my own preference is that we adhere to our own practices and our own law. It's a very fine line between dealing with a strict devolution issue point and becoming involved in Scottish criminal practice or Scottish substantive criminal law.'

During the devolution debates in 1998 Lord Hope expressed anxieties that the Scottish public, in their enthusiasm for devolution, did not understand that the new parliament would not be sovereign, like Westminster, but open to review.

Last week he said: 'You may remember that Tony Blair said in an unguarded moment that the powers were similar to those of a parish council, and that caused a lot of unease. Technically there was quite a lot in what he said.'

But, he stressed, it was Westminster which was 'the odd one out'. The typical position in Europe and the Commonwealth was that parliaments were subject to review. 'Scotland has moved, as it were, into the 21st century by having a parliament which is the same as everywhere else in the world.'

The devolution settlement had produced a lopsided result. England was a uniform country with no attempt to divide it into regions. 'And then you have Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland with a devolution system and a uniform appeals structure.'

He added: 'To that extent, in a loose sense, you might say that the Privy Council is a kind of constitutional court, although we're again a long way from a typical constitutional court.'

Lord Hope, the former Lord President who was appointed a Lord in Ordinary in 1996, expected the number of human rights cases would eventually fall after the 'initial wave' had passed.

But he continued: 'If one finds that the government changes or the political complexion alters a bit, one may find a greater tension between Edinburgh and Westminster than exists at the moment. It's just possible that there may be a greater inclination by Westminster to challenge things done at Edinburgh and the avenue for doing that is through the Privy Council.'

webTitle: Letter:   Motor functional

fields.headline: Motor functional
fields.trailText: My artist wife was happy to see that Nicholas Serota drives the same car as her. But what is Stephen Bayley doing making fun of the Volvo 340 (Life, last week)?
fields.body:
My artist wife was happy to see that Nicholas Serota drives the same car as her. But what is Stephen Bayley doing making fun of the Volvo 340 (Life, last week)?

As an amateur design consultant, I could make a good case for the 340 as a statement for our time - restrained styling, de Dion rear axle, some of the best seats available. Above all, the rear hatch and com modious boot offer exceptional facilities for carrying items such as pictures, bedsteads or bricks. What design-conscious artist could ask for more?
Laurence Cook
Stockport
Gtr Manchester

webTitle: Letters: What sort of option is alternative medicine?

fields.headline: The big issue: What sort of option is alternative medicine?
fields.trailText:
I read with incredulity the article by John Diamond about alternative medicine with a particular bias against homeopathy (Comment, last week). As a general practitioner, I have treated a large number of patients with homeopathy who had not responded to conventional treatment and are very grateful for this alternative approach. This means more to me than research but, I am glad to report, there is a growing evidence base for homeopathy which Mr Diamond did not mention.
Dr Michael Cannell
St Albans
Herts

Dr Michael Cannell
St Albans
Herts

I enjoyed reading John Diamond's article about alternative therapies. It reminded me of what happened in 1988 when I tried the alternative route to a cancer cure. After my doctor and local hospital had failed to diagnose my condition, which had been deteriorating for about seven months, I went to the local natural healing centre. I had a consultation where I was given a lecture about dislocations in my karma, and prescribed unpalatable herbal infusions. The consultation also included an iridology session at the end of which I was told there was no tumour.

Five weeks later I was in hospital being operated on for bowel cancer. After a course of radiotherapy that led to about two years of side effects, such as sudden nausea, fatigue, and headaches, which diminished over time. Nearly 13 years later I am fit and well, thanks to orthodox surgical and medical treatments.
Michael Ayris
Kingston Upon Thames
Surrey

John Diamond fervently expresses his hatred of alternative medicine. But the only actual argument he presents to support his views is that a homeopathy student he is in correspondence with offered no proof of her opposing view. Homeopaths might be tempted to turn the tables on John and say that if he can present no good arguments showing that alternative medicines do not work, then they do work.
Peter Adams, Homeopath
Stroud Natural Health Clinic
Glos

webTitle: Comment: Empty winds of emotion

fields.headline: Empty winds of emotion
fields.standfirst:
We see child-preying monsters on every corner yet we miss the everyday dangers

More about the Damilola Taylor case
fields.trailText: We see child-preying monsters on every corner yet we miss the everyday dangers
fields.body:
He was a studious boy, observant of the Bible and so quiet that bullies used to pick on him at school. His mother brought him from Lagos in Nigeria to London in search of a decent education and a better life. That bright future expired in a dank block of flats in Peckham, where he was found, a few yards from home, dying of a stab wound. This is not Damilola Taylor but Shola Agoro, who was killed nine days previously and a few hundred yards away from the grubby stairwell where Damilola perished.

No Government Ministers offered outrage or regret. No bewildered strangers dropped flowers where Shola fell. No closed-circuit cameras captured his last steps. 'He was my angel, my baby, my best friend,' his mother said, but few outside her family were invited to share her grief. The death of Shola Agoro went almost unremarked. Publicity, or lack of it, aside, there were only two variants in the parallel lives and fates of the two boys. Police have charged a youth with Shola's murder while no suspects have been traced in connection with Damilola's stabbing.

But the real difference was one of age. Damilola was 10. Shola was 17; too young to vote, too young to have completed his engineering diploma, but old enough to become one more statistic in a litany of violence in a place where the stabbing of young men is too humdrum to register on the Richter scale of public shock.

Of course, the murder of a 10-year-old is especially horrific. The dignity, the tears and the televised mourning of Damilola's family at his memorial service last week provoked a tide of sympathy and collective guilt. Beforehand, journalists made their pilgrimage to his home in Lagos and discovered, in sand streets where chickens scratched and children trekked to spartan classrooms, the seeds of what British society has supposedly squandered. This was a place where family values counted for something, reported those too moved by the lure of simplicity and communalism to note the corruption, the exponential rise in armed robbery or the fact that almost five murders a day are logged in a city where crime goes largely unreported and those who escape violence are likely to die of natural causes before they reach 50.

And besides, look what miracles a rich society can perform for children. The most compelling portrait of last week was the dimpled infant fist of Jodie, the surviving conjoined twin, clamped round her father's finger. Here was an emblem of Britain's ability to marshal medical science and judicial wisdom to secure a child's life. How everyone loves a fairy-tale ending. And how quickly they forget that only weeks have passed since the Roman Catholic Church and assorted doctors and commentators clamoured that Jodie should, in the name of morality or humanity, be left to die.

If her case reeks of ambivalence, then so does our attitude to children in general. We hype up the terror of murderers and abusers, rarely seeing how good intentions blur into mawkish sentiment and hysteria. Anyone in doubt over the prevalence of sex abuse in care homes and outside should reread Sir William Utting's damning report in 1997. Three years on, David Jones, a former football manager and care worker, is acquitted of abuse in a case that exposed the flaws of police work and the CPS. A dead priest is accused of paedophilia in a media storm in which evidence of culpability is secondary to the piquancy of the fact that he worked at the school attended by the Prime Minister's sons.

Meanwhile, the NSPCC becomes the National Society For The Protection Of Corporate Culture. Its annual report suggested (a conclusion the charity disputes) that pen-pushers and advertisers fared better from its beneficence than abused children. The current appetite for naming, shaming and incarcerating for ever the armies of paedophiles perceived to be preying on our kids is not a spur to action. Screeches for something to be done merely occlude the suspicion that vast amounts of money are being spent on not doing it.

But the real contradiction over how children are supported and protected resides with government. In several ways, Labour has had a good week. Stephen Byers' Green Paper on working parents finally acknowledges that babies do better if their parents get enough time off. Two weeks paid paternity leave and an increase in statutory maternity pay from £60.20 to £100 a week, with the option of an extension of leave for a year, remains Scrooge-like by the standards of Paris or Stockholm. It is, however, a nod in the right direction.

So is Tessa Jowell's explosion of the 'marriage-is-best' strategy. She doesn't want a family policy that makes 'some children feel they are first-class and others second-class'. All must be equally valued, cherished and made to feel worthy as long as their childhood endures. The pity is that others in Government set such a short expiry date. When do children stop being the potential prey of monsters and emerge as aggressors in their own right? Around the age of Damilola Taylor, according to the rules of matriculation into Jack Straw's yob culture.

Henceforth, those between 10 and 13 found loitering after 10pm may be removed under curfew orders designed to underpin the Home Secretary's dislike of under-16s 'racketing' round the streets. That is what most teenagers do. But it will not be your child, or mine, who is delivered in a police van after being intercepted on a ramble home from a party. Given the police's lukewarm response, it may not be anyone's child. That does not diminish the Alice-in- Wonderland perversity of a policy that criminalises non-offending children in the hope of decriminalising them. There are more effective, quieter initiatives in place for turning children away from violence, but pointless, harmful measures supposedly play better to the mood decreeing that family breakdown inevitably breeds trainee 'yobs'.

Of course there is a link between poverty and bad parenting and crime. But to wish to feed a criminal underclass with a Government-created army of mini-conscripts is as absurd as the idea that sober, Christian, family values are a guarantor of perfect outcomes. If they had been observed, then Jodie, now a symbol of survival in a toy-packed cot, would be dying or dead.

But that is history now. So, soon, will be the brief flurry of national mourning for Damilola; a mood awkwardly rooted in comfort as well as in grief. The murder of a 10-year-old remains a rare aberration. So does the threat of the paedophile-at-large, but how much easier it is to deal with horrors unlikely to befall our children rather than to confront the fact that the vast majority of victims are other people's children assaulted by one of their own family in their own homes. As for Shola Agoro, still only a child at 17, he will remain one crime statistic among many. Too young to die, too old for martyrdom, his memory will be unruffled by hot gusts of public emotion and political posturing on solutions for a violent society. In the absence of easy answers, it is safe only to assume that the real problem centres not on those we vow to remember but on those whom we choose to forget.

That is what most teenagers do. But it will not be your child, or mine, who is delivered in a police van after being intercepted on a ramble home from a party. Given the police's lukewarm response, it may not be anyone's child. That does not diminish the Alice-in- Wonderland perversity of a policy that criminalises non-offending children in the hope of decriminalising them. There are more effective, quieter initiatives in place for turning children away from violence, but pointless, harmful measures supposedly play better to the mood decreeing that family breakdown inevitably breeds trainee 'yobs'. Of course there is a link between poverty and bad parenting and crime. But to wish to feed a criminal underclass with a Government-created army of mini-conscripts is as absurd as the idea that sober, Christian, family values are a guarantor of perfect outcomes. If they had been observed, then Jodie, now a symbol of survival in a toy-packed cot, would be dying or dead. But that is history now. So, soon, will be the brief flurry of national mourning for Damilola; a mood awkwardly rooted in comfort as well as in grief. The murder of a 10-year-old remains a rare aberration. So does the threat of the paedophile-at-large, but how much easier it is to deal with horrors unlikely to befall our children rather than to confront the fact that the vast majority of victims are other people's children assaulted by one of their own family in their own homes. As for Shola Agoro, still only a child at 17, he will remain one crime statistic among many. Too young to die, too old for martyrdom, his memory will be unruffled by hot gusts of public emotion and political posturing on solutions for a violent society. In the absence of easy answers, it is safe only to assume that the real problem centres not on those we vow to remember but on those whom we choose to forget. webTitle: Letter: Not such a hero

fields.headline: Not such a hero
fields.trailText: I see the stars were out in force cooing over their departed hero, John Lennon (Review, last week). That Lennon numbered among the first wave of libertarian scribes and crooners who relied entirely on corporate media to manufacture their images and careers seems to have been lost.
fields.body:
I see the stars were out in force cooing over their departed hero, John Lennon (Review, last week). That Lennon numbered among the first wave of libertarian scribes and crooners who relied entirely on corporate media to manufacture their images and careers seems to have been lost.

Also overlooked is the alternative Freudian view that all 'radical art' is a sublimation... in other words, an attractive but harmless substitute for the action that can follow thought and feeling. The few tangible benefits that the working class squeezed out of corporate capitalism this century were the result of the mundane, grinding politics of ordinary working-class activists, who needed little inspiration over and above their own sense of injustice and solidarity. To these people, popular music was what it should be, a bit of fun.

To redress the balance, perhaps we could commemorate someone like Aneurin Bevan with as much gusto as a wealthy pseudo-radical art student who lay around expensive hotel rooms taking photographs of his willy.
Steve Hall
Newcastle upon Tyne

webTitle: Jockey's wild ride that ended in murder

fields.headline: Jockey's wild ride that ended in murder
fields.standfirst: 'The Ant' was always his own worst enemy but someone else took his life, writes  Edward Helmore in New York
fields.trailText: 'The Ant' was always his own worst enemy but someone else took his life, writes Edward Helmore in New York
fields.body:
For a prince in the sport of kings it was an ignominious end. Last weekend, the lifeless body of Chris Antley, 34, the greatest American jockey of his generation, was found by his brother and a close friend in the hallway of his mansion in Pasadena, California. He had been beaten with a blunt-force wound to his head.

The racing world was stunned. To owners, trainers, fellow jockeys and racing fans Antley was a mercurial figure who rose from a small South Carolina farm to become one of the world's top riders. American courses held a minute's silence for the fallen hero.

But Antley, known as 'The Ant', was also deeply troubled and his life beyond the track had been as dizzying a ride as any. He withdrew from the sport at least three times in his career when he ballooned over his 117lbs racing weight or became locked in the throes of amphetamine and cocaine addiction.

He made two spectacular comebacks and was wrestling with a third when he was killed. So far investigators have made no arrests, named no suspects and a postmortem examination proved inconclusive. But they have said Antley's death was premeditated and not simply a robbery gone wrong or a 'random act of violence'.

So far speculation has focused on some kind of drug deal that turned sour. A pattern of troubling behaviour preceded the tragedy. In the past few months, Antley had been arrested twice on drug and alcohol charges, and his pregnant wife claimed he had threatened to kill her.

Two days after he was found dead, police picked up 24-year-old Timothy Tyler who had been arrested with Antley in July when police found marijuana and methamphetamine-making equipment in Antley's house after being asked to check up on the jockey by his wife. They later said Tyler was not a suspect.

But whatever happened to Antley last Saturday night, the manner of his death came as more of a shock than the fact he had died.

At his peak, Antley was a natural master of his craft. A two-time winner of the Kentucky Derby, 'The Ant' was the first jockey to win nine races in a single day.

In 1985 he led the country with 469 winners; in 1987 he rode at least one winner on 67 consecutive days. During his career he won 3,480 races, and for the wealthy owners and trainers of his mounts, he won more than $92m in prize money.

Eighteen months ago, he performed a remarkable resurrection. Picked to ride Charismatic, a three-year-old colt that had only run in relatively minor races and had bounced from jockey to jockey, Antley rode to victory at the Kentucky Derby and then the Preakness.

Just one win away - the Belmont Stakes - from winning the biggest achievement in US racing, the Triple Crown, Antley was back at the top of his game.

'One second you're in South Carolina and you're wearing cutoff shorts, driving a 1967 Mustang, staying home with Mom and Dad and playing the stock market,' Antley said after winning the Preakness, 'and the next you're back in the game you'd have given anything to be back in.'

So determined was he to overcome his depression, drug and weight problems to race again, Antley liked to say - perhaps only half in jest - 'I'll die trying to get back'.

But he missed winning the Triple Crown when the horse finished third, then pulled up just past the finishing line with a broken leg. Antley jumped off and immediately held the colt's leg until veterinarians arrived.

'He instinctively came to the aid of the horse,' said Bob Lewis, Charismatic's owner. He added that Charismatic might not have been saved without Antley's quick intervention. In the aftermath, Antley's career again seemed to spiral down. He gained weight and managed to win only three out of 30 races before finally retiring last spring when he left California's Santa Anita track without saying a word. Many in America's racing community understood that their favourite jockey was unlikely to make yet another comeback.

Gary Stevens, a fellow rider and longtime friend, said Antley had spoken of a premonition. 'He seemed to harbour a fear that something like this was going to happen. A lot of things he was saying were not making sense to me.

'He talked about coming back and galloping horses again but he had fears, and he was depressed. I had the feeling when I left that he was not going to be around much longer. He had a lot of demons haunting him.'

Friends said the pressure of keeping his weight down - he ran 25 miles a day to reach condition before his last comeback - had overwhelmed him and locked him in an emotional paralysis.

'He was trying to get his weight under control but he just couldn't,' said trainer and friend Franklin Smith. 'He gave up the pills but he was in withdrawal, and psychologically he didn't like it. He had married and his wife was expecting. He felt like he had to be riding.'

webTitle: Heaven can wait

fields.headline: Heaven can wait
fields.standfirst: Save us from the just of the Earth
fields.trailText: Heaven, we're in heaven or at least we now harbour the aspiration that we might get there eventually since the Pope confirmed last week that 'all of the just on Earth', not just adherents of the Roman Catholic Church, can pass through that eye of the needle.
fields.body:
Heaven, we're in heaven or at least we now harbour the aspiration that we might get there eventually since the Pope confirmed last week that 'all of the just on Earth', not just adherents of the Roman Catholic Church, can pass through that eye of the needle.

If the keeper of the gate is paying attention, this new policy will considerably swell the numbers. And what a change it will mean in the old place. We had always imagined a Catholic heaven as an opulent, exclusive club - all silver chalices, gilded pillars and vaulted ceilings - populated by Raphael Madonnas, wise men wearing velvet, and fat cherubs. And noisy, too, with 24-hour Latino music and marathon Riverdance performances.

What's going to happen to all that when the just of the Earth arrive? The Puritans will hate the decor, Buddhists will want peace to meditate, mixed dancing may offend Muslims. A heavenly UN might have to define spheres of influence. It's all sounding less attractive. In fact, like Groucho Marx, we're not sure we want to be a member of a heaven that would accept us as members.

webTitle: Irish all suspect, police are told

fields.headline: Irish all suspect, police are told
fields.standfirst:
Secret orders 'to make arbitrary arrests' are condemned as racist

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: British police have been secretly ordered to treat all Irish-born citizens on their patch as potential terrorist suspects, according to a memo leaked to  The Observer .
fields.body:
British police have been secretly ordered to treat all Irish-born citizens on their patch as potential terrorist suspects, according to a memo leaked to The Observer .

The investigation, codenamed Operation Pre-Empt, instructs officers to report all dealings with anyone of Irish descent or background - including the most routine checks on drivers and even reports from suspicious landlords - to Special Branch, as a precaution against a feared terrorist bombing offensive.

The crackdown was condemned as racist and offensive by politicians in Northern Ireland and on the mainland last night. Lawyers warned it could be challenged under human-rights legislation, while Sinn Fein called for the matter to be raised in Parliament.

'This is a prime example of racism and it has no place whatsoever in any so-called police service,' said a spokesman for Sinn Fein. 'We would call on all Irish organisations in Britain to voice their opinion to this very, very strongly and very, very openly. This sort of activity certainly does not contribute to the search for a reconciliation between our two nations.'

The leaked memo comes from Humberside Police, whose patch includes two major ports and a cluster of chemical factories regarded locally as a bombing target. As the storm grew last night, the force's chief constable, David Westwood, rushed out a statement promising a review to ensure that nationality was not used as the basis for suspicion without considering 'all the circumstances'.

'The use of Humberside as a route into the UK mainland to import terrorist devices cannot and will not be ignored,' he said. 'We must take steps to prevent the horror of terrorist action. I am not suggesting all Irish people are terrorists. Our intelligence suggests that the threat relates to Irish terror groups.'

The Home Office said last night that it did not believe the practice had spread nationwide.

Gareth Peirce, the lawyer who helped the Guildford Four to overturn their convictions, demanded urgent clarification of how many other forces could be secretly operating similar rules. 'This provides an open-ended licence for arbitrary arrest and makes everyone an informer,' she said. 'The police are making an entire community suspect on the basis of national origin. It violates every possible guarantee under the new Human Rights Act.'

The memo on forthcoming initiatives, dated 20 October, describes Operation Pre-Empt as a drive to 'identify, prioritise and monitor likely targets for terrorist attack'.

It asks divisions and branches to notify Special Branch as soon as possible of 'anyone of Irish origin, descent or background' who is brought into custody, subject to a routine street or driver check, subject to police inquiry 'for any reason', or brought to their attention by members of the public 'in particular when seeking accommodation'.

The tactics risk throwing up mountains of low-grade information on innocent Irish people, rather than identifying serious suspects.

'We have all got to be vigi lant against threats from dissident terrorists, but this goes much wider than that. It seems like a racially inspired fishing exercise,' said Robin Corbett, chair of the Commons Home Affairs Select Committee.

Humberside has a relatively small Irish community but is strate gically important because of its ports. Any pre-Christmas bombing offensive is thought likely to focus on 'softer targets' outside London.

Kevin McNamara, MP for Hull North, and himself of Irish origin, said last night he would table questions to Ministers urgently. 'This is offensive and it is racist,' he said. 'I thought the days of snooping on the Irish were over. This is taking us back to the Seventies.'

Jane Winter of British-Irish Rights Watch warned the measures could lead to miscarriages of justice. 'We had hoped the days of "any Irishman will do" were over,' she added.

John Wadham of the civil rights organisation Liberty described the techniques as crude racism. 'We need a real shake-up if those protecting us from terrorism have such an unprofessional approach to investigation,' he added.

The recent discovery of a 500lb bomb in a horsebox on the outskirts of Belfast, thought to have been des tined for the mainland, underlined the risk of a bombing offensive from the Real IRA republican splinter movement. The row comes at an awkward time, with President Clinton due to fly in on Tuesday for a valedictory tour of the province designed to galvanise the peace process.

webTitle: Letter:  Iraqis on the list

fields.headline: Iraqis on the list
fields.body:
Your article on Saddam's executioners (World, last week) must be malign propaganda. The Home Office, (Immigration and Nationality Directorate) has only recently decided to place Iraq on the 'white list'. This means that asylum seekers from Iraq fall to be treated under the expedited procedure as the directorate is satisfied that the conditions of law and order, treatment of prisoners, and civil liberty is such that it is unlikely that Iraq will produce genuine refugees. I appreciate that you give UNHCR as a link, but surely in terms of veracity, there is no contest when comparing UNHCR's opinion with that of Jack Straw and his driven minions.
Francis Deutsch
Saffron Walden
Essex

webTitle: Letter:   Must do more

fields.headline: Must do more
fields.trailText: I naturally share Will Hutton's enthusiasm for increased public sector investment (Comment, last week), but he understates what is already being achieved. For example, 38 major hospital projects, the expansion and modernisation of 242 accident and emergency units, 17,000 schools, repairs to 1.5 million council houses and accelerating investment in transport through both public and private sectors.
fields.body:
I naturally share Will Hutton's enthusiasm for increased public sector investment (Comment, last week), but he understates what is already being achieved. For example, 38 major hospital projects, the expansion and modernisation of 242 accident and emergency units, 17,000 schools, repairs to 1.5 million council houses and accelerating investment in transport through both public and private sectors.

It is wrong to claim that PFI is somehow holding back this investment. Labour reformed PFI and dropped the requirement that all projects had to be assessed first for PFI. Where it offers best value, it makes an important contribution - over £4 billion this year - but that is alongside more than £25bn of other public investment planned this year.

I agree with Will Hutton that there is more to do to achieve the levels of investment the country needs. That is why Labour are committed to doubling net investment over the next three years.
Andrew Smith
Chief Secretary to the Treasury
London SW1

webTitle: Europe will never be a superstate

fields.headline: Europe will never be a superstate
fields.standfirst:
Hague's trite test stifles debate

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Bring back Sir Alec Douglas-Home. A Tory leader who demonstrates economic policy with the assistance of matchsticks is less constipating to sensible political thought than one who invents an 'Elephant Test' to determine the nature of our future involvement in Europe. William Hague's trite test - if it looks, and smells, and walks like an elephant, or a superstate, then it must be one - was designed for the same audience as his invention that he once drank 14 pints a day. Nevertheless, even in the aftermath of Nice, it still inhibits our constructive engagement with Europe.
fields.body:
Bring back Sir Alec Douglas-Home. A Tory leader who demonstrates economic policy with the assistance of matchsticks is less constipating to sensible political thought than one who invents an 'Elephant Test' to determine the nature of our future involvement in Europe. William Hague's trite test - if it looks, and smells, and walks like an elephant, or a superstate, then it must be one - was designed for the same audience as his invention that he once drank 14 pints a day. Nevertheless, even in the aftermath of Nice, it still inhibits our constructive engagement with Europe.

Careful examination of the European Union, as demonstrated in our Focus pages today, makes absolutely clear that there is no European superstate, either at present or anywhere on the horizon. All the critical indicators of such an entity - unitary taxes, compulsory involvement in a defence force, a single executive - simply do not exist.

However, Conservatives cannot alone be blamed for the infantile nature of the domestic debate over Europe. Improbable stories about straight bananas and square tomatoes have been easily prosecuted by Eurosceptic dissemblers because for too long the debating chamber has been left empty by the European idealists. Expressions such as 'superstate' and 'tax harmonisation' have been invented by anti-Europeans and, in the absence of any balancing vocabulary from Britain's nervous pro-Europeans, have become idiom.

The Observer is committed to a European ideal. But we also believe, for example, that the vast majority of fiscal powers should stay with member states, not least because that enables any member of a single currency to tune its economy to the inelasticities of a universal monetary policy. Our health and education services are dramatically different from those of many European countries too, and should stay so. Continued expansion of the EU will heighten rather than minimise those differences between nation states. So every additional EU member in the wake of Nice makes a future superstate look less rather than more likely.

The elephant test, just like Norman Tebbit's similarly fatuous cricket test, is fitting only for the pantomime season. Once Britain acknowledges that Europe is not a superstate and never will be, we can all start an intelligent dialogue about what the European Union is now and what it should be in the future.

Expressions such as 'superstate' and 'tax harmonisation' have been invented by anti-Europeans and, in the absence of any balancing vocabulary from Britain's nervous pro-Europeans, have become idiom. The Observer is committed to a European ideal. But we also believe, for example, that the vast majority of fiscal powers should stay with member states, not least because that enables any member of a single currency to tune its economy to the inelasticities of a universal monetary policy. Our health and education services are dramatically different from those of many European countries too, and should stay so. Continued expansion of the EU will heighten rather than minimise those differences between nation states. So every additional EU member in the wake of Nice makes a future superstate look less rather than more likely. The elephant test, just like Norman Tebbit's similarly fatuous cricket test, is fitting only for the pantomime season. Once Britain acknowledges that Europe is not a superstate and never will be, we can all start an intelligent dialogue about what the European Union is now and what it should be in the future.

webTitle: Euro talks in deadlock as UK defends tax veto

fields.headline: Euro talks in deadlock as UK defends tax veto
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was last night fighting a bitter rearguard action to protect Britain's right to set social security and tax policy, as crucial talks on the future shape of Europe were suspended in deadlock.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was last night fighting a bitter rearguard action to protect Britain's right to set social security and tax policy, as crucial talks on the future shape of Europe were suspended in deadlock.

Officials said last night that Britain would be prepared to torpedo the entire summit rather than surrender its veto in these key areas.

The British battle was taking place amid mounting anger among smaller members of the EU over plans to redistribute power within an enlarged Europe.

Blair is ready to move to majority voting in a series of areas which he says will be to Britain's advantage. But he insisted last night that the veto would remain on tax and social security.

The French President, Jacques Chirac, has demanded a deadline of noon today for completion of the negotiations. As a sign of the deep division in the negotiations, German chancellor Gerhard Schröder told French officials last night he would not consider a revised version of the draft treaty until it was translated into German. Other European leaders, including Irish Taoiseach Bertie Ahern, also ruled out attending a summit dinner, called by President Chirac, while they considered their position.

A French draft treaty launched yesterday has been rejected by Britain, with the Prime Minister telling his officials that no deal was possible at present. A set of one-to-one meetings took place last night to try to hammer out a deal.

'It is still not acceptable because it breaches the fundamental point of principle that tax is a matter for the British government, the British parliament and the British people,' the Prime Minister's official spokesman said. 'The Prime Minister has made it clear to the British people that it [changes on the issue of tax] is not going to happen, so it will not happen.'

French officials told The Observer last night that a new draft of the treaty merely committed EU leaders to a discussion of the tax issue while maintaining the right of veto - a commitment still rejected by Blair.

Although Britain is now considering the surrender of its veto in up to 30 areas, British officials said that if France, which holds the EU presidency, did not drop the taxation and social security clauses in the treaty then the summit would end in failure.

Asked if Britain would refuse to surrender its veto even if it meant the summit would fail, a British official said: 'At the moment it is a hypothetical question. But if it became a reality, then, yes, the summit would fail. We are not moving.'

British officials were irritated when they saw the taxation and social security clauses in the 'final' draft treaty produced by French officials yesterday morning. By lunchtime, the French Foreign Minister admitted that another treaty would have to be written.

Britain has now agreed to allow a clause on immigration and border controls, even though it is a 'red line' issue, because of an opt-out Britain achieved from immigration matters. 'It will not affect us,' a Downing Street spokesman said.

But Conservatives said the move was a signal that Blair was softening his stance in order to get a deal. 'It would be completely wrong for Britain to give up its veto in immigration,' said the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Francis Maude. 'This was one of the key areas on which it pledged it would not abandon the veto.'

With the deadline looming, Britain's stance on the 'red line' issues was just one of a series of rows that threatened to derail the summit.

Portugal led a furious group of nations who claim they have been 'humiliated' by a decision to change the balance of power in favour of the five larger nations - Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Spain.

A plan put forward by the French tripled the number of votes given to the big five while only doubling the votes given to smaller nations.

Last night Maude insisted there should be no more majority voting in Europe and added: 'Above all, Nice must break the completely artificial link between relentless political integration and enlargement.'

webTitle: A month of mayhem in the White House race

fields.headline: How they got here
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A MONTH OF MAYHEM
fields.body:
A MONTH OF MAYHEM

7 NOVEMBER - America goes to the polls

8 NOVEMBER - Television networks declare Bush the winner, Gore concedes but later retracts

11 NOVEMBER - Bush turns to the courts to prevent manual recounts in four pro-Democratic Florida counties

13 NOVEMBER - Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris prepares to certify statewide results. Gore starts lawsuit to prevent tally from being made final

16 NOVEMBER - Florida Supreme Court refuses to halt manual recounts

18 NOVEMBER - Bush increases Florida lead to 930 votes through addition of overseas absentee ballots

21 NOVEMBER - Florida Supreme Court sets 26 November deadline for recounts

22 NOVEMBER - County officials in Miami-Dade call off recount, saying they cannot meet deadline. Republican lawyers petition US Supreme Court to overturn Florida Supreme Court decision over manual recounts

25 NOVEMBER - Gore challenges Palm Beach county results on grounds that 'dimpled', or merely indented ballots, were undercounted

26 NOVEMBER - Election officials declare Bush the winner in Florida by just 537 votes

2 DECEMBER - US Supreme Court sends decision on extending recounts deadline back to Florida court

4 DECEMBER - Leon county circuit judge rejects Gore's challenge to certified statewide victory

8 DECEMBER - Florida Supreme Court orders recount of 9,000 Miami-Dade ballots, orders lower court to add 215 votes for Gore from Palm Beach and 168 from Miami-Dade, and orders manual recount of all undervotes

webTitle: Battle for the White House

fields.headline: Now it's a fight to the bitter death
fields.standfirst:
Ed Vulliamy in New York watches as the struggle between Al Gore and George W. Bush takes the US to the brink of constitutional chaos. In a bare knuckle brawl for power, can US democracy survive?

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Ed Vulliamy in New York watches as the struggle between Al Gore and George W. Bush takes the US to the brink of constitutional chaos. In a bare knuckle brawl for power, can US democracy survive?
fields.body:
Al Gore and George Bush are no longer rival contenders for the US presidency - they are pit bulls with teeth sunk deep into the United States' limbs, one apiece, with neither man able to let go until the body is ripped in half.

The faces in court had turned to stone with disbelief on Friday night as Florida's Supreme Court judges ordered the hand recount to restart, launching the US's most remarkable election into another spiral of bitterness, battle and hope.

As the news reached Washington it detonated a celebratory fiesta at Gore's residence, audible from the sidewalks of Massachusetts Avenue, including the dangerous pop of a champagne cork. Gore reached for his pager to summon campaign manager Bill Daley and running mate Joe Lieberman who, in observance of the Sabbath, came on foot. They arrived to find Gore swinging a string of Christmas lights over his head.

Bush, meanwhile, was hosting a holiday buffet dinner party, at which - by way of echo to Gore's lights - a man dressed as Santa Claus was swirling a lasso above the governor's head. Bush was due to fly to Washington today to announce Colin Pow ell as Secretary of State and meet President Clinton to discuss the handover of power.

But, the smirk of imminent victory wiped from his face, Bush beat a path back to the federal courts, including the highest in the land, seeking to stop the count that could overturn his declared victory, or else rip up the result.

The order that manual recounts continue not only in Miami but across the whole of Florida blows the vote open yet again, putting the presidency back within Gore's grasp and potentially sending the US headlong towards constitutional crisis.

'It's going to be madness,' one Democrat official told The Observer , 'it's going to be nothing but absolute partisan war.' 'This judicial aggression must not stand,' came a menacing retort from the feared Republican chief whip Tom DeLay, referring to the court ruling.

The Gore camp was flung into a frenzy of preparation for victory snatched from the jaws of defeat. 'Two strikes, two outs at the bottom of the ninth,' said former White House aide David Gergen.

The astonished Bush team, punched in the windpipe, mapped a two-track federal appeal: one at 9.30pm with the US Supreme Court in Washington, plus an emergency injunction in the Atlanta 11th district federal court of appeals to try to stop the count. Republican Senator Chuck Hegel of Omaha, however, warned that the epic drama was heading into 'dark, dangerous and murky waters'.

The ruling detonates a blinding array of possibilities. First and foremost, 9,000 remaining votes must be recounted in Miami - abandoned after the count was stopped with a baying mob at the door. A further 383 votes already counted there and in West Palm Beach must be added to the tally, plunging Bush's lead in Florida from 537 to 154 without a single vote recounted.

But the court went further. It instructed the recount of any 'undervote' (not recorded by the machine count) across almost the entire state - a minimum of 43,432 votes across 62 counties. These votes are concentrated in four counties: the 9,000 in Miami, 5,331 in Hillsborough, 4,967 in Duval and 4,226 in Pinellas.

In Tallahassee, Leon County Court went into session at 8pm, soon after the ruling, to make arrangements for the count which, said Judge Terry Lewis, must be completed by 2pm today, US time.

With problems already emerging yesterday morning, the votes cannot - and will not - be counted by this afternoon, but that may not matter as Gore throttles and overtakes Bush's lead.

What mattered for the moment is that the count was due to begin, faced with a labyrinth of logistical, political and legal hazards, slightly after 8am. And with bated breath, the preceding minutes ticking away as appeal judges whom Bush had asked to intervene kept their silence.

In the wake of the ruling, there is no one left with any debt to compromise or peace. Throughout the week, the battle lines which entrench the aftermath of the already embittered election were boldly drawn even before Friday night's explosion.

Talk from the Bush camp of bipartisan co-operation and unity was unveiled as no more than guff, as the Republican leadership appointed a hardline Conservative team to preside over the new assembly, split on a knife-edge, 50-50.

Democrat demands for power-sharing and positions for co-chairmen of key committees were dismissed by Republican leader, Trent Lott. The hawk of the far Right, House chief whip Tom Delay, ratcheted up the rhetoric by saying that an end-of-session budget impasse could lead to a government shut-down. The Republicans, he said, could now act 'unfettered'.

Bush's proposed Vice-President, Dick Cheney, meanwhile, provided a taste of things to come, saying the administration waiting to assume office would aggressively pursue the most combative ingredients on its political wish-list: dramatic privatisations in health care and social security, and tax cuts favouring the wealthiest slice of society.

The incensed Democrats, for their part, refused to allow their leader in the Senate, Tom Daschle, to be called 'minority leader'.

Within the Gore camp the situation - as explained by sources to The Observer - was more complex. While the Vice-President vowed to fight on in the courts, he was being dogged by those his staff called 'doubting Thomases' within the party, resigned to a bad result on Friday and a rapid concession of defeat.

'We were ready to pull the plug,' said one senior Democrat strategist. Some in Congress believed that such a move, made gracefully, would end the bitterness and begin the campaign to win back Capitol Hill in 2002 and even a Gore-Hillary Clinton Presidential ticket for 2004. Either way, the Democrats had in Gore the first European-style leader of the opposition the US has ever seen.

The Observer is told that even Gore's dog-fighting campaign manager Bill Daley was buckling - and Gore agreed that if the Florida Supreme Court went against him, he would call it a day. But the Naval Observatory - known as 'The Bunker' - had become the kernel of his operation, in which a hard core had formed: himself, wife Tipper, daughter Karenna and the man of steel, Joe Lieberman, determined not to give up until the bitter end.

Gore was committed, at minimum, to taking this to the last trench: his appeal to the Florida Supreme Court on Friday, aiming to overturn the disastrous ruling last Monday by Judge Sanders Sauls, which cast aside the continued recounting of votes in pro-Democrat Miami, and inclusion of precious votes already tallied in Palm Beach.

It turned out to be a day of history or of infamy, depending on which political prism you look through. On Friday morning, Bush was confident to the point of radiance. He insisted he was not following the Florida saga on television but deliberating on his Cabinet - teasing reporters anxious to know the nominations and unable to keep his own secrets. Gore, meanwhile, was watching every frame of CNN, and counting every hair on his lawyers' heads.

'There is almost no political question in the United States,' wrote de Tocqueville, who has been made the Nostradamus of American politics by recent events, 'that is not resolved sooner or later as a judicial question.'

And, he added prophetically: 'The American man of law resembles the priests of Egypt; like them he is lone interpreter of an occult science.'

There can be few more practised priests in the occult science of law than the one Gore dispatched to fight Friday's Apocalypse: lead attor ney David Boies, who had taken apart Microsoft in the famous anti-trust case, and now faced his last hurrah against another trust, the Bush family. And Boies won - for the moment.

The Court of Appeals in Atlanta put in a call for overnight briefs from the appellant Texas governor, and 130 pages of lawyers' briefs and counter-briefs blew and counter-blew from fax machine to fax machine throughout the night. The Gore team adjourned for an hour's sleep at 4am. In dead of night, a chartered plane left the capital for Florida loaded with staff from the Democrat National Committee set to oversee the count.

The order to recount takes the mayhem into the ether, with the possibility that the presidency could be decided in a riven Congress next year. The formal, dry timetable is this: the Electoral College is committed to meet on 'the first Monday after the second Wednesday of the month' - 18 December - to elect the President. The electors must be agreed upon six days beforehand, 12 December.

Congress must meet to count the college votes on 5 or 6 January, but could end up with two competing slates of electors, since the Republican-controlled Florida legislature is threatening to select its own slate during a 'special session' convened on Friday and due to sit until the deadline of Wednesday.

And with Congress hung, there are various paradigms as to who might have the casting vote, including Gore himself or Florida Governor Jeb Bush. One scenario has Bush able to claim the Presidency only if he appoints Joe Lieberman as his deputy, removing his vote from the Senate.

But all that is many twists and turns away. By the time Judge Lewis set down his deadline of today, the Democrat leaders on Capitol Hill - Tom Daschle and Dick Gephardt - had embarked on a night of delirious mobilising and whip-cracking, to make sure the party was back in line, and aware that - tentatively - it can dream again.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Kufuor leads Ghana contest

Returns put John Kufuor, main opposition candidate in Ghana's presidential election, on 58 per cent, with Vice-President John Atta Mills on 37 per cent.

Gunman kills 20 Sudanese

A gunman who murdered 20 worshippers near Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, was said by the authorities to be a Muslim zealot.

Corsica 'autonomy' approved

A bill to give Corsica greater autonomy from France has been approved by the island's assembly.

Unkind US electricity cut

Californians trimmed electricity consumption and residents of nearby states were asked to reduce usage after an energy crisis caused by cold weather, a shutdown of generating plants and utility deregulation.

Slovenia links with Yugoslavia

Slovenia and Yugoslavia established diplomatic ties, nine years after Slovenia's declaration of independence from former Yugoslavia triggered off a brief war that killed 64 people.

Ocalan barred from amnesty

An amnesty in Turkey may halve its prison population but it excludes Kurdish rebel Abdullah Ocalan, above, sentenced to death. Nor does it cover organised crime, rape and misuse of public funds.

Roof gardens

The Tokyo metropolitan government will require owners of new buildings to turn part of the rooftop into gardens to combat rising temperatures.

Rights pay-out

A woman strip-searched by police in New York after she was accused of shop-lifting has been awarded $120,000 for the violation of her civil rights.
