webTitle: The three wise women who inspire Clinton

fields.headline: The three wise women who inspire Clinton
fields.standfirst: Britain is preparing to greet America's First Family.  Ed Vulliamy  reports from New York
fields.trailText: Britain is preparing to greet America's First Family. Ed Vulliamy reports from New York
fields.body:
A globetrotting young woman who wields increasing power over the President of the United States will cross on to British soil from Ireland on Wednesday, one of three generations of women accompanying Bill Clinton on the last trip of his presidency.

At her side will be a sprightly octogenarian, her grandmother - also a cogent influence on the US President and his legacy in the twilight of his office. The third woman will be the link between them: the senator for New York, who took her seat on Capitol Hill last week. They are Dorothy Rodham, her daughter Hillary and 20-year-old Chelsea.

As the curtain descends on his presidency, Clinton already has one foot in the shadows as Hillary makes history and Chelsea emerges as a quiet power in her own right, after years of protected and protective seclusion.

Chelsea has bloomed from a gawkish, frizzy-headed 12-year-old into a poised and independent young woman who posits vegetarianism against her father's taste for Big Macs.

She has undergone a sea change in her ambitions - from the long-proclaimed profession of medicine to the family business of politics. As many interview requests for Chelsea as for the President now arrive at the White House (the answer is always no). And, like her father, she wants to go to Oxford.

The other relative stranger in the formidable female trio is the President's mother-in-law, Dorothy Rodham. For of all the places that Bill Clinton could go when he faces his identity crisis next January as the youngest former President (there's been much talk of Hollywood and Manhattan), he has chosen to stay with his mother-in-law down in Little Rock, Arkansas, where it all began.

At Dorothy's condo in Hillcrest Heights, tucked among the cliffs that plunge into the Arkansas River, there's always an easy chair for Bill. 'I really like her,' explains the President. 'We really get along.'

In Chelsea, Britain will get a close-up of a young woman steeled for the rigours of public life since the age of six. When her father was running for the governorship of Arkansas, Hillary told her daughter that people might one day say nasty things about Pop which were not true.

There have been two very different moments when Chelsea stole the limelight from her parents. The first came during the summer horribilis of 1998, at the height of the Lewinsky scandal. After the President's trial by television, the Clinton trio took its longest walk across the South lawn towards an awaiting helicopter; Chelsea was a firewall wedged between her parents, part peacemaker, part victim.

Chelsea's second moment came this autumn, during what is universally regarded as the proto-perfect political campaign her mother waged for the New York Senate seat.

'A pleasure to meet you,' grinned Chelsea to the phalanx of cameras that turned away from their usual target, Hillary, to focus on the 20-year old - looking relaxed and the spitting image of her father.

Although she had been at her father's side during the campaigns of 1992 and 1996, this was Chelsea's coming-out moment. More important - for both herself and the President's legacy - it also signalled Chelsea's emergence as a junior First Lady in her own right.

Although Hillary insists that campaigning was Chelsea's choice, her appearances 'had some strategic value', says the New York pollster Maurice Caroll. 'It's a plus, because Chelsea humanises Mrs Clinton; she makes her a Mom' - an image crucial to winning the women's vote.

'We need your help, we need your support,' Chelsea urged diners in a Polish restaurant in Buffalo. 'I love your grandchildren,' she beamed at an elderly minister. 'They're terrific.'

But it was not only Hillary's political future that Chelsea was brought in to enhance. She had also opted to skip the fall quarter of her university year 'to spend more time with her father as he closed his two terms in office', says Hillary's spokeswoman Lissa Muscatine.

Chelsea, says Muscatine, has wanted to 'experience and enjoy the final months of her father's presidency'. Chelsea spent much of the year travelling with her father on foreign policy assignments, including the Group of Eight meeting in Japan and the Camp David peace talks.

Sources in the White House say that Chelsea played a 'delicate behind-the-scenes role' at Camp David, 'calming her father' who had 'blown a fuse a few times, with almost everybody'. She also mingled with the leaders to ease tensions, notably during a sticky dinner with Yasser Arafat and Ehud Barak.

One adviser admits that Chelsea was strategically deployed to embody the generations that would benefit from a Mid-East peace. When Clinton announced the collapse of the talks, he glanced straight at his daughter when he said: 'The clock is working against us'.

In March, Chelsea accompanied her father to Asia and, more recently, to Africa and Colombia.

'She's terrific, charming and poised,' says Letita Baldridge, former chief of staff to Jaqueline Kennedy and Grande Dame of women's political image-building.

Hillary and Chelsea were hosted by Vicky Swanson at a cancer benefit rock concert in Syracuse; Swanson said: 'She talked strongly about her passion and commitment - because of her grandmother'. This is an intriguing inspiration, given the weight of parental influence, but grandmother and granddaughter are known to be exceptionally close.

The opaque but spirited octogenarian has only given two interviews since her son-in-law won the presidency in 1992. She liked Bill Clinton, she said in Vanity Fair two years ago, and thought he was good for her daughter.

At the age of eight, Dorothy Howell was abandoned by her divorced parents and sent to live with her grandparents. She has since inculcated in her daughter and granddaughter the horror of divorce.

As his presidency nears an end, Bill Clinton is said by aides to have seen more of Dorothy, consulted her and heeded her advice. One says that 'her presence [is] one of the things that makes him kind of sprightly these days'.

Dorothy has, says a senior White House aide, become the pivot of the family - as she herself said once: 'Imagine having a carpenter's level inside you. You try to keep that bubble in the centre. Sometimes it will go way up there and you have to bring it back.'

webTitle: China sells organs of slain convicts

fields.headline: China sells organs of slain convicts
fields.standfirst: Desperately ill Malays pay a 'special rate' of $10,000 per kidney. The 'donor' pays with his life
fields.trailText: Desperately ill Malays pay a 'special rate' of $10,000 per kidney. The 'donor' pays with his life
fields.body:
For more than a week Yong Puay Sim had lain alongside 10 other kidney patients in a grim hospital ward in China to which she had travelled from her home in Malacca, Malaysia.

She could understand little of the language being spoken by the doctors and the conditions were far from clean. Outside her window the air was thick with smog, the roads packed with people.

But a Chinese festival was approaching, and a friend who had travelled with her to China brought the news she'd been waiting for: 'They are going to shoot - to execute - the criminals. Then we will have the organs and they can carry out the transplant for you all.'

This was in April, and Yong had travelled to a hospital run by the People's Liberation Army in the Chinese provincial city of Chongqing. She paid the hospital $10,000 in cash for her new organ.

The friend who had travelled with her was Wilson Yeo, who had paid for a kidney from the same hospital a few months earlier, and has since helped many others make the trip. He, too, was in no doubt about where his new organ came from, though he did ask for more details about the donor.

'I said to the doctor, give me more information, I'm worried, you know. He said: "Don't worry, yours is a 19-year-old kidney, probably a drug smuggler, put to death".' He had organised his trip directly with the head of the transplant unit and says the doctors were very open about the source of the kidneys.

One of Wilson's biggest worries was carrying so much cash. But he was met at the airport by the head of the unit, in army uniform, and taken by army van to Chongqing's Third Affiliated Hospital.

'At that point my only consideration was that I had to survive. I have a family. I have kids,' he says, 'I didn't think about the ethical part.'

He says 30 people in three wards were waiting for a transplant during his stay. Four foreigners on his ward, paying twice as much as the Chinese, were given priority. He says one older man from Malacca was told he was unfit for the operation. But he slipped some extra cash to the doctor. He got his transplant, but died several days later.

Yong, a science teacher, had been desperate, warned she would not survive on dialysis: 'It's only when the doctor said it's a problem, it's endangering my life, that I decided to go to China.' She says she showered the doctors with gifts after her operation - a pewter teapot, a silver chain and necklace. 'They treated us well, so we rewarded them.'

Support groups in Malacca reckon several dozen desperate people suffering from kidney failure have made the journey, since two top officials from the Chongqing army hospital visited in 1998. They gave a presentation in this ethnic Chinese community, offering what they called the 'special rate' of $10,000.

An informal support network is centred on the Dialysis Association of Malacca. Five of the seven committee members at a meeting I attended have had transplants in China. They say their kidneys were all from executed convicts.

'Ethics is only applicable to those who are not involved personally,' says John Tan, a paramedic who runs a Malacca dialysis centre and helps run the association. He confirms most kidneys are from executed prisoners, and says the executions take place in the Chongqing hospital, the condemned prisoner being allowed to die under anaesthetic after organs have been removed.

'They do not suffer any pain as compared to the trauma they'd suffer just before being shot.'

The rush to China for transplants presents an acute ethical dilemma for kidney doctors in Malaysia, where there is strong cultural resistance to donating organs. There is a 16-year waiting list for a kidney: with more than 6,000 people on dialysis, there were only six donors in Malaysia last year.

Although moves are afoot to strengthen the Malaysian donor programme, kidney failure for most means life on a dialysis machine - four hours a day, three days a week.

The director of the National Kidney Foundation in the capital Kuala Lumpur, Dr Thiruventhiran, says people come to him daily asking about going to China.

'Most of my patients are desperate,' he says. 'I spend hours talking to patients. I'm not too sure what I'm doing now - trying to convince them not to do it or to do it. But I do want to give them a true picture of what's going on.'

He says hospital records show 60 to 70 people have returned after operations in China this year, though the true figure is probably much higher, since records show only those needing after-care.

He reckons several hundred have made the journey from Malaysia to a string of provincial Chinese hospitals offering commercial transplants.

He confirms most kidneys are from executed convicts and says those returning have no paperwork about the donor and often awful complications.

It's to Chongqing, though, that most of those from Malacca have travelled for their transplants. Posing as a prospective client, a Mandarin-speaking colleague telephoned the army hospital and was put through to Professor Li Qian Sheng, deputy director of the transplant unit.

He offered the 'special' rate of 80,000 to 90,000 renminbi ($9,700 to $11,000) for a kidney. He said his unit had carried out 100 transplants this year alone on patients, largely from the overseas Chinese communities in Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia.

His tone changed when asked whether the organs were from convicts: 'It's not convenient. I don't want to talk about this on the phone, but I can tell you they are good stuff.' Just say yes or no, we asked. 'No, no, no,' he said uncomfortably.

In Malacca, Yong had to spend a month in hospital with complications after her return. But she has no regrets, and is now running a stall in a busy tourist street, trying to raise money to pay back the loan her daughter took out for the operation. Wilson is now jogging most afternoons, and organising another small group for Chongqing early next year. They will travel ahead of a Chinese festival, traditionally a time of large-scale executions.

Foo Eng Suan, a restaurant owner, hopes to be among them. He travels round the temples of old Malacca seeking donations to pay for his transplant. 'Nobody can give us a kidney [in Malaysia], not even our own brothers.' He has few qualms about accepting a kidney from an executed convict. 'That's the way they do things in China.'

For the desperate - those who can afford it - it's a question of survival. And with no shortage of prisoners awaiting execution, the Chinese army hospital in Chongqing is only too willing to oblige.

Ian Williams is Asia Correspondent of Channel 4 News. His report on the kidney trade will be shown tonight at 7pm.

webTitle: Peter Preston on the US elections

fields.headline: We're back where  we started. Now let's finish it
fields.standfirst:
The ballot box, not the courts, is the only fair way to settle the result, says Peter Preston

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The ballot box, not the courts, is the only fair way to settle the result.
fields.body:
Four months ago, for no apparent reason, the recorded voice of Stephen Hawking echoed ethereally round the Los Angeles convention centre. A weird, dislocated moment. The voice was backing Al Gore for President. Democrat delegations, partying on the floor, did not stop to listen - but now, perhaps, they should.

This election has turned into a new, impenetrable chapter for Hawking's impenetrable book. A chapter, perhaps, called Finality Lost. The latest twist from Florida's Supreme Court - whether or not the decision is stayed or overturned as it leaves the sunshine state for federal courtrooms to the north - means one bleak thing. Emotionally, there can be no finality along any legal route. There may be decisions from Atlanta or from the US Supreme Court which hand the White House to George W. Bush, but there will be no settled end to the argument.

If one more Florida judge out of seven had tipped the other way on Friday night, that would have signalled a reasonable close. Gore's backers on Capitol Hill, sensing defeat there, had long since decided to abandon the Vice-President and his unavailing fight: we would surely have been watching Al and George W. embracing, good sports in defeat and victory, healing statesmen bringing the country together (for at least 15 minutes).

Forget it. The true focus - the only hope of finality - is back to the boxes of votes stacked in Leon County court house and in canvassing board cupboards around Florida.

There are 40,000 or 50,000 of them that matter. They are the sole, emotional means left of telling America who really won - and the crazy thing is that three weeks of suit and counter-suit have brought us back only to a solution of common-sense fairness. The lawyers and politicians have merely got in the way.

Simple facts. Florida's electoral system is a broken-down joke, a mix of clanky machines and muddy law. It is not up to coping with an election of massive import and harrowing closeness.

There are four different ways of voting around the 67 counties, some ancient (like ticks on a piece of paper), some relatively modern (such as scanning marked forms into a computer). Only 25 counties use the wretched punch cards, and they, overwhelmingly, are where the problem lies.

Sometimes, as the world now knows, the punches do not wholly detach the chad and the votes do not register on the IBM tabulating machines. You can count and recount mechanically, but only holding the cards up to the light and the human eye can discern intention. Does intention matter? It does when majorities are wafer thin.

The Bush camp, for all their arrogancies and yobbo tactics, have always had a decent case - more decent than Democrat partisans have allowed. Look, they say: if the punch mechanisms are defective, they are at least neutral; they under-count equally between candidates. They are also the chosen, agreed way of deciding. The canvassing boards in Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties are all dominated by Democrats. The superviser who designed the butterfly ballot is a Democrat. If you play by the rules, these are the rules. We won.

Worse still, they add, Gore is a bad loser. He will do anything to grind out spurious victory. He will shout 'Let every vote be counted' while his acolytes try to rule out tens of thousands of absentee ballots on technicalities. Desperate hypocrisy.

There is no settled pattern for counting the semi-detached chads and dimples. Different counties have already staged their hand recounts differently. Shambles. Just stop messing about and admit it: We won.

Bush's problem, though, has always been political rather than textbook technical. The 25 punch-card counties include most of Florida's biggest, poorest and most Democratic areas. Recounting there by hand would - statistically - favour Gore.

That is why the gap (in Supreme Court terms) is down to 154, the whole presidency hanging by a chad. That is why Gore has been so desperate to set the hand recounts going.

And the trouble for the Republicans today is that, emotionally again, he must be right. Almost three weeks back he offered his own solution - a statewide hand recount with plenty of time to agree standards and analyse the ballots.

The Bush boys did not bite because (of course) they thought they might lose and wanted to hang on to the victories they had. Now the Florida Supreme Court has wrecked that strategy by ordering a statewide count of undervotes, the variously punctured chads. They have, in effect, ordered what Gore offered in early November: that a count not a court decides.

You can whisk through dozens of immediately permutating scenarios from this point. The challenges, the injunctions, the stops and starts, the threat that Florida's state legislature, with its big Republican majority, will produce its own slate for the electoral college, the doomsday forecasts of the street-fighters on Capitol Hill deciding in the mists of Janu ary. Nightmare stuff: but this is an American nightmare. Yet the answer that matters is still in those boxes. The chads are hanging in there.

You can, from afar, make too much of the political bias of judges, canvassing boards, even State warrior women like Katherine Harris. It was (remember) the Democrat Dade board who thwarted Gore by stopping recounting and the Democrat Palm Beach board which did not count chads the way he wanted.

The Florida Supreme Court divided Democrat against Democrat. The hand recounts so far have had observers from both parties in at the death and, for all the Republican noise, been conducted without fundamental challenge to their fairness.

On the ground, in short, there is more integrity and independence than the screaming politicians would have you believe. Nor, with proper manpower, need a recount of the undervotes take long. This is not putting a man on the moon: it is scrutinising the votes from a couple of British constituencies on election night.

Is that better than Jeb Bush's legislature battalions producing their own 'victory' in the electoral college - or Tom DeLay's attack dogs picking Bush on the Hill next year?

Absolutely, if there is to be any tranquillity thereafter. It is even better than the US Supreme Court stepping in and calling an artificial halt before the ballots can be recounted - for the ballots themselves will remain, testimony to an enduring, contrary reality throughout the Bush years.

Crisis, what crisis? This, at root now, is a reality crisis. Finality Regained.

The latest twist from Florida's Supreme Court - whether or not the decision is stayed or overturned as it leaves the sunshine state for federal courtrooms to the north - means one bleak thing. Emotionally, there can be no finality along any legal route. There may be decisions from Atlanta or from the US Supreme Court which hand the White House to George W. Bush, but there will be no settled end to the argument. If one more Florida judge out of seven had tipped the other way on Friday night, that would have signalled a reasonable close. Gore's backers on Capitol Hill, sensing defeat there, had long since decided to abandon the Vice-President and his unavailing fight: we would surely have been watching Al and George W. embracing, good sports in defeat and victory, healing statesmen bringing the country together (for at least 15 minutes). Forget it. The true focus - the only hope of finality - is back to the boxes of votes stacked in Leon County court house and in canvassing board cupboards around Florida. There are 40,000 or 50,000 of them that matter. They are the sole, emotional means left of telling America who really won - and the crazy thing is that three weeks of suit and counter-suit have brought us back only to a solution of common-sense fairness. The lawyers and politicians have merely got in the way. Simple facts. Florida's electoral system is a broken-down joke, a mix of clanky machines and muddy law. It is not up to coping with an election of massive import and harrowing closeness. There are four different ways of voting around the 67 counties, some ancient (like ticks on a piece of paper), some relatively modern (such as scanning marked forms into a computer). Only 25 counties use the wretched punch cards, and they, overwhelmingly, are where the problem lies. Sometimes, as the world now knows, the punches do not wholly detach the chad and the votes do not register on the IBM tabulating machines. You can count and recount mechanically, but only holding the cards up to the light and the human eye can discern intention. Does intention matter? It does when majorities are wafer thin. The Bush camp, for all their arrogancies and yobbo tactics, have always had a decent case - more decent than Democrat partisans have allowed. Look, they say: if the punch mechanisms are defective, they are at least neutral; they under-count equally between candidates. They are also the chosen, agreed way of deciding. The canvassing boards in Palm Beach, Broward and Miami-Dade counties are all dominated by Democrats. The superviser who designed the butterfly ballot is a Democrat. If you play by the rules, these are the rules. We won. Worse still, they add, Gore is a bad loser. He will do anything to grind out spurious victory. He will shout 'Let every vote be counted' while his acolytes try to rule out tens of thousands of absentee ballots on technicalities. Desperate hypocrisy. There is no settled pattern for counting the semi-detached chads and dimples. Different counties have already staged their hand recounts differently. Shambles. Just stop messing about and admit it: We won. Bush's problem, though, has always been political rather than textbook technical. The 25 punch-card counties include most of Florida's biggest, poorest and most Democratic areas. Recounting there by hand would - statistically - favour Gore. That is why the gap (in Supreme Court terms) is down to 154, the whole presidency hanging by a chad. That is why Gore has been so desperate to set the hand recounts going. And the trouble for the Republicans today is that, emotionally again, he must be right. Almost three weeks back he offered his own solution - a statewide hand recount with plenty of time to agree standards and analyse the ballots. The Bush boys did not bite because (of course) they thought they might lose and wanted to hang on to the victories they had. Now the Florida Supreme Court has wrecked that strategy by ordering a statewide count of undervotes, the variously punctured chads. They have, in effect, ordered what Gore offered in early November: that a count not a court decides. You can whisk through dozens of immediately permutating scenarios from this point. The challenges, the injunctions, the stops and starts, the threat that Florida's state legislature, with its big Republican majority, will produce its own slate for the electoral college, the doomsday forecasts of the street-fighters on Capitol Hill deciding in the mists of Janu ary. Nightmare stuff: but this is an American nightmare. Yet the answer that matters is still in those boxes. The chads are hanging in there. You can, from afar, make too much of the political bias of judges, canvassing boards, even State warrior women like Katherine Harris. It was (remember) the Democrat Dade board who thwarted Gore by stopping recounting and the Democrat Palm Beach board which did not count chads the way he wanted. The Florida Supreme Court divided Democrat against Democrat. The hand recounts so far have had observers from both parties in at the death and, for all the Republican noise, been conducted without fundamental challenge to their fairness. On the ground, in short, there is more integrity and independence than the screaming politicians would have you believe. Nor, with proper manpower, need a recount of the undervotes take long. This is not putting a man on the moon: it is scrutinising the votes from a couple of British constituencies on election night. Is that better than Jeb Bush's legislature battalions producing their own 'victory' in the electoral college - or Tom DeLay's attack dogs picking Bush on the Hill next year? Absolutely, if there is to be any tranquillity thereafter. It is even better than the US Supreme Court stepping in and calling an artificial halt before the ballots can be recounted - for the ballots themselves will remain, testimony to an enduring, contrary reality throughout the Bush years. Crisis, what crisis? This, at root now, is a reality crisis. Finality Regained. Key document Download the Florida supreme court ruling (pdf file) Related stories Timeline - when will America decide? webTitle: French row over school 'porn' book

fields.headline: French row over school 'porn' book
fields.trailText: On the face of it, the novel seemed an ideal text for schoolchildren in their early teens.  Le Grand Cahier, by award-winning writer Agota Kristof, was hailed a classic on its publication in 1986. It has been published in more than 30 countries.
fields.body:
On the face of it, the novel seemed an ideal text for schoolchildren in their early teens. Le Grand Cahier, by award-winning writer Agota Kristof, was hailed a classic on its publication in 1986. It has been published in more than 30 countries.

The novel is a trenchant critique of fascism and the corrupting effect of war. It is told through the story of twin boy evacuees during a nameless conflict that resembles the Second World War, who grow up during a totalitarian regime. The book is recommended as a suitable text for pupils by France's national centre for teaching documents, the CNDP.

But when a 26-year-old literature teacher bought copies of the book for his class to read at his college in Abbeville, northern France, he was arrested in front of his pupils and thrown in jail for three hours while officers searched his home. 'We saw the cops arrive and take him away,' said Sylvain, a pupil.

Fifteen anonymous complaints had been made by parents to the local public prosecutor's office, claiming the teacher was diffusing 'pornographic literature'. According to Marie-Françoise Hiroux of the teachers' union: 'The children wouldn't have had time to read the text because the complaint had already been lodged. [The parents] went straight to the authorities without the normal stage of a dialogue between parents and teachers.'

But the local public prosecutor, Patrick Steinmetz, told the local paper, the Courrier Picard, that he had intervened quickly to protect children confronted with violent and pornographic messages, and that the search of the teacher's home had been authorised 'to make sure there were no other dangers'.

The 'Abbeville affair' has provoked a national scandal. Teachers, pupils and parents have demonstrated in the town's streets in support of the teacher.

Eric Duhaupas, a history and geography professor at the college, said: 'We're really concerned about the over-zealousness of the police and the judiciary in this matter.'

Education Secretary Jack Lang wrote to the Millevoye College principal, saying: 'The authorities, which have nothing to do with education, brutally arrested and questioned a teacher because of his teaching choices. This is an abnormal situation and I can't approve of it. Teaching choices must remain exclusively the concern of teams of teachers.'

On Friday teachers from 15 colleges in the Picardy region went on strike in support of the teacher.

Le Grand Cahier is a short, sometimes shocking, and - on two occasions - sexually explicit book. In one scene, a girl is sodomised by a dog. In another there is fellatio. Much of the violence is used to show the lack of a moral code at a time of war. Le Grand Cahier is the first in a trilogy. The final volume won the Prix du Livre Inter in 1992. Kristof, who left her native Hungary in 1956 and has since lived in Switzerland, declined to comment on the affair. But her publishers, Editions du Seuil, deplored the actions against the Abbeville teacher, who has since been transferred to a college in Amiens.

'He has not been sanctioned or suspended,' said the rector of Amiens College, Alain Morvan. 'He has simply received friendly counsel. There are passages that are very strong indeed. The teacher is passionately interested in literature. But... some children, aged 13, are perhaps a little too young to study this book.'

The public prosecutor has dropped any action, but politicians and teachers are angry over the continuing anonymity of the parents who complained.

Francis Hammel, deputy for the Somme department, suggested 'reactionary bourgeoisie' involvement.

The Courrier Picard newspaper reported that two students at the school, one the son of a National Front functionary, had been suspended just before the teacher's arrest.

webTitle: Letter:  Guns flaw

fields.headline: Guns flaw
fields.body:
Professor John Benyon says 'our unarmed police force is the envy of the world' (News, last week). I used to believe that guff, then I became addicted to holidays in hot countries where all the police carry side arms, and don't feel any less respect for those policemen because they carry a weapon. The only noticeable thing is there always appears to be a lot more around when you need them, and sometimes when you don't!
Joe Phillips Bingham
Notts

webTitle: Scandal of children poisoned by Russian space junk

fields.headline: Scandal of children poisoned by Russian space junk
fields.standfirst:
The debris from rocket launches is causing sickness and birth defects deep in Siberia. Amelia Gentleman reports from Moscow

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: The debris from rocket launches is causing sickness and birth defects deep in Siberia. Amelia Gentleman reports from Moscow
fields.body:
Every time a Russian rocket lifts off from its launch pad at Baikonur, residents in the tiny Siberian village of Ploskoye, more than 1,000 miles away, are shaken nine minutes later by a terrible explosion.

If it is dark, firework flashes are visible in the sky above their homes, with streaking flames burning through the air as fuel falls to Earth. During the day a misty yellowish cloud sometimes hangs over the region. Villagers say the noise of the blast sets dogs howling for hours.

In the days after each launch, rocket fragments from the shuttles ferrying astronauts and equipment to Mir, or to the International Space Station, can be found in the hills and forests nearby.

From time to time, local farmers discover massive, shining metal cylinders - up to seven metres long and three metres wide - which have in the past been seized with delight and converted into chicken coops, hunting huts or grain storage tanks.

Recently, however, as more information emerges about the poisonous fuels lining the wreckage, locals have started to regard the debris with mounting alarm. Village doctors have charted a growth in illnesses among their patients - from cancer to bronchial spasms to defects in new-born children - and concluded they are connected to the scattering of cosmic litter on the region. Teachers report that in the days following each launch, children complain of stomach pains, dizziness and headaches and find it hard to concentrate.

After decades of concealing the problem, the Russian space agency, Rosaviakosmos, has conceded the regular jettisoning of sections of rocket engine on this region of Siberia and up to 20 other areas in Russia may have a harmful effect on the local population and has agreed to fund preliminary research. Villagers demand compensation for the harmful effects of living for the past 40 years in what they see as a huge dustbin for Russia's space programme.

The problem lies in the design of the Soyuz and Proton rockets, built to discard the engines that power their lift-off and passage through the atmosphere. The Soyuz's first four side-blocks - each of which contains four engines - drop from its hull around a minute after lift-off over Kazakhstan. The second stage of the rocket, which contains another four engines, drops eight minutes later, while a third is meant to burn up in the sky.

According to maps held at Rosaviakosmos's headquarters in Moscow, the second section should fall somewhere within an area in an uninhabited part of the mountains of Gorno-Altai, classified Dropping Region 306. In reality, say the villagers of Ploskoye and nearby Novoaleiskoye, several miles outside the allocated space, the rocket pieces rain down on them.

The danger of anyone being hurt by a falling fragment is extremely slim, and Rosaviakosmos officials point out that since Russia's space programme began in 1960, the only casualties have been cattle. But the real danger lies in the unburnt rocket fuel that falls with the metal.

While Soyuz rockets are powered by a relatively innocuous combination of kerosene and liquid oxygen, Proton rockets run on a highly noxious fuel called heptyl which can cause severe blood and liver problems. Viktor Pakhomov, 55, head of the Ploskoye administration, is seeking to discover why, in his village of 1,000, people are becoming more and more unwell. For 40 years, little official research has been done into the connections between illness and the space programme; so Pakhomov has tried to catalogue its effects himself.

As a result of his attempts to collect and identify toxic fuel remnants, he has burnt his retinas to the point of near-blindness, suffered from temporary paralysis in his hands and scorched his lungs by breathing in poisonous fluids. 'We have never been sent any protective equipment to help us handle the material, because the local authorities have never admitted there is a problem,' he said.

The space agency warns him of most launches, and he broadcasts a radio warning telling locals to stay inside and avoid drawing water from rivers in the days following.

He has recorded all cases of sickness after launches. Villagers have become ill from eating cucumbers from their gardens after rocket debris was found nearby, men have come out in blisters from swimming in the river, and farmers' arms have been covered in sores harvesting hay.

Ploskoye doctor Olga Varova is besieged by new patients every time a rocket is launched. 'We have people complaining of nausea, vomiting, headaches and finding it hard to breathe,' she said. 'But more worrying are what appear to be the cumulative effects of the pollution. In the last five years, not one child in the village has been born completely fit - each baby has been diagnosed with blood problems or nervous system complaints.'

Emma Ladoga, acting head doctor at the regional hospital, said: 'People here aren't ill because they're poor; we think their illnesses are connected to the environmental situation.' A study showed people from the affected villages were twice as likely to suffer from thyroid cancers as those in a control village.

Mikhail Shashin, head of the Siberian environmental group, Katun, said pollution from space activity was a serious international problem - only American citizens did not suffer in the same way, because rockets launched in the US drop their debris over the ocean. 'If the situation is to improve, we need to have a global agreement restricting the number of rocket launches,' he said.

Under a new agreement signed between Rosaviakosmos and the local authorities, the region surrounding Ploskoye will get 90,000 roubles (£2,250) every time a commercial launch takes place. The money does not represent compensation, but is allocated as rent on the land for the six hours during which lift-off occurs.

'We don't believe there is any case for compensation yet. Rocket launches, like industrial activity, aeroplane or car travel, naturally have some effect on the environment, but there is nothing to prove people are suffering,' Alexander Bolysov of Rosaviakosmos commented. 'These environmental issues have become very fashionable recently. Nobody ever suggests that we should stop air travel because people occasionally die on aeroplanes.'

But the allocation of new money to fund research into environmental and health problems in the region indicates the organisation has become uncomfortable about inhabitants' complaints.

So far the only money villagers in Ploskoye have seen was a nine rouble (22.5p) handout from the local administration to each inhabitant earlier this year.

Nikolai Shtifinov, head of the local environment committee, said: 'In any civilised country, the government would admit the problem and would pay us compensation. What do we get? Nine roubles - it's not even enough to buy a jar of coffee.'

webTitle: Barbara Ellen: Me, myself, I

fields.headline: Me, myself, I: An unholy trinity
fields.trailText: It's so rare that cinema throws up decent female role models. Having just seen the remake of the 1970s TV series Charlie's Angels, I am delighted to report that it features one of the strongest, most complex, female characters ever.
fields.body:
It's so rare that cinema throws up decent female role models. Having just seen the remake of the 1970s TV series Charlie's Angels, I am delighted to report that it features one of the strongest, most complex, female characters ever - feisty, yet vulnerable, apocalyptically intelligent, yet with a lovable daffy side, independent of spirit, yet kind of cuddly with it. Oh, and, crucially, 'good in bed' in a cute/stern, nice girl/bad-girl, Madonna/whore, rock chick/girl next door, dominatrix/best chum sort of way. Call me impressionable, but I love this woman, and I want to be her. Trouble is, there simply aren't enough of me.

For, strangely, the portrayal of this 'perfect' movie woman has not been entrusted to one actress. Rather 'she' has been chopped into three, with one third each played by Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Lui respectively. There's Cammy, the ditsy blonde who breaks off from fighting baddies to chew her little finger and make baby talk to her paramour on her mobile phone. Then there's Drew, the sexually liberated reddish blonde who definitely wears the (tight) trousers. And finally there's Lucy, the flint-eyed academic Oriental who, in that wonderful non-racial stereotyping way Hollywood has, is portrayed as the kind of inscrutable, frightening chick who would happily suck the brains out of kittens for breakfast.

Taken individually, these characters are merely one-dimensional wafer-thin cardboard cut-outs of modern femininity. Put together, they not only make perfect sense, they transmogrify into the Perfect Woman.

In Charlie's Angels, one doesn't get so much a 'she', as a 'she-three', with each actress chipping in with those man-pleasing sexual-intellectual characteristics not to be found in the other two. You never caught Bette Davis and Joan Crawford helping each other out like this. Nor, remarkably, do male actors seem to end up being he-threes. Indeed, some might see it as an indictment of modern Hollywood mores that it takes three actresses to produce one vaguely credible female. However, personally, I think this 'collaborative attractiveness' is a great idea, and one that could catch on in the real world. As the Charlie's Angels she-three proves, it could simply be bad form to expect a woman to be attractive all on her own these days. Maybe it's time to swallow our pride and admit that we might need a bit of back-up.

Read any romantic self-help book, and they all say the same thing - men get bored easily. It's not their fault (crush that thought). They need variety. That's why, to keep 'him' happy, a woman must be, in effect, many women - morphing her personality into several different shapes in order to satisfy her man. Putting it like that, it becomes clear that it's not only Mormons who practise polygamy. Perfectly ordinary couples are doing it all the time - the only difference being that the woman is forced to be several women all on her own. The technical term for this is 'Keeping Him Guessing', but, if you ask me, women are simply exhausting themselves with all this psychosexual multi-tasking. Maybe it's time to get together with our friends and share out the 'chores' of modern femininity.

Of course, men have been compartmentalising women like this for years. That's where infidelity comes from. However, in romance as in the workplace, maybe women should learn to delegate. Man-share as others job-share. A woman for each male 'need' as it were. As any man could tell you, variety is not a simple matter of unlimited access to different bodies. They could just about put up with that, but it would be even more fun if there were different 'talents' on offer, too. This is where the trouble could start. Jerry Hall famously said that a woman should be 'a maid in the drawing room, a cook in the kitchen, and a whore in the bedroom'. I could just about rustle up that winning team, but what about me? Where is the opening, so to speak, for an argumentative scruff-pot with no culinary abilities and an attitude problem? Which room do I get? And, for that matter, which body part?

It is frightening to belatedly take on board the fact that I am not a male fantasy on any level whatsoever. Even more devastating to realise that no self-respecting she-three would ever want me on their team. I would be a liability, someone who has nothing to offer 'our' man, except maybe myself (which is clearly not enough). Bearing this in mind, maybe this man-share/collaborative attractiveness deal wouldn't be such a winner after all. It seems that, while it works very well in cinemaland, when real women club together to try to be Everywoman, they somehow become less than the sum of their parts. The whole dissolving into a screaming mess of female irregularity and insecurity. Unlike Charlie's lovely angels, it would seem that real women are just not team players.

Rather 'she' has been chopped into three, with one third each played by Cameron Diaz, Drew Barrymore and Lucy Lui respectively. There's Cammy, the ditsy blonde who breaks off from fighting baddies to chew her little finger and make baby talk to her paramour on her mobile phone. Then there's Drew, the sexually liberated reddish blonde who definitely wears the (tight) trousers. And finally there's Lucy, the flint-eyed academic Oriental who, in that wonderful non-racial stereotyping way Hollywood has, is portrayed as the kind of inscrutable, frightening chick who would happily suck the brains out of kittens for breakfast. Taken individually, these characters are merely one-dimensional wafer-thin cardboard cut-outs of modern femininity. Put together, they not only make perfect sense, they transmogrify into the Perfect Woman. In Charlie's Angels, one doesn't get so much a 'she', as a 'she-three', with each actress chipping in with those man-pleasing sexual-intellectual characteristics not to be found in the other two. You never caught Bette Davis and Joan Crawford helping each other out like this. Nor, remarkably, do male actors seem to end up being he-threes. Indeed, some might see it as an indictment of modern Hollywood mores that it takes three actresses to produce one vaguely credible female. However, personally, I think this 'collaborative attractiveness' is a great idea, and one that could catch on in the real world. As the Charlie's Angels she-three proves, it could simply be bad form to expect a woman to be attractive all on her own these days. Maybe it's time to swallow our pride and admit that we might need a bit of back-up. Read any romantic self-help book, and they all say the same thing - men get bored easily. It's not their fault (crush that thought). They need variety. That's why, to keep 'him' happy, a woman must be, in effect, many women - morphing her personality into several different shapes in order to satisfy her man. Putting it like that, it becomes clear that it's not only Mormons who practise polygamy. Perfectly ordinary couples are doing it all the time - the only difference being that the woman is forced to be several women all on her own. The technical term for this is 'Keeping Him Guessing', but, if you ask me, women are simply exhausting themselves with all this psychosexual multi-tasking. Maybe it's time to get together with our friends and share out the 'chores' of modern femininity. Of course, men have been compartmentalising women like this for years. That's where infidelity comes from. However, in romance as in the workplace, maybe women should learn to delegate. Man-share as others job-share. A woman for each male 'need' as it were. As any man could tell you, variety is not a simple matter of unlimited access to different bodies. They could just about put up with that, but it would be even more fun if there were different 'talents' on offer, too. This is where the trouble could start. Jerry Hall famously said that a woman should be 'a maid in the drawing room, a cook in the kitchen, and a whore in the bedroom'. I could just about rustle up that winning team, but what about me? Where is the opening, so to speak, for an argumentative scruff-pot with no culinary abilities and an attitude problem? Which room do I get? And, for that matter, which body part? It is frightening to belatedly take on board the fact that I am not a male fantasy on any level whatsoever. Even more devastating to realise that no self-respecting she-three would ever want me on their team. I would be a liability, someone who has nothing to offer 'our' man, except maybe myself (which is clearly not enough). Bearing this in mind, maybe this man-share/collaborative attractiveness deal wouldn't be such a winner after all. It seems that, while it works very well in cinemaland, when real women club together to try to be Everywoman, they somehow become less than the sum of their parts. The whole dissolving into a screaming mess of female irregularity and insecurity. Unlike Charlie's lovely angels, it would seem that real women are just not team players. barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Nick Cohen: The end of innocence

fields.headline: The end of innocence
fields.standfirst:
Banal, headline-grabbing policies have obscured plans to curtail fundamental principles of justice | Stand by your man and put a ribbon in your hair
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Banal, headline-grabbing policies have obscured plans to curtail fundamental principles of justice | Stand by your man and put a ribbon in your hair
fields.body:
We can fix the moment and cherish it like the memory of first love through the long, Mogadon days of the election 'debate'. On the afternoon of Wednesday 6 December, Tony Blair levelled with the public and described the joint programme of New Labour and the Old Conservatives with unprecedented candour and a scrupulous respect for all the relevant facts. He stared across the Commons at the admittedly disorientating figures of William Hague and Ann Widdecombe and countered their ridicule of his Queen's Speech with:

'What is the alternative? What does the Right Hon Gentleman offer? Why was it that he made a policy-free speech, apart from a load of nonsense from the shadow Home Secretary, most of which we are doing in any event?'

I couldn't have put it better myself. As an epitaph for a political class that strikes the poses of tough-on-crime populism to keep the proles' eyes from fixing on anything but the ball, the Prime Minister's flash of honesty is impossible to beat.

Before us we have the first Labour administration in a generation. For two years it stuck to Conservative tax and spending limits while the gap between rich and poor spanned an ever-wider chasm and squalid public services degenerated yet further. For about six months it busied itself with this and that. My progressive colleagues were impressed, although I'm afraid all that lodged in my brain was the Government's determination to privatise hospitals and air traffic control - services which Thatcher at her most unbalanced had left unmolested.

Now Blair is rushing into a needlessly early election with the slogan that there is no reason to vote for nonsensical Tory stunts because New Labour's will be just as asinine. A glance at Blair's programme confirms that this is one promise which will be kept. The Queen's Speech showed him to be a trivial man who believes his most urgent tasks are to go for fox hunters, juries, drunks and children up after bedtime.

There is a great temptation when confronted with such banalities to dismiss the Hagues and Blairs as gesture politicians who can't do real damage. And in many instances contemptuous indifference is all you need.

Last week's headline-grabbing announcement was that the age at which curfews could be imposed on children who have committed no crime would rise from 10 to 16. Alert journalists noted that Blair's love of the tactics of martial law wouldn't change the world. English councils already have the power to place the under-10s under house arrest. No local authority has used them. Not one.

Who can blame them? The inspiration for kiddie curfews came from a conversation I had with a rambling Jack Straw in 1996. He was impressed by the poll ratings Bill Clinton had achieved after he advocated treating teenagers as the enemies within (or, rather, without). Straw phoned me back to say he didn't mean it and asked me to forget what he had said.

Because I refused and The Observer ran the story, New Labour had to invent a policy in 30 seconds and pretend it was the result of a solemn and rigorous analysis.

But the banal can also be dangerously brutal. All the punditry of the past week has missed the Government's decision to introduce a bill which tears up the presumption that we are innocent until proved guilty.

If you have money and the police take against you, they will be able to demand that you either prove your wealth was earned legally or lose it. An accusation will be enough to force you to reveal your finances. Your assets will be frozen while you wait for the case to come to court. When it does, the police will not have to 'prove beyond reasonable doubt' that your lucre is the proceeds of crime - just that the money was 'probably' made illegally.

The measure, of course, is aimed against the gangsters whose astonishing fortunes have been built on drug prohibitions that Blair and Hague support. Like many others, I find the criminal profits that the unwinnable war creates terrifying, not least because of the corruption the money promotes - you can't move in the Old Bailey these days without running into alleged bent copper prosecutions.

What the Government is saying is that if the police 'know' that Bloggs is a drugs baron we should trust them and that should be enough. No need for boring old legal procedures. Often detectives do know and if the bill becomes law our mafiosi could become like Al Capone, another beneficiary of prohibition, and be caught by accountants rather than detectives.

But in the US, to which New Labour has again turned for ideas to fill its tiny mind, some gangsters are caught but many more flourish unmolested. It is the innocent who carry cash who suffer the most. Gamblers going to Las Vegas, black men in flash cars and those who pay in notes rather than with credit cards are stopped and fleeced and have to fight for years to get their property back. The lesson is that when you remove the rule of law, the law of unintended consequences kicks in with a vengeance.

Unfortunately, the lesson from America our politicians want to learn is the exact opposite. Peter Mandelson and Tony Blair are disturbed that a booming economy, for the wealthy at any rate, has not yet produced an Al Gore victory. A strong economy was not enough for the US Democrats, Mandelson has been telling his friends. New Labour must fight on 'quality of life issues' - of which crime is the most prominent. Hence a Queen's Speech stuffed with assaults on liberty Xeroxed from Bill Clinton's worthless administration.

I often wonder if Mandelson is animated by any intelligence beyond low cunning. If Gore loses, he should blame his and Clinton's ferocious crime policies. Two million Americans are denied the vote because they have been dumped in a vast prison system, whose size only the countries of the old Soviet Union can match. Those who have served their time are disenfranchised on release as an additional punishment. If they could have voted, most who bothered would have voted Democrat and Gore would have the White House.

The American Third Way is, gratifyingly, being destroyed by its own cynical barbarism - or 'pragmatism' as it's now called. How does the cliché run? Something about what is happening in America today happens in Britain five years later.

We know that Peniel Pentecostal Church has taken over much of the Brentwood and Ongar Conservative Association. The papers have been full of how dissident Essex Tories begged Martin Bell to stand against their MP, Eric Pickles, who found it politic to welcome the evangelists to the Conservative congregation. Less has been said about what it was in the theology of the Peniel Pentecostalists which has driven loyalists in one of the last ditches of Tory England to revolt.

The sect is led by 'Bishop' Michael Reid, a Mercedes-driving former policeman, who promises his credulous flock that his miracles can cure cancer. (He has made millions by selling insurance policies to the faithful as backups in case his prayers for divine intervention are unanswered.)

The Bishop is a traditionalist on sexual questions, and if he ever gets thrown out of the God business he could make a comfortable living on the Daily Mail . At the Peniel Women's Conference, Reid read from the Good Wives Guide , published in America a mere 50 years ago, and commended its rules. Here, for the benefit of women readers wondering how to keep a man, is the advice of the pastor tending the soul of the modern Conservative Party.

'Have dinner ready. Plan ahead, even the night before, to have a delicious meal ready on time for his return. This is a way of letting him know that you have been thinking about him and are concerned about his needs.'

On no account must you look tired after the cooking, rather, 'take 15 minutes to rest so you'll be refreshed when he arrives. Touch up your makeup, put a ribbon in your hair and be fresh-looking. He has just been with a lot of work-weary people. Be a little gay and a little more interesting for him. [No, I do not think the Bishop wants wives to pander to male lesbian fantasies.] His boring day may need a lift and one of your duties is to provide it.'

The children must look as good as you do. 'Take a few minutes to wash their hands and faces (if they are small). Minimise all noise. At the time of his arrival, eliminate all noise of the washer, dryer or vacuum.'

When the grooming is done, the wife must be prepared to defer to the man at all times. If she speaks at all it should be in a 'low, soothing and pleasant voice'. She may think that her husband has fallen under the influence of crackpot preachers and politicians, but she should learn to hold her tongue. 'Listen to him. Let him talk first - remember, his topics of conversation are more important than yours.' Even in suspicious circumstances she must be silent. 'Never complain if he's late home for dinner or even if he stays out all night. Remember, he is the master of the house and as such will always exercise his will with fairness and truthfulness. You have no right to question him.'

The humiliated and servile Tory wife has always been a figure of fun. How good it is to see that the party of young Willie Hague is keeping the tradition alive.

webTitle: Monarchy debate: Europe is not the answer

fields.headline: Europe is not the answer
fields.standfirst: Join the debate online
fields.trailText: The papers, or so it has seemed, have been full of the republican question. Largely forgotten in the discussion has been the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty, which distinguishes the Westminster Parliament from others in the democratic world.
fields.body:
The papers, or so it has seemed, have been full of the republican question. There has been much discussion of the Acts of Settlement and the constitutional position of the Church of England, apparently without the realisation that there is another established church, north of the border, which doesn't recognise the sovereign as its head, though its loyalty has never been in doubt.

Largely forgotten in the discussion has been the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty, which distinguishes the Westminster Parliament from others in the democratic world. The idea of a fused monarchical and democratic power is as antique as the lost gerund. It justifies the supremacy of a Parliament not bound by its predecessors and puts all its legislative acts beyond the reach of the judges, who can interpret them in the light of other statutes and of common law but cannot override them. Even the Human Rights Act, enshrined the European Convention on Human Rights in domestic law, retains the ultimate sovereignty of Parliament.

Last week, on the eve of the state opening of Parliament, I was in the House of Lords discussing the convention with Lord Hope, the former Lord President and Lord Justice-General, and a Law Lord since 1996. He described to me his work on the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council, which in addition to its long-standing diet of appeals from the Commonwealth now adjudicates on so-called 'devolution issues'. These arise because the powers of the new legislative bodies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are defined by statute and, therefore, open to review.

So far, the first cases have concerned the interaction between the public prosecutor, the Lord Advocate, and the rules of the convention, by which he as a member of the Executive is bound. But Lord Hope could imagine a situation when there was a Tory Government at Westminster and a Labour or Nationalist administration in Edinburgh, in which the Privy Council might have to arbitrate between them if the Scottish Parliament, for example to meet some popular demand, legislated beyond its competence.

In the short term, he said, there is little chance of that situation arising. But what we have seen, in cases that have come before the Scottish courts and on appeal to the Privy Council, is our nervous and halting progress towards a kind of federalism, with a nascent constitutional court.

Of course, as Lord Hope pointed out, it is a lopsided process. The Privy Council last week established itself as a quick route to regularising issues that first arose in Scotland but apply throughout the UK. But from this new constitutional order in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, England otherwise stands apart. It has shown little interest in regional devolution, clinging to the notion that Westminster is the English Parliament, believing with Enoch Powell and Simon Schama that it culminates from 1,000 years of history rather than a body flowing from the Treaty of Union of 1707 and therefore, as a UK entity, less than 300 years old.

Herein lies the flaw in William Hague's proposal to exclude Westminster's Scottish MPs from English business. If carried through this would leave Scotland with a domestic parliament of limited powers unable to influence reserved matters which, even if determined on an England-only basis, would determine public priorities north of the border.

Although they are now prepared to discuss abandoning the constitutional monarchy, the English theorists do not seem ready to consider the consequences -the end of the doctrine of parliamentary sovereignty. It would be no great loss if it were replaced by a federal Commons, an English Parliament and an elected upper house to balance regional interests.

Let us have a bicycling monarchy, by all means; but also let us end our fixation with a chimera of a European superstate. Europe is striving to become a confederation, and a weak one at that. Our problems are much closer to home.

webTitle: Northern Ireland: Commitment is the key

fields.headline: Commitment is the key
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: President Clinton's visit comes at another critical stage in the evolution of the Good Friday Agreement. The issues remain decommissioning, policing and the recent unionist veto on Sinn Fein Ministers attending North-South Council meetings. Failures in progressing these threaten the full implementation of the Agreement.
fields.body:
President Clinton's visit comes at another critical stage in the evolution of the Good Friday Agreement. The issues remain decommissioning, policing and the recent unionist veto on Sinn Fein Ministers attending North-South Council meetings. Failures in progressing these threaten the full implementation of the Agreement.

Loyalist and republican paramilitaries need to acknowledge the uncertainty caused by failure to genuinely engage on the arms issue. Paramilitaries associated with pro-Agreement parties have accepted obligations to achieve lasting peace and political stability by co-operating with the International Independent Commission to achieve the 'total disarmament of all paramilitary arms'. Having done so, there is an understandable expectation that they deliver.

Dialogue with the decommissioning body would in itself be a confidence building measure and a sign of serious intent to resolve the arms issue. Failure to live up to commitments on decommissioning only breeds distrust and fuels suspicion. And, worse, threaten the Agreement.

A police service enjoying the allegiance of both communities is a core element of the Agreement. The service must be one in which nationalists and unionists can serve comfortably side by side. It must also be a service rooted in an ethos of human rights and democratically accountable to the whole community.

The SDLP is continuing to work positively for that outcome. Key unresolved issues include ensuring that independent inquiries take place into such controversial murders as those of Pat Finucane, Rosemary Nelson and Robert Hamill; a properly developed and detailed implementation plan to guide the process of change; and assurance that the powers the new Police Board will not be inhibited by the Secretary of State or the chief constable.

Failure to provide guarantees on these issues would also produce a crisis endangering the whole of the Agreement. The SDLP is working with both governments to achieve these guarantees so a new, widely accepted service can exist.

Equally, Unionism needs to abandon its self-service approach to the working the new institutions. The difficulties experienced by David Trimble in holding the pro-Agreement wing of his party together need to be better appreciated by others, as do the difficulties faced by paramilitaries in making progress on decommissioning.

The comfort offered to all by the Agreement only exists when it is operated in its entirety. Protecting that integrity requires progressing all aspects in parallel and in ways clearly seen as fulfilling our respective responsibilities. In other words, unionists must be convinced that the nationalist community is fully committed to implementing all aspects of the Agreement, and vice versa.

The Executive and the Assembly are serving the people of Northern Ireland well. Within the last six weeks we have agreed a programme for government and a budget which will be put to the Assembly for approval before Christmas. We are delivering on issues vital to the continuing development of a competitive economy which will benefit all the people. The North-South Council is developing a range of programmes covering key economic, cultural and social issues, including tourism, trade, education, agriculture, inland waterways and language. New east-west structures will facilitate the development of co-operative arrangements between the islands.

Most people, North and South, want the the agreement to work. They recognise that local politicians working together can make a real and positive difference. There would be so much to lose if the whole process were to falter at this point. That is why the message of hope and support that is President Clinton's decision to visit us for a third time will assist in resolving outstanding difficulties.

Sean Farren (SDLP, North Antrim) is Minister for Higher and Further Education, Training and Employment

Dialogue with the decommissioning body would in itself be a confidence building measure and a sign of serious intent to resolve the arms issue. Failure to live up to commitments on decommissioning only breeds distrust and fuels suspicion. And, worse, threaten the Agreement. A police service enjoying the allegiance of both communities is a core element of the Agreement. The service must be one in which nationalists and unionists can serve comfortably side by side. It must also be a service rooted in an ethos of human rights and democratically accountable to the whole community. The SDLP is continuing to work positively for that outcome. Key unresolved issues include ensuring that independent inquiries take place into such controversial murders as those of Pat Finucane, Rosemary Nelson and Robert Hamill; a properly developed and detailed implementation plan to guide the process of change; and assurance that the powers the new Police Board will not be inhibited by the Secretary of State or the chief constable. Failure to provide guarantees on these issues would also produce a crisis endangering the whole of the Agreement. The SDLP is working with both governments to achieve these guarantees so a new, widely accepted service can exist. Equally, Unionism needs to abandon its self-service approach to the working the new institutions. The difficulties experienced by David Trimble in holding the pro-Agreement wing of his party together need to be better appreciated by others, as do the difficulties faced by paramilitaries in making progress on decommissioning. The comfort offered to all by the Agreement only exists when it is operated in its entirety. Protecting that integrity requires progressing all aspects in parallel and in ways clearly seen as fulfilling our respective responsibilities. In other words, unionists must be convinced that the nationalist community is fully committed to implementing all aspects of the Agreement, and vice versa. The Executive and the Assembly are serving the people of Northern Ireland well. Within the last six weeks we have agreed a programme for government and a budget which will be put to the Assembly for approval before Christmas. We are delivering on issues vital to the continuing development of a competitive economy which will benefit all the people. The North-South Council is developing a range of programmes covering key economic, cultural and social issues, including tourism, trade, education, agriculture, inland waterways and language. New east-west structures will facilitate the development of co-operative arrangements between the islands. Most people, North and South, want the the agreement to work. They recognise that local politicians working together can make a real and positive difference. There would be so much to lose if the whole process were to falter at this point. That is why the message of hope and support that is President Clinton's decision to visit us for a third time will assist in resolving outstanding difficulties. Sean Farren (SDLP, North Antrim) is Minister for Higher and Further Education, Training and Employment

webTitle: Interiors: John Pawson

fields.headline: Cupboard love
fields.standfirst: Clutter is anathema to John Pawson. So where does the famously minimalist architect put his possessions, asks Tamsin Blanchard?
fields.trailText: Clutter is anathema to John Pawson. So where does the famously minimalist architect put his possessions, asks Tamsin Blanchard?
fields.body:
The question everyone wants to ask John Pawson, who appears to live his life with only the clothes on his back and the bare walls of his home, is 'Where's all your stuff?' You know - the books, the newspapers, the bits of post, the elastic bands, the odd socks, the CDs, the spare change, the coffee cup left over from breakfast - the detritus that clutters up most of our lives. Well, I have the answer. I've seen it with my own eyes. The general mess and chaos is all there. It's just hidden behind closed doors. What Pawson has managed to do in his own west London home is not pare down his life to a Zen-like minimum of possessions and 'stuff', but to build a house with adequate storage. Open any of the cupboard doors in the family's kitchen, and you will be relieved to discover that John Pawson is a human being, just like the rest of us. He's just a bit more organised.

We've seen the Pawson home, where the minimalist architect lives with his wife Catherine and their two children, Caius and Benedict, on TV. We've seen it in the pages of magazines, and we've read about it in books. To actually set foot inside feels a little like stepping on to a film set. It's a Victorian semi that has been gutted and pared back to a modern, open space filled with light and calm, and very little else. Early next year, Pawson's latest project - a new showroom for Bulthaup, the German kitchen company - will open to the public. 'My thing was not to upstage the kitchen or the art - it's a fairly neutral background. I wanted to provide a calm place where you and your partner can go and sit and have a bit of fun planning your kitchen.'

'Bulthaup is a very functional and well designed product,' says Pawson. And kitchens are an area he is interested in. He's currently working on a cookbook with food writer Annie Bell. 'It's called Living and Eating . I wanted a list, so throughout the year there are very simple, straightforward meals for friends and family - not highfalutin dinner party stuff, just proper food. He and Bell have been discussing menus for some time, and the photos for the book are being shot in his own kitchen. She does the eating part and he provides the lifestyle angle. 'I also wanted to say to people, "I suggest before the meal you have this apéritif and you drink it out of this glass, and for this particular meal you use this knife, fork and plate." It's just like saying here is a blueprint and then you can say bollocks if you want to. You can either adopt it or completely disagree with it.

'For me, heaven is a beautiful piece of white fish and some interesting green vegetables or a bit of salad on the side. It's a plate with a bit of space and something I can visually handle, rather than this pile of food that I used to have as a child because my father liked a joint of meat every night. I'm not saying I don't like that occasionally. It's not precious nouvelle cuisine all the time.' But Pawson does prefer fish to meat, unlike his children, who have developed a taste for steak - the bloodier the better. 'Caius likes his blue.'

It seems as though we are soon going be as familiar with Pawson's kitchen as we are with Nigella Lawson's. 'It's the focal point of the house,' he says. It's the place where the family eats together, where the boys might do their homework, where guests might socialise. It's where the family plays canasta. The first thing that sets the basement kitchen apart from most others is that it is divided into two sections - one indoors and one out. The two spaces are divided by a wall of glass, but the kitchen units - a long run of white, floor-based units - are built along the full length, 7 metres of them outside and 10 metres inside. The limestone floor is the same inside and out, but obviously discolours and weathers outside. And even the tables are the same. Like the floor, the one outside has turned dark from being exposed to the elements. Outside, there is a built-in barbecue. The boiler is kept in one of the outside units, too. It all makes for a strange symmetry.

Although it might look as cold on the inside as it is outside, the kitchen is a very comfortable place to be. 'You can't do good architecture unless you understand about living in it,' he says. The under-floor heating makes it warm, and the smell of coffee is inviting. I can hear a coffee machine spluttering away, but of course it is nowhere to be seen. Then Pawson opens one of the tall floor-to-ceiling cupboards on the opposite side to the floor units and, as if by magic, pulls out a simple white Wedgwood handle-less china cup half-filled with dark, thick espresso. It's like watching a TV chef - 'And here's one I prepared earlier.'

Just as many people have their fridge or dishwasher built into their kitchen units, John Pawson has everything, including the coffee machine and kettle, built in. 'I don't like gadgets,' he says. 'We all have too much stuff because of weddings and presents. You just accumulate things - the juice extractor, the ice-cream maker. You have to make a decision to limit them.'

The family has a toaster, but Dad prefers to make his toast under the grill. He is not a big cook. Catherine does the supermarket shopping (he says he is banned from going because he just buys armfuls of raspberries or cases of water, and she complains that he never checks the prices) and she does most of the cooking, too. 'Ben says I am quite good at toast,' he says.

The kitchen system itself was designed by Pawson in 1996 for the exclusive Belgian specialists, Obumex. Most of the units, made from very hard polyester with stainless steel trim, have drawers in them. Pawson opens a cupboard door (there are no knobs, or bars - just a handle built into the top of each door) and behind it is a series of drawers. Deep ones contain pots and pans, or glass storage jars filled with cooking ingredients. Others hold stacks of white china plates and bowls, or cups and mugs, which, like most people's, are reassuringly mismatched. Shallower ones are for cutlery.

'I haven't got round to doing the insides yet and organising. I've got this white rubber on the bottom because I don't really like divisions. I just like things lying there.' As it is, it's organised. Everything has its place. But it is by no means anally retentive. If Pawson had his way, however, he would have a whole bank of dishwashers so that they would act as storage as well as machines. 'It's crazy that you take a dish from the dishwasher to the cupboard and then to the table.' he says. He thinks you should simply unload dishes as you need them and put the dirties into the other machine ready to be washed.

With a kitchen as minimal as this, detail is everything. The sink, which is filled with the remains of Catherine's morning porridge dishes - 'She puts everything in the sink. There's a beautiful rubbish bin specially for rubbish, but she just puts it in the sink' - has a single, sweeping arc of a tap for 'elegant delivery of water'. The taps are underneath the work surface - two linear chunks of steel that are satisfying to hold and turn.

The same knobs are used for the customised gas cooker hob. Pawson replaced the original ones with his own. Even the door hinges are his design. Like all of the appliances, he prefers the Gaggenau oven to be behind closed doors because, although he says it is perfectly well designed and functional, he doesn't want to be reminded of the brand name every time he looks at it.

After spending an hour or so in the Pawson kitchen, it seems to me that minimal living does not require such a compromise after all. Take away the cupboard doors and there is as much 'stuff' as in any kitchen. All it needs is perhaps a little more time, a lot of storage, an organised mind, and a slightly more methodical approach to cooking, eating and washing up. Details are important. But ultimately, the kitchen is a space for living, working and playing. It is not a museum. And Pawson confesses that, when Catherine buys patterned kitchen roll at the supermarket, a bit of kitsch once in a while is probably good for him.

 The new Bulthaup showroom opens at North Terrace, Alexander Square, London SW3, on 1 February 2001 (020 7495 3663). For information on John Pawson's kitchen system for Obumex, contact 00 32 51 705 071.
