webTitle: Rights we all have earned

fields.headline: Rights we all have earned
fields.trailText: It is 52 years since the United Nations signed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (on 10 December 1948). Now we need some clear, positive statements about fundamentals that are of direct relevance to each and every one of us.
fields.body:
It is 52 years since the United Nations signed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (on 10 December 1948). This year has been particularly significant because for the first time since 1688, a rights-based framework has passed on to the British statute book. Now we need some clear, positive statements about fundamentals that are of direct relevance to each and every one of us.

How many British people even know they have human rights? Human rights are often seen as something that happens to other people. The image of an Amnesty International prisoner of conscience comes to mind. This represents an important facet of human rights, but it does not touch the everyday lives of most British people.

While our country is rightly proud of the individual civil and political freedoms it can offer, we hear very little about the economic, social and cultural rights that are an equal part of the Universal Declaration. Issues such as health, education and housing are not easily seen by British people as human rights issues at all, but rather as facets of the welfare state or acts of charity. We will hear a lot about the National Health Service in the media this winter, but will anyone refer to our 'right' to health? The quality of our children's education is also a 'right' for their future development and should not be a product of their local environment, parent's income or élite schooling for the few.

A 'rights-based' culture will bring about slow but fundamental changes in how we view our lives and what we expect from government. We would already be well ahead in this area, if the United States (our role-model in many ways) had signed and ratified enough international human rights law, which it has not. While economic, social and cultural rights are regarded as 'socialism through the back door' by many opinion leaders in the USA and not as the universal human rights which they are, millions will remain excluded from even basic health care. To effect a change here we need to look across the channel, not the Atlantic.

The British Human Rights Act came into law on 2 October and incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights; which is nothing to do with the European Union but everything to do with the Council of Europe - an older, more inclusive organisation. Most of the coverage given to this historic moment was negative - speed cameras, loony lawyers, bosses reading our emails. Try to see how the Human Rights Act might change our lives in the short-term and you resort to fringe issues and miss the point. As crazy cases are dismissed and real issues upheld by British judges, a rights-based culture will develop.

Yet the European Convention on Human Rights, despite its name, is mainly only concerned with civil and political rights and so is only two slices of the full human rights pizza set out in the Universal Declaration. For non-governmental organisations (NGOs) to be able to protect our economic, social and cultural rights, the UK Government needs to improve our access to Strasbourg under the European Social Charter (again a Council of Europe construct). Until the British Government signs and ratifies the Additional Protocol to the European Social Charter, we as British citizens do not enjoy this right.

The most important message today, International Human Rights Day, is that we should spread the word. The pre-amble to the Universal Declaration states that 'every organ of society shall strive by teaching and education to promote respect for these rights', and this is why The Body Shop will continue to be involved in this area through its Human Rights Award and international campaigns. Why, for instance, do so few of us stand up for asylum-seekers and refugees who are currently being denied some of their most basic rights in our country?

But most of all, this is why the British Government should set up an independent human rights commission to help educate us all about our rights and make sure we are living up to all our obligations.

webTitle: No future for an isolationist Britain

fields.headline: No future for an isolationist Britain
fields.standfirst:
Labour learnt the hard way that voters are less obsessed with sovereignty than are politicians

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Labour learnt the hard way that voters are less obsessed with sovereignty than are politicians
fields.body:
The temptation to be isolationist is always strong in the British political character. Exactly 100 years ago, the term 'splendid isolation' was coined to describe the foreign policy of a Great Britain then under Conservative rule.

Urged on by similar forces - a press that proclaims Anglo-Saxon supremacy and rejects engagement with Europe as threat to national identity - today's Tories are going down the same road.

A century ago, Conservative politicians picked quarrels with all of Britain's potential partners, even threatening to go to war with the United States over an obscure border dispute in South America.

Economic isolation followed political posturing when, in 1902, Conservative leader Joe Chamberlain launched his campaign for economic protectionism through a system of trade preferences within the British Empire.

Winston Churchill, then a rising young Tory star, left the Conservatives in horror, crossing the floor of the Commons to join the Liberal Party which fought against the isolationist political and economic forces.

The turn to isolation and imperial preference had the enthusiastic support of the Times and Daily Mail. Chamberlain and his supporters filled town halls every week. Yet to no avail. In the 1906 and subsequent elections the voters rejected the isolationist Tories and ushered in a long period of non-Conservative rule.

The lessons took a long time to sink in. In the Thirties, the Tories became even more isolationist. Stanley Baldwin and Neville Chamberlain kept well away from European politics, refusing to lift a finger to stop Hitler's annexation of the Rhineland or to send arms or men to defend democracy in Spain.

Neville Chamberlain, who had inherited his isolationist politics from his father, Joe, famously looked upon central Europe as 'a far-away place of which we know nothing'. Conservative Central Office even tried to secure the de-selection of Winston Churchill as an MP because of his warnings about the folly of disengagement from Europe.

The 40 years after 1945 saw a revolution in Tory thinking as successive Conservative Prime Ministers ditched the failed policy. Winston Churchill called for the creation of a 'United States of Europe' in 1946 and extended the reach of Nato so that for the first time in British history, sovereignty over defence was pooled with other countries.

Tory Ministers worked to strengthen free trade agreements, now under the umbrella of the World Trade Organisation, despite the central rle that trade has played in British history. In the era of 'splendid isolation' the Conservative Prime Minister, Lord Salisbury, had declared that only 'Teutonic races' were equipped to live under democracy, unlike the Irish and other 'Hottentots.'

Above all the Conservatives led us into Europe. The decision was never popular. Opinion polls in the early Eighties showed a clear majority for withdrawing from the European Community or seeking a semi-detached status. Margaret Thatcher ignored the polls and focus groups and in the 1983 election and afterwards took Britain deeper and deeper into Europe, surrendering British vetoes in dozens of key areas.

Francis Maude, today's Euro-hostile Shadow Foreign Secretary, signed the Maastricht Treaty and neither that contested treaty, the Single Europe Act, nor Britain's membership of the exchange rate mechanism damaged the Tories in the 1987 or 1992 elections.

Yet no one seems to have learned that iron political lesson of the twentieth century, which is that isolationism is not rewarded in the polling booths. In 1950, Denis Healey, then international secretary of the Labour Party, wrote a pamphlet explaining that Britain could not join the European Iron and Steel Community - forerunner to the European Union - because it would involve an unacceptable loss of national control over steel and energy. Hugh Gaitskell ranted against membership of the Common Market as involving a betrayal of 'a thousand years of British history'.

Peter Shore, according to Tony Benn's diaries, exploded in cabinet in 1978 when Ministers were shown the new European-style claret colour passport. Such a monstrosity would replace the blue paste-board passport over his dead body, he proclaimed. In the 1983 election, Labour wanted to pull out of Europe, a position that was maintained into the Nineties by senior Labour politicians and trade union leaders.

John Smith defied this disfiguring Euroscepticism and fought to pull the party away from isolationism. Along with Neil Kinnock and Tony Blair, he helped transform the party's attitude.

In 1997, Conservative newspaper adverts depicted Blair as a tiny puppet sitting on the knee of Chancellor Kohl. It did not prevent a Labour landslide. Instead of learning the obvious lesson, William Hague has become a latter-day champion of isolationism. It matters little what the European issue is. On the Euro, the Rapid Reaction Force and now the Treaty of Nice, the Conservative line is to say No.

History is said to repeat itself, first as tragedy then as farce. In the case of the politics of isolationism, history in our country simply repeats itself, period. The Conservatives have become a single-issue party obsessed with saying No to Europe. As a Labour MP, I may welcome the electoral gains that come to Labour as the British people will always reject such politics.

But our nation's interests are not served by the obsessive press and political campaign against Europe. I long to see a young Tory John Smith who will stand up in the Conservative Party for common sense on Europe.

Isolationist anti-Europeanism is dead-end politics. Labour learnt that lesson the hard way. Can William Hague or Michael Portillo?

Denis MacShane is MP for Rotherham.

In the 1906 and subsequent elections the voters rejected the isolationist Tories and ushered in a long period of non-Conservative rule. The lessons took a long time to sink in. In the Thirties, the Tories became even more isolationist. Stanley Baldwin and Neville Chamberlain kept well away from European politics, refusing to lift a finger to stop Hitler's annexation of the Rhineland or to send arms or men to defend democracy in Spain. Neville Chamberlain, who had inherited his isolationist politics from his father, Joe, famously looked upon central Europe as 'a far-away place of which we know nothing'. Conservative Central Office even tried to secure the de-selection of Winston Churchill as an MP because of his warnings about the folly of disengagement from Europe. The 40 years after 1945 saw a revolution in Tory thinking as successive Conservative Prime Ministers ditched the failed policy. Winston Churchill called for the creation of a 'United States of Europe' in 1946 and extended the reach of Nato so that for the first time in British history, sovereignty over defence was pooled with other countries. Tory Ministers worked to strengthen free trade agreements, now under the umbrella of the World Trade Organisation, despite the central rle that trade has played in British history. In the era of 'splendid isolation' the Conservative Prime Minister, Lord Salisbury, had declared that only 'Teutonic races' were equipped to live under democracy, unlike the Irish and other 'Hottentots.' Above all the Conservatives led us into Europe. The decision was never popular. Opinion polls in the early Eighties showed a clear majority for withdrawing from the European Community or seeking a semi-detached status. Margaret Thatcher ignored the polls and focus groups and in the 1983 election and afterwards took Britain deeper and deeper into Europe, surrendering British vetoes in dozens of key areas. Francis Maude, today's Euro-hostile Shadow Foreign Secretary, signed the Maastricht Treaty and neither that contested treaty, the Single Europe Act, nor Britain's membership of the exchange rate mechanism damaged the Tories in the 1987 or 1992 elections. Yet no one seems to have learned that iron political lesson of the twentieth century, which is that isolationism is not rewarded in the polling booths. In 1950, Denis Healey, then international secretary of the Labour Party, wrote a pamphlet explaining that Britain could not join the European Iron and Steel Community - forerunner to the European Union - because it would involve an unacceptable loss of national control over steel and energy. Hugh Gaitskell ranted against membership of the Common Market as involving a betrayal of 'a thousand years of British history'. Peter Shore, according to Tony Benn's diaries, exploded in cabinet in 1978 when Ministers were shown the new European-style claret colour passport. Such a monstrosity would replace the blue paste-board passport over his dead body, he proclaimed. In the 1983 election, Labour wanted to pull out of Europe, a position that was maintained into the Nineties by senior Labour politicians and trade union leaders. John Smith defied this disfiguring Euroscepticism and fought to pull the party away from isolationism. Along with Neil Kinnock and Tony Blair, he helped transform the party's attitude. In 1997, Conservative newspaper adverts depicted Blair as a tiny puppet sitting on the knee of Chancellor Kohl. It did not prevent a Labour landslide. Instead of learning the obvious lesson, William Hague has become a latter-day champion of isolationism. It matters little what the European issue is. On the Euro, the Rapid Reaction Force and now the Treaty of Nice, the Conservative line is to say No. History is said to repeat itself, first as tragedy then as farce. In the case of the politics of isolationism, history in our country simply repeats itself, period. The Conservatives have become a single-issue party obsessed with saying No to Europe. As a Labour MP, I may welcome the electoral gains that come to Labour as the British people will always reject such politics. But our nation's interests are not served by the obsessive press and political campaign against Europe. I long to see a young Tory John Smith who will stand up in the Conservative Party for common sense on Europe. Isolationist anti-Europeanism is dead-end politics. Labour learnt that lesson the hard way. Can William Hague or Michael Portillo? Denis MacShane is MP for Rotherham.

webTitle: Bread sauce

fields.headline: Bread sauce
fields.standfirst: Sourdough is the sexiest new item on the baking scene, says Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: Sourdough is the sexiest new item on the baking scene, says Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
'Food is the new sex and bread is its lingerie,' confides Wendy Leighton, as we watch Prince Charles inspecting the ovens at her new bakery, La Fornaia, in north London. 'It's the foreplay for the whole meal.'

HRH, meanwhile, is heading towards the packing lines where rustic-looking loaves of Duchy Originals ready-to-bake Organic Mild Sourdough are being slipped into their inflated pillow packets. Officially, he is here to open the new bakery. Unofficially, it is an opportunity to highlight this new addition to the Duchy Original portfolio and thus benefit his charitable foundation, which is partially funded by its profits.

As well as being executive director of La Fornaia, the versatile Mrs Leighton is also responsible for introducing Marks & Spencer to bikini briefs and strings (even briefer briefs), so who better to quiz her on the next fashionable bread? 'Oh, sourdough,' she exclaims, 'it's on every New York restaurant table. The only question is whether we are ready for it.'

Clearly, Duchy Originals thinks we are. Its new bread, developed by La Fornaia, is a deliciously mild, wheaty sourdough, with just a hint of rye. Traditionally, sourdough is made with a leaven of flour and water in which wild yeasts have been encouraged to grow. It can take several days to ferment and is notoriously temperamental. Most modern bakers use a yeast starter mixed with flour and water to ensure a reliable fermentation. Duchy Original's confidence in selling this relatively unfamiliar bread in Britain lies, I suspect, in its having turned it into a ready-to-bake product. The naturally damp texture of an organic sourdough is perfectly adapted to being rebaked without the need for any additives. Thus, after 10 minutes in the oven, you have a gorgeous, chewy bread with a good crust rather than the usual overly-crisp, dry specimen. Amazingly, it actually tastes home-made.

As the Prince of Wales disappears through the loading bay, still dressed in his baker's hat and white coat, I wonder whether he ever indulges in a slice or two at home. An aide informs me that his chef makes everything from scratch at Highgrove. A pity, as he is missing out on some scrummy bread, that is just heavenly smothered in butter and honey.

 Duchy Originals Organic Mild Sourdough costs £1.10 and is available from Sainsbury's and Tesco's.

webTitle: Health: Accidental heroes

fields.headline: Accidental heroes
fields.standfirst: Serendipity has played a role in shaping modern medicine. Jo Carlowe reviews some lucky breaks
fields.trailText: Serendipity has played a role in shaping modern medicine. Jo Carlowe reviews some lucky breaks.
fields.body:
In the last week, HIV patients currently bound to a relentless regime of therapeutic drug taking have received some hopeful news. A trial in the US carried out on monkeys has revealed that taking regular breaks from medication may be more beneficial than slavishly following a course of combination drug therapy.

The theory is that by stopping the drugs at set intervals, the body's own immune system is primed to control the virus by itself, eventually enabling the patient to cease treatment for months on end. Similar studies are now taking place on humans.

But on the face of it, it all seems so unfeasible. Surely stopping daily doses of antiviral drugs - long proven to suppress virus growth - would be more harmful than helpful?

How then did scientists dream up so improbable a theory? The answer, it turns out, lies not so much with good acumen than with good fortune. Like so many medical discoveries before it, this breakthrough was made by pure serendipity.

It all happened when a German man, known in the world of Aids research as 'the Berlin patient', went against doctor's orders and temporarily stopped his triple combination drug treatment. In fact, he stopped and started his treatment several times before eventually ceasing the drugs for good. To the astonishment of his physicians, the virus has remained undetectable in his bloodstream ever since.

His haphazard approach to treatment thus sparked the current spate of trials.

Of course, such serendipitous leaps forward have happened before. One of the most shocking examples occurred in 1847 when a man named Phineas Gage accidentally lobotomised himself.

He was working on the American railroad blasting rocks when an explosion sent an iron bar through the front of his skull. Miraculously, he survived but his personality changed profoundly.

Unwittingly, he had become the first man to undergo a frontal lobotomy, allowing scientists to make a connection between aggression and the brain's frontal lobes.

'For the first time, scientists were able to relate pathological behaviour to what was going on in the brain,' explains Tilli Tansey, historian of modern medical science at the Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine. She is a great advocate of 'blue-sky' research - the term given to curiosity driven investigations which often have their origins in the accidental, unexplained or unexpected. She claims that some of medicine's most ground-breaking advances have occurred in this way.

Take the case of the South African doctors who stumbled across a potential treatment for the deadly Ebola virus which recently killed over 100 people in Uganda. The disease is fatal in almost 90 per cent of cases, and yet in 1997 a patient managed to beat the condition after receiving the 'wrong' medication.

The man had arrived in South Africa seeking treatment for his 'chronic gastritis' and doctors, unaware that he was actually suffering from Ebola, put him on steroids.

Amazingly, he responded so positively that he was well enough to return home. Details of the patient's case were passed to American researchers and tests are now taking place to see if steroid treatment can be used to combat Ebola.

Viagra, dubbed the miracle cure for impotence, is another accidental triumph. Scientists may like to think they discovered the so-called 'love pill' through years of painstaking research but Viagra actually began life as a rather disappointing angina treatment.

It was the drug's unexpectedly pleasant side-effects that put a smile on its patients' faces.

Patients were refusing to come off Viagra even after surgery had successfully dealt with their angina, prompting medics to investigate further.

Although Viagra's profitable side-effects were discovered by accident, as Louis Pasteur pointed out: 'Chance favours only the prepared mind.' In the 1960s, psychiatrists came across an anti-depressant which, like Viagra, unexpectedly helped correct erectile dysfunction. Rather prudishly they decided to bury their findings - no doubt missing out on a fortune.

'Serendipitous observations really do only get made by the prepared mind. A lot of us miss things because we only follow our noses,' says immunologist and transplant physician Professor Robert Lechler of Imperial College London.

He notes that in the last 50 years so much emphasis has been placed on having set goals that researchers can rarely attract funds for more unconventional theories.

'It is a shame. There needs to be flexibility in the system to allow for doing slightly batty things. Sometimes, important observations come out of high-risk strategies.'

It was the potential for profit that prompted one drug company to take a closer look at an anti-depressant called Wellbutrin.

During trials of the drug, and quite by chance, it was realised that smokers taking Wellbutrin were not craving cigarettes as they normally did. The result was 'Zyban' - which is basically the same drug marketed as a smoking- cessation treatment and launched on the NHS in June.

Unfortunately, not all drugs have had such welcome side-effects. In the 50s, Thalidomide became notorious for causing birth defects. It was subsequently banned. But the black cloud cast by Thalidomide may have an unexpected silver-lining. Had it not had such devastating contraindications, scientists would not be looking at it today as a potential cure for cancer.

Thalidomide caused birth defects because it blocked the growth of new blood vessels needed to form the limbs and organs of the unborn baby. Tumours also only thrive when new blood vessels supply them with nutrients and oxygen. So scientists have put two and two together and believe Thalidomide could be used to starve cancer of its food supply. Clinical trials are now taking place in America.

The side-effects of drugs have long provided scientists with this sort of inspiration. A similar phenomenon occurred in 1952 when Parisian surgeon Henri Laborit noticed how calm his pre-operative patients became when given the antihistamine Chlorpromazine. Patients who had previously been anxious about their forthcoming operations suddenly seemed not to care.

Laborit was quick to realise that the drug could have some use in psychiatry and persuaded a psychiatrist colleague to test it on disturbed patients. The results were astounding - violent patients could be left without supervision and those who had been virtually catatonic were able to hold conversations. The drug became one of the first anti-psychotic treatments for schizophrenia. Most notably it ended the barbarism of lobotomy - Phineas's legacy.

Drug therapies also became an alternative to electroconvulsive shock therapy (ECT) yet another medical practice discovered in the least scientific of ways. Italian neurologist Ugo Cerletti dreamed up the idea after watching how calm pigs became after being electronically stunned by abattoir workers. In the late 30s, he developed an apparatus to pass a current of electricity through the forehead of patients, to relieve the symptoms of mental disorders such as depression. There is some evidence that the procedure impairs short-term memory but it is still used where depression is thought to be life-threatening.

Chance has played a part in many medical discoveries, but in all these cases the key to their advancement has been with scientists enlightened enough to recognise the potential of blunders and unexpected side-effects.

The scientists who created Dolly the sheep were quick to capitalise when their experiments into genetically modifying animals yielded information beyond their wildest dreams. The researchers at the Edinburgh-based Roslin Institute had started out with the modest intention of finding a better way to produce proteins from milk. It was as a by-product of cloning and re-programming cells in animals that they came away with a wealth of information about how embryonic stem cells - the body's 'master cells' - could be used to take over the work of damaged tissue and organs in humans.

'The original object of Dolly was to find better ways of genetically modifying animals. The current interest in therapeutic cloning was something that only came up later,' admits Dr Harry Griffin, assistant director of the Roslin Institute.

Since Dolly's creation, a number of expert centres have begun studying therapeutic cloning. In the future, stem cell therapy in humans may end the misery of Parkinson's disease, coronary heart disease, strokes, diabetes and other degenerative effects of ageing.

Tilli Tansey, of the Wellcome Trust, believes the history of medicine has more than demonstrated the value of serendipity. In recognition of this, the trust now runs an annual award to encourage innovative 'blue-sky' research. 'Science is easily as creative as the arts. It is a dynamic, kinetic activity dependent on a synthesis of old, new, completed and random ideas.'

Professor Peter Lachmann, President of the Academy of Medical Sciences, agrees. He urges scientists to be alive to ideas which stem from unorthodox roots. 'Discoveries through serendipity are of equal worth to those set out in a hypothesis,' he says.

The public obviously agrees - in September 'serendipity' was voted the UK's favourite word.

Breakthrough blunders

A bizarre example of a breakthrough by blunder is the tale of baby Kristin Gillespie. In 1989, Kristin was born prematurely at only 23 weeks. The doctors thought she was dead and the body was taken outside the ward, where it lay for several hours, ready for the morgue.

Eventually, a nurse came to remove the body but noticed that the baby was breathing. Kristin was alive without the help of an incubator, although her temperature was so low that she was hypothermic.

The medics gave her a 5 per cent chance of survival. They said that even if she did pull through her brain had been so starved of oxygen that she would be severely mentally impaired.

But Kristin developed into a bright, active and totally normal child. And her miraculous recovery has been put down to the hypothermia that ensued after she was left in the cold corridor. It was this that reduced her need for oxygen and protected her from brain damage.

In the past, it had been accepted practice to keep babies warm after birth. Now paediatricians were forced to accept the idea that maybe hypothermia could stop cell death leading to brain damage.

As a result of baby Kristin's near death experience, paediatricians at University College London have developed a 'cooling cap' to reduce the temperature around a baby's head. Their work is now part of an international trial which is already starting to show positive results.

webTitle: Kipper culture

fields.headline: Kipper culture
fields.standfirst: Put your taste buds on the line with the best of smoked fish
fields.trailText: Put your taste buds on the line with the best of smoked fish.
fields.body:
The strength of smoke for fish (indeed the whole philosophy) varies widely from one producer to another. At Inverawe Smokehouses, Taynuilt, Argyll (01866 822 446) they buy smaller farmed salmon because they believe the lower fat content makes them tastier than larger ones. Traditional methods prevail: the fish are dry salted, washed, smoked over oak logs for anything from 16 to 24 hours depending on conditions (which always vary, so craft skills and experience are required for accurate timing), and then hand-sliced. The result is a rich and freshly oaky taste in a huge range of formats from a 112g sliced pack (£5.95) via whole sides (£20.65) to trimmings (for quiches), as well as gravadlax, smoked trout, eel (200g for £13.25) and halibut, plus a whole slew of pre-packed hampers. Prices include delivery.

Knipoch Smokehouse, by Oban, Argyll (01852 316 251) on the other hand believes that large salmon typically weighing 6kg to 7kg produce the best quality. Its robust approach involves a dry salt cure strengthened with sugar, whisky, juniper and rowan berries, plus a lengthy two- to three-day smoke. The fish comes out so black it has to be washed and trimmed to look presentable, and the taste is unusual: strong, sweet, sharp and almondy. A whole side costs £45, but it will cut any size to order: sliced at £17.60 per 500g, unsliced at £15.95. Add postage on a sliding scale.

Over in Wales, Vin Sullivan, 4 Frogmore Street, Abergavenny (01873 856 989) serves Menai oysters at 70p each to eat in or take-away, as well as smoked salmon and gravadlax. It's the first to appreciate the irony of seeing locally caught eels exported to Holland for smoking (the Dutch are considered experts), and then re-imported, where they sell at £4.50 for a 150g eel.

Michael Brown at Brown & Forrest, Bowdens Farm, Hambridge, Somerset (01458 250 875) smokes his own eels, having learned the skill in Germany. Autumn is the time when fat adult eels, gorged with food ready for their trans-Atlantic voyage to the Sargasso Sea, launch themselves down the Test, Avon, Itchen and other chalk streams. An eel rack, looking like a toothcomb, is bedded into the river to catch them, and the wriggling silver bodies are then flicked into a box. After brining they are cooked over beech and apple logs for about two hours, to render them succulent, then the fire is 'throttled' to emit more smoke, which produces the flavour. Whole eels weighing between 450g (£10) and 900g (£20) are vacuum packed into long tubes, and will last up to three weeks in the refrigerator. Skinned and filleted eels are sold in 113g (£5.50) and 227g (£10) packs; all prices include p&p.

Smoked haddock may not have quite the cachet of salmon, but Rick Stein (in his Seafood Lovers' Guide ) is prepared to consider Arbroath smokies in the same breath as caviar. Bill Spink of M&M Spink, 10 Marketgate, Arbroath (01241 875 287), who featured in the round Britain odyssey, smokes fish he buys from Aberdeen and Peterhead. Pairs are tied on poles and hung over hardwood fire pits for around half an hour to cook in the hot smoke, then sold at around £2.30 per lb. Buy half a stone (about six pairs) vacuum packed for £14, and add £6.30 postage.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

The fish comes out so black it has to be washed and trimmed to look presentable, and the taste is unusual: strong, sweet, sharp and almondy. A whole side costs £45, but it will cut any size to order: sliced at £17.60 per 500g, unsliced at £15.95. Add postage on a sliding scale. Over in Wales, Vin Sullivan, 4 Frogmore Street, Abergavenny (01873 856 989) serves Menai oysters at 70p each to eat in or take-away, as well as smoked salmon and gravadlax. It's the first to appreciate the irony of seeing locally caught eels exported to Holland for smoking (the Dutch are considered experts), and then re-imported, where they sell at £4.50 for a 150g eel. Michael Brown at Brown & Forrest, Bowdens Farm, Hambridge, Somerset (01458 250 875) smokes his own eels, having learned the skill in Germany. Autumn is the time when fat adult eels, gorged with food ready for their trans-Atlantic voyage to the Sargasso Sea, launch themselves down the Test, Avon, Itchen and other chalk streams. An eel rack, looking like a toothcomb, is bedded into the river to catch them, and the wriggling silver bodies are then flicked into a box. After brining they are cooked over beech and apple logs for about two hours, to render them succulent, then the fire is 'throttled' to emit more smoke, which produces the flavour. Whole eels weighing between 450g (£10) and 900g (£20) are vacuum packed into long tubes, and will last up to three weeks in the refrigerator. Skinned and filleted eels are sold in 113g (£5.50) and 227g (£10) packs; all prices include p&p. Smoked haddock may not have quite the cachet of salmon, but Rick Stein (in his Seafood Lovers' Guide ) is prepared to consider Arbroath smokies in the same breath as caviar. Bill Spink of M&M Spink, 10 Marketgate, Arbroath (01241 875 287), who featured in the round Britain odyssey, smokes fish he buys from Aberdeen and Peterhead. Pairs are tied on poles and hung over hardwood fire pits for around half an hour to cook in the hot smoke, then sold at around £2.30 per lb. Buy half a stone (about six pairs) vacuum packed for £14, and add £6.30 postage.  Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: surviving the Christmas party season, coping with fibocystic breasts, and pain-free footballing
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: surviving the Christmas party season, coping with fibocystic breasts, and pain-free footballing.
fields.body:
The time for officially letting your hair down is here again so it might be timely to examine the procedures involved in deriving optimum enjoyment from the party round.

The expression itself implies the loosening of one's bun - or other such constrictions of one's coiffeur - in order to facilitate some sort of catharsis of the wild spirit within. This is usually expressed with the help of alcohol or other mind-bending substances on the dance floor or in broom cupboards at office parties, often followed by bouts of self-recrimination and feigned amnesia the following morning.

It is no coincidence that the expression relates to the head, for according to those old Taoist party animals of bygone eras, the acupuncture points that trigger a release of self-control and inhibition are located at the base of the skull along the gall bladder meridian, that organ being ascribed the function of keeping everything about a person's act in shipshape order. It is interesting also to note that the gall bladder as part of the liver complex is the organ most affected by alcohol and drugs.

So would it follow that by manually unblocking the flow of energy in the meridian through the points at the rear of the skull, you'd be able to slough off your inhibitions and awkwardness and thus have a properly enjoyable knees-up at this season's social gatherings without recourse to hammering yourself with booze or drugs? Yes, partly. But you'll also have to attend to the psycho-emotional mind-set, if you wish to party to your full potential with little or no artificial help and thus preclude the possibility of saying or doing things you may regret in the sober light of day.

The kind of excessive self-control causing inhibition, often appropriate for the working environment, is patently inappropriate for party time. It makes you appear wooden, wood being the element associated with the gall bladder, by the way, and as you know, it's not easy to let go and have a good time when you feel like a plank.

If you're interested in attempting a substance-lite bun release, begin immediately, as the effects take some days to build up in the system. Place your thumbs at the points at the base of the skull where the trapezius muscles meet the bone in two ridges, one either side of the spine. Keeping your arms and shoulders relaxed, gently press in, under and upwards towards the centre of the brain, until you feel the muscle tissues soften and give a little. Now whatever position you find yourself in, try and hold yourself completely rigid, making no movement whatsoever. You will quickly notice that this is all but impossible and that from somewhere deep inside comes an urge to make movement. Now, instead of succumbing to that urge, maintain stillness of the outer shell while allowing movement to be instigated within the skin - micro-movement, in other words.

To explore this fully requires a time and place where you won't be disturbed and a willingness to bypass habitual internal chatter to enable your awareness to focus within. Once you have located and followed it for a moment or two, this micro-movement becomes amplified until it feels like a full-blown belly dance occuring within your skin. At the point when the dance feels too vibrant to contain, allow it to take over your physical form altogether until you find yourself dancing round the room with gay abandon. Not only will regular practice of this derigidifying technique benefit your circulation, calm your mind, engender cheerfulness and positivity and make you more supple, but it will also help you enjoy yourself far more when you actually do go out dancing, an activity which must come near the top of the list for helping maintain elasticity and youthfuless of mind, body and spirit.

To lock the benefits of this exercise into real-time party situations, some psycho-emotional reframing is also necessary. As with all healings - for freeing one's inhibitions surely constitutes a healing - there are two primary tools which must always be utilised: breathing and self-acceptance. So when you walk into the party feeling awkward and shy, pay attention to not holding your breath, enabling it to flow in and out freely, and rather than fighting off or denying the shyness, accept it. Simply remind yourself over and over, 'It's perfectly natural and OK for me to feel shy and awkward.' Because it is. In fact, shyness and awkwardness, when one is open and accepting about it, can be quite fetching. Thom York, for example, has made a career from it. So be shy, but be proud to be shy. Don't be ashamed of it or yourself. If you find it hard to make conversation without being drunk and filled with false bonhomie, try asking people about themselves and their lives - they'll always be glad of the opportunity to talk about themselves.

Finally, try a little auto-suggestion by telling yourself enough times for it to penetrate your unconscious, 'When I display my vulnerability with dignity, people find me irresistible, which makes it a doddle for me to let my hair down every time!'

If you find that all falls short of the season's mark, remember to take milk thistle complex before and after the party to help support the liver, and drink a glass of mineral water with half a freshly squeezed lemon to cool down your gall bladder.

Your letters

Dear Barefoot, 10 days before my period, my breasts become swollen and painful. The doctors have told me it's fibrocystic. I also become irritable and moody. Have you any advice?
Anne Smallfield, Angmering, West Sussex

Dear Anne, Cut out all caffeine, including colas, sugar and chocolate, after every ovulation, as these are known to aggravate fibrocystic breast disease, which is obviously coming and going with your period. Take 400mgs of vitamin E daily and Evening Primrose Oil, as these are known to help break up cystic tissue. I also recommend daily dry skin brushing of the whole body to encourage lymphatic drainage, or visit a lymphatic drainage masseur. Additionally, massage your breasts in a circular motion up the outsides and down the cleavage 30 times a day and avoid wearing wire bras.

Dear Barefoot, I play football once a week. Recently I've started aching all over my body for three days after each game. What's causing this and is there anything I can do about it?
Geoffry Miller, Lincoln

Dear Geoffry, This is happening because you only play once a week. This causes a build up of lactic acid. So start by playing twice a week instead. Be sure to stretch thoroughly after each game and soak in an Epsom salts bath which will alleviate the muscular spasm and draw out the toxins. Take up yoga on a regular basis, as yoga is surely the mother of all exercise and is the most efficient way of maintaining all-over flexibility no matter what sport you play.

 Barefoot Doctor is author of 'Handbook for the Urban Warrior' and teaches Taoism, meditation, Chinese medicine and t'ai chi. He has been in practice for more than 20 years, specialising in personal-crisis management. If you have any problems you would like answered, please write to Barefoot Doctor at Life magazine, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or email him at barefoot.doctor@observer.co.uk. Also, you can visit www.barefootdoctorglobal.com.

webTitle: Happy talk

fields.headline: Happy talk
fields.standfirst: Three people talk about the different ways in which they have combatted stress and depression
fields.trailText: Three people talk about the different ways in which they have combatted stress and depression.
fields.body:
Lorraine Tapper, social worker, 45

There wasn't anything specific that made me go into therapy, my whole life just didn't seem to be working out. It was a combination of factors: career, money, bad relationships. Being unhappy was a dominant theme for me. I really wasn't enjoying my life and it probably was pretty miserable for people to be around me. I was shy, afraid, angry and resentful - all these things that I just didn't want to be. Then I saw an ad for a one-day self-development course run by Christene Burgess who works from London's Ability Centre.

The self-esteem course helped me see I could do things differently, so I decided to have one-to-one therapy. It took a while to work because I was still very resistant. I'd had a lot of years of being scared and sad, and there wasn't going to be an immediate solution. I'd been in therapy for about a year and a half when a friend recommended the Life Training programme in Belsize Park. I did one of the weekend workshops and it was a real eye-opener. We did a lot of partnership work in a variety of situations - on the course they teach you that people are your mirrors - they give you feedback and that, in turn, gives you opportunity for growth.

One of the biggest things I learnt was how to deal with resentment. My father had been dead for 22 years and I was still angry with him for being strict with me as a child. One of the processes they teach you is how by holding that resentment, it affects your life and not the life of the person you're holding that resentment for. Knowing my part in my unhappiness meant that I could choose to be different.

I used to be angry all the time, rigid - I was always right, everyone was always wrong. Before, I wouldn't let people see me upset, sad or vulnerable, now I realise the strength in having all my emotions. A few months ago a male client came into the office ranting and raving. At one time I'd have been defensive and stressed by the situation. Now I was able to see in front of me a man who was very hurt, very scared and frightened. I let him say what he had to say, and he really calmed down.

I'm now developing my own business as a personal life coach. Before I'd only be happy if I'd got the right job, the right boyfriend. Now I'm just happy because I'm alive. I've found my sense of self and become a rounded person who makes a contribution to the world, whether it's through work, relationships or my teaching. And I've discovered that real happiness isn't attached to external things, it's an internal way of being.

Max Mezzowave, composer, 34

At 24, I was a complete stress victim. I worked as a courier, driving around London in the rush hour. I was very aggressive. I also used to go out drinking and partying every night. I was incredibly self-destructive and I'd rely on drink as an escape. I was in huge debt. I was almost in the gutter, living in bedsits and bumming around on people's floors. As a result, I wasn't very healthy either. In truth, I wasn't a desirable person. I was very depressed with myself, I felt I had an ability to do more with my life.

Luckily, someone came along at the right time to point me in the right direction. Ironically, it was a person I'd met in a bar. She told me about sahaja yoga and meditation. Sahaja yoga focuses on the Indian philosophy of the seven chakras in your body; you meditate while someone heals you. I started to see the benefits straightaway. It was the first time I'd felt relaxed in a while.

After five years, I moved on to the Chinese practice of Qi Gong. This is similar in that through movement and exercise, an instructor will give you the 'software' to channel your energy. When you reflect and expand on that, it's possible to become completely harmonised with your surroundings.

Both yoga and Qi Gong have benefited me in lots of ways; I'm much calmer and more at peace with myself. I've started to understand what I'm about as a person, that whatever your actions give out, they affect other people and if you do or say something aggressive, it has a way of coming back. But when you become more positive, you feel more balanced, more open to people, more understanding of others and you see their value. I suppose I've just accepted how I am. Of course there are days when you feel shit, but if you accept it and have the faith that it's going to get better, then it starts to change.

It's been magical really, and comes through when I'm composing, so it's helped my music career. The healing part of Qi Gong also gives me great satisfaction, I do one-to-one teaching but I now want to push the practice out to a wider audience. I'm working on a project so that people can benefit from Qi Gong through the internet (www.mezzowave.com), video and live performance. I know this may open me to cynics, but I see it as a test. Now I'm just enjoying what I have and living in the moment. I've got a good message to give to other people, that of happiness and goodwill - it's just up to them to accept it.

Faith Buck, artist, 29

I spent three years in college studying graphic design. I thought this would be the best route to a creative career: I'd be a qualified graphic designer and somebody would employ me. But it didn't work out like that. After college I spent 18 months on the dole, then went through a variety of poorly paid, mundane jobs. I'd get ill frequently and it didn't help that I didn't get sick pay.

In May this year I went on a cycling holiday in Lefkada, Greece. It was a tremendously special place, really uplifting for the soul. I was telling everyone I was an artist, even though I wasn't drawing anything. It was then that I decided to rediscover my creativity. My main problem had been getting my artwork seen. I hadn't knocked on too many doors and the few times I had, it had been so discouraging.

I can't motivate myself; there has to be a reason for drawing a picture, so I set up the drawing room website (www.the-drawing-room.org.uk). All I wanted was ideas to unblock my creativity. I say to people, 'What do you want a picture of and I'll draw it?' I don't charge: I want the ideas to be free-flowing and I thought asking for money would put people off.

The site has made me feel purposeful, it's given me motivation and the recognition I craved as an artist. I used to doubt my abilities, but the positive responses I've had to my pictures have added to my self-esteem and confidence. It's gratifying when people turn round and say you've correctly interpreted how they feel. Or that you've added something to their perception of things.

One guy told me he'd broken up with his girlfriend and all that he had left was four walls and five picture hooks. So I drew him flattened on his bed, staring up at his ceiling, and he really liked it. The touchy-feely side of things is really nice, I quite like the idea of being a visual agony aunt.

The past six months have been really busy; the site averages 100 hits a day, and I draw a picture a day, as well as holding down a full-time job. It's something I get excitement from. It's drawn a lot of my friends in and it's given them something to respond to. If you're sitting there saying everything is crap, what can people give you back that's interesting? The ideal would be to turn what I do into a lucrative career. But I'm still happy because I'm working as an artist - I might not be getting paid, but I'm working and that's fulfilling.

webTitle: Happy?

fields.headline: Happy?
fields.standfirst: Drugs, therapy, self-help gurus... our craving for contentment has spawned a multi-million pound 'happiness' industry. And yet many of us are still miserable. Psychologist Dorothy Rowe knows why - and here reveals how you too can be happy
fields.trailText: Drugs, therapy, self-help gurus... our craving for contentment has spawned a multi-million pound 'happiness' industry. And yet many of us are still miserable. Psychologist Dorothy Rowe knows why - and here reveals how you too can be happy
fields.body:
Am I happy? Why can't I be happy? Shouldn't I be happier than I am? These are questions that nowadays plague us. In past centuries, people worried about dying and whether they would go to heaven, but nobody worries about heaven any more; we want to be happy now. Until therapists came along and told us to talk about our feelings, people rarely talked about being happy or unhappy. In most of the years I have been alive - I was born in 1930 - most people were unhappy and many depressed, but they kept their feelings to themselves. Nowadays, a particular feature of the baby boomers and those younger is that they talk about happiness, and their lack of it, all the time.

We like to think that suffering ennobles us and gives us distinction, and so we like to think that previous generations had happier lives than we do. When Oliver James says, in Britain on the Couch, that in the 1950s people were happier than they are today, he is talking sentimental nonsense. The 50s were very tough and for many of us just plain horrible. I know, because I was there. I would much rather be in my twenties now than, as I was, in my twenties in the 50s.

In those years, women's magazines were devoted to instructing women how to make their husbands happy. There was no advice about how a woman could make herself happy, except by being a devoted wife and mother. Now magazines overflow with advice about how we can spend every moment of our lives achieving happiness. Unhappiness has become unacceptable. We often feel so overwhelmed by the endless bad news the media brings us that we turn away from any mention of misery. Moreover, we believe that if we are happy we will be seen as successful. Thus the word 'sad', which refers to the appropriate emotion to follow loss or disappointment, is used derogatively. 'He's a sad guy. He ought to get a life' is a major condemnation. Depression, once a state of mind of which to be ashamed, is less stigmatised, but it is discussed endlessly and described as a vast epidemic sweeping the planet, while the words 'depressed' and 'depression' are applied to any dysphoric feeling such as unhappiness, disappointment, lack of enthusiasm, even irritability.

Over the years that happiness and unhappiness emerged from the shadows and became major topics of discussion and anxiety, I had to deal with happiness and unhappiness in my personal life and in my professional life as a clinical psychologist. I became an expert in my own personal happiness, and, although I cannot tell you exactly how to go about being happy, I can certainly tell you how to stop yourself from being happy. And if you can practise not stopping yourself from being happy, there is a good chance that you will be happy.

I spent the first 40 years of my life being unhappy. There were bursts of happiness, usually associated with my son or with places I visited, but there was a leaden quality to my life, as if it were a permanent rainy day. I became happy very slowly, and did not realise that this was happening until one summer day in 1975, when I was walking across an ordinary stretch of grass. I looked down and saw little white daisies rising up from the grass, as if they were floating and dancing. I had been so busy establishing and then heading a new department of clinical psychology in Lincolnshire, I had not noticed that I was changing. The 1970s were what I now call the golden age of clinical psychology in the UK. Then we were not yet ground down by managers who cared about money but not people, and there was money available for us to study the new therapeutic techniques that were being developed and that changed us as much as they changed our clients.

My unhappiness must have started not long after I was born to a depressed mother. Recent research on the interaction between depressed mothers and their newborn babies shows that a baby is keenly aware when a mother does not respond in the way that the baby wants and needs. After repeated failures to attract the mother's attention, the baby gives up trying and becomes distressed.

This was the pattern not just of my babyhood but also my childhood. I loved my mother and wanted to gain her loving attention, but I could never please her. In no uncertain terms, she let me know that I was fat, ugly and lazy and that I irritated her with my cough. The fact that I had a lung disease, now diagnosed as bronchiectasis, which required me to cough in order to breathe, and which caused periods of intense physical weakness, passed her by. Unfortunately, there are many people like my mother who are so wrapped up in themselves that they are quite unable to give their children the unconditional love that all children need in order to keep that sense of being valuable and acceptable with which they are born. Like all small children deprived of unconditional love, I could explain my situation in only one way - there was something about me which was wrong, bad, unacceptable. The fault was in my essence and could not be eradicated.

Likewise, my friend Jack decided as a child, as many children do, that the disappointments, losses and betrayals he had suffered at the hands of adults were his own fault because he was not good enough. As an adult, he presented himself as cool and self-confident, but inside was a worm of self-doubt. However, he made life much harder for himself because he habitually thought in particular ways; he could never admit that he was wrong in anything, because doing that made him feel weak and vulnerable, yet at the same time he criticised himself harshly and endlessly. He was sure that he did not deserve to be successful and therefore happy. Like many people, Jack was a confirmed pessimist, believing that it is better to expect little and avoid the pain of disappointment. Moreover, he believed that worrying about something prevented it happening. He would complain to me that, with his success in his chosen field, he ought to be happy, but, as I would point out to him, thinking as he did, how could he be happy?

The turning point in my life came when the intellectual knowledge I had as a psychologist, that I actually could eradicate my self-doubt and instead value and accept myself, became knowledge of the heart and not just the head. A frequent theme in my books is why people refuse to let such knowledge into their hearts. If you have built your whole life on doubting your self-worth, then learning to value and accept yourself will change everything - how you think, how you get on with people, the choices you make. Change creates uncertainty, and uncertainty creates fear. Frightened of change, many people choose to stay with the devil they know, and so they remain unhappy.

If you do decide to change, you have to set out on a journey that only you can make. There are no maps. Gurus like me can only tell you about their journey, and perhaps you might be helped by that. We can always learn from other people's stories. As a psychologist, I had the privilege of listening to many different stories, and, as I did, I learned a great deal about my clients, but I learned even more about myself. The question that fascinated me was not why my client had become depressed, or obsessional, or psychotic - as their story unfolded that was easy to see - but why I had not fallen into any of those dreaded states.

Many of my clients had had childhoods far worse than mine, but equally many had had childhoods little different from mine - my mother was by no means unique. During my first job in England, as I listened to these clients, I became aware that, despite similar upbringings, they often had ideas and responses that were profoundly different from mine. I wanted to research this.

Fortunately for me, a major shift in the way research in psychology is done was under way in the 1960s. Instead of having to study large groups of people, it was now becoming scientifically respectable to study individuals, which was what I wanted to do. Also, one of my colleagues, Don Bannister, had just come back from the USA with a new psychological theory and research method - George Kelly's Personal Construct Theory and repertory grids - which I could use. For 10 years, I did academic research and wrote academic papers, but burying my results in academic journals helped no one. I began to write books that everyone could read.

George Kelly had not discovered something new but had simply repackaged what the ancient Greek philosopher Epictetus had said, 'It is not things in themselves that trouble us but our opinion of things.' It is not what happens to you that leads you to be happy or unhappy, but rather how you interpret what happens to you. It was my interpretation of what had happened to me that led to my being a psychologist and not to being a patient in a psychiatric clinic. As a small child, I realised that, if I were to survive, I had to discover why my mother behaved as she did. I did not hear the word 'psychologist' until I was 15, but I had been one all those years.

I certainly had not heard of Epictetus, but I did know what Epictetus knew. I could easily see that, whatever occurred, my mother would interpret it pessimistically, my father optimistically, while I had my own interpretation, and my sister had hers. How we interpreted an event determined what each of us did next. I was very fortunate, in that my parents' example didn't teach me that there is only one way to interpret events. This can result in growing up to believe that the world is only as we see it, and when we are too fixed as a person in this way, we soon get into difficulties, because events keep disconfirming our expectations. If you want to be very unhappy, spend your life insisting that you are right and everyone else is wrong.

When we are forced by circumstances to live and work in ways that bring us little joy, we need to protect ourselves against a sense of unending misery by putting into every day some little activity which we enjoy. If we can concentrate on carrying out that activity and not think about matters outside of what we are doing, we create the circumstances where happiness can arise. As a child, I would go for a swim, and I knew that if I concentrated on the shape of the next wave and how I would catch it, I forgot about the miseries of home and school and I would feel happy. Later, as a psychologist, I came to see that happiness is an emotion like all other emotions - a by-product of an experience. We cannot will an emotion into being. You can be angry only when you are angry. You can be happy only when you are happy.

And happiness, like other emotions, comes in different strengths - from mild contentment to ecstatic joy. Instead of enjoying whatever strength of happiness they feel, though, some people destroy this feeling by worrying that they ought to be happier. They forget that we cannot physically sustain any strong emotion for any length of time, and that a lasting sense of mild contentment makes life so much easier. Equally, whenever we get angry or frightened, or hate someone, or feel shame or guilt, it is extremely important to ask ourselves whether the strength of the emotion we feel is an appropriate response to what has happened. Getting wildly angry over something you would ordinarily find mildly irritating shows that there is something amiss in your life.

Many people are confused about unhappiness. How much should they bear? When does it become unhealthy? Unhappiness, like happiness, is an emotion, and it arises from how we interpret an event. Often people will seek to shame us for being insufficiently distressed - as my cat-loving friend often seeks to do to me when a moggy dies - and at the same time people will criticise us for not getting over a disaster quickly enough. Fearing unhappiness, many people fail to recognise that there are losses that we can never get over completely, even though the pain might lessen with time. These are losses for which there can be no replacement or recompense, and to which unhappiness is an entirely rational response. We can replace a television set or even a flooded house, but we cannot replace someone we love who has died.

I have heard a professor of psychiatry declare that the appropriate length of time to mourn one's parents is two years. Any longer, and mourning is the symptom of depression known as 'irrational grief'. So much nonsense is talked about depression that it is no wonder that people get confused about what is unhappiness and what is depression. Yet the two states are very distinct. In our society, it is easy to become depressed because our culture teaches us that to be good we have to accept responsibility for whatever goes wrong. Someone bumps into you in the street and you say, 'Sorry'. Through the incompetence of the managers, your firm goes bust, and you, a worker, feel that you are to blame. If you want to turn your unhappiness into depression, all that you have to do is to blame yourself for the disaster that has befallen you. You will know when you are depressed, because you will feel that you are utterly alone, locked in some kind of prison. When you are unhappy, no matter how great your suffering, other people can comfort you and you can comfort yourself, but when you are depressed you feel nothing of the comfort people give you, and you treat yourself as your own worst enemy.

Depression, unhappiness and happiness can be understood and dealt with only by understanding how we each interpret ourselves and our world. We create our own individual interpretations, and our interpretations determine what we do and feel. We cannot always change what is happening to us, but we are always free to change how we interpret what is happening to us.

People are able to be much happier now than they were when I was young, because we can know so much more now about ourselves, because we are prepared to discuss these matters among ourselves, sharing and changing our ideas. I was lucky enough to be able to do this, and slowly I found that the accompanying feeling to my life changed from unhappiness to happiness. I wish I could do this for every unhappy person, but it is something we each have to do for ourselves. If we want to, we can.

Towards a brighter future: Five steps to a happier life

It will help you be happy if you bear in mind the following:

1 Happiness is not a goal to be achieved, but an emotion that is a by-product of what you do.

2 Thinking in terms of whether you deserve or don't deserve to be happy will stop you being happy.

3 There is nothing wrong with feeling sad, which is the appropriate emotion to feel after you have suffered a loss or disappointment.

4 Depression is not just being very unhappy. We become depressed when we blame ourselves for the disaster that has befallen us. Being depressed means feeling that you are utterly alone, locked into some kind of horrible prison, where no comfort can reach you and you will not comfort yourself.

5 To create the conditions whereby happiness can blossom you have to do some or all of the following:

 Understand that what you do is a result of how you have interpreted what happens, and that you are free to change your interpretations.

 See yourself as valuable and acceptable. To do this, you may have to review your childhood and recognise that as a child you came to the conclusion that you must have been bad and unacceptable, otherwise the adults around you would not have treated you as they did. Look at this now from an adult's perspective.

 Listen to how you talk to yourself and, if you are constantly criticising yourself and making impossible demands on yourself, stop doing it. Be your own best friend.

 Cultivate the ability to live in the present, paying attention only to what is going on around you. By fretting about what has happened in the past and anxiously planning the future, we inevitably shut ourselves off from a great source of happiness - that of fully experiencing what is before us.

 Use the ability to be in the present by, every day, giving yourself some little treat or reward. Do not do this because you deserve it, but because it's a nice thing to do.

webTitle: The happiness quiz

fields.headline: The happiness quiz
fields.standfirst: How content are you?
fields.trailText: How content are you?
fields.body:
1 How would you describe the way your parents/carers brought you up?

a) Sometimes confrontational, but on the whole fair
b) Warm, loving and supportive
c) Emotionally cold, critical or abusive

2 How many days did you take off work this year because of illness?

a) 0-5
b) 5-10
c) 10-20

3 Which of the following most accurately describes your income and expenditure?

a) You are constantly in the red and despair of ever having enough money
b) You have more than enough to buy the basics, and can afford to buy yourself regular treats
c) You have to be careful with money, but are no worse off than anybody else

4 Thinking back to the last major traumatic event in your life (eg, divorce, failed relationship, job loss, death of a loved one), what did you do?

a) Get over it/are getting over it gradually, through introspection and the support of friends/family
b) Seek professional therapeutic help
c) Take a course of antidepressants or other medication to alleviate the distress

5. On the day you are due to go on holiday, your car breaks down and the railways are delayed. After a long, circuitous journey, you miss your plane. What do you do?

a) Sit in the airport bar and get smashed
b) Feel frustrated, but store up the saga to amuse your friends
c) Reflect that these things always happen to you

6 If you are currently engaged in a sexual relationship, how would you describe it?

a) a roller coaster ride, with many emotional highs and lows
b) sexually fulfilling, but socially problematic
c) settled, but with more emphasis on friendship than sex

7 How many times a day do you find yourself smiling or laughing?

a) once or twice
b) frequently
c) all the time

8 You apply for a more senior position in your company, but the post is advertised and filled by an outsider. What do you do?

a) Feel angry and decide to look for a similar position elsewhere
b) Comfort yourself with the thought that you would have hated the added responsibility anyway
c) Resolve to work harder and devote more time to your professional development

How to score:

1 a - 2, b - 3, c - 1 2 a - 3, b - 2, c - 1

3 a - 1, b - 3, c - 3 4 a - 3, b - 3, c - 1

5 a - 1, b - 3, c - 1 6 a - 2, b - 2, c - 3

7 a - 2, b - 3, c - 1 8 a - 3, b - 1, c - 2

Conclusions:

Score 9-13
Think carefully about your assumptions - it may be that some elements of your daily life are causing you to feel at odds with the world. With a little determination, you may be able to change some of those circumstances and/or your attitude towards them. Remember, for example, that being rich and feeling rich are not the same thing. If you often feel put upon by others, it may be your own self-esteem that needs boosting; don't be ashamed to talk things over with a counsellor.

Score 14-18
Apart from the odd blip, your life seems to chug along nicely, but there may be personal situations that you have yet to come to terms with. Burying the past and contriving for a smooth present won't help; part of life's challenge is the variety of emotions it throws up. Ask yourself why certain relationships are more appealing than others and then consider carefully their positive or negative impact on your life.

Score 19-24
You are either in denial about the problems that you have or are indeed a truly happy person. Freudian slips, repeated clumsiness or angry outbursts over trivial things can all be signs of the former. A sense of contentment, an abundance of love for friends and family and the ability to deal with life's slings and arrows and see the funny side of them are all signs of the latter. Life will never be perfect, but you could try to spread your happiness around a little - this will probably enhance your own.

webTitle: The perfect theatre

fields.headline: The perfect theatre
fields.standfirst: Sir Richard Eyre
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Eyre.
fields.body:
The perfect theatre should make you feel as if your presence has made a difference, which of course you don't feel when you stand in line at the cinema - the film will happen whether you're there or not. Going to the theatre, going to any live performance is an event, an occasion and the staff at a theatre need to have a sense of that, too. It's terribly alienating if you feel that it's just any old job for the people working front of house.

The theatre itself needs to create a relationship between the performer and the audience - no one in the audience should feel that they're getting an unreasonably prejudiced view of the actor. It's important that they're not too far away, they can hear, they can see, they can feel in some sense in contact with what's going on on stage.

The proportions of an auditorium are important. They have to respond to the human voice and the scale of the human body. If an auditorium dwarfs the human body, there's something wrong with it because you can't deny the human form at the heart of drama. A lot of theatres in the late-19th century got it right because they managed to shape an auditorium that somehow embraces the stage.

And I like theatres that have a sense of the past in them. They are like worn stone steps in a church, you get the sense of layers of human presence. The Royal Court, The Old Vic or the Theatre des Bouffes du Nord in Paris, where Peter Brook works, are all good examples of this.

From the point of view of the plays, you can't have something for everybody. You can't second-guess an audience because they don't know what they're going to want to see. When you visit the theatre, you want something done in a way you can't imagine, otherwise you may as well have stayed at home.

webTitle: Go see

fields.headline: Go see
fields.standfirst: Works not to be shown: 1-80
fields.trailText: Works not to be shown: 1-80.
fields.body:
'Panda on an orange', 'Mock-Picasso ceramic (painted)', 'Ceramic puppy in pieces' and 'Battery-operated black ping-pong ball with on/off switch' are just a few of the strange sculptural objects artist Matthew Thompson has spent the last three years fiddling about with in his studio.

If they don't sound much like artworks, that could be because they're not. They're the 3-D doodles made during the playing around process most artists go through between ideas. Thompson's combination of found and crudely fashioned bits and bobs were never intended for gallery viewing but, in a suitably conceptual twist, the objects that were probably formed as a distraction to the work have become the work itself. Documented as photographs, 80 of Thompson's objects made not to be shown have become a piece of work in the form of a slide show that is now being shown in London's Mobile Home Gallery.

'It's really work about making work,' Thompson explains. 'It shows something about the artistic process and how work gets from an artist's studio to display. And, of course, there's that contradictory appeal of revealing something not meant to be seen.'

This isn't the first time Thompson has unintentionally turned an innocent pastime into a major art project. A liking for the 1970s-style logo found on board games by the now defunct company Philmar Ltd resulted in Thompson picking up its jigsaws from second-hand stores. Initially completing and framing them, 130 or so puzzles down the line, Thompson now photographs them, documents them in his Philmar booklet and returns them to the second-hand recycling system.

He's even applied to pay up the £200 it would cost to own the Philmar logo. If he's successful there could be Philmar T-shirts and embroidered patches in the offing and maybe even a future show of things not meant to be worn.

 Works Not To Be Shown: 1-80 starts on Wednesday 13 December and runs until Saturday 6 January 2001 at the Mobile Home Gallery, 3rd Floor, 42 Theobalds Road, London WC1 (020 7405 7575). Open Monday to Saturday, 12-6pm. Admission free

webTitle: Phil Hogan: Tales from the grotto

fields.headline: Tales from the grotto
fields.trailText: Our 10-year-old is so keen to embrace the season of giving generously that it only takes us half the afternoon of threatening to call in the electricity-disconnection fairy before we manage to uncouple his mind from his Nintendo AddictBoy.
fields.body:
Our 10-year-old is so keen to embrace the season of giving generously that it only takes us half the usual entire afternoon of threatening to call in the electricity-disconnection fairy before we manage to uncouple his mind from his Nintendo AddictBoy and persuade him to see the wisdom of killing two bores with one moan by coming out with Dad to support the community Christmas shopping fund-raiser and at the same time search for a slightly more imaginative gift for his grandparents than a bag of mint imperials from Unwins or a novelty cat-shaped soap that grows fur when you take it out of the packet.

We park the car. But we've barely sneaked past the woman on the door selling raffle tickets to win a leading brand of dog shampoo than he starts dragging his feet outside the big hall and pretends to be reading the sign about why we are all fighting a losing battle against head lice.

'Dad, can't I wait outside?'

'Come on,' I say. 'We might see someone you know.'

'Exactly,' he says, because obviously being spotted on a Saturday with a parent immediately scores a top-five spot in the annals of shame. We go in and he makes an immediate purchase of the first thing he spots among the rustic dough things and aprons with kittens on them that is least likely to bring him into disrepute or cost more than £2.50, in other words a plant pot.

'Let's go , Dad,' he says.

But we can't go until I have bought an armful of twisty willow branches, which are just the thing to hide the holes in the living-room wall where my wife made the mistake of asking me to take the Rawlplugs out and now looks as though we are infested with rabbits. The boy has the brilliant idea of grabbing my branches and exiting backwards through the doors using them as camouflage, though I have to tell him that dragging a rail of clothes behind you and poking stallholders' eyes out as you go is not the official SAS technique of keeping a low profile.

When we get home - surprise! - I am now expected to take the two youngest out to Santa's grotto at a garden centre, which is apparently so near to the A10 you can really only miss it if you have no brakes or if your regular navigator and person you are married to is busy at home making artistic table decorations out of old conkers and Shredded Wheat.

We set off. Needless to say the children are so elated that they are asleep by the time we have done eight fruitless circuits of Ware, Hertford, and by the time we actually arrive the only way I can pacify the little annoyed one is by carting him in the freezing cold around the millions of rows of shrubs and plants and statues of Roman discus throwers and naked deities without arms and handcrafted water butts aimed at people without modern plumbing, until I am suddenly saved by the whistle of a miniature locomotive unexpectedly steaming past the pergola shed.

'Thomas the Tank Engine!' yells the little one excitedly, scrambling down out of my arms to follow the chugging noise round to the platform, only to find that - oh God, no - the train is the wrong colour. He throws himself wailing to the ground.

'Can we get this over with?' asks the seven-year-old.

So we head back past the novelty sundials and ornamental stirrup pumps and into the main building, which has been transformed into a frosted emporium of twinkling trees and bunches of wooden grapes and mountains of chocolate and white candles and clockwork wassailers and things made out of twigs. We follow the signs through the store for Father Christmas. 'I want to go home,' the little one shouts, the minute he sets eyes on the white beard. 'I want to go_' Santa gives him a lollipop.

'Hmmm...' he says.

We tell Santa what we want and get back into the car. The seven-year-old is not impressed. 'He's not the real one,' he says.

'How can you tell?'

'Because he didn't know where our house was.'

'I'm not too sure myself,' I say cheerfully, 'but we'll get there.'

I consult the map. 'Well, before him anyway...'
