webTitle: Loafer's guide

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Cirque du Soleil
fields.trailText: Cirque du Soleil.
fields.body:
Ah, the circus! The lions, the clowns, those people in glittery leotards who stand on the backs of horses for no good reason...
It's not quite like that, I'm afraid.

Don't tell us, it's one of those new-fangled jobs with chainsaws, goldfish-people in tanks with water pouring from the ceiling, and those freaks who eat worms and hang weights off their testicles, isn't it?
Actually, Canadian troupe Soleil, with its death-defying abseiling acrobats plummeting through smoke and fireworks or racing round giant wheels like manic hamsters accompanied by hairies grinding out deafening prog-rock, formed in 1984 and paved the way for animal-free but danger-heavy New Circuses such as Archaos (the chainsaws), De La Guarda (the water), and the Jim Rose Circus Sideshow (those other unseemly things).

And it presumably doesn't have anything so de trop as a big top?
So Billy Smart, darlings. Soleil has a Grand Chapiteau, a huge white thing 3,500m square, which, before you can say 'Millennium Dome,' they will be raising on 134 poles in - they claim - a mere 150 seconds this Thursday, in the post-apocalyptic setting of Battersea Power Station.

So what's inside? A Somersault Zone?
Something like that. Cirque's new show Quidam will feature sliding, soaring, swinging and snaking on a grander scale than ever before - 52 performers, 1,000 tons of equipment, 2,500 seats, 10,000 packets of Anadin.

And not even a single little bungee-jumping puppy?
Not yet, but they're getting worried at the Dogs' Home: the Battersea sitemay become Soleil's permanent home.

Well, whatever would Nelly the Elephant say?
Easy. Trumpety-trump, trump, trump, trump.

 Quidam is at Battersea Power Station from 14 December (020 7957 4090) and Manchester's Trafford Centre from 15 February 2001 (0161 930 8080).

webTitle: The way we live now: Mind your language

fields.headline: Mind your language
fields.standfirst: Word play
fields.trailText: Mind your language.
fields.body:
I was relaxing in an Old Compton Street café when the waiter jogged my elbow, sending a hot stream of cappuccino up my nose. As I gave him a piece of my mind, he announced to the floor, 'God, she is soooo butch!' and whisked away, chortling. I was irked by this poisonous retort, but my gay friend was reassuring.

'He doesn't mean you're dykey. Butch is Polari for upfront, strong,' he said. 'It's the lingo, innit? Like "vada the bona casa". Or "get a load of her lallies."'

He could have donned a bowler hat and spoken in Droog for all I understood, but Polari did strike me as something novel and, well, fantabulosa (a useful Polari adjective). Paul Baker, a research associate at Lancaster University who is writing a PhD on Polari, has noticed something of a revival of interest in Polari in certain circles, as well as increasing interest in gay linguisitics among academics.

'Most people under 30 are too young to be familiar with Polari, but they will have picked up on the odd word or phrase here and there and you can hear it being spoken in the gay bars of Soho and the suburbs,' he says. 'Gays tend to be clever with language and love inventing words for people and objects.'

Peter Gilliver, associate editor of the Oxford English Dictionary , tells me that Polari is actually more than 200 years old, and that the roots of some words are older still. Reference to the verb 'troll' (to take a walk) is to be found in a 14th-century text (although Polari gave us the derived noun 'trollette'). The ubiquitous 'bona' (good, attractive) was absorbed into English as long ago as Shakespeare's Henry IV Part II , where it appears as 'bona roba' (a wench, apparently, one wearing a lovely dress).

'What people are doing with Polari is less about inventing new words and more about reviving ones that have fallen out of fashion,' says Gilliver.

Polari - or 'parlyaree' from the Italian 'to talk' - emerged from London's West and East Ends as a slang created by outsiders, such as theatre folk and circus people, cockneys, sailors and itinerants, who felt a special need to protect their identities or actions. 'There's little written evidence of Polari before the 1890s,' says Gilliver. The OED 's entry for 'rozzer' (a policeman or detective) cites this quote from a book dated 1893: 'If the rozzers was to see him in bona clobber they'd take him for a gun.' Meaning: if the cops see him dressed like that, they'll know he's a thief.

Polari was adopted big time by the British gay community from the 1900s onwards and its use was rife in Soho's gay clubs, bars and 'backslums' (sex rooms) in the 1950s, before homosexuality was decriminalised. Retaining its roots in showmanship, secrecy and dodgy dealings, Polari evolved into a vehicle for campery, bitchiness, filthy jokes and innuendo. For the last, look no further than the Carry On films, but most of all the 1960s BBC radio series Around the Horne , featuring the ribald antics of Julian and Sandy (Kenneth Williams and Hugh Paddick). The death last month of Hugh Paddick may spark a further revival of Polari.

' Around the Horne was ahead of the game,' says Paul Baker. 'Julian and Sandy were always on about bona this and that, and having to "do" a pile of "dirty dishes".'

And they did not mean sloshing round with Fairy; dish is Polari for anus. Modern Polari covers all major anatomical parts and there is choice aplenty for the sexual act - how about 'charvering' or 'mollying'?

Other core words include vada (look); nanti (no/none); omi (man); palone (woman); and omi-palone (gay man). Drag, camp and queer have long since been mashed into the mainstream, as has naff, now widely understood to mean anything lacking taste. But a definition from the 1930s gives naff as 'an acronym for Not Available For F***ing, used by gays about straights'. Polari 'backslang' is just as playful - 'eek' equals face (from ecaf, ie, face reversed) and 'riah' is hair.

It's like masonic code: once you're in on the lingo, you can read the signs. Julian Clary slips the odd phrase into his shows and Morrissey released an album called Bona Drag featuring the track Piccadilly Parlare .

'The language is constantly changing and evolving as any "secret" language must,'says Paul Baker, 'to avoid being sucked into the swamp of the mainstream.' Baker's own addition to the lexicon is 'Imeldarous', from Imelda Marcos, denoting anything excessive or extravagant.

Further evidence of a revival comes from a spokesnun for the London order of the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence (gay men in habits) who use Polari for masses and ceremonies (find them at www.indulge. demon.co.uk/sisters/sishome.htm).

Says Sister Sadomystica, 29, 'There are few fluent speakers of Polari left now, but we have noticed that a number of younger men are picking it up from listening to Around the Horne tapes.' She sees the renewed interest as a resistance by gays to being mulched into maintream culture. 'Some people are using Polari to assert their individuality or separateness from straight society.'

There is also a weekly column in Boyz magazine. 'Ooh I say! - words to slip straight into your conversation'. My current favourite is 'Tara' from Tara Palmers/dramas - as in 'You wouldn't believe the "Taras" I've had today!'

'Julian and Sandy were always on about bona this and that, and having to "do" a pile of "dirty dishes".' And they did not mean sloshing round with Fairy; dish is Polari for anus. Modern Polari covers all major anatomical parts and there is choice aplenty for the sexual act - how about 'charvering' or 'mollying'? Other core words include vada (look); nanti (no/none); omi (man); palone (woman); and omi-palone (gay man). Drag, camp and queer have long since been mashed into the mainstream, as has naff, now widely understood to mean anything lacking taste. But a definition from the 1930s gives naff as 'an acronym for Not Available For F***ing, used by gays about straights'. Polari 'backslang' is just as playful - 'eek' equals face (from ecaf, ie, face reversed) and 'riah' is hair. It's like masonic code: once you're in on the lingo, you can read the signs. Julian Clary slips the odd phrase into his shows and Morrissey released an album called Bona Drag featuring the track Piccadilly Parlare . 'The language is constantly changing and evolving as any "secret" language must,'says Paul Baker, 'to avoid being sucked into the swamp of the mainstream.' Baker's own addition to the lexicon is 'Imeldarous', from Imelda Marcos, denoting anything excessive or extravagant. Further evidence of a revival comes from a spokesnun for the London order of the Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence (gay men in habits) who use Polari for masses and ceremonies (find them at www.indulge. demon.co.uk/sisters/sishome.htm). Says Sister Sadomystica, 29, 'There are few fluent speakers of Polari left now, but we have noticed that a number of younger men are picking it up from listening to Around the Horne tapes.' She sees the renewed interest as a resistance by gays to being mulched into maintream culture. 'Some people are using Polari to assert their individuality or separateness from straight society.' There is also a weekly column in Boyz magazine. 'Ooh I say! - words to slip straight into your conversation'. My current favourite is 'Tara' from Tara Palmers/dramas - as in 'You wouldn't believe the "Taras" I've had today!'

webTitle: The in-Equitable choice - less cash now or later

fields.headline: The in-Equitable choice - less cash now or later
fields.standfirst: Neasa MacErlean and Tracey Boles on the plight of policyholders lost in the space left by the House of Lords ruling
fields.trailText: Soothing slogans uttered by actresses and TV personalities of a certain age and class have been the hallmark of advertising by mutual insurer Equitable Life.
fields.body:
Soothing slogans uttered by actresses and TV personalities of a certain age and class have been the hallmark of advertising by mutual insurer Equitable Life.

This weekend there is little reassurance to be gleaned from this national institution so beloved of well-heeled, middle-class investors. The firm that proclaims its age so proudly on its literature - 'founded in 1762' - announced plans last Friday to close to new business.

Equitable remains solvent, but now exists only to wind down its remaining policies and meet its existing obligations. This could take 30 years, as some policyholders will be young people who recently started pensions.

The company acknowledged that its returns will probably suffer because its with-profits fund 'will need to be invested to a greater extent in bonds and gilts rather than equities, which historically have generated higher returns in the longer term'.

Insurers can spread their risk heavily into equities only if they are generating new business, particularly long-term pension business where the risks can be divided between thousands of new policyholders and over an unending time span.

Most of Equitable's 500,000 policyholders will be free to move their funds, although the firm has said it will apply a 10 per cent deduction by taking advantage of the 'market value adjustment' rules, which let insurers penalise leavers to help protect policyholders who stay.

But those in the with-profits fund are likely to suffer a second 'hit'. They will have to pay for guarantees to 90,000 people who, in a House of Lords case, forced Equitable to pay them a controversial 'guaranteed annuity rate'.

Equitable warned: 'Bonuses for current and future years are likely to be lower than in previous years.'

Investors in unit-linked funds could also struggle if charges rise, as they may, to help prop up the rest of the business.

People with annuities, however, cannot move their money. This is fine for those who get the 'guaranteed annuity rate' of 12.5 per cent a year. But it could harm investors who have with-profits annuities, a type that aims to deliver higher returns than conventional annuities. Hundreds of thousands of employees who have Additional Voluntary Contribution plans with Equitable Life - the UK's biggest provider of such schemes - are being urged to stop making payments and move their money. These 'money purchase' AVC schemes are thought to cover 75 per cent of FTSE 100 companies, the police, and NHS and council staff.

'We're going to have to make an appointment with them fairly quickly,' said a spokesman for the Local Government Pension Scheme.

Advisers Towry Law and Hargreaves Lansdown are both, reluctantly, encouraging younger people with Equitable AVCs to get out.

'If you're in your twenties, thirties or forties, you should transfer,' says Charles Levett-Scrivener of Towry Law. 'If you are in your fifties or sixties, you may want to stay and accept the bad returns.'

The Royal College of Nursing is 'trying to establish the scale of the issue' with the NHS pension scheme. 'Quite a significant' number of nurses - many of them ripped off in the personal pensions mis-selling scandal - invest in AVCs: they could find that they are about to lose out a second time.

The RCN is braced for widescale losses among nurses in the form of poorer investment performance than they would otherwise expect. 'The amounts are probably quite small,' said a spokeswoman. 'But the issue is significant, and it is unfair.'

Levett-Scrivener believes policyholders should go, despite losing 10 per cent of their funds. It will be worth it in the long run, since he and other advisers expect the long-term investment returns in Equitable funds to be poor.

They 'will come down and down', says Mark Rowlands of Hargreaves Lansdown. This is because Equitable will move more money into less risky assets, particularly fixed-interest stocks, to try to pay its future liabilities.

It is likely to lose its best fund managers and will probably have to sell some of its best shareholdings at bad times to pay out to departing policyholders.

Employees will probably want to speak to their pension scheme administrators and trustees as soon as possible. Many firms are already considering a different provider, or setting up a scheme for new contributions.

Employers may feel reluctant to be seen to give anything that could amount to financial advice to staff because they are not registered financial advisers. Nevertheless, they will need to make it clear what will happen about the AVCs.

Towry Law is encouraging younger AVC-holders who stop contributions to save the money they would have paid in for a few months and then decide what to do. They could put it with a new AVC provider if their employer sets up another scheme. Those earning less than £30,000 a year are eligible for the new stakeholder pensions, which start in April.

Pensions specialists will be working out what advice to give to AVC holders over the next few days. Many may transfer their funds, but Joanne Segars, the TUC pensions officer, urges people to wait and see how the situation develops: 'Don't do anything rash. Take advice.'

For Equitable products other than AVCs, such as endowments and personal pensions, independent financial advisers are more divided on what policyholders should do. Thomas McPhail, of Wolverhampton IFA Torquil Clark, says they should 'take the hit from the transfer value and get out'. But other professionals advise sitting tight.

McPhail says: 'With-profits investors may not get the full value of their investments if they move. But this could be a small price to pay in the long run, as returns are likely to decline if they stay.'

Equitable's terminal bonuses will be very small without equities to generate capital growth, warns industry analyst Ned Cazalet of Cazalet Financial Consulting. And its with-profits fund will be plundered to pay guaranteed annuity policyholders - a bill totalling at least £1.5 billion.

Given the prognosis for the with-profits fund, the advisers recommend you review endowment policies, especially if they are assigned to a mortgage. Again, check transfer values before switching.

Personal pension holders should go over to any similar scheme which does not carry penalties for any future transfers, says Torquil Clark.

But Jon Briggs of Bath adviser Chartwell says a lot depends on individual circumstances. A move may be wrong if you are coming up to retirement, for instance. And if an Equitable pension is not your only retirement holding, the pressure to decide is reduced.

Briggs believes it makes sense to wait: the punitive transfer values designed to prevent an exodus of policyholders may improve.

But other reasons for staying, such as potential windfalls from demutualisation now look like pie in the sky.

One group who could benefit from the mess are the guaranteed annuity holders in line to be compensated for bonuses withheld from them - but only if Equitable has the money to pay up. People who took out policies in the last 14 days are in the statutory 'cooling off' period. Equitable will allow them until 22 December to decide whether to back out.

Equitable has set up an advice helpline: 0870 900 8020. A free guide will be available this week from Towry Law (tel: 0845 788 9933).

webTitle: Row assured over blame for a £1.5bn black hole

fields.headline: Row assured over blame for a £1.5bn black hole
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott on what  went wrong - and how
fields.trailText: 'How could this have happened?' was the question on lips throughout the investment industry last Friday as one of the country's oldest and once most revered institutions shut up shop. Short of going bust, such a move is the worst way for an insurer to be obliterated from the history books.
fields.body:
'How could this have happened?' was the question on lips throughout the investment industry last Friday as one of the country's oldest and once most revered institutions shut up shop. Short of going bust, such a move is the worst way for an insurer to be obliterated from the history books.

The demise of Equitable Life has left insurance companies, policyholders and investment advisers aghast. This, after all, is an organisation credited with inventing life insurance in its present form and even with coining the word 'actuary'.

Ministers will be none too comfortable, either, as they contemplate the shattering effect of the crash on confidence among small investors. It comes as the Government prepares to farm out another huge chunk of the nation's retirement planning to the private sector, with the launch of stakeholder pensions.

The roots of Equitable's problems go back four decades, when it began to sell pensions with guaranteed incomes. Typically these promised a return of around £11 a year for every £100 invested. As people who started their pension plans 30 years ago began collecting their retirement incomes in the late Nineties, the guarantees looked very attractive in an investment environment that offered annuities paying around half what Equitable was promising. But the insurer had not set aside the reserves that, with hindsight, it needed to back these guarantees. So it looked at its contracts and decided it had the right to cut the amount investors receive, by reducing the 'maturity' bonuses on its policies.

Policyholders protested, and Equitable launched a series of court cases that ended in a House of Lords judgment forcing it to meet the guarantees in full, at an estimated cost of £1.5 billion.

There are a series of puzzling questions: o Why didn't the firm spot the potential snag sooner? o When it did find the £1.5 bn black hole in its books, why didn't it seek a buyer quickly? o And why, eventually, did a succession of potential bidders walked away?

Mick McAteer, senior policy officer at the Consumers' Association, says the management is entirely to blame. 'I don't understand why they couldn't have managed the risk,' he says.

Equitable spokesman Alistair Dunbar argues that the firm always believed it had a legal right to reduce the bonuses . To have held money back to underpin them would have deprived other investors in the insurer's with-profits fund of returns they might have claimed. The company was surprised when the Lords' judgment was much harsher than it had expected.

Equitable's approach to its problems seems to have satisfied the Financial Services Authority, whose judgment is also being questioned now.

Charles Levett-Scrivener of independent adviser Towry Law says: 'Regulation seems to have totally failed.'

But the FSA believes the Lords' judgement could not reasonably have been foreseen and says the insurer's management of the outcome was not unreasonable.

The potential buyers walked away because they feared that the potential cost of paying out on the Equitable guarantees was virtually unquantifiable and potentially much greater than the £1.5bn estimated after the Lords' ruling. A hitherto unknown aspect of the guarantees is that younger policyholders could choose to top up their investments to cash in on the attractive guarantees. If the potential black hole was as immeasurable as the potential bidders feared, the chances of Equitable striking a deal so late into the problem must always have been in doubt. Yet it continued to sell policies with the blessing of the regulator.

Not all observers lay all the blame at Equitable's door, or even at the regulator's. Insurance industry expert Ned Cazalet says: 'It all went wrong for Equitable when they wrote the contracts in the first place. The policyholders also showed a lack of sense by bringing the case. Their victory has ended in tears.'

But Stuart Bayliss, director of Annuity Direct, the adviser that began the policyholder campaign against Equitable, accuses the insurer of arrogance and an unwillingness to negotiate a settlement with the unhappy policyholders.

'The policyholders were interested in offering the company a deal two-and-a- half years ago which would have limited the guarantee to half the current figure and capped it,' Bayliss says. 'They [Equitable] bet this company's future on their belief that what they were doing was right. They chose not to listen to anyone else. They chose to ride the bet right to the Lords. I still feel the judgment was surprising, but I know that what they were doing was unfair.'

webTitle: Glitzy prizes that repulse the public

fields.headline: Glitzy prizes that repulse the public
fields.trailText: On Tuesday evening at London's Park Lane Hilton a man in a dinner jacket and a bow tie navigated a course between the tables of his well-dined peers, stepped into the sweaty spotlight and accepted his outfit's award as company of the year.
fields.body:
On Tuesday evening at London's Park Lane Hilton a man in a dinner jacket and a bow tie navigated a course between the tables of his well-dined peers, stepped into the sweaty spotlight and accepted his outfit's award as company of the year.

So what, you may think. These sort of junkets go on in scores of venues, night after night. Jolly good for Moss Bros's business and extremely enjoyable for those with a penchant for warm chablis and cold beef wellington.

OK, so he was handed the award by Ian Hislop, editor of Private Eye and panellist on BBC's Have I Got News For You.

Rather swankier than collecting a trophy from, say, local radio's Simon Bates or the editor of Company Car Driver.

But the status of the celebrity is no surprise because the Growing Business Awards were jointly presented by the CBI, Britain's premier industrial organisation. And you can see why this man's firm deserved its gong. 'Rapid growth since its inception just five years ago ... The past 18 months has seen its turnover rise from £7 million to £40m - a staggering 471 per cent increase,' exulted the subsequent press release.

No, the surprise is this model company's identity - Claims Direct. You may not have come across this thrusting operation unless you watch daytime television - where its commercials are ubiquitous. The press release, somewhat managerially, refers to this as 'accessibility of the product to its customer base'.

And what is that customer base? The victims of personal injury, whom Claims Direct invites to call it on a 'No win, no fee' basis to seek compensation. The company is not a firm of lawyers; rather, it passes respondents on to solicitors who pay Claims Direct a fee. And the company also sells its customers an insurance policy for £1,350 - to cover legal costs if they lose. Set aside the fact that this may seem to sit oddly with the 'no fee' slogan - and the fact that Claims Direct has attracted a certain amount of unfavourable publicity - even from 'victorious' customers complaining that they could not recover the insurance cost and were left with very little compensation.

Let us assume that the company has helped lots of little people win redress for the pain they suffered. Even so, what it amounts to is that the CBI's company of the year is, effectively, an ambulance chaser.

Were there no innovative manufacturers available for consideration? If not, what does this tell us, and the Confederation, about the state of British industry?

Of course, we all accept that profit is the bottom line - without it we'd be down the Swanee, or perhaps the Tyne. Capital no longer has to battle for the hearts and minds of the people against red-blooded socialism. But it should be aware of the picture it presents. The fact that its award winners are completely above board is not enough.

The title 'company director' has never commanded instant respect. In my youth a high proportion of the defendants in cases of armed robbery were described as company directors (often, for some reason, from Essex).

A sceptical public has watched and detested as the privatisation 'fat cats' lined their pockets, and is now more than half-convinced that, left to their own devices, railway and airline chiefs would always put profit before safety.

We love business: we know it's the only way. But we have to at least try to help the rest of the population to agree.

Oh yes, and in case you thought this year's award was a solitary publicity mistake, guess who picked up a gong last year? Martha Lane Fox. And how does that play to the gallery now the shares have so mightily fallen.

webTitle: The cost of... survival

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... survival
fields.trailText: ... survival
fields.body:
You may have spent much of the past month marooned on a stationary train, or adrift in the wettest autumn on record. As scientists warn that such extreme weather will become a more frequent occurrence, it's not such a bad idea to pick up some emergency survival techniques - after all, it's not as if we can trust politicians to do anything about climate change.

The basic principles of wilderness survival are instinctive: shelter, water, fire and food. Don't leave home without the following kit - it should fit into a compact pack so is perfect for the daily commute or even shopping trips. Water supply is obviously not a problem, but carry iodine tablets to purify drinking water, or a complete purifier (£65), which will remove bacteria and viruses. Boiling water on a small Calor gas burner (from £20, replacement gas canisters £3) will also kill most bugs. A firestick, costing £6, is made from 20 metals and will spark easily in wet conditions.

Although a fire can be used to signal for help, more sophisticated technology is available. A £475 Emergency Position Indicating Radio Beacon (EPIRB), more commonly used on yachts, transmits a digital code that can be instantly detected by geostationary satellites. Ensure the beacon is registered and avoid false alarms, alternatively a canister of orange smoke costs just £13.95 (not practical for use on public transport). If you feel able to make your own way home from your stranded train island or stalled vehicle, a Global Positioning System (GPS) could come in handy. Better models have international maps and can precisely pinpoint your position.

To make the most of your new survival pack, sign up for a survival weekend, usually run by apocalyptically inclined ex-SAS instructors. They've often written helpful books on the subject and will insist you call them by their army nicknames. However, Ray Mears, who presents a TV series showing where other lost souls went wrong, runs his own courses: the Family Bushcraft weekend is £75, while, for those made of sterner stuff, the Wilderness Cookery classes are £175.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Man killed as private jet crashes during test flight
fields.body:
Man killed as private jet crashes during test flight

One man died and another was taken to hospital after a private jet believed to be on a test flight from Humberside Airport crashed on farmland yesterday in Lincolnshire.

Body of Rory, 5, washed up

The body of Rory Sambrook, aged 5, has been found on the shore near Doolin, Co Clare. He had been swept out to sea by a large wave as he was walking with his mother and three-year-old sister.

Baby found dead in toilets

A newborn girl has been found dead in the toilets of Newham College, London.

Blairs in the abstract
An abstract painting of Tony and Cherie Blair, entitled The Golden Couple , the work of Mo Mowlam's husband Jon Norton, is to be exhibited at a Birmingham gallery next year.

The 45-year-old artist, from Stratford upon Avon, took up full-time painting after being made redundant from his job as a merchant banker last year.

Wilde bill paid - 105 years on
After 105 years, Worthing artist Royston du Maurier has settled Oscar Wilde's unpaid bill for £3 6s at James Long & Co, hatters, of London. He did not add the interest of £200.

First book out

Helen Dowling has had her first book published at the age of 94. A Kitten Cat Lost is the story of her cat Dinky.

Oasis singer turns Santa to boost store chain's toy appeal

Oasis singer Liam Gallagher and girlfriend Nicole Appleton of All Saints, above, paid £90 for toys at Woolworths in Haslemere, Surrey - then walked up the street to donate them to the Pass the Parcel toy appeal run by Boots the chemists.

webTitle: Soft landings in deep waters

fields.headline: Soft landings in deep waters
fields.trailText: The squabbling between governments at this weekend's European Summit in Nice is infinitely preferable to the kind of fighting that led to the need for the European Economic Community in the first place.
fields.body:
The squabbling between governments at this weekend's European Summit in Nice is infinitely preferable to the kind of fighting that led to the need for the European Economic Community in the first place.

Wrangling over national vetoes and voting weights, while inextricably linked with the process of enlarging the European Union to the east, has also rather diverted attention from the historic importance of that enlargement. Few members of my generation ever thought such a possibility, let alone probability, would be remotely on the cards until the amazing events of 1989 and after.

Some former communist nations have coped better than others with the opportunities afforded by the collapse of the Berlin Wall in 1989 and the Soviet Union in 1991. The ones that have done best are those which, unlike Russia and its closest associates, retained a cultural memory of market economies and the economic policies that steer them best.

Some of these, such as Hungary, had been resisting communism for decades. So eager are such nations to join what in the UK is called EUROPE (as if we ourselves were on another continent) that the Hungarian finance minister joked some time ago that his country could well sign up to the single currency before the UK. (Or perhaps it wasn't a joke.)

A recent book (Europe Incorporated, Wiley), based on interviews with the chief executive officers of many multinationals, suggested that the leading CEOs in the US and elsewhere see Europe as a market of 450 million consumers - 'almost twice as large as the market of the USA' - with vast potential.

But these multinationals also acknowledged that the euro had 'been a curse, because it has effectively brought an end to the era of lucrative price differentiation in Europe'. The author, Gianni Montezemolo, was told by one manufacturer that 'price transparency would reduce total operating profits in Europe by 40 per cent.'

From an economic policy point of view, and therefore from the point of view of the welfare of Europe's citizenry and the chances of fighting unemployment, the disinflationary impact of the single market and the single currency is good news, provided policymakers in general and the European Central Bank (ECB) in particular draw the appropriate lesson.

Taken with the burgeoning belief that the euro may have touched bottom, and could even be set for a rapid recovery, thereby easing the inflationary impact of higher oil prices, the newly competitive environment should help the ECB to keep the European economic recovery going.

With the US economy undoubtedly slowing down, and Japan stagnating (albeit at a high level), an enormous responsibility is about to descend on Europe's policymakers. For the past few years the US has been 'importer of last resort' from the rest of the world, helping Europe to overcome the inhibiting impact on growth of the policies associated with Maastricht, and also helping Japan to offset (to some extent) the deflationary impact of its high-saving, reluctant consumers. US demand has also assisted south-east Asia to recover (up to a point) from the disasters of the 1997 financial crisis.

Japan's problem has been a classic case of the Keynesian 'paradox of thrift'. The country seems trapped in a vicious circle, in which fears about the future make people save too much, and, because they save too much, the government cannot wisely introduce the reforms that ought to put them at ease about the future - because that would involve tax and social security increases (aimed at dealing with the 'demographic time bomb' of the social security costs of an ageing population) which would further depress the economy.

By contrast, nobody can reasonably accuse the aver age American consumer of thrift. The average American consumer has been spending as if there were no tomorrow, and the 'importer of last resort' has been running a trade deficit of over $1bn a day in a frenzied consumer boom that has at last shown signs of being deflated.

As Chancellor Gordon Brown never tires of reminding us, booms tend to be followed by bust. It happened in the UK in the early Nineties. It happened in Japan for most of the Nineties, and the Japanese are still not out of the wood in which they experienced their hard landing.

And the US? Well, under the guidance of chairman Alan Greenspan the Federal Reserve has pursued its brief of 'maximum employment and price stability' to the limit. The need to rescue the world's financial system in both 1997 and 1998 (first the threat from the Asian crisis, then the Russian default and the collapse of Long Term Credit Management hedge fund) meant that Greenspan almost certainly overdid his support of the US boom.

Greenspan is assumed to have oracular powers, and, like the original oracle, he can be quite Delphic when he wishes. Last week he uttered one sentence which led many investors and analysts to breathe sighs of relief and infer that he was about to come to the rescue once again.

The sentence was: 'In an economy that already has lost some momentum, one must remain alert to the possibility that greater caution and weakening asset values in financial markets could signal or precipitate an excessive softening in household and business spending.'

The sentence came in the middle of a long disquisition on the financial markets and the banking system. This one remark gave rise to all those speculative stories about interest rate cuts soon, and Greenspan's determination to avoid a 'hard landing'.

Well, good luck to Greenspan and all who sail around him. I think the sentence has been overinterpreted; and, even if it hasn't, the speculative boom in the US has been so extraordinary that the achievement of a 'soft landing' is likely to test Greenspan's supposedly divine powers to the limits.

Greenspan cannot manage the world economy alone. We are entering deep economic waters, in which he will need help.

It is up to Europe and the ECB to rise to the challenge of ensuring that the impact of the US slowdown is offset, not compounded, by economic policy in Europe.

webTitle: My money: Adrian Chiles

fields.headline: Family finances tax TV expert
fields.standfirst: It should be Chiles' play... but Adrian's house deal nearly ruined him - and his shares are 'shite', he tells Jill Insley
fields.trailText: It should be Chiles' play... but Adrian's house deal nearly ruined him - and his shares are 'shite', he tells Jill Insley.
fields.body:
Financial journalist Adrian Chiles, who presents BBC2's Working Lunch programme, claims he would gladly pay more tax if it meant he no longer had to battle with his tax returns.

'My accounts are in good order, but it takes an inordinate amount of time. I probably spend as much time trying to work out my receipts as I do working. Being freelance I have no idea how much money I have or what my next tax bill will be.

'Every day I get another letter from my accountant that I don't understand. When I went freelance I thought "Oh good", but now I'd gladly pay 40 per cent rather than fiddle around with all this.'

Anyone who has seen Chiles in action is likely to think he has escaped from the trading floor of a City bank. But while his barrow boy looks and strong Midlands accent now add authority to his pronunciations on the daily business and personal finance show, they initially threatened to keep him off the screen.

'I started in 1992 on work experience, and ended up as a researcher on Business Breakfast ,' he says. 'But I couldn't get on air because of my appearance and accent.'

Since then, however, he has worked as a reporter on Radio 4's Financial World Tonight , joined Working Lunch in 1994, presented Radio 5 Live's early-morning business news, and now has his own sports show, Chiles on Saturday . He was the third person to be heard on Radio 5 Live at its launch; his wife, presenter Jane Garvey, was the first.

Chiles says the couple feel lucky to be well paid for doing jobs they enjoy.

Asked how much he earns, he replies: 'Too much. But they could just sack me the day after tomorrow, so it compensates me for the insecurity.'

Although Chiles spends all week discussing money, he neglected his own finances until the arrival of his daughter Evelyn, nearly a year ago, spurred him into starting a pension and saving in a unit trust.

'Life insurance is the next thing,' he says.

The family nearly came a cropper when moving house recently. The owners of the place they wanted wished to sell before the Chiles had a buyer for their old home. 'For six weeks we owned two houses and we were bleeding hundreds of quid a week. It was just by the skin of our teeth that we managed it.'

Chiles now has a big house in Hammersmith, near his work, and a correspondingly big mortgage. This has changed his attitude to work and money: 'Before, I was quite happy not to work all the time. But now if someone offered me a paper round I'd do it. We have to get the loan down.'

Otherwise, he is not a big spender. He drives a Ford Focus, and spends free time at his parents' Welsh holiday home. He's a season ticket holder at West Bromwich Albion, and likes food: 'Since the baby we can't just go out to a restaurant, but I'm a fanatical cook.'

He has cash stashed in Isas, and a with-profits policy. He owns a few shares, but is not impressed with his choice.

'They are all shite - Leeds Sporting [the parent company of Leeds United], BT and M&S. Everybody at the BBC bought M&S thinking they couldn't go any lower, but they did.'

 'Working Lunch' is on BBC2 from noon every day this week, and from 12.30pm thereafter.

webTitle: How the EU's lines were redrawn

fields.headline: How the EU's lines were redrawn
fields.standfirst: President Chirac's refusal to acknowledge national interests has left a new treaty in disarray
fields.trailText: President Chirac's refusal to acknowledge national interests has left a new treaty in disarray.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, political editor and Denis Staunton
fields.body:
At eight o'clock on Friday night Tony Blair and Robin Cook were ushered towards President Chirac's suite of offices at the Acropolis Centre in Nice. They would have 20 minutes to speak to the French president and Lionel Jospin, the prime minister.

In that 20 minutes Britain was being asked to lay out its final negotiating position in Europe's most important summit in a generation - one that would define the future shape and scope of the goverance of an enlarged European Union.

With Blair and Cook was Sir Stephen Wall, the head of the Cabinet Office European Secretariat and the man brought to Downing Street by Blair to give Number 10 a bit of European backbone.

Chirac began the meeting by asking what Britain's final position was on the Nice summit. Blair once again went through the so-called 'six red lines', the six areas where Britain would not budge on giving up its veto in Europe, including the three most problematic: tax, social security and border issues. Britain was not bluffing, Chirac was told. There would be no compromise on these issues.

At 8.20pm Chirac thanked the men for coming and brought the meeting to a close. It was one of 15 meetings Chirac was to have that night, 'the confessionals' where each of the members of the European Union would lay down their 'non-negotiable' position.

Blair and Cook returned to their hotel, the West End, near the sea front. They knew the meeting they had just had with Chirac was a 'biding time' meeting. The real battle would commence in the morning.

At 7.30am the redrafted treaty was delivered to them, written overnight by French officials. It was supposed to take into account everybody's 'red lines' so carefully explained the night before. Over breakfast, Cook and his officials went through the draft page by page. On the European Commission, Britain was relaxed about plans to reduce the number of commissioners for the big countries from two to one. On the issue of the weighting of votes in the Council of Ministers, the key decision-making body in the EU, Britain was happy with plans to increase the overall number of votes and give Britain proportionally more power in the council. Britain's parity with Germany was also maintained.

But then came page two and two phrases neither Cook nor Blair wanted to see - social affairs and tax. Two of Britain's red lines had been breached: indirect taxation would be discussed without a British veto in five years' time and social security schemes would be 'co-ordinated' by the EU.

Blair and Cook met to discuss the document. In an hour's time would be the first meeting of the heads of government in the Acropolis Centre. They would have to make it clear that there was no room for manoeuvre.

At 9.30am the heads of government meeting began. and it was immediately clear that it was not only Britain that was having problems.

Portugal's Prime Minister Antonio Guterres condemned it as 'an institutional coup d'état'. Ireland's Bertie Ahern was described as going 'ballistic'over the abandonment of the national veto over some areas of taxation - a no-go area for the Irish and Luxembourg as well as Britain.

The small states were especially outraged by a French proposal to reweight votes in the EU's decision-making Council of Ministers so that three big states and one small one could block any decision.

Among the few EU leaders who did not reject the draft out of hand was Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, who said simply that more work had to be done. The reason that Schroeder was so sanguine was straightforward. Schröder and Chirac - both staying at Nice's smartest hotel, the Negresco - had sat up into the small hours on Saturday discussing possible compromises.

As Chirac went around the room, delegation after delegation made it clear that the lat est French version of the treaty was doomed to failure.

And among the British delegation, Blair and Cook knew that, even if they were isolated, they had to make it clear that they were willing to risk the whole summit, and with it the whole of the French EU presidency, rather than bend on their red lines. 'We know that Blair cannot go back to the House of Commons and sell what he has at the moment to the British people,' said a senior French official.

Now with the summit deadlocked, questions are already being asked over the way Chirac has conducted the treaty negotiations and the summit, amid anger over his highhanded behaviour..

And it is not only the Britain and the smaller states who are angry over their treatment by the French leader. Signs of tension were already clear on Friday when Chirac clashed with the President of the European Commission, Romano Prodi. When one of Prodi's aides entered the room, Chirac ordered him out, provoking a sharp rejoinder from Prodi: 'I see my civil servants wherever I want and whenever I want,' he is reported to have said.

Although the two men appeared at a joint press conference later, Chirac rejected Prodi's offer to attend the bilateral confessionals. Officials suggested that Prodi's absence could damage Chirac's chances of achieving a compromise.

But it is not only the French who are being accused of a lack of finesse. It has also emerged that cack-handed diplomatic manoeuvring on Thursday afternoon had put paid to Britain's one firm ally on the social security issue - Denmark. At 4pm, a press officer for the British EU team went over to the Danish press desk and asked the assembled journalists if they would be willing to meet Kim Darroch, director of the Foreign Office EU division, for a briefing.

In a highly unusual move, Darroch then came down to the press room and, with a huddle of Danish journalists around him, started briefing against the Danish government on the social security issue, saying that they had got bad legal advice. The Danes went back to their Prime Minister to ask for clarification and were met with astonished and angry rebuttals. The gaffe meant that Britain could no longer count on Denmark as an ally.

By lunchtime yesterday it was stalemate. During a short break Hubert Védrine, the French Foreign Minister, admitted that the situation was 'difficult'.

The package can never make everyone happy,' said Védrine's deputy, Pierre Moscovici. 'We are overstepping some of these lines and compromise means everybody has to give, even on the most sensitive issues of national interest.'

Védrine admitted that such was the failure of the first document, France would have to redraft the treaty again, only hours before the summit was due to end. Other delegations muttered that most of these issues should have been sorted out weeks ago.

At 5pm a second draft was drawn up and officials began to prepare to work through the night, trying to find a way through the fog. 'Put it this way,' said one Foreign Office official, 'I've booked my hotel room for one more night.'

A third draft was expected in the early hours of this morning. Britain expects the taxation and social security issues to be dropped from the final agreement but not until much later in the negotiations. In his introductory letter to the heads of government, Chirac said that he wanted the summit complete by noon. As they worked through the night, that deadline was becoming ever closer, with the whiff of stalemate still in the air.

'I am still confident we will get an agreement,' the Prime Minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said. 'But there are still some difficult areas to deal with.' At breakfast again this morning, Blair and Cook may have some tough negotiating still to do.

Chirac began the meeting by asking what Britain's final position was on the Nice summit. Blair once again went through the so-called 'six red lines', the six areas where Britain would not budge on giving up its veto in Europe, including the three most problematic: tax, social security and border issues. Britain was not bluffing, Chirac was told. There would be no compromise on these issues. At 8.20pm Chirac thanked the men for coming and brought the meeting to a close. It was one of 15 meetings Chirac was to have that night, 'the confessionals' where each of the members of the European Union would lay down their 'non-negotiable' position. Blair and Cook returned to their hotel, the West End, near the sea front. They knew the meeting they had just had with Chirac was a 'biding time' meeting. The real battle would commence in the morning. At 7.30am the redrafted treaty was delivered to them, written overnight by French officials. It was supposed to take into account everybody's 'red lines' so carefully explained the night before. Over breakfast, Cook and his officials went through the draft page by page. On the European Commission, Britain was relaxed about plans to reduce the number of commissioners for the big countries from two to one. On the issue of the weighting of votes in the Council of Ministers, the key decision-making body in the EU, Britain was happy with plans to increase the overall number of votes and give Britain proportionally more power in the council. Britain's parity with Germany was also maintained. But then came page two and two phrases neither Cook nor Blair wanted to see - social affairs and tax. Two of Britain's red lines had been breached: indirect taxation would be discussed without a British veto in five years' time and social security schemes would be 'co-ordinated' by the EU. Blair and Cook met to discuss the document. In an hour's time would be the first meeting of the heads of government in the Acropolis Centre. They would have to make it clear that there was no room for manoeuvre. At 9.30am the heads of government meeting began. and it was immediately clear that it was not only Britain that was having problems. Portugal's Prime Minister Antonio Guterres condemned it as 'an institutional coup d'état'. Ireland's Bertie Ahern was described as going 'ballistic'over the abandonment of the national veto over some areas of taxation - a no-go area for the Irish and Luxembourg as well as Britain. The small states were especially outraged by a French proposal to reweight votes in the EU's decision-making Council of Ministers so that three big states and one small one could block any decision. Among the few EU leaders who did not reject the draft out of hand was Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, who said simply that more work had to be done. The reason that Schroeder was so sanguine was straightforward. Schröder and Chirac - both staying at Nice's smartest hotel, the Negresco - had sat up into the small hours on Saturday discussing possible compromises. As Chirac went around the room, delegation after delegation made it clear that the lat est French version of the treaty was doomed to failure. And among the British delegation, Blair and Cook knew that, even if they were isolated, they had to make it clear that they were willing to risk the whole summit, and with it the whole of the French EU presidency, rather than bend on their red lines. 'We know that Blair cannot go back to the House of Commons and sell what he has at the moment to the British people,' said a senior French official. Now with the summit deadlocked, questions are already being asked over the way Chirac has conducted the treaty negotiations and the summit, amid anger over his highhanded behaviour.. And it is not only the Britain and the smaller states who are angry over their treatment by the French leader. Signs of tension were already clear on Friday when Chirac clashed with the President of the European Commission, Romano Prodi. When one of Prodi's aides entered the room, Chirac ordered him out, provoking a sharp rejoinder from Prodi: 'I see my civil servants wherever I want and whenever I want,' he is reported to have said. Although the two men appeared at a joint press conference later, Chirac rejected Prodi's offer to attend the bilateral confessionals. Officials suggested that Prodi's absence could damage Chirac's chances of achieving a compromise. But it is not only the French who are being accused of a lack of finesse. It has also emerged that cack-handed diplomatic manoeuvring on Thursday afternoon had put paid to Britain's one firm ally on the social security issue - Denmark. At 4pm, a press officer for the British EU team went over to the Danish press desk and asked the assembled journalists if they would be willing to meet Kim Darroch, director of the Foreign Office EU division, for a briefing. In a highly unusual move, Darroch then came down to the press room and, with a huddle of Danish journalists around him, started briefing against the Danish government on the social security issue, saying that they had got bad legal advice. The Danes went back to their Prime Minister to ask for clarification and were met with astonished and angry rebuttals. The gaffe meant that Britain could no longer count on Denmark as an ally. By lunchtime yesterday it was stalemate. During a short break Hubert Védrine, the French Foreign Minister, admitted that the situation was 'difficult'. The package can never make everyone happy,' said Védrine's deputy, Pierre Moscovici. 'We are overstepping some of these lines and compromise means everybody has to give, even on the most sensitive issues of national interest.' Védrine admitted that such was the failure of the first document, France would have to redraft the treaty again, only hours before the summit was due to end. Other delegations muttered that most of these issues should have been sorted out weeks ago. At 5pm a second draft was drawn up and officials began to prepare to work through the night, trying to find a way through the fog. 'Put it this way,' said one Foreign Office official, 'I've booked my hotel room for one more night.' A third draft was expected in the early hours of this morning. Britain expects the taxation and social security issues to be dropped from the final agreement but not until much later in the negotiations. In his introductory letter to the heads of government, Chirac said that he wanted the summit complete by noon. As they worked through the night, that deadline was becoming ever closer, with the whiff of stalemate still in the air. 'I am still confident we will get an agreement,' the Prime Minister's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said. 'But there are still some difficult areas to deal with.' At breakfast again this morning, Blair and Cook may have some tough negotiating still to do. webTitle: More floods on the way

fields.headline: More floods on the way, warn glum Met men
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Britain was braced for more flood chaos last night as heavy rain and gale force winds threatened to swamp a country already reeling from fierce storms on Friday.
fields.body:
Britain was braced for more flood chaos last night as heavy rain and gale force winds threatened to swamp a country already reeling from fierce storms on Friday.

A brief respite brought good weather yesterday but was set to change for the worse, with forecasters predicting more bad weather blowing in from the west.

'More rain is on the way. Areas at risk of flooding will have to be vigilant - that's anywhere draining off high ground including parts of south Wales, south-west England and Northern Ireland,' said meteorologist Jeremy Plester.

The last set of storms that swept across Britain at the end of last week killed four people and brought widespread rail chaos, triggered power cuts in south Wales and created deadly road conditions. At one stage most of west Wales was effectively cut off as two major roads were flooded.

However, as well as rendering hundreds homeless and causing millions of pounds of damage, the storms also produced their share of 'Dunkirk spirit' as a beleaguered population came to terms with yet more flooding.

In what is thought to be the first operation of its kind in Britain, the Royal Mail rescued three of its postal trains stranded by floods and transported them by road to rail lines unaffected by the rising waters.

Three £1 million engines and 18 coaches had been marooned west of Exeter, but after being driven 40 miles up the M5 on low-loader lorries the trains were put back on the railway and were able to continue their journey to deliver sacks full of Christmas post.

'The response was an unusual response to an unusual situation,' said a spokesman for English, Welsh and Scottish railways.

The operation had lasted throughout Friday night and involved dozens of railway workers, most of whom had volunteered their time for free.

Elsewhere, several people were rescued from their cars after getting stuck in flood waters in west Wales, and coastguards and police in wetsuits rescued a man who was stuck up to his waist in mud at a flooded caravan park in Dawlish Warren, Devon. More than 160 people, including pensioners, were eventually evacuated from the site by boat and helicopter after it was cut off by a local river that had burst its banks.

Last night the Environment Agency said 102 flood warnings were still in force across England and Wales, but warned that the number could rise as the expected fresh rainfall would boost river levels. In Wales especially people were urged to be on their guard as large swathes of Monmouthshire and west Wales were still under at least a foot of water.

Severe flood warnings have been placed on the River Monnow at Skenfrith and Forge Road, and Waterly Lane, Monmouthshire. The River Wye from Hereford to Ross-on-Wye and the River Severn between Bevere and Powick are also on severe alerts.

The River Ouse in York, which came within inches of flooding the city's historic centre during last month's floods, peaked yesterday at 13ft above its normal level, but still 5ft below the critical level. Officials said riverside paths in the city were being flooded but there was nothing like the disruption caused in November.

Experts believe the coming rains are unlikely to be the last in what is already the wettest autumn since records began. 'I can't see how the situation is going to ease much now until Spring,' said Environment Agency director Archie Robertson.

Ben Gill, president of the National Farmers Union, said the disastrous weather could destroy up to five million tonnes of winter cereal crops in yet another blow to an already battered farming industry.

webTitle: Europe not amused by a French farce

fields.headline: Europe not amused by a French farce
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The biggest casualty of the debate about how to give the EU the capacity to function successfully with a future membership of 30 or more states is French pretension to the leadership of Europe.
fields.body:
The biggest casualty of the debate about how to give the EU the capacity to function successfully with a future membership of 30 or more states is French pretension to the leadership of Europe.

The handling of the negotiations on reform of the EU and its institutions during the past six months, culminating in an incompetently managed, at times chaotic and frequently bad-tempered meeting in Nice, has dealt a serious blow to French prestige.

It was clear from the beginning of the six-month French presidency of the European Union that it would be fatally hamstrung by persistent and vicious internal infighting between President Jacques Chirac, and Prime Minister Lionel Jospin, and his Socialist-led government in Paris. With each man eyeing up his prospects for next year's French presidential election, neither wanted to take any of the risks which accompany the running of an EU presidency, for fear the other would exploit any concession for electoral advantage.

The French have shocked their EU partners by using the presidency to advance narrow national interests. At times this stratagem was made farcical when the presidency put forward proposals which were then promptly vetoed by the French government. 'If this is what a Europe run by the so-called big member states, rather than the Commission and the EU institutions, looks like, we want no part of it,' one senior Finnish diplomat observed in Nice.

At the Biarritz summit in the autumn, Chirac outraged the leaders of smaller member states by his arrogant manner in the debate about proposed changes in the voting system in the Council of Ministers and the issue of streamlining the Commission. Chirac has made no secret of this desire to marginalise the role of the Commission and its President, Romano Prodi. In Nice this led to a bitter exchange between the two men.

At almost the same time, sharp words were exchanged between the French Foreign Minister, Hubert Vedrine, and the EU foreign policy chief (and former Nato secretary general) Javier Solana. Although the EU, through Solana, has been invited to participate in the planned Mitchell commission inquiry into Israeli-Palestinian violence, Vedrine insisted he would lead his own mission with Solana required to attend as little more than a bag carrier.

Meanwhile, several EU heads of government have made no secret of their profound distrust of the French Minister for European Affairs, Pierre Moscovici, for his machiavellian handling of the EU reform negotiations. 'I will no longer take telephone calls from him,' one head of government said recently.

The damage done to France's long-term standing in Europe may be lasting. The experience is bound to influence the debate which will now begin on the final political shape of the EU.

The French - together with the British - have been in the forefront of those who want to move the balance of power away from the EU institutions and back to a club of member state governments. But French behaviour has strengthened the determination of most EU countries to take a different route - reforming and strengthening of the Commission and other institutions.

There are lessons in all of this for New Labour's European strategy. At Nice, French arrogance has at times been matched by that of the British. British officials tried to use the Danish media to pressurise the Copenhagen government against leaving the UK alone in blocking majority vote decisions on cross-border social security problems. Danish 'No' campaigners were united in outrage with supporters of closer European integration at this .

Both Britain and France have a great deal to contribute in helping shape the EU. But their influence will crucially depend on recognising that the great majority of member states will refuse a Europe dominated by inter-governmentalism (that is, by a few big states).

The wiser path, already proposed by Germany and other states, would lead to a European Union bound together by a constitutionally sanctioned federal style division of powers between EU institutions, national and regional governments, with a legally enforceable Charter of Fundamental Rights and maybe an elected Commission President.

Ironically French behaviour in the past six months may have brought that option closer.

 John Palmer is director of the European Policy Centre in Brussels. He writes in his personal capacity.

webTitle: Youth suicide alerts double at Feltham

fields.headline: Youth suicide alerts double at Feltham
fields.trailText: The number of young prisoners put on suicide watch at one of Britain's most violent jails has nearly doubled in a year,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
The number of young prisoners put on suicide watch at one of Britain's most violent jails has nearly doubled in a year, The Observer can reveal.

More than 800 prisoners at Feltham, the troubled young offenders institution near London, have been put on suicide watch this year. Experts say that the rise has occurred because of the appalling conditions in the jail where prisoners have to stay in their cells for 23 hours a day and a third of inmates were assaulted last year.

'This is a matter of serious concern,' said Stephen Robinson-Grindey, director of the prison information service, the Penal Lexicon, and a member of a government monitoring unit at another jail. 'Twenty-three hours a day in a cell would make anyone suicidal, and bullying is a prime factor leading to self-harm.'

When prison officers consider an inmate to be a risk to himself, they open a report, called an F2052sh. The Prison Service confirmed last week that 813 such reports had been opened at Feltham since January - nearly one for every 10 prisoners that the jail has housed during the year. Between November 1998 and September 1999, there were 434 reports opened.

The institution's culture of violence has been under increased scrutiny since the brutal racist murder of Zahid Mubarek, 19, by Robert Stewart, 20, a known psychopath on remand for sending malicious communications.

Stewart was sentenced to life for the murder and the Commission For Racial Equality has been asked to investigate racism in the prison system.

Last year the Chief Inspector of Prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, described the conditions at Feltham as 'rotten to the core' and 'unacceptable in a civilised country'.

The practice of putting a prisoner on suicide watch is embroiled in controversy. While authorities say that it keeps the suicide rate down, campaigners say that only a quarter of suicides occur among prisoners on suicide watch and that officers have to spend a lot of time filling in forms when they could be monitoring inmates.

'This is my number one priority,' said Martin Narey, the Director General of the Prison Service. 'There is some improvement we can make and I am investing millions next year to improve the screening of prisoners.'

Narey added that he thought Feltham had improved its care of under-18s and that suicides were expected to drop across the service, but he added: 'The regime for over-18s is not as good.'

A prison service spokeswoman added: 'Only one prisoner killed themselves last year [at Feltham]. Don't you think that means we're doing quite a good job?'

The prison is on average home to 700 male inmates at one time, aged between 16 and 21. The Prison Service confirmed last week that one in 20 prisoners was now on suicide watch at Feltham.

An Observer investigation has also unearthed a culture of low morale and falling standards among prison officers at the prison. Fifty-nine prison officers have been transferred from the jail this year and 40 have been transferred in. There are 398 trained officers at the jail.

Much of the prison is being refurbished since a riot in one unit on 21 October this year. Three prison officers drew batons during an attack by 32 inmates, who were throwing pool balls and furniture.

The pay and living conditions of prison officers has been the subject of strong criticism. Many are from the North of England and are owed relocation grants to help them settle in the London area. It is understood that many payments were delayed, placing the officers in financial difficulties.

As many as five of Felt-ham's officers have been living on a nearby campsite in Chertsey. The rules of the campsite mean they are able to stay for only 28 days in a row, and are then obliged to move on for a night, when they can then return for another 28 nights.

'Pay rates are a serious problem in the Prison Service,' said Robinson-Grindey. 'A baggage handler at Heathrow may earn much more than a prison officer.'

webTitle: Pupils to learn Blairite values

fields.headline: Pupils to learn Blairite values
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Children as young as seven are to be taught the civic values of New Labour, prompting accusations that the Government is intent on extending the 'nanny state' to the next generation.
fields.body:
Children as young as seven are to be taught the civic values of New Labour, prompting accusations that the Government is intent on extending the 'nanny state' to the next generation.

The Education Secretary David Blunkett will this week unveil new teaching materials that will inform children that their 'rights' include privacy and the private ownership of property. The guide, to be used as part of 'citizenship' classes, suggests pupils have 'Socratic seminars' on subjects such as, 'Why do we have litter laws?'

Young people will be taught that value systems feature not only Christianity and conventional religions, but also the 'Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics'. These include: 'Thou shalt not snoop around in other people's computer files.'

Jim Mulligan, who helped prepare the manual Active Citizenship , said: 'These lessons are valuable for children of every age. They can start in the nursery. They are to do with advocacy and making decisions democratically. A teacher shouldn't say to a child, "That's your peg." You should say, "Which of these three pegs would you like?" '

The guide includes key words for children to learn as they develop an awareness of ethical values. 'Business', 'credit' and 'television' are all included in the recommended modern vocabulary. Old-fashioned aspirations such as charity, equality and tolerance - as well as the specific words 'rights' and 'responsibilities' - do not feature.

Blunkett has been determined to force through the introduction of lessons in citizenship since his appointment in 1997. The new curriculum was pioneered by his former politics teacher, Professor Bernard Crick.

Crick recommended that 5 per cent of teaching time be devoted to the subject. However, after disputes with teachers, the citizenship curriculum will be compulsory for secondary schools only on its introduction in September 2002. It has been tried out at primary schools in preparation for it to be implemented in them later. Its authors claim it will lead to better behaviour and attendance.

Nigel de Gruchy, general-secretary of the teachers' second largest union, the NAS/UWT, said: 'Good schools teach these important issues in a natural way. Compulsion just means more policy statements and meetings and bureaucracy. Why do schools have to be given a whole lot of extra work to do for no particular purpose?'

A spokeswoman for the largest union, the National Union of Teachers, said: 'You can still teach right and wrong and involvement in the community across the curriculum. You don't need to be told to cross every I and dot every T by central government. Teachers start griping justifiably when something is imposed on them which they think is a waste of time.

'No doubt this will all go off with a huge fanfare. Both this Government and the previous one have been too happy to overload teachers with all sorts of things. But you have to have time to teach.'

As they prepare to receive citizenship lessons, British 11-year-olds are still failing to reach key targets in basic subjects. Latest tests show that 28 per cent of children beginning secondary education are not reaching the Government's expected standard in maths, and 25 per cent are failing to achieve an equivalent level in English.

Blunkett will unveil the new teaching materials on Wednesday, the same day Home Secretary Jack Straw launches 250,000 Government-funded guides telling children of their entitlements under the new Human Rights Act.

Mulligan concedes: 'Seeing the politicians around them, many children will be very cynical about citizenship by the time they're 14 or 15. They've got to learn the lesson that life's like that.'
