The Education Secretary David Blunkett will this week unveil new teaching materials that will inform children that their 'rights' include privacy and the private ownership of property. The guide, to be used as part of 'citizenship' classes, suggests pupils have 'Socratic seminars' on subjects such as, 'Why do we have litter laws?' Young people will be taught that value systems feature not only Christianity and conventional religions, but also the 'Ten Commandments of Computer Ethics'. These include: 'Thou shalt not snoop around in other people's computer files.' Jim Mulligan, who helped prepare the manual Active Citizenship , said: 'These lessons are valuable for children of every age. They can start in the nursery. They are to do with advocacy and making decisions democratically. A teacher shouldn't say to a child, "That's your peg." You should say, "Which of these three pegs would you like?" ' The guide includes key words for children to learn as they develop an awareness of ethical values. 'Business', 'credit' and 'television' are all included in the recommended modern vocabulary. Old-fashioned aspirations such as charity, equality and tolerance - as well as the specific words 'rights' and 'responsibilities' - do not feature. Blunkett has been determined to force through the introduction of lessons in citizenship since his appointment in 1997. The new curriculum was pioneered by his former politics teacher, Professor Bernard Crick. Crick recommended that 5 per cent of teaching time be devoted to the subject. However, after disputes with teachers, the citizenship curriculum will be compulsory for secondary schools only on its introduction in September 2002. It has been tried out at primary schools in preparation for it to be implemented in them later. Its authors claim it will lead to better behaviour and attendance. Nigel de Gruchy, general-secretary of the teachers' second largest union, the NAS/UWT, said: 'Good schools teach these important issues in a natural way. Compulsion just means more policy statements and meetings and bureaucracy. Why do schools have to be given a whole lot of extra work to do for no particular purpose?' A spokeswoman for the largest union, the National Union of Teachers, said: 'You can still teach right and wrong and involvement in the community across the curriculum. You don't need to be told to cross every I and dot every T by central government. Teachers start griping justifiably when something is imposed on them which they think is a waste of time. 'No doubt this will all go off with a huge fanfare. Both this Government and the previous one have been too happy to overload teachers with all sorts of things. But you have to have time to teach.' As they prepare to receive citizenship lessons, British 11-year-olds are still failing to reach key targets in basic subjects. Latest tests show that 28 per cent of children beginning secondary education are not reaching the Government's expected standard in maths, and 25 per cent are failing to achieve an equivalent level in English. Blunkett will unveil the new teaching materials on Wednesday, the same day Home Secretary Jack Straw launches 250,000 Government-funded guides telling children of their entitlements under the new Human Rights Act. Mulligan concedes: 'Seeing the politicians around them, many children will be very cynical about citizenship by the time they're 14 or 15. They've got to learn the lesson that life's like that.' ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Damilola: a victim of Britain's knife culture

fields.headline: Damilola: a victim of Britain's knife culture
fields.standfirst:
Tracy McVeigh and Paul Harris find armed child gangs causing havoc in cities across the country

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Tracy McVeigh and Paul Harris find armed child gangs causing havoc in cities across the country.
fields.body:
Detectives are investigating claims that a boy the same age as Damilola Taylor may have been responsible for the 10-year-old's murder in an attempt to win 'ratings' - points scored for the number of wounds inflicted on other children.

The disclosure, which will heighten concerns about the violent youth culture in Britain's sink estates, comes as an Observer investigation reveals the staggering scale of the use of knives among young Britons, many of whom believe they must arm themselves to survive.

In inner-city housing estates where childhoods are scarred by parental abuse and neglect, drugs, crime, failing schools and under-resourced social services, youths are arming themselves with a remarkable array of knives.

In Peckham, where Damilola was found dying from stab wounds to his leg 10 days ago, knives are so common that youngsters hide blades behind brickwork or in liftshafts - within easy reach should unforeseen circumstances arise.

Police searching the immediate area where Damilola was stabbed found four knives, none of which is thought to be the murder weapon. In the Metropolitan area crimes involving the use of knives leapt from 13,184 in 1998/99 to 15,527 in 1999/00.

For 18-year-old Robbie, a father-of-one living in Peckham, knives and knife fights are a part of everyday life.

'You carry a weapon even if you don't want to use it. You get a tool just in case,' said Robbie, whose personal 'ratings' made him a VIP, a leader among youths and a veteran of many stabbings.

Robbie took The Observer for a tour of north Peckham, ending at Hordle West, the ugly concrete block where Damilola tried to escape his attackers, crawling up a decaying stairwell where he was found, bleeding to death, by demolition workers.

Robbie shook his head as he stared down the stairwell to the recently scrubbed dusty concrete landing. He has his own theory about who killed the schoolboy.

'I know it's a young, young kid,' said Robbie.

'It makes me sick. Ten-year-olds stabbing 10-year-olds. Man, that's too young. When you're 13, 14, you maybe make a little kid like that run, a little kid who do his schoolwork and be nice to his mum, but stabbing him will get you no respect.

'But younger boys want to see what the older boys doing. The people be saying "we smashed up a youth" then the little ones want to have a go.

'When the young ones start stabbing, they stab in the leg, most famous as a safe place to stab. When I started stabbing, I stab in the leg. You're young, you're frightened at what you're doing, you don't really want to do it.

'Older, you stab in throat, belly. I wanted a name. I knew I had to start stabbing when I was 13, 14.'

Robbie, whose single mother 'tried to work to take care of me', was excluded from school at 12 for swearing at a teacher. He had not learnt to read or write and carved a living through extortion and cannabis dealing.

'Mostly all you want is to chill, smoke some weed, see some girls. Some robbing up west. Maybe 40 of us crash into a shop take what we get and run again, maybe one gets caught, so what?

'But there is always someone with a stinking attitude and then you have to sort it out. And girls call out they want the bad boys and the young ones want to impress.'

He also dismisses theories that Damilola interrupted a crack deal or that racism was a motive.

'Most of the crack dealers around here don't smoke it, they just deal it. They not off their heads, they are not going to be standing out here. Class A drugs are not smart with the kids round here, you know.

'Even the Yardies that sell drugs in Peckham, they tell little kids to run on home. Racism is not a fighting thing in Peckham. I've got African brethren and you might be saying "stupid African, stupid rice and peas Jamaican" but we all mix. You'd be surprised how many white boys mingling,' he said.

But it's not just in south London that children are picking up the violent culture of the knife.

In the North End estates of Birkenhead, gangs of youths, many still in their teens, have reduced other residents to prisoners in their homes. Many of the young boys carry knives and often engage in fights on the streets in this slum area of Merseyside, dubbed 'Birkenhell'. Between stretches of wasteland, stand isolated groups of houses, most with boarded up windows, some burnt out by the youths that prowl the streets at night.

'You don't dare go out at night. They are so young but they are not afraid of anything,' said Doris Jones, 60, who was recently threatened by a gang of young boys ransacking a delivery van outside her home in broad daylight.

The child gangs are so vicious that workmen on the estate laying a sewage pipe earlier this year had to build special escape tunnels if they came under attack. Some youths even poured lighter fuel into their diggings and tried to set them on fire. In another attack they rammed a stolen car into the base of a crane and tried to set it ablaze even though there were terrified labourers still working on it. Eventually the workers had to hire private security and put up signs saying 'Danger! Beware of children in this area.'

On one of the walls a mis-spelt graffito seems to sum up the despair. 'Merry Exmas?,' it reads.

In Manchester's infamous Moss Side district, youths have become so enamoured of the drugs culture that when Martin Bennett, a convicted drugs trafficker with strong links to the local crime scene, was shot dead in a street, they turned the spot into a makeshift shrine.

In Newcastle's roughest estates, the arson of cars and buildings by youngsters is now so common that local police and the fire brigade have set up a task force to tackle the problem in an area with one of the highest arson rates in Europe.

In Peckham the problems are not so visual. No one is rioting. The damaged and desperate children who stab each other under cover of darkness could long have gone unnoticed had not a 10-year-old Nigerian boy from a decent family died on a lonely stairwell.

webTitle: Lords too ill, old or busy to vote...ever

fields.headline: Lords too ill, old or busy to vote...ever
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lords reform
fields.trailText: Nearly one hundred peers failed to appear for a single vote in the House of Lords last year, according to figures passed to  The Observer which raise serious questions about the workings of the chamber.
fields.body:
Nearly one hundred peers failed to appear for a single vote in the House of Lords last year, according to figures passed to The Observer which raise serious questions about the workings of the chamber.

An analysis of voting patterns by the office of the Clerk to the Parliament reveals that another 20 peers voted in fewer than one per cent of divisions.

The figures reveal that Tory peers are much less likely to vote in the House of Lords than Labour peers, even though the Conservatives are campaigning strongly not to have the House of Lords abolished.

The figures will be seized on to question whether the Lords can claim to represent a wide swathe of public opinion- and how peers see their job.

Critics say that the growth of 'empty benches syndrome' in the Lords shows that many members are too old, too ill, or too busy with business and other interests to attend.

The trend to appoint younger peers, who have 'day jobs' and young children, may also affect attendance.

The voting patterns, analysed for the Labour peer Lord Lipsey, reveal that many of the most famous names in the Lords rarely appear for votes on Government business.

Andrew Lloyd-Webber, the theatre tycoon and Conservative peer, voted once once out of 186 votes between November 1999 and the end of the last session of parlia ment - and that was for the Government. Lord Archer, also a Tory peer, appeared for four votes.

Lord Lawson, former Chancellor of the Exchequer and a Tory peer, voted 14 times, a rate of 7.5 per cent. Lord Wakeham, head of the Press Complaints Commission, voted 26 times, a rate of 12.4 per cent, while Baroness Thatcher voted 25 times.

A spokesman for Lady Thatcher, who has recently turned out for debates on the age of consent and Section 28, said she had 'lots of commitments elsewhere' but tried to attend when possible. 'She travels overseas extensively, but she tries to get to the House whenever she can. I think she works hard enough for Britain.'

Meanwhile friends of Lloyd-Webber said he was given his title for service to the arts and was 'obviously not a working peer', adding that he had opened a West End show and a Broadway show in the past year.

Lord Owen, former leader of the Social Democratic Party, voted only once.

For the Labour peer and film director Lord Attenborough the figure was 15 votes or 8 per cent, while for Lord Hattersley it was 16 votes.

In contrast Labour peers Lord Bragg and Lord Alli, who have often been criticized for being members of Labour's 'luvvie wing' voted 135 and 130 times respectively.

'This gives the lie to the claim that Tony Blair's peers are idle cronies,' Lord Lipsey, who has voted 163 times, said. 'It also gives the lie to Tory claims that only they are working hard in the Lords. It is Labour peers who attend the house and vote.'

Of the top 30 peers who vote in the Lords, 29 are Labour, including the Government ministers Lord Macdonald and Lord Bassam. Of the top 100 voters, only 14 are Conservatives.

Unlike MPs, members of the Lords are unpaid, receiving expenses for the days on which they turn up.

webTitle: Hamilton's new case against Fayed founders

fields.headline: Hamilton's new case against Fayed founders
fields.standfirst:
Police have thrown out a claim that was crucial to the appeal

Special report: the Hamilton v Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Police have thrown out a claim that was crucial to the appeal.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton, the disgraced Conservative Minister, will tomorrow launch a bid to overturn last year's High Court decision that he was not libelled when Mohamed al-Fayed, the owner of Harrods, accused him of taking payments in cash, gift vouchers and holidays at the Paris Ritz in return for asking questions in parliament.

The Hamiltons' lawyers are expected to say that Fayed improperly obtained defence documents which helped him - though not his legal team - to win the court battle. The tycoon is accused of paying Benjy 'The Binman' Pell, a freelance tipster who is reported to make his living rifling the rubbish of the rich and famous for saleable documents, a total of £10,000 for notes thrown away by Hamilton's lawyers. Fayed has always denied the claim which, if true, could lead the Appeal Court to overturn the original verdict.

But The Observer has learned that a City of London police investigation into the allegation, launched nine months ago following a complaint by Hamilton's solici tors, has been dropped. Last week, the officer leading the inquiry wrote to Fayed's lawyers telling them that 'on the basis of the evidence available at this date' the Egyptian tycoon was not to be interviewed and that, following advice from the Crown Prosecution Service, he had decided not to charge anyone. The timing could not be worse for the Hamiltons.

At the weekend, no one seemed certain whether the case would go ahead. Max Clifford, the publicist who is spokesman for Fayed, said he could no longer see 'any point' in Hamilton's appeal. The Hamiltons' lawyers were not available for comment.

The stakes are high and interest is fierce. Last year, after a five-week case dubbed 'Liar vs Liar' by the press, a jury decided that the allegations made by Fayed were fair and that he had not libelled the former MP. The court ordered Hamilton, 51, to pay both sides' million pound- plus legal costs.

Hamilton, who lost his Tatton seat in the 1997 election to the broadcaster Martin Bell, was ruined. Since then he has busied himself giving legal advice to former constituents. His wife, Christine, recently confessed to turning to alcohol and pills. Appearances on talk shows and two books have kept the couple afloat but they are ostracised from Conservative Party circles.

Though a victory next week is unlikely to mean a political, or a social, comeback it would offer an escape from the massive legal bill. Currently the Hamiltons' Cheshire manor house is mortgaged to the lawyers. The couple, who once enjoyed four overseas holidays a year, have been reduced to bucket-shop trips to Spain where they stay at friends' villas. They say the rain streams through the roof of their London flat because they do not have the money for repairs.

Yet there are backers who are willing to provide funds for continuing legal action. The Hamiltons have hired a legal team headed by one of Britain's leading libel QCs. The former politician has admitted drawing on the financial support of 'a blind trust' of the wealthy and influential, reportedly including Gyles Brandreth, the former Conservative MP, Taki, the Greek-born society columnist, and Norris McWhirter, the founder of the Guinness Book of Records.

Supporters of Fayed are outraged by the flow of funds to Hamilton. 'There are many people out there who are enemies of Mohamed [al-Fayed] who want to attack from a distance but remain in hiding. Someone is putting a lot of money into this. I do not think it is at all healthy,' said Clifford yesterday.

Last November the country was transfixed as 'the phoney Pharoah' and 'the biggest crook in town' - as they were described by lawyers - battled it out in the law court. George Carman QC, for Fayed, put in a bravura performance as he explained how Hamilton took £30,000 in cash and gifts from Fayed between 1985 and 1989 in return for a variety of services including putting down parliamentary questions.

Describing the high cost of the Ritz, owned by Fayed, at the time of the Hamiltons' all-expenses paid visit in 1987, he said: 'It would have cost a dog £47 to spend the night and that's before the wretched animal had anything to eat.'

Fayed himself provided equal entertainment. When asked why he had added the prefix 'al' to his name - denoting nobility in Arabic - the tycoon merely answered: 'You can call me Al Capone if you want.'

webTitle: Jane Clarke: Sweet talk

fields.headline: Sweet talk
fields.standfirst: When Fergie confessed she played dietary games with her daughters, the media feeding frenzy got it all wrong
fields.trailText: When Fergie confessed she played dietary games with her daughters, the media feeding frenzy got it all wrong.
fields.body:
The recent furore over the dietary games that Sarah, the Duchess of York, apparently plays with her daughters seems to me to be misplaced. If the press coverage of the Duchess's strategy - helping her daughters to deal with emotions in a way that doesn't involve overeating - is to be believed, then I'd support her. What the so-called 'experts' on eating disorders who have condemned her seem to have chosen to ignore is, firstly, that children whose mothers make them aware of the relationship between what they eat and drink and their physical appearance don't automatically become paranoid about food, and, secondly, that the incidence of obesity in children is far higher than anorexia or bulimia.

It is a sad fact that increasing numbers of children are eating too much, aided and abetted by the ready availability of chocolates, crisps and fast food. More often than not, children simply don't realise that the food they eat will have an impact on their physique. Many children first run into problems with their eating habits during their teenage years, when they're often disinclined to run around and burn off calories and prefer to sit in front of the TV or computer screen instead. Combine these sedentary habits with an unawareness of the link between overeating and lack of exercise, and obesity becomes a real danger.

Children are also confused about food, often believing that because a product is labelled 'fat-free' it gives them carte blanche to eat as much of it as they like, or that taking a multivitamin excuses them from eating vegetables and fruit. All in all, today's youngsters have very little idea of food's nutritional value, and therefore of the benefits that their bodies can glean from it.

Anorexics could probably rattle off the calories that a specific food contains far quicker than I could, but apart from its fat content, they rarely have an informed knowledge of how its nutrients can affect their bodies. If a child is made to feel guilty when they eat 50 calories more than their ideal daily quota, or they end up studying the nutritional information printed on a food's packaging, then the seeds of a potentially destructive relationship with food could have been sown. Indeed, some eating disorders in children, particularly girls, come to light when they become addicted to dieting.

Contrary to popular belief, this doesn't always occur in girls who perceive themselves as being too fat: children usually only fall victim to anorexia and bulimia when they are feeling emotionally insecure. The sort of nutritional information that our children should be learning are the general principles of a healthy diet, that is, eating something fibrous, like wholegrain toast or cereal, at breakfast, having a main meal based around protein and carbohydrates and eating plenty of vegetables and fruit.

Many endocrinologists see overweight children at the urging of their parents, who believe that they must have an underlying hormonal problem, such as an underactive thyroid. The truth, however, is that most overweight children are fat as a result of eating too many fatty and sugary foods.

If parents can teach their children to understand how eating more fruit, vegetables and nutritious food can make them feel healthy, give them energy and help them sleep, for example, they will be far more likely to give eating healthy food a go.

I also see many overweight adults who are anxious to ensure that their children don't go through life battling against obesity as they did. Most want to instil the principles and benefits of a well-balanced diet in their children, so that they understand that moderation in everything is the key to a happy and healthy lifestyle free of weight issues.

At the end of the day, however, children usually become overweight when they start comfort-eating and using food as an emotional crutch when they're feeling unhappy, stressed or even celebrating - in fact, anything unusual will send them heading for the fridge. The less children associate feeling low with having some chocolate to make them feel better, the less likely it is that they will become overweight. Similarly, an important way in which parents can help their children to avoid becoming overweight is to reward them with activities rather than food. I'm not saying that you shouldn't give your children treats or rewards in the form of food, but children should be - and feel - rewarded in other ways, too.

Finally, how your child eats is just as important as what they eat - in fact, I would suggest that it's slightly more important, because wolfing down their meals and not concentrating on their food will deprive them of the physiological feedback mechanisms of satiety that help them to recognise when they're full. Getting them used to sitting down at the table to eat, instead of in front of the TV, and to taking breaks between mouthfuls, instead of eating too quickly, are just two simple habits that will help them to stay slim and healthy in the years to come.

webTitle: What makes a blockbuster movie? Love, ghosts and dogs

fields.headline: What makes a blockbuster movie? Love, ghosts and dogs
fields.standfirst: Movies that caught mood of the age
fields.trailText: Movies that caught mood of the age
fields.body:
f there is no obvious blockbuster to catch at the cinema this holiday season, film fans should look to the past. A book published tomorrow celebrates the history of the biggest-hitting films released in every year since 1930 and reveals what constitutes a winning commercial formula.

The essential ingredients turn out to include dwarfs, robbers, singing nuns, sharks and, more than anything else, ghosts.

Robert Tanitch's book Blockbuster lays out for the first time the chronological story of the biggest box office sensations. His list is accompanied by full credits, an encapsulation of the plot and the titles of the opposition.

While there are many well-known favourites, there are surprises too. For instance, while the sequels Terminator 2 and Home Alone 2 both made the grade in the early Nineties, neither of the original films were the most successful in their year.

'The outstanding films from each year are sometimes a very good indication of their historical moment,' says Tanitch. 'But what is really remarkable is how little the cinema-going public has really changed. They want the same things: disaster, divorce, Dalmatians - in fact, all sorts of cute dogs.'

Action and special effects have always been a huge draw. However, Tanitch believes that certain forms of entertainment have cyclical phases of popularity. The early Fifties was, for example, the era of unbeatable biblical spectaculars, such as Samson and Delilah and Ben-Hur .

Tanitch's list shows that the highest-grossing films each year have fallen into just a few basic categories.

Audiences have always liked to be scared and the most successful horror movies of all time, relative to their competitors, are Dracula in 1930, Frankenstein the next year, and the Fay Wray version of King Kong the following year. The horror movie did not come back into its own until the Seventies when The Exorcist took the crown in 1973 and Jaws followed in its wake in 1975.

Audiences now seem to require an element of comedy if a horror story is to be taken to the bosom of the modern family (such as Ghostbusters and Men in Black ).

The musical, once the soul of Hollywood, also took a severe dip in popularity. The length of the reign of the Technicolor musical is marked out in Tanitch's list by the 1958 Rodgers and Hammerstein hit, South Pacific, and the last flings of Fiddler on the Roof and Grease in the Seventies.

Comedy is now an element in most popular films, but an entirely comic screenplay has rarely written its name all over the box office receipts.

An out-and-out love story, on the other hand, has proved more bankable. Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert started the trend in 1934 with It Happened One Night and in 1939 Gable was back again with Vivien Leigh in Gone with the Wind. There are only four other truly romantic films on his list, including, of course, Love Story in 1970.

There is only one category that confounds analysis. Every few years a movie emerges from the pack which defines its age and knocks others from contention. The identities of these 'mood' movies are among the most interesting of Tanitch's list.

In 1942 we have Mrs Miniver, in which Greer Garson plays the English rose who keeps a stiff upper lip as war rages. Then in 1967 comes The Graduate, and two years later the buddy movie Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid speaks volumes for the nostalgia of the period.

In 1979 Kramer vs Kramer chronicled the pressures on the modern home front and Dustin Hoffman reappeared with his 1988 movie, Rain Man.

The most pronounced trend, looking back at the past 70 years of blockbusters, is the growing dominance of films made for children, from Walt Disney classics to ET - The Extra Terrestrial in 1981.

Screenwriters have had to adapt to a hard economic truth: they must appeal to a youth audience, or fail to make it big.

Blockbusters is published by Batsford at £14.99

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Walks, work and kayaking - prince mucks in on Chile trip

fields.headline: Walks, work and kayaking - prince mucks in on Chile trip
fields.standfirst:
William mixes with 'some real characters' on Operation Raleigh

Special report: The future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: William mixes with 'some real characters' on Operation Raleigh
fields.body:
Prince William yesterday allowed pictures of his gap year visit to Chile to be distributed to British newspapers, writes Ben Summerskill. The Prince is spending 10 weeks in South America with a Raleigh International expedition for young people. As well as walking in the Andes and kayaking along the Patagonian coast, the 18-year-old has spent four weeks doing community work in Tortel, a coastal village. He has been teaching English to local schoolchildren and helping construct boardwalks and wooden waste bins.

A Raleigh staff member said the Prince was 'a very comfortable person, a genuine person, very open and honest'. The Prince said: 'I'm with a group of people I wouldn't normally be with. There are some real characters who don't hold back any words at all.'

He is sleeping in a former nursery classroom with 15 others - 'The living conditions here aren't exactly what I'm used to' - who share two toilets and a makeshift shower. During his visit William has been nicknamed 'el principe' by locals and 'Little Princess' by his British contemporaries, 27 of whom are on Raleigh's 'at risk' programme, which takes socially excluded young people.

The Prince will spend Christmas at Sandringham. He starts studying the history of art at St Andrews University next September.

webTitle: Observer Christmas appeal: Child victims of Africa's 'World War'

fields.headline: Child victims of Africa's 'World War'
fields.standfirst: In the second week of our appeal,  Burhan Wazir looks at the work of British charity Merlin, fighting infant mortality in one of the poorest regions of the Congo
fields.trailText: In the second week of our appeal,  Burhan Wazir looks at the work of British charity Merlin, fighting infant mortality in one of the poorest regions of the Congo
fields.body:
Anne Mette Kjaerby, 34, has returned from Maniema, in the eastern part of the Congo, where Merlin, the British charity she works for, helps doctors and nurses to fight infant mortality. For her seven months on site, Kjaerby was the only Westerner in the region. Having returned only two days ago, she sat in her flat in Bayswater, west London, and explained Merlin's involvement.

There is a high child mortality rate: four in 10 children die from a variety of causes, including complications at birth and poor diet. Merlin first moved to the Congo in 1997 after a successful Rwandan programme. The charity is the only one working in the country and runs a health centre project that supplies 25 hospitals. Water and sanitation are also a daily priority.

'Merlin's health care project for mothers and their children is very important,' says Kjaerby. 'With a lack of education in the area, people just don't know the economic problems that a large family can have. And there is still a notion that large families are important. Women, in the region, still have quite a limited role in society.'

Kjaerby says her time in the country was frustrated by the reluctance of men to engage in pre and post-natal care for their wives. 'Men are not expected to turn up and watch the birth itself.

Far from it. They are normally found out in the fields with other men. So there is a genuine cause for concern here.'

Emphasising the importance of family planning is a difficult process - the average household consists of six children. Contraceptives are not always used because almost half of the region's nearly-three million population are Catholics and there is a sizeable Muslim population of around 10 per cent. The use of contraceptives is also regarded as a sign of loose morals - likened to prostitution. 'It is difficult teaching the importance of contraception to religious groups,' says Kjaerby. 'It is a slow process that cannot be rushed. You have first to teach them that contraception and family planning shouldn't infringe on their religious beliefs.'

The area is fraught, with frequent clashes between guerrilla groups. When Laurent Kabila marched into Kinshasa, the capital, in May, 1997, overthrowing Mobutu Sese Seko, the corrupt dictator, he proclaimed himself emancipator of the new Democratic Republic of Congo.

The country is still in a wretched state. On the third anniversary of Kabila's rise to power, the Panafrican News Agency reported that the country's infrastructure was 'in total chaos'. Schemes to rehabilitate hospitals and industry had been stalled, dirt, decay and disease were rife, and more than 60 per cent of the working population had no jobs.

All of Merlin's work is achieved against the backdrop of full-scale war. For two years, six African nations and a dozen guerrilla groups have overrun the country in a conflict likened to Africa's First World War. And despite last summer's peace accord, the fighting continues.

'Locals are understandably scared of the fighting,' says Kjaerby. 'So there are all kinds of other problems that need addressing. Counselling sessions are needed to help mothers get over the trauma of the loss of their children. But all these things take time: you work with whatever resources you have.'

Alternatively, you can make a credit card donation by calling 020 7378 4845 or by email to fundraising@merlin.org.uk

webTitle: £7,000 - the price of a badger's life

fields.headline: £7,000 - the price of a badger's life
fields.standfirst:
20,000 badgers will die in a cull to test whether they spread bovine TB. Antony Barnett reports on the battle between animal activists and the Government

Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: 20,000 badgers will die in a cull to test whether they spread bovine TB.  Antony Barnett reports on the battle between animal activists and the Government
fields.body:
Debbie Vincent brandished a pair of bolt-cutters, produced from her ripped Barbour jacket, and began cutting through the bars of a rusty cage placed outside a badger sett in the heart of Exmoor.

As torrential rain fell and thunderclaps sounded, she cut the cage into quarters and hurled it down a grassy bank into a raging river. The cage, laced with peanuts, was intended to snare any badger tempted by the easy meal. A trigger traps the badger, slamming the iron doors shut.

The animals' torment would be ended when an official from the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food arrives at dawn, tips the cage on its side, puts a pistol to the badger's head and blows the creature's brains out. The animal would then be put into a body bag, hurled into the back of a Land-Rover and taken to a government lab to be cut up and examined for traces of bovine turberculosis.

This is the disease which is sparking real fear in a farming community still devastated by the legacy of mad cow disease. Cases of TB- infected cattle have soared in recent years and farmers blame the badgers for spreading the disease to their cows by urinating on grazing pasture to mark their territory.

As a result, more than 20,000 badgers are to die in a prolonged cull over the next few years. But protesters claim there has never been any firm scientific evidence to prove the link between badgers and TB in cattle.

Two years ago the Government set up trials in 10 'hot spot' regions of the country where more than 20,000 of Britain's badgers would be exterminated. If TB in the trial regions of the badger cull falls, the link will be proved.

Horrified by the killing, a coalition of hundreds of animal rights activists around the country are determined to stop the cull, using direct action to destroy Maff's traps.

Not only do the campaigners argue there is no proof that badgers pass TB on to cows, but they also believe that the problems are down to intensive farming techniques. They want resources spent on promoting better animal husbandry techniques and the development of vaccines.

Exmoor is the seventh 'killing' zone so far to witness the daily battles between the activists and Maff officials. Debbie Vincent, who has been going out day and night to free badgers from traps, said: 'It is cruel and completely unscientific. There is no proof of any badger giving a cow TB. People can be put in prison for killing badgers, but this Government is using barbaric techniques to kill thousands of healthy badgers who are harming no one.'

Official figures published this month reveal that the cull's cost is running at about £7 million a year - or £7,000 for each badger killed. This is more than the annual income of some small farmers and the spiralling cost of the trials has brought the animal rights activists an unlikely ally in their opposition to the cull.

While most local farmers are highly critical of the actions of the campaigners, they are growing increasingly hostile to the trials, which will not deliver any results for another four years.

Barry Jones, chairman of the National Beef Association's TB committee, said: 'Our view is that the trials are flawed at a time when the number of new cases of bovine TB is getting out of control. Farmers say they cannot wait for results ... Their businesses are at risk now.' The fear is that frustrated farmers are killing any badgers that appear on their land. Not only is this illegal but it undermines the whole study because it makes it dif ficult to compare trial areas.

One farmer, who did not want to be named, said: 'I can't believe the taxpayer is forking out £7,000 for every badger killed. If I see any on my land I'd do it for free.'

Chris Everard owns a large farm in Exmoor which has had five outbreaks of TB since 1993. He has no doubt badgers are infecting his cows. He said: 'These trials are a waste of time and money. They will take years to prove what we already know; by then it will be too late for many. There is also the view that, even if the trials proves a conclusive link between badgers and the spread of TB, the Government is unlikely to order the com plete extermination of the badger population because it would cause political uproar.

Everard believes the best way forward is for the Government to plough money into developing a vaccine to protect badgers from the disease. He said: 'In New Zealand they have developed a vaccine that stops possums contracting bovine TB. Over there, possums are blamed for spreading the disease to cattle. It seems hard to believe that the science could not be adapted for badgers.'

While Everard might agree with the animal rights campaigners on the need for a vaccine, out on the moors the battle is intensifying. Debbie has smashed up another two cages and is on her mobile to Gary and Joanne, planning the next act of sabotage.

Chris Everard owns a large farm in Exmoor which has had five outbreaks of TB since 1993. He has no doubt badgers are infecting his cows. He said: 'These trials are a waste of time and money. They will take years to prove what we already know; by then it will be too late for many. There is also the view that, even if the trials proves a conclusive link between badgers and the spread of TB, the Government is unlikely to order the com plete extermination of the badger population because it would cause political uproar. Everard believes the best way forward is for the Government to plough money into developing a vaccine to protect badgers from the disease. He said: 'In New Zealand they have developed a vaccine that stops possums contracting bovine TB. Over there, possums are blamed for spreading the disease to cattle. It seems hard to believe that the science could not be adapted for badgers.' While Everard might agree with the animal rights campaigners on the need for a vaccine, out on the moors the battle is intensifying. Debbie has smashed up another two cages and is on her mobile to Gary and Joanne, planning the next act of sabotage. www.maff.gov.uk/animalh/tb/ TB in cattle and badgers (Agriculture Ministry site) www.geocities.com/RainForest/ Canopy/2626/ National Federation of Badger Groups www.badgers.org.uk/brockwatch/ Brockwatch badger pages

webTitle: Van Gogh letters shed new light on his 'madness'

fields.headline: Van Gogh letters shed new light on his 'madness'
fields.trailText: Fresh evidence of the nature of the madness that dogged Vincent Van Gogh and led to his early death has come to light in a newly discovered letter written by the Dutch painter days after he cut off part of his ear.
fields.byline: Vanessa Thorpe, arts correspondent and John Vincent
fields.body:
Fresh evidence of the nature of the madness that dogged Vincent Van Gogh and led to his early death has come to light in a newly discovered letter written by the Dutch painter days after he cut off part of his ear.

In the 111 years since his death, art historians and doctors have put forward a range of explanations for the violent symptoms exhibited by Van Gogh. Rival theories have suggested he was a manic depressive, suffered temporal lobe epilepsy, was poisoned by the wormwood in absinthe, had inherited the rare liver disease, porphyria, and even that he simply acted mad whenever he was emotionally thwarted.

Now a letter in the artist's own hand, written to his friend, the painter Arnold Koning, shows that the cause of his illness was just as perplexing to Van Gogh himself.

The four-page letter, dated 19 January 1889, was sent to Koning in answer to a card the artist received while he was recovering from his self-inflicted injury in hospital in southern France. In it, he poses questions about the sudden deterioration of his mental health. 'I received your postcard in the hospital at Arles,' he begins, 'where I have been quartered following an attack of something the matter with my brains, or otherwise fever, which had nearly passed off already.'

Three years earlier, at the age of 33, Van Gogh had travelled to Paris and became a particularly close friend of Paul Gauguin. But on Christmas Eve 1888, they argued badly and Van Gogh lunged at Gauguin before mutilating himself by cutting a large slice from his ear. He wrapped the severed piece in paper and gave it to a prostitute. This bizarre behaviour prompted his brother, Theo, to have him institutionalised in Arles.

In the letter to Koning, Van Gogh claims he did not know what had happened to him. 'And as for the causes and consequences of said illness,' he writes, 'I think I shall be wise to leave the solving of these problems to the fortuitous discussions of the Dutch catechists, that is to say whether I am mad or not, or whether I have been mad, and am still mad, in some imagination of a purely sculptural nature.'

The date of the letter, which is expected to reach more than £100,000 at auction at Sotheby's in New York on Wednesday and which belongs to a descendant of Koning, marks the beginning of the end of a productive period for the artist. Al-though he sold only one painting for 400 francs in his lifetime, he painted more than 200 canvases in the 15 months from February 1888.

The letter goes on to describe the portrait the artist had on his easel at the time. Comparing his output to that of a Dutch philosopher of the day, Frederik Van Eeden, he wonders whether he is artistically capable of singing 'a lullaby in colours' and decides to leave that 'to the critics'.

'But we talked all this over sufficiently at the time, didn't we?' he goes on. 'I mean the eternal problem of colours, which leads us on as far as our tranquillity of mind will allow.' Van Gogh then mentions the famous picture he had just painted of his doctor, Félix Rey, now in the Pushkin Museum, Moscow. 'At any rate,' he writes, 'on leaving the hospital, I made a portrait of my own doctor. And I haven't wholly lost my equilibrium as a painter.'

The clarity of thought in the letter supports the theory that Van Gogh's bout of illness had been brought on by poor diet and alcohol. The symptoms of acute intermittent porphyria - skin rashes, sensitivity to light, indigestion and mental disturbances - are brought on by both.

In the past, art historians have pointed to Van Gogh's periods of intense activity as evidence of manic depression.

Despite an improvement after his stay in the hospital, he declined again. In the last 70 days of his life, Van Gogh painted 70 canvases. On 29 July 1890, he died at 37 from a self-inflicted bullet wound.

webTitle: Medicating unhappiness

fields.headline: Medicating unhappiness
fields.trailText: How much do antidepressants help?
fields.body:
The number of people taking antidepressants has more than doubled in the past 10 years. How much they are actually being helped is a matter of some debate.

There are currently three main types of antidepressant on the market and they all work in roughly the same way - by boosting levels of the brain chemicals that improve mood. The difference between them lies with the chemical they act upon - the group called tricyclics (like amitriptyline) work on noradrenaline.

The group known as SSRIs - or Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (of which Prozac is one) work on serotonin and a third group (which don't have a catch-all name and include the drug venlafaxine) work on both. The recently developed SSRIs are the most widely used, but according to Dr Cosmo Hallström, fellow of the Royal College of Psychiatrists, 'There have been no major improvements in the efficacy of antidepressants since the 1940s when tricyclics were first discovered.

Yes, the newer drugs may have fewer side effects, but in terms of what they can achieve, nothing much has changed.' Most doctors say that only around 70 per cent of those who take antidepressants actually receive any benefit from them, and that without some form of cognitive therapy used alongside them, the majority of patients will relapse once the treatment is over.

This is particularly true for those with mild to moderate depression where the biological link is likely to be less intrinsic to the condition. Charles Medwar, director of medical research group Social Audit, also points out a placebo effect with antidepressants. Indeed, a recent study at the University of California's Neuropsychiatric Institute found that while just over 50 per cent of patients given Prozac reported an improvement in their symptoms, so did an almost identical number of a group who were given a placebo drug. So why do we now reach for them so readily?

'There really isn't much choice for a GP who has around five minutes to spend with a patient,' says Dr Iain McGilchrist, deputy medical director of the Priory Clinic, Hayes. 'Determining true depression takes a lot of investigation - problems such as alcoholism, anxiety disorders or even physical problems such as disorders of the thyroid can all hide behind depressive symptoms, but the average GP can't find all that out in the time available.' The result is that not all of the 20 million people on antidepressants in the UK should be on them. Often what we end up medicating is not the pathological condition of deep despair and lack of hope that categorises clinical depression, but another illness or, increasingly, merely the natural sadness that we all experience at one time or another.

'There are a lot of people taking antidepressants for unhappiness because they don't know where else to turn,' comments Cosmo Hallström. 'There is a distinction between depression and unhappiness. Depression is an illness, it's pathological and it's unhealthy - unhappiness is a normal response to a bad situation.' Charles Medawar says that the definition of what depression is and therefore when it should be medicated has changed dramatically over the last 10 years. 'So anti-depressants can be prescribed for a problem like grief as well as for a more severe affliction like clinically defined depression.'

Obviously this doesn't mean that it is always wrong to prescribe drugs. 'For people with severe depression antidepressants are often the only answer,' says Dr McGilchrist. 'And for those with even mild to moderate true depression, antidepressants can help break the cycle of despair and allow people to respond to cognitive therapy.'

There are currently 26 drugs in development for depression in the US (the equivalent UK figures are kept secret), of these the majority will still work using the SSRI route. 'None of them really offers a new type of action that we need to improve efficacy,' says Dr Hallström. 'The problem is that because we don't fully understand the mechanism of depression we don't know how to move forward. Companies are looking at synthesising herbal remedies such as St John's Wort, they're looking at acting on other neurotransmitters such as dopamine or at influencing neurotransmitter levels at a different point in the process than the drugs work on now, but the truth is no one really knows where to go next with drugs.'

Which is why research from the National Institute of Health in Washington may be so exciting. A team there has found that magnetically stimulating the part of the brain involved in producing sadness seems to reset the brain in people with depression. It's controversial and it needs years more research but at least it's a way out of the serotonin cycle that currently has us trapped using ineffective treatment for a condition the World Health Organisation say will be the second biggest cause of death by the year 2020.

'I see antidepressants as the biological equivalent of thumping a TV on the top to help improve the picture,' says Charles Medawar. 'It works but it's not the most effective method of solving the problem. My belief is that in 30 years, our grandchildren will look at the way we treated depression in the 20th century with the same disbelief as we look at the way we prescribed tranquillisers 30 or 40 years ago now. I hope I'm proved right.'

webTitle: First human learned to swim before she walked

fields.headline: First human learned to swim before she walked
fields.standfirst: The old notion that man evolved from the hot, dry plains is being swept aside by a feminist theory, reports  Robin McKie
fields.trailText: The old notion that man evolved from the hot, dry plains is being swept aside by a feminist theory, reports Robin McKie
fields.body:
It was one of the most outrageous, improbable evolutionary ideas ever proposed: humans are amphibious apes who triumphed only when women started to stand on their own two feet at the water's edge.

But now the idea, derided for most of the past 30 years by academics, is becoming respectable. Key scientists, over recent months, have announced their support for Elaine Morgan's controversial aquatic ape hypothesis.

Sympathisers include the US philosopher Daniel Dennett, the distinguished South African palaeontologist Philip Tobias, and the natural historian Sir David Attenborough, who is to deal with the theory in his next TV series, Mammals.

In addition the Norwegian Academy of Sciences has just awarded Morgan a medal in honour of her work, while New Scientist ran a feature supporting the theory.

The aquatic ape theory was proposed in 1960 by British biologist Sir Alister Hardy, who argued that apes evolved into humans when they descended from the trees to live, not on the savannah as was then supposed, but beside the sea. To keep their heads above water, our ancestors evolved an upright stance, freeing our hands to make tools to crack open shellfish. Once safely in the swim of things, we lost our body hair and instead developed a thick layer of sub-cutaneous fat to keep warm in the water. This explains why new-born babies can float, unlike other apes, he said.

Hardy's ideas were ignored by mainstream scientists, but not by Morgan, a feminist writer and TV dramatist who had become enraged by popular anthropologists who claimed that apes evolved into humans when males, not females, began to hunt and kill. Men lost their fur to keep cool and evolved big brains to help co-ordinate hunts, ran the theory. Women followed in their wake.

'It was macho nonsense, and I hated it,' she told The Observer last week. 'Then I heard about Hardy's work and I thought that has got to be it, that makes sense.'

Morgan transformed the ideas of a somewhat astonished Hardy in her book, The Descent of Woman. Females led the way to the beach, she said, arguing that women can 'survive immersion in cold water for longer, and the one athletic sport at which they outdo males is long-distance swimming'.

She envisaged a group of apes becoming trapped on an island in a flooded valley or by the sea. To survive they became adept divers, and had to develop more complex ways of breathing - an adaptation that aided the evolution of human speech. Morgan pointed out that the patterns of fine hairs of our bodies - which sweep across our backs and down our spines - are consistent with those of a marine animal, not a land one. We are primates born of water, she says.

Her ideas were ridiculed, however, and until recently were shunned by academics who insisted that humans evolved on the searing heat of North-East Africa's expanding savannahs. However, this idea was dealt a blow last year when Tobias, once a savannah supporter, announced that his research showed that Africa possessed little open grassland at the time, and was most probably covered with vast bodies of water.

Tobias's support for the aquatic ape hypothesis is also backed by Attenborough, who used his recent presidency of the British Association to organise the country's first full scientific debate of the theory. 'Five million years ago, north-east Africa was affected by techtonic rifting that would have created flooded forests and isolated islands. We also know now that when primates, such as proboscis monkeys and chimpanzees, get caught in flooded land they will wade and carry infants. So the idea makes sense.'

The American philosopher Dennett is a convert. 'When in the company of distinguished biologists, evolutionary theorists and other experts, I have often asked them to tell me, please, why Elaine Morgan must be wrong. I haven't yet had a reply worth mentioning.'

Not everyone has been turned to the cause. Many palaeontologists complain that Morgan's dating is vague. They also point out that there was a gap of several million years between the appearance of features like smooth skin and upright stance in humans, which suggests our stay by the sea would have had to have been an improbably long one.

Prof Chris Stringer, of the Natural History Museum, London, accepts the theory's explanation for our upright stance is as good as any other. 'However, we don't have proof, and in combining this idea with so many other suggestions - about our voices, brains and tools - aquatic ape supporters are going too far.'

But the theory has gained ground in recent years, much to Morgan's delight. 'The scientific establishment is retreating in good order,' she said. Or as New Scientist put it: 'The tide is turning.'

webTitle: Focus: Europe - the elephant test

fields.headline: Europe - the elephant test
fields.standfirst:
It's got a President and a parliament, a currency, a court and a Champions' League and now it's even got an army. So is it a Superstate? Well, not exactly. The Nice summit is part of the EU's development into a completely new sort of alliance, say experts: Special report by Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor, and Denis Staunton in Nice, with Andrew Osborn in Brussels

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The Nice summit is part of the EU's development into a completely new sort of alliance, say experts.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, foreign affairs editor, and Denis Staunton in Nice, with Andrew Osborn in Brussels
fields.body:
Call it the elephant test. If it looks like an elephant and sounds like an elephant then - the test goes - it is an elephant you're dealing with. Last week the elephant test, originally outlined by William Hague, was being applied to the emerging shape of the European Union.

If it has a flag - the Eurosceptics say - and its own anthem, standard passports and a single currency; if it has a president and laws; if it is going to have a constitution and an army, then that's a European superstate you're dealing with.

What that means has been spelt out in apocalyptic terms by the same Eurosceptics who have been using the elephant test to divine the future structure of the EU. Writing in the Mail on Sunday , John Laughland has warned that such a superstate would be worse than Stalin's Soviet Union.

In a European superstate, the Eurosceptics say, British soldiers will be forced to march to 'President' Romano Prodi's tune. The blue and gold of Europe's flag will flutter above our public buildings - No 10 included. Centuries of British culture, our common law and political traditions would be consigned to history. Then, as Tory MP John Redwood predicts, the United Kingdom will have perished as an independent nation.

This weekend as Europe's leaders met in Nice for the most fractious EU summit in a decade, no one underestimated its scope and importance. Officials in Nice have drawn comparisons with the Congress of Vienna in 1815 and the Treaty of Versailles in 1919, insisting that the treaty which emerges will define the shape of Europe for the next 100 years. But the unanswered question remains: Exactly what kind of a beastie will the new Europe be? The answer, according to academics, constitutional experts, diplomats and European officials interviewed by The Observer, is that it will fall far short of a superstate, though they are divided about what form the EU will eventually take.

The question will not be answered in Nice alone. Behind the momentum for greater European integration, there exists a separate momentum that is making Europe more homogeneous by the day. Nor is the changing culture exclusively European.

From Trieste to Tralee, a generation of Europeans has grown up watching the same Hollywood films and television shows, reading the same books, wearing clothes from Gap and drinking Starbucks' coffee. Despite the tentative emergence of a European identity, that identity is defined by the globalisation of culture as a shared sense of a European values. And, for all the warnings of the Eurosceptics, one feature of this new European identity is undeniable: in spite of all the efforts of the French, the lingua franca of the businessmen, officials, and academics of the emerging European generation is English.

One powerful image of a new Europe that is developing outside the political debate is provided by the Eurostar service from Brussels to London. Last Friday evening David, an 18-year-old student was leaning up against the newsagent's wall opposite the Eurostar terminal in the Belgian capital. 'I feel more European than Belgian,' he said 'but that's probably because I'm of Italian origin. Europe is a strong state and it's going to get stronger.'

On the train itself Maxim, Stephanie and Melanie were travelling home to France from university in Brussels. 'We all feel European,' Stephanie said, 'but we can still keep our national identity.'

'There are two real tests,' Dr Julia Smith, director of the European programme at the Royal Institute of International Affairs, says, calling from Zagreb, where she has been explaining the intricacies of the Nice summit to an audience of Croatians - whose country aspires to membership of the expanded EU.

'Is there going to be a single European defence force - a real European army - and a single tax regime throughout Europe? Those are the two things that are stopping us from becoming a European superstate. The reality is that they are never going to happen.

'The French position on the European rapid reaction force, all the posturing, is purely for domestic consumption. The real problem, I'm afraid, is the British media. Take the claims that Germany and Italy are planning a new inter-governmental conference after Nice to draw up a constitution to create a European superstate. What absolute nonsense!'

Her view is shared by other prominent British academics and historians, including Eric Hobsbawm, Norman Davies, Corelli Barnett and Larry Siedentop.

'The fact is,' says Hobsbawm, 'that the idea of the nation state which is sovereign, independent and that no one interferes with - the nineteenth-century idea - no longer corresponds to the reality of the world today. There is one such state - the United States - and perhaps Japan and China also qualify. But in the rest of the world we are subject to the influence of the international markets, global corporations, bodies like the World Trade Organisation set up by treaty or convention that affect all our lives.

'We live in a world where more and more states are banding together - whether in Europe, the Americas or Asia - to make policies that benefit the member states. That does not mean new superstates are being created, rather that we are living in a world where layers of governance overlap in many different ways.

'The real problem Europe is facing is not one of the creation of a superstate, but of the balance of power of states within such an organic grouping that may eventually represent 27 states. Those problems will be enormous.'

Historian Norman Davies too is dubious about the use of terms such as superstate to describe the future enlargement and political development of Europe. 'The debate is presented in terms of two extreme positions, neither of which is going to apply to a Europe of the future. The first describes an amorphous, glorified Common Market of the kind we started out with, foreseeing no further radical changes to the structure despite the challenges of enlargement. That can't go on.

'The second describes a classic superstate which would have a head of state, an executive in permanent session, a legislative assembly to whom it is answerable and its own individual judiciary. There is no sign of that happening or any likelihood of it in the future. The truth is that what we are seeing is the development of a new kind of polity of the kind that has never been seen before.'

Davies believes drawing up a European constitution of the kind envisaged by Germany and Italy for a new inter-governmental conference four years after Nice, as well as a charter of rights, would not qualify the EU for statehood, let alone super-statehood.

'You cannot have a social club or economic organisation - or even a football club - without an executive that organises it on the basis of an understood set of rules. At the moment that executive - contrary to what the Eurosceptics would have you believe - is the Council of Ministers, not the European Commission under Romano Prodi... And those Ministers represent their national interests, not the interests of a superstate.'

Larry Siedentop, an Oxford politics don and author of the recently published Democracy in Europe , believes that a 'federal superstate' in the European context is 'a complete misnomer'. 'Ultimately the present moves may lead to a kind of federation but a different kind of entity than we have seen elsewhere.

'The important thing is not to confuse centralism - of the kind espoused by the French - with federalism.' It might, he says, look 'something like a state', although of the loosest possible kind. Indeed, experts in European law believe that far from seeing more power transferred from sovereign states to a 'European state', any effort to draw up a constitution post-Nice, drawing on powers already invested in the existing European treaties such as Maastricht would - in reality - define the practical limits of centralised European powers.

'Rather than expanding the power of the Commission or the EU they want to limit it... Indeed what we are seeing at Nice is not the building of a superstate but the opposite in the way in which individual states are fighting to retain their national identities within Europe.'

It is a trend reflected in the development of a European jurisprudence which, the Eurosceptics warn, would subsume British common law. It is a view not shared by the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Bingham, who, in a landmark ruling on a European human rights case last week, said the justice system in the EU allowed flexibility to reflect national priorities.

'The problem is that Britain is a society totally geared to winning or losing, and that is how they approach EU summits - like a football game. That is wrong. What is not being understood in Britain is that within Europe we want everyone to win. That is what is driving all this.

'People seem to connect the idea of a constitution with a superstate. Look, the policy-making power of anything in the world that you might want to call a superstate is defined by the size of its budget. All-powerful Brussels? Ten people with more clout in Europe than Prodi

1: Alan Greenspan

Chairman of American Federal Reserve, architect of US economic boom. World economists hang on his every word. A soothing Greenspan speech has the power to calm agitated global markets. Has been called the world's most powerful unelected figure.

2: President Bill Clinton

Leader of the world's remaining superpower, his influence extends beyond the US borders and sways world foreign and economic policy.

3: Bill Gates

Chairman of Microsoft, which dominates the global software industry. He is worth $60bn. A philantropist, he has pledged to leave 95 per cent of his wealth to good causes.

4: Vladimir Putin

President of Russia. His country is not the superpower it was, but Putin is still a world force. He presides over a massive army and has influence over foreign policy elsewhere.

5: George Soros

President and chairman of Soros Fund Management LLC. World's most powerful financial speculator and philanthropist, responsible for Black Wednesday eight years ago and collapse of Asian economies in the Nineties. In 1999 donated $560 million 'towards building and maintaining open societies'.

6: Wim Duisenberg

President, European Central Bank. Europe's top central banker, Dutch Duisenberg is now dubbed 'Mr euro'. A formidable force in world finance.

7: Kofi Annan

United Nations Secretary-General. A career diplomat, Annan has reinvigorated the UN and dared to ask if it should set up a dedicated peace-keeping office.

8: Madeline Albright

The first female American Secretary of State. Czech-born and rumoured to be considering running for Czech president. Major player in American and international politics.

9: Pascal Lamy

European commissioner for trade, Frenchman Lamy is Europe's trade tsar. Sees dark and bright side of globalisation and aims to get more of the bright side by bringing governance up to speed with globalisation.

10: Pope John Paul II

In 1978 Karol Wojtyla became the first non-Italian pope since Hadrian VI in 1522-3. The most travelled pope in history, has a global congregation of close to a billion Catholics.

webTitle: Huge expansion is planned for strained airports

fields.headline: Huge expansion is planned for strained airports
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Faced with a near trebling of passenger numbers over the next 20 years, the Government will this week announce proposals for a building programme to vastly expand the capacity of Britain's airports and a relaxation of rules on night flights.
fields.body:
Faced with a near trebling of passenger numbers over the next 20 years, the Government will this week announce proposals for a building programme to vastly expand the capacity of Britain's airports and a relaxation of rules on night flights.

A consultation document on the future of aviation is set to ignite battles with environmental groups, residents and local authorities as fierce as those over Heathrow's Terminal Five and the second runway at Manchester.

The plans - to be outlined by Transport Minister Lord Macdonald on Tuesday - include a huge expansion of regional airports. A second priority will be to build new runways and terminals for airports around London.

Sixty local authorities will launch a pre-emptive strike tomorrow with the publication of a study highlighting the environmental and economic costs of allowing unrestricted growth in the number of flights. The Strategic Aviation Special Interest Group of the Local Government Association will be urging the Government to look at alternative ways of developing the economy.

The Government will set out ways to meet the growing demand for air travel up to 2030. The Department of the Environment Transport and the Regions recently forecast that the number of passengers would grow from 160 million to as many as 461m over the next 20 years.

The document is set to infuriate environmentalists by suggesting there is not much that can be done to slow the growth in air traffic.

The Government wants to introduce a tax on aviation fuel, but thinks that it would only have a marginal impact on traffic numbers, and can only been done in co-operation with all other world powers, including the US.

Instead, it will suggest ways to cater for the growing numbers of passengers. The top priority will be looking at how regional airports - including Birmingham, Liverpool and Newcastle - can be extended. The DETR is already carrying out studies on building up regional airports.

The paper will also suggest that the rules on night flights should be relaxed. At the moment, night flights are restricted at certain hours and must meet noise quotas. However, the Government considers that the benefit to the economy far outweighs the cost in terms of noise for people living near airports. It will suggest changes to the way that planes take off and land to minimise the noise.

It will also set the ball rolling for the expansion of airports around London, including a new runway at Gatwick, increasing its capacity by 40m passengers. Stansted could also get a second runway, and Heathrow's controversial Terminal Five is almost certain to go ahead.

Environmental groups are pressing the Government to reduce demand for flights by improving rail facilities across the country and to Europe. They claim that aviation - which pays virtually no tax - is heavily subsidised and that passengers should pay the full environmental costs. Aviation is considered to be the fastest growing contributor to global warming.

Roger Higman, transport campaigner at Friends of the Earth, said: 'Anyone who lives near a disused RAF base with a runway should be concerned. The Government has to admit that we're going to have problems in the air with crowded skies, problems getting people to airports, and problems with pollution.'

fields.headline: Crash fears as planes fly closer
fields.standfirst:
Experts warn collision could happen over Europe as safety margins are cut to make space in the skies and pressure grows on controllers

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Experts warn collision could happen over Europe as safety margins are cut to make space in the skies and pressure grows on controllers
fields.body:
Plans to allow passenger planes to fly closer together in the overcrowded skies above Britain have outraged safety experts. From next spring air traffic control chiefs plan to halve the minimum space separating jets to 1,000ft at the higher levels.

The news comes as senior industry experts are expressing fears that a mid-air crash over Europe is 'imminent'.

Controllers in Scotland, who deal with more than a thousand planes a day flying across the north Atlantic at these higher levels, told The Observer that such narrow separation had been known to produce violent turbulence, causing jumbo jets to roll without warning.

They warned that introducing similar moves with only minimal training into the teeming skies over Europe, where most aircraft are climbing or descending and military traffic regularly causes safety alerts, would reduce the margin for error and 'could be very scary'.

A spokesman for the UK controllers' union IPMS said: 'Our chief concern is that controllers are only going to get one day's training now prior to the new system going live in April.'

The row adds to an increasingly chaotic picture of air traffic control across Europe, where the new separation limits will be introduced in 2002, with widespread safety failings and overworked, understaffed services mirroring the problems at the heart of the creaking London ATC system.

Well-placed sources at Eurocontrol told The Observer that soaring traffic over the Continent and serious under-resourcing in radar centres such as Maastricht in the Netherlands posed serious threats. 'Safety has been eroded to the point where the risk of a collision is imminent,' said a senior source.

Other sources say there have been at least 50 safety-related incidents investigated at Maastricht this year, mostly of aircraft infringing legal separation limits, said by one source to be 'a near-miss by another name'. The number is rising dramatically every year, The Observer was told, although official figures have yet to be released.

Other causes of concern at the Maastricht centre include:

 Operating manuals more than five years out of date;

 Controllers adapting to new procedures 'on the job' without simulator training;

 'Vast differences' between controllers over acceptable risk when aircraft converge;

 Lack of preparation for an expected 100 per cent rise in air traffic in the next decade.

One controller said: 'We are in a business that is trying to juggle safety with stuffing as many aircraft into the sky as possible. The fundamental procedures are unsafe.'

The Observer was given a startling insight into the pressures on controllers and gaps in the safety system last week on a visit to the Maastricht control room, the second busiest in Europe after London. It handles up to 100 aircraft and 2,000 passengers in its air space at any one time - around a quarter heading to or from Britain. The centre controls flights above 24,500 feet in an exceptionally busy sector of sky bordering the London control area and extending over parts of France and Germany and all of Belgium and Holland.

Bert Verstappen, a 27-year-old controller from Belgium, is working a Dutch sky sector, eyes glued to his screen in the hushed room, closed off from daylight and fitted with banks of computers. The computers - described by one controller as 'atrocious' - date from 1972. Yet Maastricht is considered one of the most modern of Europe's 65 ATC centres.

Verstappen is tapping coordinates and flight levels into the consul in front of him and talking to the pilots coming in and out of his slice of sky. A controller at Maastricht has a maximum of 25 aircraft under his control at any one time. They handle 6,000 flights each a year, more than any other controllers in Europe.

Referring to the increasing workload, he said: 'We used to peak for 40 minutes at a stretch but now the peaks continue for up to two hours and then it gets very tough.

'That's when the "flow management" unit in Brussels starts restricting flights all over Europe for safety reasons. While pilots everywhere apologise to their frustrated passengers and curse air traffic control, the Brussels unit keeps the aircraft on the ground or forces them to fly in airborne "stacks" waiting to land, threatening gridlock in European air travel.

'If they did not control the flow of aircraft our job would be impossible. We are definitely stretched to the limit.'

Officials complain that one of the biggest operational and safety problems is military traffic, which restricts the capacity available for commercial flights and also causes most of the risk-related incidents when military aircraft cross passenger flightpaths.

Andrew Robinson, a 29-year-old controller from Macclesfield, Cheshire, who works on the busiest sector covered by the Maastricht centre, over Belgium, described a 'near miss' earlier this year. He told The Observer that an Air France pilot had suddenly radioed him from French air space to say the collision warning in his cockpit had gone off and he was frantically climbing to get out of the way of two French air force fighter planes.

Robinson could see the military planes' marks on his radar screen, but when he telephoned the civilian controllers in France they had no idea of the fighters' existence. One of the fighters passed 500ft below the passenger jet - the legal gap is 2,000ft.

Fred Konnemann, a senior Eurocontrol executive at Maastricht, said safety was the top priority and the centre's record was good. It suffered an average of eight near misses a year and had not had a 'Category A' miss with a significant risk of collision in the past three years.

He also insisted that the operational and safety instructions were 'constantly' updated and all controllers were properly trained.

Maastricht safety manager Roger Bartlett said the centre was still implementing a full safety assessment and management system.
