webTitle: Nervous Dixons prays for a very merry Christmas

fields.headline: Nervous Dixons prays for a very merry Christmas
fields.trailText: Dixons has proved the truth of the theory that it is better to travel hopefully than to arrive. The market has been awaiting the sale of its Freeserve offshoot for much of the past six months yet, when it finally came last week, the reaction was to knock more than 12 per cent off its share price.
fields.body:
Dixons has proved the truth of the theory that it is better to travel hopefully than to arrive. The market has been awaiting the sale of its Freeserve offshoot for much of the past six months yet, when it finally came last week, the reaction was to knock more than 12 per cent off its share price.

On the face of it, the reaction is logical enough. Wanadoo, the internet business owned by France Télécom, is offering the equivalent of 153p for every Freeserve share, valuing the British internet service provider at £1.6 billion.

That is just 3p above the price at which Freeserve floated 17 months ago and compares with the March peak of 920p.

More importantly, as far as the market is concerned, it is little over a quarter of the price apparently offered by German group T-Online in June, but rejected.

Critics should not, however, get too carried away. Like the current deal, the aborted T-Online takeover would also have been an all-share offer. T-Online's shares have fallen from DM40 to DM16 over that period.

Given that Dixons would surely have been prevented from selling its shares at least until now, its holding in the combined group would, therefore, be worth little over a third of what it was then. Not such a big difference from the takeover price.

It is also worth remembering that Dixons has invested only around £75,000 in Freeserve, raised close to £100 million from last year's flotation and that its stake in the business is currently worth more than £1bn, on paper.

Of course, Wanadoo's shares could well fall further before Dixons is allowed to offload its stake - it can sell a fifth within the first six months following the completion of the deal and the remainder within five years. But which analyst could say with certainty that Freeserve's shares do not have further to fall?

Add in reports that consumers are already bored with the internet, the slump in advertising as dotcoms become deadcoms, the low level of e-commerce and the rise in unmetered access. These factors will combine to make it even harder for Freeserve to actually make money from its position as Britain's leading ISP.

The sale to Wanadoo effectively removes the risk that Dixons would have to bail out Freeserve when it uses up the £60m cash remaining in the business.

It also makes it easier to separate Dixons' real business of selling computers, camcorders and washing machines from the results of Freeserve. Its stake in the combined group will be just 12.7 per cent, compared with its 80 per cent holding in Freeserve, so it will be treated differently in Dixons' accounts.

Unfortunately, however, the state of that underlying business is looking less healthy than it was.

The evidence from the high street so far is that Christmas is being delayed, and the fear is it may be completely cancelled.

Dixons is still signalling that there is no cause for concern, but the pessimists worry that it is simply playing for time while it waits to see whether sales recover some momentum.

That nervousness is likely to continue until Dixons reports its results, and gives some indication of Christmas trading, on 1 January - so the shares will be volatile until then.

In the longer term, the question is where it goes next. Will it be looking for more acquisitions on the continent, which could put it into competition with Kingfisher? And will its cost-cutting programme be enough to prevent a further erosion of margins?

Those with the stomach for a bit of turbulence should buy for the long term.

Buoyant Bass keeps a cool head

Sir Ian Prosser, chairman of Bass, must be wondering what on earth he has to do to please the City. No sooner has he flogged off his brewing assets - and for a very handsome price - than it is clamouring for a demerger of the restaurant and pubs chain from the hotels business.

Bass does not completely rule it out - a company that can sell its brewing birthright is clearly not going to be emotionally attached to its pubs. But it points to the excellent returns it is currently enjoying from refurbishing both its own estate and the 550 pubs acquired from Allied Domecq, now dubbed the development estate, and hints that it will wait until more of those benefits have flowed to profits before it does anything drastic. It should be careful not to leave it too late.

On the face of it, its pubs chain is doing well. Sales rose almost a fifth and operating profit by a quarter in the year to September. But much of the sales growth came from the Allied pubs; excluding that, sales are down and those falls have continued into the start of the current year.

Bass prefers to concentrate on the potential for improving the Allied estate. Certainly, the rises have been spectacular - a trebling in sales is not unusual. Only 15 per cent of the Allied pubs have been converted so far, so there is still plenty of scope for growth there.

It is also reviewing the future of 1,000 or so underperforming pubs. The review will not be complete until January but if, as the City expects, they are sold, it will highlight the performance of the rest of the estate.

The question is, how long will they continue performing? Food and drink retailing through large chains seems to be a constant race to stay ahead of a fickle public: as soon as a successful format is rolled out, the public gets fed up with it.

Bass's hotel chain is enjoying buoyant trading, with sales up by 36 per cent and profits by 24 per cent. The £3 billion war chest it has following the disposal of its brewing operations is most likely to be invested here.

Bass' record on acquisitions is patchy - it has been unable to roll out the Inter-Continental chain fast enough to justify the high price it paid - so it must buy wisely this time.

The fact that it is taking the power to buy back more shares suggests it is not in a rush to spend its cash, which is encouraging. But the rise in the shares last week makes them look fully valued.

Until it decides what to buy, the shares are a hold at best.

webTitle: Birth pains of a super watchdog

fields.headline: Birth pains of a super watchdog
fields.standfirst:
But who will claim parenthood of Ofcom, asks Oliver Morgan

Net news
fields.trailText: Next week, the Government will unveil one of its most ambitious initiatives since it came to power in 1997 - a communications White Paper that will attempt to impose evolutionary logic in an arena which deserves the overused title revolutionary.
fields.body:
Next week, the Government will unveil one of its most ambitious initiatives since it came to power in 1997 - a communications White Paper that will attempt to impose evolutionary logic in an arena which deserves the overused title revolutionary.

One important decision is how perpetual change can be regulated. As one government official said: 'There is convergence between broadcasting, internet, satellite, mobile phones and broadband, with companies becoming more powerful through vertical integration. Regulating this is the real challenge.'

Culture Secretary Chris Smith and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers have been bombarded with 159 suggestions in their consultation, reflecting the interests of the most powerful corporate players - the BBC, BSkyB, BT, Vodafone and regulators Oftel, the Independent Television Commission and the Broadcasting Standards Commission - all insecure about their futures.

As digital technology develops, the barriers between platforms which carry information - telephone calls, data, entertainment - are eroding, while platform-builders such as BT and BSkyB are also changing.

From next year, for example, BT will be able to provide its own entertainment services, while TV companies will have increasing choice between networks to provide programmes.

The Government is likely to set out challenging plans for a super communications regulator, Ofcom, rolling up current bodies to monitor mutating companies across the changing sector.

But how will it do this? The starting point is the difference between content and economic regulation. Content concerns organisations such as the ITC, the BSC and the Internet Watch Foundation. These try to prevent inappropriate material reaching consumers, while ensuring the provisions of positive content. Economic regulation includes ensuring fair access to platforms - similar to Oftel's role in allowing access to BT's network.

An Oftel spokesman says: 'In both telecoms and broadcasting, building networks is expensive. To provide innovation and choice to consumers, new companies need access to them that doesn't jeopardise network owners.'

However, content and economics are interdependent. 'You can't make a decision on content - for example the BBC deciding on a children's channel - without impacting on the economic position of others,' says a government official involved in the paper.

Then there is the issue of competition - policing mergers and making sure dominant players do not abuse market power. This role is played concurrently by the Office of Fair Trading - using the Competition Act - and some sector regulators.

This is complicated by the fact that some regulation is 'ex ante' - setting out clear rules in advance - while competition regulations often deal retrospectively.

Some experts believe it would be a mistake to bring regulators together in one body. Oxford university economist George Yarrow, an adviser to the Government, says different regulatory activities demand different skills, and correct decisions are more likely to be made by distinct bodies.

Another adviser, Damien Tambini of the Institute for Public Policy Research, disagrees: 'Efficiency, speed and concentration of expertise suggest one regulator across the sector. You already have turf wars between regulators: different bodies could send confusing signals.'

Submissions by Oftel and the ITC betray significant differences. Oftel believes ex ante rules prevent abuse and ensure competition.The ITC is concerned about the concentration of power.

The jockeying among regulators is reflected by that between companies - particularly on economics.

BSkyB says the Competition Act should be the basis, with sector regulations a last resort. It argues against having to carry positive programming. Vodafone argues that ex ante regulation obstructs innovation. The BBC is in favour of ex ante regulation, and demands the continuation of positive programming. Both argue for one regulator.

Others are less sure. BT says Ofcom should be shorn of an economic role - which should be bundled with competition under the OFT.

The Whitehall smoke signals suggest BT will be disappointed, and Ofcom will be born with a full arsenal of economic and cultural powers.

It only remains to be seen who will claim parenthood when it is presented to parliament - Chris Smith or Stephen Byers. Two more players with their futures on their minds.

webTitle: Bandwidths of gold?

fields.headline: Bandwidths of gold?
fields.standfirst:
Portioning out the radio spectrum may offer untold riches, Faisal Islam explains

Net news
fields.trailText: Ask anyone about the spectrum, and you might get vague references to rubber keyboards or games on cassette tapes. Clive Sinclair's ZX Spectrum, the pioneering home computer, is so low-tech that it's become a collector's item.
fields.body:
Ask anyone about the spectrum, and you might get vague references to rubber keyboards or games on cassette tapes. Clive Sinclair's ZX Spectrum, the pioneering home computer, is so low-tech that it's become a collector's item.

The value of the radio spectrum, however, is driven by more straightforward economics and reached its apotheosis with this year's £22 billion third-generation mobile phone auction.

The unexpectedly high take from the 3G auctions in the UK and Germany (where the auction garnered £31bn) has led to a reappraisal of the value of all slivers of the radio spectrum. Indeed in some European countries there has been a scramble to ape the UK experience, mainly without success.

Similarly, the inflated cost of one section suddenly changes the economics of the rest of the spectrum. Does the technology and capacity of 3G licences justify £22 billion when the entire UK digital radio spectrum was snapped up for £50,000? Digital radio, for example, will allow text and even pictures to be downloaded at transmission speeds comparable to today's home internet experience.

With such a disparity in the cost of different segments, and given the way the media are converging, businesses could pay billions to mine every technological nook and cranny of the spectrum for alternatives and still make money.

And can governments justify auctioning mobile licences to make the 'efficient' price, while handing out licences to run TV services for practically nothing?

The Communications White Paper, expected on Tuesday, will treat the spectrum as a continuum of services from radio and TV to mobile telephony and wireless internet access.

There are five main factors to consider in assessing its value. Bandwidth capability, range, the necessity for 'line of sight', existing usage, and how that section of spectrum relates to international standards. The first three relate to the physics of the airwaves. The final two relate to government regulation.

The spectrum starts at low frequencies and increases: from short-wave radio to FM radio, then TV through to mobile phones, eventually reaching visible light. Higher-frequency waves are of higher energy and, broadly speaking, can carry more information. Until the Eighties no one thought existing mobile phone frequencies were usable.

'Over the past 20 years technology has allowed the exploitation of frequencies over 1GHz, as high as 40GHz,' says Stephen Pentland a partner at Spectrum Strategy Consultants. 'It's a bit like discovering a new oil field.'

But the increased capacity is traded off against the reach of signals. The lower the frequency the wider the reach of a signal. So, for example, because the frequency used for 3G is higher than for mobile phones, its reach is shorter, so more mobile phone masts will need to be built.

The last scientific consideration is the necessity for 'line of sight'. At frequencies above about 3GHz, signals can be received only if in a direct line from the transmitter. This is no good for mobile telephones, but works for receiving large amounts of data in a fixed place. Infra-red is of very high frequency, but requires perfect line of sight with no obstructions. Bluetooth, the successor technology, is of lower frequency and can transmit the same data around corners.

The division is considerably more detailed than depicted above. At the lower end, maritime frequencies are interspersed with low broadcast frequencies. At the high end, astronomers use many frequencies for radio telescopes. The entire spectrum is peppered with frequencies used by the military.

Under new Treasury accounting rules, Ministry of Defence budgets will be charged the annual cost of owning these frequencies. Together with a strategic review of military-owned spectrum, the signs point to a massive rationalisation of these frequencies.

Attractive slivers of demand are created by governments and by agreements reached by supranational organisations such as the International Telecoms Union and the EU. Indeed it was the Department of Trade and Industry that led the push for adopting the standard that has helped propel Europe to the forefront of mobile technologies.

Future technologies run hand in hand with these technological standards. In today's volatile markets investment is forthcoming only for technology that will achieve clear economies of scale by being suitable for a global market. 3G will be a global standard enabling, for example, European phones to be used in the US.

For example, the spectrum could be allocated to private organisations, which could 'sublet' specific ranges. It would be a logistical nightmare to introduce, but may mark the endpoint of a process that begins with Tuesday's White Paper.

webTitle: Look on my inventions, ye mighty - and take careful note

fields.headline: Look on my inventions, ye mighty - and take careful note
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: How are the mighty fallen. Shares in Xerox, the copier giant, are in free fall. Last week they were knocking around under $5, giving the company a market cap of only $8 billion. If it weren't for the fact that it has something like $18 billion of debt, the predators would already be circling for the kill.
fields.body:
How are the mighty fallen. Shares in Xerox, the copier giant, are in free fall. Last week they were knocking around under $5, giving the company a market cap of only $8 billion. If it weren't for the fact that it has something like $18 billion of debt, the predators would already be circling for the kill.

At one level, it's just another tale from the capitalist jungle. But there is a delicious irony in the story, for Xerox ought to have been the most valuable company the world has ever seen - as big as Microsoft, Intel, IBM, 3COM and Hewlett-Packard combined. Why? Because there was a time, in the early Seventies, when Xerox owned almost every key ingredient of personal computer technology, but spectacularly failed to recognise the fact. When company executives eventually realised what magic their research scientists had unleashed, they were too late and too clumsy in bringing the technology to market. Someone later wrote a book about this. Its title - Fumbling the Future - said it all.

The Xerox story is one of the defining legends of the computer business. In 1969, in a rare fit of inspiration, the company decided to set up a high-powered research lab in California in order to find out what the 'paperless office' hype was all about. The Xerox Palo Alto Research Center (PARC) turned out to be an inspired bet. The director of its Computer Science Lab was Bob Taylor, the guy who had commissioned and funded the Arpanet. Taylor recruited a cohort of formidable computer scientists and gave them unlimited research funds and an open brief. In four years they repaid his trust by inventing most of the computing technology we use today - high-resolution, bit-mapped screens, windowing interfaces, template-based word-processing, the laser printer and ethernet local area networking.

The first laser printer was invented by Gary Starkweather and was working in November 1971. In April 1974 Chuck Thacker switched on the Alto, the first computer that looked and worked like a modern PC or Macintosh. (Its first task was to display an animated image of Sesame Street's Cookie Monster.) The following month, Bob Metcalfe wrote a patent application for ethernet networking. By August, software for displaying overlapping, resizable windows and pop-up menus was working. By October 1974 Charles Simonyi and others had finished 'Bravo' - the world's first user-friendly, general-purpose word processing program (and the precursor of Microsoft Word).

Xerox executives were bemused by all this stuff. They couldn't figure out a business model for exploiting the technology. Eventually they marketed it as a clunky, expensive, large-scale, integrated 'office system'. But in the meantime, the techies had demonstrated their stuff to Steve Jobs and Bill Gates.

Jobs famously asked them if they had any plans to exploit it. They shrugged - that was up to the suits. So Jobs decided that he would bring the technology to the mass market if Xerox wouldn't. The Apple Macintosh - and, later, Microsoft Windows - were the results of this heist. Afterwards, Jobs quoted Picasso's celebrated aphorism: 'Minor artists borrow; great artists steal.'

All of which is no consolation to Xerox's current bosses as they wriggle to save the company. Last week, in a poignant gesture, they spun off a small company, Gyricon Media, to exploit technology recently developed by PARC - a flexible, paper-thin material that can be used to display computer-generated text.

The first applications will be in creating changeable signs for retail stores. For example, during the day, when housewives are shopping, displays might feature families using a product. When office workers start filing in at night, the store manager could hit a button and change the display to show men in suits. Or Xerox executives, looking lost.

webTitle: Galloping black horse slows to an old-fashioned trot

fields.headline: Galloping black horse slows to an old-fashioned trot
fields.standfirst: Abbey National has rejected Lloyds - and rubbed its nose in the fact. Paul Farrelly  on Pitman's final furlong
fields.trailText: Two years ago the Black Horse was riding high. Worth more than £50 billion, mighty Lloyds TSB could do no wrong. Rivals twitched at the merest hint of ending up as the beast's next meal. It was a accepted that the big black horse would simply trample any opposition underfoot.
fields.body:
Two years ago the Black Horse was riding high. Worth more than £50 billion, mighty Lloyds TSB could do no wrong. Rivals twitched at the merest hint of ending up as the beast's next meal. It was a accepted that the big black horse would simply trample any opposition underfoot.

Ian Harley, chief executive of Abbey National, for one, was a fully paid-up member of the trembling brigade. A year ago, when Harley took a call from Peter Ellwood, his opposite number at Lloyds TSB, his face turned ashen, insiders recall. It was at the height of hostilities between the Scottish banks for NatWest. Abbey was already on red alert and a defensive review, carried out by Harley's traditional advisers, Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, had long identified Lloyds TSB as the most likely aggressor. Now, as Ellwood demanded a meeting, the alarms rang hysterically.

Lloyds TSB would, Harley was told, like a 'merger of equals'. Except that in this 'friendly' deal, Abbey would have just two seats on the board - one for Harley, the other for his soon-to-retire chairman Lord Tugendhat - and they would not be meaningful positions. 'It meant rape and pillage, Harley knew that,' one Abbey insider said. 'It was his worst nightmare. It meant the undoing of everything he had tried to achieve.'

Armed with a fresh battle plan from new advisers UBS Warburg and Lehman Brothers (DKB had inconveniently jumped ship to defend NatWest and is now advising Bank of Scotland), Harley mustered the courage to resist. Abbey, he told Ellwood at meeting number two, was determined to go it alone.

Having tweaked Lloyd TSB's tail last Christmas, Harley felt brave enough last week to rub the black horse's nose right in it. Lloyds TSB's board had finally given the green light for a takeover approach at an emergency board meeting on Sunday.

But at a hastily convened meeting on Monday morning at Ellwood's central London town house, the Lloyds TSB chief and his canny chairman, Sir Brian Pitman, were told by Harley and Tugendhat that, after an unpromising start, Abbey's current merger talks with Bank of Scotland were going well.

And by Thursday, after an exchange of letters outlining a £19bn bid, Harley had brusquely sent Lloyds TSB packing. 'The board has concluded that the proposals contained in the letter are unattractive and accordingly it does not intend to enter into discussions with Lloyds TSB,' Abbey proclaimed in a dismissive five-line statement. It is now 'put up, or shut up' time for Lloyds TSB. Having settled the thorny question of who does what, Abbey and Peter Burt, Bank of Scotland's chief executive, now expect to announce a merger by the end of this week. For Burt, the deal will be some consolation at least after his £23bn bid for NatWest was pipped by Royal Bank of Scotland earlier this year.

Then, for fear of being blocked by the Competition Commission, Lloyds TSB chose not to intervene but bid for NatWest itself. However, if Ellwood finally swallows his private distaste for hostile takeovers, there is no guarantee the City will applaud. And, with little spare cash and its shares languishing at just two thirds of their peak two years ago, it is by no means sure that Lloyds TSB will see off the Scots at all.

'Lloyds has come out with all guns blazing, but it's been slapped down,' one City banking analyst said. 'Being so gung ho was a mistake. It's now in a corner, and assuming it will prevail would be another big mistake.'

So, barely four months before Pitman is due to retire, what has gone wrong with his fearsome acquisition machine? How has the black horse stumbled so far from grace that, as City wags put it, BOS's Burt might be well advised to dust off his NatWest game plan, ditch Abbey and bid for Lloyds TSB instead?

At the start of the Eighties, Lloyds was an also-ran. The smallest of the UK's 'big four' clearing banks, it had also taken huge hits through ill-advised lending to Latin America and the third world.

In 1983, the ambitious Pitman, a career Lloyds banker, took the helm and set about revolutionising the whole of the British banking sector. However, an early bid in 1986 for Standard Chartered failed (fortunately - Standard has seen more black holes than Calcutta). Pitman lost out, too, to HSBC when he tilted at Midland Bank eight years ago. Then Lloyds' bid was referred to the Monopolies & Mergers Commission, while HSBC's was cleared - a nightmare Lloyds fears may well happen again with Abbey.

In the meantime, Pitman had already become a City darling. First to go was investment banking, where rivals squandered billions in vainglorious pursuit of their pretensions. Instead, Lloyds focused on becoming not only Britain's biggest provider of personal finance products, but the world's most efficient bank, too.

'Brian's brilliance was that he had a fantastic vision for the Nineties,' one close associate said. 'He also foresaw the meltdown that was going to happen on the high street: Lloyds started shedding thousands of jobs long before rivals woke up to reality.'

Pitman's first successes in building a 'bancassurance' giant came in 1995 with the audacious £1.8bn bid for Cheltenham & Gloucester, the most efficient building society around, and the takeover of insurer Abbey Life a year later. In between, Pitman pulled off his masterstroke: a £13.6bn merger with the TSB, which turned the group into Britain's biggest bank, with over 3,100 branches in all.

That merger was only fully completed last year, but ruthless cost-cutting has already added £400 million a year to the bottom line and nearly 600 branches have been closed. Fuelled by its fearsome reputation, Lloyds TSB's shares quadrupled to £10 from 1995 to 1999, outperforming the market by 50 per cent as the City eagerly awaited the next deal.

Ellwood, who took over the reins from Pitman in early 1997, was not shy of boasting about his ambitions, both in the UK and in Europe, where Lloyds TSB has held on-off talks with Fortis, the leading Benelux bancassurer, and has eyed France's Credit Lyonnais and ABN Amro of the Netherlands. All that happened, though, was the £5.4bn takeover of Scottish Widows at the end of last year.

Though the deal was widely praised at the time, the integration of Widows has been cackhanded, to say the least. Fund managers from Lloyds TSB's Hill Samuel operation quit rather than move to Edinburgh, there were public clashes with top management and Widows' sales have been poor. More tellingly, the deal was tiny relative to the City's enormous expectations.

'Widows was a watershed,' one City analyst said. 'The market had been waiting for deal for years. Now people finally realised the numbers didn't stack up and this was all that Lloyds could do.'

Fashion, too, has changed. Sticking to your knitting is on the way out; international expansion is back in. For Lloyds TSB, a European deal is aimed at giving it enough size and clout to cut a merger in the US to compete with, rather than be swallowed by, giants such as Citigroup. The bank, however, has learned that European takeovers are hard to do, hence the easier attractions of Abbey.

But where penny-pinching was once all the rage, now growth is back in vogue, too. And that is seen to be Bank of Scotland's forte, not Lloyds TSB's. 'There are nagging doubts about Lloyds' culture, that it's just cost-cutting,' one City analyst said. 'There's no doubt the fashion is for top- line growth now, and Lloyds has misjudged that mood.'

webTitle: House of cards, part 2

fields.headline: House of cards, part 2
fields.standfirst: Mortgage lenders are again taking the risks that caused the last property slump, says  Heather Connon. Only a buoyant economy is keeping real danger at bay
fields.trailText: A quarter of a million homes repossessed, a 7 per cent slump in house prices - and double that in London - as well as a 50 per cent drop in the number of sales... Who could forget the Nineties housing slump?
fields.body:
A quarter of a million homes repossessed, a 7 per cent slump in house prices - and double that in London - as well as a 50 per cent drop in the number of sales... Who could forget the Nineties housing slump?

No one, if the Government has its way. From debt summits and task forces to campaigns fronted by pop star Louise, the authorities are warning us of the perils of borrowing too much. Last week, it was the turn of Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, to have a go at those responsible for the bulk of our debts: the mortgage lenders.

London house prices, Davies said, were remarkably close to the peaks reached before the last slump. So is it wise for mortgage lenders to be quite so generous?

'It may be that the London premium will remain at this historically high level,' Davies told the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML). 'But clearly one cannot exclude the possibility of a fall in London house prices, which could put very high loan-to-value loans into the danger zone.'

So is there a risk of a rerun of the boom-and-bust housing market which proved so painful a decade ago? Or is Davies taking regulatory prudence to the extreme?

The doom-mongers could certainly find plenty of similarities between the current market and that of the Eighties boom. It may now be a bit less frothy than it was, but London dinner parties are still buzzing with tales of gazumping, of lottery-style profits made in just a few years, and of houses in desirable areas being snapped up almost beforegoing on sale.

Figures from the CML show that the average loan is now 2.24 times the borrower's annual income, rising to 2.28 times for first-time buyers. That is higher than it was at the height of the Eighties boom when, even for first-time buyers, the average was less than 2.2 times income.

It is once again relatively easy to borrow 100 per cent of the value of the property - something few lenders would offer during the post-slump Nineties. Indeed, you can get even more than that: Northern Rock's Together mortgage offers borrowers up to 125 per cent of the price of their house.

And prices have been rising. The average house now costs over £102,000, a 20 per cent rise in two years; in London, the rise has been an even more dramatic 33 per cent. But what most worries Davies is that house prices in London are now almost 60 per cent above the national average, higher than at the top of the Eighties boom.

'The last peak in this ratio was followed by five to six years in which London prices underperformed the rest of the market by around 30 per cent,' Davies points out.

Yet no one, not even Davies, is predicting a slump of that proportion this time. Indeed, most forecasters expect the housing market to show steady, if unspectacular, growth. The CML, for example, thinks prices will rise by 6 per cent next year and 5 per cent in 2002, with the number of transactions staying close to the average of around 1.5 million a year.

The key reason for the confidence this time round is interest rates. The Eighties boom was killed by a dramatic hike in rates. They rose from 9.5 to 15 per cent in little over a year, pushed up largely to kill the consumer boom which soaring house prices had caused. It's different this time. Davies says: 'The level of interest rates is considerably lower now than it was then, and with monetary policy now in the safe hands of the Bank of England, there is good reason to hope that we shall not see the kind of high interest rate peaks which characterised the Seventies, Eighties and early Nineties.'

If he is right - and most economists agree with him - the high debt levels are far less worrying than they would have been. 'The critical point is that if interest rates are low, you can afford to borrow more,' said Rob Thomas, housing market analyst with UBS Warburg.

This is reflected by the fact that despite the recent rise in house prices, borrowers are paying only around 25 per cent of their salaries in mortgage payments, compared with more than 36 per cent at the peak of the last boom.

The problem is, mortgages are not the only debts we have, and our other borrowings have been rising fast. The Office of Fair Trading, which used Louise to launch its debt campaign last month, points out that the average person has £2,500 in unsecured borrowing - personal loans, credit card debt and so on. Total unsecured borrowing has increased by 60 per cent over the past year to a total of more than £159 billion. Taking that into account, borrowers are far more stretched than they used to be. Of course, mortgage lenders insist that they take unsecured debts into account when deciding how much to lend for a house purchase. And all say they have learnt the lessons of the Eighties, claiming to be far more prudent about lending than they were then.

The evidence suggests, however, that the only thing that has changed is the economic outlook. Loans as a multiple of income are higher than they ever were. Some new entrants to the market, such as Standard Life, do not even look at such things as income multiples in deciding whether to grant a mortgage; they concentrate on how much is left by people's existing outgoings to meet mortgage payments.

And, following the furore over endowment policies, which were pushed with such enthusiasm by lenders in the Eighties boom, many lenders no longer concern themselves with the way in which a loan will be repaid.

The most extreme example of this is the interest-only mortgage, designed for the well-heeled. Users of these do not have to take out any insurance or investment product to pay off the loan when it matures. Instead, the aim is to repay it with anticipated bonus payments, inheritances or perhaps a large future salary increase. It is, obviously, a high-risk product. Yet the most recent statistics show that 16 per cent of all new lending was made on an interest-only basis.

One mortgage broker said: 'I would be interested to know how many of these people really understand the risks they are taking.'

Northern Rock insists that its Together mortgage, which may be repaid in any way, is a prudent approach to lending, even though borrowers can end up with loans 25 per cent higher than the value of their homes.

The former building society says most of these customers have credit card and personal loan debts, and if they switch these to their mortgage account, the interest rate is so much lower they can afford to borrow more.

This is fine if house prices remain stable or go on rising. But if they fall, borrowers who have to sell could find it impossible to pay off their loans - just as so many people did in the Eighties.

How the boom went bust

The Nineties housing slump was much more than bad news for the banks and building societies, who were faced with a rising tide of bad debts and a stagnant market which lasted for much of the following decade. The boom-and-bust in the property market touched all corners of the economy, affecting almost everyone in the country. Indeed, much of the downturn in the early Nineties can be directly attributed to it.

The key was confidence. As house prices soared, so did a general feeling of well-being. The more you think your house is worth, the more you will be willing to spend on other things, from foreign holidays to smart restaurants. The consumer economy boomed.

When house prices started falling and interest rates began to rise, such feelings of wealth evaporated. People who are worried that they won't be able to pay their mortgage are not likely to spend their savings on other things. The consumer economy slumped. Unemployment rose, which exacerbated the problem.

So is there such a risk to the economy this time round? The consensus is no. John Butler, UK economist at HSBC, points out that the economy is no longer being driven only by the strength of the housing market. Falling unemployment and the strength of equity markets are both big contributors to confidence.

So even if the property market does turn down, it is unlikely to have the serious impact it had in the Eighties. But there will still, of course, be many casualties.

webTitle: Seagram goes to court over Captain Morgan

fields.headline: Seagram goes to court over Captain Morgan
fields.trailText: Canadian drinks giant Seagram has gone to court to defend its rights to the Captain Morgan rum brand from British rival Allied Domecq.
fields.body:
Canadian drinks giant Seagram has gone to court to defend its rights to the Captain Morgan rum brand from British rival Allied Domecq.

The action, contesting a lawsuit now launched by the rum's producer and Allied's ally, Destileria Serralles, was taken in the Puerto Rican High Court last week.

The legal skirmishing comes as Seagram awaits final bids for its spirits and wines division - the world's third largest, with brands such as Chivas Regal and Glenlivet - by 5pm tomorrow, New York time. The actions began following the completion last week of Seagram's $26 billion merger with France's Vivendi to form the film, TV and entertainment giant Vivendi Universal.

Diageo, Allied Domecq's British rival, is confident of victory in the $7bn-plus auction. Diageo chief executive Paul Walsh has held encouraging meetings, sources say, with Seagram chief Edgar Bronfman Jnr and Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier.

Diageo formally signed a joint bidding agreement with France's Pernod-Ricard last week, and will fund the deal from the $10bn sale of its Pillsbury foods division.

Bacardi, the third contender, is already heavily in debt and understood to be negotiating with US bank Chase Manhattan in a consortium involving Sweden's Vin & Sprit, maker of Absolut vodka, and Brown Forman, the US owner of Jack Daniel's.

Allied, for which Seagram is seen as the best fit, has so far failed to find a partner. It has also prejudiced its chances by not carrying out due diligence checks and refusing to sign Seagram's confidentiality undertaking.

Allied chief executive Philip Bowman's tactic in signing up to Serralles' challenge to Seagram's ownership of Captain Morgan has further angered the Canadians. He is also understood to have tried to woo Pernod Ricard away from Diageo.

'Bronfman has not been impressed. He thinks Bowman has tried to make a fool out of Seagram,' one source close to the talks said. 'It has not gone down at all well.'

This weekend, Allied declined to confirm whether it would bid seriously tomorrow. Industry sources said its tactics had fooled no one. 'Diageo and Bacardi will bid on as if Allied is there,' said one. 'It's the last chance now for Allied to close the gap between itself and Diageo.'

webTitle: British casino struggles to pull a genie out of the bottle in Vegas

fields.headline: British casino struggles to pull a genie out of the bottle in Vegas
fields.trailText: The first British casino operator to open a gambling joint in Las Vegas has racked up a £3 million operating loss in just four months, writes Nick Mathiason .
fields.body:
The first British casino operator to open a gambling joint in Las Vegas has racked up a £3 million operating loss in just four months, writes Nick Mathiason .

London Clubs International, which posts its interims this Thursday, opened the spectacular 2,600-room Aladdin Hotel at a cost of £700m last August. But a slowdown in the US economy has dealt LCI a dud hand. Last week America's most powerful hotel and gaming analyst, Jason Ader of Bear, Sterns, downgraded four international hotel and casino operators on the back of falling consumer confidence.

Several major operators are feeling the squeeze in a town that in the past decade has reinvented itself from a family destination into an adult version of Disneyland. Experts admit that returns on Vegas casino investments are dwindling.

Senior LCI executives privately concede that the Aladdin needs to 'shout louder'. The hotel is achieving 90 per cent room occupancy rates.

webTitle: New review adds extra £5bn to Sellafield's clean-up bill

fields.headline: New review adds extra £5bn to Sellafield's clean-up bill
fields.trailText: The cost of cleaning up contaminated nuclear facilities at Sellafield in Cumbria could rise by further billions.
fields.byline: Nick Paton Walsh  and Oliver Morgan
fields.body:
The cost of cleaning up contaminated nuclear facilities at Sellafield in Cumbria could rise by further billions.

Increased liabilities estimated at at least £5 billion have been identified as part of a review of Sellafield operations by the industry regulator, the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate. They are being fed into a review of state-owned British Nuclear Fuels commissioned by the Government from accountant Arthur Andersen.

The escalation comes only two months after BNFL published its own liabilities review, which pushed decommissioning costs up from £27bn to £34bn.

The problems arise from difficulties with highly complex work to dismantle fuel reprocessing and waste storage structures.

Some of the concerns are outlined in the latest quarterly report from the NII to the local liaison committee, which monitors Sellafield. The NII wants to draw a 'line in the sand' below BNFL's liabilities. The NII doubts if BNFL will achieve its targets unless it boosts its decommissioning activity.

It sets out new 'licence specifications' which force BNFL to carry out work on seven buildings to strict timetables. It also details a series of problems with existing programmes. At two plants, B29 and B30, problems with recovering radioactive sludge and transferring contaminated fuel are singled out.

At the B204 reprocessing facility, collapsing steelwork has halted work.

Experts suggest these and other delays, along with the NII licence specifications, will have a radical impact on Sellafield's decommissioning costs, currently calculated at around £20bn.

One industry source said: 'BNFL has set targets before and not achieved them. It is finding decommissioning a lot more difficult than envisaged. The NII's measures are bound to add significantly to costs. I calculate at least £5bn.'

A BNFL spokesman said: 'The NII is allowing us further time to carry out the work. There is no evidence that this will have an impact on costs.'

webTitle: Watchdog warns on large loans

fields.headline: Watchdog warns on large loans
fields.standfirst: Some lenders tempt buyers to overstretch, says  Jill Insley
fields.trailText: Homebuyers are putting themselves at risk by taking out mortgages that are large compared with their salaries, Britain's financial services watchdog has warned.
fields.body:
Homebuyers are putting themselves at risk by taking out mortgages that are large compared with their salaries, Britain's financial services watchdog has warned.

Sir Howard Davies, chairman of the Financial Services Authority, says the number of 'high income-multiple' loans - where a person borrows more than three times their income or more than 2.5 times joint incomes - has increased sharply and represents as much as a third of new lending.

The problem has been particularly acute in London, where the average property price was 75 per cent higher than the average price for the rest of the country in the third quarter of this year.

Homeowners who take out large mortgages compared with their salaries are more likely to suffer negative equity or even lose their homes if property prices fall and interest rates rise. But mortgage brokers say plenty of borrowers are willing to take the risk. Ray Boulger, of London independent mortgage brokers Charcol says: 'We had a borrower interested in borrowing seven times his income this week. We told him to go away - he clearly couldn't afford it.'

Although no lender would consider allowing a mortgage worth seven times the borrower's annual income, many are prepared to lend four times a single income or 2.75 times joint incomes if the borrower meets certain criteria. Boulger says the Woolwich will lend four times income to someone who has saved a 10 per cent deposit; the Halifax, the UK's biggest lender, will lend 4.25 times income if the borrower has a 10 per cent deposit and earns at least £100,000. Lenders are also more likely to agree large multiples for people who opt for a long-term fixed-rate loan, on the grounds that if they can afford the monthly payment now, they should be able to afford it over four or five years.

Boulger says high income-multiples are normally only extended to borrowers who can manage them - professionals whose incomes are likely to increase rapidly, or City workers who will earn large bonuses or be able to cash in share options. He believes such borrowers are not taking on undue risk given the economic environment. 'People just need to be sensible. Someone conservative about spending might manage four times their income quite easily, but another might struggle on three times their income.'

Johannes Kennard, of Bath independent mortgage brokers London & Country, believes very few buyers should borrow more than 3.5 times a single income, or 2.5 times joint incomes. 'The difference between someone borrowing three and four times their income might be minimal at current interest rates, but if rates go up, that difference will become much more exaggerated.'

He cites the example of someone earning £25,000 a year buying a £100,000 property with a 25-year repayment mortgage. Assuming interest of 5.74 per cent, a homebuyer borrowing the full £100,000 or four times their income will pay £159 more than if they borrowed £75,000.

But if interest rates rose to 10 per cent, borrowing four times income would cost £230 more.

Kennard recommends that homebuyers save as much as possible before looking for a property so they have a decent deposit. This will not only protect borrowers from falling into negative equity but could also enable them to borrow more cheaply. Repayment mortgages also reduce the risk.

He also suggests borrowers who move house should reduce their mortgage term so their loan ends at or before their expected retirement date. 'Borrowers who keep taking out 25-year mortgages could end up having to pay a mortgage out of their pension,' he warns.

webTitle: Nomura on Granada hotels' shortlist

fields.headline: Nomura on Granada hotels' shortlist
fields.trailText: Nomura's ubiquitous dealmaker, Guy Hands, has been shortlisted by Granada Compass in the £2 billion-plus sale of its prestigious Le Meridien international hotel chain.
fields.body:
Nomura's ubiquitous dealmaker, Guy Hands, has been shortlisted by Granada Compass in the £2 billion-plus sale of its prestigious Le Meridien international hotel chain.

The Japanese bank, however, faces strong competition from some of the world's biggest hoteliers in bidding to add Le Meridien's 125 luxury hotels to its burgeoning leisure and property empire.

Also understood to be still in the running are Hilton, Marriott, Accor, and Bass, now the world leader through its Intercontinental, Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza chains.

The disposal, revealed in The Observer in September, marks the final unwinding of Granada's £3.8bn hostile takeover of Forte four years ago and also includes Posthouse, Heritage, and London Signature.

One of the four-strong Signature chain, the Cavendish, was sold to De Vere - the former Greenalls pubs group - for £60 million last week following the collapse of £65m talks with a private buyer.

In October, France's Accor pulled out of talks to buy the whole division, but it is understood to have revived interest in Le Meridien's 32,000 rooms around the world. Spain's Sol Media, the world's tenth-biggest hotelier, is playing down its interest.

So far Bass - and UK rival Whitbread - have been tight-lipped about their interest. But Bass may yet bid for the entire chain. Whitbread has been seen as a front runner for Posthouse's 79-strong chain - worth £750m - and Heritage's 47 country inns, worth around £250m.

Pre-tax profits for Granada Compass's catering, hotels and hospitality operations are expected to come in at over £700m this week, up from £639m, and the group is set to please the City by confirming that the hotels will be sold by the end of March.

webTitle: Equitable chaos prompts FSA warning to investors

fields.headline: Equitable chaos prompts FSA warning to investors
fields.trailText: Small investors may in future be warned to take care before investing in one of the country's most popular types of investment fund.
fields.body:
Small investors may in future be warned to take care before investing in one of the country's most popular types of investment fund.

The Financial Services Authority is to review the way with-profits investments are run following the crisis at Equitable Life, the 238-year-old mutual insurer which was forced to close to new business last Friday.

Equitable closed after failing to find a buyer to plug a £1.5 billion liability for paying a guaranteed level of income on pension funds. The disaster grew out of contracts to pay the money from with-profits investments. These funds aim to smooth stock market peaks and troughs through the payment of bonuses which are distributed at the discretion of managers. The row at Equitable followed its decision to cut maturity bonuses on the guaranteed pensions.

The FSA has no plans to ban with-profits funds, in which more than £550bn is invested, but it may order insurers to explain the workings of the funds more clearly, and increase risk warnings.

Equitable believed its contracts allowed it to cut the bonuses, but the House of Lords ruled this illegal.

The insurer's difficulties have focused the regulator's attention on the complexity of with-profits funds and the snags that can arise when managers believe they have discretion to alter payments.

Although the Lords' Equitable judgment applies to specific types of contract, it is these funds' discretionary nature that is causing concern.

With-profits funds are at the centre of other controversies in the investment industry. They have resulted in the build-up of huge excess profits at some firms. Insurer Axa is due in court on 19 December to seeking a ruling on the way it plans to distribute its 'orphan' estate - a scheme attacked by the Consumers' Association as unfair.

webTitle: Lloyds to axe Abbey jobs

fields.headline: Lloyds to axe Abbey jobs
fields.standfirst: 8,000 face redundancy if new bid suceeds  Merrill Lynch in 'conflict' row  BoS talks could fail
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB plans to cut 8,000 jobs if it succeeds in its controversial £16 billion bid for Abbey National.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB plans to cut 8,000 jobs if it succeeds in its controversial £16 billion bid for Abbey National.

This week, Lloyds TSB expects to lift its offer for the former building society, tightening its 'bear hug' in order to coerce Abbey into talks and a recommended deal.

Until Lloyds TSB's dramatic intervention last week, Abbey had expected to announce a £24bn merger with Bank of Scotland by this Friday. This weekend, however, sources close to the BoS talks said it was not certain terms would be agreed.

To furious protests from banking unions, around 10,000 jobs and 600 branches went after Lloyds merged with TSB in 1995. But Abbey and BoS have little overlap, which makes it more likely Lloyds TSB's bid would be the only one referred to the Competition Commission in the run-up to a general election.

In a letter following a meet ing between the two sides on Monday, Lloyds TSB also pledged not to close any Abbey branches for at least two years.

Scottish sources injected further controversy this weekend by alleging a conflict of interest at US investment bank Merrill Lynch, which has now joined Lloyds TSB's advisory team.

Merrill, which declined to comment, also advises National Australia Bank, which has been eager to merge its Clydesdale and Yorkshire banks with BoS. Last week, Abbey rejected an approach from the 'black horse', which offered 1.43 Lloyds TSB shares plus £2.10 in cash for every Abbey share, valuing Abbey at £15.9bn at Friday's prices.

Following Abbey chief executive Ian Harley's swift rebuttal, Lloyds TSB chief Peter Ellwood is expected to turn up the pressure with a further letter, raising his offer, early this week.

'There's very little chance of us going hostile immediately,' one source said. 'If we do it this way, Abbey will have to explain what it has rejected and we may get a friendly deal.'

Since buying Cheltenham & Gloucester five years ago, Lloyds TSB has 9 per cent of the UK mortgage market, compared with Abbey's 13 per cent. In talks with Harley last year, Ellwood is understood to have offered to drop Cheltenham & Gloucester to satisfy regulatory concerns.

The bank now believes fierce competition in the mortgage market means it may escape an automatic Competition Commission referral. But with so many jobs on the line, analysts think Lloyds TSB and Abbey National's 27 per cent share of personal current accounts would provide excuse enough.

'Lloyds needs a friendly deal to be able to explain away the competition concerns,' one City banking analyst said. 'It won't be able to do that with a hostile bid. The trouble is the City won't buy a deal if it doesn't mean taking a huge axe to costs.'

Lloyds TSB's intervention has lifted the pressure on Harley by strengthening BoS's hand. The Scots' chief executive, Peter Burt - who is well respected despite losing NatWest to Royal Bank of Scotland last year - has insisted on a merger rather than takeover by Abbey. He has also been holding out to be chief executive, and talks have centred on finding a face-saving role for Harley.

webTitle: Banks threaten Rover suppliers

fields.headline: Banks threaten Rover suppliers
fields.trailText: The likelihood of MG Rover remaining a volume manufacturer is being thrown into fresh doubt by banks, who are warning component suppliers in the West Midlands that funds will be cut if they continue to rely on the car maker for business.
fields.body:
The likelihood of MG Rover remaining a volume manufacturer is being thrown into fresh doubt by banks, who are warning component suppliers in the West Midlands that funds will be cut if they continue to rely on the car maker for business.

Engineering companies clustered around the Longbridge plant in Birmingham have traditionally focused production on the giant plant, funding their operations through overdrafts with high street banks. But banks have made it clear that they consider this strategy too risky, and will continue funding only companies which diversify away from MG Rover.

Banks have also raised their concerns with the local Regional Development Authority, Advantage West Midlands, which was charged with allocating £129 million of government money to improve productivity among supply chain companies in the area after BMW dumped Longbridge in the spring.

The problems were raised at an AWM board meeting last week, chaired by Alex Stephenson, brother of MG Rover director Nick. Some members of the AWM board are concerned that there is local pressure to use funding to support Rover rather than to help suppliers find new markets.

One AWM member told The Observer: 'Banks for customers that continue to be substantially dependent on Rover without diversifying want to cut their exposure. These companies have traditionally focused on Rover. They have to understand that the world is changing.'

While banks accept there is little prospect of Rover going out of business - it has more than £1 billion in cash, stock and loans - they are concerned that any reduction in the 200,000-unit production target promised by John Towers when he took over the company from BMW in May will squeeze suppliers.

'There have been concerns from the beginning about how realistic the 200,000 is,' said the AWM member.

The banks and AWM have three worries about MG Rover. One, are its current models - the new flagship 75, and the older 45 and 25 - attractive enough? Two, how aggressive will price competition be? Three, is there a viable new model programme?

MG Rover has consistently said it is in discussions with a major overseas producer to develop a new range of models, but no significant deal seems in prospect.

Recent reports suggest that Towers is now revising downward the 200,000 figure which he set after a tussle with venture capital outfit Alchemy.

At the time experts warned that Alchemy's plan to concentrate on sports cars would see Longbridge's 8,000 workforce fall to 1,500. Union sources indicated last week that more than 2,000 workers had taken redundancy since Towers arrived.

webTitle: Top City stockbroker faces insider dealing charge

fields.headline: Top City stockbroker faces insider dealing charge
fields.trailText: A former vice-chairman of leading stockbroker Hoare Govett will appear at Southwark Crown Court tomorrow in one of the City's highest-profile insider dealing cases.
fields.body:
A former vice-chairman of leading stockbroker Hoare Govett will appear at Southwark Crown Court tomorrow in one of the City's highest-profile insider dealing cases.

Johnny Townsend, who left Hoare Govett in 1998, is accused by the Department of Trade and Industry of encouraging a client to buy shares on the basis of inside information.

The 57-year-old broker, who is pleading not guilty, is the most senior City figure to be charged under insider dealing legislation. If convicted - in only the second case brought under this government - Townsend faces a fine and a maximum seven years in jail. In the 20 years since insider dealing was made a crime, however, only one person has spent time behind bars, and then only for a few months.

The biggest fine, £25,000, was imposed in the Eighties on the only senior City figure convicted so far, former Morgan Grenfell director Geoffrey Collier.

Townsend was charged by the DTI last April following an investigation two years ago by the City watchdog, the Financial Services Authority.

It is alleged that he passed inside information on WT Foods, a Hoare Govett client, gained at a briefing with the company. It also claimed he encouraged Salah Shohet, a client and former head of the Dukeminster property company, to deal in WT Foods shares the following day.

There is no suggestion that Shohet acted illegally. The trade was allegedly booked through Shohet's Swiss investment company, Etablissement Finital, but referred by Hoare Govett staff to the broker's compliance department and cancelled.

Townsend, nicknamed Johnny Rat after his initials JRAT, is well known in the City after a 30-year career taking in brokers de Zoete & Bevan, BZW and Kleinwort Benson. He joined Hoare Govett, now owned by the Dutch bank ABN Amro, in 1993.

webTitle: AEEU plans German merger to create Euro 'super union'

fields.headline: AEEU plans German merger to create Euro 'super union'
fields.trailText: Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical union wants to seal a merger with Germany's giant IG Metall to create a pan-European union representing more than 3 million manufacturing workers.
fields.body:
Sir Ken Jackson, head of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical union wants to seal a merger with Germany's giant IG Metall to create a pan-European union representing more than 3 million manufacturing workers.

Jackson is due to outline his proposal at a dinner on 6 January - to be attended by IG Metall head Klaus Zwickel - marking the 150th anniversary of the AEEU's forerunner, the Amalgamated Society of Engineers.

A prominent Europhile, Jackson has already held discussions with Zwickel about the plan, which would create the first significant cross-border European trade union.

Jackson believes that European integration and the growth of pan-European companies demands that unions operate across the continent.

He said he aimed to foster relations with other European unions: 'It is essential that trade unions respond positively to European developments. We already have close relationships with European unions, and that will continue in the coming year. In the longer term these will lead to mergers, including with IG Metall.'

The AEEU is currently merging with the professional Manufacturing, Science and Finance Union to create a 1.3 million strong organisation. It hopes to complete the process by the middle of next year.

A merger with IG Metall, Germany's largest union, could improve the position of UK workers employed by European goliaths.

Union officials say, for example, that if the two unions had been merged, BMW would have found it impossible to keep plans to drop Rover secret from its UK workforce, because of German laws on consulting workers about company strategy.

webTitle: He'll have hell to pay...

fields.headline: He'll have hell to pay...
fields.standfirst: Angus Young plays guitar like a man possessed - then again, maybe he is
fields.trailText: AC/DC London Wembley Arena
fields.body:
AC/DC London Wembley Arena

I have a theory about AC/DC - a wispy thought that hits me halfway through their set. Their lead guitarist, Angus Young, is playing a guitar solo, balanced on a rising lift in one corner of the stage. Coaxing all manners of bluesy screams from his guitar, slowly riffing on the spot, Young glares demonically at the audience. He looks enraptured in his instrument's black noise. Robert Johnson, the old Mississippian blues guitarist who famously gave himself to the devil in 1938, seems momentarily reincarnated.

This wasn't always the case. In the mid-Seventies, AC/DC ushered in the age of hard rock - innuendo-laden and musically forthright - to FM radio. The group set the foundations for their genre; Bon Scott's vocals evoked images of bleeding arteries, alongside Young's alcoholic blues riffs and a square rhythm section. A clutch of early albums, 1975's High Voltage , 1976's Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap and 1977's Let There Be Rock have been effortlessly recycled over a 25-year career. And the blueprint would later inspire US heavy metal (Guns 'n Roses, Hanoi Rocks), the New Wave of British Heavy Metal (Iron Maiden, Saxon) and grunge (Nirvana, Soundgarden).

But Scott died in 1980, choking on his own vomit in the back of a friend's car. A new singer, Brian Johnson, resurrected the group's fortunes, producing the finest moment of their recording career - 1980's Back In Black. And over the past 20 years, the group has enjoyed steady success as an unpretentious but entertaining live act. Their dedication to the three-chord riff-- hardly the most adventurous of musical tangents - remains astounding.

Brian Johnson now rations his voice down to a comfortable wheeze that alternates between a carburettor hum and a masonry drill: 'Ya doin' alright?', 'Are there any bad boys in the house?' Web-footed and awkward, he stands stage-edge, pounding his fists together -his audience, likewise, returns similar movements. The set-list weighs heavily towards the group's Bon Scott era - 'Whole Lotta Rosie', 'Let There Be Rock' and 'TNT'.

But it's Young who provides the most melodramatic moments, stalking the stage in tiny, ferret-like movements - finally stripping off his trademark schoolboy uniform down to his shorts. A 25-foot tall, bronzed statue of him gazes out from the back of the stage -the idol breathes smoke, glinting its eyes across the crowd as fans chant 'Angus! Angus! Angus!' Young's presence - and the histrionics it produces - is the closest thing to idolatry in rock today.

The guitarist, perhaps surprisingly, in recent years has been reclaimed as hard rock's solely functioning rock god - younger rock/rap groups such as US-based Limp Bizkit, Creed and Korn, perhaps conscious of their inattentive fanbase, encourage a democracy that shuns guitar solos. And while veterans like Eric Clapton, Jimmy Page and Buddy Guy have been redesigned by an MTV-generated sheen, Young seems to remember the sweatshop days of his youth in Sydney.

The comparisons with Robert Johnson are irresistible - overlooking the obvious racial differences, the recorded output of both displays an economic use of guitars, reliant on riffs and nuances. Both were principally guitarists who catalogued the same interest in their lyrics - sex. On 'I'm a Steady Rollin' Man', re-corded in 1937, Johnson perforates his words with an insistent riff. He sings: 'I'm a steady rollin' man, I roll both night and day/But I haven't got no sweet woman, boys to be rollin' this-a-way.'

Likewise, Young, the principal songwriter in AC/DC, wrote the similarly themed 'Highway To Hell' in 1979. Bon Scott's edgy vocals compete with Young's amped-up vision of Johnson's womanising: 'I'm on the highway to hell/No stop signs, no speed limit/Nobody's gonna slow me down/Like a wheel, gonna spin it/Nobody's gonna mess me around'.

In 1937, perhaps predicting his own untimely death, Johnson penned 'Me and the Devil Blues': 'Me and the Devil was walkin' side by side/Me and the Devil, ooh, was walkin' side by side/And I'm going to beat my woman/Until I get satisfied'. 'Highway To Hell' is similarly full of devilish imagery, alternately pleading for absolution while fetishising the occult: 'Hey Satan, paid my dues/Playing in a rocking band/Hey Momma, look at me/I'm on my way to the promised land/I'm on a highway to hell'. It mightn't be any more than coincidence, of course. Only, Young instils the feeling that he might indeed have sold his soul to some otherworldly cause. Always lean and ragged, he looks beanpole thin these days, almost meditative in his craft. His bandmates seem peripheral as Young wields solos like a man running for the finishing line.

The group's sexual fixations - no more sophisticated than adolescent fantasies - are legendary. On 'Hard As A Rock', as Johnson blares out the second verse - 'The lightnin' rod, strike it hot/Gonna hit you like a Rushmore rock/No nicotine, and no pipe dreams/So low and dirty it's damn right mean' - a cinema projector swings into view. Animated images of naked, purple-faced dwarves chasing voluptuous maidens race across the screen. As the rhythm section flails out the last chorus, German V2 rockets explode from battlefields, a train enters a tunnel and plumes of gaseous fire ejaculate from sidestage.

All impossible to watch without grinning of course, and I leave still sniggering. Next morning, as the train shudders to a halt outside Kentish Town, I break into a smile. Perhaps the railroad metaphor isn't so clumsy after all: as Young well understands, every old Mississippian bluesman should fall on to the wrong side of the tracks.

He sings: 'I'm a steady rollin' man, I roll both night and day/But I haven't got no sweet woman, boys to be rollin' this-a-way.' Likewise, Young, the principal songwriter in AC/DC, wrote the similarly themed 'Highway To Hell' in 1979. Bon Scott's edgy vocals compete with Young's amped-up vision of Johnson's womanising: 'I'm on the highway to hell/No stop signs, no speed limit/Nobody's gonna slow me down/Like a wheel, gonna spin it/Nobody's gonna mess me around'. In 1937, perhaps predicting his own untimely death, Johnson penned 'Me and the Devil Blues': 'Me and the Devil was walkin' side by side/Me and the Devil, ooh, was walkin' side by side/And I'm going to beat my woman/Until I get satisfied'. 'Highway To Hell' is similarly full of devilish imagery, alternately pleading for absolution while fetishising the occult: 'Hey Satan, paid my dues/Playing in a rocking band/Hey Momma, look at me/I'm on my way to the promised land/I'm on a highway to hell'. It mightn't be any more than coincidence, of course. Only, Young instils the feeling that he might indeed have sold his soul to some otherworldly cause. Always lean and ragged, he looks beanpole thin these days, almost meditative in his craft. His bandmates seem peripheral as Young wields solos like a man running for the finishing line. The group's sexual fixations - no more sophisticated than adolescent fantasies - are legendary. On 'Hard As A Rock', as Johnson blares out the second verse - 'The lightnin' rod, strike it hot/Gonna hit you like a Rushmore rock/No nicotine, and no pipe dreams/So low and dirty it's damn right mean' - a cinema projector swings into view. Animated images of naked, purple-faced dwarves chasing voluptuous maidens race across the screen. As the rhythm section flails out the last chorus, German V2 rockets explode from battlefields, a train enters a tunnel and plumes of gaseous fire ejaculate from sidestage. All impossible to watch without grinning of course, and I leave still sniggering. Next morning, as the train shudders to a halt outside Kentish Town, I break into a smile. Perhaps the railroad metaphor isn't so clumsy after all: as Young well understands, every old Mississippian bluesman should fall on to the wrong side of the tracks.

webTitle: Waltzing off to war

fields.headline: Waltzing off to war
fields.trailText: Royal Ballet Royal Opera House, London WC2
fields.body:
Royal Ballet Royal Opera House, London WC2

Instead of cafeteria dance - a bit of this, a bit of that, something sweet at the end - a good mixed bill of ballets is like a well-chosen menu: each dish enhances another. Anthony Dowell's selection of English ballets to French music (until 20 December) is a five-star programme, excellently danced.

It begins with a premonition of war and ends with an angry elegy. Kenneth MacMillan's closing Gloria, to Francis Poulenc's setting of part of the Latin Mass, summons the spirits of a lost generation. As ecstatic Amens ring out from the chorus in the orchestra pit, the dancers above them tilt their helmeted heads to one side. They are listening to the voices of the dead, whom they are about to join. The context of the ballet is the First World War but the soldiers could belong to any army, any era.

Frederick Ashton's opening ballet, La Valse, has its waltzing couples whirling on the edge of the abyss suggested by Ravel's ominous music. The orchestra, which rumbles almost imperceptibly at the start, ends with a cataclysmic roar. The curtain rises and descends on a haunted ballroom: these demonic dancers, like the Wilis in Giselle, are trapped in time. There is a wonderful moment near the start when a woman in a red dress is swung into the air. Her flaring skirt is a distress beacon, doomed to go unanswered.

Because Ravel's waltz rhythms slip and slide, the distinction in the dancing between hectic and messy is a close call, even with Emmanuel Plasson conducting. It's almost impossible for the men in black, coat-tails flying, to leap and land in unison. But Zenaida Yanowsky, long and willowy as the leading lady in white, is the clear focus of the swirling mass, the queen bee of the swarm.

Ashton's Symphonic Variations (1946), created after the end of the Second World War, floats like the sigh of a long-held breath. The worst is behind. Ashton's magic trick is to ask for unaccented dancing: if the six soloists 'just do' the steps, without emphasising any at the expense of others, the choreography flows effortlessly on César Franck's music. If the dancers are seen to try too hard - especially the two women, who have to keep pace with the fastest variation - they can look frantic. Belinda Hatley and Jaimie Tapper get it just right. Miyako Yoshida in the central role is blessed with a thistledown jump, so light that her partner, Inaki Urlezaga, seems scarcely to hold her.

Antony Tudor's Lilac Garden (1936), at the heart of the programme, has been high on Dowell's wish-list of ballets for his farewell season as artistic director. The potential problem for audiences here is that Lilac Garden is a very English ballet, returning changed by its reincarnation in the United States, where Tudor emigrated in 1939. Its American curator, Sallie Wilson, has mounted it with French ballerina Sylvie Guillem in the leading role of Caroline.

It could have been a travesty: instead, it's a gift to treasure. True, Guillem's style is too extravagant to be in period: the ballet is set in Edwardian times, when emotions were buttoned up behind a stiff upper lip. Caroline has to renounce her lover and marry a stick of a man she does not love - an unlikely sacrifice for a woman of Guillem's temperament. But she is a magnificent dance-actress, and she makes it work.

Her high extensions when she dances with her lover are in great contrast with her submissive posture towards her husband-to-be. She absents her true self from her encounters with the man she must marry: she can't bear to touch him or meet his eyes. He takes her away from her life at the end, renouncing his past as well. Everyone in the lilac-drenched garden is in collusion, covering up for each other, preserving the facade.

All the young men are in dress-uniform. In the context of this programme, their military bearing is a reminder that their world is about to crack apart. The pretty girls who try to console Caroline's broken-hearted lover will soon be bandaging his wounds. Like Ashton's waltzers and MacMillan's soldiers, Tudor's Edwardians shield their eyes in pain.
