webTitle: Tea and sympathy with the geisha girl from Azerbaijan

fields.headline: Tea and sympathy with the geisha girl from Azerbaijan
fields.trailText: Madama Butterfly Scottish Opera, Theatre Royal, Glasgow
fields.body:
Madama Butterfly Scottish Opera, Theatre Royal, Glasgow

Opera costs a lot and frays the nerves of accountants and executives. It is an emotional art form both on and off the stage (and not only in London). Scottish Opera has endured severe financial hardships in the past few seasons, compounded by administrative muddle and loss of key personnel. Yet its productions, with only one or two exceptions, have been outstanding. Musical standards remain high and musicians perform with palpable enthusiasm. Somewhere, someone has had the imagination to secure exceptional combinations of singers and artists.

The results have been impressive. Their Wagner earlier this year - Parsifal and Rheingold - won high praise. Now a new Madama Butterfly produced by David McVicar, fresh from his radical staging of La Bohème for Glyndebourne Touring Opera, adds to the company's roster of accomplishments.

In contrast to his Bohème, this Butterfly observes convention down to the smallest detail. The argument that the more popular an opera is, the more it requires updating, conceptualising or generally messing around simply does not apply to Butterfly . Puccini's realisation of the true-life story of a young geisha girl who marries, and then is deserted by Pinkerton, a brash American naval officer, defies attempts to separate it from its cultural context. The musical content in effect forbids it: five Japanese folk songs and pentatonic motifs are woven into the score together with Sousa's 'The Stars and Stripes Forever'. Not much scope for concentration camp, espresso bar or inner-city wasteland settings here (though doubtless they have been tried).

Yannis Thavoris, the designer, has created a clean, handsome set in which eccentric particulars (such as the tilted perspective) offset tradition and familiarity. All is minimal, in echt Japanese style. A teahouse of seemingly perfect authenticity fills the stage, its flimsy sliding panels - upon which Pinkerton snidely comments - implying a fragility at the heart of this make-believe love nest. In Act II, it adapts to become the house interior. In each case, the structure of the house creates framed images in which the action takes place. Butterfly wears a version of geisha costume and arranges her only belongings - a clasp, a clay pot, the dagger with which her father killed himself - on a small shrine to one side. Her censorious family dresses in sober Edwardian costume (the work was premiered in 1904), as if at once flirting with foreign customs while yet condemning Butterfly for falling prey to their very charms.

One of McVicar's strengths as a director is his ability to push singers to explore the dramatic potential of their characters. Here, as in Bohème, Puccini's apparently two-dimensional figures (they are often portrayed as such) can take on greater psychological depth, enabling us to hear with new, bright clarity what the music is telling us. Pinkerton can seem merely a rudimentarily cruel xenophobe and no more. Here, expressively sung by Ian Storey, he seemed almost poignant - genuinely captivated by Butterfly, blindly and clumsily unaware of his power over her. His actions are shockingly crass, while his musical character is strangely vulnerable. For the first time, he won our sympathy.

When he returns, married to an American bride, his remorse at finding the faithful Butterfly still waiting for him seems real. No longer is this merely a bathetic tale of cultural imperialism but a human love triangle in which Pinkerton, at the centre, has wholly misjudged the situation. There is nothing here that we don't already know, but McVicar has made the drama boldly convincing. Without tricks or gimmickry, he has added salt to the cloying sweetness of this dangerously sentimental drama. Indulgently done, no opera makes one more inclined to share Britten's view of Puccini ('I think his operas are dreadful'). But mawkishness is kept to a minimum in this brisk, thoughtful production.

Guido Ajmone-Marsan, conducting, must take much of the credit. He tackled the edgily contrapuntal orchestral opening with an attack which showed he meant business. The orchestra responded with zest and pre cision, sustaining momentum throughout the evening yet saving enough passion for the grand, tear-jerking climax. In the title role, the Azerbaijani soprano Natalia Dercho demonstrated intensity, fervour and intelligence. Her powerful voice has a slightly rasping edge. If this perhaps reduced the usual tenderness or fragility of the child-bride, it nevertheless added emotional depth. Peter Van Hulle's simpering, whining Goro was excellent and Jason Howard, despite a heavy cold, brought insight and troubled humanity to the role of Sharpless, with Jane Irwin equally touching as the maid Suzuki. As Butterfly's young son, forced to watch his mother destroy herself, Sam Aschavir pulled our collective heartstrings and stole the show.

Another small boy could be said to have stolen the show at the opening ceremony of the Great Court of the British Museum. The eight-year-old Mozart's short sacred piece, 'God is our Refuge and Strength', was sung by in-house singers on Wednesday night. This motet is the first vocal composition in the Kochel catalogue (the list of Mozart's works compiled by an admiring botanist nearly a century later). With remarkable foresight, Leopold Mozart presented the score to the museum in July 1765 so that they might have a copy of his son's work. As a symbol of promise for the future, it was a fitting choice to salute the new building.

webTitle: A love skate relationship in Somerset House's liberated courtyard

fields.headline: A love skate relationship in Somerset House's liberated courtyard
fields.standfirst: The transformation of the former Civil Service redoubt continues with the opening of London's only outdoor ice rink
fields.trailText: The transformation of the former Civil Service redoubt continues with the opening of London's only outdoor ice rink
fields.body:
Somerset House feels as if it is turning into a particularly upmarket village green, run by a committee of particularly altruistic squires bent on outdoing each other with ever more munificent entertainment.

With the eviction of parked cars from its courtyard and the liberation of large parts of the interior from the clutches of the Civil Service, it has turned into a place to sit out in summer to watch its fountains gushing up in unpredictable spouts without any visible warning of where the next jet will come from. They have prompted such outbreaks of conspicuously un-British behaviour as fully clothed, apparently sober, commuters taking a dip. And from this week it will become central London's only outdoor ice rink.

Rockefeller Centre this is not. Somerset House's rink is a temporary structure, which will sit like a shallow pool on the cobble stones. Somerset House's resident architects Jeremy Dixon and Edward Jones (the team behind the Opera House and the National Portrait Gallery extension) have done little more than tidy up an off-the-peg design and advise against striped canvas awnings. 'They would have looked too much like pyjamas,' says Jones. 'And we worried about the shape of the balustrade.' But despite initial scepticism, the rink looks set to be as popular as the fountains.

The rink, which will be open late into the evening thanks to special floodlighting, cleverly deals with the courtyard's pronounced slope by being deeper at one end than the other. Skaters will be able to perform in front of their friends sitting in the sheltered seats under awnings. And a balustrade is in position to stop them cannoning off into the crowd.

'My fellow trustees thought I was daft when I first mentioned it,' says Ricky Burdett, who runs the London School of Economics' cities unit just across the road and is able to use the Somerset House as a live case study in urban renewal.

Ever since that famous painting by Sir Henry Raeburn of a portly Scottish gent taking to the ice in a top hat, skating has managed to convey a powerful mix of glamour and good-natured fun. It offers something to do in the city that is a brilliant alternative to the bovine passivity of shopping.

Somerset House has had a remarkable year. Duncan Wilson, director of the trust that runs the building, says visitor numbers are on course for one million - double the number expected. 'Above all, the liberation of Somerset House's courtyard has given London a magnificent new urban space, used by thousands of commuters every day as they walk north over Waterloo Bridge, past the fountains in the courtyard and out into the Strand,' says Wilson.

Burdett says: 'The first job was to attract people to what is really a totally unknown part of London.'

Despite its remarkable setting, Somerset House was not a natural draw initially. When the Courtauld Institute moved in a decade ago, it had fewer visitors for its collection of paintings than before it moved from Bloomsbury. That is why the concerts and the fountains and the ice rink are so important. And they have certainly delivered.

The Gilbert Collection of silverware, sweet enough to make your fillings ache, may not be everybody's cup of tea, but it has been beautifully installed, and attracted an audience. And now there is a glimpse of the Hermitage, also brought to London by the indefatigable Jacob Rothschild, whose idea the new Somerset House is. But it does not stop there. The Inland Revenue clings to 200,000 sq ft of office space in the west range of the courtyard and there is more space unused in the south block, looking out over the Thames. With an audience in place, the trust has time to ponder its next moves. Potential tenants would include anything from the Architecture Foundation, looking to set up a public architecture centre for London, to the Hayward Gallery, which will need a temporary home if it ever gets round to rebuilding its existing accommodation across the river.

The problem is that, despite the palatial façades that Sir William Chambers designed for the government office block that Somerset House once was, the interiors are mainly domestically scaled. 'Users would need to be able to work with suites of rooms, rather than big spaces,' says Wilson.

'We have to leave some of it as commercial space, because it is those rents that pay everything,' he adds, 'but we have been talking to the Courtauld about moving its Impressionist paintings into a new gallery in the south range, which would free up space in the wing overlooking the Strand for temporary exhibition space.'

The Inland Revenue has a 22-year lease on its part of the building, but there are hints that it may move out long before that.

The ice rink opens on Thursday and closes on 7 January. 11am-10pm daily (24-hour info line: 020 7845 4670). £6 for adults; £4 for children under 12 (including skate hire).

webTitle: If you want to feel better, keep on taking the tablas

fields.headline: If you want to feel better, keep on taking the tablas
fields.standfirst: Nitin Sawhney trawls the world - and uses its fastest rapper - to create a masterful show
fields.trailText: Nitin Sawhney The Forum, London NW5
fields.body:
Nitin Sawhney The Forum, London NW5

'Beyond politics, beyond nationality, beyond religion, beyond skin' - Nitin Sawhney's credo, projected on to a massive screen behind him - may be utopian, but his show last Thursday realised it perfectly.

Sawhney's much acclaimed 1999 album Beyond Skin remains the most accomplished fusion of Indian and Western influences to date, entwining funk and flamenco with the subcontinent's classical forms and adding a narrative that reflects his experiences as a British Asian. Live, its creator seems an almost marginal figure, sitting behind his keyboards to one side of the stage while a succession of vocal talents take turns with his songs, and a deftly edited barrage of images and film clips provides visual commentary upon them. With a string quartet and a busy rhythm section also in play, the show works better then one might imagine, building a series of enchanting moments into an uplifting experience.

Many of the highlights were provided by the lanky, bearded figure of Jayanta Gose, a singer of wondrous quality. After an opening wail straight from a temple courtyard, set to tremulous bass synth and with a shot of planet earth to go with it, he moved on to some soaring, meditative melodies for numbers like 'Vidya'. He was soon holding his own in an Anglo-Hindi rapping duel with JC001, a bounding figure who is listed in the Guinness Book of Records as the fastest rapper alive. Propelled by a tabla blitz, the exchange of phonetic fisticuffs between the two men is a phenomenon you won't see anywhere else.

Entirely different shades were provided by Sawhney's three female vocalists. Tina Grace delivered a new song, 'Cold and Intimate', which was laced with a bluesy, rocky feel. Nina Miranda, of Brazilian group Smoke City, lent her lilting samba tones to 'Homelands', a number that wafts breezily between Rio and Bombay. Then there was Eska, blasting soulfully forth alongside Jayanta Bose on 'Immigrant', and various other combinations to keep the palate refreshed.

Sawhney himself is content to act as musical director, periodically turning aside from his keyboards to pick and strum at an acoustic Spanish guitar, threading delicate flamenco lines through numbers. Flamenco and North Indian classical, he contends, are close relations, and he has the music to prove it.

Towards the end, the mood shifted soberly to 'Beyond Skin', a commentary on nuclear weapons (no minor issue where India and Pakistan are concerned), with Robert Oppenheimer's quotation from Indian scripture, 'Now I am become death, Vishnu, the destroyer of worlds', on the screen. For a finale there was 'Broken Skin', a number soaked in jazz-funk influences which were also apparent on the encore - a massed rendition of the clubland favourite, Nuyorican Soul's 'Black Gold of the Sun'.

It was a masterful performance, drawing a line beneath Beyond Skin . Next month he sets off to draw inspiration from sources as disparate as South Africa, Aboriginal Australia and Native America - while collaborations with Sting and Algeria's Cheb Mami are in the bag for his next record. Watch his space.

webTitle: Let's get metaphysical

fields.headline: Let's get metaphysical
fields.standfirst: Yasmina Reza goes cosmic in the living room; Rita, Sue and Bob do it in the car...
fields.trailText:
Life x 3 Lyttelton, London SE1
Rita, Sue and Bob Too & A State Affair Soho, London W1
I Just Stopped By To See The Man Royal Court, London SW1
Pinocchio Lyric Hammersmith, London W6
fields.body:
Life x 3 Lyttelton, London SE1
Rita, Sue and Bob Too & A State Affair Soho, London W1
I Just Stopped By To See The Man Royal Court, London SW1
Pinocchio Lyric Hammersmith, London W6

Minimally, millennially chic, Yasmina Reza is one of the most acclaimed and commercially successful dramatists of the past decade. To see her new play - the best since Art, now in its fourth year in the West End - is to understand why. Life x 3 is swift, sharply phrased, poised and awash with uncertainty.

Under Matthew Warchus's flawless direction, it draws from Mark Thompson an expressive design which makes the audience feel like interlopers in a Soho club: a naturalistic sitting room is trapped within a rectangle of fluorescent lights. It's stingingly well translated by Christopher Hampton. It's performed by four magnificent actors. But what's it for?

Three different versions are provided of one evening. An ill-prepared astrophysicist and his wife (a lawyer, but that's not her main point) are obliged to entertain a couple who might offer the husband professional advancement. In the first (the funniest) version, the wails of a child punctuate the action; in another, the infant is pronounced unusually self-sufficient. In one version, the host breaks down at news of a rival's publication; in another, he is stimulated by it. His wife is in turn intrigued by their male guest ('When a woman says "arrogant", she means attractive') and totally seduced.

As in Michael Frayn's Copenhagen, a correspondence is suggested between human and cosmic manoeuvres. But in Frayn's play a scientific proposition is precisely mapped on to human behaviour. Here, a comedy is lightly tethered to a vague speculation: just as, the argument seems to go, there are black holes and unknowable matter in the universe, so there are in human conduct. Meanwhile, a predictable rift opens up between the erudite and the empathetic. This is not a resonant play: it's a wheeze hitching a ride from metaphysics.

But it gives rise to an airborne production. A perfectly assured Oliver Cotton is an Alan Clark-style lounge lizard; Imelda Staunton is always truthful as she crumples and flares; Harriet Walter turns from tiger to kitten with a lift of her chin and a flick of her heel. Mark Rylance, as always, makes every line sing and every line his own. Together, these actors present a masterclass in comic timing.

An entirely different lesson is to be learnt from Max Stafford-Clark's production of Rita, Sue and Bob Too. Andrea Dunbar's play, set on a Bradford council estate, was first staged in 1982: it's lost none of its conviction. Two 15-year-old schoolgirls cop off with a married man, taking it in enthusiastic turn to have a 'jump' with him in his car: ankle socks wave in the air, rubber johnnies slosh around alarmingly.

Within Es Devlin's coal-black cave of a design - in which windows turn out to be television screens - are enacted divorce, a pregnancy, a major street row, a muted feminist ending. The play carries its themes lightly. The dialogue is punchy and funny. The girls are brilliantly played by Emily Aston and Emma Rydal: vigorously fleshy, vocally deadpan, hilarious, callous and loyal. Thatcherite policies are glimpsed obliquely: men who lose their jobs lose their cars - and their potency.

Dunbar was writing about the world she came from: she did so with the confidence of an insider. The other half of the Soho double bill is Robin Soans's A State Affair, a compilation of interviews conducted this year on Dunbar's estate. These interleaved first-hand accounts have the anti-climactic ebb-and-flow structure of documentary; they are performed with a combination of naturalism and rhetoric. They show that things have got worse since Dunbar's day: the old fear was pregnancy; the new fear is death from drugs. Stafford-Clark's idea of the theatre as a place for reporting news is an important one; he directs superbly: he will help secure Soho's reputation as a beacon for realistic drama in London.

Richard Wilson's direction is proving one of the Royal Court's chief assets. In his hands, I Just Stopped By To See The Man has so many beguiling touches that you're almost charmed into overlooking the hokum at the centre of Stephen Jeffrey's play.

It's inspiriting to hear the blues sung - that's to say, barked, yelped, whinnied and growled - by Tommy Hollis, whose grave and gravel-voiced performance is the linchpin of the evening. It's enlivening to watch Julian McGowan's design - a small, faded clapboard house - crack apart, to reveal a garish wider horizon. It's fascinating to see Sophie Okonedo picking a tear-sodden, haughty path through her trials.

But who would think that improbability and cliché could be so closely intertwined? Surrey rock star (a stranger to real pain) prises ex-cotton-pickin' blues singer (dignified and honourable) out of unexplained hidey-hole and is allowed to play his guitar; blues singer's graduate daughter turns out to be a gun-toting political activist. Sorry, but I don't believe it.

Parents and teachers are reported to have been alarmed at the use of rude words (eg 'balls') in Lee Hall's version of Pinocchio. Actually, the original tale is latently lewd, what with the wooden puppet's famous expanding protuberance: 'I'm a boy,' he whoops unnecessarily at the play's climax.

Under Marcello Magni's direction, it's not crudity but dolefulness that's the worry. Grisliness - the rabbit of death, a blinded cat, a defunct, blue-rinse fairy - isn't sufficiently leavened by pleasure. To the accompaniment of an accordion - most solitary of instruments - Pinocchio is disconcertingly turned from wood to flesh, from tiny to overgrown: he's a big puppet manipulated by two dark figures got up like gangsters; he's a tiny puppet tossed across the stage in a giant net; he's a human played like an escapee from the Ministry of Silly Walks. He's loomed over by a giant scarlet monster-puppet; the entire stage is swallowed up by the huge crimson jaws of a shark. The story is obscured by the relentless cutting of capers: it's a continuously ingenious evening, but rarely magical.

webTitle: School or friend? You decide

fields.headline: School or friend? You decide
fields.trailText: My daughter is due to start primary school in January. I have succeeded in placing her at a school near the top of the league tables. However, her best friend, whom she has known since they were babies, is going to   a different school, one my daughter probably could have gone to if I had applied there.
fields.body:
My daughter is due to start primary school in January. I have succeeded in placing her at a school near the top of the league tables. However, her best friend, whom she has known since they were babies, is going to a different school, one my daughter probably could have gone to if I had applied there.

She is very upset that she and her friend are going to be separated and now I am questioning my decision. Is there a danger I will put her off education from day one? I am keen for her to make new, different friends, not just the ones she has known from playgroup, and also get the best education possible, but not at the price of her happiness.
A.H. of Hayes

Every devoted mama loses her sense of proportion at times and becomes convinced that the extremes of happiness or misery of her child's future hinges upon a decision that may in truth carry little weight. As a parent you are primed to be in the most unselfish mode you will ever experience. You cannot bear to think of your daughter suffering; but this intense emotional input on your part can impair your judgement.

It is better to be over-anxious than laissez-faire, though. Your daughter, like all children, will make friends with consummate ease. It would hardly be a desirable outcome if she went through her entire school career with only one and the same bosom chum. Nor is it at all likely. At primary school, she will come into contact with a larger group of people, will discover new affinities, new channels, fresh areas of mutual interest.

It is even possible that she will maintain an old friendship better because it is not competing with new ones. She is certainly better placed to engage with her new companions if she is not cosily concealed behind a familiar figure. It is also good to have a friend outside the school, one who can enlarge her circle of friends in the future.

Objective assessment of the school's educational potential is important, but bear in mind that league tables are crude measures of relative merits.

You have chosen the school as well as you can, but make sure you monitor it constantly.

Readers' replies

You have left it too late to worry about your daughter's happiness. Did you consult her or the parent(s) of her best friend while you were considering which primary school to choose? Your dilemma highlights the danger of making choices solely on the basis of league tables. I suggest, as a former chair of governors of a primary school, that you see how your daughter settles in. If she is not thriving by the beginning of the summer term, find out whether there are vacancies in the other school; if there are, arrange a visit. Remember that moving schools can be traumatic, so proceed carefully.
C.G. of Birmingham

Although your daughter is understandably upset at the prospect of going to a different school from her best friend, I think you're making the right decision in trying to get the best possible education for her. Starting primary school can be an anxious time for parents and children, but it's also exciting and opens up new experi ences, challenges and people to meet. You could help your daughter by trying to meet up with other children in her class before term starts, and encourage her to build new friendships by inviting friends home. At the same time, it's important to assure your daughter that she can still see her best friend.
B.B. of Edinburgh

Next week's dilemma

My fiancé and I plan to marry next May. We have been together for three years. The problem is that my fiancé is Afro-Carribbean and I am white. My father, who is 72, is opposed to our marriage. He feels it would be unfair to bring up a child of mixed race, even though we are both atheists and there would be no religious conflict.

I love my fiancé but does my father have a point? Is it unfair to bring a mixed-race child into the world?
Y.D. of Basingstoke

webTitle: Your heroes, our heroes

fields.headline: Your heroes, our heroes
fields.standfirst: Who is your Man or Woman of the Year? The Observer wants its readers to vote for the person who most inspired Britain in 2000. This is your chance to have a say
fields.trailText: What are the qualities we look for in the people we admire? Or, to put it another way, what makes a Man or Woman of the Year? Is it to do with power or success or charisma or triumphing over adversity, or what? Is it political, commercial, artistic or spiritual? Is it courage, dedication or performance? Is it..? Well, what is that intangible, but instantly recognisable, quality that gives A the edge over B and C?
fields.body:
What are the qualities we look for in the people we admire? Or, to put it another way, what makes a Man or Woman of the Year? Is it to do with power or success or charisma or triumphing over adversity, or what? Is it political, commercial, artistic or spiritual? Is it courage, dedication or performance? Is it..? Well, what is that intangible, but instantly recognisable, quality that gives A the edge over B and C?

It's all relative, of course. The answers to these questions will vary from country to country, from community to community. In America, it's a fair bet that Time and Newsweek will reflect the values of their society and choose someone like Hillary Clinton or Madonna or - perish the thought - George Dubya. In France, such polls have nominated philosophers, artists, latter-day militants like eco-protesting farmer José Bové, generals and film stars. But in Britain - what, or rather, who?

Do we, for instance, really subscribe to the cult of celebrity ? Is fame - and yet more fame - what matters? Or do we, in our secret hearts, want to redress the balance of power, to break away from an agenda set by an omnivorous, and seemingly omniscient, news media? Dorothy Parker, a woman who knew a thing or two about the workings of the press and its values, once wrote: 'I'm never going to be famous. My name will never be writ large on the roster of Those Who Do Things. I don't do anything. Not one single thing. I used to bite my nails, but I don't even do that any more.'

From the catalogue of Those Who Do Things, but glancing away from the headlines and the morning blare of the Today programme, should we recognise fearless Don Hale, the editor of the Matlock Mercury whose long campaign to free Stephen Downing (wrongly jailed for 27 years for a murder he did not commit) looks to be on the brink of vindication? There can can be few finer achievements in recent journalism. Or should we pick out Sir Nicholas Serota, the man behind Tate Modern? Or Tim Smit, the eco-dome fanatic from Cornwall whose vision of a better future environment will speak urgently to thousands of waterlogged home-owners? Or Pam Warren, 'the lady in the mask' who so bravely gave evidence at the Paddington rail inquiry? Or Joanne Rowling, for giving so many millions of hours of reading pleasure to so many millions of all ages? Or Steve Redgrave, that 'oar-some' Olympic champion? Or Nigella Lawson for her grace, charm and fortitude? Or the amazingly talented Susan Greenfield, for making science as approachable as high-heels? Or Sam Mendes, the prodigiously gifted director of the year's best film, American Beauty?

The choice, frankly, is endless and impossible to adjudicate. Which is why we are placing it in your hands.

Observer readers are not easy to characterise. Like the newspaper itself, they are instinctively original. They do not dwell in pigeonholes. They resist labelling. They know their own minds. And they are interested in an extraordinary range of pursuits, which may or may not include crossword puzzles. They want the world to be their oyster. There's probably no guessing who, finally, will emerge from an Observer poll that's only slightly less haphazard than Miami-Dade's.

Who might I nominate? I am thinking of a woman. She is not wholly unknown, but not celebrated (wouldn't want to be). She has, indeed, been mentioned in the press several times. She has many devoted admirers. She is both steely, yet seductive, fiercely high-minded yet amusingly opportunistic. Her work does nothing but good, and for those around her she is the queen of all she surveys. Is she, then, my woman of the year? Perhaps.

Then again you may decide that a Man or Woman of the Year should have already achieved some measure of public recognition, which would exclude our private and personal heroes and heroines. The choice is yours.

Humankind, according to the Chinese proverb, should fear fame as pigs fear fat. Whoever you nominate will be slightly taken aback, probably surprised, possibly a little bit pleased, and certainly apprehensive for the consequences.

Andy Warhol, at the end of his life, said: 'I'm bored with that line ["In the future, everyone will be famous for 15 minutes"]. I never use it any more. My new line is, "In 15 minutes everybody will be famous." '

The clock is ticking. As they say in Tallahassee, vote early, vote often.

There are two ways to vote for your Man and Woman of the Year:

On a postcard to

The Observer Man/Woman of the Year, The Observer Review, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

By email to person.of.the.year@observer.co.uk

Please include a reason of no more than 20 words for your choice.

Visit the Observer website at www.observer.co.uk/personoftheyear to find out more and discuss possible candidates with other users.

Votes must be received by noon on Tuesday 19 December and the results will be announced on New Year's Eve.

Or Joanne Rowling, for giving so many millions of hours of reading pleasure to so many millions of all ages? Or Steve Redgrave, that 'oar-some' Olympic champion? Or Nigella Lawson for her grace, charm and fortitude? Or the amazingly talented Susan Greenfield, for making science as approachable as high-heels? Or Sam Mendes, the prodigiously gifted director of the year's best film, American Beauty? The choice, frankly, is endless and impossible to adjudicate. Which is why we are placing it in your hands. Observer readers are not easy to characterise. Like the newspaper itself, they are instinctively original. They do not dwell in pigeonholes. They resist labelling. They know their own minds. And they are interested in an extraordinary range of pursuits, which may or may not include crossword puzzles. They want the world to be their oyster. There's probably no guessing who, finally, will emerge from an Observer poll that's only slightly less haphazard than Miami-Dade's. Who might I nominate? I am thinking of a woman. She is not wholly unknown, but not celebrated (wouldn't want to be). She has, indeed, been mentioned in the press several times. She has many devoted admirers. She is both steely, yet seductive, fiercely high-minded yet amusingly opportunistic. Her work does nothing but good, and for those around her she is the queen of all she surveys. Is she, then, my woman of the year? Perhaps. Then again you may decide that a Man or Woman of the Year should have already achieved some measure of public recognition, which would exclude our private and personal heroes and heroines. The choice is yours. Humankind, according to the Chinese proverb, should fear fame as pigs fear fat. Whoever you nominate will be slightly taken aback, probably surprised, possibly a little bit pleased, and certainly apprehensive for the consequences. Andy Warhol, at the end of his life, said: 'I'm bored with that line ["In the future, everyone will be famous for 15 minutes"]. I never use it any more. My new line is, "In 15 minutes everybody will be famous." ' The clock is ticking. As they say in Tallahassee, vote early, vote often. There are two ways to vote for your Man and Woman of the Year: On a postcard to The Observer Man/Woman of the Year, The Observer Review, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER By email to person.of.the.year@observer.co.uk Please include a reason of no more than 20 words for your choice. Visit the Observer website at www.observer.co.uk/personoftheyear to find out more and discuss possible candidates with other users. Votes must be received by noon on Tuesday 19 December and the results will be announced on New Year's Eve.

webTitle: My bra ended up in a field of cows... because I'm worth it

fields.headline: My bra ended up in a field of cows... because I'm worth it
fields.trailText: As I turned to watch my dark blue La Perla bra and knickers flying across a Normandy cowfield, I knew that this was the nail in the coffin of my half-hearted attempt to become a Because I'm Worth It kind of gal.
fields.body:
As I turned to watch my dark blue La Perla bra and knickers flying across a Normandy cowfield, I knew that this was the nail in the coffin of my half-hearted attempt to become a Because I'm Worth It kind of gal.

I had made a drunken pact with a friend who, like me, can't really be bothered to make the best of herself. Both of us bite our nails and have days when we dress in an unflattering and eccentric way. Sometimes we do give the impression of gorgeousness, but it's a transvestite kind of glamour - all fancy gowns and teetering heels. Neither of us goes down well in Paris, where beautifully groomed women tell you off for eating in the street and having thread hanging from your hem.

My friend and I decided that we would have a go at being 'ladies' - try to discover some mystique - because being hearty had done neither of us much good. Both of us are closely related to ladylike women, and some of our best friends are ladies too, so we concluded that it has nothing to do with title, class, money, looks or body size.

Instead, the main characteristic of Because I'm Worth It ladies is that they have their legs, bikini-line and eyebrows waxed at regular intervals, go to the hairdressers quite often and buy lots of face creams. Their partners never see them on the loo, exfoliating, or have any inkling of how much time and money they spend on their appearance. These women tell you, with a little laugh, that they are 'high-maintenance'. They treat themselves to things they feel they 'deserve': massages, facials, private gynaecologists.

The pecking order among ladies and non-ladies is so strong that even though one of my friends (a lady through and through) and I were pregnant at the same time, when we went out shopping together I found that I didn't hesitate to carry her bags too. People do things for the Because I'm Worth It type; hearty types are expected to muck in.

Oh yes, and ladies ration sex so that their husbands and lovers always long for more, whereas women like me make men run away gasping for air and screaming 'Too much intimacy, too much intimacy!'

Which brings me back to the bra and knickers. Having surprised my husband by asking for underwear for my birthday - as part of the attempt to be 'worth it' - I decided to take my La Perla, rather then the usual dull stuff, on our family camping holiday. I stuffed the underwear into the ugly pod that sits on the roof-rack - we had bought it the day before from Exchange & Mart; there was something wrong with the lock.

My husband was driving when the pod suddenly opened its jaws and vomited my clothes into the muddy cowfield. My daughter, clearly a lady-in-waiting, alerted me, and as I turned to look I saw £230 of lace disappearing over the hedge. A cow may have eaten it, or perhaps it found its way to a farmer's wife. If so, let's hope she's worth it.

webTitle: In the lap of the gods

fields.headline: In the lap of the gods
fields.standfirst: The Buddha, the Virgin and Mayan deities cluster too close for comfort in the British Museum's new gallery
fields.trailText: Human Image Joseph Hotung Great Court Gallery, British Museum, London WC1 until 11 February
fields.body:
Human Image Joseph Hotung Great Court Gallery, British Museum, London WC1 until 11 February

Far above the Great Court a tiny plane glides by, its vapour trail hyphenated in the immense lattice of Norman Foster's glass roof. The whole sky seems to be contained in this rival canopy. Light chases across its vaulting expanse, clouds cast shadows on the marble courtyard below. Watch long enough and you might see the Milky Way appear. You feel yourself shrink as you look.

Bigger than the Turbine Hall, higher than the Dome, the Great Court dwarfs everything in sight. It wants you to be lost in awe, amazed by the architecture, dazzled by its canyon of pale, gleaming stone. The scale is completely inhuman - how could it not be? Foster's canopy has to accommodate a quartet of neoclassical facades, the largest courtyard in Europe and the full height of the Reading Room, its dome even larger than St Paul's. All the pigeons in Trafalgar Square could wing through this space and seem no more than a pinch of confetti.

Enter through any of the four grand doors and you immediately become part of the spectacle, a walk-on in the Library Scene, an extra in the milling crowd. Gaze up at the broad, spiral stair case that wraps around the Reading Room and you see others leaning over the bannisters like passengers at the prow of the Titanic. Climb those steps yourself and you can look way down into Sydney Smirke's great rotunda and see your fellow actors wandering the set with its authentic props: the desk where Karl Marx wrote Das Kapital, the catalogues where vanished readers once prospected for books.

Presuming on his modesty, I don't believe Foster would claim any more for his designs than that they enhance what already existed. His stairways take you inches from the roof of those neoclassical facades, put you on a level with Smirke's fabulous cupola, where you can see the original latticework from which Foster so clearly took his cue. He has clarified the British Museum's muddled layout by making the Great Court its central hub - and he's done it by illuminating the architectural past. The only confusion left is the museum's baffling, even shocking response.

'A vibrant meeting place' is the museum's telling description of the Great Court, as if it were no more than a mall full of cafés and shops selling lattice-pattern ties. Monumental sculptures have been installed beside the four doors as 'markers' to the different wings. An Easter Island statue, once vast, is now reduced to another face in the crowd - albeit magnificently stern - beside a busy exit. The monumental lion that crowned a cliff edge in Turkey, four centuries before Christ, now acts as a handy signpost to the Asian collection. As for the Joseph Hotung Gallery itself, in which objects are jammed like ornaments in a cupboard, I guess it's a shorthand 'taster' for the rest of the museum.

The gallery is a meagre space, a curve of corridor up near the roof that feels like an awkward attic. It is far too small for the 100 works in 'Human Image', the opening exhibition. If they were hairpins, stamps and toby jugs, it might just be big enough. But these are some of the largest, not to say greatest, treasures anywhere in the museum - marble goddesses, golden gods, tall totems with elaborate ritual scars. Michelangelo's sketch for the Sistine Adam could do with a wall to itself. The stunning Discobolus, a classical athlete compressing all his rippling power into one fling of the discus, would fill the gallery in its own right.

Still, the curators have made the best of their lot, dividing this tight space into nine separate zones - Creation, Devotion, Power and so forth, any category broad enough to unite an Estonian banknote, say, and a statue of Mao in the same notional bracket. These zones are eccentric. The Greek Nereid you might expect to find under Perfection appears in the Drapery department, her tunic contrasted with the Fortuny pleats of an Egyptian monarch. Meanwhile, the Degas drawing of woman alongside is not remotely concerned with drapes. What's so startling here is that the woman looks straight back at you through a pair of binoculars - as if caught on early Kodak in a Paris crowd.

Clearly, these categories are meant to tease. Shouldn't Mao be in Power? Doesn't this amazing bronze Hercules deserve to be in Portraits, since it looks exactly like a Scorsese mafioso? Why is this African head, its features so exquisitely refined, in Abstraction instead of Perfection? The answer to that one lies in Picasso's sketch for Les Demoiselles d'Avignon, placed just beyond it in a cunning sightline.

Spot the likeness, make the connection: that's the idea behind this show. But the associations it sets up are often meaningless and visually trite. A bust of sightless Homer is reflected in the glass protecting a Japanese watercolour of Diogenes: two greybeards - so what? A crystal skull sits next to a sinister Aztec mask, made from a human skull inlaid with turquoise and jet, two spheres of glinting pyrite for eyeballs. The juxtaposition makes dead-heads of them both, yet the mask is that most extraordinary leap of imagination: an image of the Mexican god Tezcatlipoca, a likeness of something - or someone - that cannot be seen.

So many of the objects in this show were made to awe and unsettle. They were vested with powers that Western art hasn't been able to muster for centuries. How they were once seen, what they were for: you get at least some sense of this when you come across them in the museum's separate collections. Out of context, shoehorned in with Picasso and the rest, they are merely presented as unusual examples of the human image; worse, as source material for modern art.

It might be argued that nothing could diminish the impact of the Mayan maize god, so beautiful in his erotic trance. Or the thirteenth-century ivory Virgin, leaning back to get a prouder look at the child in her lap. Or the tiny Buddha, desert winds lifting his fragile robes. But jam them all together in a frantic cocktail party and you can barely see them, let alone experience their charisma. Just as the Great Court now looks like a giant computer graphic, flawless, smooth and utterly impersonal, so this show, in the words of the chief curator, is meant to function like hypertext. Why not, in that case, consign all these pointless cross-references to one of the computers in the Reading Room and allow these great works of art to speak uniquely for themselves?

webTitle: Real men don't shop. We just swoop and buy

fields.headline: Real men don't shop. We just swoop and buy
fields.standfirst: Ordering a gift token from a website is male shopping heaven, writes  Phil Hogan
fields.trailText: Ordering a gift token from a website is male shopping heaven, writes  Phil Hogan
fields.body:
It's that time of year again when all good people are trying to avoid Christmas shopping, especially us men. It's not just that we can't stand shopping; we hate it in our own idiosyncratic, highly complex way. The famous distinction between 'going shopping' - which counts as a leisure activity - and 'doing the shopping' - which was first added to a woman's list of things to complain about when supermarkets were built - is one that perfectly separates men and women.

Men - who are naturally more laidback about domestic drudgery - refuse to make a chore of food shopping, even at Christmas. While women go round Sainsbury's in hiking boots with an alphabeticised list and an architect's drawing of the store in their head, men tend to be more intuitive and discerning and creative. We prefer to wander freely, flouting supermarket law by dawdling our way back to the same aisle more than once, humming and hawing, wondering what smoked oysters are like. Left to our own urges we come back laden with Danish pastries and convenient ready-to-eats with sell-by dates the day after tomorrow, plus perhaps a tin of peas and a Fray Bentos steak-and-kidney pie for emergency storage (nuclear aftermath, unexpected divorce, antidote to turkey overdose). If we do return with oven-cleaner or Mr Muscle for Bathrooms, it is because we have accidentally picked up one of somebody else's carrier bags.

So, no, we don't mind going to the supermarket, as long as we don't get earache for being spontaneous and taking all week about it. What we do hate is having to shop for clothes, which involves abandoning the relative safety of the one-stop shop and facing the tyranny of choice that is the high street. In her recent book Carried Away: The Invention of Modern Shopping (Faber £12.99), the academic Rachel Bowlby explains how the civilised practice of 'strolling' and the detailed examination of shop windows common in days of yore has given way to 'high speed foot traffic'. We are carried along by crowds. We are hurrying to the office or the gym. We are thinking about anal sex or flexible mortgages or Coronation Street. We have learnt to 'read' windows as we pass.

My problem is I'm a slow reader. I'm a nineteenth-century shopper trapped in the future, constantly in danger of being mown down by other pedestrians as I dither outside Shellys wondering if I'm too old for leopardskin shoes.

Inside shops it's even worse, with assistants insisting on trying to assist, when it is immediately obvious that there's nothing I would remotely be seen dead in that I actually need or can raise the necessary finance for. Even if I spot something vaguely not too horrible it loses its charm the minute I see it in proximity to the rest of my clothes. No wonder men are flocking to mail order, which gives you the opportunity to buy something that doesn't suit you on the grounds that it at least suits the man in the picture.

Tim, whom I bump into on the school run, doesn't go 'shopping', he goes 'buying'. 'If I decide I need a pale-blue button-down shirt for work,' he says, 'I go in a shop and buy one. I refuse to be distracted by anything else.'

'But what if they don't have one?'

'Then I don't buy one.'

'What - not even, say, a darker blue?'

He shakes his head. 'Sorry. Thin end of the wedge.'

My wife's friend Lorna tells me about her ex-husband, who would never go shopping for clothes. 'He just used to wear his old ones until they were worn out,' she says. 'So I'd have to go out and buy replacements - it was either that or be married to a scarecrow. I did take him once into M&S to buy his father a sweater but he said he was having a panic attack and had to go and wait outside. Needless to say, he never bought me any presents. But the minute we were going through the divorce he turned up one day in a new jacket and trousers! I think he must have discovered retail therapy, but it took a life crisis to do it.'

You have to have some sympathy for the poor man. I get disoriented, too, wandering round department stores, which are like being stuck in a country where all the roadsigns are in a different alphabet and everybody knows the word for soft furnishings except you. The worst has to be Selfridges, where glossy young women come up and spray perfume at you every 10 minutes and expect you to be delighted, even though you only came in to use the toilets on bonfire night and have been trying to get out again ever since.

As for present-buying, I have discovered an excellent website called menhateshopping.com, which is devoted to listing places that sell gift vouchers online - surely the ideal convenience for people who don't want to buy anything and don't want to have to go in a shop to do it. Gift vouchers should come with a little greetings card saying: 'Have you any idea what a nuisance this is?'

You can't risk a gift voucher with someone you're supposed to like. Next week I will spend the whole day trawling round Covent Garden and Bond Street for my wife's Christmas present before buying something in desperation from the Sock Shop at Liverpool Street station on the way home. You can't win. Because even when you try, fate will always step in and make it look as though you've spent the afternoon in the pub.

The internet is full of subversive anti-shopping material. My favourite is Top 30 Hints for Men Who Hate Shopping. Examples include: 'Take shopping carts for the express purpose of filling them and stranding them at strategic locations around the store' and 'Drag an armchair on display over to the magazines and relax with a cooling drink from the food court'. Another site suggests the reason men hate Richard Gere is because he shows almost as much interest in shopping in his films as he does in appearing nude.

And it can't be good for us. In a survey of London shoppers in The Soul of the New Consumer (Nicholas Brealey, £18) psychologist David Lewis reports: 'In some cases, when we looked at heart rate and blood pressure, [we found readings] that you'd expect to see in a fighter pilot going into combat.' All the men in the survey showed signs of stress, compared to only one in four women.

So what's our problem? 'Impatience, intolerance of crowds, queuing,' says Lewis, when I ring him. 'And men don't like the pressure of time. That's why they hate going out shopping with women. Women are methodical, comparing prices and quality from store to store, trying to make an informed purchase. Men on their own go crashing in like SWAT teams, grab the first thing they see and run out again. They're all right shopping for computers and cars and gadgets but on the whole they'd rather be somewhere else.'

Like the dentist's perhaps...

Gift vouchers should come with a little greetings card saying: 'Have you any idea what a nuisance this is?' You can't risk a gift voucher with someone you're supposed to like. Next week I will spend the whole day trawling round Covent Garden and Bond Street for my wife's Christmas present before buying something in desperation from the Sock Shop at Liverpool Street station on the way home. You can't win. Because even when you try, fate will always step in and make it look as though you've spent the afternoon in the pub. The internet is full of subversive anti-shopping material. My favourite is Top 30 Hints for Men Who Hate Shopping. Examples include: 'Take shopping carts for the express purpose of filling them and stranding them at strategic locations around the store' and 'Drag an armchair on display over to the magazines and relax with a cooling drink from the food court'. Another site suggests the reason men hate Richard Gere is because he shows almost as much interest in shopping in his films as he does in appearing nude. And it can't be good for us. In a survey of London shoppers in The Soul of the New Consumer (Nicholas Brealey, £18) psychologist David Lewis reports: 'In some cases, when we looked at heart rate and blood pressure, [we found readings] that you'd expect to see in a fighter pilot going into combat.' All the men in the survey showed signs of stress, compared to only one in four women. So what's our problem? 'Impatience, intolerance of crowds, queuing,' says Lewis, when I ring him. 'And men don't like the pressure of time. That's why they hate going out shopping with women. Women are methodical, comparing prices and quality from store to store, trying to make an informed purchase. Men on their own go crashing in like SWAT teams, grab the first thing they see and run out again. They're all right shopping for computers and cars and gadgets but on the whole they'd rather be somewhere else.' Like the dentist's perhaps...

webTitle: The height of fashion

fields.headline: The height of fashion
fields.standfirst: Now that trainers have done a runner, women are looking for sexual heeling - and that means four inches minimum. After all, size really does matter...
fields.trailText: This season you will hunt in vain for a moderate heel. That flattering but practical two-inch bunk-up is nowhere to be found. Instead, everyone from Manolo Blahnik to Ravel via Pied a Terre is peddling at least four inches of extra lift. And it comes in the strangest shapes. There are chunky columns, spindly stilettos, odd angular wedges that announce their separateness from the rest of the shoe with a big, flappy join. You might find a kitten heel left over from last year, but chances are that it will have been elongated and then chipped and chiselled until it resembles nothing so much as a bit of contemporary sculpture. Wear your favourite flats by all means this Christmas, but realise that you'll be making a statement. To blend, you need to soar.
fields.body:
This season you will hunt in vain for a moderate heel. That flattering but practical two-inch bunk-up is nowhere to be found. Instead, everyone from Manolo Blahnik to Ravel via Pied a Terre is peddling at least four inches of extra lift. And it comes in the strangest shapes. There are chunky columns, spindly stilettos, odd angular wedges that announce their separateness from the rest of the shoe with a big, flappy join. You might find a kitten heel left over from last year, but chances are that it will have been elongated and then chipped and chiselled until it resembles nothing so much as a bit of contemporary sculpture. Wear your favourite flats by all means this Christmas, but realise that you'll be making a statement. To blend, you need to soar.

There are no easy answers as to why heels are suddenly sky high. In the past they have been used for both affected decoration (all those Restoration dandies) and sensible foot protection (raised clogs evolved from a desire to avoid street debris in pre-sanitation industrial towns).

The fashion historian Professor Elizabeth Wilson of the University of North London thinks it may be a way of marking out the present moment as different from what has gone before. 'For the past few years young women have been wearing trainers everywhere - to parties, to the office, as well as to the gym. High heels are an extreme reaction to that, a way of saying that the saturation of fashion by sports clothing is finally over.' In which case, Miu Miu's attempt last year to mix elements of both by producing trainers with huge heels starts to make a strange (if hideous) kind of sense.

Wilson points out, too, that the current focus on heels may be simply pragmatic, a response to the fact that there's not a lot of leeway when it comes to playing around with shoe design. 'Like all clothing, shoes have a basic and unchanging function, which is to keep you protected from the environment. But whereas a jacket can be all sorts of shapes and sizes and still do its job, a shoe is much more constrained. The heel is one part of the structure that you can alter without compromising the whole enterprise.'

There are economic forces at work, too. Fashion's obsession with novelty is a way of making sure we spend money on new clothing before the old stuff has worn out. And over the past few years accessories, and shoes in particular, have proved themselves particularly profitable. 'Shoes and bags are comparatively cheap to produce,' explains Alice Rawsthorn, the architecture and design critic. 'Some time ago clever design companies like Prada and Gucci realised that there was much more money to be made in shoes and accessories than in other kinds of high-fashion items. They threw their best design talent in that direction, and the result has been an outpouring of creativity.'

As a result shoes, or certain brands of shoes, have achieved a kind of iconic presence, even among those who don't usually consider themselves footwear-oriented. Go into Prada's flagship store in Bond Street on a rainy Monday and you will see gaggles of women, all ages and sizes, patting and murmuring over rocket-heels which start at £200.

I recently succumbed and bought a pair. They look like something a mill girl might have worn for a date with a visiting GI. The heel is clunky and, crucially, four inches high. There is a lot of top stitching, reprising the look of this season's crucial Prada bowling bag (matching your shoes and bag, if you can afford it, is no longer confined to Hyacinth Bouquet).

I know I should feel foxy, but on the couple of occasions I've worn my new shoes I feel like a little girl who has been rummaging in the dressing-up box (either that, or an unconvincing transvestite). Half a size too big (that's no one's fault but mine), I have to clench my toes and, every other part of me in order to stay upright. Far from sashaying around parties with a tall and eager stride, I shuffle like a Chinese adolescent who hasn't got used to her footbinding. Of course, if you're good at these things, like Naomi Campbell, you can fall off your platforms, laugh like a drain, and everyone thinks it's fresh and cute. I tried it and people thought I was drunk.

Clearly I'm unusual, though, since it is female desire for high heels which is making them walk out of the shops in such phenomenal numbers. Shoe designer Emma Hope believes that women buy them for the simple reason that they make them look fantastic. 'The most ordinary leg looks long and sexy when it's perched on top of an extra three inches. A good ankle becomes an elegant one, and thighs and hips look magically thinner.' Wendy Dagworthy, Professor of Fashion at the Royal College of Art, says that there's something about even a modest kitten heel that makes you suddenly aware of your posture and automatically stand up taller.

Of course, this all assumes that you know how to pick out the right pair of shoes in the first place. The key thing this winter is to team your heels with trousers rather than skirts, short or otherwise. Realising the potential for turning out like white trash, Red magazine helpfully devotes its lead fashion feature this month to achieving a shoe-trouser match which aims for YSL while avoiding Loughton.

But other kinds of pleasure are in play. High heels set in motion all kinds of desires, visual or otherwise, in both men and women. Beatrice Faust, an academic commentator on fashion, believes that wearing high heels 'makes the buttocks undulate about twice as much as walking in flat heels, with correspondingly greater sensation transmitted to the vulva,' which could explain why the woman standing next to you in her Manolo Blahniks looks quite so cheerful. Men also seem to pick up on the physical re-alignment that high heels involve. Pelvis and breasts are thrust forward, bottom tucked under and yet, as Faust observes, simultaneously jiggling about. It's about as graphic as you can get while still keeping your clothes on. And then there's Alison Lurie's theory. According to her classic The Language of Clothes, an extended leg is a sign of sexual availability in several animal groups: a pair of heels from Gucci, she believes, sends the same message among humans.

All this comes marinaded with a bit of light-hearted sado-masochism. Once she puts on her Pradas, an average-sized woman knows she will tower over at least half the men in the room. 'It doesn't make me feel remotely unfeminine to talk down to a man. I love the feeling,' says Alice Rawsthorn, (5ft 6in in her stockinged feet). Emma Hope (5ft 8in) concurs: 'I've never known any of my customers mind about being taller than their partners. The only exception is on their wedding day, when they worry it might look a bit odd. The big fear then is looking like Bernie Ecclestone and his wife.'

In case anyone should doubt that the way a woman feels about her heels is intimately entwined with her stance towards her partner, you have only to look at the cautionary tale of Diana, Princess of Wales. In the early years of her marriage, when she was desperate to make Charles love her, the 5ft 10in youngster wore shoes as flat as ballet pumps. By the early Nineties, when she had given up on him, she was towering over him in killer spikes.

The dominatrix effect of high heels doesn't stop there. The click-clack sound they make on hard flooring announces your arrival in a satisfyingly strict way, and you also find yourself becoming more assertive in your movements.

'Since heels are more difficult to walk in, it means that you don't waste a single bit of energy', says Hope. 'When I'm wearing them I'm able to stride boldly through rooms full of people, rather than scuttling round the outside, just because I don't want to put myself to any extra discomfort.'

There's also a hint of danger too. Stiletto, after all, means 'little dagger' and the combination of spiky heel and pointy toe means that a shoe can turn into a cruel and handy weapon in a moment. 'Last year Gucci did some black patent shoes with a steel heel which men seemed to find incredibly exciting,' remembers Rawsthorn, who also admits that the steel heels were incredibly uncomfortable to wear.

It plays, of course, on the whole S and M fantasy. The woman, who is usually smaller, weaker and more vulnerable, has temporarily become the strong, dangerous predator.

'Temporarily', though, is the key word here. As in all sado-masochistic fantasies, the power imbalance must be safely negotiable and reversible for the fantasy to work. The situation is sexy because at any moment the woman can take off her shoes (or, more crucially, be told to take them off) and go back to being a stumpy and unthreatening 5ft 4in.

Which begs the question whether high heels are the sort of thing that any good feminist should be seen dead in. They throw up all the tensions which surrounded the Wonderbra several years back. Do women pad out their breasts for their own pleasure or for men's? Eva Herzogovina seemed pretty thrilled with hers in the original Wonderbra advert, but you can't spend your whole time peering down your own cleavage. Likewise, although you may feel like a big, sexy girl in your high heels, it's impossible to see the things unless you're sitting down. Is it the male gaze rather than yours which is being catered to?

Alice Rawsthorn has thought long and hard about the issue. 'As a young, educated, independent woman in the mid-Eighties, I absolutely refused to wear high heels. I felt that to do so would have been to send out the wrong message about how I wanted to be seen. It would have been like betraying my gender.'

But something has happened since then, and by the early Nineties Rawsthorn had become a dedicated wearer of high heels, with a particular passion for Manolo Blahnik, which have now become something of a signature for her. 'As women achieved more real economic and social power in the late Eighties, those old Stalinist dictates about what a good feminist should and shouldn't wear fell away,' explains Rawsthorn. 'Independent, educated, professional women are now sufficiently secure not to have to worry about whether a pair of high heels sends out the wrong message.'

Post-feminist or not, Rawsthorn still refuses to do cleavage, even during a season when every V-neck sweater is slashed to the navel. 'That, to me, still seems to generate the wrong signals about femininity. But I have a friend who feels the complete opposite. She doesn't mind showing cleavage, but she absolutely refuses to do high heels. The key word here is choice.'

And choice, indeed, also explains why the old feminist argument about high heels ruining women's feet and spines while laying them open to attack (no chance to run from a mugger) no longer holds water. 'The difference with high heels this time around is that women aren't wearing them all day, every day, like they did in the Forties and Fifties,' says Professor Elizabeth Wilson. 'As a result they're not developing the hammer toes and bunions which bedevilled an earlier generation.'

Wendy Dagworthy recalls with a shudder the 'perpetual pain' she experienced in the Seventies and Eighties from constantly wearing high heels, and swears that she will never put herself through it again, no matter how fashionable they might be. Among her young and trend-conscious students, however, she notes that high heels are worn only sporadically, and juggled with trainers.

Rawsthorn concurs: 'I wear Manolos out to dinner and Nikes during the day. And as for the safety issues, I always drive or walk to my destination in flat shoes and then change when I get there. There's no way that wearing heels means that I've compromised my health, safety or anything else.'

webTitle: Money writes: Mix-up on tax made me a mad axeman

fields.headline: Mix-up on tax made me a mad axeman
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
I hiked across the United States last summer, from the Mexican border to Canada. After crossing the snowfields of the High Sierra, I posted my ice axe back to the UK, as I did not wish to carry it for a further 1,500 miles.

In October, after I had returned home, Parcel Force delivered it to my door, with customs duty of £22 to pay, though I had bought the axe a year before in Birmingham, England (not Alabama). I refused to pay on the grounds that I had already paid UK VAT, and the deliveryman took it back, giving me the telephone number of Customs & Excise in Coventry to contact. Since then I have phoned the number up to six times each day, but I always get the engaged tone. Short of suggesting that I ride naked through the streets of Coventry - an approach I believe that has worked before in matters of unjust taxation - can you suggest a way of escaping this impasse?
CD, Telford

All overseas mail arriving in this country is funnelled through a depot at Coventry airport, where it is cleared by Customs & Excise. Customs staff watch the parcels on the conveyor belt, looking for items on which duty should be paid, as well as for drugs, guns and pornography. They select for investigation any parcel that looks suspicious, and your ice axe obviously attracted attention. Parcel Force is then told to demand the duty. In theory you can sort out the problem by phone, but they admit the line is constantly busy. Customs & Excise is now looking for your parcel and has promised to return your ice axe with nothing to pay.

If it sounds too good to be true...

I have been contacted by a Millennium Finance representative in Zurich offering me the opportunity to purchase a block of shares in a well-known supplier of computer ancillary equipment with a prediction that these shares are going to provide an excellent return over the next six to eight months. The amount involved is several thousand pounds but I do not want to take any risks with my resources.
JR, Thurso

Millenium Finance is based in Uruguay and has offices in Brazil, Mexico, Singapore and Switzerland. It is not bound by British law and, if anything went wrong, you are not covered by UK investor-protection schemes. If you want to take no risks with your investments, do not buy shares. Above all, do not buy shares through a company you have heard of only because it sent you a mailshot, that is based outside UK jurisdiction and that suggests you will make money in a short time.

No excuse for lack of interest

After my wife died last March I approached NatWest Bank to look after her estate of £200,000 until, as executor, I was ready to distribute it according to her wishes. Some two months later, I checked how much interest it was earning and found, to my astonishment, it was earning none.
PW, Macclesfield

NatWest has no excuse for advising you to put £200,000 into this administration account. It says you wanted an account with a chequebook but admits that was no reason to put so much money into a non-interest bearing cheque account.

Its instant access account without cheque book pays 3.45 per cent; a one-month notice account 4.95 per cent. NatWest has now calculated the interest the money would have earned in the one-month account for the 47 days until you switched. This is £1,275, which the bank is crediting to your account.

When you wish upon a car

I had to pay an extra £30 plus Vat for my Budget hire-car at Glasgow airport, as my Easyjet flight from Luton was delayed and I picked up the car after 11pm.
IM, London

Easyjet says it refunds the cost of a seat only if a flight is delayed by more than four hours but, even if you had been on time, you had only 35 minutes to reach the car rental office. Budget now says the office normally shuts at 10.30 pm, although staff wait for the last flight. You could not see Budget's terms of contract until you picked up the car, and staff say they did not warn you that time was short because your flight was due in before closing time. You should have been given more information beforehand and it is a warning to readers to ask about any possible extra charges.

Bond salesman disappoints

While in Greece this year, I found a house on Aegina that I wanted to buy, paid a deposit and signed a binding agreement. Returning home in October, I tried to surrender my Equitable Life with-profits bond but was told the society would impose a hefty penalty clause, reducing the fund's value from £69,743 to £66,194. When I had investigated the previous year, no penalty was mentioned and, if I had surrendered then, no penalty would have been imposed.

If Equitable had warned me that the penalty clause was being invoked, I could have opted to pay for the house in instalments.
AJ, Pickering

You checked your policy's value with the Equitable salesman on 24 July but it was not until three days later that the society decided to activate a little-used clause, the market value adjuster (MVA), on policies re-deemed outside certain anniversary dates. Knowing your intentions, he should have contacted you again to warn you. Most policies include an MVA option which entitles insurers to cut bonuses, annual or final, if they believe on-going policyholders would suffer from too many others cashing in.

Because of its current troubles, Equitable Life is using the MVA to cut final bonuses by 20 per cent which, it says, reduces your whole fund by about 4 per cent (although you are losing over 5 per cent because Equitable also suspended bonus payments for seven months this year). You should complain to Equitable Life that the salesman let you down.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.
