webTitle: The all-seeing eye that  understands nothing

fields.headline: The all-seeing eye that  understands nothing
fields.standfirst: From Diana to Damilola, CCTV has thoroughly invaded our lives. But its cold, merciless gaze offers no fitting memorial to wasted lives, writes Peter Conrad
fields.trailText: From Diana to Damilola, CCTV has thoroughly invaded our lives. But its cold, merciless gaze offers no fitting memorial to wasted lives, writes Peter Conrad
fields.body:
Last week the newspapers summed up an abbreviated life in four frozen frames. A child, captured by a series of closed-circuit security cameras, skips across a paved square then slows down as he enters a building. Next he is seen inside a lift, solemn and composed. An hour later the same child bled to death in a grimy stairwell, this time out of sight of the cameras.

Those CCTV images have become Damilola Taylor's perfunctory memorial. Sad hindsight now finds puzzles and mysteries in them. In his silver jacket, which playfully copies an astronaut's uniform, he seems to be moonwalking through bleak Peckham. He leaps between decorative oblong blocks, bent sideways to maintain his balance. Children never just walk or plod or slouch or trudge like the rest of us. They have too much energy to get rid of, and because their vitality is infinite they feel no need to conserve it.

Two minutes later, caught by the next camera, Damilola has set himself a geometrical test: he sprints in a straight line, keeping to a track marked on the pavement. Here again is the essence of childhood, which makes private maps and fills empty space with obstacles to be overcome. What invisible gauntlet did he think he was running?

The last image, taken by the camera in the library lift, is the most unsettling. The space entombs him: the man with whom he shares this box holds a bundle of flowers. But Damilola is smiling. The exhilaration of his race through the streets has not yet drained from his body. And besides that, he has so much future to look forward to.

From these four images, the papers constructed a short story, which ends in a trail of ellipses leading to that nearby stairwell: the Daily Mail called it 'Dammy's Final Hour', which The Mirror varied to 'Dami's Last Steps'.

The omnipresence of security cameras like those in Peckham means a visual obituary can be pieced together for any of us. But whereas spoken tributes try to honour lives which have ended, the camera has a drier, colder eye and reveals the awkward, ignorant haste with which people rush towards death or disaster. Princess Diana, hustled through a revolving door at the Paris Ritz, thought she was speeding home to bed. Jill Dando, efficiently running errands in a Hammersmith shopping mall, had office supplies to buy. James Bulger, happily teamed up with two new friends, straggled off to play down by the railway line. Leanne Tiernan, shopping in Leeds two weeks ago, had Christmas presents to find: the CCTV cameras followed her some of the way but can't report on her present whereabouts.

All these people were smiling, like Damilola, in the confident contemplation of un-numbered tomorrows. CCTV tells a harsher truth than most elegies. Lives don't end at some appointed moment; they just stop, abruptly and unexpectedly, as if a camera had suddenly run out of tape.

The footage replays itself in a perpetual present, which is the blithe tense in which we all live. But if you look more closely the tempo has something eerie and unsettling about it. The cameras don't record motion; each time they blink they freeze an instant, and there's a gap before the next exposure, so that bodies look jittery, artificially animated from outside - not so much alive as undead. Their testimony is all the crueller because, after a death, images are no consolation. You can rerun the tapes but you can't reverse time and bring back the person you have lost.

The images of Damilola are also a reminder of our accountability to technology, and of our blind trust in it. We are living inside a panopticon, inhabiting a prison of transparent walls, with guards ceaselessly invigilating the internees. Everything must be made visible. There are 150,000 CCTV cameras in London, a million elsewhere in the country, and their professional snooping is augmented by the efforts of amateurs. Camcorders in the delivery room make home movies of our bleeding, screeching entry into the world, and preserve on tape a trauma we have mercifully forgotten. When a disaster occurs there's always a witness with a camera to hand: remember the footage, taken from a passing lorry, of Concorde blazing as it crashed outside Paris last summer.

We have become used to being perpetually on set, our every movement in a public place overseen from some secret control room. Is this the fulfilment of Andy Warhol's prophecy, which promised a few minutes of stardom for all?

Not everyone is happy with this visual conscription. A while ago a man called Geoff Peck slashed his wrists in the street. He didn't intend his death to be a spectacle for passers-by; he was homeless and therefore had no private space to retire to, no door to close behind him. CCTV operators saw his suicide attempt, and sent the paramedics to save him. When Peck recovered he learned to his dismay that his anguish had been used to entertain the nation: the local authority which maintained the cameras had sold the tape, without consulting him, to the BBC and ITV.

He was right to feel betrayed, abused, belittled. Though the omniscient cameras have become our memorialists, they lack the emotional qualifications for the job. Their view is negligently blurred since they can't discriminate between the indifferent blobs they photograph - until Damilola is outlined by a red circle, as if detained in a rifle sight. And their silence has an anaesthesia of its own, muffling any response.

Charlie Chaplin once said that tragedy was life seen in close-up, whereas comedy represented the world in long shot. CCTV cameras need to keep watch on entire precincts so they prefer long shots, which make room for crowds; the singularity of the close-up is no part of their duty. Inside the lift, Damilola gets closer to the camera but he remains a background figure. The foreground is monopolised by the man with the bouquet, who must have a rendezvous ahead of him.

Casually unfocused, blandly unable to tell the difference between a man on his way to meet his girlfriend and a boy on his way to be killed, this image is already a species of Pop Art, like those bright, glossy Warhol paintings of car crashes and executions in the electric chair which acknowledge misery and pain. To the distress of his family, James Bulger became one of Pop's short-lived celebrities after his death when the artist Jamie Wagg took newspaper reproductions of the CCTV tapes and made laminated prints from them, which he called 'cartoons for tapestry'. The pictures didn't bother to commemorate the child: Wagg simply entitled them 'Shopping Mall' and 'Railway Line'. In this he was true to the CCTV aesthetic since the cameras are concerned with places, not with the people in messy, fugitive transit through them. Their purpose is to protect property, not human life, and they are only interested in us if we happen to be vandals or shoplifters or derelicts whose blood, like Geoff Peck's, seems likely to be an insanitary nuisance.

If you've ever glimpsed yourself on a monitor inside a shop door, you'll know how reductively ruthless CCTV is. Here you are in all your scruffy, grungy insignificance. The camera is egalitarian, as the Marquess of Blandford discovered in August when a security guard watching CCTV at Harvey Nichols in Knightsbridge saw him pocket two pairs of sunglasses. The Marquess was found not guilty in court, but video evidence like this turns us inside out and exposes the pitiful banality of our misdeeds; the Marquess's alleged haul included a stick of deodorant.

Jill Dando's shopping list on the last morning of her life was equally humdrum. CCTV showed her buying fax paper at Rymans and searching in Dixons for a blue ink cartridge, which she couldn't find. The tapes draw baleful attention to the short-term thinking we rely on to get through our lives. How important was the elusive cartridge, when seen by the eye of eternity?

I remember once, as a child in Australia, thinking I might have been singled our for attention by that punitive eternal eye. I had misbehaved all afternoon. Now the sun was setting, and it looked like a bloodshot eye, burning a hole in the membrane of the sky. 'He's looking at you,' said my mother, meaning God. I thought about her threat, and after a while, when the glaring sun had disappeared, decided not to be afraid. How could the all-seeing supervisor be everywhere and see everything?

Now I know better. God's ocular chores have been taken over by machines, which between them have a million eyes. Sleeplessly staring at us, they know what happens while we are asleep. In 1999 a railway engineer was convicted of indecently assaulting a woman on the station platform at Harrow and Wealdstone. It was CCTV that accused him; the woman, who had been at a St Patrick's Day revel, had no memory of the assault. 'I became hysterical,' she told the judge, 'when I saw the video.'

Tapes, unlike human beings, have total recall. Student protesters in Chicago in 1968, defending themselves against Mayor Daley's thuggish police, chanted an appeal to the television cameras: 'The whole world is watching!' That faith in an impartial, objective jury of viewers seems sadly dated. Today the whole world is being watched - and by whom? Probably, if we recall the closed house where Big Brother took place, by Davina McCall. The God who judged our actions has been replaced, thanks to CCTV, by a sniggering, prurient goddess, delighted to catch us picking our noses, scratching our bums and stabbing our best friends in the back.

The Royle Family caters to this paranoia: it suggests that, while the Royles think they are watching television, television actually watches them, thanks to a camera secreted in the cathode tube. An eye as disenchanted as that of CCTV shows them up in all their dreary squalor. In our cities the avoidance of eye contact is a crucial, cautious protocol. As Robert de Niro demonstrates in Taxi Driver - when talking to his reflection in the mirror - to catch someone else's eye is to ask for trouble. But though we don't look at each other any more, we are collectively under observation. CCTV represents all that's left of the communal sense.

Cameras like these are supercilious. Because they look down on the world and its foreshortened populace, they confer power on whoever does the looking. What if they decide that they know how to foresee the future? At Bristol University computers are analysing video clips of criminals in order to develop software which will prompt CCTV cameras to predict assaults before they occur. Behaviour deemed to be suspicious is being minutely anatomised; the language of bodies about to pounce or start a fight is being systematically studied. The scientists writing software for Home Office computers assume that people are automata, pre-programmed and incorrigible. Therefore why not arrest malefactors before they do anything wrong?

If the cameras are permitted to make such judgments they may, as the civil rights campaigner Simon Davies has warned, 'start penalising extreme or unusual behaviour, which leads to social exclusion'.

The state usually justifies its incursions on our freedom and privacy by claiming we're being deprived of liberty for our own good. CCTV surveillance is meant to guarantee security. But will a society policed by cameras be utopian or totalitarian? The film director Wim Wenders speculates about compulsory visibility in The End of Violence, where Gabriel Byrne, as a scientist who once worked for Nasa, studies Los Angeles on a battery of video screens inside the Griffith Park Observatory. Satellites, like angels in orbit, can zoom in on traffic violators, muggers and jay-walkers; there will surely be no more violence in a city where everyone is on tape. At least that's what Byrne believes, until he realises - just before his employer has him killed - that the observer is being observed.

In Philip Noyce's film Sliver, William Baldwin plays the owner of a New York skyscraper who oversees the lives of his tenants from his CCTV headquarters. His motives, he imagines, are benign; when the tape shows a man molesting his step-daughter, he issues a divinely disembodied warning over the telephone. 'We should wire the whole town,' he tells Sharon Stone. But his own merely human eyes are fickle, inattentive. He records a murder, but never gets round to viewing the tape which identifies the culprit. He prefers to replay footage of himself making sweaty love to Stone. Breaking into his electronic den, she demands that he hand over over her cassette. 'I want my privacy,' she says. 'I want my own experiences.' She regains this autonomy, with the aid of a gun, and shoots holes in Baldwin's bank of monitors.

It's the kind of falsely conclusive victory which is only possible in a film. Cameras ensure that nothing is private, and nothing therefore is sacred. Last week David Attenborough added to television's armoury of intruders by introducing a cheeky gadget which he called Bouldercam - a camera camouflaged as a boulder, which needs no intrepid human operator. Left in place in the savannah, Bouldercam spied on two mating lions. The male lowered himself into place and did some thrusting while he bit the scruff of his partner's neck to hold her down; flies settled on the recumbent, snarling female, which might have bothered her if the whole brusque transaction had lasted more than a few seconds. As seen by this candid camera, the king of beasts was just one more shaggy, unkempt member of the Royle Family.

If a God existed, he'd need an eye as multifaceted as a fly's in order to keep track of all those monitors which exhibit the destructive antics of his creation. And that is what those desolate images from Peckham suggest - the world as it might be viewed by a fly on the wall, which discerns no special providence in the fall of a sparrow or the death of a 10-year-old boy, seeing everything but understanding nothing.

webTitle: Property: I'll buy in Scotland afore ye

fields.headline: I'll buy in Scotland afore ye
fields.standfirst: The system north of the border may be quick, but it can work out very costly, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: The system north of the border may be quick, but it can work out very costly, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Have the Scots got it right on house selling?

English and Welsh property professionals are arguing over the Government's plan for seller's packs - the survey and search information given to potential purchasers to speed things up and restrict gazumping.

The Scottish system is fast, but some buyers face very high costs for 'multiple surveys'. This is how it works:

 First, find a property. Only a minority of Scottish homes are found through estate agents. Most home-buyers use the co-operatively run solicitors' property centres. These handle properties being sold by rival law firms but displayed together to prevent buyers having to register at several separate practices. If you want to view or buy a house there, you deal exclusively with the solicitor engaged by the sellers and you miss out on estate agents completely.

 Get a survey. Traditionally, this is done before you make an offer. This is the opposite to the system in England and Wales, and is the cause of much unnecessary expense for Scots, say critics. It can lead to a string of buyers paying for surveys on the same property only to find it has a major fault, which means they make no offer.

 Making an offer is much more formal than in England and Wales. It is a legal document in which buyers say how much they will pay for the house and when they want to move in. If there is more than one interested buyer - and in Scotland early this year there were four buyers to every seller - there is a closing date for offers.

 Now comes the critical anti-gazumping element: rival offers are made 'blind', so once accepted they should not be 'renegotiated' by a greedy seller. In practice, however, vendors occasionally try to find a different solicitor to represent them if they get a later, higher offer they wish to accept.

Once an offer is accepted in writing, it is binding. If either party pulls out the other can sue for damages.

The biggest winners in all this are the surveyors, who may be commissioned to check the same property many times.

Buyers benefit because gazumping is minimised, but they may have spent so much on surveys that they still feel hard done by.

Sellers get the best deal, because they move house quickly, and the blind offer process can bring unusually high prices in a hot market.

There is debate in Scotland about introducing a single survey funded by the seller, but some lenders and buyers have said this would be unacceptable.

'When you're buying a second-hand car you don't look at a survey done by the seller's garage and say that's good enough - so why should you do the equivalent on a house?' says Gillian Meighan of the Law Society in Scotland.

Instead the cost problem could be overcome by a buyer using solicitors' contacts to obtain a copy of a recent survey undertaken for an earlier buyer, at a cut price fee, she says. 'Obviously sur veys need to be renewed if a property is on sale for a long time, which is another weakness of getting the seller to do one. This problem is concentrated where the market is busiest - in Edinburgh, Glasgow and parts of Aberdeen.'

Surveyors, of course, defend the current system. The Royal Institute of Chartered Surveyors in Scotland keeps no record of the numbers of surveys, but says anecdotal evidence suggests most buyers pay for only one or two before moving.

'If a buyer has been unlucky and has had to pay for three or four surveys, they can ask the surveyor if there's something that can be done about the price on future ones,' suggested a spokeswoman.

Other countries - such as Canada and parts of Australia and New Zealand - have based their selling and buying systems on the Scottish model, but often with amendments to avoid unnecessary expense.

In Canada for example, offers are still legally binding but are usually made subject to a satisfactory survey - ensuring that only the buyer whose offer is accepted has to pay. The process is still much quicker than in England and Wales because strict time limits are imposed. A seller is legally obliged to consider an offer, sometimes within hours,' says Canadian Andrea Matyszczyk, who now works in London.

When she sold her house in Toronto last June, 'there was an offer at 7pm one evening, and by just after 11pm we had accepted it, subject to the survey.'

An acceptance document set a deadline for the survey, which reached the buyer in only two days.

webTitle: Broke in Britain: it's still just a shame

fields.headline: Broke in Britain: it's still just a shame
fields.standfirst: For those who know it first-hand, being bankrupt is largely a harsh experience, writes  Barbara Oaff
fields.trailText: For those who know it first-hand, being bankrupt is largely a harsh experience, writes Barbara Oaff.
fields.body:
Has the rise and spectacular fall of dotcom entrepreneurs changed Britain's attitude to bankrupts? Do we see them as spirited visionaries who are prepared to take risks? Or as a bunch of dodgy dealers who get what they deserve? The answer depends on who you ask.

The Government, some entrepreneurs, and a few banks claim a shift in attitude is taking place. But what about those who have experienced bankruptcy?

'I don't think anything is different. It is still a taboo. It is still a stigma. It is still something to feel ashamed of and embarrassed by,' says James (not his real name).

James ran a fashion business for five years. But it folded after he made 'a couple of mistakes' in a fickle, unforgiving trade. He managed to pay off the smaller traders, but was left with a £3,000 VAT bill. He was made bankrupt for the standard three-year period. (You can be made bankrupt for owing as little as £750.)

While serving his time James was an 'undischarged' bankrupt and as such faced several restrictions. He could not have a chequebook or a debit card. He could not, in fact, have any sort of credit whether with a tradesman, a utility service or a department store. 'I was reduced to a passport account. I felt like a 15-year-old again. It is was so humiliating and [it] made doing everyday normal things virtually impossible.'

He could not work as a director, a manager or a company owner. He could not keep any wages. Living expenses were allowed but the rest went to the official receiver to pay off creditors - in this case the Inland Revenue. 'I was having to do some crappy job when I could have been out there again, doing something great. We were having to living hand to mouth.We still are.'

A family man, James finished his bankruptcy period last year, was duly 'discharged' and is now employed at a wholesale firm. Looking back, he says: 'It felt like I was serving a civil imprisonment. You are not trapped behind physical bars, but you are trapped behind intangible bars.'

And the emotional effects can be devastating. John Yates, who ran a successful mail-order business in Birmingham which suddenly collapsed during a prolonged local postal strike in June 1998, says: 'I have never felt so hobbled and helpless.' At the time, Yates felt 'emasculated to the point of total ineffectiveness - of just being allowed to exist under the auspices of a trustee. I had no rights of redress. It's akin to modern-day slavery - can't own anything, can't run anything, can't do anything but breathe and obey.'

Friends and family stood by Yates. But as for the rest of society - 'I no longer felt welcomed.' But this was far from the experience of Andrew (not his real name). During the 1980s property boom, Andrew borrowed heavily: more than a million pounds. The venture failed and eventually Andrew found himself in a low-paying job owing £27,000. Becoming a bankrupt was a relief. He says: 'It was a big load off my shoulders'. He also notes that bankruptcy is 'almost a source of pride in the States. I don't think we're there yet, but I do think we're moving in the right direction'.

The Government is trying to align Britain's bankruptcy laws to America's. A consultative document called Bankruptcy: A Fresh Start proposed several changes. The main one is to distinguish between the honest bankrupt, eligible for discharge after just six months, and fraudulent bankrupts, eligible for discharge after 15 years - five times the current maximum.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, acknowledges that 'UK cultural attitudes are among the least supportive of entrepreneurs and respect for them is lower here than in any other comparable economy, except Japan. The Government must take a lead in helping to tackle the low level of motivation to start and grow new businesses.'

Some banks claim to have recognised the need to be more supportive towards bankrupts (see below). Bristol & West has recently introduced the 're-start mortgage package' offering discharged bankrupts a standard variable rate with a loading of just 1 or 2 per cent scaled over several years. It also offers a counselling service. Denzil Morgan, director of special lending at Bristol & West, says this aims to 'break down the barriers people come up against when they try to talk about their financial difficulties'.

But one industry insider, who didn't want to be named, has a cynical view of these developments. 'What this is about is that some banks have identified a big market out there,' he says.

He also pointed out that to date most high street lenders 'still refuse to deal with bankrupts. They are interested only in selling products and as they can't easily do that to bankrupts they don't want to know them.'

Yet some entrepreneurs say things are getting better. Kim Polese encapsulates the sentiment. Chairman of an American internet infra structure company, Marimba, she observed just six months ago that 'in Silicon Valley failure is a badge of courage [whereas] in the UK it is a disgrace.' But now Polese believes the 'industry landscape [over here] has changed somewhat'.

If there has been a change it is not a positive one, according to bankruptcy advisers. Sophie Brooks, a development officer at the National Debtline, says: 'What we are seeing is the emergence of two classes of bankrupts. There is the big, brash internet star who goes bust, and that's cool. And there's the average person in the street who can't cope with consumer debt and that certainly is not cool.'

John McQueen, founder of the Bankruptcy Association, agrees. 'Society is becoming more willing to accept the "failures" of high-flying dotcom entrepreneurs. But it remains unwilling to accept the "failures" of ordinary men and women. Most of the bankrupts I speak to are still very unhappy people.'

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Extra Income & Growth Plan 5
fields.trailText: Extra Income & Growth Plan 5.
fields.body:
Contact 0800 169 2670 or www.extraiandg.com

Aim 10.05 per cent gross income a year for three years, 2.37 per cent each quarter or 30.3 per cent capital growth, return of capital linked to the Dow Jones Eurostoxx 50 index.

Offer closes 31 January, 2001.

Bells & whistles By investing £14,000 in the 2000/01 and 2001/02 Isas and £25,000 directly selecting the growth option, and by using CGT allowances and taper relief, an investor could receive tax-free gains of up to £11,817.

How it works The plan is run by NDF and Abbey National. Investors' money buys shares in a Dublin-listed company, which passes the money on to Abbey National to invest in equity-linked deposits. If the Dow Jones Eurostoxx 50 index falls by no more than 15 per cent from its starting point on 21 February 2001 to 7 April 2004, investors get all their capital back. But if it falls by more than 15 per cent, the 'safety net' is removed and the capital returned relates directly to the final level of the Eurostoxx 50. Abbey says back-testing over every period since the Eurostoxx 50 was launched (Dec 1991) shows investors would have had their capital returned in full.

Minimum £10,000

Charges Built in to product.

Tax Tax-free if through an Isa, Pep transfer or using CGT allowance for 2003/04. Income from direct investment will be subject to 10 per cent tax for basic-rate taxpayers;32.5 per cent for higher-rate taxpayers.

Risk Medium.

Should you buy it? Bruce Jamieson of Bognor Regis adviser Jamieson Financial Management says: 'You can have any number of statistics showing you will get all your money back, but it doesn't mean it will happen. It's an expensive way to get a return.' Anna Bowes of Bath firm Chase de Vere says: 'The small print stipulates that once the 'safety net' has gone, the plan reserves the right to take the index's lowest point in the past 28 days, so investors could still lose capital.'

Points out of 10 Jamieson - 3, Bowes - 6.

webTitle: Maria Scott: The death of Life

fields.headline: The death of Life leaves villains galore
fields.standfirst: The debate about who is to blame for the demise of Equitable Life - forced to close to new business last Friday - will rage for months or years.
fields.trailText: The debate about who is to blame for the demise of Equitable Life - forced to close to new business last Friday - will rage for months or years.
fields.body:
The debate about who is to blame for the demise of Equitable Life - forced to close to new business last Friday - will rage for months or years.

Fingers are being pointed firmly at the management, who seem to have failed to grasp the seriousness of the situation. Next in line come the regulators, who appear to have been too easily soothed by Equitable's reassurances.

Many in the investment industry were shocked that Equitable was allowed to shut up shop without a rescue being forced under the guidance of regulators and politicians. But perhaps it should not be such a surprise. Faced with the onerous responsibility of protecting small investors' money, regulators and politicians - even Labour ones - have tended in recent years to talk about the need for consumers to take responsibility for their own decisions.

In allowing Equitable to close, they may be sending a message to investors about risk and the extent to which customers will be shielded from management blun ders. If so, it is a sobering message as the Government prepares to pump up its campaign to encourage private pension provision through the introduction of its stakeholder plan.

Wealthy investors can spread their risks, but this is much harder for those with £50 a month to put in a pension. If it was as easy for us all, regulators might get away with a light touch in holding managers to account. Offloading risk on to small investors is not acceptable.

The FSA must review its handling of the Equitable fiasco to see whether it should have been tougher on the management, less willing to believe its view and more pessimistic about the potential outcome of the company's problems.

Equitable's demise raises afresh questions about the nature of with-profits investments. Around £550 billion is invested in such funds, which are at the root of the latest disaster.

They are intended as a medium-risk way into the stock market but rely on management discretion when it comes to sharing the returns.

These investments are looking much riskier than they did. The FSA should push ahead with the review it had already begun into the nature of this investment and the way it is marketed.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Technology, or the old cakes and ale

fields.headline: Technology, or the old cakes and ale
fields.trailText: The index says it all. The ejection of Bookham Technology, Baltimore Technologies and Sema Group from the FTSE 100 means that all but one of the 'pure' technology stocks that stormed into the index over the past year stormed out again just as fast.
fields.body:
The index says it all. The ejection of Bookham Technology, Baltimore Technologies and Sema Group from the FTSE 100 means that all but one of the 'pure' technology stocks that stormed into the index over the past year stormed out again just as fast. Old-economy rejects such as Safeway, and Associated British Foods, pushed out to make way for the upstarts, are being welcomed back in.

On the face of it, that is a victory for active fund managers over indexed funds.

Indexed funds, so the argument goes, have had to jump in and out of technology so fast it will have made investors dizzy. Indeed, they were accused of fuelling the technology mania by scrambling to buy the small number of technology stocks on offer. But active investors did not have to follow the herd. They could sit back and watch the indexed funds pay over the odds for technology shares while they waited for their old-economy favourites to recover.

That argument has two major flaws. First, and most serious, is that few investors were able to resist the temptation to buy technology stocks. A year ago, professional and private investors alike were dumping brewers and builders so that they could buy into the latest hot name. Many who bought in at the peak will still be in there, praying that their investments will eventually be worth what they paid.

If they do eventually decide to cut their losses, they will find they have missed much of the old-economy recovery.

Indexed funds may have had to cut or add to their technology holdings as the market varied, but they stayed invested in the brewers, food manufacturers and others which are now taking off - these were still part of the index. That helped iron out the more dramatic fluctuations caused by techno-mania and techno-phobia. And, portflio churning or not, they are cheap: the average charge is as low as a third that of an active manager.

True, the FTSE All-Share, tracked by the majority of indexed funds, is 9.5 per cent down on a year ago; the FTSE 100 is down 11 per cent. But that is small beer compared with the Techmark index of technology shares, which has plunged 50 per cent from its March high. The technology boom- and-bust is not a demonstration of the perils of indexation; it is an object lesson in managing risk. The pursuit of growth seen at the start of the year was as reckless as ignoring the value which has long been evident in traditional companies was short-sighted.

The recovery in value stocks undoubtedly has fur ther to run, but that does not mean all cheap shares will prove good value.Likewise, while technology will once again have its day, not all stocks will recover. Those who are not confident of their ability to choose the right one in either camp could be as well in an indexed fund as an actively managed one.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Staying out of the rough

fields.headline: Staying out of the rough
fields.standfirst: A golf writer tells  Margaret Dibben why his problem's a nice one to have
fields.trailText: A golf writer tells Margaret Dibben why his problem's a nice one to have.
fields.body:
Tony and Michelle Dear

Age 29 and 28

Live in St Ives, Cambridgeshire

Occupation journalist and nurse

Earn £20,000 and £15,800

Mortgage none

Debts none

Investments £180,000 due on his 30th birthday

Pensions company pension and NHS scheme

Aims to review finances in light of his inheritance

Tony Dear is a golf journalist and his wife, Michelle, is a nurse. They met four years ago while they were both travelling. Neither has a clue about money. He says: 'We are never really certain about where our money is, where it is going or how much we have.'

Tony admits: 'My wife is infinitely more sensible than I am. I have always been gung ho about buying a villa in Spain, and my wife is very cautious. She knows what I am like with finances and how ignorant I am. Any hair-brained scheme I come up with, she pooh-poohs.'

It was Michelle who got them back into the black when they returned seriously in debt from travelling.

But their situation may be less disastrous than for most people with a careless attitude to money because next May, on his 30th birthday, Tony will inherit £180,000.

He already has £55,000 of his inheritance in a high-interest deposit account: 'This sum represents roughly a third of the inheritance my brother and I received after our parents' death in the early Nineties.' The proceeds of his mother's house, £30,000, are locked away at his solicitor's because his mother's will said he could not receive it until he turned 30. He does not know what the solicitor has done with the money or whether it earns interest. He assumes not.

A further £75,000 was invested five years ago which should, by next May, be worth £95,000 to £100,000; all told, when his birthday rolls around next year, Tony should have around £180,000. He realises that it is 'a bit rich' to suggest they have money problems: 'That is a lot of money, but it is not enough to allow my wife and me to pack it all in and move to Hawaii (something neither of us actually wants to do) but I am concerned that we are doing nothing at the moment to maximise our money's potential.'

Tony earns £17,000 a year, with another £3,000 to £4,000 from freelance work. Michelle earns roughly £15,800 a year. He pays £20 a month into his company pension and £20 a month into the firm's SAYE share scheme. Michelle pays £75 a month in the NHS pension scheme.

They pay rent of £450 a month and have no serious plans to buy a house at the moment, although Tony's inheritance could crystallise their thinking. Their joint bank account has £2,000 to £3,000 in it most of the time. Says Tony: 'This is a nice problem to have, but we feel totally out of our depth and in desperate need of good advice if we are to get the most out of what we have.'

Adviser 1: Danielle Leich

Tony and Michelle should use at least some of the capital to buy a home so as to save on rent. They could buy the property outright or take a mortgage and invest the remaining capital, hoping that the return is higher than the mortgage payments.

This is risky, however, and they should fund a property at least in part by their capital. If they do take a mortgage, they should look for flexibility.

When the full money is received, they should keep around £15,000 in bank or building society accounts - I urge them to look for better rates than they are getting. They should invest the balance in equity-related investments.

If Tony wants to be cautious, he should consider with-profits bonds, which give exposure to the stock market without fluctuations. The returns should be better than the average interest-bearing account.

To invest over 10 years or more with some risk, he should consider unit trusts or investment trusts, through an Isa for tax relief. First he has to decide which geographical area to invest in and then decide which market sector he fancies.

The alternative is a fund of funds, where the selection of unit trusts is made for you, although these cost more as you are paying twice for fund management.

The solicitor should have his money in an interest-earning account and pay Tony the interest.

Danielle Leich works for PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Adviser 2: Lynne Maltby

Tony and Michelle should identify their monthly outgoings and fixed expenses to get a clear picture of what is left over to spend and save. As they have some £2,000 in their bank account, I suspect they could make regular monthly savings, perhaps into an Isa.

Tony should check his pension, as paying £20 per month is very low. To give their savings focus, they should decide their short- to medium-term objectives over one to five years, including holidays, house purchase, children and education fees.

Because of their ages, I assume they will accept average to above-average risk for their investments. I suggest they put £20,000 to £25,000 in a deposit-based, low-capital risk area for a rainy day and look for a good interest rate.

For the remainder, they could choose from a range of higher-risk unit trusts: Save and Prosper Premium Equity Growth, HSBC FTSE, Merrill Lynch British Blue Chip, Rathbones Smaller Companies, Cazenove European, Newton Continental, Merrill Lynch American, Threadneedle American Growth, Martin Currie Japan, Invesco GT Japan Growth, SocGen Technology, Norwich Union Property or Fidelity South East Asia. They should expect to hold their investments for five to 10 years, although they can switch funds over the period.

Lynne Maltby works for independent financial adviser Willis National.

webTitle: The couch potato's guide: Savings accounts

fields.headline: Happily, it could all end in tiers
fields.standfirst: How to find an account that will make your money grow quickly and safely
fields.trailText: How to find an account that will make your money grow quickly and safely.
fields.body:
Sliding rates

It is tempting for financial institutions to launch savings products with rates high enough to get into the best-buy tables for a week or two. 'The chances are they won't be maintained,' warns the financial research firm Moneyfacts.There have been many cases of rates dropping after savers have piled in, though some institutions do recognise that this would dent their trustworthy image.

But, for people who do not want to monitor rates, Rachel Thrussell of Moneyfacts says: 'On the whole, the mutual societies pay higher rates. Nationwide, Yorkshire and Britannia building societies usually pay more on branch-based accounts thansocieties which converted to banks - Halifax, Abbey National, Cheltenham & Gloucester and the others. But the converted societies still pay better than the high street banks.'

Some new internet accounts, including Egg and Woolwich's Open Plan, have rates to attract new savers.. Being heavily automated keeps their expenses down, but many analysts believe they will need to put their rates up in the medium term.

Limited access

Some high-paying accounts penalise those who withdraw cash frequently. You might be limited to taking out money just three times a year, or lose interest for 90 days.

Crashing interest

Most accounts run on tiers - paying a higher rate on balances above certain levels. Sainsbury's bank, for instance, pays an acceptable 5.75 per cent on a £2,500 balance in its Direct Saver Account. But if your balance falls to £2,499, the interest crashes to 1.25 per cent. Yet Egg and Smile, for example, pay 6.3 and 7.25 per cent respectively on any sum over £1.

High-paying Isas

Tax-free Individual Savings Accounts, or Isas - launched in April 1999 - offer good rates because they expect customers to leave the money on deposit for months or years to gain the most benefit.

The top payers now are mainly building societies. Britannia, for example, pays 6.85 per cent on £1 or more. This equates to 8.78 per cent for someone taxed at the basic rate on the interest.

Trust that costs

Don't have too much respect for authority. The Government's National Savings is making a killing because people trust it. Yet its rates are not particularly keen.

Independent financial adviser Colin Jackson of Baronworth, who specialises in elderly clients, has reservations about the Pensioners' Bond. 'If you have only £500 to invest, National Savings are fine,' he says. 'But if you have £5,000 or more and are a taxpayer, guaranteed income bonds are far better.'

Silence on risks

Many bank and building society counter staff get bonuses for persuading savers to swap basic deposit accounts for something more profitable.

'I've often seen people in building societies being told to put their money in a with-profits bond,' says Garry Spencer of Wilbury Financial Management in Worthing. 'They're not told the risks - just given a brochure.'

Saving graces

Banks and building societies which appear most often in the best buy tables

Abbey National

Bristol & West

Chelsea

Northern Rock

Scarborough

Banks and building societies which appear less often - but may produce better rates over the long term

Coventry

Egg

Portman

Scottish Widows

Standard Life

Source: Money£acts

Notes:

1) Some of these institutions - particularly those in the first category - have become adept at launching products that get into best buy tables. The most consistent providers are more likely to be those in the second group who are frequently just outside the best buys, but they stay nearer the top of the tables for longer.

2) The fact that an institution appears in these or best buy tables does not guarantee that it offers good rates across all its products. An institution can lead the market with one product and lag behind with others.

webTitle: The couch potato's guide: Managing your money

fields.headline: Be a financial wizard - without really trying
fields.standfirst: Too busy to monitor rates? Can't be bothered to switch accounts with each new best buy table?  Neasa MacErlean does the hard work for you
fields.trailText: Too busy to monitor rates? Can't be bothered to switch accounts with each new best buy table? Neasa MacErlean does the hard work for you.
fields.body:
There are two ways of managing your money. You can give it a lot of your time, scout around for the best deals and regularly take your custom to places offering better rates and rewards. Or - like most of us - you probably find yourself too busy doing other things to spend time each month deal-hunting. My aim is to help both groups, but particularly inactive investors. For them, the first tip is that if you'll end up staying with the same mortgage lender or savings institution for years, pick a good one to start with.

True, the deal-hunters should come out best in the long run. A new intensity of competition over the past five years means that the shrewdest mortgage borrowers will gain most by moving their loan every few years.

But a financial couch potato can still prosper. Finding a lender that consistently charged 1 per cent less than most and sticking with it would save £12,500 over the life of a £100,000 mortgage. Savers who choose badly could lose potential interest of between 5 and 6 per cent a year - worth perhaps £500 a year on a £10,000 deposit.

So how do you find the best institutions? And does your estimate of 'trustworthiness' matter? For a start, don't always put your faith in'best buy' tables. Players in all areas of personal finance deliberately structure their products to appear in the best buys. Researcher Moneyfacts calls this 'playing the chart'. The best are often not listed those listed as the best buys, but those consistently appearing near the top of the tables.

Many are rather cavalier in the way they describe their products. E-loan, the website information provider on mortgages, classifies 26 loans as'flexible' - but says it has probably had twice that number of providers who claim they have flexible products. When these products have been scrutinised, however, they have not turned out to be different.

The word 'ethical' is misused,too. Ethical investment plans have become extremely popular, but not because fund managers and product providers have seen the light: some are plain cynical and will call a product 'ethical' just to attract new groups of investors.

Unfortunately, personal finance is too complicated a subject to allow easy answers. Which? magazine does good work researching consumer areas from holidays to gym membership to building contractors, yet it does not look at specific savings and mortgage products. 'The mortgage market changes so rapidly that we haven't been able to look at it,' says spokeswoman Kate Levine.

So consumers can find themselves very confused when they try to differentiate between product providers. If you manage to keep out of the grasp of the bad ones, you have done half the job. Just as the devil is supposed to have the best tunes, so the bad providers and ruthless salespeople are expert at cynical marketing.

The fact that more than a million people may have been wrongly advised to switch from employers' pension schemes into personal pension plans a decade ago shows how easy it is for marketing schmooze to prevail over cold, hard facts.

But if you want to do the job properly, find a bank or building society you like and approve of. 'If you don't like your service provider, you should change it,' says Frank Eve, managing director of E-loan. If you find it too authoritarian, slow to answer your questions or obfuscating, these are all indications that it may not be right for you.

The most important factor when choosing a product is the interest rate, according to research organisation Mintel. But believing the institution to be 'trustworthy' is also important. This was cited as one of the two most important factors by 28 per cent of adults in Mintel's 'Deposit and Savings Account' research conducted this year.

Nationwide, the UK's largest building society, is very clearly aiming to be trustworthy. Like many of the other societies fighting to retain mutual status, it is working hard to prove that it does give good service to its customer-owners. By and large, it does seem to avoid marketing gimmicks. Many of its products are genuinely and consistently competitive, even though they do not appear in the best buy tables each week. Its mortgage and savings rates, cash Isas and even contents and buildings insurance policies are all attractive.

UK borrowers and investors probably take trustworthiness too much for granted, however. Perhaps we are too trusting ourselves. The controversy that emerged over Tessas, or Tax-Exempt Special Savings Accounts, last September is a reminder to consumers to be wary. After investigation by the Financial Ombudsman Service, it emerged that many firms had let the interest rates on the leftover accounts slide once the Tessa regime came to an end in April 1999. The only people who could hold these accounts after that date were people who had already invested. So there was no commercial need to get good publicity for them. Some providers let rates drop and tried to lock in their customers by having penalties for people switching out. When the Ombudsman said Tessa providers should pay compensation - to put account-holders on a par with people using other products with the same provider - some institutions responded with good grace and paid compensation immediately. Others dragged their heels.

Either way, the controversy shows just how willing the industry is to neglect customers if there is no compelling commercial reason to nurture them. The Government is now playing a major role in ensuring that some of the scandals of the past do not occur again. No longer, for instance, should savers be left in 'obsolete accounts', where the rate is run down below other similar accounts which are offered to newer customers.

The Mortgage Code is constantly being extended and, within the next year, lenders are due to be forced to register with the City regulator, the Financial Services Authority, for the first time. This will not stop people getting poor mortgage deals, but it should stop outright crooks from preying on them.

Personal service

David Georgiou, a 35-year-old car salesman from Aylesbury, took out a mortgage three years ago with Chesham building society in Buckinghamshire. He had previously had mortgages with big high street lenders but prefers this smaller society. With 2,000 borrowers, the Chesham is 46th in size out of 67 building societies. 'They are ever so friendly at the Chesham,' he says. 'Some larger organisations seem rather faceless. And the Chesham isn't trying to sell you other products. The banks are more interested in selling you other products on the mortgage, which can be a turn-off.'

If he could get a far better rate from a faceless internet bank, Mr Georgiou would go there. But he thinks rates are 'much of a muchness' and is more than happy to stay with the Chesham. With a standard variable rate of 7.45 per cent, the society undercuts Halifax, Nat West and many other big names.

Several other lenders have similar rates, but some offer a variable rate under 7 per cent. Mr Georgiou - who transferred part of his current mortgage from his previous house when he moved a few months ago - pays part of his mortgage on a 5.75 per cent rate fixed until May 2002 and part fixed at 6.4 per cent for another 18 months. When these deals finish, he and his wife plan to contact Chesham again. As a salesman himself, he appreciates the personal service. 'My customers come back to me because I work hard for them,' he says. 'At the Chesham, you can go in and speak to the manageress. You build up a relationship.'

webTitle: The couch potato's guide: Mortgages

fields.headline: Find the best, shun the rest
fields.standfirst: What to watch for when taking out a mortgage
fields.trailText: What to watch for when taking out a mortgage.
fields.body:
Exit penalties

Some lenders have lured borrowers with low interest rates, and then used the threat of hefty early redemption penalties to force them to stay several years after their attractive deals ended.

Northern Rock building society caused an outcry by doing this in 1995. Under huge public pressure, it was forced to back down and now says that it would never do this again. Most lenders' penalties are now less harsh, but you need to be wary.

Compulsory cover

Many lenders used to force borrowers to take out buildings and contents insurance with them, and many charged over the odds for it.

Although the practice is less common, it still exists. The Skipton, Newcastle, Bristol & West and even What Mortgage's 'top lender of the year', the Chorley & District, charge 'compulsory insurances'. This adds about 0.25 per cent a year to your costs, according to London & Country Mortgages. On a £100,000 loan, this costs £250 a year.

Fickle firms

Be wary of firms without records in the mortgage market, especially if they are not backed by recognised names.

Some have attracted borrowers and only then jacked up the interest rate. This has tended to happen when they have decided not to try to attract new customers, and no longer cared about bad publicity.

Interesting sums

Having your outstanding interest calculated daily rather than annually can save you nearly £4,000 over the life of a £50,000 repayment mortgage.

Under 'daily calculations', your outstanding liability is recalculated each day, so the capital element in your monthly payments is reduced immediately.

If, however, your lender does the sums annually, your payments will not be totted up until the end of the year, so you will not get the benefit of some of them until 12 months after paying.

The Government's Ca' standard mortgages, which conform to conditions on Charges, Access and Terms, must have daily interest.

Local lenders

Good deals can be achieved with the smallest building societies. Some have more than 100 years of trading history, and they are tightly regulated by the Building Societies Commission. Many now reach out nationally through the internet.

Quick service

Lenders are increasingly trying to compete on service as well as charges and products. Intelligent Finance and Abbey National, for instance, have speeded up their decision-making. In some circumstances, they can now agree loans in principle within a few minutes.

A small society might give a far better, more personal service, but it could be slower if it has not updated its systems recently.

Vanishing charges?

Lenders eager for your business often drop the upfront charges they levy to arrange fixed or discounted mortgages.

Some also help in other ways, for example by refunding the surveyor's fee. Watch out for firms which charge - perhaps £10 - to replace lost statements.

webTitle: Gore hopes dashed as count halted

fields.headline: Gore hopes dashed as count halted
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The US Supreme Court, the highest authority in the land, rolled into the embittered US election like a juggernaut yesterday, stamping out the ballot recount that had barely begun in Florida and probably handing George Bush a decisive advantage.
fields.body:
The US Supreme Court, the highest authority in the land, rolled into the embittered US election like a juggernaut yesterday, stamping out the ballot recount that had barely begun in Florida and probably handing George Bush a decisive advantage.

In a second dramatic volte-face in the epic election saga in less than 24 hours, the court voted by 5 to 4 to shut down the count which had been ordered by the Florida Supreme Court on Friday night, and which had given Al Gore a sudden and unexpected lease of life and hope.

Even before a vote was counted, the Florida court's ruling reduced Bush's lead from 537 to 153 votes, as ballots from Miami and Palm Each were added.

The Supreme Court will hear arguments tomorrow morning, but even if it rules in Gore's favour and allows the counts to continue, the order will almost certainly have come too late. The deadline for certifying electors to the Electoral College that chooses the President falls on Wednesday, 13 December, with Bush still the official winner of Florida's 25 votes.

The court's decision crowned a day that was a roller coaster even by the standards of this most remarkable election.

George Bush had petitioned two federal courts - the 11th circuit court of appeals in Atlanta, and Washington. The former was asked to grant an injunction to stop the count before it had even begun, and a 41-page brief to the Supreme Court pointed to 'serious constitutional errors' in the Florida court's decision. It asked the court to rule the recount unconstitutional and stop it. The formal appeal was due later yesterday afternoon, but was not necessary.

The judges kept their silence, however, as the time drew near to commence counting at 8am.

The count duly started of 9,000 votes cast in Miami, abandoned two weeks ago with a baying Republican mob kicking at the counting room door, and which the Gore camp was confident would see him overtake Bush's lead before the end of the day. Counts in other areas were complicated by logistical problems and an imposed deadline of 2pm today, but some, completed early, showed modest gains for Gore.

Even the excitement of Democrats in the counting rooms was qualified by the knowledge that the Supreme Court could stop the count at any moment.

Bush had accordingly submitted a 'supplemented memorandum' arguing that the situation 'powerfully demonstrated the need for a stay'.

Justice Anthony Kennedy arrived at the Washington court to convene all nine judges - an unpredecented move on a weekend.

The court itself is bitterly divided. Its rulings on major issues over the past two Presidential terms have invariably been settled 5-4, occasionally 6-3, with President Clinton's judges, Stephen Beyer and Ruth Bader Ginsburg, cancelling out ultra-conservatives Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas, who take a hard right-wing line (George Bush has praised both of them).

But seven of the nine judges were appointed by Presidents Bush, Reagan, Ford and Nixon - and two moderate conservatives have held the balance. Yesterday they voted on partisan lines.

The stay on the count was supported by Scalia, Thomas, Judge Anthony Kennedy and Sandra Day O'Connor - all appointed by Republican presidents - headed by the Chief Justice William Rehnquist, who has a long conservative track record.

Gore's lawyers had urged the Supreme Court to allow the counting of votes while the court considered its juris diction over a formal appeal from Bush, due yesterday afternoon. Gore's lawyers said it was 'remarkable' for Bush to simply ask the court to stop the count.

The court had one basic question before it: would it allow the vote to continue before Gore's time ran out, or not? Even if the court had granted Bush's appeal, the count would have continued and Gore's possible lead established before any hearing.

The baffled counters dropped their ballots, which were put back in file boxes; the counting rooms were empty within minutes.

Officials in the Gore campaign were almost speechless with bitterness. Spokesman Ron Klain said the counts were 'going well', with 13 counties finished. 'We were in a position for Vice President Gore and Senator Joe Lieberman to take the lead,' he said.

Looking shattered, David Boies - the attorney whose victory on Friday had brought Gore to the brink of the presidency - said: 'The timing issue is the most disappointing thing about what the Supreme Court has done. It makes it much more difficult to get the count completed even if the count gets the go-ahead'.

webTitle: Barak resigns as Israeli prime  minister

fields.headline: Barak resigns as Israeli prime  minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak flummoxed the nation yesterday when he announced he would resign today and push for re-election to the prime ministership in 60 days to seek a fresh mandate to tackle what he called the country's emergency situation.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak flummoxed the nation yesterday when he announced he would resign today and push for re-election to the prime ministership in 60 days to seek a fresh mandate to tackle what he called the country's emergency situation.

"There are those who doubt the mandate I received from the citizens of Israel", Mr Barak said in a televised address to the nation.

"Tomorrow I will advise the president of my resignation (and) in 60 days we will go to special elections for prime minister."

He said he made his decision in consultation with his family over Friday night dinner, and took it to prevent Israel from contending full general elections for both the prime ministership and the parliament at a time when the country's security was so fragile.

"Due to the emergency situation the country is in... and the need to continue reducing the violence and moving forward the chances of peace negotiations, I have decided to ask again for the trust of the people of Israel," said Barak at a hastily convened news conference at his Jerusalem office.

"Tomorrow morning I will officially inform the president of my decision to resign and to stand in special elections as the head of the Labour Party for prime minister of Israel."

Israeli law prevents parliament from dissolving itself, and Mr Barak's opponents for a prime ministerial vote must be sitting assembly members.

A beleagured Barak will therefore avoid competing against former prime minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who opinion polls suggest would win an election.

"I, as prime minister, who was elected by a large majority, intend to ask the nation's permission to continue the path that we started on in the secure belief this is the right and true and only way for the state of Israel," Mr Barak said.

Explaining his decision to call a special election for his position and not hold a general election, he said: "I see no need to drag the country into unnecessary elections."

He added that if parliament now chose to dissolve itself, then a suitable date would be found for prime ministerial and parliamentary elections.

The cunning move for special elections for prime minister would reduce the chance that Mr Barak would be challenged for his party's leadership. He would likely stand against right-wing Likud leader Mr Ariel Sharon for the prime minister's post.

The tormented Israeli leader has come under attack for his handling of a Palestinian uprising that broke out in the vacuum left by deadlocked peace talks.

It had been speculated in the past that Mr Barak would use this time to make a major efforts to reach some sort of an agreement with the Palestinians before an election, and polls suggest that without such an achievement, his chances of re-election would be extremely slim.

The Speaker of the Palestinian Legislative Council, Ahmed Qrei, said that it could be difficult to conclude a deal under such a tight timetable.

"I don't think there is any possibility to reach a peace agreement within this period," Qrei said.

He added that the coming 60 days would appear to be a "time out" from the peace process.

Mr Barak told a press gathering in Jerusalem that he would continue to seek ways to restart talks with the Palestinians but that he could not promise anything.

Popular support for Mr Barak has taken a nosedive in the two months since fighting broke out. The vast majority of some 300 people killed have been Palestinian, but Israelis' sense of security has been battered and bruised, and many have lost faith in the peace process.

A poll in the Hebrew daily, Maariv, indicated that Mr Netanyahu is ahead of Mr Barak by 45 to 27 percent, suggesting that half of Mr Barak's voters in the last election have now deserted him.

Mr Barak's move is widely viewed as an effort to ensure that he runs against the opposition Likud leader Mr Sharon and not Mr Netanyahu, who resigned from politics upon his election defeat. When a prime minister resigns, triggering elections for prime minister but not for parliament, Israeli law requires any candidate to be members of parliament.

A Likud member close to Mr Netanyahu said that he expected the prime minister to honour his commitment to change the law to enable Mr Netanyahu to run.

Mr Danny Naveh insisted that in any case, "any Likud leader will defeat the prime minister of Israel, and we will revert Israel to what we all hope will be a road of peace with security."

webTitle: Blair ready to torpedo Nice summit over tax

fields.headline: Blair ready to torpedo Nice summit over tax
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was last night fighting a bitter rearguard action to protect Britain's right to set social security and tax policy as crucial talks on the future shape of Europe were suspended in deadlock.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was last night fighting a bitter rearguard action to protect Britain's right to set social security and tax policy as crucial talks on the future shape of Europe were suspended in deadlock.

Officials said last night that Britain would be prepared to torpedo the entire summit rather than surrender its veto in these key areas.

The British battle was taking place amid mounting anger among smaller members of the EU over plans to redistribute power within an enlarged Europe.

Blair is ready to move to majority voting in a series of areas which he says will be to Britain's advantage. But he insisted last night that the veto would remain on tax and social security.

The French President, Jacques Chirac, has demanded a deadline of noon today for completion of the negotiations. A French draft treaty launched yesterday has been rejected by Britain, with the Prime Minister telling his officials that no deal was possible. A set of meetings took place last night to try to hammer out a deal.

'It is still not acceptable because it breaches the fundamental point of principle that tax is a matter for the British Government, the British Parliament and the British people,' the Prime Minister's official spokesman said. Although Britain is now considering the surrender of its veto in up to 30 areas, British officials said that if France, which holds the presidency of the European Union, did not drop the taxation and social security clauses in the treaty then the summit would end in failure.

Britain has now agreed to allow through a clause on immigration and border controls, even though it is a 'red line' issue, because of an opt-out Britain achieved from immigration matters. 'It will not affect us,' a Downing Street spokesman said.

But the move was pounced on by the Conservatives as a signal that Blair was softening his stance n order to get a deal. 'It would be completely wrong for Britain to give up its veto in immigration,' said the Shadow Foreign Secretary, Francis Maude.

Britain's take on the 'red line' issues was just one of a series of rows at the summit. Portugal led a furious group of European nations who claim they have been 'humiliated' by a decision to change the balance of power in favour of the five larger nations.

webTitle: Euan Ferguson meets...Shelaine Green

fields.headline: Take a girl like her
fields.standfirst: When most of us talk about 'buying a plot', we mean land to plant cabbages. But this particular Everywoman shelled out six grand to feature in a fictional story.  ' Ever wondered who bought those Bridget Jones chick-lit rip-offs? Who kept the trillions rolling in for Body Shop and Phil Collins and Tesco Metro and  Friends and  Hello! magazine? It was Shelaine Green'
fields.trailText: Euan Ferguson meets...Shelaine Green
fields.body:
Some time in the Eighties, a certain type of woman began climbing from the messy detritus left by post-feminism, the anti-radical backlash and the booming economy. We called her Cosmo Woman. A decade later we called her not-too-distant relative Bridget Jones, and she was to play a huge, vital and unforeseen role in our life and culture.

We all know her, or her characteristics. Apolitical. Flirting for a fashionable while with the liberal freedoms won by others - sex and drugs - while at college winning a 2:2 in something anodyne and business-oriented, although she's now happier with a glass or two of white wine on the sofa with a girlfriend. Not keen on 'difficult' literature or music, because after all it's there to entertain , surely. A masterful knowledge of Ikea and the intricacies of flat-buying for the single girl. Photos, somewhere, of the life-affirming trip with chums to Tibet or Nepal. An overfondness, in writing and emails, for pointless exclamation marks.

If we were to be more cynically misanthropic we would include the 'witty' postcards sent from Meribel (arrows on the front showing the hotel bedroom and a message on the back about the antics of Mizzi, Tiggers, Flozza and Meee!!! ), having a boyfriend possessed of big jumpers and an MBA, referring to people as 'mad' or 'crazy' for having opened a second bottle and anthropomorphising their car with a joke name such as Hector or Murgatroyd. Enough...you know her. You might well be her.

And there's no real point in sneering, for this woman is one of the most potent forces in society today. Ever wondered just who buys all those Tube advertised Bridget Jones chick-lit rip-offs in their millions? Who it was that kept the trillions rolling in for Body Shop and Phil Collins and Tesco Metro and Friends and Louis de Berniéres and Hello! magazine? It was Everywoman. It was Shelaine Green.

I'd wanted to meet Shelaine after reading last week that she paid over £6,000 to have her name used as a character in the next novel by Kathy Lette. Hers was the highest bid in an auction in aid of the Medical Foundation for the Victims of Torture, in which authors such as Kathy and Nick Hornby agreed to use the bidder's name in their next works; so Kathy's fans will next year meet a character called Shelaine Green who will be feisty, sassy and other ballsy girl-traits. But I'd wanted to meet the real one because I suspected there might be an important circular irony here, in that the Everywoman Kathy and others have been selling to for years was now about to star in a book designed exactly for her. I suspected that in Shelaine I might find some answers: who, really, was Everywoman, and how would the reality of the book-buying woman collide with the fiction of the female character she would become? I couldn't have been more right in my prejudices; and I couldn't, of course, have been more wrong.

Shelaine is almost unbearably pleasant. Trying to argue with her is like having a soft pillow-fight with the goddess of benignity, and she refuses to take offence at anything I say, even when trashing her chosen profession of marketing. She was born in Guernsey, 'a lovely place to grow up, safe and prosperous, and wonderful beaches.' This has bequeathed to her the odd accent of the island which leads many to think she's Australian: a fast throaty giggle and ready smile add to the impression. She left, however, as it was growing too stifling. She went, at 18, to Bath, to read chemistry - 'I'd loved all the bangs and smells at school. But research chemistry was a little duller than that. So I looked around for something that would keep me using my brain, and that's how I went into marketing. Friends who did it said they were really busy, and it was all common-sense stuff.'

So she lived with two other girls in a flat in Olympia. 'We used to call ourselves the blonde, the brunette and the mousy-brown. Guess which I was! That was how we did our invitations _ we had great fun, great parties.' Later, she won a Cosmopolitan competition to spend a year at INSEAD, the French business school, and recalls it as her 'wildest year: you should have seen us, crazy, walking through the airport with our little badges on saying "Cosmo high fliers". It was a good year.'

Now she lives with her long-term boyfriend - usually, anyway: he's away doing an MBA of his own - in a large, light penthouse flat off Ladbroke Grove. She's just spent three months travelling round South America (the mandatory Nepal trip was in 1991), and she adores her job, working freelance from home and proving rather successful at it (although her ability to bid at the auction was helped by a 'bit of an inheritance' earlier this year). She's always looking for 'fresh challenges', she says, and if bored she gets on the phone to one of her girlfriends for a 'good gossip'. She's 'not big on opera or ballet, but I like gentle classical, to switch off. A lot of my entertainment's like that. fields.headline: Another fine Messerschmitt...
fields.standfirst: Laurel and Hardy meet the Luftwaffe in the new Günter Grass, Too Far Afield
fields.trailText: Laurel and Hardy meet the Luftwaffe in the new Günter Grass, Too Far Afield
fields.body:
Too Far Afield
Günter Grass
Faber £25, pp658
Buy it at BOL

Too Far Afield was published in Germany in 1995, four years before Günter Grass won the Nobel Prize, and although it fulfils some of what is expected from a public writer in a time of drastic change, it has its own perverse agenda.

The novel's time-frame, from the tearing down of the Berlin Wall in 1989 to the unification of the next year and beyond, follows the progress of Germany's greatest post-war upheaval. There is plenty of detail about daily life in a rapidly transforming city and country, but Grass's real obsession is with registering ripples of correspondence, many of them faint and all of them obscure to an international readership, across two centuries of German history.

The hero of the novel is Theo Wuttke, a 70-year-old who once wore the blue of the Luftwaffe uniform. In East Germany during the Cold War, he lectured on cultural subjects and managed to ruffle the feathers of the regime, however untopical the title of his presentation might seem to be. He has long since renounced controversy but can't shake off his 'day-and-night shadow', the security agent Ludwig Hoftaller, who still knows any number of exploitable secrets, whether about Wuttke's wartime dalliances in France or the questionable loyalties of his estranged sons living in the West.

Grass's cover illustration shows a crowd of tall Wuttkes and stumpy Hoftallers in conversation, and at various points in the book he seeks to impose them on the reader, usually by the same conceit of multiplication, as an iconic couple, if not Laurel and Hardy then Quixote and Sancho Panza.

It is Wuttke's quixoticism to regard himself as the reincarnation of 'the Immortal', a writer and political commentator born in the same town (Neuruppin) on the same day (30 December), albeit 100 years earlier (in 1819 rather than 1919). His conversation skips back and forth between the centuries, in a way that his intimates now take for granted. Hoftaller is well used to being addressed as 'Tallhover', his nineteenth-century equivalent, the agent who kept tabs on the Immortal. The Immortal is never named in full, but his books are given their titles, and Wuttke is nicknamed 'Fonty', so it isn't hard to identify 'T.F.' as Theodor Fontane.

Part of the attraction of Fontane for Grass (born 1927) may be that the work for which he is best remembered is 'an old man's late harvest' (Effi Briest appeared in 1895). In any case, Fontane's varied output of essays, war journalism, poems and fiction offers rich pickings for a twentieth-century writer who seeks, like Wuttke's favourite remembered schoolteacher, 'to eliminate the meaningless separation between the subjects of history and German by incorporating historical quotations into the latter and literary evidence into the former'.

It's true that Effi Briest has achieved classic status, as a novel of adultery fit to share a shelf with Madame Bovary and Anna Karenina (Grass has tracked down a suitably lugubrious homage in Krapp's Last Tape: 'Scalded the eyes out of me reading Effi again, a page a day, with tears again'), but the details of his life and work are somewhat out of the way. Too Far Afield (the title is taken, without apparent irony, from Effi Briest) provides nothing in the way of exposition, just incessant allusion. The effect is to burden the modest flow of the story with cryptic references, to the point of inducing thromboses and aneurysms of narrative.

When Wuttke's unknown granddaughter, whose mother was the product of a liaison in wartime France, shows up in Berlin, some breaking up of sclerotic literary deposits might be hoped for, some clearing of drains. But she too is an enthusiast of the writer she calls 'Monsieur X', to the point of having written a paper on the role played in his works by Newfoundland dogs.

The habit of withholding names is extended to history and politics as well as literature. Any reader who doesn't immediately recognise 'the Sulfur-Yellow Collar' as Bismarck will have to be patient indeed, since the identification is spelled out only on page 524. And as for 'the Saxon Goatee'...

Grass does come up with one grand image, free of allusive encrustation, for the repetitiveness, almost the repetition-compulsion, of German history: the old-fashioned lift, of the sort known as a paternoster, in the Ministries building where Wuttke works half days as a file courier, its chain of cabins open at the front and continuously moving, passing turning points in the cellar and the attic. It was while riding the paternoster that Wuttke met his wife in the 1930s, when the building housed Goering's Air Ministry, and the antiquated mechanism is still functional when the Handover Trust moves in to facilitate unification, that velvety Anschluss.

Alongside the political pessimism of Too Far Afield is an incongruously pure faith in high culture. When, in a branch of McDonald's, Fonty recites all 23 stanzas of a ballad of Fontane's on a Scottish theme, he is applauded rather than moved on. His clandestine anti-Nazi broadcasts in France were highly effective, even though he was largely reading from Fontane's memoirs of the Franco-Prussian war: he 'had the impact of a bomb every time they broadcast him. Just look at the statistics on defectors round Lyon'.

Even after unification, a lecture of Fonty's on literary themes electrifies a mixed audience into shouting the names of their favourite Fontane characters ('Where's Alonzo Gieshübler, the noble apothecary?'). If the repetitiveness of history, the sense that 'in Germany nothing ever changes', as Fonty puts it, is a source of anguish, the continuity of German culture seems, for Grass at least, to be a potent consolation. But how can it be, when history and German are the same subject? If literature has no separate status, then it must suffer a cancellation of immunity.

But the problem with Too Far Afield, from most readers' point of view, is more likely to be textural than philosophical. Fontane defended his old-fashioned preference for chapter headings on the basis that he favoured resting places, not only in art but in life: 'I have no use for parks without benches.' Grass has admittedly provided chapter headings for his combination of memorial garden and public park. But it is an expanse not so much turfed as paved with monologues, seeded largely with allusions.
