fields.headline: Fancy a quick think?
fields.standfirst: A history of philosophy needs depth as well as breadth. Anthony Gottlieb skates over much that is dark in The Dream of Reason
fields.trailText: A history of philosophy needs depth as well as breadth. Anthony Gottlieb skates over much that is dark in The Dream of Reason
fields.body:
The Dream of Reason: A History of Philosophy from the Greeks to the Renaissance
Anthony Gottlieb
Allen Lane/The Penguin Press £20, pp469
Buy it at BOL

There is no shortage of popular introductions to the history of Western philosophy. These can be deliberately middle-brow, such as Will Durant's, or idiosyncratically challenging, as is Bertrand Russell's. Badly needed are authoritative guides, written for the general reader, to the philosophic contributions of Judaism and to the rich history of speculative thought with Islam. Neither of these is on offer, except by oblique reference, in Anthony Gottlieb's survey.

None the less, a good case can be made for the singular wonder of Western philosophy as it emerges somewhere around the sixth century BC in Ionia, in Sicily and in mainland Greece. However familiar the facts, one's sense of astonishment and gratitude should remain lively.

Disinterested, resplendently useless, wholly abstract modes of articulate thought, of logical investigation, of playful yet profoundly serious debate, are, in many ways, unique to Western sensibility and consciousness. The notion that an unexamined life is not worth living, that the pursuit of metaphysical truths is man's peculiar and non-utilitarian dignity, spring, almost fully-armed out of Hellas.

Gottlieb scarcely pauses to analyse what may have been the reasons. Could it be that the leisure afforded an élite by slavery, by the 'domestication' of women, by a climate which favoured outdoor meditation and exchanges, provided a unique matrix? Superb astronomical and geophysical observations had been achieved in Sumeria and ancient Egypt. The Hellenic leap into abstraction, the intuition that the solution of a problem in conic sections is worth dying for (Archimedes) remains Greek - and in many ways enigmatic.

Once the Milesians - pioneers such as Thales, Anaximander and Anaximenes - had set out on the royal road to nowhere, the unfolding was rapid. Absolutely fundamental questions as to the nature of the cosmos, of the specificity of the human intellect, and the possible relations between truth and virtue were posed and variously answered. That these answers often took the form of poetry and myth - as in Parmenides and Empedocles but also, and supremely, in Plato - adds to the fascination of the case. Controversially, but with enormous impact and force of suggestion, Martin Heidegger has altered, has made integral to the current climate of understanding, the primordial importance and interpretation of the pre-Socratics. The name of Heidegger does not appear in this book.

Given this very Anglo-Saxon limitation (or haughtiness), Gottlieb's treatment is of admirable clarity and balance. It would be difficult to find a more lucid introduction to Parmenides's vexed yet formidably actual reflections on the capacity of language to say 'that which is not' or on his identification of thought with being itself. Nor can the layman have a clearer, more incisive guide to Zeno's vexing paradoxes than Gottlieb's. This is haute vulgarisation at its very best.

The summation of Plato, on the other hand, is a disappointment. Concentrating almost exclusively on the Republic and the Timaeus, it conveys little of Plato's incomparable genius, both as thinker and writer. It is the Parmenides and the Theaetetus which most concern philosophic argument to this day; it is the Phaedrus and the Symposium which shape Western valuations of immortality, or Eros and the human spirit. As Alfred North Whitehead famously put it, the whole of our Western philosophy is a footnote to Plato.

As befits an executive editor of the Economist, Gottlieb rises to Aristotle. It is Aristotle's truly awesome range, toughness of intellect and systematic powers which engage Gottlieb's enthusiasm. Here 'the dreams of reason' are dreamt and acted upon in daylight. Works which encompass physics and semiotics, comparative anatomy and formal logic, poetics and politics, theology and meteorology, were to determine the agenda of Western philosophic and scientific inquiry for more than 1,000 years. Via Latin translation (and thanks to Cicero), concepts such as 'potential', 'dynamics', 'energy', 'substance', 'quality', 'essence', 'category' and many others continue to articulate our questions to the world. Even 'Mrs Aristotle' finds her chastened place in Gottlieb's lively perspective.

A useful look at the Epicurean, Stoic and Sceptic sages who follow on Plato and Aristotle takes the narrative to St Augustine. It is both refreshing and absolutely legitimate to find Augustine considered as a major philosophic player. A fair measure of our readings of consciousness and self-consciousness derive from Augustine's formidable strengths and candours of introspection. Very possibly, we would have had neither Montaigne, nor Rousseau nor, it may well be, Freud without Augustine's precedent. Augustinian analyses of free will and determinism remain fresh. As do his meditations, in so many ways unsurpassed, on the nature of time (here also, omission of any reference to Heidegger detracts).

By the time of Augustine's death in AD 430, the foundations of philosophy, of psychology, of political theory, of logic and inquiry into the nature of language in the West had been laid. Gottlieb's breathless account of medieval scholasticism and renaissance Neo-Platonism is, intentionally no doubt, an epilogue. The great subversions of Bacon and of Descartes lie on the horizon.

The virtues of this compendium are manifest. It is written with brisk humour. Lewis Carroll turns up next to Parmenides; Flann O' Brien helps illuminate Hesiod; Umberto Eco hovers in the Aristotelian wings. The skills of a senior journalist and expositor inform even opaque and controversial issues. The 'common reader' owes gratitude to Gottlieb's avocation. But it is these same virtues which entail an underlying drawback. Only very rarely does this cool, often amused chronicle provide its readers with any intimation of the strangeness, the almost physical obduracy, the solitude of 'doing philosophy'. It is not in these smiling pages that we will experience the brain-numbing tensions which generate a theorem in formal logic. Gottlieb's enviable good sense skates lightly over much that is dark.

It is both refreshing and absolutely legitimate to find Augustine considered as a major philosophic player. A fair measure of our readings of consciousness and self-consciousness derive from Augustine's formidable strengths and candours of introspection. Very possibly, we would have had neither Montaigne, nor Rousseau nor, it may well be, Freud without Augustine's precedent. Augustinian analyses of free will and determinism remain fresh. As do his meditations, in so many ways unsurpassed, on the nature of time (here also, omission of any reference to Heidegger detracts). By the time of Augustine's death in AD 430, the foundations of philosophy, of psychology, of political theory, of logic and inquiry into the nature of language in the West had been laid. Gottlieb's breathless account of medieval scholasticism and renaissance Neo-Platonism is, intentionally no doubt, an epilogue. The great subversions of Bacon and of Descartes lie on the horizon. The virtues of this compendium are manifest. It is written with brisk humour. Lewis Carroll turns up next to Parmenides; Flann O' Brien helps illuminate Hesiod; Umberto Eco hovers in the Aristotelian wings. The skills of a senior journalist and expositor inform even opaque and controversial issues. The 'common reader' owes gratitude to Gottlieb's avocation. But it is these same virtues which entail an underlying drawback. Only very rarely does this cool, often amused chronicle provide its readers with any intimation of the strangeness, the almost physical obduracy, the solitude of 'doing philosophy'. It is not in these smiling pages that we will experience the brain-numbing tensions which generate a theorem in formal logic. Gottlieb's enviable good sense skates lightly over much that is dark.

webTitle: Observer review: Fear and Loathing in America by Hunter S Thompson

fields.headline: Magnum enforcer
fields.standfirst: He writes like a gunslinger, but he's really a disillusioned dreamer. Fear and Loathing in America is the second volume of Hunter S Thompson's letters
fields.trailText: He writes like a gunslinger, but he's really a disillusioned dreamer. Fear and Loathing in America is the second volume of Hunter S Thompson's letters
fields.body:
Fear and Loathing in America: the Brutal Odyssey of an Outlaw Journalist !968-1976
Hunter S Thompson
Bloomsbury £20, pp756
Buy it at BOL

Hunter S Thompson learnt how to write while straddling a motorbike among a pack of cursing, grunting, vroom-vrooming Hell's Angels. For him, writing is an engine, trampling or noisily obliterating all resistance; style is speed, fuelled by amphetamines and hallucinogens not gasoline.

He writes, as the Angels rode, to ventilate what he calls, in this second volume of his collected letters, a 'killing rage - a savage hatred of the venal politicians, thuggish police and crass commercial developers' who during these years in his view transformed America into a fascist state.

In 1975, sent to Vietnam by Rolling Stone to gloat over the withdrawal of American troops, Thompson wrote an uncharacteristically deferential letter to a Vietcong official, requesting an interview. He apologised for his typing, but assured the colonel that, 'I am one of the best writers currently using the English language as both a musical instrument and a political weapon.' It was sweetly naive of him to imagine that military despots value such credentials; nevertheless, his self-assessment was just. The music made by the language, in his use of it, resembles the percussive iteration of gunfire, or the fulmination of an exploding grenade. From inside his fortified bunker in Colorado, with his pet Dobermans slavering at the perimeter, he fires off missives as if they were missiles.

Occasionally his violence goes beyond verbal bluster. He kills a bear in his front yard and playfully discharges a 19-gauge shotgun inside his living room ('a hideous accident caused by a mixture of gunpowder and LSD'). Admiring a moonlit sky above the Rockies, he gives himself over to an inimitably American spasm of romantic sublimity: the Milky Way is so clear and close that 'a madman with good reflexes could shoot the stars out of the sky, one by one, with a .264 Magnum'.

Thompson's electric typewriter sounds like a machine gun, and serves much the same purpose. Writing to an editor at Random House, he shows off a row of inky column-breakers, which look like bullet-holes on the page. His chosen weapon discharges an arsenal of virtuoso abuse.

Thompson has his own fond equivalents to the endearments which are customary in letters. He greets Tom Wolfe as a 'worthless scumsucking bastard', a 'decadent pig' and a 'pile of albino warts', and calls Anthony Burgess a 'lazy cocksucker' and 'cheapjack scum'. Has there been anything so inventively foul-mouthed since the Montagu and Capulet gangs abused each other in Romeo and Juliet?

This rabid, lethal anger is of course the cover for a thwarted love; Thompson fears and loathes America because it has disappointed him, betraying its initial ideals.

During the decade traversed in this volume, he is planning a book - never completed, though he regularly invoiced the patient publisher for expenses - called The Death of the American Dream, which would show how a peaceful agrarian society had grown into a belligerent empire, renamed Amerika by Thompson.

That 'king-bitch stud' John Wayne would now, Thompson argues, 'be proud to pistol-whip a radical punk like Thomas Jefferson' and beat him into a 'bloody, screaming hamburger'.

Thompson's response is to vilify those who killed the dream - the 'criminal geek' Nixon; the 'babbling, pus-filled nightmare' Spiro Agnew, 'that bone-head ward-heeler' Gerald Ford with his skull like a 'rotten pear'. At the same time, in a move which suggests either quixotic innocence or celebrity megalomania, he sets out to renovate politics by presenting himself as a candidate for public office.

Mobilising what he calls Freak Power, he campaigns to become mayor of Aspen, and in 1976 makes a trial run for the presidency. (Jimmy Carter, who was elected that year, jokily deferred to him. He said he thought of withdrawing from the contest in Thompson's favour, then wondered if he might be bought off with 'the higher office of sheriff', which would enable him to do more shooting). In between volleys of rhetorical fire-power, Thompson lobbies the same elected officials, hoping for a sinecure.

He wanted to be made governor of American Samoa, 'the last Jeffersonian frontier, and in selling the notion to Senator George McGovern (a presidential candidate in 1972) he quotes The Great Gatsby, that earlier elegy for a polluted dream.

This offshore America in the Pacific would be his 'fresh green breast of the new world'. Gatsby is omnipresent in these letters, and Thompson's allusions to it reveal what a sad, disillusioned romantic he is at heart. Finally he decides - realising that Fitzgerald has written his intended book for him - that 'the saga of Richard Nixon is the death of the American Dream. He was our Gatsby, but the light on the end of his pier was black instead of green...' Fitzgerald's narrator Nick Carraway goes back to the Midwest at the end of the novel; Thompson, moving further west for safety's sake, retreats to a 'goddam soundproof dungeon' atop the isolating mountains.

Though Thompson enjoys representing himself as a madman, he is in fact a mythomaniac, in whose imagination national dreams and nightmares do lurid battle.

At the end of the book, he proudly recalls his career as a juvenile delinquent in Louisville, Kentucky. His great triumph was to steal a case of beer and then throw all 24 unopened bottles through the windows of the house owned by a petty bureaucrat who'd had him expelled from school. 'I was,' he boasts, 'Louisville's answer to Billy the Kid.'

The outlawry he claims for himself in the subtitle is another of America's grandiose mythical roles. Like all Western heroes, Thompson is a fuming conscience armed with a gun - or rather with an IBM Selectric - whose keys smell of cordite when he smites them.

webTitle: Dangerous conjugations

fields.headline: Dangerous conjugations
fields.standfirst: The Social Affairs Unit has just published  a dictionary of 'dangerous words'...
fields.trailText: The Social Affairs Unit has just published The Dictionary of Dangerous Words edited by Digby Anderson, claiming that 'some 200 words are being used in new ways which reveal new values'. These, apparently, include 'alternative', 'bourgeois', 'closet' and so on, right the way through to 'xenophobe', 'youth' and 'Zionist'.
fields.body:
The Social Affairs Unit has just published The Dictionary of Dangerous Words edited by Digby Anderson, claiming that 'some 200 words are being used in new ways which reveal new values'. These, apparently, include 'alternative', 'bourgeois', 'closet' and so on, right the way through to 'xenophobe', 'youth' and 'Zionist'.

The redefinition of 'just' is particularly good: 'an adverbial qualification that diminishes the seriousness of the conduct... it qualifies. Thus 'just a slap' means 'I broke her jaw', 'just burglary' means 'I am in prison because I have broken into 78 houses'.

It's an entertaining volume that almost lives up to John Cleese's claim that it will 'replace a university education'. Like all lexicographers, Digby Anderson is eager to detect a larger purpose to his efforts. So he says that, in the battle between new and old use, much more is involved than a simple war of words. 'It's a clash of cultures,' he writes, 'a battle to define good and bad in economics, politics, the arts and personal behaviour.'

Well, I have news for Dr Anderson. As the Christmas party season opens, we, in the world of books, will be using the English language in ways that should keep the Social Affairs Unit in seminar material for months to come. So (with apologies to a dozen Anglo-American columnists who've been here before) I offer my own modest primer to some crucial contemporary conjugations and some vital new usages:

I am a lonely artist

You are a struggling freelance

He is a talentless hack

We are an undiscovered talent

You are a 'New Puritan'

They couldn't write 'bum' on a wall.

I have a wide circle of friends

You are very well-connected

She's a social mountaineer

We are invited everywhere

You will go to the opening of an envelope

They are shameless gate-crashers

I have personality

You are eccentric

He's as mad as a hatter

We have character

You are a weirdo

They are bonkers

I have a cult following

You are obscure

He is unheard of

We've written a roman à clef

You are short of ideas

They think fiction is what happens to ball-bearings

I am incredibly well-read

You are eclectic

She is an autodidact

We love New Writing

You're an inveterate reader

They have no discrimination

I have high standards

You are a bit pretentious

He is insufferable

We celebrate the European tradition

You claim to have read Proust in the original

They've just bought themselves The Unbearable Lightness of Being

I am taking a sabbatical

Your contract is up

She has just been fired

We've gone freelance

You've taken unpaid leave

They're pregnant again.

I know Martin and Ian

You are a literary groupie

He will suck up to anyone

We are friends with Salman

You talk about the literary mafia

They are dreadful star-******s

I've been short-listed

You are a runner-up

She's a Booker judge

We are the favourite

You're attracting the smart money

They have an outside chance

I take inspiration from Dickens and Beckett

You are derivative

He plagiarises

We have a wide range of reference

You are looking for a voice

They are literary ventriloquists

I hold my own

You are difficult

She is impossible

We have strong views

You are argumentative

They are a pain in the neck

I converse

You are indiscreet

He is a liability

We are chatty

You love gossip

They are malicious

 The Dictionary of Dangerous Words also offers advice on how to use such words as 'affirm' 'backward', 'diversity', 'partner' and 'discrimination'. It is available from the Social Affairs Unit, 314-322 Regent Street, London W1B 3BB (£5.95 plus 55p p&p)

webTitle: Paperbacks: 10 Dec

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Marvell the politician is predominant in this dispassionate biography, plus Eating Naked, Pinter the Playwright, The Basque History of the World and My Century
fields.body:
Andrew Marvell: World Enough and Time
Nicholas Murray
Abacus £10.99, pp342
Buy it at BOL

Undiminished by the subsequent evolution of language, Marvell's verses can stir our deepest emotions and make us laugh aloud. His best known work (' To His Coy Mistress', 1646) is by turns grisly, profound and in its sexual candour, the work of a first class 'satyrist' in the truest sense.

Its imagery was appropriated by Eliot and overshadows even Shelley. For the first time,though, Marvell the politician is predominant, making this biography invaluable to historians of the Civil War and Restoration. Murray acknowledges that most biographical details are as unverifiable as those pertaining to Shakespeare. But in an effort to avoid the fanaticism that has plagued Shakespearean criticism (Was he (Marvell) gay? He was a spy!), he only tentatively discusses what might have happened, without really conveying what it might have been like. Rather dispassionate then, but well-written and intelligently so.

Eating Naked (Stories)
Stephen Dobyns
Penguin £7.99, pp276
Buy it at BOL

Characters are crushed by pigs, molested with carrots, and take dining al fresco very (un)seriously. But the common denominator is that, having fallen out of love, most are able to fall back in love with life again. Of these 16 (progressively darker) stories, not one is a dud.

Dobyns's moral is that getting the girl/boy is often less important than getting the joke. Like Winston Groom or Chuck Palahniuk, Dobyns has a deliciously deadpan humour, his 31st book the most exhilarating read I have had in years.

This is a fully stocked cabinet of antidotes to the feeling life's 'pen[ned] you up within its chain-link fence'. Whether or not you feel like a pig falling out of a helicopter, or your mind is 'a mass of question marks', make the most of the view.

Pinter the Playwright
Martin Esslin
Methuen £9.99, pp296
Buy it at BOL

This is a superlative guide for any artist, critic or thinker. It is the definitive work. Concerned with language's hidden meanings and hidden meaninglessness, Pinter is utterly lucid and true to his subject. Esslin keeps biography to a minimum. The result is a collection of pure, uncluttered thought.

Alongside the great Heideggerian existentialists, Beckett, Ionesco and Sartre, Pinter is less evasive, much less egotistical and more intelligible. In his own words, 'Between my lack of... data about [characters] and the ambiguity of what they say, there lies a territory which is not only worthy of exploration but which it is compulsory to explore.' Mount an expedition at once!

The Basque History of the World
Mark Kurlansky
Vintage £7.99, pp387
Buy it at BOL

The Basques have been everywhere and nowhere throughout history, pioneering by themselves and assimilating others' innovations, while retaining a strong sense of identity. Their country (between France and Spain) is on no maps but their own, and some historians claim their unique language was that of Adam and Eve.

They are Europe's oldest, most mysterious and adventurous people - introducing the continent to whale meat, cod, chocolate and capitalism. The Basques reached America before the Vikings. A Basque founded the Jesuits who subsequently persecuted them during the Inquisition; although, as the Romans discovered, suppressing them was near impossible. More than an idiosyncratic microcosm, Basque culture, described with great verve by Kurlansky, seems like one of the motors that has propelled the world.

My Century
Günter Grass
Faber & Faber £7.99, pp280
Buy it at BOL

Germany's century - in the form of 100 short stories - could not fail to be interesting and Grass is evidently the best writer for such a task, having begun his career with a classic, an allegory of Germany's history. This is the century of war authors Remarque and Junger, a fictitious creation by Conan Doyle and the woman who gave her name to the Big Bertha Mortar.

There is an extraordinary variety of styles, and historical events are neatly interrelated (Kristallnacht is poignantly recounted on its anniversary, the night the Wall fell), but Grass alienates the reader by mostly writing in the first person; inadvisable when the narrator changes every three pages.

Some of these windows to the past may be misted, but overall this is the work of a master, Germany his favourite subject.

webTitle: Children's choice: Where are you Robert?

fields.headline: Children's choice
fields.trailText: Robert takes an admirably philosophical attitude to his time-travelling adventures
fields.body:
Where are you Robert?
Hans Magnus Enzensberger
(translated by Anthea Bell)
Hamish Hamilton £14.99, pp252
Buy it at BOL

Robert is 14 and has trouble with his eyes. His mother thinks he's watching too much TV and playing too many computer games. But Robert is 'seeing things'. Images roll in front of his eyes. But: 'Robert is no fool. He takes good care not to let on about his own private film show.' The moving pictures get more and more real until one evening, left alone in the house by his mother, he steps into one and finds himself in Russia in 1956.

This is only the beginning of a series of adventures that take him further and further back in time. Robert takes an admirably philosophical attitude to these strange happenings, which include being thrown into a Russian cell, meeting his grandmother as a little girl and becoming a member of a robber band.

He's even fairly sanguine about which part of the world he might be in: 'He knew by now the past was the strangest of all countries.'

Enzensberger's novel is a bestseller on the Continent and it is hardly surprising.

Enzensberger's novel is a bestseller on the Continent and it is hardly surprising.

webTitle: In Siberia by Colin Thubron read by John Rowe

fields.headline: In Siberia by Colin Thubron read by John Rowe
fields.trailText: Listening to Thubron's account of his extensive travels in Siberia in 1997 is a different experience from reading his book
fields.body:
In Siberia
Colin Thubron
read by John Rowe
2hrs 15mins
BBC Radio 4 Books £8.99

Listening to Thubron's account of his extensive travels in Siberia in 1997 is a different experience from reading his book. John Rowe's deft pauses and the subtle veneration in his intonation invest the country with the aura of a classic Russian novel. The music which ends each episode is haunting and romantic, emphasising an interpretation of Siberia as an unreal land of mystery and fearful beauty, which is only part of Thubron's response to it.

Lake Baikal certainly has its mysteries, with its 2,000 species of life - including the translucent fish you can read a book through - and its mile-and-a-half depths, frozen over in winter, which can suddenly open up an 18-mile crack to swallow beyond retrieval whatever vehicles are travelling over it.

The horrors of the past are unrelenting, but today stout babushkas strip off to bathe in the waters newly blessed by the Bishop of Omsk. Survivors remind Thubron that there was sometimes laughter even in the gulags. The bleakest of Thubron's experiences are not included here, however. Thus at Potalovo, a reindeer farming community poisoned by acid rain, Thubron found the blighted children drunk on vodka and American machine oil. But still, one of the finest audiobooks of the year.

webTitle: Observer review: The Middle Kingdom by Andrea Barrett

fields.headline: She's a poor judge of men - until the Chinese doctor's son shows up
fields.standfirst: The divide between Andrea Barrett's style and her neurotic subject makes The Middle Kingdom a fascinating read
fields.trailText: The divide between Andrea Barrett's style and her neurotic subject makes The Middle Kingdom a fascinating read
fields.body:
The Middle Kingdom
Andrea Barrett
Flamingo £9.99, pp281
Buy it at BOL

Grace is not a suitable name for Andrea Barrett's heroine. She is out of control: her body is her enemy. She has Rapunzel-like hair but balloons beneath it. She is a dedicated eater: she scoops peanut butter out of jars, rams dark chocolate into her mouth, binges in clandestine protest, in an attempt to subdue the dissatisfactions of her life.

The fascination of this absorbing novel - Barrett's fifth - is partly in the contrast between her competent style and neurotic subject. The prose is sensible, possessed, sane, while Grace herself is given to fainting, fever and rebellion. She is barely contained by the narrative in which she finds herself.

Grace is more at home in China than in her native America. She can give herself the slip, release herself from the captivity of an unhappy marriage and from the trap of her flesh (in China, her Rubenesque contours are admired).

The novel begins in Tiananmen Square, a stagy start that reads like a second-hand news story. But the initial suspicion that Barrett may be overreliant on historical excitement and unable to contribute anything fresh of her own is overthrown once Tiananmen Square is left behind. She looks at China with clear-eyed sympathy before taking us back to America, her homeground, in a prolonged and unusual flashback.

Grace has a disastrous eye for husbands. Her first, Randy, is a psychotic artist and their marriage ends in a scene that will not yield quietly to paraphrase. Randy insists that they paint in the nude and cover a single mighty canvas in green paint. The scene is at once funny and frightening - a convincingly insane combination. Grace's second husband, Walter, is expertly drawn. He is more in love with his work than anything else (he is a celebrated scientist); even his nightmares are academic. He is so dry he could almost be dead.

Barrett's dryness is of a more vital kind. She sees Grace with wry perception and irony; describing a balance between self-knowledge with self-disgust. She shows that it is possible to be foolish and wise, vulnerable and courageous. Grace never says more than she has to - she expresses herself with damning economy. And she has a wildness and intelligence that will upstage all her intimates in the end.

When in China, Grace would like to do as the Chinese do. She gives her husband (Walter is in China for a conference he has helped to organise) the slip and daringly goes to have dinner with Dr Yu, who has been attending the conference. This is the start of a mutinous erotic adventure, as she finds herself transfixed by the beauty of Dr Yu's son. (She reacts with a rather weird image: 'In that tiny, shabby room, he stood out like a rhododendron.') The taxi ride they share at night is a mesmerising account of journeying into the unknown, of losing yourself - in a literal way (the Chinese cabbie does not know where he is going; he breaks down) and in a metaphorical, sexual way (as Grace opportunistically surrenders to her desire). All of China to Grace resembles a forbidden city; no wonder she finds her forbidden fruit so fast.

Barrett must have had extensive experience of China herself - her novel reads like a memoir at times. The portrait of Dr Yu and her tribulations is sensitive and fascinating. And the book enshrines some Chinese thoughts, offered to the reader like small gifts. Dr Yu's husband explains to Grace his tactic for remembering what mattered to him during the Cultural Revolution. He turned his mind, he says, into a memory palace furnishing it gradually.

I'd want to find a place for this novel somewhere on my palace bookshelf.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: The Last Laugh

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: You might be forgiven for thinking that comedy has lost its potential to subvert in Britain - Index on Censorship reveals that it is still alive and kicking elsewhere
fields.body:
Index on Censorship: The Last Laugh
£8.99, pp193

You might be forgiven for thinking that comedy has lost its potential to subvert in Britain. Comedians who once lampooned Thatcher are selling out to the Murdoch networks or shackling themselves to Tory peers. A self-congratulating government hires comedy writers to pen its speeches, and, if the great Tom Lehrer had not pronounced satire dead when Kissinger won the Nobel Peace Prize, someone else would have had to in the wake of the current presidential fiasco.

Elsewhere, comedy is still a potent weapon, as the current issue of Index on Censorship demonstrates. If you're Colombian or Palestinian, satirising the wrong people can get you shot, as the respective pieces here by Fabio Castillo and Mark Nesbit explain.

Psychoanalyst Adam Phillips suggests, in his interview with Index editor Ursula Owen, that 'humour is the last thing before violence. It would be optimistic to say that all you've got to do is laugh and the regime comes tumbling down, but it would be equally naïve to assume that humour has no power'.

Two of the most interesting essays here are about a more insidious form of censorship, perpetrated in the name of political correctness. US comic Bill Hicks became the first comedian to be censored on the David Letterman show, for a few relatively innocent digs at Christians, pro-Lifers and lesbians. Hicks discovered that CBS was screening pro-Life commercials in the breaks during the Letterman Show. New Yorker journalist John Lahr picked up his story and exposed it.

The second piece is by US comic Scott Capurro, whose Edinburgh show this year had audience members walking out in disgust at his very near-the-knuckle Holocaust material. This bears out an earlier assertion that the point, if not the explanation of humour is that nothing, and no one, is sacred.

webTitle: Observer review: Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams by Mark Ford

fields.headline: Poet, maniac - and caravan designer
fields.standfirst: Mark Ford strikes an impeccable balance between the life and work of the poet Raymond Roussel
fields.trailText: Mark Ford strikes an impeccable balance between the life and work of the poet Raymond Roussel
fields.body:
Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams
Mark Ford
Faber £20, pp303
Buy it at BOL

Leafing through your Sunday paper in Paris in 1897, you would have come across 'Mon âme' , a poem by the 17-year-old Raymond Roussel which, so the byline ran, clearly signalled 'the sort of promise his precocious and fecund genius holds for the future'.

'Mon âme est une étrange usine,' Roussel begins: 'My soul is a strange factory - a huge mine - A multitude of workers grimace/As they extract from this fiery pit/Rhymes flying like masses of sparks.'

By day the poet is a captain of industry, worshipped by his workers and the flocking crowds of devotees although he cannot bear to look at them. By night, however, the tables turn nightmarishly: now at the furnace's mercy, Roussel is forced to conjure up discordant images and write interminable works which no one understands - 'Complaining that no one realises/The infinite is in my least verse'. Only in the final eight quatrains is order restored: by prodigious work, the poet reasserts control over his imagination, flames flare up as a fresh shift of workers produces verses and 'At this explosion deriving/From my universal genius/I see the world bow/ Before this name: Raymond Roussel.'

What is extraordinary about this poem is how uncannily it predicted Roussel's career and life, in all but one crucial respect. Two years after it was written, 'Mon âme' became a sober description of his mental state. For six months he was gripped by 'an extraordinarily intense sensation of universal glory' as, barely sleeping or eating, he wrote a 5,600-line poem. This period featured in a study of displaced forms of religious mania written by his psychologist, Pierre Janet. 'Whatever I wrote was surrounded by rays of light; I used to close the curtains, for I was afraid the shining rays emanating from my pen might escape into the outside world through even the smallest chink'. There could be no doubt that this poem would secure him the fame of his heroes Jules Verne, Victor Hugo and Pierre Loti.

Strikingly enough, 'La Doublure', the poem in question, is, as Mark Ford says, a story of mundane disappointment and obscurity which gives no sign of having been written with 'a thousand flaming pen nibs'. The understudy of the title fails on stage and in love, and two-thirds of the poem is given over to minutely detailed descriptions of the revellers at Nice Carnival. It received two reviews - 'more or less unintelligible', 'very boring'. Roussel collapsed.

His night of the soul lasted 10 years. He wrote interminable poems - the 20,000-line, unfinished 'Les Noces', for instance, page after page describing soap bubbles blown by a child on a café terrace - as he struggled to discover the compositional method, procédé, which would allow him to recover la gloire.

Essentially based on puns, the procédé is a way of playing with language to make it generate his increasingly fairytale works. He would break down a random sentence - 'Napoleon premier empereur', for instance - into assonantally related words. The result - nappe ollé ombre miettes (tablecloth, olé, shadow, crumbs) - would give him the image of castanet-clicking flamenco dancers on a heavily leaden table. With his love of illusion, he cast this as a tableau wrought by a sculptor capable of shaping water into momentary reliefs. Et voilà. A liquid drawing so detailed one can discern the shadows cast by the breadcrumbs on the tablecloth.

Or he would take two almost identical sentences, in which each word has two, unrelated meanings, and extract the beginning of a story - a cryptogram on a billiard table in a country house - and its end - a group of Europeans held hostage in an African kingdom. All that was left was to write it.

By 30, feeling he had achieved the required 'sensations of art', he embarked on the novel Impressions d'Afrique. This reveals an extraordinary world which he elaborated for the rest of his life, suspended, as Cocteau said, 'from elegance, fairyland and fear' and full of inventors, virtuosi and miraculous inventions. A worm, for instance, in a trough full of a strange water as heavy as mercury with a narrow slit in its base, suspended above a zither. Trained by a Hungarian musician, the worm arches its body to regulate the flow of drops on to the zither and thus plays wondrously complex rhapsodies and waltzes with 'a savagely dramatic range of expression'. Entering his flood of stories is, as André Gide said, like being swept up in a Gulf Stream of the imagination.

What 'Mon âme' failed to see, however, is to whom such an experience would appeal. Roussel couldn't stand psychology and since his works start and end with language, they have a uniquely strange, distant quality, like 'a complicated set of tools whose use cannot be discovered', as John Ashbery puts it. Yet still Roussel all but bankrupted himself publishing, advertising, serialising and staging his work. His books barely sold. Performances became pitched battles between Surrealists and their opponents who bombarded the stage with coins and baked apples. And he could never understand why.

Born in the same circumstances as Proust, Roussel lived an equally insulated life. He never wore clothes more than a certain number of times - collars once. He worked furiously, writing in a vacuum-sealed room in his vast villa or as he travelled endlessly round the world by ship without ever looking out of his cabin. It seems that, rather as Percy Grainger may be said to have been the inventor of the tracksuit, Roussel's impact on mass culture may have lain in tourism, rather than literature. When he became phobic to luggage, he devised a luxury caravan which became the talk of the motor shows. The total lack of consolations in his lonely life led him to commit suicide in 1933.

As he has reached near-canonical status in France, people have tended to dwell on the life more than the work. But in this wonderful, first full-length account in English, the poet Ford has struck an impeccable balance. Roussel emerges as a luminous, unique figure, 'outrageous in his innocence and logic'. Reading this book, one understands why Breton said that he, along with Lautréamont, is 'the greatest hypnotist of modern times.'

webTitle: Observer review: Travels Without my Aunt by Julia Llewellyn Smith

fields.headline: The rough guide to Greene lands
fields.standfirst: From Brighton to Haiti, Julia Llewellyn Smith follows in some giant footsteps and makes her own impression in Travels Without my Aunt
fields.trailText: From Brighton to Haiti, Julia Llewellyn Smith follows in some giant footsteps and makes her own impression in Travels Without my Aunt
fields.body:
Travels Without my Aunt
Julia Llewellyn Smith
Joseph £16.99, pp304
Buy it at BOL

At first Julia Llewellyn Smith proclaims herself 'a determined virgin'. Then, 125 pages later, she is tempted, as was Garbo in Ninotchka, by a chic garment - except that when duly accoutred, she 'looked in the mirror. I looked like I had just been placed last in a wet T-shirt contest'. Such a transformation might appear the very essence of the unchaperoned title of her worldwide odyssey.

It has the sub-title, 'in the footsteps of Graham Greene': her spurious virtue was a means of fending off the Mexican bell-hop who showed her to a room some 60 years after Greene had taken those lawless roads. As for the T-shirt, few can resist Saigon's regained allure.

To follow some of Greene's many trails is a neat notion that suggests a publisher with lavish resources. The novelist's restless nature made him so often at home in territory around the world which he duly rendered in finely-honed prose as vibrantly on the edge.

Decades later this evocative sense of places draws visitors whose fervent hope it is that things have not improved. A prologue finds her in Brighton, with a potato and tuna at the Cricketers', where she notes that Greene's character, the gangster Colleoni, holed up in a version of the Bedford Hotel. 'It had burned down in 1964.'

That should be 'was burned', for it was a notorious case of arson, in which a waiter died, and which, as Greene said, was never properly investigated. The offence was compounded by the hotel's replacement with a grey hulk now trading as a Hilton. Some might say that she now had no reason to leave the town; rather than linger in the Lanes, she could seek out resurgent gangsters, hucksters, violent death, corruption and sharp practice a few hundred yards away; all this can make Mexico, Saigon, Haiti and Paraguay, if not Berkhamsted and Sierra Leone, appear havens.

'Footsteps' often prove a desperate, slippery course. Few, for example, are as adroit as Johnson and Boswell when it comes to the Western Isles, and - despite an introductory reference to a certain misanthropy - Smith, variously accompanied, does not pretend to any of those solitary obsessions, which were the obverse of Greene's great conviviality. Not for him a world in which CNN is as much a part of every hotel room as a kettle and teabags.

With palpable cool, she chronicles an overlapping past and present - whether the bloody enforced amputations in Sierra Leone or the little-reported killings in Mexico, such horrors underpinned by an eye for the comic. The word 'topes' appears on a road sign but not on the map; it turns out to be Spanish for sleeping policeman, 'a Mexican obsession. They punctuated every highway in the land and were responsible for the extraordinary number of Beetles in circulation lacking a front bumper'.

One had not realised that more than 60 per cent of Vietnam's population was born after 1975. 'It is a rule of air travel that the grottier your destination, the better the service' - as if the airline is compensating for the staple goat's-shin stew which lies ahead.

Nobody except Smith has said of Cuban couture that 'this is the only country in the world where the question, does my bum look big in this? demands the answer yes'. Speak to anybody and talk is soon of the eruption, invasion, or both, which will come with Castro's death.

Perhaps the oddest moment is in arid Haiti, where, outside a Holiday Inn, a guy whispers a surreal litany in her ear, 'Hey lady, do you want voodoo? A sunny beach? A boyfriend? A girlfriend? Are you English? Do you know Maggie O'Kane from the London Guardian?'

She describes him as having 'pencil-point pupils, jerky limbs, the anxious expression of a Haitian and the accent of a taxi driver from the Bronx'. Such descriptions, unlike Norman Sherry's lumbering travelogue, are in the spirit of Greene who always insisted that his were not fanciful tropes but a product of careful observation.

He is an intermittent presence - perhaps most effectively caught in Paraguay - and one hopes that this book, apparently written instead of one mentioned in passing, will lead to something unshackled by so strong a presence.

When the real Julia Llewellyn Smith steps forward, she will not be wearing the T-shirt. 'There was no way I could ever be seen in public in this garment.'

Decades later this evocative sense of places draws visitors whose fervent hope it is that things have not improved. A prologue finds her in Brighton, with a potato and tuna at the Cricketers', where she notes that Greene's character, the gangster Colleoni, holed up in a version of the Bedford Hotel. 'It had burned down in 1964.' That should be 'was burned', for it was a notorious case of arson, in which a waiter died, and which, as Greene said, was never properly investigated. The offence was compounded by the hotel's replacement with a grey hulk now trading as a Hilton. Some might say that she now had no reason to leave the town; rather than linger in the Lanes, she could seek out resurgent gangsters, hucksters, violent death, corruption and sharp practice a few hundred yards away; all this can make Mexico, Saigon, Haiti and Paraguay, if not Berkhamsted and Sierra Leone, appear havens. 'Footsteps' often prove a desperate, slippery course. Few, for example, are as adroit as Johnson and Boswell when it comes to the Western Isles, and - despite an introductory reference to a certain misanthropy - Smith, variously accompanied, does not pretend to any of those solitary obsessions, which were the obverse of Greene's great conviviality. Not for him a world in which CNN is as much a part of every hotel room as a kettle and teabags. With palpable cool, she chronicles an overlapping past and present - whether the bloody enforced amputations in Sierra Leone or the little-reported killings in Mexico, such horrors underpinned by an eye for the comic. The word 'topes' appears on a road sign but not on the map; it turns out to be Spanish for sleeping policeman, 'a Mexican obsession. They punctuated every highway in the land and were responsible for the extraordinary number of Beetles in circulation lacking a front bumper'. One had not realised that more than 60 per cent of Vietnam's population was born after 1975. 'It is a rule of air travel that the grottier your destination, the better the service' - as if the airline is compensating for the staple goat's-shin stew which lies ahead. Nobody except Smith has said of Cuban couture that 'this is the only country in the world where the question, does my bum look big in this? demands the answer yes'. Speak to anybody and talk is soon of the eruption, invasion, or both, which will come with Castro's death. Perhaps the oddest moment is in arid Haiti, where, outside a Holiday Inn, a guy whispers a surreal litany in her ear, 'Hey lady, do you want voodoo? A sunny beach? A boyfriend? A girlfriend? Are you English? Do you know Maggie O'Kane from the London Guardian?' She describes him as having 'pencil-point pupils, jerky limbs, the anxious expression of a Haitian and the accent of a taxi driver from the Bronx'. Such descriptions, unlike Norman Sherry's lumbering travelogue, are in the spirit of Greene who always insisted that his were not fanciful tropes but a product of careful observation. He is an intermittent presence - perhaps most effectively caught in Paraguay - and one hopes that this book, apparently written instead of one mentioned in passing, will lead to something unshackled by so strong a presence. When the real Julia Llewellyn Smith steps forward, she will not be wearing the T-shirt. 'There was no way I could ever be seen in public in this garment.'

webTitle: Observer review: The Doctors of Revolution by Shlomo Barer

fields.headline: Movers and shapers
fields.standfirst: Shlomo Barer's cultural history of the 19th century, The Doctors of Revolution, reads like a novel
fields.trailText: Shlomo Barer's cultural history of the 19th century, The Doctors of Revolution, reads like a novel
fields.body:
The Doctors of Revolution: Nineteenth-Century Thinkers who Changed the World
Shlomo Barer
Thames & Hudson £29.95, pp1216
Buy it at BOL

Psychobiography is currently the height of literary fashion. Professional biographers have become more and more efficient at providing exhaustive accounts of the inner crises that inflect the daily life of famous individuals, and less and less effective at offering coherent historical narratives of the times from which they emerge. Biography is the historiographical expression of a culture that fetishises personality. It's history lite.

The Doctors of Revolution, by the Israeli writer Shlomo Barer, is scarcely adulterated or dilute. It's the real thing, or so it seems: a collective biography that, as the sleeve-notes tell us, is also 'history in the grand style'. In his acknowledgments, Barer rather blokeishly refers to his hope 'to bring to life in authentic detail a bunch of unusually controversial characters'. But this is a far more ambitious book than that.

Covering the period between 1796 and the aftermath of 1848, it traces the lives of a group of philosophers and poets who, with Promethean impudence, set out to change the world as well as merely to interpret it. The biographies of Marx, Heine, the anarchist Bakunin, and at least 50 other lesser figures are unfurled by Barer in a fascinating narrative of the social and cultural history in which modernity itself was defined.

The first half of the nineteenth century was a period in which European culture was capillarised with a sense of political optimism. On the margins of bourgeois society, confederations of exiles congregated to argue in crowded cafés or the smoke-filled offices of literary journals. With the pace of industrial capitalism accelerating, their blueprints for a better society suddenly seemed practicable.

Barer is superb at communicating the intellectual passion of this period. He is also a skilful storyteller, who carefully ties the overarching narrative of war and revolution to the activities of influential individuals.

The book often reads like a historical novel, as Barer focuses on the psychological and even physical quirks of his leading characters, before panning out to sweep across the European political landscape.

webTitle: Observer review: Ehud's Dagger by James Holstun

fields.headline: The killer, a king and his lover
fields.standfirst: The bit players of the English Civil War are brought to life and then buried in Marxist rhetoric in Ehud's Dagger by James Holstun
fields.trailText: The bit players of the English Civil War are brought to life and then buried in Marxist rhetoric in Ehud's Dagger by James Holstun
fields.body:
Ehud's Dagger: Class Struggle and the English Revolution
James Holstun
Verso £25, pp460
Buy it at BOL

On the morning of Saturday, 23 August 1628, Charles I's favourite, the Duke of Buckingham, was assassinated at Portsmouth as he pushed through a crowd of soldiers and well-wishers on his way to a rendezvous with the king. Buckingham was widely hated for his Catholic sympathies and his flagrant manipulation to his own ends of the Stuart patronage and subsidies system - the more so in view of his perceived Svengali-like influence over the king.

Contemporary ballads openly accused the two of them of sodomy (though the perpetrators of such 'libels' were invariably arrested and imprisoned). The king was devastated by Buckingham's death while the general public openly rejoiced at the end of a malign influence over their monarch.

John Felton, the man who fatally stabbed Buckingham in the chest with a ten-penny knife, was a professional soldier from a respectable, strongly Protestant family which had fallen on hard times. Buckingham owed him £80 in back pay and had apparently denied him promotion. Arrested without a struggle at the scene of the crime - 'I am the man! Here I am!' he is supposed to have cried - Felton was tried for murder and hanged in November. His body was displayed on a public gibbet until it rotted. The event is seen as a turning point, a wake-up call to the king presaging the forthcoming civil wars.

Buckingham's assassination has been described ever since as the deranged act of a loner with a grievance against his victim. Felton's behaviour, however, suggests more control and calm premeditation. In July he had borrowed a copy of a formal complaint lodged by the House of Commons against Buckingham for his Popish sympathies, and for the way he was conducting hostilities with France. Having read it, Felton fasted and prayed for two months, then, on 18 August, resolved to kill Buckingham.

He borrowed money from his mother, purchased a dagger, and sewed a paper inside his hat stating that he was acting 'for the honour of his God, his king and his country'. Before setting out for Portsmouth he asked a local London church to say prayers for him the following Sunday. Afterwards he was calm and coherent; he conducted himself with dignity during his trial and while awaiting execution.

In Ehud's Dagger, James Holstun re-examines Felton's story, and those of a sequence of other non-élite individuals and groups who changed the course of history around the time of the so-called English Revolution. He argues that a coherent story can be told 'from below' of the events which led up to the execution of Charles I and the establishing, first of an English Commonwealth, and then of the Protectorate under Oliver Cromwell. According to Holstun, Felton, the visionary Anna Trapnell and the would-be assassin of Cromwell, Edward Sexby, were all motivated in part by immediate, personal contingencies and in part by arguments and attitudes held in common with the generality of their community - what Holstun anachronistically calls their 'class'.

According to Holstun, Felton's mixed motivation - part private grievance, part sincerely held belief in his victim's pernicious influence upon the whole nation - produced a series of decisions which culminated in a consciously executed revolutionary act.

'Felton complexly fused his personal and public motives: as a gentleman forced into military service, then subject to labour without pay and the humiliation of a public rebuff, he generalised the injury to his status and his stomach as an injury to the nation, and undertook a project that he thought would heal both at once.'

Holstun wants to make a collection of seventeenth-century malcontents into the true heroes of the English Revolution. Exploiting the rich work which has been done on contextualising the English Revolution over the past 20 years, in both history and criticism (specifically new historicist criticism), he sets out to retrieve an unashamedly Marxist story of victorious proletariats, and the overthrow of protocapitalist élites. Indeed, he spends almost half the book on a detailed appraisal of the work of the major scholars in the field of the past two decades - expending an enormous amount of verbal effort on winnowing the grain from the chaff, and ending up with a rather meagre kernel of what he regards as usable methodology.

Holstun is charmingly open about the fact that such a turning back towards a Marxist account of this period of English history smacks of nostalgia. He is engaged, he says, on a radical project. 'By radical project, I mean praxis organised in a collective effort to totalise society by changing it from an oppressive inhuman thing controlling people from without, to a human process that people control for themselves in a relatively democratic way. That's at best a down payment on an argument, at worst a musty exercise in romantic anticapitalism. Even I feel a little awkward writing this way.'

If Holstun feels awkward, so, I fear, does his reader. Holstun's accounts of his working people's lives and actions are vivid and compelling. Sadly, whenever he arrives at the point of serious analysis, the creaky Marxist categories arrest his fluency, and bog down fascinating evidence in a mire of jargon.

John Felton and Anna Trapnell, Holstun shows us convincingly, did understand what they were undertaking. They acted strategically. Trapnell's swoons and prophetic trances enabled her to continue to speak out at moments when decorum and political exigency threatened to silence her. The soldiers of the New Model Army knowingly manipulated a language of group responsibility and no named leaders to thwart the efforts of senior officers to head off their radical initiatives.

Holstun cannot establish whether any of his maverick agents of history could see the larger picture, or had a clear idea of what kind of crisis their actions might precipitate. The explanatory framework he chooses hampers his best efforts. Ehud's Dagger brings the events of the Civil War period and ordinary people who made them to life. But the failure of its painstakingly justified approach is one more piece of telling evidence that Marxist historiography and criticism have had their day.

webTitle: Observer review: Collins Encyclopedia of Scotland and Scotland - The Story of a Nation

fields.headline: Picts and stones
fields.standfirst: Magnus Magnusson weaves a new narrative out of cutting edge Scotland's history, while Collins produces an attractive new edition of the Keays' encyclopedia
fields.trailText: Magnus Magnusson weaves a new narrative out of cutting edge Scotland's history, while Collins produces an attractive new edition of the Keays' encyclopedia
fields.body:
Scotland: The Story of a Nation
Magnus Magnusson
Harpercollins £19.99, pp752
Buy it at BOL

Collins Encyclopedia of Scotland: The Story of a Nation
edited by John & Julia Keay
Harpercollins £45, pp1120

A historian after past events is like Vladimir Nabokov butterfly-hunting: he has to find the creatures first, and then get them to keep still to be identified. Here Magnus Magnusson has unfair advantages. He has just finished a radio series about new Scottish historians; as a lot of them are red-hot revisionists, this leaves him right at the cutting edge of new interpretations. And he was for eight years chair of the old Ancient Monuments Board. So he knows where the relics of the past are, and what they look like. Few other Scots do; the land is small, yet full of remoteness.

The outcome is an unusual book. It is a very readable, traditional history told as a tale from its beginnings up to now. It perfectly replaces dear old 'Scotland's Story' with its gory, sob-inducing pictures of dying heroes, offering instead hundreds of well-chosen photographs and reproductions.

Magnusson introduces new ideas. Maybe the Scots never sailed to Argyll from northern Ireland in the sixth century, but were already there. Maybe Edward I of England was not just a brutal invader, but a king with a noble vision. Maybe the Forty-Five was not a Highland lost cause, but a European near-miss. (All the same, giving the Rising 52 pages is too much.)

This is a narrative, consciously alluding to Walter Scott's Tales of a Grandfather. Magnusson points out why Scott (the Tory patriot) blotted out some crucial episodes: the uncomfortably democratic Declaration of Arbroath, for instance. But Scotland is not a 'critical text' aimed at unmasking history as propaganda, which means that the mandarins will never choose it as a school book. A pity, because Magnusson is too optimistic about the teaching of Scottish history in schools, which remains - in my view - this emergent nation's disaster area.

A new edition of Keay, the lively tome first produced in 1994 by John and Julia, is good news. There are something like 1,000 additions and more than 100 new entries. It runs from Aaron Scotus (d.1052) Music Theorist through 1,100 pages to Zetland.

Glints of humour and temper recur. My favourite is Tartan, where you get two entries for the price of one, mutually incompatible and insulting each other's assumptions. Witty as the book is, and succulent as are its pre-1914 photographs, its history is much more conservative than Magnusson's. It's time to stop calling the Picts 'mysterious', for instance. And surely nobody still seriously thinks, after the Stone of Scone conference in 1998, that the Stone was used for royal inaugurations in Dalriada.

The entry for Clearances is oddly grudging. What does it mean to say that 'population figures contradict the notion that clearance boosted emigration'? And one technical complaint: the system of cross-references and parent references isn't always carried through. (Where is the mighty bleach and chemical industry at St Rollox, for example?)

These are small criticisms. In general, this encyclopaedia is so attractive that a reader setting out towards one item will almost certainly be hijacked by another along the alphabetical way. The assessments of Scottish painters and literati are especially good and opinionated. But on the way to Clerk, Sir John I fell into Chirnside, Berwickshire and learnt that the old Rock House there 'in 1917... suffered a near-miss by a bomb from a passing Zeppelin'. Well, jings!

webTitle: Observer review: The Quarrel of the Age by AC Grayling

fields.headline: Just call him an old Romantic
fields.standfirst: William Hazlitt liked things with 'gusto'. Would AC Grayling's story of his life and times, The Quarrel of the Age, have come up to scratch?
fields.trailText: William Hazlitt liked things with 'gusto'. Would AC Grayling's story of his life and times, The Quarrel of the Age, have come up to scratch?
fields.body:
The Quarrel of the Age: the Life and Times of William Hazlitt
AC Grayling
Weidenfeld and Nicholson £25, pp399
Buy it at BOL

'I wish people made larger paper,' wrote William Hazlitt at 12. Even in childhood there seemed too many thoughts for his page, before he became one of the most astonishing writers of the Romantic age. Bare-knuckled controversialist, plangent lonely heart, impassioned theatre and art critic, he reinvented journalism and the essay. His favourite quality in art was 'gusto', which animates his own prose.

AC Grayling (philosopher and broadsheet regular) is drawn to the critic-metaphysician, but forbearingly shunts philosophical discussion to the appendices of his measured biography. Hazlitt's unflinching directness helps Grayling keep emotion close to the surface. His most personal writing was his most public, full of fire and grudge, and his published work was his most confessional.

Coleridge told Hazlitt that he had guts in his brains. A dissenting childhood and education encouraged uncomfortably independent thought, which remained a touchstone whether in impassioned response to Edmund Kean's magnetic acting, which made his reputation as a critic, or in his unpopular lifelong advocacy of Napoleon. He became a star hack, but could not long toe the party line for any publication.

'I have never given the lie to my own soul,' claimed his last published essay: Hazlitt 'set out in life with the French Revolution' and clasped his principles close. He had an unforgiving eye for backsliders like Wordsworth and Coleridge, whom he had trudged 10 muddy miles to hear as a youth, but who later disappointed ('Alas! Frailty, thy name is Genius!'). His attacks on the poets were cruelly supported by close reading, though generous about their best work. In turn, Grayling amusingly tracks their elaborate tittle-tattle, slinging more dirt with each repetition.

A friend said he had never known Hazlitt out of love, but although he married two spirited women, he never achieved the relationship he idealised. Unusually sexually savvy in print - he caused outrage by insisting that Desdemona married Othello because she fancied him rotten - he yearned for a romantic, erotic and intellectual partnership. Too much reading, probably.

webTitle: This is where I came in...

fields.headline: This is where I came in...
fields.standfirst: Pattie Hearst gets kidnapped again as maverick director John Waters assaults Hollywood in a movie that mixes farce and Godard
fields.trailText: Philip French: It's a film to be discussed rather than enjoyed
fields.body:
Some acts are so extreme it's difficult to know what to do for an encore. For instance, what could John Waters do in 1972 after Divine (the obese transvestite who appeared in most Waters films until his/her premature death in 1989) eats a genuine dog turd at the end of Pink Flamingos ?

Well, he could go on affronting the comfortable bourgeoisie of Baltimore that had nurtured him, and this he proceeded to do for the next 25 years, mocking middle-class aspirations and family values, celebrating the vulgarity of trailer-park trash. He revelled in the sobriquet of 'Sultan of Trash' and called Pink Flamingos 'the most disgusting film of all time'.

All this, in a world of celebrity worship where show business permeates every facet of society, inevitably leads to him coming to be regarded as a national treasure. Before Waters had turned 40, the mayor of Baltimore had declared 7 February 1985 'John Waters Day' (though let's remember that to mark the opening of Nightmare on Elm Street VI, the mayor of Los Angeles named one Friday the thirteenth in 1991 Freddy Krueger Day).

Now Waters is in his mid-fifties, and over the past dozen years critics have written of his 'mellowing', though he hasn't entered a phase that could be termed mature. He occasionally works with actors on their way up (Johnny Depp, for example) and frequently with those on the way down (Sonny Bono, Troy Donohue, Pia Zadora, Kathleen Turner), but while his movies have become more polished, he's never left the independent sector or moved out of Baltimore.

However, while he's been bathing in public esteem, his dirty clothes have been stolen from the riverbank by young Hollywood filmmakers like the Farrelly Brothers, in whose sticky fingers his camp art-house outrages have become the staple of mainstream cinema.

Like Andy Warhol and Russ Meyer, both of whom influenced him, Waters has always had a love-hate relationship with the movie industry, his films relating to the star system and Hollywood values, if usually in a parodic or dialectical form. Asked once how he'd like to be be reincarnated, he said: 'As a mirror in a Douglas Sirk movie.'

Now at last in Cecil B. Demented he has turned on Tinseltown itself with a hysterical comic assault that, though a good deal inferior to his better pictures, throws some light on his current frustrations.

The film's title is the nom de guerre of an independent filmmaker (played by Stephen Dorff), head of an underground collective in Baltimore who kidnap a declining Hollywood star, Holly Whitlock (Melanie Griffith), who is in town for the premiere of her latest picture, 'Some Kind of Happiness'.

The Sprocket Holes, as the subversive group call themselves, intend to give her a makeover and redeem her career in an anti-Hollywood epic of their own devising. After the mayhem at the cinema where they take her prisoner, they stage a violent demonstration at a meeting of the Maryland Film Commission, which is trying to lure big-budget productions to Baltimore, and they break up the shooting of a sequel to Forrest Gump , killing several people, including members of the Teamsters' Union.

They've sworn to remain celibate until the last shot is in the can and the movie concludes in an apocalyptic orgy of polymorphously perverse sex-and-violence as the moviemakers shoot it out with the cops.

The most obvious influence on this wild and wilful picture is Jean-Luc Godard, though the treatment is somewhat less fastidious. Cecil B. Demented is clearly a version of Waters himself, the visionary super-director working outside the system, and all of his followers have tattooed on their arms the name of a cult moviemaker who has defied or attempted to subvert Hollywood - Sam Peckinpah, Spike Lee, William Castle, Pedro Almodóvar, Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Hershell Gordon Lewis, Kenneth Anger, Samuel Fuller.

Also built into the film, and its most disturbingly playful aspect, is a parallel with one of the most controversial incidents of the counter-culture of Sixties, the kidnapping and brain-washing of Pattie Hearst by the Symbionese Liberation Army.

Pattie Hearst, who has been in three previous Waters pictures, here plays the mother of one of Demented's followers, and the experience of the Melanie Griffith character in this movie is history repeating itself as farce. Hearst must clearly have been a party to this, and the picture's climax sees a deranged Griffith walking through the TV cameras to be arrested, her words, 'I'm ready for my close-up, Mr Demented', a distorted echo of Norma Desmond's parting line in Sunset Boulevard . It's a film to be discussed rather than enjoyed.

webTitle: United to net bigger fortune

fields.headline: United to net bigger fortune
fields.trailText: Mega-rich Manchester United are set to soar into the financial stratosphere by charging their global army of fans to watch their team online.
fields.body:
Mega-rich Manchester United are set to soar into the financial stratosphere by charging their global army of fans to watch their team online.

United, already the world's richest club, could make hundreds of millions of pounds annually in extra income from the scheme within a few years. They plan to launch subscription services that would see millions of supporters worldwide paying to see goals, highlights and even full-length matches played at Old Trafford.

The key to United's move is the fact that from next season all 20 Premiership clubs will, for the first time, be allowed to show their home league matches anything from a few to 72 hours after the final whistle on their own television station or website.

Peter Kenyon, United's chief executive, said that the club were determined to exploit fully the massive commercial opportunity that these 'delayed transmission rights' represent.

'We have an estimated six million fans in Britain and another 20m worldwide. When we get the rights back, we will be able to exploit those [pictures] across all our platforms in different ways,' said Kenyon. 'Even come Tuesday or Wednesday, that's a valuable product for supporters to access.'

With TV and internet technology set to converge in the next few years, the likeliest way United will exploit their 'valuable product' is through a merger between their MUTV channel, which has few subscribers, and their website, manutd.com, which already gets 10m page impressions every month - 90 per cent of them from outside the UK.

Kenyon confirmed that United intend to get as many of their fans as possible visiting their website and, when technology makes it possible, United will make some offerings on it - perhaps goals packages, interviews with injured players in the treatment room or club press conferences - available only to those who pay. Even if only a few million of their 26m fans stumped up, and paid relatively small sums, United's income would soar.

Arsenal and Liverpool are both likely to follow United's lead, using the expertise of Granada Media, who have a stake in both clubs. Like United, both might expect to charge fans in Asia, Europe and America, as well as Britain. Kenyon denied that United's increased riches would turn the Premiership into a permanent one-horse race: 'We want to operate within a healthy league. We need [there to be] other strong teams. The idea that Manchester United is going to grab everything and do its own thing is a myth, because we would have nowhere to play.'

'Delayed transmission rights' may be the thin end of the wedge for Premiership clubs keen to make more money from British football's enduring popularity. In a foretaste of likely battles ahead, Kenyon admitted United would like to broadcast their live home games that other broadcasters do not already show live, possibly beginning in 2004, when a new broadcasting deal will start.

webTitle: New Wembley to 'lose 5,000 seats'

fields.headline: New Wembley to 'lose 5,000 seats'
fields.trailText: The new Wembley will have thousands fewer seats than planned because of the Football Association's decision to build a far cheaper, scaled-down stadium.
fields.body:
The new Wembley will have thousands fewer seats than planned because of the Football Association's decision to build a far cheaper, scaled-down stadium.

The capacity of the stadium will shrink from 90,000 to about 85,000 as part of the FA's drive to slash around £100million from the overall £660m cost.

Thousands of fans will now forever miss out on England games and FA Cup Finals at Wembley because of the disastrous bungling which has blighted every stage of the planned transformation of the national stadium.

The FA, who have belatedly taken control of the project from their Ken Bates-led subsidiary Wembley National Stadium Limited, have not decided whether there should be fewer seats for ordinary fans or corporate visitors.

FA bosses have decided to cut Wembley's capacity rather than reduce the size of seats and the amount of personal space - the most in the world for fans.

A WNSL insider said that removing several thousand seats could damage Wembley's future viability if that meant fewer places for executives paying large sums.

Observer Sport understands that the FA decided to take a hands-on role after bankers involved in the project said that their warnings - that a planned hotel-office complex at Wembley might generate no income - had been ignored.

Now the colourful Bates could face a challenge as chairman of WNSL at their board meeting tomorrow. Fellow directors accuse him and Wembley managing director Bob Stubbs of excluding them from key decisions about the revamp.

Meanwhile, in another blow to the beleaguered scheme, the man who was going to rebuild Wembley - and whose last job was building Stadium Australia in Sydney - has quit.

Ed Obiala, a senior manager with builders Multiplex, had already begun working on Wembley.

webTitle: Spurs throw it away again

fields.headline: Spurs throw it away again
fields.trailText: Bradford leave it late - again.
fields.body:
It is no coincidence that Bradford's fans have abandoned the five-minute dash to leave early since Jim Jeffries took over as manager as, for the third consecutive match since the Scotsman replaced Chris Hutchings, his side were involved in a dramatic finish.

At Middlesbrough they conceded a late goal which cost them victory, against Coventry the following week they came from behind to record a rare win and they completed the sequence here when Benito Carbone's spectacular 89th-minute volley rescued a point against Tottenham to take them off the bottom of the Premiership.

That looked an unlikely conclusion when Ledley King scored for the visitors after only 10 seconds, the fastest goal in the Premiership's history, and again when Chris Armstrong put them 3-1 up nine minutes into the second-half.

But, having come out of the blocks like an Olympic sprinter, Tottenham collapsed across the line like a Sunday jogger hitting the wall in the London Marathon. The fans will no doubt blame Tottenham's negativity under George Graham as they sat back, believing that all they needed to do was play out time for their first away league victory of the season. They paid an expensive price which will do little to ease the pressure on Graham or Alan Sugar, his chairman.

The match saw the reappearance of the popular Bantam Bird mascot after a local campaign to have him restored. But it was the Tottenham cockerel which crowed first. It was an unusual goal too.

Spurs kicked off but the referee made them retake it because Les Ferdinand had encroached into the Bradford half. From the restart the ball fell to King, who hit a shot from 25 yards which took a deflection off Jamie Lawrence and spun past Matt Clarke into the bottom corner of the net.

It provided an early wake-up call and within eight minutes Lawrence had restored the balance. Dean Windass hitting in a corner which the Bradford midfielder bundled past Neil Sullivan.

If the Spurs fans expected their team to capitulate at this point they were pleasantly surprised in the 21st minute. Having withstood some home pressure, they won a disputed corner which Stephen Clemence landed onto the head of Sol Campbell, who directed it past Clarke with a diving effort.

The Spurs support were transported back to a happier era with their side's third goal seven minutes after the break, which was in the old Tottenham tradition. Ferdinand cushioned a long ball from Sullivan and displayed wonderful awareness to slip the ball to Tim Sherwood. He responded with a pass back to Ferdinand, which dissected the home defence, allowing the former England striker to roll the ball into the path of Armstrong who tapped it home.

They should have known better than to start celebrating too early because in the 69th minute Bradford brought themselves back into it when Peter Atherton crossed for Windass to head home. Stan Collymore had a header ruled out for offside and Windass hit the post before Bradford drew level. Lee Sharpe's cross was headed back across the goal by Stuart McCall for Carbone to smash the ball home. It was little wonder that Jeffries praised his side's spirit.
