webTitle: Zola caps dire day for Derby

fields.headline: Zola caps dire day for Derby
fields.trailText: Zola caps dire day for Derby.
fields.body:
Four clean sheets in five games since Colin Todd returned to Derby had allowed dreams of defensive solidity. But their only consolation after a nightmare here that left them with the worst defensive record in the Premiership was that it could have been so much worse.

The continued excellence of Mart Poom in goal prevented Chelsea from at least doubling their winning margin. Twice in the first half he smothered the ball as Sam Dalla Bona raced through; twice he was fully extended by long-range shots from Dennis Wise and Rati Aleksidze. Rarely did Chelsea fail to cap a promising move with a shot on target, most notably when Celestine Babayaro's 19th-minute cross was headed wide by Eidur Gudjohnsen.

The Icelandic striker could be excused such profligacy, as by then he had already scored twice. After 10 minutes he kept his head while all around were losing theirs, interrupting a prolonged scramble with a fine sidefooted finish when fed by Babayaro. Six minutes later Taribo West, given an opportunity to clear Wise's flick, somehow allowed Gustavo Poyet to produce a low centre that Gudjohnsen slid in to prod home.

'He's got a lot of talent, and he's only young,' said Wise after a performance in which Chelsea's youth shone in all areas of the pitch, with Dalla Bona in midfield and John Terry in defence sharing the plaudits with Gudjohnsen.

'All our young lads played extremely well. It's nice to have youngsters playing because as you get older you can't play as often as you like.'

Eight minutes before half-time, Chelsea scored their third as Terry's immaculate 45-yard crossfield pass fell at Babayaro's feet on the left wing. The Nigerian's control was poor, but only sent the ball rolling to Gudjohnsen, who had time and space to find Poyet with a right-footed cross which was headed emphatically past Poom.

'We were just too passive, and I don't know why,' said Derby manager Jim Smith. 'The first goal should have been cleared with comfort, the second was schoolboy defending by West which really just summed the first half up, and for the third we had two men in the box and Poyet got a free header. They were all really amateur goals.'

To be fair, Derby were forced into changes after last week's impressive win at Ipswich, with Seth Johnson suspended and Georgi Kinkladze and Stefano Eranio victims of colds. Smith was forced to play the transfer-listed Lars Bohinen, whose last start had been in Derby's 4-0 defeat here in May.

He is unlikely to have been too pleased by the improvement. Chelsea were also hit by suspensions, with Frank Leboeuf and Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink ruled out, but any fears that the loss of their top scorer would see them lose their cutting edge were swiftly dispelled.

Eight minutes after half-time Gianfranco Zola capped another fine move with the fourth, lashing in a left-footed drive when fed by Dalla Bona. Chris Riggott's consolation, a free header from Lilian Martin's free-kick two minutes later, lent the scoreline a flattering sense of dignity for Derby, when in truth it should have shouted only humiliation.

'We're fine at home,' said Wise. 'We play very well at home. But we've got to sort something out away from home, because that's where things seem to be going wrong.'

A record of one defeat in 20 home games is certainly not what one would expect from a team sitting 11th in the league. But there is hope for Chelsea - next week they visit Middlesbrough.

webTitle: Robson calmed by his mentor

fields.headline: Robson calmed by his mentor
fields.standfirst: Amy Lawrence watches the changing of the guard at Boro
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence watches the changing of the guard at Boro.
fields.body:
Better off working on the suntan and in the studio? Defeat, compounded with the stark reality that his new club are now all alone at the bottom of the Premiership, suggests as much. But the manner of the performance means that Wor Tel has a half-decent chance of making himself a Middlesbrough hero.

For a man prone to crooning My Way in his London nightclub, the Terry Venables way had an astonishing effect on a bunch who spent all season looking lost. Middlesbrough actually resembled a team. One training session, one motivational peptalk, one all important presence on the sidelines to aid a set a players in desperate need of new guidance and new ideas and Venables has made his mark and summoned fresh hope.

Given the wretched conditions at the club - a squad terribly short on quality and points - you wonder if the ghost of Sir Alf Ramsay, helped out by some Bill Shankly pearls of wisdom, a dose of the Alex Ferguson hairdryer and a tactical tweak from Giovanni Trapattoni would be enough to make this curious collection of overpaid underachievers into a cohesive force. Could a twinkle-eyed son of Dagenham, who breezed into the North-East admitting it was difficult to get the jaw working in the bitter wind, find the answers?

Come kick-off the whole thing seemed to be a mirage. Bryan Robson had picked the team and there was standing alongside Viv Anderson in familiar pose - arms folded, lips pursed - side by side in the dugout. Where was the man of the moment? Observing from the back of the stands. Not for long, though.

He was soon welcomed to the hazardous way of the world at Boro as Ugo Ehiogu crashed into Phil Stamp early on, bloodying the head of his team-mate. Clumsy, disjointed, business as usual really. It was time for Tel to make a stand.

After 13 minutes he had seen enough, marching down to the touchline to cajole Christian Karembeu, instructed to replace the injured Stamp. Robson, looking rattled and told by the fourth official to calm down was instantly appeased by his mentor. Uncle Terry placed an arm protectively, paternally almost, around Robbo's waist, pointing and planning and informing.

Heartwarming though this sorcerer and apprentice scene is, Venables has enough of a job coaching his players without having the added complication of a second job coaxing a battered, marginalised, ex-leader as well (not to mention the third job at ITV). Fresh ideas tend to be fresher when the stale ones are consigned to history.

None the less, Venables's appearance at the dugout had a remarkable effect on his new charges. They continually glanced over to the bench for approval. Suitably reassured by a presence they clearly trust and respect more than Robson, they suddenly looked more solid, steely, settled, even ruffled a few feathers. Amazing. You could feel positive vibrations drifting over from bench to pitch and back again. Sunderland were hushed. Middlesbrough were comfortable.

Half-time would prove England's artful dodger's next big test, but Terry let Bryan take the team talk first of all before offering a few choice words. Whatever motivational speeches filled the visiting dressing room, next door Peter Reid was no doubt turning the air blue, which worked a treat. Sunderland soon took the lead, Boro couldn't muster a reply, and Venables was left under no illusions: he faces perhaps his toughest task in 40 years in the game, and one from which he cannot afford to be distracted.

It was understandable that a fair degree of scepticism greeted his appointment. Apart from the fact he needed enormous persuading and had never worked further north than north London, he had weaned himself off the daily fix of top-flight club football for the best part of a decade. Would 23 months out of the game (bar punditry), and prior to that unsavoury spells 'upstairs' sandwiching his stint on the international circuit dampen the magic touch?

Not a bit of it, and Boro need every ounce of his experience in the weeks ahead. From now on he will be picking the team, deciding the tactics, leading the team talks and - so Boro keep praying - showing them his way is up.

webTitle: Robinson's relish

fields.headline: Robinson's relish
fields.trailText: Charlton fight back for draw in thriller.
fields.body:
Arsene Wenger should try to watch a video tape of this game, and not just because it was one of the most entertaining matches in living memory and contained a contender for goal of the season.

If the Arsenal manager studied it closely, he would not only discover that Manchester United are fallible after all, which should give his side some hope of catching them at the top of the table; it should also disprove comprehensively his theory that other teams tend to live in awe of Manchester's finest and are only too happy to roll over and die when confronted by Sir Alex Ferguson's red menace.

As Ferguson observed of Wenger, after this compelling roller-coaster of a game, 'He does say some strange things.' Certainly you could not accuse Charlton of being intimidated by United or giving up the ghost when the points appeared to be heading north.

Having been denied the three-goal lead their first-half performance deserved, Charlton were devastated to go into the break 2-1 down following two United goals in the space of 30 seconds, the latter being driven home by Ole Gunnar Solskjaer after Ryan Giggs had hit the bar with a volley from the halfway line.

And even though they looked dead and buried when Roy Keane made it 3-1 midway through the second half, Charlton stormed back in rousing fashion with two goals in the final 12 minutes to salvage a draw and some London pride. It was magnificent entertainment. Six goals was scant return on such attacking football, and both goalkeepers made numerous excellent saves to keep the scoreline down.

There were two goals on his home debut from Shaun Bartlett, the South African striker Charlton have taken on loan from FC Zurich; a terrific example of Giggs's versatility as he wreaked havoc in a free attacking role, and plenty of good constructive football.

'It was a magnificent game of football for anyone watching,' said Ferguson afterwards. 'We have not been involved in a better game, certainly away from home, and it must have been a great spectacle.'

Alan Curbishley agreed. 'A great game,' he said, admitting that he almost enjoyed watching Giggs attempting to outdo team-mate David Beckham's famous goal against Wimbledon four years ago.

'Even on the bench we were saying what a fantastic effort,' he said of the audacious shot by Giggs that dropped on to the cross bar from around 50 yards in the 42nd minute. 'The higher and longer it went, the worse it got for us, but I thought we'd got away with it when the ball hit the bar.'

Solskjaer had other ideas, however, running alone into the home penalty area to volley home the loose ball, and Curbishley added: 'He is the last person you would want following up.'

The combination was a reverse of United's opening goal 30 seconds earlier, when Solskjaer set up Giggs to score from the edge of the penalty area. It was a cruel blow for Charlton, who had taken a 10th minute lead when Bartlett headed home Graham Stuart's deep cross moments after he had hit the underside of the bar with a diving header.

Charlton could have had four in the opening half-hour, with Jonatan Johansson having a header tipped away by Raimon Van der Gouw, who made another fine stop to keep out a curling free-kick from Claus Jensen. Dean Kiely, in the opposite goal, had little to do until Giggs fired in a fierce shot just before his equaliser.

But the Irish goalkeeper excelled in the second half, saving well from Giggs, Solskjaer and Roy Keane, who made amends when he increased United's lead with a shot that Kiely got his hand to but could not prevent from crossing the line. That should have been that, but for the third time this season United let a 3-1 lead evaporate - or rather Charlton wrenched it away from them.

Bartlett gave them hope when his stooping header made it 3-2 in the 79th minute, and substitute John Robinson ensured it was a happy Valley when he scored with a shot on the turn after Jensen's 85th minute corner was only half-cleared.

'What pleased me most was that we got back into it by playing good football, not just through blood and guts,' said Curbishley. 'The players were really on the floor at half-time, most teams would have folded when United went 3-1 ahead.'

Ferguson agreed. 'Charlton kept going and deserved a point. In every season there is a game when you have to battle and scrap.'

webTitle: Parlour restores Arsenal's drive

fields.headline: Parlour restores Arsenal's drive
fields.trailText: Wenger hails 'turning point' as Gunners canter.
fields.body:
Arsenal in crisis? All but Manchester United in the English game would give plenty to be experiencing one like it. Lame Newcastle's challenge may have been, but Arsenal's thoroughbreds emphatically demonstrated that there are a few furlongs left yet in this supposed one-horse Premiership race.

A hat-trick by the industrious, deserving Ray Parlour, complementing goals by Thierry Henry and Kanu, were tangible proof of an attitude among the Arsenal players that, after a recent sticky patch, this was the start of the rest of their season. 'It was a turning point in the life and the confidence of the team,' said the Arsenal manager, Arsène Wenger, like his team back to his sophisticated best after a midweek loss of composure.

From the outset, there was, this time, controlled anger to Arsenal's performance, the players determined to focus fully on improving their patchy league form. Now they have 10 weeks to pursue United before attempting to remedy a poor start to their Champions League group, United's slip at Charlton fuelling the new optimism.

'We got smashed,' said the Newcastle manager, Bobby Robson, without excuse and without wanting to criticise a fragile and depleted team. With Alan Shearer still out - and his knee injury possibly needing surgery and three months' recuperation should another injection fail this week, Robson revealed - they were particularly threadbare up front, where the L-plate striker Lomana Lua-Lua wandered lonely. By contrast, Parlour made light of the absence of Arsenal's talisman, the hamstrung Patrick Vieira. 'Arsenal were hungry,' added Robson. 'Apart from their quality all over the pitch, they had a terrific desire. They beat us with passing and movement, quick two-, three- and four-touch football.'

It was seen in the early goal that Arsenal so craved and so deserved. Tony Adams, rarely called on to break up opposition attacks, instead had time to create one, with an incisive ball into the inside-left gully which found Henry one-on-one against Aaron Hughes. Instants later, Hughes was in the Frenchman's wake, the ball tucked past Shay Given's left hand and nestling in the corner of the net.

Now Arsenal were buoyant, rampant even, and three minutes later came an even better goal. With perfect timing, Kanu flicked a through ball into the path of Parlour, who took one touch to control before drilling a low shot into Given's right-hand corner. Thereafter they over-elaborated at times, Robert Pires and Freddie Ljungberg spurning chances before the team regrouped at the interval.

This time there was never a chance they would surrender a two-goal lead, even if Newcastle did not have Bayern Munich's revival in them; Dennis Bergkamp even got a late run-out. Soon it was three, Ljungberg lifting a ball between the floundering defenders Hughes and Gary Caldwell for Kanu to run on to and beat Given.

Newcastle had been bent on damage-limitation. After failing to hold Arsenal early on, they had no alternative to a game plan of contain and counter. Arsenal now have six Premiership clean sheets in succession.

The visitors did manage a shot on target, Alex Manninger turning aside the disappointing Kieron Dyer's shot, but it was a straw in the fierce wind and normal service was soon resumed. From Henry's cross, Parlour - a player who gets stronger as the game progresses - nodded home. Finally, in added time, Parlour picked up Pires's neat through-ball and scored, Newcastle's back four now in 1-1-1-1 formation, having been left exposed by a ragged midfield. A canter to curtail the crisis.

webTitle: Reinventing theatre - all the world's a stage

fields.headline: You can take it with you
fields.standfirst:
A bus station, an abandoned hotel, a department store - it's official, all the world is a stage

More Observer Theatre coverage
fields.trailText: A bus station, an abandoned hotel, a department store - it's official, all the world is a stage, says David Benedict
fields.body:
There used to come a point in almost every movie musical when one of the inevitable Broadway wannabes would look round the barn and pipe up, 'Let's put the show on right here!' The response was usually along the lines of 'Well, it's mad, but it just might work...' And lo! Everyone sang and danced their way to success.

Truth being stranger than cliché, that very notion of re-inventing theatre spaces - or, to borrow estate agent terminology, location, location, location - is spreading through theatre like wildfire for the simple reason that the biggest problem facing the allegedly dying art form is the buildings themselves.

The terms 'theatre' and 'West End' have become synonymous. Say the word 'theatre' and most people immediately think chocolate-box interiors, gilt proscenium arch and uncomfortable seats. In other words, lush, plush and dangerous to go.

Venues such as the Elizabethan Globe theatre or adaptable 'black box' studio theatres up and down the country are bold reminders that theatre did not always aspire to the polite, Victorian condition of safe, well-dressed, middle-class audiences watching similarly safe, well-dressed, middle-class characters on stage.

Yet the overwhelming majority of British theatres spring from - and are mired in - nineteenth century architecture and artistic ideals. Some of them, particularly those designed by the great Frank Matcham, are acoustic marvels in which the majority of the audience sits in close relation to the stage, but all too often they're redolent of museums. They're hardly versatile or suited to the expectations of twenty-first century audiences.

For experiment and excitement you have to look further afield, which explains the appeal of 'event theatre' such as the Shakespeare in Shoreditch season where the Almeida director Jonathan Kent turned the old Gainsborough film studios (which had been languishing in neglect, having been used as a musty, cluttered carpet warehouse) into a temporary theatre to house Richard II and Coriolanus starring Ralph Fiennes. With that success under his belt, Kent has turned his attentions to two further events, both home and away.

Before closing for a lottery-funded refit, the Almeida will host his production of The Tempest , designed by his Gainsborough designer Paul Brown and starring his fellow artistic director Ian McDiarmid as Prospero. As soon as that is up and running, Kent and company will decamp to less than luxurious Kings Cross.

This means that although Anna Friel recently graced Broadway in Patrick Marber's Closer, from next March you can see her in Kent's production of Lulu - Wedekind's study of sexual obsession - in an old bus station, which designer Rob Howell will be turning into a 500-seat theatre.

Originally, there was talk of creating the production at The Old Vic, but Kent is excited that the Almeida team has pulled off the Kings Cross project. 'It has its own aesthetic, a sort of urban brutalism in rather sharp contrast to the high Romanticism of the Gainsborough Studios.' Kent's father, brother and cousin are all architects so the language is second nature to him. The neatness of presenting so famous a sexual portrait in this location hasn't escaped him - 'the area has its fair share of Lulus' - and he welcomes the fact that this will help give the play a contemporary edge.

Placing plays in context in this way is nothing new. As far as I know, nobody has yet staged The Sound of Music in an Austrian Schloss, but five years ago Max Stafford-Clark presented his production of Three Sisters upstairs, downstairs and in my lady's chamber in a dramatically snowbound country house in Hertfordshire to illuminating effect.

It's not quite a case of 'if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen', more 'if you want to be truly theatrical, get out of the theatre'.

Kent is one of those directors who still cleaves to tradition by presenting plays but who tends to shy away from traditional buildings. He has successfully directed the Almeida company in the West End but he seems happier being involved in increasingly imaginative makeovers of often derelict buildings.

The term 'location scout' used to be confined to cinema, one of those vaguely self-explanatory phrases that drifted past you during the credits unlike its more enigmatic compatriots 'Key Grip' or 'Best Boy'. Increasingly, however, 'location scout' is becoming part of Kent's job description. And he's not alone.

Tastes have changed and much of this is bound up in a question of size. Many directors are now more than a little uncomfortable working in large-scale theatres. You don't have to run the National to realise that an enormous stage like the Olivier Theatre (let alone the 1,100-seat auditorium) is hugely problematic to fill.

Tim Supple recently foundered directing Romeo and Juliet at the Olivier, but his small-scale Shakespeare at the RSC and the Young Vic had been strikingly atmospheric. Indeed, exceptions like Michael Grandage's powerful work on the vast open stage of the Sheffield Crucible notwithstanding, almost every great Shakespeare production of the last 25 years from Trevor Nunn's terrifying and justly legendary Macbeth to Stephen Pimlott's arrestingly analytical Richard II has taken place in a small space.

That is directly reflected in the the atres that regularly hog the limelight, ie the 250-seat Donmar and the 300-seat Almeida. Why? Because audiences weaned on TV and film close-up want to get up close and personal. Furthermore, the addiction to TV-style naturalism - more behaving than acting - can initially make the bolder, more energised acting required in large theatres seem vaguely out of proportion and difficult to take.

Those directors who don't have the organisational back-up or clout to convert an industrial building into a theatre are opting in ever greater numbers for the late-twentieth century alternative: site-specific work. Utterly unlikely venues are being commandeered for one-off experiment. Are You Being Served? proved that department stores aren't usually centres of dramatic excellence, but passers-by (and the media) were fascinated when the London International Festival of Theatre (LIFT) presented an ongoing, non-stop life-story 'acted out' behind the windows of Clapham's department store Arding and Hobbs.

Two years earlier, director Deborah Warner took individuals along a shiveringly creepy journey through the abandoned St Pancras Hotel. It was like being on a ghost train with no engine but real chills. She then put angels in the architecture, turning a disused top floor of the Euston Tower into what might be termed 'a playground'.

All of these might more usefully be described as theatrical installations, a form that reached an early high with Robert Wilson's thrilling, gravely beautiful HG in London's Clink vaults - the most highly charged drama I've ever seen without actors, each room absolutely hummed with the uncanny tension between absence and presence. A minutely recreated 1900s dining room ached with the sense of its inhabitants having fled, leaving behind overturned chairs and a congealed, unfinished meal; a post-First World War influenza ward was conjured up by serried ranks of immaculately-made, ghoulishly over-lit, empty beds.

Over the past 20 years, LIFT has radically - and occasionally roguishly - redefined what we regard as theatre and much of the experimentation in this country can be traced to its influence.

Theatregoers were even to be found lapping up experiments in Bobby Baker's north London kitchen. And next year boasts further frontline activity with, among other things, pyrotechnics in a Hackney park, a show which ditches seats and replaces them with beds, and a night-time journey in boats along the Thames.

Not that every out-of-theatre experiment has produced ravishing results. The Turn of the Screw at Clerkenwell's ancient House of Detention turned out to be all gong and no dinner: heaps of atmosphere and spooky lighting but no clearly defined space in which to present a convincing narrative.

Even Thétre de Complicité wunderkind Simon McBurney came a cropper when he went site-specific with The Vertical Line . He crossed a John Berger lecture with a walking tour in a disused tube tunnel: it was full of resonance, little substance and less drama.

Kent's valedictory production at the Almeida cunningly straddles both styles. The site-specific quality comes from designer Paul Brown's almost 'Goodbye to all that' approach, putting up scaffolding and knocking down part of the structure in advance of the rebuild. At the same time it amounts to a re-invention of a known space.

Brown sees it as being highly appropriate to the ideas that course through Shakespeare's final play. ' The Tempest is peculiarly appropriate. It's about discord and union: we're doing the chaos, the actors are doing the resolution.' The rebuild and roof replacement - for reasons of safety and audience comfort - means that Brown has licence to make waves. Literally. His design uses tons of water to create a space in which the elements appear to have taken over. 'The storm's a storm, not a slight shower. It would be so much safer to stick with grains of sand and a jug of water but we're going for big again.'

Such grand projects - so-called 'event theatre' - can have unlooked-for consequences. The circumstances of a hyped production can outweigh its true content. Kent is also aware that short-term gain can lead to long-term strain. 'The danger is that you brutalise an audience who only respond to the event,' he observes cautiously. Brown is even clearer. 'The danger of constantly trying to find different ways is that you re-invent theatre, but forget to do the work.'

Nevertheless, the future of theatre unquestionably lies in upsetting deadening certainty. Satisfaction guaranteed is fine for Holiday Inns but stultifying for audiences. The secret is in the equation between audience, material and environment.

Or, as Jeanette Winterson put it in Oranges Are Not The Only Fruit: 'Something unexpected in a usual place (our favourite aunt in our favourite poker parlour) or something usual in an unexpected place (our favourite poker in our favourite aunt).'

Coincidentally, in the mid-Eighties, Winterson used to write the odd theatre review. Maybe she was on to something.

'The Tempest' opens at the Almeida, London N1 on Thursday (020 7359 4404)

'Lulu' opens at Kings Cross in March.

For experiment and excitement you have to look further afield, which explains the appeal of 'event theatre' such as the Shakespeare in Shoreditch season where the Almeida director Jonathan Kent turned the old Gainsborough film studios (which had been languishing in neglect, having been used as a musty, cluttered carpet warehouse) into a temporary theatre to house Richard II and Coriolanus starring Ralph Fiennes. With that success under his belt, Kent has turned his attentions to two further events, both home and away. Before closing for a lottery-funded refit, the Almeida will host his production of The Tempest , designed by his Gainsborough designer Paul Brown and starring his fellow artistic director Ian McDiarmid as Prospero. As soon as that is up and running, Kent and company will decamp to less than luxurious Kings Cross. This means that although Anna Friel recently graced Broadway in Patrick Marber's Closer, from next March you can see her in Kent's production of Lulu - Wedekind's study of sexual obsession - in an old bus station, which designer Rob Howell will be turning into a 500-seat theatre. Originally, there was talk of creating the production at The Old Vic, but Kent is excited that the Almeida team has pulled off the Kings Cross project. 'It has its own aesthetic, a sort of urban brutalism in rather sharp contrast to the high Romanticism of the Gainsborough Studios.' Kent's father, brother and cousin are all architects so the language is second nature to him. The neatness of presenting so famous a sexual portrait in this location hasn't escaped him - 'the area has its fair share of Lulus' - and he welcomes the fact that this will help give the play a contemporary edge. Placing plays in context in this way is nothing new. As far as I know, nobody has yet staged The Sound of Music in an Austrian Schloss, but five years ago Max Stafford-Clark presented his production of Three Sisters upstairs, downstairs and in my lady's chamber in a dramatically snowbound country house in Hertfordshire to illuminating effect. It's not quite a case of 'if you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen', more 'if you want to be truly theatrical, get out of the theatre'. Kent is one of those directors who still cleaves to tradition by presenting plays but who tends to shy away from traditional buildings. He has successfully directed the Almeida company in the West End but he seems happier being involved in increasingly imaginative makeovers of often derelict buildings. The term 'location scout' used to be confined to cinema, one of those vaguely self-explanatory phrases that drifted past you during the credits unlike its more enigmatic compatriots 'Key Grip' or 'Best Boy'. Increasingly, however, 'location scout' is becoming part of Kent's job description. And he's not alone. Tastes have changed and much of this is bound up in a question of size. Many directors are now more than a little uncomfortable working in large-scale theatres. You don't have to run the National to realise that an enormous stage like the Olivier Theatre (let alone the 1,100-seat auditorium) is hugely problematic to fill. Tim Supple recently foundered directing Romeo and Juliet at the Olivier, but his small-scale Shakespeare at the RSC and the Young Vic had been strikingly atmospheric. Indeed, exceptions like Michael Grandage's powerful work on the vast open stage of the Sheffield Crucible notwithstanding, almost every great Shakespeare production of the last 25 years from Trevor Nunn's terrifying and justly legendary Macbeth to Stephen Pimlott's arrestingly analytical Richard II has taken place in a small space. That is directly reflected in the the atres that regularly hog the limelight, ie the 250-seat Donmar and the 300-seat Almeida. Why? Because audiences weaned on TV and film close-up want to get up close and personal. Furthermore, the addiction to TV-style naturalism - more behaving than acting - can initially make the bolder, more energised acting required in large theatres seem vaguely out of proportion and difficult to take. Those directors who don't have the organisational back-up or clout to convert an industrial building into a theatre are opting in ever greater numbers for the late-twentieth century alternative: site-specific work. Utterly unlikely venues are being commandeered for one-off experiment. Are You Being Served? proved that department stores aren't usually centres of dramatic excellence, but passers-by (and the media) were fascinated when the London International Festival of Theatre (LIFT) presented an ongoing, non-stop life-story 'acted out' behind the windows of Clapham's department store Arding and Hobbs. Two years earlier, director Deborah Warner took individuals along a shiveringly creepy journey through the abandoned St Pancras Hotel. It was like being on a ghost train with no engine but real chills. She then put angels in the architecture, turning a disused top floor of the Euston Tower into what might be termed 'a playground'. All of these might more usefully be described as theatrical installations, a form that reached an early high with Robert Wilson's thrilling, gravely beautiful HG in London's Clink vaults - the most highly charged drama I've ever seen without actors, each room absolutely hummed with the uncanny tension between absence and presence. A minutely recreated 1900s dining room ached with the sense of its inhabitants having fled, leaving behind overturned chairs and a congealed, unfinished meal; a post-First World War influenza ward was conjured up by serried ranks of immaculately-made, ghoulishly over-lit, empty beds. Over the past 20 years, LIFT has radically - and occasionally roguishly - redefined what we regard as theatre and much of the experimentation in this country can be traced to its influence. Theatregoers were even to be found lapping up experiments in Bobby Baker's north London kitchen. And next year boasts further frontline activity with, among other things, pyrotechnics in a Hackney park, a show which ditches seats and replaces them with beds, and a night-time journey in boats along the Thames. Not that every out-of-theatre experiment has produced ravishing results. The Turn of the Screw at Clerkenwell's ancient House of Detention turned out to be all gong and no dinner: heaps of atmosphere and spooky lighting but no clearly defined space in which to present a convincing narrative. Even Thétre de Complicité wunderkind Simon McBurney came a cropper when he went site-specific with The Vertical Line . He crossed a John Berger lecture with a walking tour in a disused tube tunnel: it was full of resonance, little substance and less drama. Kent's valedictory production at the Almeida cunningly straddles both styles. The site-specific quality comes from designer Paul Brown's almost 'Goodbye to all that' approach, putting up scaffolding and knocking down part of the structure in advance of the rebuild. At the same time it amounts to a re-invention of a known space. Brown sees it as being highly appropriate to the ideas that course through Shakespeare's final play. ' The Tempest is peculiarly appropriate. It's about discord and union: we're doing the chaos, the actors are doing the resolution.' The rebuild and roof replacement - for reasons of safety and audience comfort - means that Brown has licence to make waves. Literally. His design uses tons of water to create a space in which the elements appear to have taken over. 'The storm's a storm, not a slight shower. It would be so much safer to stick with grains of sand and a jug of water but we're going for big again.' Such grand projects - so-called 'event theatre' - can have unlooked-for consequences. The circumstances of a hyped production can outweigh its true content. Kent is also aware that short-term gain can lead to long-term strain. 'The danger is that you brutalise an audience who only respond to the event,' he observes cautiously. Brown is even clearer. 'The danger of constantly trying to find different ways is that you re-invent theatre, but forget to do the work.' Nevertheless, the future of theatre unquestionably lies in upsetting deadening certainty. Satisfaction guaranteed is fine for Holiday Inns but stultifying for audiences. The secret is in the equation between audience, material and environment. Or, as Jeanette Winterson put it in Oranges Are Not The Only Fruit: 'Something unexpected in a usual place (our favourite aunt in our favourite poker parlour) or something usual in an unexpected place (our favourite poker in our favourite aunt).' Coincidentally, in the mid-Eighties, Winterson used to write the odd theatre review. Maybe she was on to something. 'The Tempest' opens at the Almeida, London N1 on Thursday (020 7359 4404) 'Lulu' opens at Kings Cross in March.

webTitle: Horlock the warlock

fields.headline: Horlock the warlock
fields.trailText: Royle comes back to crunch Toffees.
fields.body:
Joe Royle's entrenched belief that his Manchester City are better than a recent run of six consecutive defeats implies was given substance by an emphatic victory that in no way flattered his team.

The win spared Royle collecting a seventh straight league loss for the first time in his 18-year managerial career. The fact it came against Everton, the club he left so acrimoniously in March 1997, could have given him much pleasure.

It helped that the opposition consistently looked as confused as a Florida voter, turning in a performance that was almost unspeakably inept, to hand their manager Walter Smith the worst defeat of his management career at Dundee United, Rangers and now Goodison. But, for one day at least, the ceaseless and largely unfounded superiority complex that City supporters possess - parodied humorously by one Manchester United fan who called national talk radio last week to pose as a Blue and claim endlessly 'We're a massive club' - looked justified.

'It was hard to keep giving mitigating circumstances for losing,' said Royle, deservedly basking in the glow of victory. 'But it was just a case of keeping the faith going.

'The spirit has never changed, heads have never dropped, and after the game it was like some valve had been released. Everyone was saying someone was bound to get it sooner or later.'

And get it Everton most certainly did. All of 12 seconds had elapsed when Paul Gerrard, Royle's keeper at Oldham and Everton, raced from his line to smother at the feet of Paulo Wanchope, and from there it was steadily downhill.

The key first two goals were the product of excellent deliveries from Kevin Horlock, accused this week by Royle of 'sulking' during a recent spell out of favour but now revelling in a third consecutive start. In the 13th minute David Unsworth conceded a free-kick on the edge of the Everton area, body-checking the irrepressible Shaun Wright-Phillips with costly effect. Horlock's driven free-kick beat the wall and was parried by Gerrard at the feet of Wanchope who bundled in his sixth league goal of the season.

Nine minutes later, Horlock's left-wing corner found the head of Howey, having slipped his marker Kevin Campbell six yards from goal, who finished tidily.

City's enthusiasm was unquenchable and Everton's performance disgraceful, another City goal an inevitability. It arrived in the 41st minute, a goal to shame any Premiership defence as City keeper Nicky Weaver's long punt forward was headed on by Wanchope, Shaun Goater shrugged off David Weir and drove his first Premiership goal past Gerrard.

'We lost the first goal to a free-kick, the second from a corner and the third from what we call in Scotland a booter,' admitted Smith. 'By the way we defended, we deserved to lose in the manner we did.'

Goater's pre-half-time departure with a groin injury hardly signalled an end to the Everton embarrassment, Wright-Phillips only being denied by an excellent reflex Gerrard save on the stroke of half-time.

The rout continued, and showed no signs of abating, when Laurent Charvet's well-hit cross was touched past Gerrard by defender Gary Naysmith in the 66th minute. It was a goal that spoke volumes of an abysmal afternoon for the visitors and one that surely, in his first competitive encounter with his former club, must have given Royle special pleasure.

'The three points were more important,' insisted Royle. 'I've no axes to grind with Everton. As a fan, as a manager, as a player, I have nothing but good memories. There is no twisted pleasure in it for me. Someone was going to get it. It happened to be my old club.'

webTitle: Gray puts Tel in black

fields.headline: Gray puts Tel in black
fields.trailText: Gray matter puts Tel in the black.
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Sunderland are now fourth in the Premiership and beaten only once in 16 matches, so Peter Reid's team were never likely to accept a supporting role when the Terry Venables Show rolled into the Stadium of Light.

So it proved, with Peter Reid's team displaying their customary resilience and denying troubled Middlesbrough the point that would have been an appropriate reward for their improved performance.

Middlesbrough finally succumbed to a goal gifted to Michael Gray thanks to a dreadful error from keeper Mark Schwarzer early in the second half. The Australian's mistake condemned Middlesbrough to bottom place in the Premiership and left them with just one point from their last nine league games.

But Venables witnessed enough to make him optimistic about the future, not least the fact that the Premiership may not be too daunting nowadays if Reid's honest outfit can mount a realistic challenge for a place in Europe.

The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson, who picked yesterday's team before handing the responsibility to the new coach next week, said: 'Terry told me he was encouraged by the performance.'

Sunderland manager Peter Reid agreed: 'Middlesbrough I think will stay up. I had a chat with Terry on Friday night and he seems relaxed and lively, which showed in his team's performance.

'They've been given a spark and I just think it will work out well for them. Look at the players and what they've got - that tells you everything. They are certainly good enough to win matches at this level.'

They would certainly have won this one if Hamilton Ricard had accepted any of the four chances that came his way on a day when he proved a handful for the Sunderland defence. When the Colombian international did beat keeper Thomas Sorensen in the 36th minute, referee Graham Poll detected a push on defender Jody Craddock.

The decision angered Robson, who said: 'The ref didn't help us with a few decisions. He's the only person who saw a foul. If it had been at the other end, I don't think it would have been disallowed, but that's how it goes.

'We haven't come away with anything, but the players did well and we created a few chances. Our luck will change. They've got to believe in themselves, but we'll be OK if they keep playing like that.'

Even Reid was surprised to see the goal disallowed and such was Middlesbrough's first half pressure, told his players at the interval that 0-0 would represent a satisfactory outcome. In that context, Gray's goal must be regarded as a bonus for Reid. Yet Sunderland's second-half performance was certainly more incisive. No doubt chastened by what Reid usually describes as 'a few words' during the break, Sunderland coped better with Middlesbrough's rugged approach.

The home team promised much with Gavin McCann's 20-yard shot which prompted a fine save from Schwarzer in the opening seconds of the half. And they delivered on that promise thanks to the gruesome error by Schwarzer.

The angle was sharp when Sunderland skipper Gray closed in on a loose ball in the 54th minute, but the keeper allowed a low shot to skid through his arms and under his body for the full-back's first goal of the season.

Kevin Phillips came close to scoring on either side of the goal, but Middlesbrough's spirited response to the setback was another plus point for Venables. They might even have had a penalty if Ricard had not tried to make too much of an incident when he was challenged inside the area by Darren Will. Ricard's theatrical dive brought him only a booking and a rebuke from Robson: 'Hamilton said there was contact, but maybe he made too much of it.'

Sunderland, who accepted that reprieve and were largely untroubled in the closing stages, had rated little more than a footnote in the Venables-obsessed build-up. But this was confirmation that they are contenders for Europe, even if Reid refuses to mention the word. They can win without playing well, which is always a useful habit

Reid said: 'Some people were saying it would be easy, but I always knew it was going to be difficult. Middlesbrough have a lot of good players who came here to do a job. We found it hard to break them down. I was pleased for Michael Gray because he's been outstanding all season. He did the keeper for sheer pace.'

Sunderland finished seventh last season and Reid believes his team are now even better. 'We have more strength in depth than last year,' he said. 'It's going well for us at the moment.'

webTitle: Gateshead fall to Cowe-Howe show

fields.headline: Gateshead fall to Cowe-Howe show
fields.trailText: Gateshead fall to Swindon's Cowe-Howe show.
fields.byline: Will Buckley at The County Ground
fields.body:
'Let's get behind them!' shouted the announcer and the home crowd booed the lot of them, apart from Danny Invincible. The most prolonged boo being reserved for Bobby Howe, 5ft 4in with ginger hair, who has, by all accounts, been underperforming of late. Swindon are not having the best of seasons. Fourth from bottom of the Second Division, two home wins out of 10, and knocked out of the Worthington Cup by Tranmere, they needed a cup run. Standing in their way was Unibond League team Gateshead FC.

Swindon could have scored within 20 seconds when Gateshead keeper Adrian Swan fell over his own central defender on the edge of the box but Martin Williams' shot was cleared off the line. Two inswinging corners from Ian Woan followed - Gateshead players failed to touch either, but somehow a goal was averted. Minutes later O'Halloran pulled off a back-heel, received the ball back and fizzed a shot just past the upright.

Piling on the early pressure it was obvious that Swindon had taken in new gaffer Andy King's wise words in the programme: 'I have said for a long time now that we will find it easier to compete if we can get ourselves ahead in games instead of going behind.' Absolutely, Andy, and here's another thing - the team that scores the most goals wins.

On 17 minutes O'Halloran struck again. Danny Invincible, once of the Marconi Stallions, teed the ball up on the edge of the area and O'Halloran belted it over Swan and into the net. It was a high-quality goal, quite out of keeping with the game.

The big question, now: would Swindon, one-nil up, find it 'easier to compete'? Gratifyingly for Andy King the answer was yes. Williams cantered down the right, crossed the ball across the face of the goal and Invincible, not infallible, failed to get a nick. The impressive Gary Alexander had a couple of shots blocked. Swindon were in the ascendant, Gateshead were struggling to defend their one-goal deficit.

Six minutes after half-time, the ball bobbled on the edge of the area and O'Halloran scissor-kicked it on the half-volley over Swan and into the net. Gateshead, who had never really got into the game, were now pretty much out of it.

But encouraged by their fans, who banged on their drum and chanted throughout, Gateshead struggled on and even forced Bart Griemink to make a save when he backpedalled quickly after Paul Talbot's cross turned into a shot. Swindon, however, remained the more dangerous. They should have increased their lead as Williams first missed the goal from four yards and then from six yards and finally managed to place a glancing header on target only for the ball to be cleared off the line by captain Kitchen. He was promptly substituted.

Time ebbed away. Earlier in the week Gateshead had lost to Marine in the FA Trophy, now they were slipping out of the FA Cup. Not a good week. Even their fans stopped singing. Substitutions were made, 'young Alan Young', just 17, coming on for Invincible and setting up a goal for Steve Cowe. With three minutes to go Bobby Howe scored and the crowd, well, they thought about booing but most of them gave him a polite clap. They were more enthusiastic about Cowe's second and Swindon's fifth. At the end they gave their side a standing ovation. So fickle, football fans.

webTitle: Levein's delight

fields.headline: Levein's delight
fields.trailText: Levein's day to savour as Hearts kill off Killy.
fields.body:
This was a match a visiting manager would find easy to love. Especially if, as in Hearts' Craig Levein's case, he had only taken over eight days earlier. For Levein, here was a day to savour. For Bobby Williamson and those supporters with Kilmarnock tattooed onto their affections, it was something of an ordeal.

In the conditions - a freezing, cutting wind made Rugby Park a trial - nobody could reasonably expect an exhibition of top-quality football. In this regard, the home support would not have been surprised to see their side give a pedestrian and aimless performance.

In these circumstances, players are often accused of a lack of endeavour. It is, of course, usually quite the opposite, with those taking part striving energetically to gain an edge and managing only to aggravate their own problems with passes over-hit through anxiety and defensive lapses induced by haste. No amount of urgency can alter those days - and, for Kilmarnock, this was one of them - when most of those taking part appear to be afflicted by a loss of touch.

Steve Fulton, Andy Kirk and a number of other Tynecastle players proved immediately before and soon after half-time to be gratifying exceptions to the general dishevelment of the first half - when Hearts, too, looked quite cumbersome - when they scored the goals which made victory a certainty.

But just before Fulton's opener no bookmaker would have accepted a single wager on the game ending scoreless. Opportunities had been as rare as an accurate train schedule, thanks largely to moderate and unimaginative passing from defence and midfield.

An individual piece of improvisation was required and Fulton provided it on the stroke of half-time when he carried the ball forward from midfield, played a slick one-two with Colin Cameron and slid the ball low to the left of Gordon Marshall from the left side of the penalty area.

Kirk owed his later opportunities to appalling defending by the home side, but the little striker's finishing was magnificent. A long kick from Antti Niemi was completely missed by Sean Hessey, giving Kirk possession 25 yards out. He quickly volleyed it over Marshall, his technique so precise that the ball dipped under the bar with feet to spare.

Gus MacPherson must have been infected by Hessey's sluggishness soon after, when he miscalculated a clearance and knocked the ball against Kirk, leaving the Hearts man to run unchallenged into the penalty area. He chose a spot low to the right of Marshall and delivered the ball to it with his right foot from 12 yards.

Victory was the least Hearts deserved. Even during that generally uninspired first half, they were the more compact and intelligent side, always appearing more likely to inflict damage.

By the time they had finished, their composed defending, shrewd and precise midfield passing and astute forward play from Gordon Durie and his apprentice, Kirk, made them the better side by a distance. Considering the standard Kilmarnock have set this season, this was hugely encouraging for Levein, following the slightly unlucky defeat by Rangers on his managerial debut.

For Levein, here was a day to savour. For Bobby Williamson and those supporters with Kilmarnock tattooed onto their affections, it was something of an ordeal. webTitle: To serve them all his days

fields.headline: To serve them all his days
fields.trailText: After 15 loyal years at Sheffield Wednesday, Kevin Pressman is being given the axe.
fields.body:
Fifteen erratic years in the life of Sheffield Wednesday have persuaded Kevin Pressman to rethink the cliché about a week being a long time in football. He reckons a day is a long time in football - and after 5,475 and counting spent at Hillsborough, he came in one morning to discover that his number was up.

Wednesday are a club feeling the financial squeeze so sharply they recently decided they could not afford to renew the contracts of three of the club's longest-serving players. Des Walker has been there for seven years, and Andy Booth for five, but for Pressman the wrench is particularly severe. He grew up in Sheffield, joined the club as a boy, currently coaches the kids at the academy two nights a week and is a proud one-club man. His treatment is symbolic of the problems at a club making decisions based more on accounts than ability.

After more than 350 appearances in goal, Pressman deserves better, and frankly, if the board see sense they will realise what a mistake it is to discard a player prepared to dedicate his whole professional life to a club whose idiosyncrasies he appreciates acutely and astutely. And he cares. Truly, madly, deeply, he cares about Sheffield Wednesday Football Club - and there haven't exactly been truckloads who do on the payroll in recent years.

His brand of loyalty borders on self-sacrifice. He was booed by his own fans when the team leaked goals, dropped for showpiece finals, deprived of the trust to try to turn England under-21 and B appearances into a full cap, never had the testimonial his service earned - but he's always remained faithful. Naturally, he is feeling a little sore at the moment.

'It hurt me,' he confesses, blue eyes staring into the middle distance. 'I feel I've got another seven years in the game. I've still got a lot to offer, but if the powers that be decide that's not here then so be it. I'd love to stay, I want to finish my career here, and I'm available if they want to do something.

'But if players have to leave because of wages then that's what the club have to do. There is life on the other side and if I have to look elsewhere I'll carry on.'

For a man who has seen, among other things, eight managers, three Cup Finals, a string of promotions and relegations, and a continental experiment that virtually killed the club off, this campaign has brought yet another new experience. He has been part of arguably the most remarkable turnaround in the club's 133-year history.

A few weeks ago, there was no chink of light through the suffocating clouds over Hillsborough. Running out of money and players, they were spiralling down, down, down. Now, a hotch-potch side comprising kids, loan players, and a few cheap signings have clicked. Admittedly, they still need to find some consistency to hoist themselves away from danger, but at least there is hope.

Much of the credit goes to Paul Jewell, who everybody thought was either incredibly brave or barmy to take on what seemed an impossible job. He has welded something positive after encouraging promising youngsters such as Alan Quinn and Owen Morrison to show their worth, and begging and borrowing low-key signings such as Efan Ekoku, Steve Harkness and Ashley Westwood to help them along.

After a handful of quite unexpected results - winning away at West Ham in the Worthington Cup and high-flying Watford in the League - confidence is brewing nicely. Players who used to dread games now look forward to them.The cloak of negativity has been torn off and they feel liberated. If the relentlessly ridiculed Gerald Sibon can score a hat-trick there must be something pretty potent in the air.

Jewell's virtues of strong principles and steely enthusiasm have impressed Pressman: 'I can imagine it's very soul destroying because there will be things he wants to do that he can't because of financial restrictions. With the limited budget, he's done extremely well and hopefully it will improve with time.

'He's not a quitter. He made that clear to us when we were going through a bad run, that he would be there through thick and thin. If you've got a manager that is behind you he earns respect and maybe you give that extra five yards for him. That backing helps to make the club strong.'

The atmosphere around the place compared to a year ago is a breath of fresh air. Purged of the fancy dans who appeared to play for themselves rather than the club - Benito Carbone and Gilles de Bilde spring to mind - the enthusiasm of youngsters striving to prove themselves is invigorating.

'Without a doubt the team spirit within the club is a lot better now,' agrees Pressman. 'It's not just about individuals. We go out and win as a team or lose as a team. The young ones have learnt the ropes quickly and now the whole thing seems to be gelling.

'You can't deny the players we had here were very, very talented. Because of the way things went sour, they were probably right to get them out of the club because they were giving no benefit, only doing the biz when it suited them, which dragged the others down. You can't have a bad apple amongst us, you've got to get him out, no matter how good the player is.

'I'm a believer in the saying, "Great teams beat great players". The supporters see the commitment and ambition and will to win now and they haven't seen that for a while.'

The mood of apathy that had Hillsborough in its depressing stranglehold has transformed into a crusade, but Pressman warns the fans not to get carried away. He still fears for the club's future. 'We're not in the clear at the moment. Because of the start we had, danger is always looming and our goal is to stay out of trouble this season and not get relegated.'

It upsets him that avoiding Division Two is the sum of the club's current ambitions. 'I was here in 1990-91 when we won the cup, got into Europe, and went on to reach the two Cup Finals in 1993. The club were financially solid and there wasn't a worry in sight. Since then it has been a slow decline. Relegation from the Premiership has hit us hard.

'It was especially sad for me after the time I've been here. I've been through highs and lows and this period has been the worst I have seen.'

Poignantly, the turning point came in a tussle against the old foes from down the road at Bramall Lane in the Worthington Cup. Wednesday beat United, finishing the game with seven players aged under 21, and the injection of pride was enormous. It has inspired them for a massive week ahead.

On Tuesday, they travel to Birmingham for the quarter-final, before renewing hostilities with United in the League next weekend. The derby always brings back memories of 1993, when they filled Wembley with blue and red balloons for an all-Sheffield FA Cup semi-final jamboree. Pressman would love to see this success-starved footballing city thrive again. The question is, will he be around to see it? All he knows is that he will continue to give everything, with no regrets, until he is shown the door. Does he feel he deserved more?

'Not really. I'm happy with what I've achieved. I look back and I've got no complaints. People say if I'd moved I might have got into the England side instead of being on the fringe. That's life. It's about deciding what road to go down. I think I made the right decision. I've had good and bad times here and it's something I'm glad to be a part of.'

webTitle: James and Di Canio shake on it

fields.headline: James and Di Canio shake on it
fields.trailText: Clarets both maturing for a happy new year.
fields.body:
When Paolo Di Canio and David James called time on their public spat with a hug and a handshake at the final whistle, there was no doubt who was the more satisfied player. Not only did James twice stand firm when confronted by the fired-up Italian, but Villa withstood several other close shaves for a hard-earned point that keeps these teams locked together in the Premiership table.

If Villa can land the Celta Vigo striker Benni McCarthy to provide much-needed support alongside Dion Dublin, and when West Ham shake off the effects of injuries, illness and suspension, both look good to challenge for European places in the new year.

Both camps pronounced themselves satisfied with the outcome. 'We had some great opportunities to have fin ished them off in the first half,' said the West Ham manager, Harry Redknapp, delighted with a sweet strike from 19-year-old Michael Carrick and another performance oozing class from Frederic Kanoute.

'We are certainly short of bodies, but if you had offered us five wins and two draws in seven games we would have taken them.' Steve Harrison, the Villa first team coach, was enthusiastic about the mature way Lee Hendrie went about his work and by how James handled the pressure.

'It was a good, honest, whole-hearted performance by us. We couldn't have asked for any more. At the moment we are just grinding out results, but there is plenty of potential there and we can certainly get better,' he said.

The war of words between Di Canio and James gave this encounter an extra dimension. Di Canio was clearly up for it and after Carrick struck his first goal of the season from 22 yards with the ball going in off a post, he had the perfect opportunity to put his side in a commanding position. Kanoute found him in space slightly to the left of goal, but Di Canio's volley finished up in the crowd.

Later Kanoute and Trevor Sinclair combined to free Di Canio, but James was off his line in an instant to smother the shot. In between, Kanoute himself, skipper Steve Lomas and Kaba Diawara had all wasted chances. Diawara's was the easiest of them all, failing to beat James from six yards after Di Canio's cross was headed back from a far post position by Sinclair. That is to take nothing away from James's block. 'David was top quality today,' said Harrison. 'He made some excellent saves.'

West Ham paid the price for those misses when Hendrie, who had twice gone close from distance, took a pass from David Ginola just outside the penalty box and found the net with a skimming drive off both uprights. West Ham came out for the second half on full throttle, but the longer the game went on the more assured Villa became and Harrison added: 'We had them on the back foot for the last 15 minutes.'

Apart from his assist for the goal, Ginola was largely on the periphery of the game in his first start in a match in London since leaving Tottenham in the summer. The frustration was evident - even though Harrison believes he will adjust to Villa's style - none more so than when he was shown a yellow card for his challenge on Rigobert Song. Ginola had to be restrained by Dublin from remonstrating more than he did with the referee, Mike Riley.

webTitle: Said & Done

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: The legend that is Harry
fields.body:
The legend that is Harry

Hurst, Moore, Peters - and Redknapp? Confusion reigned last week at Chadwell Heath, West Ham's training ground. As French agents representing Frederic 'King' Kanoute and non-scoring 'striker' Kaba Diawara waited for them to change, they admired the pictures of Hammers past and present on the walls. Pausing before a picture of the 1966 World Cup winners, with Bobby Moore holding the trophy aloft, one of the agents asked a passerby: 'Which one is 'Arry?'. Harry, we salute you. Not only are you the game's most geezerish wheeler-dealer, but your aura of greatness has somehow convinced people you won the game's ultimate prize in 1966. And there we were thinking your most memorable footballing moment was scoring an own goal for Bournemouth at Old Trafford.

The wrong shirt

Manchester United's newly-installed spin doctor is quashing rumours that he's a closet Arsenal fan. Ex-FT scribe Patrick Harverson admits that as a naive six-year-old he was photographed in an Arsenal shirt, but blames his mum for the incident. It seems she went out to buy him a red-and-white shirt and mistakenly thought a Gooner one would do. 'I only wore it once', insists the man in one of football's real hotseats. His embarrassment may not be over yet. Fans group Shareholders United has offered to give any member of the Harverson clan £100 for the offending snap . 'Wearing an Arsenal kit is bad enough, but allowing yourself to be photographed in it doesn't augur well for a career in slick PR management', says the group's Oliver Houston. 'But he was only young at the time, and it could have been worse - it could have been a Leeds or Man City shirt!'.

Say it with T-shirts

European tours for most Sunday league teams involve boozing, shaving foam and broken marriages. Not so Philosophy Football, the team run by the T-shirt manufacturers of the same name. In their games in Rome this weekend, they're giving their opponents T-shirts with lengthy quotes by Umberto Eco and Antonio Gramsci, rather than dodgy pennants. As you do. Manager Geoff Andrew explains: 'We like playing in Italy because of the importance given to intellectual as well as physical energy, and the emphasis on style, creativity and ingenuity in the game.' Deep thinkers in the Leeds United team made pretty much the same point in their post-match interviews in the Olympic Stadium just the other night.

Diego in with a sniff

Brazil and Argentina's bitter football rivalry lives on, this time over who was the best player of the century - Pele or Maradona? A Fifa survey conducted over the internet, due out tomorrow, apparently bestows that title on Mr Hand of God rather than Mr God-Given Talent. Pele's admirers are understandably angry. 'It's a joke. Not even two Maradonas would surpass Pele', said Mario Zagallo, a team-mate in Brazil's World Cup wins in 1958 and 1962. 'Pele already is consecrated as the athlete of the century. Maradona is dreaming and should stay asleep.' Unfortunately, despite their respective records - three World Cup and over 1,200 goals versus the 1986 World Cup, a Serie A title with Napoli and loads of drugs - dastardly Diego seems set to win. The relative youth of the voters is to blame. Who was this Pele bloke anyway?

Signed calendar: winners

Brooklyn Beckham's first word - according to a Sun exclusive last month was 'scumbag' - not 'Gucci', 'Mummy' or 'Cash'. These are the winners of signed Becks or Michael Owen Danilo calendars - congratulations: Khasru Ali (London), Christian Klef (Copenhagen), Dave Pryce (London), Andy Lee (Surrey), Kieron Ashby (Liverpool), Megan Hughes (Cardiff), Willie Morrison (Dublin), Geoff Owen (Manchester), Nicole Richards (Hampshire), Amanda Barrett (Wiltshire).

Tales from the Tabs

THE SHIRT ON HIS BACK
Arsenal have already handed Swedish striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic the No 9 shirt last worn by Nicolas Anelka, even though Malmo insist the 19-year-old who bagged 12 goals for them last season is 'not for sale'.

HARTSON SEX BAN
Wimbledon manager Terry Burton has blamed his side's poor home form on players having sex the night before games at Selhurst Park. Hartson and Co may start staying in a hotel beforehand in order to conserve their energy.

And the rest...

Arsenal could re-sign Emmanuel Petit for as little as £1m within the next two months: Barcelona are desperate to offload the midfielder. Arsène Wenger also wants Swede wonder-teen Zlatan Ibrahimovic.

 Aston Villa are continuing to chase Benni McCarthy: 'Benni has told the Celta Vigo coach that he would love to go to the Premiership' says his agent.

 Bradford will sacrifice Matt Clarke for £5m to provide funds for a new midfielder - Jim Jefferies wants a left-sided player: 'I may have to step up my hunt'.

 Charlton have refused to release Carl Tiler to Huddersfield, but have listed Greg Shields.

 Chelsea have rebuffed another Barca bid for Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, but could sell Jody Morris to Leicester for £5m.

 Coventry have received a shock bid from Norwich to re-sign Craig Bellamy.

 Derby's Seth Johnson is a target for Leicester.

 Everton are leading Man City in the race for Bordeaux striker Lilian Laslandes, and could swap Danny Cadamarteri for Tranmere's Jason Koumas.

 New Ipswich striker Alun Armstrong says he's ready for the job: 'I'm completely clear of injury, I have lost weight and I'm as sharp as ever'.

 Leeds could sell Darren Huckerby to Celtic.

 Peter Taylor wants to take Villa's Lee Hendrie to Leicester.

 Liverpool have completed their deal for Croatian star Igor Biscan.

 Man City hope to sell Gareth Taylor to Luton at the start of next month.

 Man Utd scouts Martin Ferguson and Mick Brown are watching AEK's Fernando Navas.

 Middlesbrough could spend big to solve their striker crisis.

 Newcastle's deal for Sun Jihai could fall through after the sale of Alain Goma to West Ham was put on hold.

 Southampton have denied bidding for former Leicester keeper Kasey Keller - Rayo Vallecano are keen to sell.

 Sunderland reject Milton Nunez is a target for Atletico Celaya and Deportivo Toluca.

 Tottenham are eyeing up Roma midfielder Damiano Tomassi.

 West Ham are still watching Lille's Pascal Cygan, while Lazio fans have voted Di Canio the man they most want back.

It seems she went out to buy him a red-and-white shirt and mistakenly thought a Gooner one would do. 'I only wore it once', insists the man in one of football's real hotseats. His embarrassment may not be over yet. Fans group Shareholders United has offered to give any member of the Harverson clan £100 for the offending snap . 'Wearing an Arsenal kit is bad enough, but allowing yourself to be photographed in it doesn't augur well for a career in slick PR management', says the group's Oliver Houston. 'But he was only young at the time, and it could have been worse - it could have been a Leeds or Man City shirt!'. Say it with T-shirts European tours for most Sunday league teams involve boozing, shaving foam and broken marriages. Not so Philosophy Football, the team run by the T-shirt manufacturers of the same name. In their games in Rome this weekend, they're giving their opponents T-shirts with lengthy quotes by Umberto Eco and Antonio Gramsci, rather than dodgy pennants. As you do. Manager Geoff Andrew explains: 'We like playing in Italy because of the importance given to intellectual as well as physical energy, and the emphasis on style, creativity and ingenuity in the game.' Deep thinkers in the Leeds United team made pretty much the same point in their post-match interviews in the Olympic Stadium just the other night. Diego in with a sniff Brazil and Argentina's bitter football rivalry lives on, this time over who was the best player of the century - Pele or Maradona? A Fifa survey conducted over the internet, due out tomorrow, apparently bestows that title on Mr Hand of God rather than Mr God-Given Talent. Pele's admirers are understandably angry. 'It's a joke. Not even two Maradonas would surpass Pele', said Mario Zagallo, a team-mate in Brazil's World Cup wins in 1958 and 1962. 'Pele already is consecrated as the athlete of the century. Maradona is dreaming and should stay asleep.' Unfortunately, despite their respective records - three World Cup and over 1,200 goals versus the 1986 World Cup, a Serie A title with Napoli and loads of drugs - dastardly Diego seems set to win. The relative youth of the voters is to blame. Who was this Pele bloke anyway? These are the winners of signed Becks or Michael Owen Danilo calendars - congratulations: Khasru Ali (London), Christian Klef (Copenhagen), Dave Pryce (London), Andy Lee (Surrey), Kieron Ashby (Liverpool), Megan Hughes (Cardiff), Willie Morrison (Dublin), Geoff Owen (Manchester), Nicole Richards (Hampshire), Amanda Barrett (Wiltshire). Tales from the Tabs THE SHIRT ON HIS BACK Arsenal have already handed Swedish striker Zlatan Ibrahimovic the No 9 shirt last worn by Nicolas Anelka, even though Malmo insist the 19-year-old who bagged 12 goals for them last season is 'not for sale'. HARTSON SEX BAN Wimbledon manager Terry Burton has blamed his side's poor home form on players having sex the night before games at Selhurst Park. Hartson and Co may start staying in a hotel beforehand in order to conserve their energy. And the rest... Arsenal could re-sign Emmanuel Petit for as little as £1m within the next two months: Barcelona are desperate to offload the midfielder. webTitle: Money can't buy Advocaat love

fields.headline: Money can't buy Advocaat love
fields.standfirst: Ibrox renaissance is set back by lack of depth in a squad that is unattractive to top players
fields.trailText: Ibrox renaissance is set back by lack of depth in a squad that is unattractive to top players, reports Glenn Gibbons.
fields.body:
Whatever other interpretation may be placed on Rangers' pathetic attempt to resist Kaiserslautern's advances in last Thursday's Uefa Cup tie, it was certainly a reminder to Dick Advocaat that the apparently considerable distance between those two extremes, deification and vilification, can be travelled in a remarkably short time.

Less than two weeks after the acclaim he received for the 5-1 victory over Celtic that was perceived as the start of a long-lasting renaissance at Ibrox, the little Dutchman was restored to the status of a mere mortal, his team selection, tactics and motivational powers once again the primary targets of disaffected supporters.

These are trying times for Advocaat, who seems genuinely puzzled by the high expectations of the media in relation to Rangers' exploits on the continent. Curiously, he appears to believe that the club's followers have a more realistic attitude, a notion of which he would be disabused by spending five minutes in the company of the majority.

One of Advocaat's most frequently committed errors is to try to induce a sense of perspective in journalists and fans after damage has been sustained. This is a clear failure to recognise that anticipation of success against the cream of Europe is invariably heightened by his own - and especially his chairman, David Murray's - rather bombastic pronouncements in advance of each campaign.

Every time the level of the Ibrox club's debt is raised by another sortie in the transfer market - Advocaat has laid out £74 million in his 30 months at the club - he and Murray claim to have 'a squad that can take us to the next level in Europe,' implying that triumph at home is a foregone conclusion and that the Champions League is where the true merit of the team will be confirmed.

Murray reached an all-time high (or is it low?) in this regard in 1997, when he bankrolled Walter Smith's last summer spree. Having spent about £18 million the chairman trumpeted that 'we now have in place a squad that is capable of winning the European Cup by the turn of the century.'

In the event, Rangers that season collapsed at the first hurdle in the Champions League and failed to win a single trophy at home, Smith left and Advocaat took his place.

When the Dutchman arrived, he considered that the squad Murray had claimed could become champions of Europe by 2000 contained only three players - Lorenzo Amoruso, Jorg Albertz and Sergio Porrini - he considered first-team standard. Advocaat dwelled on this lack of quality on Friday when he made a spirited defence of his work.

But it was in a quieter hour, the day before the rout in Kaiserslautern, that he was more contemplative, more willing to discuss his own position, his outlook, and the limited potential at Scottish clubs, even if they are as big as Rangers and Celtic. He made it clear that he is likely to remain at Ibrox for the 18 months left on his contract. It was, however, impossible to avoid the inference that he will not remain beyond its expiry.

'Rangers are the best club I've ever had,' he said. 'The best stadium, the best supporters, the best chairman. Why should I run away from the job? If I go, it won't be sudden. I have 18 months to go on my contract.'

At this point, the introduction of a little false modesty: 'But, of course, it's not just about me. It's both parties. Not just a question of what I want, but what Rangers want.' What Rangers (that is, Murray) want is to secure his signature on an extension to his present agreement; there is no chance of his being sacked.

'But this is a relentlessly demanding job. At PSV Eindhoven, my normal media work in a week would be talking to four journalists on a Friday. That was it. You know what it's like here - very demanding. I can handle that, but there are times when decisions you make are highlighted in the media because somebody is complaining.

'For example, I decide who plays and where and when, nobody else. If you are scared to drop a player, you are not a good manager. There was controversy when I dropped Ruud Gullit at the 1994 World Cup when I was manager of Holland. But Ruud and I are still friends, he knows it was a decision I had to take.

'But, no matter how ambitious you may be, there are certain things you can't do. Dennis Bergkamp and Sylvain Wiltord were on the Arsenal bench against Bayern Munich last week. Rangers will never be able to attract players of that quality in the numbers the bigger clubs can.

'That doesn't just apply to Scotland. At PSV, I tried to sign Robert Pires when he was with Metz, but he simply did not want to come to Holland. When I arrived at Ibrox, there were only three strong players. Don't get me wrong about Walter Smith. He was a great Rangers manager. I still speak to him regularly. At the home match with Kaiserslautern, he and Graeme Souness came to my office and we had a drink and a good talk before the game. It's good to meet with them, because they are the only men who understand the job I have.'

Understanding does not come easily to fans on the outside and, if the championship is lost to Celtic in the wake of another European debacle, Advocaat will be able to reflect on his current difficulties as 'the good times'.
