webTitle: Janney sinks sorry Lincoln

fields.headline: Janney sinks sorry Lincoln
fields.standfirst: League and Cup review
fields.trailText: League and Cup review.
fields.body:
The FA Cup second round brought further embarrassment to Nationwide League teams.

The ones with particular cause to take a critical look at themselves were Lincoln City, who fell 1-0 at home to Dagenham and Redbridge - a last-minute goal by Mark Janney; Cambridge United, who fell 2-1 at Morecambe and Oxford United, who were two goals ahead at Chester but crashed 3-2.

Another team with red faces were Orient, who found themselves 3-2 behind at Northwich - after being 2-0 in front - and scrambled to a draw through a Chris Tate goal eight minutes from the end.

Such signs of vulnerability are rather more difficult to detect at the top of the First Division, where Fulham increased their lead to 10 points with a stunning 3-1 win at West Bromwich Albion. Fulham midfielder scored their first two goals - both crackers - and after Des Lyttle had given the home team a glimmer of hope, Andre Stolcers put them firmly in their place again.

In addition Fulham and Chesterfield (the only teams unbeaten away), Wimbledon also have an excellent record on opponents' grounds.

However, their players might well have viewed the 3-0 win at Birmingham with mixed feelings - and that also applies to their wives and girlfriends.

In an interview in The Sun, Wimbledon's manager, Terry Burton, had suggested that the contrast between his team's results at home and away might have had something to do with the fact that his players usually spend the eve of an away game in a hotel on their own.

To Burton, the good thing about that is that there is little danger of their energy being sapped by too much sex. Wimbledon have won as many as seven of their First Division away matches this season - compared to only one victory at Selhurst Park - and Burton said: 'Maybe they are rampant when they stay at home the night before a game and are then worn out for the game.

'Right now, we have no plans to put them in a hotel before home matches - but who knows?'

The latest away success was some result - not least because Wimbledon's centre-forward, John Hartson, was sent off. Wimbledon were 2-0 ahead when he was banished after 67 minutes, but Birmingham's hopes of a comeback were destroyed by a second goal from Damien Francis.

Being 'rampant' - in the way Burton interprets it - is clearly no problem for QPR, the only team who have yet to win away. and a side who have not exactly been impressive at home either.

Before the trip to Blackburn, their manager, Gerry Francis, had said: 'We have been letting in some disappointing goals, so we've been working hard this week to tighten that up.'

It seemed to work because, apart from a penalty which Matt Jansen missed, Blackburn had few clear chances. However, QPR's run without an away win continued; they had to settle for a goalless draw.

It was two points lost rather than one gained for them, because the teams below them in the bottom three - Huddersfield and Stockport - both won.

Blackburn defender Darren Peacock has announced his retirement from the game on medical advice.

The decision follows a serious neck injury Peacock sustained while playing on loan for Wolves at Fulham last month.

'It is disappointing to say the least and not how I planned to end my career, but the medical people said it would be too risky for me to play on,' said Peacock, who joined Blackburn on a free in June 1998 from Newcastle United.

webTitle: Hibs quick to cut lead

fields.headline: Hibs quick to cut lead
fields.standfirst: Scottish round-up
fields.trailText: Scottish round-up.
fields.body:
Hibernian had no problems in cutting Celtic's lead at the top to four points - at least temporarily - against a Dunfermline team who could count themselves fortunate that the victory margin was not more than 3-0.

Dunfermline, with a number of players unavailable because of injury or suspension, struggled to create any worthwhile attacks.

The star of the Hibernian show was Russell Latapy. Hibs had gone ahead after five minutes through Ulrik Laursen.

Then, after Dunfermline's Rob Matthaei was sent off in the 32nd minute for aiming a kick at Stuart Lovell, Latapy engineered the other goals for David Zitelli and Mixu Paatelainen after the interval.

The second, the climax to a thrilling Latapy dribble through the Dunfermline defence, was special by any standards.

It was not until 10 minutes from time that a demoralised Dunfermline came close to scoring - a Steve Crawford effort that hit the bar.

Later, Dunfermline's manager, Jimmy Calderwood, launched a scathing attack on Stockport County manager Andy Kilner over the latter's refusal to allow Andy Tod to return to East End Park before the end of the player's three-month loan period with the English club.

'It just shows you the standards of some so-called managers,' Calderwood said. 'Some people down in England have got big problems.'

St Johnstone were also home winners against St Mirren, clinching their 2-0 success with goals from John Paul McBride and Keigan Parker.

St Mirren had their chances, but lacked the finishing touch displayed by the home side.

McBride broke the deadlock three minutes before half-time, from a Parker cross. Thirteen minutes from the end, at a time when St Mirren looked capable of getting back into the game, the 18-year-old Parker killed them off with a volley from a Paul Kane pass.

One player who will be delighted to see Neil Lennon making his Celtic debut today is Gavin Rae, the Dundee midfielder who would be opposing him.

'He looks a great player,' said Rae. 'He is value for money at the fee Celtic have paid for him, and definitely brings something different - more quality - to their side. That's why I am hoping I will get the chance to play against him today. It will be a big test for me.'

Lennon, who has described his move from Leicester to Celtic as a 'dream transfer', feels that he would not have reached this stage but for the help he had from Crewe's manager, Dario Gradi, at the start of his career.

Referring to the back injury that put him out of action for a year, he said: 'I will always be indebted to them for the help they gave me. They could have let me go, but instead they paid for the operation and did all the rehabilitation.

'It was a long, hard slog. But it makes you mentally stronger and more appreciative of coming to places like this.'

Celtic's manager, Martin O'Neill, is looking forward to the game and added: 'If you are looking for a team that will entertain and come and attack you, then Dundee are exactly that. They have a lot of attacking players and are good to watch. I almost guarantee that there will be goals.'

Rangers will be fancied to get plenty against a Motherwell defence that hardly covered itself in glory in last Sunday's 3-1 home defeat by Hibernian.

Still, one of their back men, Martyn Corrigan, sees no point in dwelling on such lapses. He feels that the Motherwell back four have improved as a unit and adds: 'If you look back on individual mistakes, you can lose confidence. We are intent on looking forward.'

webTitle: Canvey relish seaside showdown

fields.headline: Canvey relish seaside showdown
fields.trailText: Things Canvey Island is famous for: being the birthplace of the decathlete Dean Macey, fish and chips, as the place where you went on holiday as a child because Southend was too posh, producing an extra-ordinary number of Stars in their Eyes contestants, providing extras for Sky's football soap opera Dream Team .
fields.body:
Things Canvey Island is famous for: being the birthplace of the decathlete Dean Macey, fish and chips, as the place where you went on holiday as a child because Southend was too posh, producing an extra-ordinary number of Stars in their Eyes contestants, providing extras for Sky's football soap opera Dream Team .

Things Canvey Island is not famous for: having a decent football team.

Until now.

Over the last week the least picturesque part of the 'Essex Riviera' has been inundated by television cameras and reporters from national newspapers, all drawn east by the mysterious pull of the FA Cup.

Every season the Cup throws up one underdog club for the media to pat on the head and, after their shock win at Port Vale in the first round, Canvey are this year's team. But as the Ryman Premier League club, who play near-neighbours Southend at Roots Hall in the second round today, are keen to stress, this match is about more than romantic underdogs versus Third Division opposition.

This, after all, is a derby and as such contains all the requisite rivalry, envy and emotion, a brew made all the more potent by the contrast between the two seaside resorts. For if Canvey Island is where good Essex boys go to pop their cherries, Southend is where their grandparents go to spend their twilight years.

Yet there have also always been close links between the two clubs. Six of the current Canvey team have played for Southend, while one, midfielder Steve Tilson, plays for one of the teams and works as a youth development officer for the other.

Tilson admits that the team were delighted to draw Southend. 'It's great for the whole of Essex. Of course we're the underdogs but don't they always say that in a derby anything can happen.'

The Canvey manager Jeff King, who has taken his team through half a dozen non-league promotions agrees, although he also admits to finding the sudden attention a bit much. 'I'm not really used to it and it's bloody tiring. It's become a much bigger occasion than I thought.'

Yet for all King's mock annoyance, he also admits that there the derby element adds an extra frisson to the occasion. 'This game is not just about the cup,' he said. 'It's probably Essex's biggest game for years.'

Tilson believes that the local aspect of the game makes it less daunting. 'It'll be very tight but we aren't frightened by them so it'll be 2-1 to us,' he said. 'Then after that they can bring on Manchester United.'

Every season the Cup throws up one underdog club for the media to pat on the head and, after their shock win at Port Vale in the first round, Canvey are this year's team. But as the Ryman Premier League club, who play near-neighbours Southend at Roots Hall in the second round today, are keen to stress, this match is about more than romantic underdogs versus Third Division opposition. This, after all, is a derby and as such contains all the requisite rivalry, envy and emotion, a brew made all the more potent by the contrast between the two seaside resorts. For if Canvey Island is where good Essex boys go to pop their cherries, Southend is where their grandparents go to spend their twilight years. Yet there have also always been close links between the two clubs. Six of the current Canvey team have played for Southend, while one, midfielder Steve Tilson, plays for one of the teams and works as a youth development officer for the other. Tilson admits that the team were delighted to draw Southend. 'It's great for the whole of Essex. Of course we're the underdogs but don't they always say that in a derby anything can happen.' The Canvey manager Jeff King, who has taken his team through half a dozen non-league promotions agrees, although he also admits to finding the sudden attention a bit much. 'I'm not really used to it and it's bloody tiring. It's become a much bigger occasion than I thought.' Yet for all King's mock annoyance, he also admits that there the derby element adds an extra frisson to the occasion. 'This game is not just about the cup,' he said. 'It's probably Essex's biggest game for years.' Tilson believes that the local aspect of the game makes it less daunting. 'It'll be very tight but we aren't frightened by them so it'll be 2-1 to us,' he said. 'Then after that they can bring on Manchester United.'

webTitle: United lead chase for the Japanese Beckham

fields.headline: United lead chase for the Japanese Beckham
fields.standfirst: Brendan Pittaway on the £10m battle to sign Hidetoshi Nakata
fields.trailText: Brendan Pittaway on the £10m battle to sign Hidetoshi Nakata.
fields.body:
Manchester United could lose out to their Premiership arch-rivals Arsenal and Chelsea in a £10 million battle for the right to sign Japanese superstar midfielder Hidetoshi Nakata.

Nakata, aged 23, currently plays for Roma in Serie A but has revealed to friends that he wants a move to one of the giants of English football at the end of this season. After learning of his desire to quit Italy, United officials have made contact with the Rome club although they have not yet made a formal offer.

United, top of their Champions' League group and strongly placed for another winning season, will prove hard to turn down, and if Nakata heads for Old Trafford it will provide more frustration for Chelsea. Gianluca Vialli inquired after the player in August - just before he was fired - but was told by chairman Ken Bates that the cash wasn't available.

Arsenal have also expressed an interest but Nakata is keen on a move to the North West. He has told friends: 'Rome is a wonderful place but it is suffocating me. I have no privacy and I need a change, not just a change of city but a change of country. I know Roma would not sell me to another rival club in Serie A so I must look abroad. I'd like to play in England and where better than a club that can win trophies, a club like Manchester United. They are a great team and I know I could help them.'

Roma are top of Serie A but even with the possibility of a league title and Champions' League place next year, Nakata is said to believe that his opportunities are limited. A close friend added: 'Hidetoshi feels that there's too much emphasis at the club placed on star players like Francesco Totti and Gabriel Batistuta and while he has developed technically and physically during his time in Italy, he needs a fresh challenge.'

In addition to the interest of United and Arsenal, reigning European champions Real Madrid, Barcelona, Marseille and Monaco have also declared their intention of trying to sign Nakata.

United could have bought him at the beginning of last year for far less than his current asking price. Rupert Murdoch reportedly attempted to bring Nakata to United shortly before Nakata joined Roma from fellow Serie A side Perugia last year. Sources in Italy claim representatives of the media tycoon unsuccessfully bid £8m for the player when BSkyB were trying to take control of Old Trafford.

But it's not only the ability shown by Nakata on the pitch that has aroused the interest of the Premiership's leading lights. The player - dubbed 'Japan's David Beckham' for his fashion sense and legions of teenage girl fans - is a massive commercial phenomenon. In addition to his contract with Roma - worth £30,000 a week - Nakata earns several million pounds more from commercial endorsements and would benefit any club seeking to exploit football's growing appeal in the Far East.

United know this and should they go for Nakata they stand to reap significant commercial rewards. On Thursday, indeed, chief executive Peter Kenyon announced a three-game summer tour of Asia next year to consolidate their popularity there.

Nakata's Premiership intentions represent a significant change of heart. While still playing in Japan's J-League with Bellmare Hiratsuka, he declared a wish to play in Europe but added: 'I'd prefer Italy or Spain. The English league is too hard, too physical.' Bellmare had been one of 11 of the 12 teams in Japan that tried to recruit Nakata straight from school.

One of the stars of the Japanese team that beat pre-tournament favourites Brazil at the Atlanta Olympics in 1996, Nakata was voted Asian footballer of the Year two years later but he insisted: 'It annoys me to think I am seen as a flag-bearer. When I was in Japan, I just thought about playing and nothing else. I didn't want to be anybody's idol.'

webTitle: United and Co are not worthy

fields.headline: United and Co are not worthy
fields.trailText: The Worthington Cup gives lesser lights a chance to shine - and Alan Smith approves.
fields.body:
The magic of the cup is an expression we hear less and less these days, which is a sad indictment of the modern game. This week in the Worthington Cup, we at Crystal Palace take on Sunderland, Fulham play Liverpool and there are two other First Division sides in the quarter-finals - Birmingham and Sheffield Wednesday.

No Manchester United, Arsenal or Chelsea in there, but this is a competition some of the bigger clubs do not take too seriously these days. And let's face it, if Manchester United can treat the FA Cup so lightly that they did not enter it last season, why would they take the Worthington Cup any more seriously?

But the bigger clubs' loss is our gain, and this competition is now the best chance for First Division and smaller Premiership clubs to have a big day out, though sadly not at Wembley for a few years to come. Whereas the FA Cup used to be the stage for giant-killings and unlikely dreams, the finals tend to be contested between the big boys now. Yet the Worthington Cup finals in recent years have seen sides such as Leicester, Middlesbrough and Tranmere have their big day out at Wembley.

It is still a route into Europe, too, which is why you will find the bigger clubs do start to take it seriously once they get within sight of the English Channel. Tottenham, for example, who have a proud record in European competition, had not qualified for almost a decade until they won the Worthington Cup two seasons ago. Try telling Spurs and their supporters that it is called the Worthless Cup in some quarters.

It is not just about glory but money, too. Football is such a costly business now that every game helps to generate valuable revenue. After we beat Tranmere Rovers on penalties in the last round, their manager, John Aldridge, was devastated because he told me that last season's run to the final had set them up financially for the following year.

The fact that we are playing Sunderland reminds me that they were involved in one of the FA Cup's greatest stories, when Bob Stokoe's side from the old Second Division beat Leeds in 1973. You cannot see that happening now. The gulf between the top sides in the Premiership and the rest is simply too great, which is why the last real upset was 12 years ago, when Wimbledon beat Liverpool in the final.

Of course there will still be upsets. The greatest cup game I have ever been involved in was the FA Cup semi-final in 1990, when Palace beat Liverpool. Having lost 9-0 at Anfield earlier that season, nobody - not even ourselves - gave us much of a chance at Villa Park. When Liverpool went 1-0 up, we looked along the bench to see Kenny Dalglish, Ronnie Moran and the rest and their expressions suggested they were expecting to give us another thrashing.

But we came back to win an amazing game 4-3 and reach the final against Manchester United. While that was the tail-end of the great Liverpool era of the Seventies and Eighties, it was the beginning of United's dominance.

Sir Alex Ferguson, then just plain Alex, was close to being sacked before United's cup run, and even at Wembley you could read the anxiety on his face, which was not helped when we held them to a 3-3 draw. But United won the replay - their first trophy under Alex. It is a truism in football that the first win makes everything else easier - it gives the players and staff the self-belief and confidence to do anything.

Despite the sports science surrounding the game, psychology is still so important. I remember Nick Faldo saying that 90 per cent of golf is played in the mind - physical ability counts for only the remaining 10 per cent.

The split may be different in football, but it is there nevertheless. I think it is fair to say we produced the biggest shock in this season's Worthington Cup when we beat the holders Leicester City 3-0 at Filbert Street. They were riding high in the Premiership and had hardly conceded any goals before that night, while we were in the First Division's relegation zone after a win of six successive defeats and had struggled to beat Cardiff and Burnley in previous rounds.

But everything we hit went into the net, while our defence kept out everything Leicester threw at us. The beauty of football is that such an unlikely result can still happen, and that happens mostly in the cup. Long may it continue.

webTitle: Land of love, blood, sex and death. And a mighty splash

fields.headline: Land of love, blood, sex and death. And a mighty splash
fields.standfirst: Opening our themed issue,  Euan Ferguson finds himself well and truly tangoed
fields.trailText: Opening our themed issue, Euan Ferguson finds himself well and truly tangoed.
fields.body:
When you think what Europe has given Argentina down the centuries - hundreds of poor, moaning Welsh farmers; the planet's most notorious Nazi war criminals; Pedro de Mendoza and his murderous conquistadors; Max Hastings yomping pompously into Port Stanley; Jeremy Irons overacting dolorously in The Mission; and the comparatively benign offerings of Catholicism, scrofula and Sun headlines - it's a wonder they don't turn us back at Buenos Aires's groovy new airport with a clack of silvered heels and a polite request to take off before we start introducing ugliness, or vegetarianism.

They don't, of course. They're too well-mannered, too friendly, too European themselves. And they're happy these days for people to see their gloriously eclectic country. Too often in recent years, it seems, Argentina has been used simply as a jumping-off point for South America in general - Peru, Chile, Patagonia - by the type of backpacker who wants to 'find himself' (stink) for six months before coming safely back to his Ladbroke Grove trust fund with a knot round his wrist and absurd hygiene theories.

So the grown-up thing to do is stay inside the borders, spend a little money and savour the oddnesses and beauties of this proud and bizarre country, from soup to nuts, tropics to tundra. There's so much to enjoy about Argentina - heady nights in the capital, all art and dance and tales and drink, or the life-affirming serenity of the pampas, and all of it floodingly scented with history, awash with love and blood, sex and death - that it's hard to take in on one trip.

But it would be daft to go to this continent without a trip north to Iguazu Falls, South America's Niagara. Here, after 800 miles gathering anger across Brazil, the river reaches the end of a high plateau on the border with Argentina and Paraguay and, as reality itself appears to schism, hurls itself into space with the force of a great sea tumbling off the edge of the world.

You can follow walkways high and low almost all the way round the 275 cataracts - some, like the seriously frightening Garganta del Diablo (Devil's Throat), falling 270 feet straight to the teeth of the gorge with a booming power that soaks you with spray and adrenalin, others catching outcrops on the way to send jets streaming towards the ferns and macaws and orchids of the surrounding jungle. There are grand views too from the Brazilian side, to which you can cross temporarily with a little organisation. But the best views are from below, by boat: walk to the foot of the gorge and board one of the 'ribs' which speed out and under the highest of the falls: you'll return soaked, but exhilarated if not downright delirious.

For falls which are more impressive (by all accounts) than Niagara, Iguazu is charmingly uncluttered with tourists. Still, if you want to get completely away from humanity, try spending a night or two at the nearby Yacutinga eco-lodge in the tropical heart of the huge protected 'green corridor' shared by Brazil and Argentina. Peace envelops you as warmly as the foliage, and days can be spent drifting in canoes in search of the perfect toucan and the scariest spider, or just eating by the pool, readying yourself for the lurch back into Buenos Aires.

Astoundingly European with its wide colonial avenues, belle epoque architecture and waterfronts worn from the first steps of generations of Italians, Spanish, Germans and British seeking the new Europe, the capital is reminiscent of Lisbon, perhaps, or Paris before the bombing, albeit with many more inhabitants - 13 million at the last count. You could stay for two weeks easily, just learning your history and wandering between flea-markets and public gardens; but there are two or three trips which you should try to make, even if simply passing through.

La Recoleta is a cemetery in the way that Iguazu is a waterfall. A strange and beautiful city of the dead, this necropolis covers acres of Buenos Aires' most exclusive land with impossible plinths and black marble obelisks and hauntingly surreal Deco sculpture. People save up their entire lives to die here. I was reluctant to leave until, at the Duarte family tomb wherein lies the body of Eva Peron, a fat, ringletted American - sporting, unaccountably, what appeared to be a velour kettledrum around her waist - decided to enhance the quiet reflection of the moment by screeching 'Don't Cry For Me Argentina', which was saddening, not least because I once vowed to get through life without having Lloyd Webber sung in front of me again except by someone holding a loaded pistol.

It took three fabulous ice-creams and a trip to the Tigre delta to rid my face of its rictus of fascinated loathing. But two minutes on the river and cares fly. The delta, a labyrinthine twist of scores of miles of criss-crossing brown water surrounding lush woodland, is where Buenos Aires, rich and poor, comes to play on weekends and holidays. Lumpen coracles and belching river buses jostle the sleek speedboats, all sending a high dirty wash blattering against the pilings of a thousand riverside homes. These range from peeling ramshackle hutches to glittering simulacrums of Versailles, but high- and low-born swim, tan and feast together and the effect is colourful, easy, wet and rather wonderful.

Take time on the way back to cruise through the San Isidro district, a kind of Hampstead of Buenos Aires, with its fine churches and views, and try not to be put off by the thought that many happy years were also spent here by Josef Mengele, thanks to Juan Peron's liberal attitude to post-war passports for architects of the destruction of European Jewry.

The waterfront in the centre is where you'll want to feed: every other capital waterfront in the world may also have been converted into ritzy wine bars, but this one's been done well. The old town itself, however, is still marvellous for food, and for decent tango clubs. Pass, too, through the other waterfront area, La Boca, once the archetypal dodgy dockside roughhouse where the tango began in brothels and wharf-rats skewered each other for the love of a good dancer (sex and death, again).

The secret of the pampas - the almost unimaginably flat, yawning grasslands where eight million cattle are suitably prepared for their eventual role in the kitchen by spending their days in one vast smooth pan - is to stop. Driving endlessly through the pampas is, frankly, boring. Stop, however, and you will hear the birds, and the water, and smell the clear air and the eucalyptus. Best of all is to stop at a ranch for a night or so, as we did at the elegant Estancia La Josefina, about 150 km south of the capital, there to sit and breathe in one long bucolic sigh. Tiny puppies played gently beneath the legs of our horses as we rode grass tracks with the so-dapper gauchos, later returning to feast outside on about 17 differently delicious barbe cued cuts of the farm's own beef. A soft wind blowing in the trees above was all there was to remind us that time had not stopped.

Which made San Carlos de Bariloche a shock. We had seen so much, learnt so much, of Argentina that this new diversity shouldn't have surprised; but, still, landing suddenly in Heidi's home town a day later raised a few (half-frozen) eyebrows. Snowy fjords, icy waterfalls, gay wooden chalets and welcoming hot chocolate emporiums ... finding the Tyrol in northern Patagonia was odd. It was almost a delight, being another glimpse of this rivetingly different country. But for me, there was a touch too much history; this was where Martin Bormann and Erich Priebke hid until taken by Mossad, and a certain red-cheeked Teutonic hand-rubbing cheerfulness to its Christmassy tweeness, made it seem simply too foreign, too many miles from the land's own history, from its unruly Mediterranean passions, from its heroic tales of Simon Bolivar and José de San Martin and Manuel Belgrano, from all the sex and all the death.

Still, our hotel, the fairly magnificent Llao Llao, would be a wonderful way to relax with spas and golf and apres-ski comfort if you were that way inclined, and the surroundings are fabulous, tugging the heart further down into Patagonia, towards the near-mystical Tierra del Fuego. Next trip, perhaps. If I can come via all the love and anger of the tango again, and skip the lederhosen.

Getting there

Abercrombie & Kent tailor-make itineraries to Argentina. Nine nights taking in Buenos Aires and Bariloche costs from £2,895. This includes BA flights from London to Buenos Aires, internal flights with Aerolineas Argentinas, all transfers, four nights B&B at the Sheraton Park Towers and four nights B&B at the Llao Llao Hotel. Phone 0845 0700 614.

Best of all is to stop at a ranch for a night or so, as we did at the elegant Estancia La Josefina, about 150 km south of the capital, there to sit and breathe in one long bucolic sigh. Tiny puppies played gently beneath the legs of our horses as we rode grass tracks with the so-dapper gauchos, later returning to feast outside on about 17 differently delicious barbe cued cuts of the farm's own beef. A soft wind blowing in the trees above was all there was to remind us that time had not stopped. Which made San Carlos de Bariloche a shock. We had seen so much, learnt so much, of Argentina that this new diversity shouldn't have surprised; but, still, landing suddenly in Heidi's home town a day later raised a few (half-frozen) eyebrows. Snowy fjords, icy waterfalls, gay wooden chalets and welcoming hot chocolate emporiums ... finding the Tyrol in northern Patagonia was odd. It was almost a delight, being another glimpse of this rivetingly different country. But for me, there was a touch too much history; this was where Martin Bormann and Erich Priebke hid until taken by Mossad, and a certain red-cheeked Teutonic hand-rubbing cheerfulness to its Christmassy tweeness, made it seem simply too foreign, too many miles from the land's own history, from its unruly Mediterranean passions, from its heroic tales of Simon Bolivar and José de San Martin and Manuel Belgrano, from all the sex and all the death. Still, our hotel, the fairly magnificent Llao Llao, would be a wonderful way to relax with spas and golf and apres-ski comfort if you were that way inclined, and the surroundings are fabulous, tugging the heart further down into Patagonia, towards the near-mystical Tierra del Fuego. Next trip, perhaps. If I can come via all the love and anger of the tango again, and skip the lederhosen. Getting there Abercrombie & Kent tailor-make itineraries to Argentina. Nine nights taking in Buenos Aires and Bariloche costs from £2,895. This includes BA flights from London to Buenos Aires, internal flights with Aerolineas Argentinas, all transfers, four nights B&B at the Sheraton Park Towers and four nights B&B at the Llao Llao Hotel. Phone 0845 0700 614.

webTitle: From: Vicky (10 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Vicky
fields.trailText: When you're in Washington, try Paparazzi, on Wisconsin, for a more expensive drink. Then just carry on down to M street till you find other bars to knock around in. Mr Smith's has a live pianist who leads the assembled throng in a sing-a-long at the weekends, with a band upstairs.
fields.body:
Hi Sam,

I'm just back from working in Washington DC for a few months. It's a great city to explore - I hope the following tips help.

Visit the Kennedy Center - a massive performing arts venue built in memory of JFK. There's a free "Millennium Stages" concert there every night at 6pm, and you can tour the centre itself during the day. Some of the concerts are great - international artists as well as the national symphony orchestra have played there as part of the season. It's right by Watergate as well, and offers an unrivalled view of the city from the roof. Take the metro to Foggy Bottom, where a free shuttle bus will pick you up and deliver you to the centre's door. From there, head back to Capitol Hill (Union Station metro on the red line). The Union Station food court - right next to the metro - offers a variety of food that'll keep you going for the rest of the day.

After refuelling, head towards the Capitol and walk straight down the mall to the Lincoln Memorial - a long walk, but it's worth it. You'll pass joggers, (sorry - you're trying to get away from them!), but it's a great place to see people enjoy the city. Along the way, stop in at the Smithsonian Museums which line the Mall. The best are Natural History and American History (get there early for a ticket for the American Presidency exhibition). Air and Space is the most popular museum in the world, but its exhibits look a little tired now. Watch out - the museums close at 5.30, so don't miss them. The Newseum in Arlington (Rosslyn Metro) is great - with very up to date exhibits on how the media screwed up its election coverage, and like all museums in the area, it's free. And if you're interested in the press, call the Washington Post to arrange a tour - they only offer them on Mondays. You'll get to see the newsroom, and hear a little bit about the history of the place. It's also free. You can also take a tour of the Pentagon, the FBI building and the White House, all of which are worthwhile if you have the time.

At night, head for Georgetown - a taxi to M and Wisconsin streets is your best bet - the metro is a bit of a hike. Try Paparazzi, on Wisconsin, for a more expensive drink. Then just carry on down to M street till you find other bars to knock around in. Mr Smith's has a live pianist who leads the assembled throng in a sing-a-long at the weekends, with a band upstairs. There's even a British bar - The Guards - should you get a bit homesick. And during the day Georgetown offers good shopping, and it's a beautiful walk along the canal which runs parallel to M Street.

Adams Morgan is also a good bet for nightlife. Try Tryst on Columbia Road for a relaxed beer - but it does get crowded at peak times. Always carry your passport if you want to get into a bar - they are very strict about ID in America. You have to be over 21 to drink, but if you look under 30 they WILL ask you for proof of your age. And nothing but a passport or a US driver's licence works. And be prepared to talk about politics all night - everyone in DC, be they a journalist, lawyer or poltiical staffer, talks about it all night in the bars - especially at the moment.

Wrap up warmly - it's freezing out there! I'm just back from a tour of the States - camping from New York to San Francisco - via Louisiana, Texas, the Grand Canyon, Las Vegas and lots of other places in between, before backpacking solo up the west coast to Seattle, Chicago, up into Canada, and then back down to Boston, Philadelphia, and finally DC. If I can be of any help on the rest of your tour, don't hesitate to email me.
All the best

Hi there Sue!

I am following your travels in the Guardian and have just read your first report. I do hope you're adjusting to your new and changing surroundings. You're a great role model to us forty and fifty somethings :-) (In case you're missing home, it's still very wet here although this morning was sunny with some lovely autumnal colours still around. Enjoy your journey.

webTitle: Let's go!

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: 'The Man Who Drew Pooh' | Clotheshow | 'A Child's Christmas in Wales'
fields.body:
See 'The Man Who Drew Pooh', an exhibition of the illustrations of E. H. Shepard. Dulwich Picture Gallery (020 8693 5254). Open 11am-5pm. Adults £4, children free.

Catch the fashion trends and rub shoulders with modelsand designers at the Clotheshow, Birmingham NEC. Open 9am-6.30pm. Admission £19.50 (0870 264 5555)

Enjoy an evening of poetry, including Dylan Thomas's 'A Child's Christmas in Wales' at The Rhondda Heritage Park, Trehafod, Pontypridd. 7pm. Adults £3, children £2.50. Phone for availability (01443 682 036).

'Apocalypse' at the Royal Academy (020 7300 8000) closes on Friday, so if you've yet to see the Pope being struck by a meteorite... Open 10am-6pm, Burlington House, Piccadilly. £8.

Try the Manchester German Christmas Market for hand-blown glass, wooden toys and decorations. St Ann's Square, 10am-8pm.

Follow forest trails to Carron Crag on a guided walk from Hawkshead Tourist Information Centre, Cumbria. Turn up at 10am with a packed lunch for the nine-mile walk. Free.

Enjoy music, carols, sonnets and steel bands at the Christmas Market in Lincoln - the largest in the country. Open 10am to 9pm, Castle Square. Free.

Pick up half-price Paul Smith or Armani at the Pre-Christmas Designer Menswear Warehouse Sale in King's Cross (www.dwslondon.co.uk). 11am - 5pm. Admission £2. The Worx, 45 Balfe Street, London.

Follow the Santa Trail through Trebah Garden (01326 250448) in Cornwall. Open10.30am - 3pm. Cost £2 adults, £1.95 children.

Toys, comics, cards, videos and Pokemon products are for sale at the Sci-fi, Film & TV Collectors' Fair (01908 671138). Holiday Inn, Bristol, noon-4pm. £1 adults, 50p children.

webTitle: A blacklist burning for Bush

fields.headline: A blacklist burning for Bush
fields.standfirst: The more you look the more disbarred and 'disappeared' Gore voters you find. You'd almost think it was deliberate
fields.trailText: Hey, Al, take a look at this. Every time I cut open another alligator, I find the bones of more Gore voters. This week, I was hacking my way through the Florida swampland known as the Office of Secretary of State Katherine Harris and found a couple thousand more names of voters electronically 'disappeared' from the vote rolls. About half of those named are African-Americans. They had the right to vote, but they never made it to the balloting booths.
fields.body:
Hey, Al, take a look at this. Every time I cut open another alligator, I find the bones of more Gore voters. This week, I was hacking my way through the Florida swampland known as the Office of Secretary of State Katherine Harris and found a couple thousand more names of voters electronically 'disappeared' from the vote rolls. About half of those named are African-Americans. They had the right to vote, but they never made it to the balloting booths.

When we left off our Florida story two weeks ago, The Observer discovered that Harris's office had ordered the elimination of 8,000 Florida voters on the grounds that they had committed felonies in other states. None had. Harris bought the bum list from a company called ChoicePoint, a firm whose Atlanta executive suite and boardroom are filled with Republican funders. ChoicePoint, we have learned, picked up the list of faux felons from state officials in - ahem - Texas. In fact, it was a roster of people who, like their Governor, George W, had committed nothing more than misdemeanours.

For Harris, Florida Governor Jeb Bush and his brother, the Texas blacklist was a mistake made in Heaven. Most of those targeted to have their names 'scrubbed' from the voter roles were African-Americans, Hispanics and poor white folk, likely voters for Vice-President Gore. We don't know how many voters lost their citizenship rights before the error was discovered by a few sceptical county officials, before ChoicePoint, which has gamely 'fessed-up to the Texas-sized error, produced a new list of 58,000 felons. In May, Harris sent on the new, improved scrub sheets to the county election boards. Maybe it's my bad attitude, but I thought it worthwhile to check out the new list. Sleuthing around county offices with a team of researchers from internet newspaper Salon.com, we discovered that the 'correct' list wasn't so correct.

One elections supervisor, Linda Howell of Madison County, was so upset by the errors that she refused to use the Harris/ChoicePoint list. How could she be so sure the new list identified innocent people as felons? Because her own name was on it, 'and I assure you, I am not a felon'.

Our 10-county review suggests a minimum 15 per cent misidentification rate. That makes another 7,000 innocent people accused of crimes and stripped of their citizenship rights in the run-up to the presidential race. And not just any 7,000 people. Hillsborough (Tampa) county statisticians found that 54 per cent of the names on the scrub list belonged to African-Americans, who voted 93 per cent for Gore.

Now our team, diving deeper into the swamps, has discovered yet a third group whose voting rights were stripped. The ChoicePoint-generated list includes 1,704 names of people who, earlier in their lives, were convicted of felonies in Illinois and Ohio. Like most American states, these two restore citizenship rights to people who have served their time in prison and then remained on the good side of the law.

Florida strips those convicted in its own courts of voting rights for life. But Harris's office concedes, and county officials concur, that the state of Florida has no right to impose this penalty on people who have moved in from these other states. (Only 13 states, most in the Old Confederacy, bar reformed criminals from voting.)

Going deeper into the Harris lists, we find hundreds more convicts from the 35 other states which restored their rights at the end of sentences served. If they have the right to vote, why were these citizens barred from the polls? Harris didn't return my calls. But Alan Dershowitz did. The Harvard law professor, a renowned authority on legal process, said: 'What's emerging is a pattern of reducing the total number of voters in Florida, which they know will reduce the Democratic vote.'

How could Florida's Republican rulers know how these people would vote? I put the question to David Bositis, America's top expert on voting demographics. Once he stopped laughing, he said the way Florida used the lists from a private firm was, 'an obvious technique to discriminate against black voters'. In a darker mood, Bositis, of Washington's Center for Political and Economic Studies, said the sad truth of American justice is that 46 per cent of those convicted of felony are African-American. In Florida, a record number of black folk, over 80 per cent of those registered to vote, packed the polling booths on November 7. Behind the curtains, nine out of 10 black people voted Gore.

Mark Mauer of the Sentencing Project, Washington, pointed out that the 'white' half of the purge list would be peopled overwhelmingly by the poor, also solid Democratic voters.

Add it up. The dead-wrong Texas list, the uncorrected 'corrected' list, plus the out-of-state ex-con list. By golly, it's enough to swing a presidential election. I bet the busy Harris, simultaneously in charge of both Florida's voter rolls and George Bush's presidential campaign, never thought of that.

But enough is never enough, it seems. We have discovered a fourth group of Gore voters also barred from the polls.

It was Thursday, 2am. On the other end of the line, heavy breathing, then a torrent too fast for me to catch it all. 'Vile... lying... inaccurate... pack of nonsense... riddled with errors'... click! This was not a ChoicePoint whistleblower telling me about the company's notorious list. It was ChoicePoint's own media communications representative, Marty Fagan, communicating with me about my, 'sleazy disgusting journalism' in reporting on it.

I was curious about this company that appears - although never say never in this game - to have chosen the next President for America's voters. Its board dazzles with Republican stars, including billionaire Ken Langone and Home Depot tycoon Bernard Marcus, big Republican funders.

Florida is the only state to hire an outside firm to suggest who should lose citizenship rights. That may change. 'Given a new President, and what we accomplished in Florida, we expect to roll across the nation,' ChoicePoint told me ominously.

They have quite a pedigree for this solemn task. The company's Florida subsidiary, Database Technologies (now DBT Online), was founded by one Hank Asher. When US law enforcement agencies alleged that he may have been associated with Bahamian drug dealers - although no charges were brought - the company lost its data management contract with the FBI. Hank and his friends left last year and so, in Florida's eyes, the past is forgiven.

Thursday, 3am. (I should say both calls were at my request). A new, gentler voice giving me ChoicePoint's upbeat spin. 'You say we got over 15 per cent wrong - we like to look at that as up to 85 per cent right!' That's 7,000 votes-plus - the bulk Democrats, not to mention the thousands on the Texas list. Gore may lose by 500 votes.

I contacted San Francisco-based expert Mark Swedlund. 'It's just fundamental industry practice that you don't roll out the list statewide until you have tested it and tested it again,' he said. 'Dershowitz is right: they had to know that this jeopardised thousands of people's registrations. And they would also know the [racial] profile of those voters.'

'They' is Florida state, not ChoicePoint. Let's not get confused where the blame lies. Harris's crew lit this database fuse, then acted surprised when it blew up. Swedlund says ChoicePoint had a professional responsibility to tell the state to test the list; ChoicePoint says the state should not have used its 'raw' data.

Until Florida privatised its Big Brother powers, laws kept the process out in the open. This year, when one county asked to see ChoicePoint's formulas and back-up for blacklisting voters, they refused - these were commercial secrets. So we'll never know how America's president was chosen.

ChoicePoint complains that I said Harris signed their contract. It was a Beth Emory. I'm still more than 85 per cent accurate.

webTitle: A top hotel manager reveals all

fields.headline: A top hotel manager reveals all
fields.standfirst: Filip Boyen, manager of the Hotel Monasterio, Cusco, Peru
fields.trailText: Filip Boyen, manager of the Hotel Monasterio, Cusco, Peru.
fields.body:
New hotel?
Originally built in 1592 on the site of the palace of the Inca Amaru Qhala, the monastery is in the heart of Cusco, a historic city more than 11,000 feet up in the Andes with pre-Inca, Inca and Spanish colonial architecture.

Is the altitude a problem?

Everybody needs time to acclimatise: we recommend guests take it easy on their first day. The famous coca tea, which helps relieve the symptoms of altitude sickness, is available on a complimentary basis. Oxygen is also available in the hotel - five minutes of pure oxygen helps anyone. Generally most people are not hampered.

What sort of guests do you have?

The adventurous and culturally inspired of all ages. Tourist interest in Peru is growing rapidly. The airline industry is booming and we have also noticed a shift from the backpacker market to a more upmarket clientele.

How is Peru's heritage being preserved?

There has been a master plan in progress since 1998 for the preservation of the entire Sanctuary of Machu Picchu, which includes not only the ruins but also the town Aguas Calientes. This is being funded by a 'debt for nature' swap with Finland. At the moment there are no restrictions on the number of people entering the actual ruins, although from 1 January 2001 only 500 people per day will be permitted to do the Inca Trail.

What about sightseeing?

Cusco is full of highlights. We recommend the ancient fortress of Sacsayhuaman with its views over the city; the Loreto Alley with its incredible walls and famous Inca stone; the Santo Domingo Monastery and the Koricancha; and the Church of La Merced. And a night out?

Start the evening by watching the sunset from Sacsayhuaman and then a meal at our Restaurant Tupay. Cusco has a buzzing nightlife and is lit up beautifully at night.

And the guinea pigs?

Yes, 'cuy', a local delicacy. It is presented whole, including teeth. Other specialities are alpaca meat and pisco sour, a popular alcoholic drink. Fermented grapes make the pisco, which is blended with lemon, ice, egg white and sometimes angostura bitters.

webTitle: Poems from the world's end

fields.headline: Poems from the world's end
fields.standfirst: Nobel laureate Pablo Neruda was inspired by the scenery of a country that still elicits verse from unexpected corners, as  Toby Green discovered
fields.trailText: Nobel laureate Pablo Neruda was inspired by the scenery of a country that still elicits verse from unexpected corners, as Toby Green discovered.
fields.body:
I can still remember my first visit to Isla Negra, the house of Chilean poet Pablo Neruda. It is such an extraordinary place that it is hard to be unimpressed. Set on a cliff overlooki ng the Pacific Ocean, the house's character is defined by the objects that Neruda amassed from Asia, Africa and Europe.

The place was overflowing with mementoes: figureheads from ships, Hindu carvings, masks from West Africa, sea shells and butterflies. In the raised gallery where Neruda worked and watched the ocean, it was easy to imagine this wanderer, romantic and lover of the sea becoming inspired.

Isla Negra has an almost mythic status for some Chileans, but this is only in keeping with the reverence with which poetry is viewed in the country. Chileans have a saying that they have a poet hidden under every stone, and certainly this is a place where the landscape inspires creativity, for the deserts, mountains, glaciers, forests and cliffs provide some of the world's most dramatic geography.

If any surroundings could be expected to elicit verse from people, these are they. And, as I spent six months travelling through the more remote areas of the country, I did come across poets in the most unlikely places.

One policeman in a lonely rural outpost, whiling away the hours as the winter rains poured down, showed me the certificates he had received from his Province's cultural centre praising the style and technique of his poems. Another man, an art teacher in a backwoods town, showed me the reams of paper on which his poems were kept. And on Navarin Island, the southernmost place in the world with a permanent settlement, I came across a farmhand who lived alone in a shanty 30 miles from the island's only town, brewing tea, frying pancakes and writing poems.

Some of the recurrent themes of Chilean poetry are solitude, the fragile and beautiful landscape, and the brutal wars waged by the Spanish against the Mapuche Amerindians. Isolated by the Atacama desert to the north, the Andes to the east and the Pacific Ocean to the west, Chileans developed a mentality of being at the end of the world - this was a place which left you with nowhere else to go.

On a more recent visit to Chile, I went to Valparaíso - Chile's second city, and home to the country's Congress - to get another flavour of Neruda's inspiration. Built on seven hills, with winding cobbled streets housing ornate Italian mansions and rundown tenements in equal measure, this is one of the most extraordinary cities in Latin America. The hills are so steep that there are numerous funicular lifts rising from the commercial heart into the warren of the upper town, where you will find rusting 2CVs and hear tangos and Mexican ranchero music echoing through the narrow streets. The houses tend to be tall and brightly painted, and the streets create such a maze that even locals get hopelessly lost. On a clear day, you can see Aconcagua, the highest mountain in the Americas.

Such a romantic and contradictory place as Valparaíso was bound to appeal to Neruda and, in the last decade of his life, he bought a house here. Brightly painted and filled with almost as many artefacts as Isla Negra, La Sebastiana echoed the organised chaos of Valparaíso itself. It is a building where you can feel the poet struggling to make sense of his bohemian past.

Almost inevitably, given his emotional fluctuations, Neruda's life ended with both great success and great tragedy. Awarded the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1971, he was diagnosed with cancer shortly afterwards. As a lifelong communist and friend of President Allende, Pinochet's coup and Allende's death in September 1973 was more than he could bear, and Neruda died in Santiago two weeks later. In the extremes and the poetry of both his life and his death, he embodied much of the essence of Chile: a place with some of the world's highest mountains, its driest desert and its largest ice-field.

webTitle: Rio's safe. Don't act like a mug, and you won't be taken for one

fields.headline: Rio's safe. Don't act like a mug, and you won't be taken for one
fields.trailText: Standing on top of the Corcovado mountain, by the statue of Christ the Redeemer, Emily Barr realised that she was in one of the most wonderful places in the world.
fields.body:
Standing on top of the Corcovado mountain, by the statue of Christ the Redeemer, I realised I was in one of the most wonderful places in the world as I looked down on Rio, spread out in all its double-edged beauty. Part of the city is edged by the white sand of Copacabana, Ipanema and other - less famous - beaches. Elsewhere there are mountains and slums. The First and Third Worlds come together here, and the result is spectacular and compelling.

The Christ statue is my favourite of Rio's sights. He stands on the mountain, arms outstretched, appearing unexpectedly between buildings as you walk around the city. He surprised me every time, an embodiment of a heavenly being watching us and, even though I don't believe in him, his presence was more concrete and comforting than usual.

It even occurred to me to wonder whether Catholic robbers see him from time to time and lose their nerve. How else to account for the very non-threatening aura that Rio has? In the public imagination, from this side of the Atlantic, it is a violent place where the innocent tourist will be ambushed by hirsute and ruthless robbers at every turn. Having relieved her of her possessions, they will probably shoot her for good measure. In fact, it is nowhere near as dangerous as its myth suggests; particularly not if you make an effort.

The most useful precaution is to look and act as much like a Brazilian - or a Carioca, a native of Rio - as possible. An obvious tourist, with red face and bulky bumbag, stands out. Rich Brazilians stand out, too. Normal citizens are not worth bothering with, in the vast majority of cases. One of my favourite aspects of prolonged travel is the dizzying prospect of repeated self-reinvention. Here was a fantastic project: to merge into the background in Rio.

I had a head start, because I was staying with a friend, The Observer's Latin America correspondent, Alex Bellos. I was able to hang out with Cariocas from the very start. I didn't get lost as much as I otherwise would have, I was taken out to bars and clubs and parties, and I had private tuition in Portuguese pronunciation. In short, I had it easy. I had it tiring, exciting and fun.

So here are my exhaustively researched tips for pretending to be a Carioca: swing your hips and keep your chin up. If possible, have dark hair. Above all, don't dress like a tourist. This is far easier to achieve than it sounds: all you have to do is pretend you're at home. Thus, you throw away that bum-bag (would you be seen dead with it at home?), and keep the guidebook tucked away, to be consulted surreptitiously only when absolutely necessary. Wear happy summer clothes. Be careful with shorts: it's hard to look stylish wearing a pair. Take absolute care not to get sunburned or the game will immediately be up.

It should go without saying that valuables should be left in the hotel safe, or at your friend's flat, as appropriate. Those that you have to carry with you should be tucked away in an invisible moneybelt. In the absence, however, of an invisible moneybelt from today's marketplace, they'd be fine in a concealed one.

The stretch of beach outside the Copacabana Palace Hotel is a prime spot for muggings. When you see the people standing outside, you understand why. They are quite clearly foreign and clueless, and might as well have 'mug me' tattooed on their foreheads.

Although violent assaults on tourists are rare, the allure of a posh bag left unattended even for a couple of seconds should not be underestimated. I met another traveller while I was there, who was interrupted during an amble along Ipanema beach by a man pointing out that he had muck all over his shoes. As the stranger bent down to help clean it off, he muttered, 'Give me money or I'll stab you.' It was an unambiguous message, and Tom wisely obliged. At which point, I should state the obvious: never argue with an armed mugger.

Most travellers, however, come away entirely unscathed. Alex has lived in the city for three years and has never been mugged or even threatened. During my few weeks there, I walked around by myself every day, and was surprised at how normal I felt. By the end I almost believed I was Brazilian. Now I just have to learn Portuguese.

emily_barr@yahoo.com

 Woman of the World returns on 31 December.

webTitle: Our choice

fields.headline: Our choice
fields.trailText: Masters of style | Dark side of the moon | Modern day pilgrims
fields.body:
Masters of style

Mix in some four-star comfort with a visit to the new exhibition of Turner watercolours at the Royal Academy of Arts. The Athenaeum Hotel, a five-minute walk from the academy, has put together a Turner package offering a double room, breakfast and admission to the exhibition for £99 per person sharing per night - a saving of more than £100 on regular rates. Or you can repair along Piccadilly for traditional afternoon tea for £19.95 including admission (worth £7). The exhibition, which marks the 150th anniversary of Turner's death, features more than 100 works, many on loan from private collections and runs until 11 February. Phone 020 7499 3464.

Dark side of the moon

Philip Briggs, author of the Bradt guides to Malawi, Mozambique and the 2001 Eclipse over Africa, leads a tour of the two African countries culminating in viewing the eclipse in Mozambique's Tete province. Rainbow Tours (020 7226 1004) has organised an 18-day itinerary for £2,795 including British Airways flights from London, transfers, most meals and park fees.

Modern day pilgrims
A pilgrimage to the modernism of Le Corbusier through France and Switzerland; the primary colours of the stained glass in Gothic France; and Caravaggio's intensity and realism in collections in Rome and Naples. These are three of the new tours in the 2001 brochure of Martin Randall Travel (020 8742 3355), which offers art, archaeology and history tours in small groups with expert lecturers. The eight-day Le Corbusier itinerary costs £1,640 including flights, private coach travel, admission fees, lectures and most meals.

Cross channel charm
Brittany Ferries has brought together all its holidays to France for 2001 into a 500-page brochure the size of a telephone directory. The French Collection lists hundreds of cottages and apartments, holiday villages, hotels, and golfing breaks. There is a separate collection for Spain and a ferry guide and short break brochure. France remains the No1 destination for British holidaymakers despite last year's difficulties with oil spillages and port blockades. Brochures from 08705 360 360.

webTitle: Oaxaca: a cliché worth visiting

fields.headline: Oaxaca: a cliché worth visiting
fields.standfirst: Mariachis, ruins and markets: it's all there, writes  Joanne O'Connor
fields.trailText: Mariachis, ruins and markets: it's all there, writes Joanne O'Connor.
fields.body:
If you were only ever going to visit one Mexican city you could make a good argument for it being Oaxaca. The Latin American equivalent of Bath, it takes all the things we expect to find in Mexico - the colours, the churches, the markets, the pre-Hispanic temples, the music and the food - and wraps them in a small package surrounded by cactus-covered hills. It even has its own answer to the Roman Baths, the ancient Zapotec capital of Monte Alban.

It's difficult to talk about Oaxaca without lapsing into cliché; so difficult in fact that I'm not even going to try. As the guidebooks tell you, it is a quaint town of cobbled streets and rainbow-coloured buildings, where you can buy Indian crafts at bustling markets, and be serenaded at dinner by a wandering mariachi band. I'm sorry but it's true. And if that hasn't put you off, here are a few suggestions on how to spend your time.

Start your day with a coffee in the Zócalo. This large and shady square is the heart of the city. Sit for long enough in one of the pavement cafes and most of Oaxaca will come to you - usually with something to sell. The Zocalo's bandstand, fountains and benches are a magnet for tourists, begging children, canoodling teenagers, shoe-shine boys (no, my Reeboks don't need polishing thank you), pigeons and street vendors wrestling with improbably large bunches of silver balloons.

Mornings are for markets and Oaxaca has plenty of these. Head for one of the covered markets specialising in local crafts or take your chances at the mammoth Mercado de Abastos. Traders will instinctively know that you are not really there to buy one of their bright yellow cornfed chickens complete with trailing giblets, or a birdcage, a bag of fried grasshoppers ( chapulines - the local speciality) or indeed anything for that matter, though anything is what they seem to do best here. One wrong turn and you could be lost forever among the piles of fat chilli peppers, cactus leaves, racks of CDs, vast tubs of cocoa beans, nuts and leather belts. Every so often you will encounter a mill where a selection of the above ingredients are taken to be ground into a mole (a paste for making the distinctive local sauces, not a small underground creature).

Time for a quick lunch - do as the locals do and opt for some tacos filled with pork, chicken or quesillo , the local stringy cheese - before heading up to Monte Alban. A 20-minute bus ride from the centre, this hilltop site was once the administrative and religious capital for the Zapotec people who lived here from about 500BC to AD600. The stones and the setting are atmospheric enough but the trip will be even more rewarding if you, or your guide, know that the terrace is where the sacrificial altar used to be, the strange hieroglyphs with their upside down heads celebrate the conquest of surrounding peoples, and the arrow-shaped building is known as the Observatory for its alignment with the sun and stars.

They throw you out at six but hang on until the last moment to savour the feeling of having this magical spot to yourself. As the sun goes down and the crowds leave, the wind picks up and bats start to circle.

This visit will have raised more questions than it answers making a visit to the Centro Cultural Santo Domingo the logical next stop. Housed in a former convent, this excellent museum tells the history of Oaxaca and its people through artifacts ranging from pre-Hispanic fertility symbols to furniture brought by the Spanish conquistadors. Most people make a beeline for Room 3 with its display of gold, silver, pearl and bones unearthed from the tomb of one of Monte Alban's great leaders.

A visit to the church of Santo Domingo next door will show that the Spanish so-called 'conquest' was always more of a process of compromise. The images of Christ on the cross are particularly gruesome - apparently the only way the Spanish could get the indigenous population to accept the story of the crucifixion was by presenting it as a bloody human sacrifice - a notion they would have been quite comfortable with. Similarly, the large squares in front of Oaxaca's churches stem from the Indians' refusal to enter temples - many of the original services would have been held outside the front door.

Your day will probably end where it began - in the Zócalo, this time with a bottle of Sol or a tequila. The Indian women will be selling gardenias and spicy tamales and a man who looks strangely familiar will try and sell you the rug you said no to that morning.

fields.headline: In the wake of Mark Twain
fields.standfirst: Sandra Jordan streams down the Río San Juan to find Nicaragua's enchanting jungle paradise intact - for the moment at least
fields.trailText: Sandra Jordan streams down the Río San Juan to find Nicaragua's enchanting jungle paradise intact - for the moment at least.
fields.body:
Little has changed since Mark Twain steamed down the Río San Juan 144 years ago. For the time being, Nicaragua's environment remains unspoilt, boasting the largest remaining rainforest north of the Amazon, which covers 17 per cent of the country. Eager to separate truth from fiction, we followed in Twain's footsteps, starting our voyage at the port of San Carlos, a scrappy, muddy town on Lake Nicaragua.

The quickest way to get to get to San Carlos these days is to fly from Managua. La Costuña airlines have a daily service for £57 return. But, while it may be quick, it's not for the nervous. Still, a splendid view of volcanoes and lakes from the minuscule 16-seater plane compensates for the fear factor. Sort of. Forty-five nerve-wracking minutes later, we landed on a runway that resembled an Irish country road, a sticky mess of muck and stones.

San Carlos, a port town of 35,000, was almost wiped-out by a major fire during the 1978-1979 revolution and has never recovered fully. The streets are unpaved, and houses, jeeps, children, roosters and pigs are all coated in mud. Russian jeeps - Sandinista relics - ferried us to the waterside where we were to begin our journey along the Río San Juan, Central America's second longest river, by 'panga' or motorised canoe.

In Travels With Mr Brown, Twain records his journey into the heart of the Nicaraguan jungle. Not being quite so brave, we were going to the Reserva Biólogica Indio-Maíz. Echoing Twain, we steamed down to El Castillo and saw the same fortress, a 'stately old adobe castle' he had visited. According to Twain: 'There is a dangerous rapid here. It is said to be artificial - formed by man in former times to keep the pirate boats from penetrating the interior. We had to climb ashore here, walk around the rapids, and get on another steam wheeler.'

Our driver, Ricardo, was more skilful than his historical counterpart. He managed to steer us over the rapids, a turbulent ride that rocked the boat roughly from side to side, bringing to mind the crocodiles and sharks that live in these parts.

We continued down the river, enchanted by the forest. It is still an unspoilt jungle - some of the most pristine rainforest in the world. Yet its days may be numbered as plans are afoot to build Nicaragua's answer to the Panama Canal. .

For now, it retains its magnificence. A mist hung over the river and cedar, mahogany and almond trees surpassed heights more usually associated with skyscrapers. Our lodgings for the night, the Refugio Bartelo, stood at the point where the Río Bartelo converges with the Río San Juan.

The sleeping accommodation was a wooden block of rooms with vaulted, high ceilings and en suite bathrooms. Mine contained a double bed, bunk beds and a few shelves. Mosquito nets are provided, but repellent is a must. There are no windows, just shutters that are closed at dusk. A generator powers a dim electric light. In the guestbook, I found this comment from Debra, a traveller from the USA: 'I like the tiny frog from the forest and the bat in my room at night.'

The garden is full of tropical flowers, the type that cost £20 a stem in London. Proof, if it were needed, that money can't buy everything for the strays in London don't attract feeding humming birds. A pet spider monkey, Daniella, a rescued orphan, roams around making eyes at men but growling at women.

Our fellow guests were Mexican scientists studying a species of river lobster. In a recent one-month study, biologists discovered every species of Central American animal within three kilometres of the Refugio, including jaguars, spider, howler and white-faced monkeys, three-toed sloths, six types of kingfisher, and 11 types of humming bird.

Although the rainy season was over, a freak hurricane in Venezeula brought heavy rain, scuppering our plans for a long afternoon walk in the rainforest. We resorted to plan B - spending the afternoon lounging around in the Rancho - a large veranda-like structure, a thatched roof on stilts. Hammocks were suspended around its perimeter, overlooking the swelling river, the Nicaraguan rainforest on our side and the Costa Rican jungle on the other bank. There was nothing for it but to take to the hammocks and drink beer.

The next morning we were afloat again, bound for the 36-Island archipelago of Solentiname, the 'Sacred Islands' of Lake Nicaragua. The freak rain continued, so we bedded down under massive binliners, leaving only our faces exposed. We glided along for about four hours before entering Lake Nicaragua. For lunch we stopped at Isla La Venada, or Deer Island. The comida corriente of chicken, fish, rice, beans, cabbage and tomato salad and pineapple rice water cost 20 Cordobas, about £1 each.

William Urroz, el Patrón of the Rancho restaurant, moved here 12 years ago to introduce new plants - coffee, avocado, lemon, lime and oranges - and organic methods to the fertile island. He has since branched out and now farms crocodiles and turtles, not for consumption but for stock regeneration. The crocodiles are 'free range' he explained - no swimming, then. On Sunday, the only day of rest for most Nicaraguans, a neighbour, sweet but somewhat the worse for wear, swung gently in a hammock, making slurred conversation. He explained himself. 'Hoy, ron. Manaña, machete' - 'Today, rum. Tomorrow, machete.' The machete is the all-round tool of choice for most men in the rural areas of Nicaragua.

It brought to mind a passage from The Jaguar Smile , Salman Rushdie's book about his journey to Nicaragua in 1986: 'The campesinos ... were familiar with the workings of the AK-47 automatic rifle. They were also geniuses with the machete. The campesino who had hacked to pieces the tree that held us up could have shaved you without breaking the skin. Alternatively, he could have sliced you like a loaf.'

Rushdie says that The Jaguar Smile 'now reads like a period piece, a fairy tale of one of the hottest moments of the cold war'. Those were the days of the communist Sandinista's fierce battle against the Ronald Reagan-funded Contras. The bad Nicaragua of the headlines has stuck in most people's minds, even though the country has been at peace for 10 years. . And if it's not war, it's weather. Hurricane Mitch struck in 1998, killing 2,200 Nicaraguans. Then there are the earthquakes.

Yet the real Nicaragua is the place that lies behind the headlines. A land of smoking volcanoes, warm tropical nights, hammocks and rocking chairs and Flor de Caña rum, a place of waters and wilds, but also of elegant colonial cities such as Léon with its cathedrals and fading Sandanista murals, and Granada, the oldest city in Latin America, and the place I dream of returning to: the city where I would spend my honeymoon.

Getting there

Sandra Jordan travelled around Nicaragua with Tours Nicaragua. Their 14 night/15 day 'Discover Nicaragua' trip, taking in colonial cities, markets, historical sites, jungles, cloud forests, volcanoes and beaches can be booked in the UK through Pura Aventura, cost £1,954. All transport (boat, plane, 4x4), a bilingual guide, return flights to Nicaragua, hotels, breakfast and some lunches/dinners. Groups, tel 01273 676712, tailormade, 01273 67771,www.pura-aventura.com.
