webTitle: Lost case makes history

fields.headline: Lost case makes history
fields.trailText: A verdict last week against a drink driver who claimed infringement of human rights was a victory for devolution.
fields.body:
When Margaret Anderson Brown drove to a 24-hour superstore in Dunfermline at around 2.30am in June last year, two things were waiting to happen. The first was that after being questioned by police she was charged with stealing a bottle of gin and driving while over the limit. The second took a little longer. But last week, though the case went against her, she made legal history.

Five judges from England and Scotland sitting on the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council ruled that when police that night asked her whether she was the driver of the car in question, they did not infringe the European Convention on Human Rights, now enshrined in domestic law.

And the judges used this new judicial machinery to settle promptly an issue that had threatened to bring chaos to the prosecution of drink driving offences throughout the United Kingdom.

With the approach of Christmas their ruling was welcomed by police and road safety organisations. Until last year the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council seemed a relic of empire, dealing largely with cases from the Commonwealth. Much of its most contentious business in recent times has concerned appeals against the death penalty in the Caribbean. It also hears appeals from professionals such as doctors or dentists convicted of misconduct.

But the late Donald Dewar saw the need to make sure that devolution did not produce quixotic results in various parts of the UK. Last year the committee began to emerge as an incipient UK constitutional court to regulate the relationship between Westminster and the new legislative bodies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. So far it has been concerned with cases arising under the convention, by which the Scottish Parliament and Executive have been bound since their inception last year. The convention became part of UK law in October under the Human Rights Act.

Last week the five judges unanimously found that Miss Brown's right to a fair trial under the convention had not been compromised by the question about who was driving the car which the police had asked her under section 172(2)(a) of the Road Traffic Act 1988. They thus rejected the view of the High Court in Scotland that her answer - 'it was me' - was self-incriminating.

Lord Bingham, Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales, said there had to be a fair balance between the general interests of the community - which justified measures against drinking and driving - and the personal rights of the individual.

The judges also settled a question debated in previous cases. They confirmed that the Lord Advocate's actions as public prosecutor and a member of the Scottish Executive could raise 'devolution issues'.

These are acts of the Scottish Parliament or the Executive which can be tested in court if their competency under statute or their compliance with the convention are in doubt.

Last week, as staff restored the peers' chamber to normal after the state opening of Parliament, Lord Hope of Craighead, who delivered one of the leading judgments in the case of Brown, explained that while the Privy Council's ruling was not necessarily final - it could be challenged either in London or Strasbourg - it would be influential.

In previous cases the English judges on the Privy Council have been reluctant to recognise 'devolution issues', probably from a reluctance to interfere in the processes of Scottish criminal law.

But the case of Miss Brown has changed their view. Lord Hope said: 'I think one might almost say that the scales fell from the eyes of the judges when they realised that the system we'd been given is a very efficient one for dealing with [certain] problems in the quickest and most economical way possible.'

Before devolution, he said, there was a right of appeal from the Court of Session in Scotland in civil but not in criminal cases which had always been regarded as 'beyond the scope of the Union'. Now there was a route of appeal, over 'devolution issues' only, to the Privy Council.

Although it was, he conceded, a 'slightly odd arrangement', the Privy Council had several advantages. It wasn't part of Westminster and its judges didn't have to be from the House of Lords but could come from a wider pool of senior figures from UK courts.

'It's also possible for the Judicial Committee to move around in a way the House of Lords can't really do. It is in theory possible for the Privy Council to hear cases in Edinburgh, Cardiff or Belfast.'

He continued: 'There's a feeling that, given that we can actually find time to do it, we'd quite like to be able to be seen to be participating in our function more visibly to the public.'

In practice, though, the judges who sat on the Privy Council were mainly judges who sat in the House of Lords. 'That may seem a bit of a charade, really, just as if you were changing your hat by moving from one place to another, but it has an advantage that one wants if possible to avoid a disagreement between the House of Lords in English cases and the Privy Council sitting in Scottish, Welsh or Northern Irish cases.'

The case of Brown, he said, showed that a definitive judgment could be achieved more quickly than by taking the case through the judicial processes of each country.

'It's a matter of equal concern north and south of the border as to what the position is under human rights if somebody's asked by a police officer to name the driver of the motor car,' he said.

The Privy Council verdict was open to challenge, either in the Court of Appeal in England, the House of Lords or by individual petition to Strasbourg. But he continued: 'I suspect that there will be fairly strong feeling in the Court of Appeal in England, which I can't speak for, not to grant leave to appeal to the House of Lords against their decision in view of the fact that the Privy Council has already reached a decision ... They would have to persuade the appeal committee in the House of Lords that there was still a point left to be argued.'

As for Strasbourg, he said: 'We've yet to find out what the result would be when the Strasbourg court places greater weight on views brought to bear by the judges of the highest level in this country. What we've tried to do is understand the Strasbourg jurisprudence. We believe that the decision in Brown is consistent with the Strasbourg jurisprudence and therefore would survive challenge. But in theory that route is open.'

Early next year the Privy Council will hear a case arising from the conviction at Paisley in June last year of Robert McIntosh for drug trafficking. The prosecutor then applied for an order under the Misuse of Drugs Act confiscating his assets. The High Court in Scotland found that this violated McIntosh's right, under the convention, to a presumption of innocence.

This case, too, said Lord Hope last week, not only involved a matter of concern on both sides of the border but also an issue reserved to Westminster. It had been dealt with in Scotland before England because the devolution legislation took effect before the Human Rights Act. The appeal to the Privy Council would be heard before an appeal could reach the House of Lords from the Court of Appeal.

He continued: 'So again the Scottish position is being used as a test-bed to decide the issue on both sides of the border.'

However, Lord Hope is anxious that the Privy Council should not become involved in pronouncing on Scottish criminal law or criminal practice. Its strength was that it had been able to develop its own system without English influence.

He said: 'I see a great deal of English law as operated in the Caribbean and my own preference is that we adhere to our own practices and our own law. It's a very fine line between dealing with a strict devolution issue point and becoming involved in Scottish criminal practice or Scottish substantive criminal law.'

During the devolution debates in 1998 Lord Hope expressed anxieties that the Scottish public, in their enthusiasm for devolution, did not understand that the new parliament would not be sovereign, like Westminster, but open to review.

Last week he said: 'You may remember that Tony Blair said in an unguarded moment that the powers were similar to those of a parish council, and that caused a lot of unease. Technically there was quite a lot in what he said.'

But, he stressed, it was Westminster which was 'the odd one out'. The typical position in Europe and the Commonwealth was that parliaments were subject to review. 'Scotland has moved, as it were, into the 21st century by having a parliament which is the same as everywhere else in the world.'

The devolution settlement had produced a lopsided result. England was a uniform country with no attempt to divide it into regions. 'And then you have Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland with a devolution system and a uniform appeals structure.'

He added: 'To that extent, in a loose sense, you might say that the Privy Council is a kind of constitutional court, although we're again a long way from a typical constitutional court.'

Lord Hope, the former Lord President who was appointed a Lord in Ordinary in 1996, expected the number of human rights cases would eventually fall after the 'initial wave' had passed.

But he continued: 'If one finds that the government changes or the political complexion alters a bit, one may find a greater tension between Edinburgh and Westminster than exists at the moment. It's just possible that there may be a greater inclination by Westminster to challenge things done at Edinburgh and the avenue for doing that is through the Privy Council.'

webTitle: Northern Ireland: Commitment is the key

fields.headline: Commitment is the key
fields.trailText: President Clinton's visit comes at another critical stage in the evolution of the Good Friday Agreement. The issues remain decommissioning, policing and the recent unionist veto on Sinn Fein Ministers attending North-South Council meetings. Failures in progressing these threaten the full implementation of the Agreement.
fields.body:
President Clinton's visit comes at another critical stage in the evolution of the Good Friday Agreement. The issues remain decommissioning, policing and the recent unionist veto on Sinn Fein Ministers attending North-South Council meetings. Failures in progressing these threaten the full implementation of the Agreement.

Loyalist and republican paramilitaries need to acknowledge the uncertainty caused by failure to genuinely engage on the arms issue. Paramilitaries associated with pro-Agreement parties have accepted obligations to achieve lasting peace and political stability by co-operating with the International Independent Commission to achieve the 'total disarmament of all paramilitary arms'. Having done so, there is an understandable expectation that they deliver.

Dialogue with the decommissioning body would in itself be a confidence building measure and a sign of serious intent to resolve the arms issue. Failure to live up to commitments on decommissioning only breeds distrust and fuels suspicion. And, worse, threaten the Agreement.

A police service enjoying the allegiance of both communities is a core element of the Agreement. The service must be one in which nationalists and unionists can serve comfortably side by side. It must also be a service rooted in an ethos of human rights and democratically accountable to the whole community.

The SDLP is continuing to work positively for that outcome. Key unresolved issues include ensuring that independent inquiries take place into such controversial murders as those of Pat Finucane, Rosemary Nelson and Robert Hamill; a properly developed and detailed implementation plan to guide the process of change; and assurance that the powers the new Police Board will not be inhibited by the Secretary of State or the chief constable.

Failure to provide guarantees on these issues would also produce a crisis endangering the whole of the Agreement. The SDLP is working with both governments to achieve these guarantees so a new, widely accepted service can exist.

Equally, Unionism needs to abandon its self-service approach to the working the new institutions. The difficulties experienced by David Trimble in holding the pro-Agreement wing of his party together need to be better appreciated by others, as do the difficulties faced by paramilitaries in making progress on decommissioning.

The comfort offered to all by the Agreement only exists when it is operated in its entirety. Protecting that integrity requires progressing all aspects in parallel and in ways clearly seen as fulfilling our respective responsibilities. In other words, unionists must be convinced that the nationalist community is fully committed to implementing all aspects of the Agreement, and vice versa.

The Executive and the Assembly are serving the people of Northern Ireland well. Within the last six weeks we have agreed a programme for government and a budget which will be put to the Assembly for approval before Christmas. We are delivering on issues vital to the continuing development of a competitive economy which will benefit all the people. The North-South Council is developing a range of programmes covering key economic, cultural and social issues, including tourism, trade, education, agriculture, inland waterways and language. New east-west structures will facilitate the development of co-operative arrangements between the islands.

Most people, North and South, want the the agreement to work. They recognise that local politicians working together can make a real and positive difference. There would be so much to lose if the whole process were to falter at this point. That is why the message of hope and support that is President Clinton's decision to visit us for a third time will assist in resolving outstanding difficulties.

 Sean Farren (SDLP, North Antrim) is Minister for Higher and Further Education, Training and Employment

webTitle: Brazil's best kept secret

fields.headline: Brazil's best kept secret
fields.standfirst: Toby Green discovers the hidden delights of the atmospheric African-influenced city of Salvador - a world apart from the glitter of Rio de Janeiro and the crowds of São Paulo
fields.trailText: Toby Green discovers the hidden delights of the atmospheric African-influenced city of Salvador - a world apart from the glitter of Rio de Janeiro and the crowds of São Paulo.
fields.body:
Set halfway between Rio de Janeiro and the north-eastern tip of Brazil's Atlantic coast, Salvador da Bahia (usually known as Bahia) is perhaps the most romantic and atmospheric city in the whole of Brazil. There is none of the hyped-up glitter of Rio, nor the oppressive capitalism of São Paulo. Bahia is a place which thrives off its unique mix of Africa and Europe, a city of winding streets and brightly painted old colonial buildings where you can feel the languor and sensuality which inspired one of Brazil's finest novelists, Jorge Amado, author of The War of the Saints and Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands.

The city's wealth was forged by the sugar and tobacco plantations of the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Hundreds of thousands of slaves came from the West African coast - especially from Nigeria and Angola - and it is this which gives the city its special character.

Bahia's lifeblood is candomblé, an Afro-Brazilian religion in which discrete African deities from nature - orixás - are worshipped as well as the supreme creator. There are temples to the orixás all over the city, and some ceremonies can be attended. Bahia is also blessed by perhaps the liveliest carnival in all Brazil, beautiful beaches and great night-life. A favourite of backpackers in South America for years, it is now opening itself to more visitors, with the start of charter flights from the UK.

Ten of the best from the jungle to beach

Sunday December 10, 2000 10:53 Bahia may be one of the main highlights of a visit to Brazil, but this vast country has an extraordinary amount to offer. Below, heading from north to south, is a sample some of the highlights:

1 The Amazon
Recommending the Amazon is, in terms of geographical size, a little like recommending Europe. Nevertheless, it is an extraordinary place: the densest rain-forest with the most diverse flora and fauna of any jungle in the world. The centre for most tours is Manaus, a city of over 2 million people where you can arrange to visit several smaller Amazonian tributaries and the largest riverine archipelago in the world.

2 Marajó
Near the mouth of the Amazon, this is the world's largest river island. Home to crocodiles, water buffalo, boa constrictors and wonderful beaches, it is an idyllic spot to relax after the rigours of a jungle trip.

3 Fortaleza Beaches
The beaches near the northern city of Fortaleza (in Ceará State) are among the most beautiful in Brazil.

4 The Sertao
Inland from Recife and Bahia, you come to Brazil's badlands, the Sertão. This is a region of dry hills, scrub and breathtaking views, providing a relatively peaceful and unexpected glimpse of rural Brazil.

5 Brasilia
Although many visitors find Brasilia a little soulless, it has to be on the list of top ten places in Brazil, simply because of its extraordinary architecture. The city is laid out in the shape of a bow and arrow, according to the winning design in a competition set by President Kubitschek in 1956.

6 Rio de Janeiro
Whatever you think of the hype, Rio is unquestionably a great city. A string of pearly white beaches, mountains thick with jungle and the 710-metre high Corcovado mountain crowned with the statue of Christ are just the most obvious of its attractions. The bohemian district of Santa Teresa has some very atmospheric colonial architecture, the Botanical Gardens are among the best in Latin America, and the surroundings provide some great excursions, especially to Paratí and Teresópolis.

7 The Pantanal
The Amazon may be more famous, but the Pantanal is probably a better bet for wildlife enthusiasts. This is a vast expanse of wetlands set near several major rivers, where you can see 650 species of birds, 230 species of fish, anteaters, armadillos, pumas, deer, caymans and yellow anacondas.

8 The train to Bolivia
It may seem strange to recommend a train ride, but this is unquestionably one of the most memorable journeys anywhere in Latin America. Leaving the dusty town of Campo Grande, the train makes for the Bolivian city of Santa Cruz de la Sierra via the border town of Corumbá, on a journey which can take three days through deserted wetlands and jungle.

9 The Vaqueiro country near Porto Alegre
Porto Alegre is one of Brazil's more prosperous cities, and in the hinterland is the home of Brazil's cowboys, the vaqueiros, who lead a classic ranching lifestyle on sprawling cattle-raising farms which may be more readily associated with Argentina or Uruguay. This is a great area for anyone who loves huge, empty skies and the real country way of living.

10 Iguaçu Falls
These tumultuous waterfalls are among the principal reasons that tourists come to Brazil. They are so immense that they can be seen clearly from aircraft passing overhead on the way to Buenos Aires.

Ten things you didn't know about Bahia

1 Bahia houses one of the most lavish sculptures of Christ anywhere in Latin America. It was made in 1730 by Francisco Xavier das Chagas, a slave with no formal training, and is set apart from other sculptures by its drops of blood, made from whale oil, ox blood, banana resin and 2000 rubies.

2 Bahia was the capital of Brazil until 1763.

3 The wealth reaped from the sugar and tobacco plantations was so immense that Baia was the second richest city in the Portuguese empire.

4 It was at Bahia that Charles Darwin first set foot on South American soil. This was in 1832, at the start of his five-year journey on the Beagle.

5 Bahia has its very own sport, capoeira, descended from the foot-fighting techniques introduced from Angola by African slaves.

6 Bahia is the most African city in the Western Hemisphere - the Universidade da Bahia holds the only chair in Nigeria's Yoruba language in the Americas.

7 Brazil may have the largest Catholic population of any country in the world but, in Bahia, it comes a poor second to candomblé: there are 166 churches in the city, but 1,000 candomblé temples.

8 Carnival in Bahia is even greater than in Rio. It is the biggest carnival in the world, and has long been the favourite of backpackers in South America. It is possible to join some of the blocos - or dance groups - with preparation.

9 The complex of colonial architecture on Bahia's Largo do Pelourinho is considered to be the finest in Latin America.

10 Bahía is now the third largest city in Brazil after Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo.

webTitle: Stand by your man and put a ribbon in your hair

fields.headline: Stand by your man and put a ribbon in your hair
fields.trailText: We know that Peniel Pentecostal Church has taken over much of the Brentwood and           Ongar Conservative Association. The papers have been full of how dissident Essex Tories           begged Martin Bell to stand against their MP, Eric Pickles, who found it politic to           welcome the evangelists to the Conservative congregation. Less has been said about           what it was in the theology of the Peniel Pentecostalists which has driven loyalists in one           of the last ditches of Tory England to revolt.
fields.body:
We know that Peniel Pentecostal Church has taken over much of the Brentwood and Ongar Conservative Association. The papers have been full of how dissident Essex Tories begged Martin Bell to stand against their MP, Eric Pickles, who found it politic to welcome the evangelists to the Conservative congregation. Less has been said about what it was in the theology of the Peniel Pentecostalists which has driven loyalists in one of the last ditches of Tory England to revolt.

The sect is led by 'Bishop' Michael Reid, a Mercedes-driving former policeman, who promises his credulous flock that his miracles can cure cancer. (He has made millions by selling insurance policies to the faithful as backups in case his prayers for divine intervention are unanswered.)

The Bishop is a traditionalist on sexual questions, and if he ever gets thrown out of the God business he could make a comfortable living on the Daily Mail. At the Peniel Women's Conference, Reid read from the Good Wives Guide, published in America a mere 50 years ago, and commended its rules. Here, for the benefit of women readers wondering how to keep a man, is the advice of the pastor tending the soul of the modern Conservative Party.

'Have dinner ready. Plan ahead, even the night before, to have a delicious meal ready on time for his return. This is a way of letting him know that you have been thinking about him and are concerned about his needs.'

On no account must you look tired after the cooking, rather, 'take 15 minutes to rest so you'll be refreshed when he arrives. Touch up your makeup, put a ribbon in your hair and be fresh-looking. He has just been with a lot of work-weary people. Be a little gay and a little more interesting for him. [No, I do not think the Bishop wants wives to pander to male lesbian fantasies.] His boring day may need a lift and one of your duties is to provide it.'

The children must look as good as you do. 'Take a few minutes to wash their hands and faces (if they are small) Minimise all noise. At the time of his arrival, eliminate all noise of the washer, dryer or vacuum.'

When the grooming is done, the wife must be prepared to defer to the man at all times. If she speaks at all it should be in a 'low, soothing and pleasant voice'. She may think that her husband has fallen under the influence of crackpot preachers and politicians, but she should learn to hold her tongue. 'Listen to him. Let him talk first - remember, his topics of conversation are more important than yours.' Even in suspicious circumstances she must be silent. 'Never complain if he's late home for dinner or even if he stays out all night. Remember, he is the master of the house and as such will always exercise his will with fairness and truthfulness. You have no right to question him.'

The humiliated and servile Tory wife has always been a figure of fun. How good it is to see that the party of young Willie Hague is keeping the tradition alive.

webTitle: From: Graham (10 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Graham
fields.trailText: Having worked in Darwin for a year way back in 1987, I would like to offer a few suggestions. As you work in education you can drop into the education department of the Northern Territories and say hello. They will give you a wonderful welcome!
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

Having worked in Darwin for a year way back in 1987, I would like to offer a few suggestions.

As you work in education you can drop into the education department of the Northern Territories and say hello. They will give you a wonderful welcome! If you express an interest in their work with Aboriginal schools they might take you to some of the outlying communities, and they are really worth a visit. Try Oenpelli. One of the most beautiful places in the world, especially at sunset! Wild horses and Pelicans!

And the Aboriginal people are wonderful. Or you might visit some of the island communities.

The education department is truly integrated in services and although they have their problems due to distance, the attitude is very refreshing.

The other thing I would suggest is trying to connect with the Duke of Edinburgh scheme, which visits places you don't have access to as a tourist; Kakadu National Park, for example. If you go to Kakadu then you need to connect with local people who will take you to places they don't take the tourists. Even the tour companies don't take you there; they are reserved for locals.

Have fun. I am sure you will!

webTitle: So, where's the beef?

fields.headline: So, where's the beef?
fields.standfirst: It was called the kitchen of the world. But Fray Bentos - a town, not just a meat factory - is now on the industrial heritage trail, writes  Nina Coon
fields.trailText: It was called the kitchen of the world. But Fray Bentos - a town, not just a meat factory - is now on the industrial heritage trail, writes Nina Coon.
fields.body:
When Prince Charles visited Uruguay last year, he cracked a joke about corned beef. 'I remember eating it until it came out of my ears,' he told a bemused delegation of Montevidean businessmen. The idea that the postwar royal household might have had trouble getting hold of fresh meat beggars belief, but the Prince meant well. He had already made a faux pas in Argentina with comments on the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands, and as an ice-breaker it could have been much worse.

The meat processing industry was just one of many trade links between Britain and this small, once-prosperous country on the River Plate. The British brought their industrial know-how to South America in the late nineteenth century, building Uruguay's now defunct railway system, introducing electric trams to the capital Montevideo and crowding the business landscape with import and export firms, utility companies, insurers and banks. Some traces of this economic interdependence remain today: Tienda Inglesa, a supermarket chain founded by Don David Robertson in 1870; a fusty British Society; a golf club that serves high tea; and the ancient British Leyland Royal Tiger buses that still belch and fart their way up and down Montevideo's high street, the Avenida 18 de Julio.

And then there's Fray Bentos. It's a place, not just a brand name; a town of 20,000, not a steak and kidney pudding. If Prince Charles's itinerary had allowed it, he might have liked to make the journey 300 km north-west of the capital, to pay homage to the tinned meat he was apparently fed as a boy. For more than a century, a factory in Fray Ben tos processed cows into a myriad of useful and edible products for worldwide export. Originally a German enterprise, the plant was taken over by a British company in the 1920s and subsequently nicknamed El Anglo.

The last machines ground to a halt in 1979, and the site has since been converted into a museum and industrial estate. Local historian Eduardo Irigoyen is on hand to guide the curious. 'We get about 2,000 visitors a year,' he says. 'Most of them are German or British - the Germans come for academic reasons, the British get very emotional and say they were raised on corned beef.'

Many tourists come to Uruguay to trace cultural and familial links. The population is just 3.2 million, but a flick through the Montevideo phone book shows that its origins can be traced to almost every European country. Benedetti, Cajarville, Giucci, Goldberg, Oxandabarat, Porcezanski, Juan Jackson, Carlos Cash, Don Juan Henderson and Guillermo Brown - the last four sounding like a quartet of modern-day gauchos. Waves of immigration during wars or periods of eco nomic depression have created a society that is neither European nor truly Latin American. Uruguayans shop at the local fabrica de pasta, have a world-class pelota team and drink Scotch as if there were no tomorrow.

One thing they don't do is eat corned beef. Norberto Bardolli tried it a couple of times during his 40 years at El Anglo, but it's clearly not a memory he savours. After the British left, he exchanged Christmas cards with his old foreman Peter King. 'I never had any problems with los ingleses ,' says Bardolli, now aged 76 and still living in the barrio built to house the factory workforce. 'We spent a lot of time together, we even caddied for them on their golf course.'

Eduardo and I retrace the steps of the doomed herd; from the crush of the corrales past the disinfecting water jets, along treacherous aerial walkways and paths fortified with cast-iron... to the slaughterhouse. We later pass a vapour measure from the Whessoe Foundry in Darlington, a pressure gauge made by Cole Marchent & Morely Ltd in Bradford, and other equipment shipped in from Loughborough, Derby and Glasgow. 'I always say the factory would be the perfect set for Ridley Scott to film Alien 4 ,' says Eduardo as we enter the dystopian control room.

No part of the beast went to waste: cattle were processed and packaged into more than 100 products on site. Apart from the familiar corned beef, braised steak and meat rissoles, tongues were minced into pté, nose hairs made into brushes and bone-meal into fertiliser. There were areas for processing leather and even a small unit turning fats into soap.

Conflicts were good for business, and World War II brought about an all-time productivity high. El Anglo had 4,000 employees on its books back then; cattle were being slaughtered at a rate of 2,000 per day to meet the military and civilian demand.

There are several old factory sites like this in Montevideo, relics of the first half of the twentieth century when Uruguay's prosperity earned it the tag 'the Switzerland of South America'. Despite pockets of grinding poverty, the contemporary capital still clings to its old reputation and is a highly dignified and cultured place. But the city's ashen complexion belies its true beauty, which perhaps explains why tour operators often shoehorn it into their Latin American itineraries as an afterthought. The majority of Uruguay's visitors are from neighbouring Argentina, many of whom own sumptuous beach houses along the coast near Punte del Este - the silicone-breasted and collagen-lipped jet-set overspill from resorts across the water, where there simply isn't enough sand to go around.

Eduardo tells me the Fraybentinos used to call the British 'the good dictators'. When the bad ones came in 1973, El Anglo was beyond salvation. As well as spelling economic gloom for Uruguay, the 12-year military dictatorship inflicted emotional wounds which have yet to heal. The junta employed the same methods of repression as counterpart regimes in Argentina, Paraguay and Brazil: universities were closed, press freedom scrapped, trade unions and opposition parties banned. Thousands of people were incarcerated and tortured, scores 'disappeared'. A fifth of the population was forced into exile; many have not returned.

In his book The Open Veins of Latin America , Uruguayan author Eduardo Galleano describes his country's global economic role as 'constantly perfecting the art of being the loser'. He accuses the richer nations of coming to countries such as Uruguay, bleeding them of precious raw materials and running off with the lion's share of the profits. He has a point. As the eye sweeps across the sprawling Montevideo coastline, from the villas and home improvement stores of Carrasco to the rubbish-dump slums of El Cerro, the República Oriental feels like a country that has been short-changed.

Back on the waterfront at Fray Bentos, two red-and-white cranes stand side by side on the rotting landing stage, sighing quietly in the autumn breeze. Both bear the inscription 'Thomas Smith & Sons. Rodley nr Leeds'. Once employed loading crates into the empty bellies of waiting transatlantic cargo ships, now they sit frozen in time, paralysed on runners terracotta with rust. Eduardo Irigoyen picks something up off the floor and hands it to me, nodding. It's a wheel - it would have had a hook attached to it, a carcass... now it hangs from my bookshelf, a bent and broken reminder of a forgotten place, a place they used to call la cocina del mundo , 'the kitchen of the world'.

'I remember eating it until it came out of my ears,' he told a bemused delegation of Montevidean businessmen. The idea that the postwar royal household might have had trouble getting hold of fresh meat beggars belief, but the Prince meant well. He had already made a faux pas in Argentina with comments on the sovereignty of the Falkland Islands, and as an ice-breaker it could have been much worse. The meat processing industry was just one of many trade links between Britain and this small, once-prosperous country on the River Plate. The British brought their industrial know-how to South America in the late nineteenth century, building Uruguay's now defunct railway system, introducing electric trams to the capital Montevideo and crowding the business landscape with import and export firms, utility companies, insurers and banks. webTitle: Go for it

fields.headline: Go for it
fields.standfirst: Great white wonders
fields.trailText: Great white wonders
fields.body:
Where better to look out over Christmas than in Wenceslas Square? Prague, with its imposing castle and fairy-tale spires, is the most popular city over the Christmas period, according to figures released by British Airways Holidays. New York is second followed by the year-round favourites Paris and Amsterdam.

The Caribbean holds the top three spots in the long-haul stakes, with Barbados drawing the largest numbers ahead of Tobago and Antigua. Newcomers to this top 10 are Egypt, which offers good value for money, and the Bahamas now served by four direct flights a week from London. The lure of sunshine makes Florida the leading North American destination, ahead of New York and Los Angeles. Here are 10 Christmas holidays, including Prague, which were still available late last week.

Prague

BA Holidays (0870 24 24 243) has four-night breaks departing on 22 December at the four-star City Hotel Moran for £392. Includes breakfast and BA flights from Heathrow.

Barbados

Kuoni (01306 747000) offers seven nights half-board at Discovery Bay, a plantation-style house, for £1,719 per person sharing, including Virgin Atlantic flights departing from Gatwick on 19 December.

France

Three nights from 23 December at the three-star Chateau de Montvillargene, near Chantilly costs £230 with Leisure Direction (020 8324 3030). This includes crossings for car and passengers, breakfast and Christmas Eve dinner(the big French celebration).

Colorado

Ski or board at Winter Park, a resort for all standards 90 minutes from Denver. Ski Independence (0870 555 0555) offers eight nights at the Creekside Chalet for £819 including flights, breakfast, tea and dinner with wine and a Drambuie. Depart between 19 and 23 December.

Cyprus

Fly from Gatwick on 20 December for 14 nights at the five-star Le Meridien Limassol spa and resort for £849 (children £309). This includes flights, transfers, B&B and Christmas and New Year's Eve gala dinners. Book with Argo Holidays (020 7331 7070). See resort activities on www.lemeridien-cyprus.com.

Malta

Fly from Manchester on 19 December for seven nights half-board at San Anton, Bugibba, for £329 (£439 for 14 nights). Book with Thomas Cook Direct on 0870 751 9927).

Madeira

Cadogan Holidays (023 8082 8303) has a Christmas Eve charter flight to the island. Ten nights at the four-star Dom Pedro Baia in Machico costs £649 including flights from Gatwick and breakfast. Gala meals are extra.

Brussels

Travel first class on Eurostar for a two-night break at the five-star Sheraton Hotel for £199 (three nights £219). Includes breakfast and a free AA guidebook. Book with Travelscene (020 8424 9648).

North Devon

There will be a Christmas tree for guests in all the Downe Cottages, near Hartland. These converted Victorian barns cost between £400 and £810 for the week beginning 22 December. Phone 01237 441881.

Lake District

Sunvil UK (020 8232 9788) offers three nights at the Ennerdale Country House Hotel, near Ennerdale Water, from £299 full board. Arrive on Christmas Eve to enjoy champagne and canapes as the village choir sings carols. There is a champagne breakfast and six-course lunch on Christmas Day.

webTitle: From: Philip Bowler (10 Dec)

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Philip Bowler
fields.trailText: One of the great things about Malaysia is the food, especially the street-market food, so find the night market ('pasar malam') in Kuala Lumpur and sample whatever is on offer.
fields.body:
Hi.

Hope you're having a good time. It's a shame your itinerary doesn't tell us how long you're going to be in a place, which makes it more difficult to advise. It's a few years since I was in Kuala Lumpur, and although I quite liked it, and it does have interesting features, I'm not sure I would have it on a 'must visit' list. Penang is far more atmospherically south-east Asian, and even accepted by Malaysians as a food mecca. I don't know Melaka, but people tell me it is very interesting, too, and you could easily stop off there between Singapore and KL.

One of the great things about Malaysia is the food, especially the street-market food, so find the night market ('pasar malam') in KL and sample whatever is on offer; especially the satay, 'koayteow goreng' (fried noodles), fresh coconut juice and 'apom balik' (folded peanut pancake). Try visiting a Chinese vegetarian restaurant and having simulated roast pork or whatever made from soya beancurd - it is amazing what they can do :-) Just the memory of Malaysian food makes my mouth water. Hope you are not dieting - the food courts in Singapore are excellent, too.

It's a shame also that Borneo wasnt included on your route (I suppose everyone would have a favourite place you 'should' have visited) - perhaps you'll get a glimpse of its magnificent forests and great rivers as you fly to Bali! Though if you are able to take the good advice of visiting Taman Negara in Malaysia, it will be some compensation for missing Borneo. It would be good, too, if you could get to the east coast of Malaysia, which has magnificent undeveloped palm-fringed beaches (besides the tourist resorts).

Selamat jalan (safe journey)!

Philip Bowler [in Abu Dhabi]

webTitle: Schools crisis looms as posts remain unfilled

fields.headline: Schools crisis looms as posts remain unfilled
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: An emergency meeting will take place behind closed doors in Whitehall tomorrow to try to avert a winter crisis in Britain's classrooms that could see pupils sent home.
fields.body:
An emergency meeting will take place behind closed doors in Whitehall tomorrow to try to avert a winter crisis in Britain's classrooms that could see pupils sent home.

The Observer can reveal that teacher shortages are set to seriously disrupt primary and secondary schools across the country from January.

Children may end up at home during school hours, which will affect employers as working parents face childcare difficulties.

Schools Minister Estelle Morris will meet representatives from councils to discuss the crisis and devise solutions. These range from four-day weeks in schools and fast-track recruitment, to action to attract teachers from abroad and bring back those who have left the profession.

One idea to be discussed is an exchange scheme to guarantee all teachers a year working abroad.

The teacher shortage has been slowly building for some time. This year many teachers who normally come from Australia and New Zealand have stayed at home because of the Olympics in Sydney, the millennium celebrations and their countries' own teacher shortages.

Research has shown that in London suburbs only 56 per cent of new teacher vacancies are being filled.

The study, by Professor Alistair Ross at the Institute for Policy Studies in Education, found schools across 22 London authorities were particularly struggling to find head and deputy heads with just 38 per cent of all posts advertised being filled. The problem is also being felt in Essex, Hampshire, Berkshire, Kent, Blackburn and rural areas of Scotland and Wales.

'This is serious, and we are in for a long-term national crisis,' said Ross.

'It is not confined to London but schools are very good at papering over the cracks because teachers will step in to cover for colleagues.'

Last week a memo was sent from the Department of Education to local authorities warning of the possibilities of a four-day week being imposed in some parts of the country. The letter asked local education chiefs to develop emergency strategies to tackle staffing problems.

Four schools in the South- east - where the problem is greatest - have already been forced to send children home this term while others have shared one teacher between two classes.

In Hampshire, Cherry Card, headteacher of Fernhill county primary school, told parents that unless a teacher can be found in the next few weeks then ten-year-olds will be sent home at noon daily.

A Hampshire County Council spokeswoman said rising house prices meant it was increasingly difficult to recruit new teachers.

'We have many vacancies for the spring term,' she said.

A spokeswoman at Surrey County Council said internal reorganisation and supply teachers would be filling the gaps in January.

Ralph Tabberer, of the Teacher Training Agency, last week announced that the number of places available for those training to be teachers on part-time and flexible programmes will more than double next year to 1,500.

Former teacher Ian Penman, now with Timeplan, the UK's biggest teacher recruitment agency, said: Britain has 400,000 teachers in its classrooms and 400,000 trained teachers who are not. I cannot think of another profession where there is such a pool of inactive people.'

webTitle: Betrayal of the carers

fields.headline: Betrayal of the carers
fields.standfirst: Former care worker David Jones was cleared last week of child sex charges, after falling victim to police 'trawling'. The Government must halt this senseless folly now, argues child abuse campaigner  Richard Webster
fields.trailText: Former care worker David Jones was cleared last week of child sex charges, after falling victim to police 'trawling'. The Government must halt this senseless folly now, argues child abuse campaigner Richard Webster
fields.body:
'It was the worst thing somebody could possibly accuse you of. He said he'd rather be up for murder than something like this because he's so anti-abuse.' These words were spoken last year by Ann Jones, the wife of former Southampton football manager David Jones. She was describing her husband's reaction to the multiple allegations of sexual abuse he was facing.

On Tuesday, in a courtroom packed with expectant journalists, the long nightmare of David Jones, his wife, and their four children, came to an end. One of Britain's most popular football managers walked out of Liverpool Crown Court an innocent man after all charges against him were withdrawn.

A week before Jones's trial began, relatively few people understood how any former care worker could possibly be facing more than 20 counts of physical and sexual abuse, all of which were false. But, by the time the trial collapsed on Tuesday, practically every national newspaper knew the explanation. David Jones was a victim of 'trawling' - a form of police investigation which has evolved only in the last 10 years.

Much credit for bringing about this transformation in public understanding should go to BBC journalists David Rose and Gary Horne and their Panorama film In the Name of the Children .

In the film, which was transmitted on the eve of the Jones trial, and in an article which was published in this newspaper on 26 November, Rose reported on the case of Roy Shuttleworth, a care worker who is serving 10 years in prison for crimes he could not have committed. Shuttleworth, too, was the victim of a trawling operation.

In such operations police officers deliberately seek out former residents of care homes and invite them to make complaints. Some of these complaints are true and have helped convict social workers who have indeed betrayed the trust placed in them.

But there are clear indications that many of the allegations are false. There is also compelling evidence, some of it captured on film by Panorama, that one of the main motives for fabricating allegations of physical and sexual abuse is money.

After Jones's trial collapsed on Tuesday, his solicitor, Stephen Pollard, said that the prosecution witnesses would have been 'utterly discredited' if the case had continued. He said that more witnesses than the defence could possibly use had volunteered to give evidence that the accusations against Jones had been fabricated in order to gain compensation.

David Jones was fortunate. As the Shuttleworth case shows, other trials where the evidence indicates that the defendant is innocent have had different outcomes.

To investigate such trials is to enter a grotesque Alice-in-Wonderland world in which convicted criminals, often with long records of deception, swear solemn oaths on the Bible and give testimony which sends decent men to prison. It is a world in which lies are ratified by the court and where honest service to other people is penalised with prison sentences of up to 15 years. It is a world where political correctness and the compensation culture have triumphed over justice.

Why, if evidence suggests that individual allegations are fabricated, do juries use them as a basis for convicting? The answer is simple.

In cases where allegations are trawled, juries are not able to assess individual complaints on their own merits. The whole purpose of trawling is to try to prove that abuse has taken place not by finding supporting evidence but by multiplying the number of complaints against a particular suspect.

In fact, the sheer quantity of allegations does not prove anything. But this method continues to be used because it works; it usually results in convictions. By launching trawling operations, and piling up huge numbers of allegations against individual care workers, police forces have found a way of destroying the presumption of innocence and obscuring the weakness of individual complaints. Whenever this happens, justice itself will almost inevitably fail.

Without any doubt these operations are dangerous. But what is truly terrifying is the speed with which they have spread from police force to police force until, at a cost of hundreds of millions of pounds, practically the whole country has been covered by a trawling net.

It should be emphasised once again that some trawled allegations will lead to the conviction of people who are guilty. But it is precisely the fact that it has a core of reasonableness that renders this particular witch-hunt so dangerous, and makes it more likely that innocent men like David Jones will be stretched on the rack which has been devised for the guilty.

The other group who are already beginning to suffer are those who were abused while in care. For, by producing large numbers of false allegations, trawling operations have debased the entire currency of complaints. Tragically, real victims may now find that their truthful testimony is disbelieved.

'If the public knew what was going on they would be appalled,' said Merseyside solicitor Chris Saltrese at the beginning of last week. He is right. Except that he was speaking before the collapse of the Jones trial on Tuesday. By Wednesday morning the public did know what was going on. Or at least they were a lot better informed.

This is crucial. One reason why the current witch-hunt has spread so rapidly and so silently is that all democracies depend ultimately on journalists to safeguard their essential liberties. Yet in this case journalists bear the main responsibility for creating a moral panic around care homes and, until very recently, for keeping both politicians and the public in the dark about what has really been happening.

Now that the media spotlight on David Jones has at last illuminated this darkness, it is time for the Government to act. Until now Home Office Ministers have responded to complaints about trawling by saying that operational matters are for chief constables to decide. But the Government did not say that in the Stephen Lawrence case, and it should not say it now. When the Government does intervene, as it surely must, it should not fall into the trap of blaming the police. Its task should be not to chastise the police but to rescue them from the folly we have forced them into.

For the police did not create a moral panic about sexual abuse in care homes. We did. By doing so and by placing intolerable pressure on police forces to investigate non-existent paedophile rings, we have created a machine for bringing about injustice. This machine is now out of control and has already led to the greatest series of miscarriages of justice in British legal history.

The collapse of the David Jones trial on Tuesday gives us an opportunity to bring this machine to a halt. It is an opportunity which should not be missed.

Richard Webster is the author of The Great Children's Home Panic .

In the film, which was transmitted on the eve of the Jones trial, and in an article which was published in this newspaper on 26 November, Rose reported on the case of Roy Shuttleworth, a care worker who is serving 10 years in prison for crimes he could not have committed. Shuttleworth, too, was the victim of a trawling operation. In such operations police officers deliberately seek out former residents of care homes and invite them to make complaints. Some of these complaints are true and have helped convict social workers who have indeed betrayed the trust placed in them. But there are clear indications that many of the allegations are false. There is also compelling evidence, some of it captured on film by Panorama, that one of the main motives for fabricating allegations of physical and sexual abuse is money. After Jones's trial collapsed on Tuesday, his solicitor, Stephen Pollard, said that the prosecution witnesses would have been 'utterly discredited' if the case had continued. He said that more witnesses than the defence could possibly use had volunteered to give evidence that the accusations against Jones had been fabricated in order to gain compensation. David Jones was fortunate. As the Shuttleworth case shows, other trials where the evidence indicates that the defendant is innocent have had different outcomes. To investigate such trials is to enter a grotesque Alice-in-Wonderland world in which convicted criminals, often with long records of deception, swear solemn oaths on the Bible and give testimony which sends decent men to prison. It is a world in which lies are ratified by the court and where honest service to other people is penalised with prison sentences of up to 15 years. It is a world where political correctness and the compensation culture have triumphed over justice. Why, if evidence suggests that individual allegations are fabricated, do juries use them as a basis for convicting? The answer is simple. In cases where allegations are trawled, juries are not able to assess individual complaints on their own merits. The whole purpose of trawling is to try to prove that abuse has taken place not by finding supporting evidence but by multiplying the number of complaints against a particular suspect. In fact, the sheer quantity of allegations does not prove anything. But this method continues to be used because it works; it usually results in convictions. By launching trawling operations, and piling up huge numbers of allegations against individual care workers, police forces have found a way of destroying the presumption of innocence and obscuring the weakness of individual complaints. Whenever this happens, justice itself will almost inevitably fail. Without any doubt these operations are dangerous. But what is truly terrifying is the speed with which they have spread from police force to police force until, at a cost of hundreds of millions of pounds, practically the whole country has been covered by a trawling net. It should be emphasised once again that some trawled allegations will lead to the conviction of people who are guilty. But it is precisely the fact that it has a core of reasonableness that renders this particular witch-hunt so dangerous, and makes it more likely that innocent men like David Jones will be stretched on the rack which has been devised for the guilty. The other group who are already beginning to suffer are those who were abused while in care. For, by producing large numbers of false allegations, trawling operations have debased the entire currency of complaints. Tragically, real victims may now find that their truthful testimony is disbelieved. 'If the public knew what was going on they would be appalled,' said Merseyside solicitor Chris Saltrese at the beginning of last week. He is right. Except that he was speaking before the collapse of the Jones trial on Tuesday. By Wednesday morning the public did know what was going on. Or at least they were a lot better informed. This is crucial. One reason why the current witch-hunt has spread so rapidly and so silently is that all democracies depend ultimately on journalists to safeguard their essential liberties. Yet in this case journalists bear the main responsibility for creating a moral panic around care homes and, until very recently, for keeping both politicians and the public in the dark about what has really been happening. Now that the media spotlight on David Jones has at last illuminated this darkness, it is time for the Government to act. Until now Home Office Ministers have responded to complaints about trawling by saying that operational matters are for chief constables to decide. But the Government did not say that in the Stephen Lawrence case, and it should not say it now. When the Government does intervene, as it surely must, it should not fall into the trap of blaming the police. Its task should be not to chastise the police but to rescue them from the folly we have forced them into. For the police did not create a moral panic about sexual abuse in care homes. We did. By doing so and by placing intolerable pressure on police forces to investigate non-existent paedophile rings, we have created a machine for bringing about injustice. This machine is now out of control and has already led to the greatest series of miscarriages of justice in British legal history. The collapse of the David Jones trial on Tuesday gives us an opportunity to bring this machine to a halt. It is an opportunity which should not be missed. Richard Webster is the author of The Great Children's Home Panic .

webTitle: Police admit harassing innocent man for 15 years

fields.headline: Police admit harassing innocent man for 15 years
fields.standfirst:
This man has been stopped by the police 37 times,but never convicted of any crime. He claims he is being victimised because he is black

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: This man has been stopped by the police 37 times,but never convicted of any crime. He claims he is being victimised because he is black.
fields.body:
Delroy Lindo is a model member of Britain's black community. He works with inner city children. He lives in a smart house with a nice family. He is articulate, well-dressed and charming. But over the last 15 years he has been stopped by police 37 times and charged with 18 alleged offences.

His crimes? He has sucked his teeth in an 'aggressive manner' in the presence of a police officer. He has been apprehended driving with a dirty number plate. He has been questioned for carrying a copy of The Observer .

In the last six months, the police have carried out 26 checks to see whether he was driving a stolen vehicle. In all the 37 times he has been stopped, he has never been convicted of a single crime.

Now, in a move that will confirm the fears of many in the black community that they are being targeted by the police because of the colour of their skin, an internal police report into the case of Delroy Lindo has found that the diminutive 41-year-old has been the subject of a sustained campaign of 'unwarranted police harassment'.

The report on the treatment of Lindo, a married father of three from London, is deemed so explosive that it may never be published. But The Observer has been passed details of the unprecedented inquiry, which blames senior Metropolitan Police management for failing to take 'a strategic overview' of the case.

Lindo is by no means the only member of the West Indian community to accuse police of harassment, but he is the first to have claims upheld by an internal police inquiry. It is thought that three of the attempts to prosecute him may prove to have been unlawful.

Scotland Yard finally ordered the inquiry by deputy assistant commissioner Tarique Gaffur in July, 15 years after the harassment began. It followed 28 separate complaints by Lindo about police harassment of him and his family. Gaffur short-circuited the Met's time-consuming complaints and disciplinary procedure - and found in favour of Lindo. Yet no officers will face charges or disciplinary action as a result.

David Lammy, the black London Labour MP who has been campaigning for him, said last night: 'This is a case that underlines what we in the black community have been saying for a long time: we are consistently stopped and searched. If I'm not dressed in a suit, I am stopped and harassed. It will be deeply regrettable if the findings of this report are not made public and the officers concerned brought to book.'

Lindo believes his troubles began when he became a prominent campaigner for Winston Silcott, who was accused of the murder of PC Blakelock during riots on the Broadwater Farm estate in Tottenham in 1985. Silcott was cleared on appeal, and last year received £50,000 for wrongful arrest and imprisonment. He is now serving a life sentence for the earlier stabbing of a young boxer, Anthony Smith.

Fed up with the police attention, in 1988 Lindo and his wife Sonia moved to Florida to avoid the harassment. They returned three years later to find nothing had changed, and the campaign continued.

On one occasion, a police officer followed the couple into their children's school and, after an argument, they were escorted off the premises in handcuffs. In December 1999, Lindo claims he was challenged by an officer as he left a newsagent's shop with a copy of The Observer , which had an exclusive interview with Silcott.

Around the same time, Lindo says he received a telephone call from his son Tyrone, telling his father he was being attacked in the street by a middle-aged white man. When he arrived at the scene, Lindo was challenged by police who asked him to hand over the keys of his car. When he refused, he was arrested and later charged with assault. In June, Highgate magistrates in north London threw out the case.

Six weeks later, Lindo was arrested again - this time, for sucking his teeth aggressively. The black community finally snapped. After pressure from Lee Jasper, race adviser to London Mayor Ken Livingstone, the police agreed to the inquiry.

Lindo says his life has been made impossible since the harassment began. His wife, a Haringey Council housing officer, has been forced to take leave from work as a result of stress, and has herself been the alleged victim of a police assault.

Deputy metropolitan commissioner Ian Blair told The Observer yesterday that the inquiry was an attempt by senior officers to break the cycle of arrests and complaints that has dogged the Lindo case. Scotland Yard hopes its swift conclusion will reassure the black community that the force is ridding itself of institutional racism in the aftermath of the Macpherson inquiry into the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence.

'We are conscious of being a post-Stephen Lawrence organisation,' said Blair. 'We are trying to learn and admit our mistakes. But we also have to be fair to officers who work in a very challenging environment.'

He said it would be impossible to discipline any of those involved because none had been given the opportunity to respond to Lindo's claims. 'This is not the vehicle for the discipline of any individual. We now need mature reflection on a complex issue.' He had no immediate plans for a further investigation.

The inquiry team studied 93 individual intelligence reports on the Lindos, involving a total of 49 officers. A number of the incidents reported involved racially derogatory comments about the family.

Gaffur said an unusually high level of correspondence between Lindo and the Police Complaints Authority had yielded no tangible result.

Delroy and Sonia Lindo want a full public inquiry, and have indicated that an apology from the police will not be enough.

martin.bright@observer.co.uk

webTitle: The magnificent Makhmalbafs

fields.headline: Keep it in the family
fields.standfirst: Dad kick-started Iran's film revolution. Now his daughter and wife are winning prizes worldwide. Sheila Whitaker reports on the magnificent Makhmalbafs
fields.trailText: Dad kick-started Iran's film revolution. Now his daughter and wife are winning prizes worldwide. Sheila Whitaker reports on the magnificent Makhmalbafs.
fields.body:
Our story begins in the Shah's Iran: a 17-year-old militant, Mohsen Makhmalbaf, sets up a guerilla movement, arms himself with a knife and stabs a policeman as he tries to steal his gun. His plan was to rob a bank for revolutionary funds. But the policeman shoots him in the stomach and the teenager is jailed for seven years.

Freed after the 1979 revolution, our former revolutionary is made head of the Propaganda Bureau of Islamic Arts and Thought. He writes radio plays and books and makes short documentaries. He then moves on to feature films and soon wins international recognition with movies such as 1989's Dasstforoosh (The Peddler). By this time he has made 15 features and written 28 books. All this from a man who left school at 11 to help support his family and didn't see his first film until after the revolution.

Mohsen Makhmalbaf is now a superstar in Iran and a legend in world cinema. He was awarded the medal of L'Officier de L'Ordre des Arts et des Lettres by the French government last year, yet little is known of him in Britain. This is about to change, with the opening in the UK on 29 December of his daughter Samira's movie, Blackboards, which won the Jury prize at this year's Cannes festival. Still only 18, Samira was a judge at the Venice Film Festival last summer and earlier this year received the François Truffaut Award and the Unesco Federico Fellini medal.

It is just four years since Samira, who appeared in her father's film The Cyclist when she was eight, decided to leave school before her diploma year to study cinema. But where? There were no film schools in Iran. Her father drafted a proposal to the Ministry of Culture asking for funds and permission to set up the country's first film school with places for 100 students. But Makhmalbaf was already a thorn in the side of the Ministry. They told him 'that one dangerous filmmaker like me was enough for one country and that 100 others like me were not needed'.

So he set up The Makhmalbaf Film School at home. His first students were his children, his wife Marzieh Meshkini and four friends. The youngest was Hana, then eight, whose short video The Day the Aunt was Ill was screened just a year later at the 1997 Locarno Film Festival. The oldest was Ebrahim Ghafori, in his twenties, who went on to photograph Samira's first film, The Apple, and Blackboards.

Makhmalbaf remortgaged his home to finance the school and the making of his 1996 film, A Moment of Innocence, in which he appears with the policeman he stabbed in his youth, who turned up one day asking to be in one of his films. Banned by the Ministry of Culture because Makhmalbaf refused to make the cuts they demanded, it remains his favourite film.

Because he was not allowed to distribute A Moment of Innocence Makhmalbaf lost the family home. Nonetheless, he dedicated himself to teaching for the next four years. Two years after the school was set up, Samira, the catalyst, made her first feature, The Apple, in which she re-enacts the lives of two young girls whose father kept them locked up for 11 years with their blind mother.

Inevitably, since her father wrote, produced and edited the film, some suggested that it was more her father's film than hers. But it was clear to those who knew Samira that, young as she was, she was too strong-minded to play second fiddle. She said at Cannes that she expected people to suggest that her father was the real auteur of The Apple, and that made her happy 'because that meant it was a good film'. But the suggestions became tiresome. 'Of course there is his presence,' she snapped one day at a press conference. He was editor, screenwriter and father. That's quite an influence.'

Her new film Blackboards, set in Iranian Kurdistan, is also edited by Makhmalbaf but this time she co-wrote with him and any lingering doubts about the extent of her father's involvement are firmly banished on viewing her brother Maysam's documentary, How Samira Made Blackboards, which was shown at Venice this year.

Shot with a handheld camera and a few professional actors among local amateurs, Blackboards centres on two itinerant teachers carrying blackboards in the mountains near the Iraq border seeking pupils. One meets a group of boys who smuggle contraband (much of it almost too heavy for them to carry), the other a group of Iraqi refugees trying to cross the border, most of them before they die of old age, all constantly in danger of air and ground attack from border guards. Samira lived with the Kurds while location-seeking and evolving her screenplay and filmed for three months ('without even calling home') in the hostile natural terrain which also hides postwar land mines. One scene of Maysam's documentary shows her unsuccessful attempts to persuade a professional actor to tone down his performance. In response to his comment that she should 'never tell an actor what to do', she replaces him with a non-professional. Her hard physical training at her father's film school also came to the fore when she plunged into an icy river in order to persuade her actors to do likewise.

For Samira, cinema 'borders between dream and reality'. She describes her film as appearing 'realistic because of the extreme simplicity of the dialogue which resembles real-life words that the characters would speak'.

Marzieh Meshkini is Samira's aunt - and her stepmother. Marzieh's sister, who died tragically young in an accident, was Makhmalbaf's first wife. A 30-year-old geology and biology graduate, Marzieh was an assistant director on Makhmalbaf's The Silence, and on Samira's The Apple and Blackboards. The Day I Became a Woman, her own first film, screened this year in Venice and winner of the Jury Prize in Thessaloniki, is as remarkable and fascinating as either of her step-daughter's. Due to open in the UK next year, it comprises three stories about women at the beginning, middle and the end of their lives.

The extraordinary Makhmalbaf Film House is now a formidable force in Iran - and not only in film. Samira, while largely conforming to dress codes, wears a black scarf wound around her head and tucked subversively behind her ears in place of a hijab. She accepted the Cannes award 'on behalf of the new, young generation who struggle for democracy and a better life in Iran' and donated her $5,000 Truffaut award to the building of a school for 40 pupils in the village of Dehbar in Kurdestan.

The family production house has clearly established its space and influence in Iranian and international cinema with films that are personal, highly original and uniquely Iranian. 'Hollywood has occupied cinemas all over the world. Because we're not occupied we can develop our own cinema,' says Meshkini.

Mohsen Makhmalbaf, whose ironically surrealist short film The Test of Democracy made its debut at Venice 2000, is shooting in remote Iranian Baluchestan Sun behind the Moon, which deals with Afghan refugees in Iran. Samira and Meshkini are deciding what to do next and we have yet to discover what the future holds for Maysam and Hana.

Blackboards opens in the UK on 29 December. The Day I Became A Woman will be screened here next year.

From Tehran to Cannes: a selection of Iran's greatest hits

Shab Ghozi (The Night of the Hunchback) Farrokh Ghaffari, 1965 A black comedy about a group of people trying to get rid of a corpse.

Gav (The Cow) Dariush Mehrjui, 1968 The film that is largely credited with beginning the Iranian New Wave tells of a peasant whose cow dies.

Davendeh (The Runner) Amir Naderi, 1985 A film which escaped censorship to become an international hit tells of a boy struggling to make a living from redeemable bottles.

Bashu, Gharibeh Kuchak (Bashu the Little Stranger) Bahram Bayzai, 1986 The tale of a young boy fleeing the war on the Iran/Iraq border.

Noon-o Goldoun (A Moment of Innocence) Mohsen Makhmalbaf, 1996 The policeman stabbed by Makhmalbaf turned up one day, asking to be in one of his films. This is it, and Makhmalbaf also appears. It is his favourite film.

Gabbeh Mohsen Makhmalbaf, 1996 A young woman in a nomadic tribe is forbidden to accept her suitor. A film in which Makhmalbaf interweaves reality and folk legend. Don Abolfazl Jalili, 1998 An extraordinary drama-documentary about a young boy without a name or birth certificate and whose father is a drug addict.

Banoo-e Ordibehesht (The May Lady) Rakhsan Bani-Etemad, 1998 One of Iran's few women directors. Her film deals with the conflicts in the life of a filmmaker and mother who seeks fulfilment, not least in her desire to be with her lover. Sib (The Apple) Samira Makhmalbaf, 1998 Portrayal of the lives of two girls locked up with their blind mother for 11 years (pictured).

Takhte Siah (Blackboards) Samira Makhmalbaf, 2000 Two itinerant teachers encounter juvenile smugglers and aged Iraqi refugees.

Banoo-e Ordibehesht (The May Lady) Rakhsan Bani-Etemad, 1998 One of Iran's few women directors. Her film deals with the conflicts in the life of a filmmaker and mother who seeks fulfilment, not least in her desire to be with her lover. Sib (The Apple) Samira Makhmalbaf, 1998 Portrayal of the lives of two girls locked up with their blind mother for 11 years (pictured). Takhte Siah (Blackboards) Samira Makhmalbaf, 2000 Two itinerant teachers encounter juvenile smugglers and aged Iraqi refugees.

webTitle: Babes and big ones, but where's the love?

fields.headline: Babes and big ones, but where's the love?
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: You can be gentle about it. Mr Richard Desmond's first fortnight as owner of three of our great national newspapers has not been an unalloyed success. Or, in Desmond's own idiosyncratic way, you can be brutal. What an expletive-undeleted shambles!
fields.body:
You can be gentle about it. Mr Richard Desmond's first fortnight as owner of three of our great national newspapers has not been an unalloyed success. Or, in Desmond's own idiosyncratic way, you can be brutal. What an expletive-undeleted shambles!

Good proprietors - an iron rule - make good newspapers. They can be laid back, like the late Lord Rothermere; they can be up front, like Conrad Black. There's no single stereotype. But all of the great ones have had a steadiness of vision and purpose, marching into history clutching a bottle of balm as well as adrenalin.They have loved newspapers and sought to understand how this essentially people business works.

The Express group, through long decades of decline, has not been so blessed. My Lords Matthews, Stevens and Hollick each - in their separate ways - flunked the steadiness and TLC tests. A couple of weeks of Desmond, though, begins to bathe even these shades in a kindlier light. Every incoming boss needs his own men and women around him: new leader, new team. But this, for the moment, is chaos theory without the theory.

The people going out of the door, such as the managers, the ad men, the marketers, the specialist correspondents, the star columnists, the editors, aren't collectively a random collection of has-beens and never-wases. They are the Daily and Sunday Express, in a real sense. They will take their talents else where, to eager competitors. It is, thus far, a dismal, disorderly performance.

And yet, remember, there was something worth bidding for, something apparently worth £125 million, before this frenzy began. The Daily Mail (like the Telegraph) was in the ring, offering professional purpose. That may not have appealed to Lord Hollick, over and out of the door carrying his cash, but it's a suitable place to start any calmer consideration of what the Express could still rescue from the debris strewn across Blackfriars bridge. Why was the young Lord Rothermere so interested?

Forget the tales of ancestral hubris: Harmsworth and Aitken, Montagu and Capulet. They're fun, but they butter no share prices. If Associated was interested in buying its ancient rival, there was method, and potential profitability, in their madness. Savings? Of course, through management synergies: but savings without recovering sales don't offer hope. The Mail had a plan.

Part of that plan, to be sure, was defensive. Why let a fresh foe operate on your middle-market patch when you can achieve an effective monopoly for a few million more? Not enough. Buying the Express titles to keep them on a life support system isn't the Mail way. Look, rather, at the growth of their Metro morning freesheets in many of Britain's biggest cities.

There are two driving ideas behind these Metros, both of them, as it happens, borrowed and developed from the Swedes who invented the concept. One is that free papers fed to a captive commuter audience can generate rich advertising revenues (especially if a core product can be rolled out to attract national display advertisers). The other is that a spartan diet of simple, politically neutral news, to be sampled on the Tube, can persuade young travellers who wouldn't otherwise get the reading habit to start picking up a newspaper for the first time.

The thesis, in sum, is that the Metros don't drain away sales from the paid-for titles (especially the Evening Standard); rather they fill a gap in the market. Perhaps, on the figures, that isn't quite true. There is some seepage on many titles. Yet, still, it remains broadly right and broadly illustrated by Metro's distribution (not circulation) figures - now nearing 800,000 every morning.

Question: if the notion of simplicity and neutrality works for these frees, would it also work for a drastically changed Express which had the same editorial approach and filled in the holes between the Tube stations - an Express which was, in effect, the core of this core product? Pull that trick and you have a different kind of mid-market tabloid reaching almost 2 million readers every morning.

We'll probably never know. The Expresses and the Star have a distinct and equally uncertain future in liaison with OK!, Big Ones and Asian Babes. Celebrities and nipples have their £125m time of national trial. What's interesting, however, is the creativity Associated brought to the table: the emphasis on new papers, and new approaches to getting them into readers' hands.

That is true strategy. In the newsprint world around us, the world where facts ordain necessary decisions, you can feel the next 'reality' taking shape. Newsprint itself won't be so so cheap: watch for 15 per cent price rises next year. This will be a particular pain for 'free' sheets, which rely on advertising to provide profit on the bottom line.

Against that (and against the march of e-commerce) there's a natural premium on original thinking, on innovation that fits changed circumstances. Maybe the Mail senses that every formula has its sell-by date; maybe it can feel the joints stiffening, the older columnists slowing up, the memory of the perfect family in the perfect (Fifties) Britain fading. In which case, it will need to move on as well.

But the Express, losing readers and staff, gaining only turmoil for the moment? That looks like the Mail 's Plan B. If you can't buy it, let it be sold to somebody who doesn't love and understand, a proprietor without the gift of calm.

webTitle: What happens now in the White House race

fields.headline: What happens now
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: The options
fields.body:
The options

1 If the US Supreme Court issues the Bush-requested stay in the 'undervote' recount and then overturns the Florida Supreme Court's decision, Bush wins Florida (and the White House) by a margin of Florida 537 votes.

2 If the US Supreme Court refuses to hear the case or upholds the ruling, and Gore comes out ahead in the count, then 25 Democrat electors will be sent to Washington this week. But the Republican-controlled legislature in Florida is poised to overrule any popular vote and send its own slate of Republican electors. Then a constitutional crisis takes shape:

Congress must choose between the Florida slates. The new House of Representatives will have a narrow majority of Republicans who will choose the Bush electors. But the Senate may be tied 50-50, giving Al Gore, as Vice-President, the casting vote. If Gore did not vote, then the deciding vote would go to the Governor of Florida, Jeb Bush, George W's brother.

Alternatively, deadlock in Washington could mean Florida electors being rejected altogether, thus giving the election to Gore with 267 electoral votes. But if the court decides that a majority of electors (270 out of 538) is required, then the decision is thrown to Congress. Each of the 51 states' delegations has one vote and since Bush won 28 states, he would then be picked.
