webTitle: Kyle MacLachlan: I, Claudius

fields.headline: I, Claudius
fields.standfirst: For the past decade, Kyle MacLachlan has been as famous for his relationship with Linda Evangelista as for his films. But new roles in Hamlet and Sex and the City should change all that. Here, he talks to Gaby Wood about death, David Lynch, and the problems of shooting sex scenes in a pool
fields.trailText: For the past decade, Kyle MacLachlan has been as famous for his relationship with Linda Evangelista as for his films. But new roles in Hamlet and Sex and the City should change all that. Here, he talks to Gaby Wood about death, David Lynch, and the problems of shooting sex scenes in a pool.
fields.body:
Kyle MacLachlan leans closely into my tape recorder. We are in a London restaurant, the first course has just arrived, and clearly he feels the occasion should be meticulously documented. 'For the record,' he tells the tape, 'this looks fantastic. Lentil soup with a little bit of basil sprinkled on top - no, arugula. I think it's arugula.'

Fans of David Lynch's cult television series Twin Peaks will recognise the gesture. As FBI agent Dale Cooper, MacLachlan developed a signature line in Dictaphone recordings. 'Diane,' he would always begin, addressing his unseen secretary, 'I must remember to find out what kind of trees these are', or 'I had a damn fine slice of cherry pie this afternoon'. In these messages, which ranged from the nerdily mundane to the pricelessly important, MacLachlan's whole style was to be found - he played the controlled, sharp-eyed cop, with a feeling for the darkness beyond and a compulsion to set down every detail, for the record.

MacLachlan knows it's his most famous role, and he likes to play with it. He will tell you, for instance, that he really isn't crazy about cherry pie, but then he will keep breaking off sentences to make sure the Dictaphone has registered his running commentary of peripheral information. He both is and is not his screen persona. And perhaps, for many, that persona is no longer the most familiar thing about him.

MacLachlan hasn't worked with David Lynch for nearly a decade, and he hasn't really inhabited a role in the same way since. The media gaze has shifted, instead, to his glamorous love life. He has had long-term relationships with two of his leading ladies, Laura Dern and Lara Flynn Boyle, but it wasn't until 1992, when he started dating the supermodel Linda Evangelista, that his private life became quite so public.

In the six years the couple were together, they adorned the pages of a thousand magazines. 'It was wonderful,' he says now, 'she'd be working in Cairo, and I'd go with her, and I'd work on scripts or I'd read...' He smiles. 'Neglecting the career, you know.' That, to some extent, was a choice. 'I liked who I was, in a way. It was a great excuse not to have to deal with struggles in Los Angeles, and the process of trying to get through that door.'

Now, though, his career has reached a turning point. No longer 'chasing the cash cow', as he puts it, or being shoehorned into a standard Hollywood career, he plays an intriguing Claudius in a new screen version of Hamlet, his favourite play ('That one and Othello. And Lear. And Macbeth. OK, I like a lot of Shakespeare'). The film's director, Michael Almereyda, says MacLachlan was concerned he might be 'too young and, perhaps, too benign to play the poisonous king'. But he cast him, Almereyda says, because of the double edge that had come across so well in his movies with Lynch, that 'something clouded and equivocal in his eyes'.

Maclachlan has longer hair now than his uniform slicked crop, and, at 41, a slightly more rugged, more bronzed face. He's confident, jokey, at ease with himself. But he does still have that all-American voice, and the charm of a boyish, accidental gentleman. Over the course of a long conversation, he becomes very open, softly self-searching, willing to peel back a few layers of his life to show you how very Lynch-like he is, after all.

Kyle MacLachlan grew up in a small town called Yakima, in Washington State, a place similar to Twin Peaks, or Lumberton, the setting for his best Lynch movie, Blue Velvet.

He describes it as 'a fruit producing and farming kind of place', and goes on: 'our house had been built on an old apple orchard. As kids we would pick the apples and try and sell them to the neighbours. I remember going down to the cannery with my Mom and canning fruit for the season. It was really, you know, one of those places where you don't have to lock your doors.' His father was an attorney, then a stockbroker, and an excellent pianist. His mother was active in the community. Kyle was the eldest of three brothers, and felt that he had to be 'not only responsible, but really good, really well-behaved. I didn't want to cause my parents any kind of worry'. He felt particular pressure from his mother. 'I wanted to make her proud of me, more than anything else.'

When he went to college, in Seattle, he felt out of place, young for his age, and frightened. His parents had recently got divorced, and although to some extent he experienced this as a liberation from the pressure to be good - 'I smoked pot for the first time, started staying out late for the first time, doing the kind of things that I would never have gotten away with before' - he only spent a couple of terms at drama school and went home again.

Back in Yakima, he worked in a lumber factory making doors, but the theatre bug hadn't quite left him. 'It was an odd mix - I was infected by it, but I was also very resistant to it. I felt I shouldn't be liking it. Should is a very big word in my life.'

After an inspiring stint in summer stock theatre, he went back to school, and this time, when he had to do an emotional scene, instead of joking around, 'I just lost my shit'. A short monologue he had written about his father precipitated an outpouring: 'It was one of the best things I could have done, for my psyche as well as for the building of my career... That says a bit about that emotional distancing that was really important to me, growing up - to stay together, to stay on top of it, to be always in control.'

It says something about his own character, but also about those he came to play on screen. In his Lynch roles, and especially in Blue Velvet, he plays a naif with a blank, fresh face - a cipher that has some curiosity behind it. In Twin Peaks he is the calm man in control of any situation, who has a hidden secret in his past. MacLachlan's screen presence is founded on precisely the kind of two-way tension he describes in relation to his life. Blue Velvet 's Jeffrey Beaumont is a boy who is, as MacLachlan puts it, 'frightened by his fascinations'. He is drawn to the world of violent adult sex, the land of 'bad things', but he is also of a piece with the red roses and the picket fence.

When David Lynch cast him in Dune, MacLachlan's first film, as a good son leading his people into intergalactic battle, he said he saw in him a 'genuine spiritual quality, a sort of innocence'. Two years later, he saw Blue Velvet 's Jeffrey in Kyle: 'He can play naive and innocent and obsessive,' Lynch said. 'With some actors, when you look in their eyes, you just don't see them thinking. Kyle can think on-screen.' MacLachlan, it seems, thought that way off-screen, too. 'I read the script,' he tells me, 'and I said, I understand everything that goes on, I understand how you could be drawn into a woman like this.'

The woman in question, a heavy-lidded nightclub singer played by Isabella Rossellini, became the source of another, rather interesting double bind in MacLachlan's life. In the film, Rossellini's character Dorothy Vallens has a sado-masochistic affair with a violent man played by Dennis Hopper. In a difficult scene, Jeffrey watches them through the slatted doors of a wardrobe. He gets drawn, not unwillingly, into a love triangle, and into their murderous world. Before he agreed to do the movie, MacLachlan asked his parents to read the script.

'My Dad was fine with it, but I gave it to my Mom to read, and she couldn't say anything. I asked her point-blank, are you all right with this, and she said, well, no. And I said, then I won't do it.' What his mother objected to was the way in which Rossellini, the sex object and mother-figure, was treated in the film. 'That whole thing was very shocking to her,' MacLachlan explains. 'I'm not saying she should have been more worldly. I'm saying she had exactly the right reaction. The reaction that was wrong was mine. Well, not wrong, it was understandable, but not honest.'

Why was it not honest? I ask. 'Well, because months went by, and I couldn't get a job. And David called again, and partly because I needed to work and partly because the script had never left my head, I said yes. And David said, "I knew you'd come back."'

Lynch and MacLachlan had, in those early days, a relationship so finely tuned it was almost telepathic. Lynch likened himself to Jeffrey, his fictional creation, and MacLachlan was sometimes seen as Lynch's alter-ego. When he played the character, he borrowed some of Lynch's personal traits. The buttoned-up shirt, for example, is trademark Lynch. Once, when asked why he wore his shirts like that, Lynch replied, with a worried logic that could just as well have come from Kyle, that he felt 'too vulnerable with the top button opened'.

Famously, Lynch directs by instinct, and somehow, MacLachlan understood what he wanted. 'He'd say, "A little more like Elvis". I was kind of going, OK... is it the hair? Is it the voice? The sneer? But it wasn't about Elvis at all. It was about the essence of Elvis. Or sometimes we'd do a take and we would huddle together, and just nod - not speaking, and I would go do the scene again and that would be it. It was very strange. It was really strange.'

Blue Velvet is now regarded as a classic, but MacLachlan's mother, whom he had been so eager to please, even as he was drawn, in fiction, to another older woman, died before the film was released. 'My Mom had been diagnosed with ovarian cancer when I was filming Dune ,' MacLachlan says, 'so that would have been '83. And she didn't want to tell me, didn't want to tell me, didn't want to tell me, and finally told me - she didn't want me to worry. That's the kind of woman she was. She didn't want to bother me, because I was working on my first film and all that. But she fought it for five years.'

I ask him how he took her death. 'Ummm...,' he reflects, 'I have guilt about it now, because I felt like I should have been there more for her during the time she was suffering - I think I was very selfish. I was 23, through like 28, and I was in the middle of my career, and in LA, and I would talk to her, and she was always very positive. Her husband would say that it was late at night when he was holding her...'

At this point, MacLachlan covers his face, and muffles a brief, unexpected sob. There is a pause, and when he takes his hands away his eyes are welled up with tears. 'At night was when the fear would overtake her. But she never let it out for kids. She was... quite remarkable. Anyway,' he goes on, fully composed now, 'she fought it, and she died on 11 January. That was '86, coming up on 15 years ago. I have so many questions for her now... I'm much more ready to talk about feelings. I wasn't then.'

MacLachlan and Lynch parted ways after Twin Peaks, and, ever self-critical, he insists that this is his own fault. 'I really abused the relationship,' he says. 'I don't know how David feels about me talking about this,' MacLachlan pauses, 'but... what the fuck, you know... Without getting too specific about it... David and Mark [Frost - the executive producers of Twin Peaks] were only around for the first series, and I fought and fought to try and get them back - but... I think we all felt a little abandoned. So I was fairly resentful when the film, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, came round. I wanted to have a meaningful discussion about some of those scenes, and David was unwilling to do that, so I was not in those scenes - Chris Isaac was in them, instead of me. And looking back, I blame myself for the process... you learn a lesson. And that sort of was... the crack. I don't know if David and I will work together again. I hope so.'

Initially, those who represented Maclach- lan in LA worried that the Lynch imprint might be too strong, and that his quirky roles would hinder him on the traditional Hollywood ladder. They vied for romantic leads on his behalf. 'I remember Sex, Lies, and Videotape came,' he says, 'and I turned it down, because I thought it was too much of the same thing. And Jimmy Spader did it. I was trying to move away from those kind of roles.' The unfortunate consequence of this plan was that he missed out on the work he would have been best at.

He has, however, worked regularly: with Oliver Stone on The Doors, in which he played a stiff Ray Manzarek, the keyboard player. He was Joseph K in a version of The Trial, a Pinter adaptation of Kafka filmed in Prague. For fun, he took a part in the movie of The Flintstones, and a year later, in 1995, he appeared in a famous chauvinistic flop, Paul Verhoeven's Showgirls. 'No, no,' he insists, laughing, 'I want you to bring up Showgirls. You can't run from your past!' He had thought, he explains, that the film would turn out to be much darker, harder.

Nevertheless, the video rests in peace as soft porn, mostly thanks to two of his own 'great love scenes', as he sarcastically puts it. 'The pool sequence,' he sighs, 'was terrifying. Because I had to be completely starkers walking into the pool... I remember reading an article about Oliver Reed, before they shot that naked wrestling scene in Women in Love, about him stroking himself off-camera, and trying to bring some life into his manhood - not to get a full on, you know, but just to sort of give it girth and... potential. And ah... when I did that scene I was completely with Oliver on that one.'

In 1997 he made a film with Mike Figgis, One Night Stand, in which he plays a prim cuckold, and he has since worked with Figgis again, on the recent movie Time Code. He did some TV, and commercials (you may even remember him in a British Vodaphone ad). But for most of the 90s, he was famous for being, as the tabloids would have it, Linda's live-in lover.

The couple met in 1992, when Evangelista was married to Gerald Marie, the head of Elite modelling agency, who recently resigned after allegations that he had seduced underage girls. MacLachlan was asked to do a photo shoot, an ad for Barney's department store in New York, with Linda Evangelista.

'I didn't know who Linda Evangelista was,' he says. 'I mean, I knew she was a model, and I fantasised that maybe she looked like Helena Christiansen or something like that... So I met her there, and I was just, quite taken, you know - and I think it was true of her, too.' A rumour soon spread that they had got together that first night, since MacLachlan turned up for work the next day wearing the same T-shirt. 'I didn't come to work in the same T-shirt,' he says, justifying himself, 'but it was a similar T-shirt. It was a motorcycle T-shirt.' He pauses, thinking whether to go on. 'We didn't get together the first night. We actually got together the second night. If truth be told.'

Evangelista left her husband, and they stayed together for six years. 'The glamorous part of it,' he remembers, 'I knew I was a visitor, somehow. The travelling, and restaurants - there was certainly a lot of that, but there was also a lot of really great family hangin' out fun. That was one of the great things about Linda, she loved to have a good time with friends, and entertaining. That's where she's at her best - she loves having people around and a bunch of noise, and we shared that.'

They broke up over the issue of marriage. They had been engaged so long, MacLachlan says, it was getting to be ridiculous. 'It was just... sealing the deal, with the marriage. I was quite happy just being with her. I wasn't necessarily resistant to marriage but it seemed like I was, and maybe I was, but I just liked things the way we were. Obviously she wanted more. So. She called it a day.' I ask if he was still in love with her for a long time. 'Yeah. Yeah, I was. Obviously the feelings that I was going through were more complex than that, but, yeah. And once I'd gotten through that I met Desirée.'

He met his current girlfriend, a publicist named Desirée Gruber, at his chiropractor's office. He describes a scene that could have been scripted by Woody Allen. 'I was in traction, because I'd ruptured a disk. I'd been there so long I knew how to take myself out of traction. So I got out of my traction chair, and hobbled up to the front desk and said hello. And quite by chance, I went to this party, and she was there. We ended up just talking and having a great night. Then I found out she lived in New York! That was about a year and a half ago. So we've been commuting, and I've been spending more time in New York - working on Sex and the City, and seeing theatre... I just started to thaw a little bit.'

fields.bodyText: Kyle MacLachlan leans closely into my tape recorder. We are in a London restaurant, the first course has just arrived, and clearly he feels the occasion should be meticulously documented. 'For the record,' he tells the tape, 'this looks fantastic. Lentil soup with a little bit of basil sprinkled on top - no, arugula. I think it's arugula.' Fans of David Lynch's cult television series Twin Peaks will recognise the gesture. As FBI agent Dale Cooper, MacLachlan developed a signature line in Dictaphone recordings. 'Diane,' he would always begin, addressing his unseen secretary, 'I must remember to find out what kind of trees these are', or 'I had a damn fine slice of cherry pie this afternoon'. In these messages, which ranged from the nerdily mundane to the pricelessly important, MacLachlan's whole style was to be found - he played the controlled, sharp-eyed cop, with a feeling for the darkness beyond and a compulsion to set down every detail, for the record. MacLachlan knows it's his most famous role, and he likes to play with it. He will tell you, for instance, that he really isn't crazy about cherry pie, but then he will keep breaking off sentences to make sure the Dictaphone has registered his running commentary of peripheral information. He both is and is not his screen persona. And perhaps, for many, that persona is no longer the most familiar thing about him. MacLachlan hasn't worked with David Lynch for nearly a decade, and he hasn't really inhabited a role in the same way since. The media gaze has shifted, instead, to his glamorous love life. He has had long-term relationships with two of his leading ladies, Laura Dern and Lara Flynn Boyle, but it wasn't until 1992, when he started dating the supermodel Linda Evangelista, that his private life became quite so public. In the six years the couple were together, they adorned the pages of a thousand magazines. 'It was wonderful,' he says now, 'she'd be working in Cairo, and I'd go with her, and I'd work on scripts or I'd read...' He smiles. 'Neglecting the career, you know.' That, to some extent, was a choice. 'I liked who I was, in a way. It was a great excuse not to have to deal with struggles in Los Angeles, and the process of trying to get through that door.' Now, though, his career has reached a turning point. No longer 'chasing the cash cow', as he puts it, or being shoehorned into a standard Hollywood career, he plays an intriguing Claudius in a new screen version of Hamlet, his favourite play ('That one and Othello. And Lear. And Macbeth. OK, I like a lot of Shakespeare'). The film's director, Michael Almereyda, says MacLachlan was concerned he might be 'too young and, perhaps, too benign to play the poisonous king'. But he cast him, Almereyda says, because of the double edge that had come across so well in his movies with Lynch, that 'something clouded and equivocal in his eyes'. Maclachlan has longer hair now than his uniform slicked crop, and, at 41, a slightly more rugged, more bronzed face. He's confident, jokey, at ease with himself. But he does still have that all-American voice, and the charm of a boyish, accidental gentleman. Over the course of a long conversation, he becomes very open, softly self-searching, willing to peel back a few layers of his life to show you how very Lynch-like he is, after all. Kyle MacLachlan grew up in a small town called Yakima, in Washington State, a place similar to Twin Peaks, or Lumberton, the setting for his best Lynch movie, Blue Velvet. He describes it as 'a fruit producing and farming kind of place', and goes on: 'our house had been built on an old apple orchard. As kids we would pick the apples and try and sell them to the neighbours. I remember going down to the cannery with my Mom and canning fruit for the season. It was really, you know, one of those places where you don't have to lock your doors.' His father was an attorney, then a stockbroker, and an excellent pianist. His mother was active in the community. Kyle was the eldest of three brothers, and felt that he had to be 'not only responsible, but really good, really well-behaved. I didn't want to cause my parents any kind of worry'. He felt particular pressure from his mother. 'I wanted to make her proud of me, more than anything else.' When he went to college, in Seattle, he felt out of place, young for his age, and frightened. His parents had recently got divorced, and although to some extent he experienced this as a liberation from the pressure to be good - 'I smoked pot for the first time, started staying out late for the first time, doing the kind of things that I would never have gotten away with before' - he only spent a couple of terms at drama school and went home again. Back in Yakima, he worked in a lumber factory making doors, but the theatre bug hadn't quite left him. 'It was an odd mix - I was infected by it, but I was also very resistant to it. I felt I shouldn't be liking it. Should is a very big word in my life.' After an inspiring stint in summer stock theatre, he went back to school, and this time, when he had to do an emotional scene, instead of joking around, 'I just lost my shit'. A short monologue he had written about his father precipitated an outpouring: 'It was one of the best things I could have done, for my psyche as well as for the building of my career... That says a bit about that emotional distancing that was really important to me, growing up - to stay together, to stay on top of it, to be always in control.' It says something about his own character, but also about those he came to play on screen. In his Lynch roles, and especially in Blue Velvet, he plays a naif with a blank, fresh face - a cipher that has some curiosity behind it. In Twin Peaks he is the calm man in control of any situation, who has a hidden secret in his past. MacLachlan's screen presence is founded on precisely the kind of two-way tension he describes in relation to his life. Blue Velvet 's Jeffrey Beaumont is a boy who is, as MacLachlan puts it, 'frightened by his fascinations'. He is drawn to the world of violent adult sex, the land of 'bad things', but he is also of a piece with the red roses and the picket fence. When David Lynch cast him in Dune, MacLachlan's first film, as a good son leading his people into intergalactic battle, he said he saw in him a 'genuine spiritual quality, a sort of innocence'. Two years later, he saw Blue Velvet 's Jeffrey in Kyle: 'He can play naive and innocent and obsessive,' Lynch said. 'With some actors, when you look in their eyes, you just don't see them thinking. Kyle can think on-screen.' MacLachlan, it seems, thought that way off-screen, too. 'I read the script,' he tells me, 'and I said, I understand everything that goes on, I understand how you could be drawn into a woman like this.' The woman in question, a heavy-lidded nightclub singer played by Isabella Rossellini, became the source of another, rather interesting double bind in MacLachlan's life. In the film, Rossellini's character Dorothy Vallens has a sado-masochistic affair with a violent man played by Dennis Hopper. In a difficult scene, Jeffrey watches them through the slatted doors of a wardrobe. He gets drawn, not unwillingly, into a love triangle, and into their murderous world. Before he agreed to do the movie, MacLachlan asked his parents to read the script. 'My Dad was fine with it, but I gave it to my Mom to read, and she couldn't say anything. I asked her point-blank, are you all right with this, and she said, well, no. And I said, then I won't do it.' What his mother objected to was the way in which Rossellini, the sex object and mother-figure, was treated in the film. 'That whole thing was very shocking to her,' MacLachlan explains. 'I'm not saying she should have been more worldly. I'm saying she had exactly the right reaction. The reaction that was wrong was mine. Well, not wrong, it was understandable, but not honest.' Why was it not honest? I ask. 'Well, because months went by, and I couldn't get a job. And David called again, and partly because I needed to work and partly because the script had never left my head, I said yes. And David said, "I knew you'd come back."' Lynch and MacLachlan had, in those early days, a relationship so finely tuned it was almost telepathic. Lynch likened himself to Jeffrey, his fictional creation, and MacLachlan was sometimes seen as Lynch's alter-ego. When he played the character, he borrowed some of Lynch's personal traits. The buttoned-up shirt, for example, is trademark Lynch. Once, when asked why he wore his shirts like that, Lynch replied, with a worried logic that could just as well have come from Kyle, that he felt 'too vulnerable with the top button opened'. Famously, Lynch directs by instinct, and somehow, MacLachlan understood what he wanted. 'He'd say, "A little more like Elvis". I was kind of going, OK... is it the hair? Is it the voice? The sneer? But it wasn't about Elvis at all. It was about the essence of Elvis. Or sometimes we'd do a take and we would huddle together, and just nod - not speaking, and I would go do the scene again and that would be it. It was very strange. It was really strange.' Blue Velvet is now regarded as a classic, but MacLachlan's mother, whom he had been so eager to please, even as he was drawn, in fiction, to another older woman, died before the film was released. 'My Mom had been diagnosed with ovarian cancer when I was filming Dune ,' MacLachlan says, 'so that would have been '83. And she didn't want to tell me, didn't want to tell me, didn't want to tell me, and finally told me - she didn't want me to worry. That's the kind of woman she was. She didn't want to bother me, because I was working on my first film and all that. But she fought it for five years.' I ask him how he took her death. 'Ummm...,' he reflects, 'I have guilt about it now, because I felt like I should have been there more for her during the time she was suffering - I think I was very selfish. I was 23, through like 28, and I was in the middle of my career, and in LA, and I would talk to her, and she was always very positive. Her husband would say that it was late at night when he was holding her...' At this point, MacLachlan covers his face, and muffles a brief, unexpected sob. There is a pause, and when he takes his hands away his eyes are welled up with tears. 'At night was when the fear would overtake her. But she never let it out for kids. She was... quite remarkable. Anyway,' he goes on, fully composed now, 'she fought it, and she died on 11 January. That was '86, coming up on 15 years ago. I have so many questions for her now... I'm much more ready to talk about feelings. I wasn't then.' MacLachlan and Lynch parted ways after Twin Peaks, and, ever self-critical, he insists that this is his own fault. 'I really abused the relationship,' he says. 'I don't know how David feels about me talking about this,' MacLachlan pauses, 'but... what the fuck, you know... Without getting too specific about it... David and Mark [Frost - the executive producers of Twin Peaks] were only around for the first series, and I fought and fought to try and get them back - but... I think we all felt a little abandoned. So I was fairly resentful when the film, Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me, came round. I wanted to have a meaningful discussion about some of those scenes, and David was unwilling to do that, so I was not in those scenes - Chris Isaac was in them, instead of me. And looking back, I blame myself for the process... you learn a lesson. And that sort of was... the crack. I don't know if David and I will work together again. I hope so.' Initially, those who represented Maclach- lan in LA worried that the Lynch imprint might be too strong, and that his quirky roles would hinder him on the traditional Hollywood ladder. They vied for romantic leads on his behalf. 'I remember Sex, Lies, and Videotape came,' he says, 'and I turned it down, because I thought it was too much of the same thing. And Jimmy Spader did it. I was trying to move away from those kind of roles.' The unfortunate consequence of this plan was that he missed out on the work he would have been best at. He has, however, worked regularly: with Oliver Stone on The Doors, in which he played a stiff Ray Manzarek, the keyboard player. He was Joseph K in a version of The Trial, a Pinter adaptation of Kafka filmed in Prague. For fun, he took a part in the movie of The Flintstones, and a year later, in 1995, he appeared in a famous chauvinistic flop, Paul Verhoeven's Showgirls. 'No, no,' he insists, laughing, 'I want you to bring up Showgirls. You can't run from your past!' He had thought, he explains, that the film would turn out to be much darker, harder. Nevertheless, the video rests in peace as soft porn, mostly thanks to two of his own 'great love scenes', as he sarcastically puts it. 'The pool sequence,' he sighs, 'was terrifying. Because I had to be completely starkers walking into the pool... I remember reading an article about Oliver Reed, before they shot that naked wrestling scene in Women in Love, about him stroking himself off-camera, and trying to bring some life into his manhood - not to get a full on, you know, but just to sort of give it girth and... potential. And ah... when I did that scene I was completely with Oliver on that one.' In 1997 he made a film with Mike Figgis, One Night Stand, in which he plays a prim cuckold, and he has since worked with Figgis again, on the recent movie Time Code. He did some TV, and commercials (you may even remember him in a British Vodaphone ad). But for most of the 90s, he was famous for being, as the tabloids would have it, Linda's live-in lover. The couple met in 1992, when Evangelista was married to Gerald Marie, the head of Elite modelling agency, who recently resigned after allegations that he had seduced underage girls. MacLachlan was asked to do a photo shoot, an ad for Barney's department store in New York, with Linda Evangelista. 'I didn't know who Linda Evangelista was,' he says. 'I mean, I knew she was a model, and I fantasised that maybe she looked like Helena Christiansen or something like that... So I met her there, and I was just, quite taken, you know - and I think it was true of her, too.' A rumour soon spread that they had got together that first night, since MacLachlan turned up for work the next day wearing the same T-shirt. 'I didn't come to work in the same T-shirt,' he says, justifying himself, 'but it was a similar T-shirt. It was a motorcycle T-shirt.' He pauses, thinking whether to go on. 'We didn't get together the first night. We actually got together the second night. If truth be told.' Evangelista left her husband, and they stayed together for six years. 'The glamorous part of it,' he remembers, 'I knew I was a visitor, somehow. The travelling, and restaurants - there was certainly a lot of that, but there was also a lot of really great family hangin' out fun. That was one of the great things about Linda, she loved to have a good time with friends, and entertaining. That's where she's at her best - she loves having people around and a bunch of noise, and we shared that.' They broke up over the issue of marriage. They had been engaged so long, MacLachlan says, it was getting to be ridiculous. 'It was just... sealing the deal, with the marriage. I was quite happy just being with her. I wasn't necessarily resistant to marriage but it seemed like I was, and maybe I was, but I just liked things the way we were. Obviously she wanted more. So. She called it a day.' I ask if he was still in love with her for a long time. 'Yeah. Yeah, I was. Obviously the feelings that I was going through were more complex than that, but, yeah. And once I'd gotten through that I met Desirée.' He met his current girlfriend, a publicist named Desirée Gruber, at his chiropractor's office. He describes a scene that could have been scripted by Woody Allen. 'I was in traction, because I'd ruptured a disk. I'd been there so long I knew how to take myself out of traction. So I got out of my traction chair, and hobbled up to the front desk and said hello. And quite by chance, I went to this party, and she was there. We ended up just talking and having a great night. Then I found out she lived in New York! That was about a year and a half ago. webTitle: Chief film censor Andreas Whittam Smith: the bishop reveals all

fields.headline: Chief film censor Andreas Whittam Smith: the bishop reveals all
fields.standfirst: Chief film censor Andreas Whittam Smith is keen to shed his image as the man from the vicarage. So watching pornographic movies all day must help a bit...
fields.trailText: Chief film censor Andreas Whittam Smith is keen to shed his image as the man from the vicarage. So watching pornographic movies all day must help a bit...
fields.body:
Andreas Whittam Smith leapt into the limelight again the other day - the Bishop as Batman - by saying there should be sex shops in every town. His argument was perfectly logical. As president of the British Board of Film Classification, he oversees a species of video-rated 'Restricted 18' that can only be sold in licensed sex shops. But if there is no licensed shop in an area - and there are very few outside Soho - porn-seekers go to illegal traders who sell videos out of the backs of cars and mix paedophile and bestial material along with the normal hardcore. So Andreas believes local authorities should control and supervise the trade rather than ignore it, by encouraging the establishment of sex shops.

Like so many of Andreas's arguments, this is on the one hand sensible and on the other hand slightly mad, or at any rate unrealistic. Naturally it sent the Daily Mail into a screaming frenzy. Stephen Glover, his old adversary from The Independent, accused him of wanting to sweep a tide of filth through every high street, so that you couldn't pop out for a loaf of bread without confronting 'window displays of mind-boggling sexual contraptions'. Other papers took up the hue and cry but Andreas, far from being alarmed by the clamour, was delighted. 'There was even a cartoon in The Sun !' he beams. He is an absolute Liz Hurley when it comes to publicity.

He became president of the BBFC two years ago, and until that moment he had never been a consumer of pornography in any form. What, really, never - not at school, not in the Army, never ever ever? 'No. I'd never seen a sex video in my life. The first one I saw - which wasn't strictly speaking a sex video - astonished me hugely. It was called Pregnant and Milking No 5 - it was the number five that got me! So I looked at this thing and I discovered that there is a genre, which some men pay money to see, which is of pregnant women very dolefully and unenergetically stripping and fondling their breasts - that's all they do. I was very new to the job; I didn't know the rules at all. So I thought, oh dear, we can't have this in ordinary shops -- we'd better make it R18. So that's what I did. I now know that that was a completely wrong decision - it's not like hard porn where the camera is about one inch from the action - but it still languishes in R18.'

I must say I find it weird discussing blue films with Andreas - I keep wanting to hoot and snigger and shout 'weyhay'! He was my boss for three years when I worked on the Independent on Sunday, and although I knew he was not the sanctimonious prig depicted in Private Eye, I don't think we could have discussed Pregnant and Milking in those days - or certainly not with the suavity he brings to it now. But he says one of the things he likes about this job is the complete absence of cant. 'If we say to the distributors, "There's not a shred of a plot here of any kind," they say, "No there isn't. We didn't intend there to be."'

Most of his job consists of classifying videos as suitable either for general release, R18 release (to sex shops only) or no release at all, and there is a very precise legal framework for making these decisions. Classifying cinema films is a comparatively minor part of his work - 700 films a year as against 7,000 videos - and so far he has shown no inclination to cut anything, as he made clear from the beginning when he licensed Lolita uncut. He believes that cinema-goers broadly know what they're getting and 'I think at 18 adults should make up their own minds. Of course I'm sure 16- and 17-year-olds are running into 18 films but I don't think 12-year-olds are; I think it's quite well policed. And no other country comes up to 18 - most of them stop at 17. We are the most highly censored country in the world.'

Alexander Walker (the Evening Standard 's film critic) had 50 fits last year when Andreas passed the French film Romance complete with full-frontal erections. 'Allow one pioneering male sex organ to rear its head,' he shrieked, 'and suddenly dozens more will come out of hiding.' (Actually, Walker was too coy to mention it, but there was ejaculation as well.) But Andreas is unconcerned - he thinks there probably will be more onscreen erections but only when the public is ready for them. 'The public is becoming less tolerant of violence on film - and you can see this in that the Hollywood action heroes aren't getting roles any longer. But the public continues to become more relaxed about sexual explicitness - that tide has not turned. So slightly more explicit stuff will gradually seep through. Because guidelines reflect what we can read as public opinion and if public opinion is slowly becoming more relaxed, then we will too.'

Apparently Jack Straw approves. According to Andreas, 'I have a very good relationship with the Home Secretary.'

Not all the issues are about sex and violence. There's a genre of videos at the moment that are offcuts of television news footage, which no one dares show on a regular news programme - people running out of houses burning, or the police opening a door and finding someone hanging. Andreas again is permissive. 'I have to say, I'm sympathetic to showing it. I suppose it's my news instinct - I think, well that's what happens. People do run out of fires burning. It isn't acting. It isn't a story encouraging violence, it's real.'

He has a team of 20 examiners who classify most of the films, but he watches the one or two a week that are 'problematic'. He has just passed Pasolini's Salo which has never been licensed in this country and refused to make cuts. 'What you find with a good film-maker - it's like with good prose - you can't cut it. Secondly, the best film-makers, when you look carefully, suggest everything, they don't actually show it. You think you've seen all sorts of things, but you haven't really. And censors can only deal with what we see.'

So has he been depraved and corrupted by watching all these dirty movies? Has he started fantasising about having sex with goats? 'No - but I don't think you ever get hardened to it. It's very like going to the dentist. You've got this date - 11 o'clock, Wednesday morning. And often you know it's going to be pretty tough, and you think "ohmigod". I always ask, "How long is it?" and if there's a lot of time spent on the introductory stuff, I think, oh that's good, 10 minutes gone! And then quite often of course it's nowhere near as bad as you fear. But when it is bad, I definitely feel as if my mind has been soiled. I come out of the Board and walk towards Tottenham Court Road tube station. And as I pass people in the street I've still got the film going in my head, and these people are part of it somehow. The only word I can think of is soiled.'

Does he find gay films difficult? 'Yes, I think I'd have to say I find it even harder to watch a gay film than I do a heterosexual one, but that's just me. They can be very sado-masochistic and often run into greater problems for that reason.' The video he found hardest of all to watch was one about body piercing - 'It showed everything - it showed the bolt going through, it showed the operations. And it ended up with men - I don't think women do it - men having hooks placed in their backs - apparently the skin is strong enough - and then they're dangled from some sort of pulley arrangement, hanging from these hooks on their back, and revolve. They're looking for an out-of-body experience, so they say. And perhaps they achieve it, I don't know. Well, that was a new one! I knew nothing about that!'

Conversely, does he ever get turned on by these videos? 'No, not by sex videos because they're too up close. They are fantastically unnatural. And one mark of that is that I can never remember individual titles. If someone says, "Do you remember Office Tarts ?" I don't. I remember the genre well enough, but they're all the same. I can easily be turned on by a beautiful or romantic comedy with fairly explicit sex, sure, but not by that. I need a bit of class to be turned on!' And he utters his strange barking laugh.

The great thing to remember about Andreas Whittam Smith is that he may look like a bishop, he may on occasions talk like a bishop, but he is not a bishop. True, he is a clergyman's son (as were seemingly half the staff of the Independent in his day) and he takes his religion seriously. But his high-minded puritanism is mixed with a wacky iconoclasm, or what Glover calls his Baader-Meinhof streak. He can do gravitas in spades, but there is also a flighty, flouncy side, subject to strange tantrums and vanities, delighted by gossip, thrilled when Pamella Bordes once came to the Independent office, happy to pose for Annie Liebovitz with a golden eagle on his arm, and always eager for any excuse to open champagne. Sebastian Faulks, who was at the Independent from the beginning, recalls him as an inspiring editor and says that 'to me he seemed a bit like the Jack Nicholson character in Easy Rider: a real straight who had suddenly been given his head'.

Rupert Murdoch said he had 'the charisma of a poached egg'. On the other hand, everyone who worked on the Independent was obsessed by him and would try to read the runes of his ever-changing complexion - was mauve a good sign? Was it better to ask for a rise when he was mildly pink or positively white? I always thought he was an actor manqué but he says, on the contrary, he would hate to be an actor, and he actually has a recurring nightmare in which he is made to act and 'I haven't learned my lines, we're just about to start, and I'm going to have to go on stage and look a complete and utter clown'. That's an imposter dream, I tell him. 'Exactly, yes.' So is he an imposter? People who believed in his bishop image were always terribly shocked when they came across his flighty side and accused him of being a hypocrite. But, as he says, it's not his fault if people read him wrong.

He doesn't understand how he ever got this bishop image: 'I'd like to shake it off - I don't really want to go around looking like a bishop. My greatest desire has been to be cosmopolitan and it shattered me one day when the then editor of La Repubblica said "Andreas, whenever I think of an Englishman I think of you". I thought, "My God - all this time I've tried to be cosmopolitan!" And when I was feeling very metropolitan one day I went to Harrods to get my hair cut, and as I lay back in the chair, the barber said, "Up from the country, sir?" And I hadn't moved out of the city for six months! So I can't achieve the self-image I want. I'd like to be either cosmopolitan or metropolitan or both really - a man of the world, at ease everywhere in the world. The nearest I came to it was when the Daily Mail was really cross with me about Lolita; the leader was a big attack, which ended up by describing me as "this urbane liberal" and I was so pleased with the urbane! That's the only thing I can set against this wretched bishop image.'

He is about to become more cosmopolitan because he and his wife have just started 'an experiment in two-city living', which means she lives in a rented flat in Paris during the week and he joins her at weekends. It sounds rather lonely for him, but he says, 'I've got lots to do, my oldest son is often here and we're slowly turning it into a men's club - it's like a men's club without any members at the moment.'

He is 63 but has no thought of retiring. When he left the Independent in 1994 he decided to plan his life on the basis that he had 30 more working years ahead of him. 'Some people have a fear of death, which I don't. But I do have a very deep, powerful fear of not working. The notion of retirement has no attraction of any kind - I can't understand it when people my age start going on cruises. I know I shall always work whatever happens. So that tells you something about what drives me. It's not to do with accumulating money, it's to do with a sort of puritanical view, I think, that I always wish to contribute in some minor way. And maybe that comes from the vicarage.'
fields.bodyText: Andreas Whittam Smith leapt into the limelight again the other day - the Bishop as Batman - by saying there should be sex shops in every town. His argument was perfectly logical. As president of the British Board of Film Classification, he oversees a species of video-rated 'Restricted 18' that can only be sold in licensed sex shops. But if there is no licensed shop in an area - and there are very few outside Soho - porn-seekers go to illegal traders who sell videos out of the backs of cars and mix paedophile and bestial material along with the normal hardcore. So Andreas believes local authorities should control and supervise the trade rather than ignore it, by encouraging the establishment of sex shops. Like so many of Andreas's arguments, this is on the one hand sensible and on the other hand slightly mad, or at any rate unrealistic. Naturally it sent the Daily Mail into a screaming frenzy. Stephen Glover, his old adversary from The Independent, accused him of wanting to sweep a tide of filth through every high street, so that you couldn't pop out for a loaf of bread without confronting 'window displays of mind-boggling sexual contraptions'. Other papers took up the hue and cry but Andreas, far from being alarmed by the clamour, was delighted. 'There was even a cartoon in The Sun !' he beams. He is an absolute Liz Hurley when it comes to publicity. He became president of the BBFC two years ago, and until that moment he had never been a consumer of pornography in any form. What, really, never - not at school, not in the Army, never ever ever? 'No. I'd never seen a sex video in my life. The first one I saw - which wasn't strictly speaking a sex video - astonished me hugely. It was called Pregnant and Milking No 5 - it was the number five that got me! So I looked at this thing and I discovered that there is a genre, which some men pay money to see, which is of pregnant women very dolefully and unenergetically stripping and fondling their breasts - that's all they do. I was very new to the job; I didn't know the rules at all. So I thought, oh dear, we can't have this in ordinary shops -- we'd better make it R18. So that's what I did. I now know that that was a completely wrong decision - it's not like hard porn where the camera is about one inch from the action - but it still languishes in R18.' I must say I find it weird discussing blue films with Andreas - I keep wanting to hoot and snigger and shout 'weyhay'! He was my boss for three years when I worked on the Independent on Sunday, and although I knew he was not the sanctimonious prig depicted in Private Eye, I don't think we could have discussed Pregnant and Milking in those days - or certainly not with the suavity he brings to it now. But he says one of the things he likes about this job is the complete absence of cant. 'If we say to the distributors, "There's not a shred of a plot here of any kind," they say, "No there isn't. We didn't intend there to be."' Most of his job consists of classifying videos as suitable either for general release, R18 release (to sex shops only) or no release at all, and there is a very precise legal framework for making these decisions. Classifying cinema films is a comparatively minor part of his work - 700 films a year as against 7,000 videos - and so far he has shown no inclination to cut anything, as he made clear from the beginning when he licensed Lolita uncut. He believes that cinema-goers broadly know what they're getting and 'I think at 18 adults should make up their own minds. Of course I'm sure 16- and 17-year-olds are running into 18 films but I don't think 12-year-olds are; I think it's quite well policed. And no other country comes up to 18 - most of them stop at 17. We are the most highly censored country in the world.' Alexander Walker (the Evening Standard 's film critic) had 50 fits last year when Andreas passed the French film Romance complete with full-frontal erections. 'Allow one pioneering male sex organ to rear its head,' he shrieked, 'and suddenly dozens more will come out of hiding.' (Actually, Walker was too coy to mention it, but there was ejaculation as well.) But Andreas is unconcerned - he thinks there probably will be more onscreen erections but only when the public is ready for them. 'The public is becoming less tolerant of violence on film - and you can see this in that the Hollywood action heroes aren't getting roles any longer. But the public continues to become more relaxed about sexual explicitness - that tide has not turned. So slightly more explicit stuff will gradually seep through. Because guidelines reflect what we can read as public opinion and if public opinion is slowly becoming more relaxed, then we will too.' Apparently Jack Straw approves. According to Andreas, 'I have a very good relationship with the Home Secretary.' Not all the issues are about sex and violence. There's a genre of videos at the moment that are offcuts of television news footage, which no one dares show on a regular news programme - people running out of houses burning, or the police opening a door and finding someone hanging. Andreas again is permissive. 'I have to say, I'm sympathetic to showing it. I suppose it's my news instinct - I think, well that's what happens. People do run out of fires burning. It isn't acting. It isn't a story encouraging violence, it's real.' He has a team of 20 examiners who classify most of the films, but he watches the one or two a week that are 'problematic'. He has just passed Pasolini's Salo which has never been licensed in this country and refused to make cuts. 'What you find with a good film-maker - it's like with good prose - you can't cut it. Secondly, the best film-makers, when you look carefully, suggest everything, they don't actually show it. You think you've seen all sorts of things, but you haven't really. And censors can only deal with what we see.' So has he been depraved and corrupted by watching all these dirty movies? Has he started fantasising about having sex with goats? 'No - but I don't think you ever get hardened to it. It's very like going to the dentist. You've got this date - 11 o'clock, Wednesday morning. And often you know it's going to be pretty tough, and you think "ohmigod". I always ask, "How long is it?" and if there's a lot of time spent on the introductory stuff, I think, oh that's good, 10 minutes gone! And then quite often of course it's nowhere near as bad as you fear. But when it is bad, I definitely feel as if my mind has been soiled. I come out of the Board and walk towards Tottenham Court Road tube station. And as I pass people in the street I've still got the film going in my head, and these people are part of it somehow. The only word I can think of is soiled.' Does he find gay films difficult? 'Yes, I think I'd have to say I find it even harder to watch a gay film than I do a heterosexual one, but that's just me. They can be very sado-masochistic and often run into greater problems for that reason.' The video he found hardest of all to watch was one about body piercing - 'It showed everything - it showed the bolt going through, it showed the operations. And it ended up with men - I don't think women do it - men having hooks placed in their backs - apparently the skin is strong enough - and then they're dangled from some sort of pulley arrangement, hanging from these hooks on their back, and revolve. They're looking for an out-of-body experience, so they say. And perhaps they achieve it, I don't know. Well, that was a new one! I knew nothing about that!' Conversely, does he ever get turned on by these videos? 'No, not by sex videos because they're too up close. They are fantastically unnatural. And one mark of that is that I can never remember individual titles. If someone says, "Do you remember Office Tarts ?" I don't. I remember the genre well enough, but they're all the same. I can easily be turned on by a beautiful or romantic comedy with fairly explicit sex, sure, but not by that. I need a bit of class to be turned on!' And he utters his strange barking laugh. The great thing to remember about Andreas Whittam Smith is that he may look like a bishop, he may on occasions talk like a bishop, but he is not a bishop. True, he is a clergyman's son (as were seemingly half the staff of the Independent in his day) and he takes his religion seriously. But his high-minded puritanism is mixed with a wacky iconoclasm, or what Glover calls his Baader-Meinhof streak. He can do gravitas in spades, but there is also a flighty, flouncy side, subject to strange tantrums and vanities, delighted by gossip, thrilled when Pamella Bordes once came to the Independent office, happy to pose for Annie Liebovitz with a golden eagle on his arm, and always eager for any excuse to open champagne. Sebastian Faulks, who was at the Independent from the beginning, recalls him as an inspiring editor and says that 'to me he seemed a bit like the Jack Nicholson character in Easy Rider: a real straight who had suddenly been given his head'. Rupert Murdoch said he had 'the charisma of a poached egg'. On the other hand, everyone who worked on the Independent was obsessed by him and would try to read the runes of his ever-changing complexion - was mauve a good sign? Was it better to ask for a rise when he was mildly pink or positively white? I always thought he was an actor manqué but he says, on the contrary, he would hate to be an actor, and he actually has a recurring nightmare in which he is made to act and 'I haven't learned my lines, we're just about to start, and I'm going to have to go on stage and look a complete and utter clown'. That's an imposter dream, I tell him. 'Exactly, yes.' So is he an imposter? People who believed in his bishop image were always terribly shocked when they came across his flighty side and accused him of being a hypocrite. But, as he says, it's not his fault if people read him wrong. He doesn't understand how he ever got this bishop image: 'I'd like to shake it off - I don't really want to go around looking like a bishop. My greatest desire has been to be cosmopolitan and it shattered me one day when the then editor of La Repubblica said "Andreas, whenever I think of an Englishman I think of you". I thought, "My God - all this time I've tried to be cosmopolitan!" And when I was feeling very metropolitan one day I went to Harrods to get my hair cut, and as I lay back in the chair, the barber said, "Up from the country, sir?" And I hadn't moved out of the city for six months! So I can't achieve the self-image I want. I'd like to be either cosmopolitan or metropolitan or both really - a man of the world, at ease everywhere in the world. The nearest I came to it was when the Daily Mail was really cross with me about Lolita; the leader was a big attack, which ended up by describing me as "this urbane liberal" and I was so pleased with the urbane! That's the only thing I can set against this wretched bishop image.' He is about to become more cosmopolitan because he and his wife have just started 'an experiment in two-city living', which means she lives in a rented flat in Paris during the week and he joins her at weekends. It sounds rather lonely for him, but he says, 'I've got lots to do, my oldest son is often here and we're slowly turning it into a men's club - it's like a men's club without any members at the moment.' He is 63 but has no thought of retiring. When he left the Independent in 1994 he decided to plan his life on the basis that he had 30 more working years ahead of him. 'Some people have a fear of death, which I don't. But I do have a very deep, powerful fear of not working. The notion of retirement has no attraction of any kind - I can't understand it when people my age start going on cruises. I know I shall always work whatever happens. So that tells you something about what drives me. It's not to do with accumulating money, it's to do with a sort of puritanical view, I think, that I always wish to contribute in some minor way. And maybe that comes from the vicarage.'

webTitle: Wine: Christmas crackers

fields.headline: Christmas crackers
fields.standfirst: Our fearless taster quaffs his way through 3,000 bottles in search of three great cases of wine for every festive occasion
fields.trailText: Our fearless taster quaffs his way through 3,000 bottles in search of three great cases of wine for every festive occasion.
fields.body:
I've been giving the local bottle bank a real pounding over the past couple of weeks. Corkscrew in one hand, spittoon in the other, I've tasted my way through around 1,000 wines. Add to that the bottles I've sampled in the course of my normal working life (someone has to do it) and I reckon I've sniffed and gurgled something like 3,000 wines in the past six months. My tooth enamel might not appreciate it, but it's the only way to gauge what's out there in the market.

My Christmas selection brings together wines from 11 different countries. I've avoided the temptation to select weird wines for the sake of it (no Kenyan Primitivo, no Danish Furmint) and concentrated on solid drinking at every price point instead. All of the major wine-drinking countries are represented, except New Zealand (a surprise) and (rather more predictably, given its inability to deliver value for money) the United States. The top dog, with nine wines out of the 36, is France, reflecting my Francophilia and the fact that the Frogs still make the best wines on the planet. Italy and Australia have five wines apiece; Germany (a comeback?), South Africa, Chile all have three slots; Portugal, Spain and Argentina two, and Austria and Hungary one each.

As usual, I've concentrated on three broad price bands in an attempt to cover every Yuletide eventuality, from casual drinks with the neighbours to a splendid Christmas lunch. I've only recommended one fizz, because you've probably still got lots left over from last year. With two exceptions, one red and one white, I've also avoided the nether reaches of the wine market. It's possible to find palatable stuff under £3.50, but, believe me, you have to work very, very hard. Just ask the people who clear my local bottle bank.

Too good to share - more than £10

Whites

Waitrose Blancs de Noirs NV Champagne (£11.99). The Champagne I'll be pouring at home this Christmas isn't one of the fancy names, but this brilliant-value Pinot Noir fizz from the Aube district. Extremely drinkable with hints of strawberry and chocolate.

1998 Saint Romain, Nicolas Potel (£12.99, Marks & Spencer). Nicolas Potel is a comparative newcomer to the Burgundian merchant scene, but he's already released a number of excellent wines typified by this minerally, tightly focused Chardonnay.

1999 Heggies Viognier (from £12.99, Oddbins Fine Wine; The Wine Society; Fortnum & Mason; Selfridges). Yalumba (owners of the Heggies brand) is leading the Viognier field in Australia at the moment. This cool-climate white is rich and creamy with intense flavours of apricot and ripe peach.

Amontillado Pastrana, Hidalgo (£14.95, Berry Brothers & Rudd, 0870 900 4300). An amber-hued sherry from one of the great names of Sanlúcar, matured for more than a decade in cask to develop almondy flavours of remarkable complexity.

Henriques & Henriques Bual 10-year-old, Madeira (£17.99, Laithwaites, 0870 444 8383). Another stunning fortified wine from Iberia whose price reflects the unfashionability of Madeira. A sweetish, mahogany-tinged Bual with marked acidity and the slightly singed character typical of the island's wines. This will age for ever.

1998 Kracher Nouvelle Vague, TBA, Grande Cuvée No 10 (£24.99 per half, Noel Young Wines, 01223 844 744; Reid Wines, 01761 452 645). £25 might seem a lot to pay for half-a-bottle of sweet Austrian wine, but Alois Kracher's stickies have been compared with the likes of Château d'Yquem. This oak and botrytis-intense blend is delicious.

Reds

1998 Château La Rose Brisson, St Emilion Grand Cru (£10.99, Safeway). Half of the wines made in St Emilion are unworthy of the famous appellation, but this is a humdinger from a pretty good vintage on the Right Bank.

1999 Altos Las Hormigas Malbec Reserva (£14, Justerini & Brooks, 0207 493 8721). Made by superstar Alberto Antonini from grapes grown 800 metres above sea level in Mendoza, Argentina, this is one of South America's best reds, with tobaccoey, plummy fruit balanced by acidity and fine tannins.

1998 Tancredi, Contessa Entellina, Donnafugata (£14.50, Vino Vino, 07703 436 949). Giacomo Rallo's wines are some of the best in Sicily, especially Tancredi, an aristocratic blend of Nero d'Avola and Cabernet. The two grapes are harmoniously matched in this structured, plum, blackcurrant and black cherry-like red.

1997 Rosemount Estates GSM (£14.87, Asda, Wine Rack, Waitrose, Bottoms Up). GSM stands for Grenache, Shiraz and Mourvèdre, the core grapes of the southern Rhône, transplanted to McLaren Vale in Australia. Philip Shaw has fashioned a typically stylish, concentrated red with lashings of oak.

1998 Errázuriz Don Maximiano Cabernet Sauvignon (£19.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Tesco, Victoria Wine, Thresher, Unwins). The price may have gone up in the last three years, but Don Max is still one hell of a wine, easily a match for its more expensive Chilean competitors. A rich, minty, multi-faceted wine that will develop over the next 10 years into something truly special.

1986 Dow's Quinta do Bonfim (£19.99, Majestic, Sainsbury's, Tesco, Bottoms Up, Wine Rack, Oddbins). An overlooked year in the Douro, 1986 nevertheless produced some splendid single quinta wines such as this one. Rich, spicy, peppery stuff.

For friends and family: £5 to £10

Whites

1999 Icardi Balera Cortese, Piemonte (£5.99, Oddbins). Cortese is one of Italy's more interesting white varieties. When it's well done, it can be quite delicious. This one is packed with flavours of clove, apple and pear, with the variety's zippy acidity and attractive perfume to the fore.

1999 Pewsey Vale Riesling (£5.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). Australian Riesling is one of the New World's most undervalued wines. This elegant, concentrated, lime-like dry white is as close to Alsace Riesling as Australia gets. Minerally, fresh and beautifully poised.

1999 Hilltop Virgin Vintage Sauvignon Blanc (£5.99, Safeway). Hungary is not the first place you'd expect to find a Sauvignon Blanc as good as this, but Akos Kamocsay is no ordinary winemaker. This intense, grapefruit and gooseberry-like white is like a cross between a Kiwi Sauvignon and a Sancerre.

1998 Château de Nages, Cuvée Joseph Torres, Costières de Nîmes (£6.99, Oddbins). Situated in the comparatively unfashionable Costières de Nîmes appellation, Château de Nages is one of the best producers in southern France. This toasty, rich, textured Roussanne white is an absolute stunner.

1999 Thandi Chardonnay (£6.99, Tesco). In winemaking terms, Thandi in Elgin is by far the best of the Cape's empowerment projects. This finely crafted, barrel-fermented Chardonnay has lovely cool-climate finesse. Very Burgundian in style with notes of butter, nut and lemon zest.

1990 Erdener Treppchen Riesling Auslese, Stephan Ehlen (£8.99, Waitrose). Mature Mosel Rieslings from top vineyard sites are something of a Waitrose speciality. This light-fingered, old, oak-matured white is petrolly and complex, with delightful balance between acidity, alcohol and honeyed sweetness.

Reds

1999 Dornfelder, Lergenmuller, Pfalz (£5.49, Waitrose). German reds are something of a minority taste, but this blend of Dornfelder with 15 per cent Pinot Noir has good colour, juicy black cherry and damson fruit flavours and sweet tannins. One to trick your friends with.

1999 Beaujolais Villages, Domaine de la Plaigne (£5.99, Majestic; on special offer at two for £5.49 per bottle until 29 January). Beaujolais Nouveau might have died a sorry death in the UK, but if you still enjoy a glass of Gamay this is wonderfully juicy stuff, with a perfumed flourish.

1998 Jaboulet Côtes du Rhône Villages (£5.99, Tesco). Jaboulet is better known for its northern Rhône reds than its southern blends, but this is one of the best sub-£6 wines I've drunk this year. A peppery, powerful, Grenache-based red with alluring aromas of Mediterranean herbs and spices.

1998 Valdivieso Cabernet Sauvignon Reserva (£6.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Victoria Wine, Thresher, Sainsbury's, Tesco). A gold medal winner at this year's International Wine Challenge, this tastes more like a £10 wine. It's a dark, brooding, blackberryish red with plenty of structure and the potential to age for another five years at least.

1999 Shiraz/Grenache, Christa Rolf, Barossa Valley (£8.65, Lay & Wheeler, 01206 764 446). The top Barossa Valley reds have shot up in price in recent months thanks to high-octane reviews in the US, but not this one. A muscular, concentrated blend from the Binder siblings with a silky core of raspberry and blackcurrant fruit.

1998 Domaine de Pavillon-Mercurol, Crozes-Hermitage (£8.99, Oddbins). No apologies for choosing a second 1998 Rhône red in my £5-10 selection. If the Côtes du Rhône Villages is all about warmth and generosity, this is a more focused Syrah red with ripe tannins and plenty of oak.

For making merry - under £5

Whites

1998 Domaine Sainte Agathe Chardonnay, Vin de Pays d'Oc (£3.29, Somerfield, until 2 January). Super value Languedoc Chardonnay from the house of Maurel Vedeau showing ripe tropical fruit flavours of mango and peach and a whisper of oak. A full-bodied white with plenty of concentration.

1999 Con Class Selección Especial (£3.99, Tesco). A highly distinctive blend of Viura, Verdejo and Sauvignon Blanc from Rueda in northern Spain, which shows that Iberian whites don't have to be as flat and baked as the plain of La Mancha. Zesty, grapefruity and full of charm.

1999 Terra Viva Organic Soave (£4.49, Tesco). Italian white wines usually score high on my personal snooze-ometer, but this organic Soave is a wonderful exception. It's nutty, appley and unoaked with just the right amount of acidity for balance.

2000 Spier Chenin Blanc (£4.49, Asda). There's an ocean of Chenin Blanc in South Africa these days, but very little of it tastes anywhere near as good as this mealy, waxy, honeyed white with its straw/hay aromas and well-balanced oak. A rich, textured white with real personality.

2000 Santa Julia Viognier (from £4.79, Sainsbury's, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). Who says it's impossible to make drinkable Viognier for under £5? From the ultra-reliable Santa Julia operation in Argentina, this is a stylish, full-bodied, well-made white with notes of peach and apricot jam

1999 Lingenfelder Riesling, QbA (£4.99, Oddbins). A splendid entry-point Riesling from one of Germany's most individual producers. A year in bottle has allowed the wine to develop extra depth and complexity. Floral, off-dry and enticingly fruity.

Reds

1999 Chianti La Capannuccia (£2.99, Sainsbury's). I'm not sure what the Italians would make of a Chianti at such a low price, but this is surprisingly drinkable stuff. A medium-weight red with the characteristic cherry/plum skin characters of Sangiovese and a rasp of pasta-friendly tannin.

1999 Co-op Australian Grenache (£3.29 until 7 January). At its knockdown Christmas price, this has to be one of the best-value Aussie reds this side of the Great Barrier Reef. A minty, easy-drinking quaffer with soft tannins and ripe, sunny flavours. Quintessential Aussie Grenache.

1999 Domaine Monpertuis, Cépage Counoise, Vin de Pays du Gard (£4.49, Marks & Spencer). Usually restricted to a spear-carrying role in the south of France, the comparatively rare Counoise is promoted to star status in this meaty, unoaked, finely wrought southern French red.

2000 Beyerskloof Pinotage, Stellenbosch (£4.99, Asda). Made by the king of South African Pinotage, Beyers Truter, this has the telltale liquorice and baked banana aromas of the Cape's most unusual red grape. The balance between sweet raspberry fruit and oak is really well done.

1999 Italia (£4.99, Safeway, Wine Cellar, Virginwines.com). The importers of this wine won't tell me what it's in this hefty, southern Italian bottle, but I'm not sure you should worry. The wine is ripe and faintly raisiny with a smidgeon of oak.

1999 Porta Merlot, Maipo Valley (£4.99, Unwins). There's a lot of good Chilean Merlot at under £5, but this came top of my tasting. It's a lively, well-balanced red, which relies on fruit concentration rather than oak for its impact. Lively and refreshing with fine tannins and bright-eyed cassis fruit characters.
