Situated in the comparatively unfashionable Costières de Nîmes appellation, Château de Nages is one of the best producers in southern France. This toasty, rich, textured Roussanne white is an absolute stunner. 1999 Thandi Chardonnay (£6.99, Tesco). In winemaking terms, Thandi in Elgin is by far the best of the Cape's empowerment projects. This finely crafted, barrel-fermented Chardonnay has lovely cool-climate finesse. Very Burgundian in style with notes of butter, nut and lemon zest. 1990 Erdener Treppchen Riesling Auslese, Stephan Ehlen (£8.99, Waitrose). Mature Mosel Rieslings from top vineyard sites are something of a Waitrose speciality. This light-fingered, old, oak-matured white is petrolly and complex, with delightful balance between acidity, alcohol and honeyed sweetness. Reds 1999 Dornfelder, Lergenmuller, Pfalz (£5.49, Waitrose). German reds are something of a minority taste, but this blend of Dornfelder with 15 per cent Pinot Noir has good colour, juicy black cherry and damson fruit flavours and sweet tannins. One to trick your friends with. 1999 Beaujolais Villages, Domaine de la Plaigne (£5.99, Majestic; on special offer at two for £5.49 per bottle until 29 January). Beaujolais Nouveau might have died a sorry death in the UK, but if you still enjoy a glass of Gamay this is wonderfully juicy stuff, with a perfumed flourish. 1998 Jaboulet Côtes du Rhône Villages (£5.99, Tesco). Jaboulet is better known for its northern Rhône reds than its southern blends, but this is one of the best sub-£6 wines I've drunk this year. A peppery, powerful, Grenache-based red with alluring aromas of Mediterranean herbs and spices. 1998 Valdivieso Cabernet Sauvignon Reserva (£6.99, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up, Victoria Wine, Thresher, Sainsbury's, Tesco). A gold medal winner at this year's International Wine Challenge, this tastes more like a £10 wine. It's a dark, brooding, blackberryish red with plenty of structure and the potential to age for another five years at least. 1999 Shiraz/Grenache, Christa Rolf, Barossa Valley (£8.65, Lay & Wheeler, 01206 764 446). The top Barossa Valley reds have shot up in price in recent months thanks to high-octane reviews in the US, but not this one. A muscular, concentrated blend from the Binder siblings with a silky core of raspberry and blackcurrant fruit. 1998 Domaine de Pavillon-Mercurol, Crozes-Hermitage (£8.99, Oddbins). No apologies for choosing a second 1998 Rhône red in my £5-10 selection. If the Côtes du Rhône Villages is all about warmth and generosity, this is a more focused Syrah red with ripe tannins and plenty of oak. For making merry - under £5 Whites 1998 Domaine Sainte Agathe Chardonnay, Vin de Pays d'Oc (£3.29, Somerfield, until 2 January). Super value Languedoc Chardonnay from the house of Maurel Vedeau showing ripe tropical fruit flavours of mango and peach and a whisper of oak. A full-bodied white with plenty of concentration. 1999 Con Class Selección Especial (£3.99, Tesco). A highly distinctive blend of Viura, Verdejo and Sauvignon Blanc from Rueda in northern Spain, which shows that Iberian whites don't have to be as flat and baked as the plain of La Mancha. Zesty, grapefruity and full of charm. 1999 Terra Viva Organic Soave (£4.49, Tesco). Italian white wines usually score high on my personal snooze-ometer, but this organic Soave is a wonderful exception. It's nutty, appley and unoaked with just the right amount of acidity for balance. 2000 Spier Chenin Blanc (£4.49, Asda). There's an ocean of Chenin Blanc in South Africa these days, but very little of it tastes anywhere near as good as this mealy, waxy, honeyed white with its straw/hay aromas and well-balanced oak. A rich, textured white with real personality. 2000 Santa Julia Viognier (from £4.79, Sainsbury's, Wine Rack, Bottoms Up). Who says it's impossible to make drinkable Viognier for under £5? From the ultra-reliable Santa Julia operation in Argentina, this is a stylish, full-bodied, well-made white with notes of peach and apricot jam 1999 Lingenfelder Riesling, QbA (£4.99, Oddbins). A splendid entry-point Riesling from one of Germany's most individual producers. A year in bottle has allowed the wine to develop extra depth and complexity. Floral, off-dry and enticingly fruity. Reds 1999 Chianti La Capannuccia (£2.99, Sainsbury's). I'm not sure what the Italians would make of a Chianti at such a low price, but this is surprisingly drinkable stuff. A medium-weight red with the characteristic cherry/plum skin characters of Sangiovese and a rasp of pasta-friendly tannin. 1999 Co-op Australian Grenache (£3.29 until 7 January). At its knockdown Christmas price, this has to be one of the best-value Aussie reds this side of the Great Barrier Reef. A minty, easy-drinking quaffer with soft tannins and ripe, sunny flavours. Quintessential Aussie Grenache. 1999 Domaine Monpertuis, Cépage Counoise, Vin de Pays du Gard (£4.49, Marks & Spencer). Usually restricted to a spear-carrying role in the south of France, the comparatively rare Counoise is promoted to star status in this meaty, unoaked, finely wrought southern French red. 2000 Beyerskloof Pinotage, Stellenbosch (£4.99, Asda). Made by the king of South African Pinotage, Beyers Truter, this has the telltale liquorice and baked banana aromas of the Cape's most unusual red grape. The balance between sweet raspberry fruit and oak is really well done. 1999 Italia (£4.99, Safeway, Wine Cellar, Virginwines.com). The importers of this wine won't tell me what it's in this hefty, southern Italian bottle, but I'm not sure you should worry. The wine is ripe and faintly raisiny with a smidgeon of oak. 1999 Porta Merlot, Maipo Valley (£4.99, Unwins). There's a lot of good Chilean Merlot at under £5, but this came top of my tasting. It's a lively, well-balanced red, which relies on fruit concentration rather than oak for its impact. Lively and refreshing with fine tannins and bright-eyed cassis fruit characters.

webTitle: Nigel Slater: 'Tis the season...

fields.headline: 'Tis the season...
fields.standfirst: The December table: with only a fortnight to go, it is time to let temptation be your guide
fields.trailText: The December table: with only a fortnight to go, it is time to let temptation be your guide
fields.body:
I feel uncomfortable, if there is too much food in the house. Temptations abound more than ever this month, so December requires a ruthless edit of the shopping trolley. While there is no more satisfying retail therapy than spotting and securing a piece of Stilton or a pineapple at the summit of its long climb to perfection, this is also the season of the impulse buy - that unused, just-in-case purchase that will embarrass us every time we open the fridge. You know the scenario, 'Will someone please have a slice of that veal and ham pie?' The wily shopper knows when to say no.

But we need to say yes, too. Especially when we come across an exquisite morsel whose time is fleeting and truly seasonal. Figs stuffed with candied peel and marzipan, perhaps, or chocolate-coated prunes from Agen, a flawless Vacherin Mont d'Or cheese, or, for the very rich, a truffle. It would just be too like Scrooge not to have something special tucked away to offer a surprise caller.

I am having fish this year for the main Christmas meal, but many will be searching for a roast to grace their table, be it turkey, pheasant or a long, lean goose. Getting the bird on the table on time, complete with its festive decking of stuffing balls, bacon rolls and bread sauce needs precision, so what precedes it should be a plate whose success is down to expert shopping rather than culinary dexterity. The smart shopper is always ahead of the clever cook.

I would always be thankful for smoked salmon, but could I suggest you ask the fishmonger about eel, trout or halibut, too? These need nothing more than a slick of home-made horseradish sauce. A plump fillet of smoked mackerel is an economical alternative - peeled from the skin of a whole fish, though, rather than vac-packed fillets, please. Its moist richness can be tempered by the kick of a pickled gherkin or, strange-but-true, a pool of Cumberland sauce. Those in the money could do no better than flash their black American Express card at a large tin of caviar.

But I am getting ahead of myself. Before the starter, there will be, I hope, a bottle of bubbly. I am not a canapé kinda guy, so this year I am passing round little strips of lardo - the white, air-cured fat of Italian pigs that is gently scented with rosemary and, sometimes, juniper. To be a treat, it must be sliced very, very thin by the purveyor. Tell him you want to be almost able to see through it. Sprinkle the translucent, pearly strips with flakes of sea salt, good olive oil and roughly crushed black peppercorns or very finely chopped rosemary.

If this delicacy evades you or sounds altogether too carnivorous, then how about four or five (only just) hard-boiled quails' eggs and individual dishes of sea salt for dipping? You could mix celery salt or smoked paprika into the seasoning, if you like that sort of thing. I have been reluctant to mention these charming grey-and-black mottled egglets here before, as I couldn't find any that were free range. But friendly ones are appearing in farmers' markets (I get mine at the Olive Farm butter and cream stall in Islington, north London), so I am happier about suggesting them.

Much of the best Christmas eating comes out of the ground. Frost-touched parsnips, Jerusalem artichokes and fat carrots will all roast sweetly. Eavesdropping at a foodie party the other night, I overheard Rose Gray of the River Café and food-writer Colin Spencer discussing the effect of frost on Cavolo Nero, that beautiful, plume-like, blue-black cabbage. They were both adamant about the benefits of the cold on this beautiful brassica. I pass this is on to anyone who is looking for an alternative to Brussels sprouts this year.

Red cabbage is worth a look, too. The age-old match with apple is a sound one, especially if there are juniper berries and some bacon around. Try heating some bacon fat in a heavy casserole, then throwing in a few handfuls of shredded red cabbage, an apple or two cut into segments and five or six crushed juniper berries. Splash in red wine vinegar, salt and just a little brown sugar. Cooked under a tight lid for 10 minutes or so, you will have a sweet-sour, lightly crisp vegetable to accompany turkey, ham or game.

The Christmas cheese may well be something blue, with Stiltons, Gorgonzolas and the Irish Cashel Blue looking particularly fine at this time of year. I offer just one, in all its glory, with celery made crunchy by a dunking in iced water in the fridge for an hour beforehand. The delights of Spanish Picos, with its wrapping of vine leaves, deserves to be better known.

The shopping list is near useless in a cheese shop at any time of year; we should go instead for whatever looks best. That may well be not blue at all, but something like the Le Fougerus Brie I found the other day, whose fern-bedecked crust undulated like a creamy-white duvet. It would have been disrespectful to have passed it by.

My shopping bag is heavy with fruit. No featherlight punnets of raspberries at this time of year, just the tonne-weight of pineapples and pomegranates. Next time you squeeze a glass of orange juice, slice a pomegranate in half and crush that, too. Apart from the sunset colour, the blast of sweet-sharpness will wake your senses better than any alarm clock.

The small citrus fruits ebb and flow as their seasons come round. One week clementines, the next satsumas and mandarins. Blink and you will miss the minneolas. I eat a lot of these little fruits, so I can confidently say the tighter the skin, the juicier the fruit. Baggy skin is a doddle to peel but will house fruit as dry as Old Nick. Sprightly, bottle-green leaves are a sure sign of a recent harvest.

The bakers will already be sporting their floury aprons, but those less inclined to shake the sugar sifter may like to thumb through the season's food catalogues for their tea. Betty's of Harrogate is offering a moist and raisin-filled Christmas wreath with a topping of huge and juicy cherries, while Carluccio's is boasting a sensational hand-made panettone, the size and price of a small house. Either will cut-and-come-again throughout the feast.

Stocking fillers should surprise and delight, and I try to make them as edible as possible, eschewing the useful for something that is pure luxury. I stuff pistachio nougat, crinkly packets of chocolate-coated almonds and wooden boxes of Turkish delight into everyone's. Then I add sweetmeats I wouldn't normally buy, such as Walnut Whips, Pontefract cakes and humbugs to give a sort of home-made selection box. (Am I the only one who remembers that, years ago, Christmas stocking-shaped selection boxes always tasted stale?) Those worried about dentist's bills can add a clementine or two.

And what about pud? I have taken to making my own in recent years, using Eliza Acton's recipe, and very good it is. Those who cannot stir themselves (sorry) should try the ones from Valvona and Crolla in Edinburgh (valvonacrolla.com) or The Carved Angel puddings available at branches of David Mellor.

I should remind you that Cox's apples and Doyenne du Comice pears are now at their best. Take your time with them, offering the orange-flecked and mossy green fruits with walnuts as a separate course after The Pudding. For those who quickly tire of the sweet richness of Christmas, a perfectly ripe and juicy pear, lovingly brought to tenderness, its flesh as cool and dripping as a melting sorbet, could be the gastronomic height of the season.

webTitle: Focus: Catfight on the catwalk

fields.headline: Absolute designer cheek
fields.standfirst: Paris fashion circles are in uproar after British bad boy Alexander McQueen sidestepped Givenchy, the label that made his name, to sell his own brand to bitter rival Gucci.
fields.trailText: Paris fashion circles are in uproar after British bad boy Alexander McQueen sidestepped Givenchy, the label that made his name, to sell his own brand to bitter rival Gucci.
fields.body:
The London headquarters of the multi-billion-dollar Gucci fashion group just off Piccadilly were electric last weekend with excitement, or about as electric as an organisation this dedicated to the art of cool can ever be.

Gucci is a company which thinks it awfully gauche to hang nameplates announcing its presence on its buildings. The interior of its Georgian mansion on Grafton Street contains no flashy promotional materials attesting to its burgeoning sales. Heavens darling, no. Everything here is a glacial confection of white lines and space, offset by pieces of elegant modern furniture in chocolate veneer and black calfskin.

Nevertheless, up on the fourth floor big things were happening. Domenico de Sole, the buccaneering chief executive who, along with creative director Tom Ford, has taken Gucci from insolvency to the very heights of success in just seven years, was putting the finishing touches to an agreement with British fashion wunderkind Alexander McQueen.

In a deal announced last Monday, Gucci is to take a 51 per cent stake in McQueen's own label company, which already has one store in London selling McQueen's jeans and is soon to roll its shops out across the world.

By itself the news of the Gucci-McQueen deal would have made headlines, but there was one detail which made this something far more: McQueen already has a contract with a luxury brand company, Gucci's arch-rival LVMH (Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy), where he is chief designer for the Givenchy label.

For the past two years, Gucci and the gargantuan $60 billion LVMH have been locked in a legal battle. There have been allegations of corruption and shady deals, of gross mismanagement and bad faith.

McQueen's deal was seen as nothing less than a major slap in the face with a crocodile-skin handbag for LVMH. For its part, Gucci denied it was meant as anything of the sort. 'We did not do this because of LVMH,' a Gucci spokesman in London said last week. 'It's part of our long-term strategy to acquire brands in the luxury market.'

LVMH was having none of it. 'We view it as a somewhat desperate attempt to gain headlines,' said James Lieber, Director of Corporate Affairs in Paris. He then claimed that McQueen had first come to LVMH looking for the investment but that it had decided it did not make commercial sense. Nonsense, says Gucci: LVMH was never even given the chance by McQueen to make such an investment.

As for McQueen, the 31- year-old East End boy who left school at 16 to learn his trade as a tailor, he was declining all requests for interviews, though it is well known that he had long been unhappy with the strictures placed on him by the demands of a great French design house like Givenchy. 'I'm here and [will] stay here till the end of my contract,' he told Arena magazine last month. 'But I'm taking control of it from now on. Otherwise fire me, because that's what I wanted anyway.'

For the men in charge, McQueen's grousing and hyperbole is only a minor skirmish in a much bigger war. It began in February of last year when Bernard Arnault, the billionaire chief executive of LVMH, began buying up shares in Gucci. For Arnault-watchers it was a classic tactic. As well as Givenchy, his company already owned the fashion labels Louis Vuitton, Kenzo and Celine, among others. He had the champagne companies Moët & Chandon, Krug and Veuve Clicquot, the Hennessy cognac company, the Tag Heuer watch company and the perfume business of Christian Dior. He had just finished a bitter and successful take over of Chteaux d'Yquem, producers of the most prestigious and expensive Sauterne in the world. If it was in the luxury sector, Arnault wanted it. So now he wanted Gucci.

The appeal was obvious. By 1993 the once great Gucci brand had been driven into the ground by the cackhandedness of the increasingly dysfunctional family whose name the company carries. One Gucci, Aldo, was jailed for tax evasion; his successor, Maurizio, was assassinated by hitmen for his ex-wife. Meanwhile the company's logo, the solid 'G' that once meant so much, had been licensed to an increasingly trashy line of goods until the gleam of exclusivity had been dulled almost to extinction.

It was this battered shell that de Sole took public in 1993. He installed the Texan designer Ford and gave him free rein to reinvigorate the brand, which he did spectacularly well, simplifying the look to something calm, smooth and, invariably, black. Licensing deals were withdrawn and the shine swiftly returned. With the acquisition of the Yves Saint Laurent brand, the Gucci group became a watchword for smart luxury, a sleek yacht to LVMH's grand ocean liner. Last year Gucci recorded sales of nearly $2.5bn (£1.7bn) worldwide.

This was the prize Arnault wanted. He swiftly purchased 34 per cent of the stock which, in a company with a divided supervising board, was enough to give him control. Gucci insisted that LVMH either make a 100 per cent bid for the whole company or sign an agreement promising it would buy no more shares. But just before discussions started, Gucci found a white knight - the French department store chain Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, headed by Arnault's arch-rival, billionaire French businessman François Pinault.

In return for an investment of $3bn, PPR was given 44 per cent of the company and de facto control of Gucci. Arnault, furious that his own stock holding had been diluted to just 20 per cent by the move and that the prize had therefore been stolen from him, immediately sued Gucci in the Netherlands where the company is incorporated. He alleged the Gucci-PPR deal was hugely detrimental to the interest of share holders. While the Dutch courts slapped Gucci down for the way it went about the deal, they ruled that its arrangement with PPR should stand.

After a recent appeal by LVMH, a higher Dutch court ruled that the Gucci-PPR deal must be looked at again. In the meantime, attention has turned to more straightforward matters of hard cash. Ten days ago LVMH alleged that Gucci had failed to disclose an enormous share option deal the company had made with de Sole and Ford. LVMH claimed that, while the company had told share- holders about the overall number of share options to be offered to executives of the company, it had not revealed that 83 per cent of them went to just the two men.

In fact, the lion's share - four million over four years out of a total of 5.25 million - goes to Ford alone, valuing him much more highly than the chief executive to whom he reports. The first tranche of a million shares mature at a price of $75 a share. On Friday the shares were trading at $87.62, down from a recent high of $121, but still enough to guarantee a profit for Ford of $12.6 million. It would be enough to buy 45,000 pairs of his double-buckled ankle boots at £280 a shot, almost 10,000 pairs of his brown leather trousers at £1,280 or even a quarter of a million pairs of Gucci babies' slippers at a modest £50 each, all available at the company's sleek Bond Street store. And that's only this year's take.

LVMH has now filed charges against Gucci over the share options in the Dutch courts. James Lieber of LVMH said: 'If there have been violations of the law, I don't think seeking to have them rectified is sour grapes.'

Alan Tuttle, chief legal counsel to Gucci, denies the charge. 'We made all the disclosures required by Dutch law.' What's more, he says, it's an excellent investment. 'Ford and de Sole are the fellows who took a company that was insolvent in 1993 and turned it into the most profitable company by margin in the luxury sector. The share- holders should be saying hurrah.' Both sides have also filed criminal defamation suits accusing each other of outrageous lying.

What the LVMH-Gucci struggle is really about is the intricate business of flogging luxury. To give their brands the gloss that will encourage the fashion-conscious to part with hundreds of pounds for a leather-clad pen or a belt or a handbag, they need edgy, controversial designers who can attract media attention.

Gucci has been almost entirely dependent so far on Ford's energy to get it where it is today and, as the company expands, he will need help. There are many who believe that, as soon as McQueen can extricate himself from his Givenchy contract, he will take over designing the Yves Saint Laurent line Ford has been running almost single-handed.

Meanwhile, LVMH is left looking like a luxury brand company that cannot keep the all-important talent happy. Whatever it may say, the McQueen deal means that this round has been won by Gucci, the little guys in the luxury market, albeit the little guys worth a cool $10bn.

Nevertheless, up on the fourth floor big things were happening. Domenico de Sole, the buccaneering chief executive who, along with creative director Tom Ford, has taken Gucci from insolvency to the very heights of success in just seven years, was putting the finishing touches to an agreement with British fashion wunderkind Alexander McQueen. In a deal announced last Monday, Gucci is to take a 51 per cent stake in McQueen's own label company, which already has one store in London selling McQueen's jeans and is soon to roll its shops out across the world. By itself the news of the Gucci-McQueen deal would have made headlines, but there was one detail which made this something far more: McQueen already has a contract with a luxury brand company, Gucci's arch-rival LVMH (Louis Vuitton Moët Hennessy), where he is chief designer for the Givenchy label. For the past two years, Gucci and the gargantuan $60 billion LVMH have been locked in a legal battle. There have been allegations of corruption and shady deals, of gross mismanagement and bad faith. McQueen's deal was seen as nothing less than a major slap in the face with a crocodile-skin handbag for LVMH. For its part, Gucci denied it was meant as anything of the sort. 'We did not do this because of LVMH,' a Gucci spokesman in London said last week. 'It's part of our long-term strategy to acquire brands in the luxury market.' LVMH was having none of it. 'We view it as a somewhat desperate attempt to gain headlines,' said James Lieber, Director of Corporate Affairs in Paris. He then claimed that McQueen had first come to LVMH looking for the investment but that it had decided it did not make commercial sense. Nonsense, says Gucci: LVMH was never even given the chance by McQueen to make such an investment. As for McQueen, the 31- year-old East End boy who left school at 16 to learn his trade as a tailor, he was declining all requests for interviews, though it is well known that he had long been unhappy with the strictures placed on him by the demands of a great French design house like Givenchy. 'I'm here and [will] stay here till the end of my contract,' he told Arena magazine last month. 'But I'm taking control of it from now on. Otherwise fire me, because that's what I wanted anyway.' For the men in charge, McQueen's grousing and hyperbole is only a minor skirmish in a much bigger war. It began in February of last year when Bernard Arnault, the billionaire chief executive of LVMH, began buying up shares in Gucci. For Arnault-watchers it was a classic tactic. As well as Givenchy, his company already owned the fashion labels Louis Vuitton, Kenzo and Celine, among others. He had the champagne companies Moët & Chandon, Krug and Veuve Clicquot, the Hennessy cognac company, the Tag Heuer watch company and the perfume business of Christian Dior. He had just finished a bitter and successful take over of Chteaux d'Yquem, producers of the most prestigious and expensive Sauterne in the world. If it was in the luxury sector, Arnault wanted it. So now he wanted Gucci. The appeal was obvious. By 1993 the once great Gucci brand had been driven into the ground by the cackhandedness of the increasingly dysfunctional family whose name the company carries. One Gucci, Aldo, was jailed for tax evasion; his successor, Maurizio, was assassinated by hitmen for his ex-wife. Meanwhile the company's logo, the solid 'G' that once meant so much, had been licensed to an increasingly trashy line of goods until the gleam of exclusivity had been dulled almost to extinction. It was this battered shell that de Sole took public in 1993. He installed the Texan designer Ford and gave him free rein to reinvigorate the brand, which he did spectacularly well, simplifying the look to something calm, smooth and, invariably, black. Licensing deals were withdrawn and the shine swiftly returned. With the acquisition of the Yves Saint Laurent brand, the Gucci group became a watchword for smart luxury, a sleek yacht to LVMH's grand ocean liner. Last year Gucci recorded sales of nearly $2.5bn (£1.7bn) worldwide. This was the prize Arnault wanted. He swiftly purchased 34 per cent of the stock which, in a company with a divided supervising board, was enough to give him control. Gucci insisted that LVMH either make a 100 per cent bid for the whole company or sign an agreement promising it would buy no more shares. But just before discussions started, Gucci found a white knight - the French department store chain Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, headed by Arnault's arch-rival, billionaire French businessman François Pinault. In return for an investment of $3bn, PPR was given 44 per cent of the company and de facto control of Gucci. Arnault, furious that his own stock holding had been diluted to just 20 per cent by the move and that the prize had therefore been stolen from him, immediately sued Gucci in the Netherlands where the company is incorporated. He alleged the Gucci-PPR deal was hugely detrimental to the interest of share holders. While the Dutch courts slapped Gucci down for the way it went about the deal, they ruled that its arrangement with PPR should stand. After a recent appeal by LVMH, a higher Dutch court ruled that the Gucci-PPR deal must be looked at again. In the meantime, attention has turned to more straightforward matters of hard cash. Ten days ago LVMH alleged that Gucci had failed to disclose an enormous share option deal the company had made with de Sole and Ford. LVMH claimed that, while the company had told share- holders about the overall number of share options to be offered to executives of the company, it had not revealed that 83 per cent of them went to just the two men. In fact, the lion's share - four million over four years out of a total of 5.25 million - goes to Ford alone, valuing him much more highly than the chief executive to whom he reports. The first tranche of a million shares mature at a price of $75 a share. On Friday the shares were trading at $87.62, down from a recent high of $121, but still enough to guarantee a profit for Ford of $12.6 million. It would be enough to buy 45,000 pairs of his double-buckled ankle boots at £280 a shot, almost 10,000 pairs of his brown leather trousers at £1,280 or even a quarter of a million pairs of Gucci babies' slippers at a modest £50 each, all available at the company's sleek Bond Street store. And that's only this year's take. LVMH has now filed charges against Gucci over the share options in the Dutch courts. James Lieber of LVMH said: 'If there have been violations of the law, I don't think seeking to have them rectified is sour grapes.' Alan Tuttle, chief legal counsel to Gucci, denies the charge. 'We made all the disclosures required by Dutch law.' What's more, he says, it's an excellent investment. 'Ford and de Sole are the fellows who took a company that was insolvent in 1993 and turned it into the most profitable company by margin in the luxury sector. The share- holders should be saying hurrah.' Both sides have also filed criminal defamation suits accusing each other of outrageous lying. What the LVMH-Gucci struggle is really about is the intricate business of flogging luxury. To give their brands the gloss that will encourage the fashion-conscious to part with hundreds of pounds for a leather-clad pen or a belt or a handbag, they need edgy, controversial designers who can attract media attention. Gucci has been almost entirely dependent so far on Ford's energy to get it where it is today and, as the company expands, he will need help. There are many who believe that, as soon as McQueen can extricate himself from his Givenchy contract, he will take over designing the Yves Saint Laurent line Ford has been running almost single-handed. Meanwhile, LVMH is left looking like a luxury brand company that cannot keep the all-important talent happy. Whatever it may say, the McQueen deal means that this round has been won by Gucci, the little guys in the luxury market, albeit the little guys worth a cool $10bn. The kings of luxury: LVMH Company value: $60 billion Fashion Louis Vuitton Loewe Kenzo Celine Givenchy Christian Lacroix Thomas Pink Champagne and wines Moët & Chandon Veuve Clicquot Chateau d'Yquem Krug Hennessy Cloudy Bay Cosmetics Christian Dior Guerlain Givenchy Watches Tag Heuer GUCCI GROUP Company value: $10 billion Fashion Gucci Yves Saint Laurent Sergio Rossi Alexander McQueen Cosmetics Van Cleef & Arpels Oscar de la Renta Roger & Gallet Fendi Jewellery Boucheron

webTitle: Restaurants: Gothic revival

fields.headline: Gothic revival
fields.standfirst: With its eerie decor, shadowy proprietor and blood-curdling menu, (Fitz)Henry is not for the fainthearted, says Jay Rayner
fields.trailText: With its eerie decor, shadowy proprietor and blood-curdling menu, (Fitz)Henry is not for the fainthearted, says Jay Rayner.
fields.body:
I have not spent an enormous amount of time in either Swedish youth hostels or gay brothels, nevertheless, when I say that the interior of (Fitz)Henry, a quietly funky bistro on the Leith docks in Edinburgh, looks like a cross between the two, I am reasonably confident of accuracy.

The ceiling is panelled in a curiously orange shade of varnished pine and the walls are hung with rococo flounces of heavy velvet or great sheets of thick linen, positioned just so. It is all rather odd, but in a nice way, which could easily serve as an advertising slogan for the place. The food is also a little odd. The service is certainly odd. But, as I say, mostly in a nice way.

I went with Ruaridh, one of Edinburgh's emerging literary lions, who used to live in a house in the Highlands with an eagle's cage attached, and who therefore seemed ideally suited to the Gothic surroundings. On a quiet Monday, we were waited on by the boss, Dave Ramsden - a thin, shaven-headed man with a gaze that penetrated through the gloom and a voice so deep that when he spoke the cutlery on our table rattled and the building's foundations shook. If the restaurant business ever lets him down, I'm sure he could make a healthy living voicing trailers for scary American movies.

For now, it is almost as if he is starring in one: he has a curious ability to appear at your side without you noticing - a neat trick to pull in a big room with only three occupied tables. And no sooner was he there than he was gone again, floating away into the shadows, leaving behind just the rumbling echo of that voice and the smell of sulphur. (OK, I made up the sulphur bit but the Gothic thing was all very odd - though, again, in a nice way.)

For his starter, Ruaridh ordered the chilled mussel and king prawn velouté with coconut milk and ginger, which struck me as a very Edinburgh thing to find on a menu. It was a dark November night, the wind outside blowing hard off the Water of Leith, but do they serve a hot soup? Not a bit of it. Hot soup is for southern nancies. In November, they serve theirs chilled. In December, it probably comes as a sorbet. I thought it a little on the underpowered side, but Ruaridh disagreed. It was, he said, a fine palate cleanser, and thick with good, fresh seafood. My steamed ballotine of rabbit confit with Savoy cabbage and haricot bean cream was the exact opposite: a solid, hearty and meaty dish. The perfect thing for a cold, early winter's night.

My main course was a genuine original: a whole baked red mullet, split down the gut and overflowing with a pine nut and squid stuffing, as though only in the very earliest stages of a brutal disembowelling. (The mood of the place is clearly getting to me.) It was an extraordinary piece of work, the fishiness of the squid playing brilliantly against the mullet. Ruaridh's main course of a stunning fillet of beef from the (relatively) nearby Buccleugh estate was exactly the kind of thing you want to find in an Edinburgh restaurant. There were a few other things on the plate - confit potatoes, a parsley emulsion - but they all played second fiddle to the marvellous piece of beef.

The puddings, it must be said, were not so much odd in a nice way as just plain odd. We passed on the chocolate and beetroot cake with orange sorbet and the frozen yogurt terrine with candied fennel and carrots. Instead I went for the warm egg doughnuts with vanilla citrus fruits, which read far better than it tasted. You wanted something straight out of the deep fat fryer but this seemed as if it had been hanging about on the plate a little too long.

Ruaridh's caramelised pine nut and sultana rice pudding looked pretty in its pastry shell, but was essentially just a great rice pudding that had been tragically interfered with. We consoled ourselves with a glass each of Tich dessert wine from a winery just across the river from Sauterne. It was rich and fragrant and nicely acidic. In April, the great vampire's castle that is (Fitz)Henry moves further into Edinburgh to a site which, appropriately, was once occupied by Scottish Widows. Somehow I suspect that the Swedish youth hostel varnished pine will not go with him, but doubtless the rest of the decor will. In any case, as long as Dave Ramsden and his voice are there to rattle the window frames the atmosphere will remain.

 (Fitz)Henry, 19 Shore Place, Leith, Edinburgh (0131 555 6625). Dinner for two, including wine and service, around £80. Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.

webTitle: Let there be light

fields.headline: Let there be light
fields.standfirst: James Turrell has harnessed the pearly skies and eerie darkness of wildest Northumbria to create his new sky sculpture
fields.trailText: James Turrell has harnessed the pearly skies and eerie darkness of wildest Northumbria to create his new sky sculpture.
fields.body:
James Turrell's Skyspace stands on Cat Cairn, a promontory looking right down the 7-mile length of Kielder Water like a watchtower or blind lighthouse. The first analogy appeals to the romanticism of being just 8 miles from the Scottish border, while the second is more accurate. To get there, you must first come through the 250 square miles of the largest planted forest in Britain and then skirt along the shores of Kielder Water, which is the largest man-made lake in Europe. Given that the purpose of my trip was to look at a piece of art set in landscape, this long, increasingly impressive approach sets you into scale by expanding your cloistered, city or village horizons and then drawing them back to the turret on the crag.

I am shamefully ignorant of this part of England, having only once paid a childhood visit to Hadrian's Wall and otherwise seen the north-east as one of those mysteries, like the Black Country or the Fens - knowing that they inspire love and passion, but having no inkling of why that is. There is no fool like an ignorant fool. Thankfully, it is never too late to learn. For a start, it is a staggeringly beautiful part of the country. And it is a breathing space away from the writhing south, which is always an advantage.

With the trains all over the shop and only a day to get there and back, I took a 45-minute flight from Birmingham of such cramped discomfort that it felt like a joke (except that the £280 price was distinctly unfunny). But Newcastle airport is downright sexy and in minutes you are driving north-east towards the vast stretches of Kielder Forest and the Scottish border. This is Viking country, raided from north and east for 1,000 years not for possession of the soil but to spoil and dispossess. To flex the border. Even on a grey November day in the wettest autumn ever, the light is pearly rather than lowering - and when you go in search of Turrell's work, the light is everything. It is his medium. Earth and stone are used only to contain and corral light and to this end he has built 'Skyspaces' in his Arizona-desert home, as well as in Ireland, Japan, Israel, Holland, France and Northumberland.

I first came across his work in June 1991. I was a freelancer then and received a commission to write about the gardens of the south-west corner of Ireland. We went to Skibbereen to see Creagh gardens, which I had read were 'charming'. (There's a hint of condescension in that expression: grand cannot be charming, stylish can never be charming, but small, muddly and eccentric can.) We popped into the local tourist office and it was suggested we go and see the Sky Gardens, which were just being made. So, before visiting Creagh, we went and had a fascinating few hours there.

The estate had been bought by a wealthy Swiss art dealer who commissioned James Turrell to create an installation. When we visited, it was still at the bulldozer stage, but Turrell also happened to be visiting (he lives in Arizona) and he was, er, charming. But not in a garden way. Rather grand and impressive. Memorable. I was very taken with that Skibbereen garden because it was the first time I had seen a large outdoor space used by an artist in such a coherent, visionary way. Visionary is exactly the right word, because all Turrell's work depends upon the way that you, the viewer, sees things. As he has said about his work: '[It] is not so much about my seeing as about your seeing. There is no one between you and your experience.' That kind of remark can easily lead to the situation where it has to be pointed out to the emperor that he is wearing no clothes unless there is an experience worth seeing. But with Turrell, there always is. He walks the walk.

The Kielder Skyspace is essentially an underground chamber approached from a round tunnel cut through the side of the hill. If you visit the excellent website (www.kielder.org) you can see from a series of photographs that the chamber and tunnel have been constructed from reinforced concrete and then piled over with rock and earth, but the effect is subterranean, a modern tumulus.

But what is buried inside is not a bundle of bones and artefacts to guide you into the dark, but light. The ceiling of the Skyspace is a framed circle open to the sky. The light from this empty space seems to fill the eye like a pulsating, glowing object and at the same time softly illuminate the chamber. It makes the space seem contained and rich and yet is exactly the same subdued, low grey cloud cover that you flew through and drove beneath.

The details are monumental and very precise: white walls running seamlessly into white ceiling making a circular frame round the open ring of sky; massive concrete seats painted grey linking to the grey interior of the circular entrance tunnel; and faultlessly crisp edges to the circles of sky and black gravel directly beneath the open roof. Sound bounces round the walls. The effect is mesmerising, quietly transfixing. At dawn or dusk your entrance into the Skyspace triggers lights around the circular space hidden behind the seats, creating a ring of ambient light and the white walls glow ochre to enrich the sky colour.

The experience of sitting quietly (albeit freezing) is enormously satisfying and enriching, even though sensation is stripped down and pared back as far as it will go without being diminished. All superfluities are abandoned. I would love this in my garden. A building like this, subterranean or overtly external, is within the tradition of temples in the landscape such as you find at Stowe or Stourhead. To find this type of building - in itself lifted from temples and bowers of medieval, Roman, Greek and Byzantine civilisations, interpreted in this modern idiom - is tremendously exciting, especially in the rather philistine world of conventional garden buildings.

Don't get me wrong: I am sure that Turrell would be amused to think of this piece of art compared to a summerhouse or merely a decorative stop in a highly manufactured landscape, but the analogy is nevertheless there. Gardens are our private, domestic landscape. Although seemingly a vast expanse of wilderness, Kielder Forest is in many ways as artificial and contrived as any garden. It is not an unpopulated space that is needed for this work so much as unpolluted light, free of the insidious ambient glow of street lamps and car headlights.

Any carefully thought out garden building, whether it uses light as skillfully as Turrell does or is simply contrived to provide calm seclusion, adds a vital element to the garden as a whole. This obviously happens on an external level, although I would prefer it if the whole thing were completely submerged beneath its hillock of earth and rock, rather than cladding it in drystone and burying only the bottom half. But perhaps in a massive public space like Kielder the sight of the tower is needed as a signpost to announce itself.

But what really matters is what happens on an internal level. The building and contemplative manipulation of light and space strongly influences how you see the world and in particular how you use light and space at home, indoors and out.

Buildings in the garden world, both domestic and public, are on the whole embarrassingly badly designed, retrospective and unambitious. But the Skyspace and the other buildings at Kielder are ambitious, modern grown-up works of art that can compete with anything else in the world. No doubt planning permission and the cost (the Skyspace cost £300,000) would constrain all but the grandest gardeners, but I will be thinking very carefully how to include the lessons of Kielder into my own backyard and I urge you to make the journey there to do the same.

My roots: A week in Monty's garden

I had some chillies in the tunnel hanging on all autumn, not growing or ripening but not dying either. Nevertheless I pulled them all up this week and the space has been given over instead to parsley that I had been growing in pots. For years, I had laboured under the delusion that parsley needs damp shade to thrive. It doesn't. It will tolerate some damp, but too much will rot its roots. In fact, I have even put cloches over the parsley growing outside to try and keep it drier.

The leaves this year clung on for dear life, but finally fell. The big hazel outside the back door is the real arbiter of season and its nakedness can only spell winter. But the most beautiful leaves this sodden autumn were those of a rose, Rosa wilmottiae . This has a shimmer of tiny leaves the colour of beaten gold that lasted for weeks, carried on plum red stems with weird and beautiful thorns bunched all together. In summer, it has small, fairly modest lilac-pink flowers. It is one of a batch of assorted roses that I planted a few years ago and which I love. They include R hugonis , R cantabridgiensis , R moyesii , R wintonensis , R sericea pteracantha, R moschata and R complicata . They are all tough and loose, and pretty unsuitable for a small garden. They prune with a pair of shears and their laxity and sprawling nature encourages a general freeing of the garden spirit. Long may they sprawl.

I have had an injured shoulder for months now which has severely limited my horticultural activities and last week I added to my infirmities by dropping a paving slab on my foot. We were shifting stone that was laid this summer in the Jewel garden for a patch indoors, reasoning that it was less work to redo the work outside than to go and find a new source of slabs that will match. Anyway, this very handsome square of York stone landed on my instep which made it swell dramatically, turn black and reduced me to a hobble for a few days. Entirely my fault. Of course, a psychoanalyst would say that these things are never accidental and that what I really wanted was an excuse not to garden. And with the rain tattooing the windows, the sodden ground either submerged or slicked with mud, the light almost gone by 3pm while I lie with my foot up on the sofa watching the rugby on television, I can believe that, subconscious or not, there might be a grain of truth in that.

All superfluities are abandoned. I would love this in my garden. A building like this, subterranean or overtly external, is within the tradition of temples in the landscape such as you find at Stowe or Stourhead. To find this type of building - in itself lifted from temples and bowers of medieval, Roman, Greek and Byzantine civilisations, interpreted in this modern idiom - is tremendously exciting, especially in the rather philistine world of conventional garden buildings. Don't get me wrong: I am sure that Turrell would be amused to think of this piece of art compared to a summerhouse or merely a decorative stop in a highly manufactured landscape, but the analogy is nevertheless there. Gardens are our private, domestic landscape. Although seemingly a vast expanse of wilderness, Kielder Forest is in many ways as artificial and contrived as any garden. It is not an unpopulated space that is needed for this work so much as unpolluted light, free of the insidious ambient glow of street lamps and car headlights. Any carefully thought out garden building, whether it uses light as skillfully as Turrell does or is simply contrived to provide calm seclusion, adds a vital element to the garden as a whole. This obviously happens on an external level, although I would prefer it if the whole thing were completely submerged beneath its hillock of earth and rock, rather than cladding it in drystone and burying only the bottom half. But perhaps in a massive public space like Kielder the sight of the tower is needed as a signpost to announce itself. But what really matters is what happens on an internal level. The building and contemplative manipulation of light and space strongly influences how you see the world and in particular how you use light and space at home, indoors and out. Buildings in the garden world, both domestic and public, are on the whole embarrassingly badly designed, retrospective and unambitious. But the Skyspace and the other buildings at Kielder are ambitious, modern grown-up works of art that can compete with anything else in the world. No doubt planning permission and the cost (the Skyspace cost £300,000) would constrain all but the grandest gardeners, but I will be thinking very carefully how to include the lessons of Kielder into my own backyard and I urge you to make the journey there to do the same. My roots: A week in Monty's garden I had some chillies in the tunnel hanging on all autumn, not growing or ripening but not dying either. Nevertheless I pulled them all up this week and the space has been given over instead to parsley that I had been growing in pots. For years, I had laboured under the delusion that parsley needs damp shade to thrive. It doesn't. It will tolerate some damp, but too much will rot its roots. In fact, I have even put cloches over the parsley growing outside to try and keep it drier. The leaves this year clung on for dear life, but finally fell. The big hazel outside the back door is the real arbiter of season and its nakedness can only spell winter. But the most beautiful leaves this sodden autumn were those of a rose, Rosa wilmottiae . This has a shimmer of tiny leaves the colour of beaten gold that lasted for weeks, carried on plum red stems with weird and beautiful thorns bunched all together. In summer, it has small, fairly modest lilac-pink flowers. It is one of a batch of assorted roses that I planted a few years ago and which I love. They include R hugonis , R cantabridgiensis , R moyesii , R wintonensis , R sericea pteracantha, R moschata and R complicata . They are all tough and loose, and pretty unsuitable for a small garden. They prune with a pair of shears and their laxity and sprawling nature encourages a general freeing of the garden spirit. Long may they sprawl. I have had an injured shoulder for months now which has severely limited my horticultural activities and last week I added to my infirmities by dropping a paving slab on my foot. We were shifting stone that was laid this summer in the Jewel garden for a patch indoors, reasoning that it was less work to redo the work outside than to go and find a new source of slabs that will match. Anyway, this very handsome square of York stone landed on my instep which made it swell dramatically, turn black and reduced me to a hobble for a few days. Entirely my fault. Of course, a psychoanalyst would say that these things are never accidental and that what I really wanted was an excuse not to garden. And with the rain tattooing the windows, the sodden ground either submerged or slicked with mud, the light almost gone by 3pm while I lie with my foot up on the sofa watching the rugby on television, I can believe that, subconscious or not, there might be a grain of truth in that.

webTitle: Short attacks 'intolerable' green lobbyists

fields.headline: Short attacks 'intolerable' green lobbyists
fields.trailText: International development secretary Clare Short has launched a stinging attack on 'intolerable' green protesters and 'self-indulgent' globalisation demonstrators, in remarks which last night prompted fresh controversy.
fields.body:
Clare Short has launched a stinging attack on 'intolerable' green protesters and 'self-indulgent' globalisation demonstrators, in remarks which last night prompted fresh controversy.

In an interview with The Observer , the International Development Secretary also rounded on consumer boycott campaigns, which urge shoppers not to buy goods made with child labour, as potentially damaging to children in poverty.

Short spoke out as she prepared to launch a White Paper on how globalisation can be harnessed to help developing countries and to eliminate world poverty.

Short offers a robust defence of the controversial World Trade Organisation and the importance of fair access to western markets as crucial to the development process.

But it is her impatience with the environmental lobby, accusing them of hypocrisy, that will create controversy. 'They infuriate the developing world because they seem to be saying "we have had all the benefits of development, thank you very much, and now we'll erect some walls to enable the sustainability of the planet which will prevent the poorest people of the planet sharing in the fruits that we have",' she said. 'It is intolerable.'

Short also attacked campaigns to boycott the products of child labour, such as footballs stitched together by young children in Pakistan, as well-meaning but misguided. Banning them from factories could leave their families dependent on begging and prostitution unless alternative income was found first, she said.

'I want children to be out of work and into education, and their parents to have enough income so that their children don't have to work,' she added. 'But we've got to do it in a way that links up their lives and does not just give you clean hands and actually damage the poorest of the Earth.'

She went on to criticise protestors against free trade and multinationals.

'I don't see how burning down McDonald's helps anyone anywhere in the world. I think it is self-indulgent. I am interested in results.'

Short's frank views on subjects from the volcano-stricken citizens of Montserrat, accused of wanting 'golden elephants next', to spin doctors have landed her in hot water before now. And last night environmentalists hit back.

'Clare Short is very good at getting things upside down,' said a spokesman for Friends of the Earth. 'Environmentalists aren't patronising developing countries by opposing polluting development, they are working with them to save these countries from people apparently like Clare Short, who want to force technologies on them that the rest of the world is now rejecting.'

Meanwhile her Tory shadow, Gary Streeter, accused her of complacency over child labour. 'This is a delicate subject but I think people should feel free if they want to protest and keep the issue in the public eye not to buy things.

'Obviously a 14-year-old working in a sweatshop may be earning the only income available to the family and if you stop that you are doing a bad thing. But I think it is right that people should have stakeholder power as consumers.'

The row marred what is expected to be a well-received White Paper, arguing that globalisation need not prove a threat to the developing world.

It is expected to propose initiatives including the launch of a new Development Act, measures to enable governments to reclaim money illicitly banked in London and further steps to untie British aid so that recipients can spend it to get best value anywhere in the world, stressing Britain's commitment to help halve world poverty by 2015.

webTitle: Rights we all have earned

fields.headline: Rights we all have earned
fields.trailText: It is 52 years since the United Nations signed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (on 10 December 1948). Now we need some clear, positive statements about fundamentals that are of direct relevance to each and every one of us.
fields.body:
It is 52 years since the United Nations signed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights (on 10 December 1948). This year has been particularly significant because for the first time since 1688, a rights-based framework has passed on to the British statute book. Now we need some clear, positive statements about fundamentals that are of direct relevance to each and every one of us.

How many British people even know they have human rights? Human rights are often seen as something that happens to other people. The image of an Amnesty International prisoner of conscience comes to mind. This represents an important facet of human rights, but it does not touch the everyday lives of most British people.

While our country is rightly proud of the individual civil and political freedoms it can offer, we hear very little about the economic, social and cultural rights that are an equal part of the universal declaration. Issues such as health, education and housing are not easily seen by British people as human rights issues at all, but rather as facets of the welfare state or acts of charity. We will hear a lot about the National Health Service in the media this winter, but will anyone refer to our 'right' to health? The quality of our children's education is also a 'right' for their future development and should not be a product of their local environment, parent's income or élite schooling for the few.

A 'rights-based' culture will bring about slow but fundamental changes in how we view our lives and what we expect from government. We would already be well ahead in this area, if the United States (our role-model in many ways) had signed and ratified enough international human rights law, which it has not. While economic, social and cultural rights are regarded as 'socialism through the back door' by many opinion leaders in the USA and not as the universal human rights which they are, millions will remain excluded from even basic health care. To effect a change here we need to look across the channel, not the Atlantic.

The British Human Rights Act came into law on 2 October and incorporated the European Convention on Human Rights; which is nothing to do with the European Union but everything to do with the Council of Europe - an older, more inclusive organisation. Most of the coverage given to this historic moment was negative - speed cameras, loony lawyers, bosses reading our emails. Try to see how the Human Rights Act might change our lives in the short-term and you resort to fringe issues and miss the point. As crazy cases are dismissed and real issues upheld by British judges, a rights-based culture will develop.

Yet the European Convention on Human Rights, despite its name, is mainly only concerned with civil and political rights and so is only two slices of the full human rights pizza set out in the universal declaration. For non-governmental organisations (NGOs) to be able to protect our economic, social and cultural rights, the UK government needs to improve our access to Strasbourg under the European social charter (again a Council of Europe construct). Until the British government signs and ratifies the additional protocol to the European social charter, we as British citizens do not enjoy this right.

The most important message today, International Human Rights Day, is that we should spread the word. The pre-amble to the universal declaration states that 'every organ of society shall strive by teaching and education to promote respect for these rights', and this is why The Body Shop will continue to be involved in this area through its human rights award and international campaigns. Why, for instance, do so few of us stand up for asylum-seekers and refugees who are currently being denied some of their most basic rights in our country?

But most of all, this is why the British government should set up an independent human rights commission to help educate us all about our rights and make sure we are living up to all our obligations.

webTitle: Best launches crusade to curb drinking

fields.headline: Alcohol-free
fields.standfirst: Best launches crusade to curb drinking
fields.trailText: Best launches crusade to curb drinking.
fields.body:
For years he joked about his fondness for brandy and champagne and seemed not to care that his heavy drinking made him an embarrassment, regularly landed him in trouble and left him a shambling shadow of the supreme sportsman he once was.

But now George Best, widely regarded as the greatest footballer ever, is set to lay bare the grimmest details of his 25-year battle with the bottle in a hard-hitting campaign to highlight the destructive effects of alcohol.

The soccer legend will speak frankly about his long struggle with alcoholism as part of an effort to raise money for research into drink-related liver damage, the condition which nearly killed him earlier this year. That near-death experience has brought about a huge change in Best, who has pledged to raise awareness about a disease which he warns can damage anyone in society 'whether you're a down-and-out or a genius'.

'I guarantee you there's no one who doesn't know someone who has had a problem, either directly or indirectly, through alcohol. Unfortunately it's there. It's easily available. It's a serious, serious problem,' Best said. 'It's a terrible illness, not only for people who drink too much, as I obviously did, but also for young kids who suffer from failure of the liver.'

The 54-year-old ex-Manchester United star, who is now teetotal, will join forces with Professor Roger Williams, the doctor who nursed him back to health after he collapsed last March, in a bid to raise £150,000 to fund a three-year study into alcohol's impact on the liver. The money will pay for research at the Institute of Hepatology at University College Hospital in London run by Williams, a leading liver specialist.

Where Best once made light of his condition, now he wants to warn about the dangers of 'a terrible illness' and help other problem drinkers. He began drinking heavily when he retired in 1974 in a vain bid to replace the 'buzz' he got from playing. Perhaps his most embarrassing alcohol-related moment came in 1990 when BBC chatshow host Terry Wogan cut short a live interview with a visibly drunk Best who was slurring and swearing.

Williams said Best's decision to speak out could radically change attitudes towards alcoholism and fund work which could lead to improvements in patients suffering liver failure.

'There hasn't been much research done into liver disease because of the stigma of alcoholism and it has been hard to raise funds,' said Williams. 'But I hope that with George being so open about his condition, that will help to put a better perspective on an illness that needs better treatment. It's a great tribute to George that he's doing this.'

Best and Williams plan to speak at a series of fundraising dinners. The first is likely to be next spring at Old Trafford, where Best used to play. A United spokesman said: 'The club has received a request to help with the initiative and is happy to consider ways of supporting the appeal. Anything that George is involved with is important to us too, because he remains a legend among our supporters.'

Best says that when he was rushed to London's Cromwell Hospital last March, yellow with jaundice, his liver was 'just about gone. It's still not right. I was pretty bad. I was lucky. I got involved with a wonderful man, Roger Williams. He basically told me that if I had another drink, that was it'. Best admits he could easily have died then. 'Every day is a bonus [now]', he says.

The star, who now divides his time between working for Sky TV and living quietly in his native Northern Ireland, is glad alcoholism 'has been recognised by the medical profession as an illness. Not so long ago, if you said alcohol, you were treated a little bit like a leper. They thought someone who drank too much was a drunk. But that's not the way it is. It doesn't have any bounds, alcohol. It doesn't matter whether you're a down-and-out or a genius.'

Dr Domhnall MacAuley, editor of the British Journal of Sports Medicine , said: 'George's decision to talk about his condition could challenge the pub mentality of British football and help young players who want to stay away from alcohol to do so.

'My only fear is that he may fall off the wagon, as he did before. That would be a heavy blow to this excellent initiative. You never beat alcoholism. You control it one day at a time.'

Best admits he has had 'one slip' since March - two glasses of champagne which made him feel 'really ill' - but says new drugs have helped to eliminate his craving for drink.

webTitle: Will Hutton interviews Clare Short: A Third Way for the Third World?

fields.headline: A Third Way for the Third World?
fields.standfirst:
On the eve of a major White Paper on globalisation, Will Hutton talks to Clare Short about the fight against world poverty

The globalisation debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Clare Short tells Will Hutton that self-indulgent protest must not deflect attention from helping the developing world join in the same capitalism that delivers the goods for us
fields.body:
The Secretary of State for International Development is nothing if not ambitious. Tomorrow, Clare Short is publishing a White Paper on how globalisation can be made to work for the world's poor. She wants everyone to read it - and then say: 'For God's sake get on with it.'

'I have set out to change the language of the international system,' she reproached me when I interviewed her and started by asking about poverty alleviation. 'Hardly anyone talks about "alleviation" any more because it is not conceptually right. It is kind of softening the impact of poverty and not getting rid of it.' Sharpen up, Will Hutton!

She wants to get on with shaping the current world system to halve the proportion of people living in extreme poverty, to ensure that every child goes to primary school and that the mother of every baby has proper health care - and all by 2015. She is impressed by the way the Asian Tigers have managed to use access to world markets, investment in education, controlled capitalism and energetic government to lever themselves towards Western living standards in less than a generation. The task now, she believes, is to ensure that the countries of South Asia and Africa repeat the Tigers' lead.

Her mission is to save development from those who think it is 'pictures of African children with flies on their faces that moves their heart, they put some money in the charity box and feel depressed.' Instead, she wants to offer a programme 'that is practical and achievable; that removes the cause of their suffering'. This, she hopes, will generate demands for action and a transformation of how we think about the world's poor.

Clare Short in full sail has always been formidable, whether she is decrying page three girls or the illiberalism of the Prevention of Terrorism Acts.

Now her commitment to capitalism in the service of poverty elimination has made her the scourge of anti-free trade protesters and environmentalists alike. The Secretary of State is trying to bring Third Way politics into an area where it seems least likely to succeed and, at the same time, to make it understandable and controversial.

For, as street protests at the European Summit in Nice this weekend follow those at the IMF and World Bank annual general meeting in Prague in September and, famously, in Seattle at the abortive World Trade Organisation meeting, globalisation has not got many popular champions.

The onward march of transnational corporations and world money markets dismantles icons such as national community and democracy, has enfeebled governments and provoked universal disquiet. From British euro-scepticism, to Islamic fundamentalism or the re-emergence of the Austrian far right - all have similar roots in locally grounded disquiet that what really matters to people no longer has legitimacy. Clare Short is taking on this movement head to head. She believes this reaction is wrong-headed, hypocritical and selfish.

What the poor want, she says, and what she wants for them, is a chance to enjoy Western living standards by joining in the same capitalism that delivers the goods for us.

Her main concern is Africa: conflict- ridden, devastated by Aids and home to the majority of the world's extreme poor. She sees the success of Mozambique and Uganda in winning inward investment and sustaining Asian Tiger-type economic growth rates that allows them to keep ahead of population growth - albeit from a desperately low base - as a model for the rest of the continent.

But although she praises free trade and private inward investment, Short still carries 'the white woman's burden' - the belief that the rich countries must take responsibility. A Western country like Britain has to get stuck in and help, especially in providing health and education and also to stop corrupt governments, she believes. Good governments must uphold rigorous standards in both the private and public sectors - and above all in their 'unreliable' African banks which ship out of Africa proportionally 10 times more savings than happens in Asia.

One of Short's intended plans is to help governments recover money illicitly salted away in London by their predecessors.

The big story, though, is to embrace the market. She talks enthusiastically about how Africa must develop by using its abundant land to grow agricultural goods for world markets with higher added-value - from coffee to flowers - and process the products in Africa.

I put it to her that this is diametrically opposed to the arguments from green campaigners like Vandana Shiva who has her own farm in South India where she grows organic food using traditional methods in order to maximise local employment - and who is sharply critical of Short's approach because it creates inequality and environmental depredation.

Short returns the fire: 'I would like to go to her house. I'll bet she's got things that come from all over the world. If you want to lock Africa and the poorest of South Asia out of that world, you're locking them into marginalisation and growing poverty. It is intolerable.'

She has the same contempt for the anti-trade protesters. 'I don't see how burning down McDonald's helps anyone anywhere in the world. I think it is self-indulgent. Actually breaking up the World Trade Organisation would put us backwards. We would then have big rich governments and companies setting the rules for trade. Small and poor countries wouldn't have any say in it.'

Nor should the rules-based trading system she defends have a rule against the use of child labour; it is only a reflection of extreme poverty and if we stop it we only condemn children to worse - beggary and prostitution.

'The Americans argued in Seattle that there should be a rule in the WTO that says any country that has child labour has barriers against its trade. But that would punish every single poor country in the world,' she says.

Her free trade instincts do not extend to free financial markets, which she thinks can be a menace. She favours the Tobin tax, taxing foreign exchange speculation, but only if it can be made to be practical and thinks that countries have to be careful how to decontrol their banks and foreign exchange markets. Governments may have to step in to stop capital stampeding out of a country in panic with capital controls.

Short is right about the World Trade Organisation, right about the potential benefits from globalisation and right about the priorities for Third World governments. fields.bodyText: The Secretary of State for International Development is nothing if not ambitious. Tomorrow, Clare Short is publishing a White Paper on how globalisation can be made to work for the world's poor. She wants everyone to read it - and then say: 'For God's sake get on with it.' 'I have set out to change the language of the international system,' she reproached me when I interviewed her and started by asking about poverty alleviation. 'Hardly anyone talks about "alleviation" any more because it is not conceptually right. It is kind of softening the impact of poverty and not getting rid of it.' Sharpen up, Will Hutton! She wants to get on with shaping the current world system to halve the proportion of people living in extreme poverty, to ensure that every child goes to primary school and that the mother of every baby has proper health care - and all by 2015. She is impressed by the way the Asian Tigers have managed to use access to world markets, investment in education, controlled capitalism and energetic government to lever themselves towards Western living standards in less than a generation. The task now, she believes, is to ensure that the countries of South Asia and Africa repeat the Tigers' lead. Her mission is to save development from those who think it is 'pictures of African children with flies on their faces that moves their heart, they put some money in the charity box and feel depressed.' Instead, she wants to offer a programme 'that is practical and achievable; that removes the cause of their suffering'. This, she hopes, will generate demands for action and a transformation of how we think about the world's poor. Clare Short in full sail has always been formidable, whether she is decrying page three girls or the illiberalism of the Prevention of Terrorism Acts. Now her commitment to capitalism in the service of poverty elimination has made her the scourge of anti-free trade protesters and environmentalists alike. The Secretary of State is trying to bring Third Way politics into an area where it seems least likely to succeed and, at the same time, to make it understandable and controversial. For, as street protests at the European Summit in Nice this weekend follow those at the IMF and World Bank annual general meeting in Prague in September and, famously, in Seattle at the abortive World Trade Organisation meeting, globalisation has not got many popular champions. The onward march of transnational corporations and world money markets dismantles icons such as national community and democracy, has enfeebled governments and provoked universal disquiet. From British euro-scepticism, to Islamic fundamentalism or the re-emergence of the Austrian far right - all have similar roots in locally grounded disquiet that what really matters to people no longer has legitimacy. Clare Short is taking on this movement head to head. She believes this reaction is wrong-headed, hypocritical and selfish. What the poor want, she says, and what she wants for them, is a chance to enjoy Western living standards by joining in the same capitalism that delivers the goods for us. Her main concern is Africa: conflict- ridden, devastated by Aids and home to the majority of the world's extreme poor. She sees the success of Mozambique and Uganda in winning inward investment and sustaining Asian Tiger-type economic growth rates that allows them to keep ahead of population growth - albeit from a desperately low base - as a model for the rest of the continent. But although she praises free trade and private inward investment, Short still carries 'the white woman's burden' - the belief that the rich countries must take responsibility. A Western country like Britain has to get stuck in and help, especially in providing health and education and also to stop corrupt governments, she believes. Good governments must uphold rigorous standards in both the private and public sectors - and above all in their 'unreliable' African banks which ship out of Africa proportionally 10 times more savings than happens in Asia. One of Short's intended plans is to help governments recover money illicitly salted away in London by their predecessors. The big story, though, is to embrace the market. She talks enthusiastically about how Africa must develop by using its abundant land to grow agricultural goods for world markets with higher added-value - from coffee to flowers - and process the products in Africa. I put it to her that this is diametrically opposed to the arguments from green campaigners like Vandana Shiva who has her own farm in South India where she grows organic food using traditional methods in order to maximise local employment - and who is sharply critical of Short's approach because it creates inequality and environmental depredation. Short returns the fire: 'I would like to go to her house. I'll bet she's got things that come from all over the world. If you want to lock Africa and the poorest of South Asia out of that world, you're locking them into marginalisation and growing poverty. It is intolerable.' Her difficulty is that capitalism isn't fair, and that the development she advocates will necessarily throw up vicious inequalities with scant means of closing them.
