webTitle: Meek women lose out in battle for pay

fields.headline: Meek women lose out in battle for pay
fields.standfirst: Labour moves to close wages gap as research shows a fifth of female workers 'expect inequality'
fields.trailText: Labour moves to close wages gap as research shows a fifth of female workers 'expect inequality'
fields.body:
Working mothers are losing out on pay because they are not as aggressive as men in the office, the chair of the Equal Opportunities Commission has warned.

Women juggling a job and family are often so grateful for a chance to get on that they may not fight as hard as men for pay rises, Julie Mellor said. It is a trait exploited by unscrupulous bosses to fuel the gulf between men's and women's earnings.

Others lost out because the 'British taboo' about discussing money meant they did not realise what they should be getting. The commission has lobbied for compulsory 'pay audits' for employers, who would have to assess what every worker earns to uncover evidence of bias between men and women.

Her comments, which will reignite the debate about the battle of the sexes at work, come on the eve of a major Government offensive to close the pay gap which leaves British women earning 18 per cent less than men for the same jobs.

Employment Minister Tessa Jowell will announce the first step - reforms allowing women to bring pay claims to industrial tribunals more easily - tomorrow. But she will argue tribunals cannot solve deeper problems and that female expectations must be raised.

'When we did our Valuing Women campaign ... one of the things that came out from women was, "I know I am paid less than the man who did my job before me, but I am so grateful for a step up the ladder",' said Mellor.

'Women feel they are a financial provider and a carer at the same time; they juggle that, and that might be part of why they are willing to accept just a step on the ladder and don't always push as hard for higher pay. But that doesn't justify employers ending up discriminating in any way.'

Mellor does not blame women for not pushing harder: She has seen female workers fired just for asking why they were paid less than men. But she said employers should be more honest about who was paid what.

Although a third of companies questioned in recent commission research had done voluntary pay audits, campaigners want them made mandatory, arguing it could solve problems without resorting to tribunals. 'The fundamental point is that to tackle cases in the workplace requires doing a pay review,' she added.

Jowell will tomorrow launch a consultation paper on streamlining employment tribunals that are so tortuous that one group of NHS psychotherapists took 15 years to win a ruling. It will focus on the 'equal pay for work of equal value' rule, where women's jobs can be compared to equivalent but different men's jobs to expose bias.

The employer's defence of 'no reasonable grounds' - under which an equal value case is struck out before full evidence is heard - is expected to be scrapped and the number of expert witnesses needed to assess a claim reduced.

Group claims will be simplified and Ministers are also likely to confirm that the burden of proof in sex discrimination cases will be shifted, putting the onus on bosses to show they were not biased rather than on defendants to prove they were.

But Jowell will also argue in a speech to the Women's National Commission that tribunals cannot help women simply trapped in universally low-wage jobs. Around 10 per cent of the pay gap is caused by women dominating the 10 worst-paid professions.

The next stages of the campaign will involve raising schoolgirls' ambitions and supporting working mothers.

The commission's research found only 23 per cent of women had ever requested a pay rise against 31 per cent of men. One in five women thought the gender pay gap was 'to be expected': nearly one in 10 even thought it acceptable.

'Men are more aggressive in negotiating promotion and salary increases while women are more likely to accept their current pay and position,' the report concluded.

webTitle: GPs warned as they snub advice on anti-flu drug

fields.headline: GPs warned as they snub advice on anti-flu drug
fields.trailText: The Government's anti-flu campaign has been thrown into chaos by doctors who have pledged to disobey new official guidance on the only NHS drug to combat the illness.
fields.body:
The Government's anti-flu campaign has been thrown into chaos by doctors who have pledged to disobey new official guidance on the only NHS drug to combat the illness.

The doctors have been warned that they could endanger lives by refusing to prescribe the drug Relenza this winter. However, doctors' groups have said that many other GPs are set to follow suit.

The Department of Health is hoping that Relenza will help keep elderly people with flu away from hospital, easing the expected NHS winter crisis. The anti-flu campaign had already been hampered by a shortage of vaccine.

The National Institute for Clinical Excellence (Nice) performed a U-turn last month and recommended that Relenza should be made available to certain high-risk patients during flu outbreaks, because it shortens the course of the disease by a day.

The decision has split the medical profession, with many doctors claiming that the drug is expensive and there is no evidence that it has an effect. The Medicines Control Agency, which licenses the drug, has said that it does not work, and the highly influential medical journal Therapeutics Bulletin also refused to back the drug. Professor Joe Collier, editor of the Bulletin, said: 'There's muddle and confusion. There's no reason to change our mind. We do not accept this recommendation.'

A group of mid-Devon doctors, representing more than 20 practices, voted not to prescribe the drug on cost grounds. Dr Charles Kent, their chairman, said: 'It's a drug we're not familiar with. I'm not prepared to prescribe a drug to my patients that I wouldn't take myself.'

The decision means that most patients in mid-Devon asking their doctors for Relenza will be turned away.

Nice has no powers to force doctors to prescribe the drugs it recommends, but the Department of Health is warning that those family doctors who do not toe the line could be in trouble. Nice's chairman, Professor Sir Michael Rawlins, said: 'I would like to remind them that a group of highly expert individuals have looked at this, which includes GPs. Just how will they feel when one or two patients in the primary care group dies of flu?'

GlaxoWellcome, which makes Relenza, had lobbied Nice hard to overturn its initial ruling that the drug was not worth prescribing. A GlaxoWellcome director sits on the Nice committee that assesses drugs; Nice insists he took no part in the decision to recommend Relenza.

The NHS Alliance, which represents GPs, said many more are likely to leave it to individual doctors to decide whether Relenza prescriptions can be justified. A spokesman said that, as extra money had not been made available to cover the £25-a-course cost of Relenza, many practices were reluctant to take money from other services to pay for the drug. 'If doctors are prescribing Relenza, they will have to make cuts elsewhere.'

Two bodies which provide legal assistance for doctors facing negligence claims, the Medical Defence Union and Medical Protection Society, have warned doctors they could face legal action if they disregard the advice of Nice.

A spokesman for the Department of Health said: 'The Department expects that Nice recommendations will be followed, although GPs obviously need to make their own clinical judgments. They are potentially letting themselves in for a bit of trouble if they don't follow them.'

www.nice.org.uk
National Institute for Clinical Excellence's guidance on Relenza

webTitle: Future investment

fields.headline: Future investment
fields.standfirst: Parental leave benefits us all
fields.trailText: Children are a collective good. The vitality of our society and economy depends upon a well-parented, well-educated, healthy generation to replace those currently in work as they retire. Moreover, the most important time to make an intervention in a child's life is soon after birth. The evidence that subsequent emotional, intellectual and physical development is closely related to the quality of the first 12 months of life is overwhelming.These are the months in which the lifelong bonds associating child and parent are formed.
fields.body:
Children are a collective good. The vitality of our society and economy depends upon a well-parented, well-educated, healthy generation to replace those currently in work as they retire. Moreover, the most important time to make an intervention in a child's life is soon after birth. The evidence that subsequent emotional, intellectual and physical development is closely related to the quality of the first 12 months of life is overwhelming.These are the months in which the lifelong bonds associating child and parent are formed.

That is why the Government's Green Paper on parental leave deserves a powerful welcome. Britain's approach is the meanest in the industrialised world after the US. One reason that so many children from poorer homes are so disadvantaged is early neglect. The prospect of extending paid maternity leave to 26 weeks with the opportunity for a further six months off or working reduced hours will be of extraordinary benefit to low-paid women workers and, therefore, their children. So will creating paid paternity leave of two weeks. Even for the better paid, recognition of the fathers' role in parenting is a significant cultural breakthrough.

Most employer groups have reacted with caution verging on scepticism, despite the customary concessions promised to small business. British business resisted the introduction of women's lavatories after the First World War as an intolerable cost. The Government dismissed this opposition 80 years ago and should do the same over parental leave.

We realise that the right for parents to take paid time off to be with their newly-born babies risks coming under challenge from the childless. Some believe that they shoulder an undue burden in supporting what is a matter of choice - having children. But there is no reason why the childless should not enjoy the same right to have periodic sabbaticals to pursue their own choices. The Government should extend the principle of parental leave so that it becomes a component of what would become a universal entitlement.

webTitle: What to do if e-Santa is running late

fields.headline: What to do if e-Santa is running late
fields.standfirst: As a net shopper, you do have rights
fields.trailText: As a net shopper, you do have rights.
fields.body:
Shopping on the internet can be great when it works smoothly. No struggling round the shops with heavy bags. No queues.

But what if the e-tailer fails to deliver your carefully selected pressies in time for Christmas?

Tim Gordon, a partner at Ernst & Young, says that many big companies would rather refuse an order than disappoint on delivery. But smaller, recently established firms may still come a cropper this Christmas, he warns.

New 'distance shopping' regulations introduced in October give shoppers the right to clear information on arrangements for delivery before they commit to buy ing - including how long it will take for the goods to arrive. Catherine Hinchcliffe at the Office of Fair Trading says: 'Arrangements are normally for delivery within 30 days, but if the retailer specifies a shorter time frame, it should stick to it.'

You are entitled to your money back if an e-tailer promises delivery within four days and fails to make the delivery. However, getting your money back after the event won't prevent tears on Christmas Day, so it's a good idea to check e-tailers' last shipping dates to ensure delivery by December 24. Print a copy of the terms shown on the website. Richard Webb, a spokesman for the Trading Standards Institute, says: 'If you have doubts, ring the company up and ask specifically about delivery dates - and keep a note of who you speak to and what they say.'

Etoys.co.uk says its last shopping date for standard delivery is midnight on 17 December, while those prepared to fork out the extra for express delivery can extend the deadline to noon on 19 December. A spokeswoman for the company says there is no danger of paid-for goods not being available at the last minute: 'We work on real-time inventory, which means you can only order if the goods are physically in the warehouse.'

Amazon.co.uk does sell goods which are still held by suppliers, but promises that any items carrying a small Christmas tree symbol in their details on the website will be delivered by Christmas Eve. Its last order days are 14 December for Europe, 21 December for the UK.

If it looks as though your internet goods are not going to turn up in time and you decide to buy an alternative, remember that even if your purchase does turn up on time you can return it within seven working days.

If your purchase doesn't arrive, complain to the company first. Make your complaint in writing, keep a copy and send the original letter by recorded delivery. If the company does not respond or refuses to refund your money, contact your local citizens' advice bureau or trad ing standards officer, who will be able to advise you on the best way to get your money back. This may involve making a claim through the small claims court - leaflets and application forms are available from local county courts.

If you spent more than £100 on your purchase using a credit card, you can throw the ball into the credit card company's court by demanding a refund and leaving it to chase recompense from the internet company.

webTitle: BBC to fight for jewels of sport

fields.headline: BBC to fight for jewels of sport
fields.standfirst: Dyke set to launch paid-for channel
fields.trailText: The BBC is set to do battle for the nation's sporting 'crown jewels' by launching a paid-for sports channel next year as part of a multi-million pound drive to win back viewers from rivals.
fields.body:
The BBC is set to do battle for the nation's sporting 'crown jewels' by launching a paid-for sports channel next year as part of a multi-million pound drive to win back viewers from rivals.

Greg Dyke, the BBC's director-general, has authorised the doubling of the corporation's £150 million annual sports budget in an attempt to lure golf's Ryder Cup, England games in rugby's Six Nations competition and Premiership football highlights from Sky and ITV.

'A sports channel is an all-round good proposition,' said Peter Salmon, the BBC's new director of sport.. 'There'll be an announcement by Easter and we aim to have something that viewers can see by autumn next year.

'We've been talking about this for years and suddenly it's on the horizon, and it's serious, and there's a will to do it from the top of the BBC. It's just a matter of making sure the deal is right and the editorial values are right.'

In a radical departure for the BBC, it will form a joint venture with a rival broadcaster to set up the station, which will be a subscription-based service. Sky, NTL, ONdigital and Channel 4 are among those thought to be interested in joining forces on the project.

'We've narrowed the field and are still in talks with several different broadcasters. There are some really good suitors, but pretty soon we're going to have to make up our mind who we're going to walk up to the altar with', said Salmon.

Senior executives hope to avoid a damaging row with the Government over the channel by not putting any licence fee revenue directly into it. Chris Smith, the Culture, Media and Sport Secretary, has already warned that he would not approve the creation of a sports station which took money from other BBC activities.

'We wouldn't invest any money. The money would come from our commercial partners,' said Salmon. 'What we'd invest is our talent and our archive and some of our existing rights.'

The BBC hopes the new channel could screen prestige events such as Wimbledon, the Open golf championship and top-flight football, not all of which can always be shown on the existing BBC1, BBC2 and BBC Choice channels. 'We've got rights that we can't exploit as fully as we'd like to', said Salmon.

'We've been talking about this for years and suddenly it's on the horizon, and it's serious, and there's a will to do it from the top of the BBC. It's just a matter of making sure the deal is right and the editorial values are right.' In a radical departure for the BBC, it will form a joint venture with a rival broadcaster to set up the station, which will be a subscription-based service. Sky, NTL, ONdigital and Channel 4 are among those thought to be interested in joining forces on the project. 'We've narrowed the field and are still in talks with several different broadcasters. There are some really good suitors, but pretty soon we're going to have to make up our mind who we're going to walk up to the altar with', said Salmon. Senior executives hope to avoid a damaging row with the Government over the channel by not putting any licence fee revenue directly into it. Chris Smith, the Culture, Media and Sport Secretary, has already warned that he would not approve the creation of a sports station which took money from other BBC activities. 'We wouldn't invest any money. The money would come from our commercial partners,' said Salmon. 'What we'd invest is our talent and our archive and some of our existing rights.' The BBC hopes the new channel could screen prestige events such as Wimbledon, the Open golf championship and top-flight football, not all of which can always be shown on the existing BBC1, BBC2 and BBC Choice channels. 'We've got rights that we can't exploit as fully as we'd like to', said Salmon.

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Volume sales
fields.body:
Volume sales

Leaders in the Times used to shake the foundation of liberal democracies around the world. Alas, they now appear to have fallen victim to Wapping's lust for cross-promotion. But where this once involved cosying up to the Chinese authorities, the conflicts of interest these days appear somewhat more mundane.

On Friday, in a paper which covered President Chirac's expanding ambitions for European defence, the funeral of Damilola Taylor, and Cambridge University's failure to widen access, the Times ran a leader entitled 'Brought to book'. Perhaps 'Bought a book?' would have been a better choice for a 420-word advert for the Thunderer's' own annual 2001, unashamedly describing the book as 'more than deserving of a glossy sheet of wrapping paper'.

Diary suggests reading the articles on the Times website before squandering your hard-earned Christmas bonus, and is currently in negotiations with Wapping's 'commercial comment' department to promote our own tome.

A Times insider told Diary on condition of anonymity: 'All I can say is that it's a fantastic read and you should go and buy it.'

One of our reporters is missing

Associated's urban freebie, Metro, has a new star hack. Her name is Anne Campbell, and diary would like to nominate her for journalist of the year. Unfortunately she doesn't seem to have an extension at Metro's south London offices, and nor has anyone seen her. Ever. Diary is beginning to wonder whether she is a prototype newspaper version of Ananova, the virtual newsreader. So Anne, if you're out there, please get in touch.

Something up his sleeve

Diary was delighted to see Private Eye supremo Ian Hislop handing out prizes at the CBI/Real Business awards. The Park Lane Hilton event was strictly black-tie, so the audience of entrepreneurs were denied a viewing of the latest manifestation of Hislop's self-confessed taste for ever more fogeyish clothing.

Hislop's hand-made suit sports an astonishing five sleeve buttons, according to Eye insiders, one more than is officially deemed posh, and two more than normal people have.

Unfortunately for the diminutive Hislop, the same Eye insiders claim those five buttons nearly go up to his elbow. More the fop than the fogey?

Was he pushed?

Was it the Pink Paper which finally nudged delightfully barking columnist Peter Hitchens to resign last week? Hitchens went on Thursday in protest at porn magnate Richard Desmond taking over his paper - but only after wrestling with his conscience for an inordinately long time. But the gay news magazine - whose readers have regularly been lambasted by Hitchens - had been teasing the great man with weekly extracts from his splenetic book The Abolition of Britain. 'The top shelves of normal newsagents now sag with explicit pornography that would once have been hidden in dingy rubber-goods shops. Even the gardens of childhood have been invaded by the sexualisers and pornographers,' was the Pink's final aide-memoire last week. Within 48 hours, Hitchens had gone. The whisper at Associated is that Mail on Sunday columnist Norman Tebbit will be told to jump on his bike in the new year in order to make room for his right-wing soul-mate.

webTitle: Why we must boldly go

fields.headline: Why we must boldly go
fields.standfirst:
Michael Jackson, chief executive of Channel 4, on his hopes and fears for next week's White Paper on communications

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Today's television viewers want and expect quality, diversity and choice in the programmes they are offered. They don't want to be patronised or told what's good for them. They want to decide for themselves. And they have choice as never before, with hundreds of channels, and more being launched every month.
fields.body:
Today's television viewers want and expect quality, diversity and choice in the programmes they are offered. They don't want to be patronised or told what's good for them. They want to decide for themselves. And they have choice as never before, with hundreds of channels, and more being launched every month.

The range and sophistication of what can be accessed increases all the time, with new technologies delivering images by phone or on the web, storing them in a personalised video recorder, allowing interactivity.

Next week the Government will publish a Communications White Paper which is intended to recognise this convergence of technologies by creating a common system of regulation for all electronic media - from the BBC to the internet. If it's bold and radical it will create a better deal for consumers and keep Britain at the forefront of global developments in communications.

The Ministers and officials drafting the White Paper say they are also committed to 'lighter-touch' regulation. All broadcasters welcome that; we do at Channel 4. But it begs the question of whether we still need special regulation for television at all. If the internet can be governed by the normal laws of competition, libel and obscenity, why not television too? Shouldn't the market decide the rest?

It's not quite so simple. As more and more channels fight for the same number of viewers, costs get squeezed. And when costs get squeezed, risk, innovation and programmes made for minority audiences are bound to be among the first casualties. Yet those are the very qualities that define Channel 4's contribution to the rich broadcasting ecology of Britain, and they will be as valuable in the future as they are today.

So the question for us, and for the White Paper, is how do we ensure a rich and varied diet of programmes in the new converged and more lightly regulated world into which we are moving?

The BBC should continue to be the principal national broadcaster, using the guaranteed funding of the licence fee to compensate for what the commercial market cannot or will not provide. The regional role played by ITV needs to be maintained. And so does Channel 4's role as a broadcaster that has to earn its living in the market place, but can at the same time take risks with programming that is innovative and distinctive.

The rationale for a publicly owned Channel 4 is that it is a home for new ideas and new talent - 'the R&D lab of the creative economy'. In the ever more competitive world of commercial television, the pressure is on to ensure every programme maximises its chances to win audiences and earn revenue for shareholders. Publicly owned, Channel 4 is able to pay its 'dividend' to viewers in the shape of new ground-breaking entertainment programmes, innovative multi-platform concepts epitomised by our cricket coverage, imaginative learning services for schoolchildren and adult learners, high-quality news seven days a week and factual programmes.

If we are to continue to play that role, we have to be able to continue growing from a single television channel to a genuinely multi-platform, multi-channel media company. The days of single- channel broadcasters are over, as most of the industry already recognises.

The BBC has announced plans for seven separate channels in the digital age, and it has a major online presence. ITV has announced plans to launch a 'family' of channels. Channel 4, too, has its own multi-channel, multi-platform strategy. For example, our new entertainment channel, E4, launching next month, aims to build on our existing reputation for cutting-edge entertainment in the same way as FilmFour built on our reputation in cinema. Our online initiatives, ranging from the award-winning education site Homework High to the more consumer-orientated car4.com, will continue to expand.

Independent production companies are a vital part of British television: they provide a fresh and independent voice. Last year Channel 4 commissioned work from over 400 production companies, at least seven or eight times more than any other broadcaster. At a time when much of the industry is consolidating and integrating, we must guarantee the independents a continuing role in the broadcast market.

Much of the interest in the White Paper is likely to con centrate on the new regulatory structures it proposes. We want to see the present jumble of regulatory bodies replaced by a single unified structure covering all broadcasters, including the BBC, and dealing with all issues of content and economic regulation. We want to see a powerful and independent consumer body to ensure, among other things, that viewers know exactly what they're getting when they buy a new piece of equipment or subscribe to a new service.

Most of all, in a world of hundreds of channels and thousands of programmes, on-screen information for viewers must be simple and fair and must not discriminate in favour of one particular service provider.

We will be interested to see what the White Paper says, or fails to say, about television advertising - the lifeblood of ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5. To allow ITV to merge into one single company will be to give it an effective strangle-hold on advertising, with hugely damaging consequences for ourselves and other advertising-funded channels. That may do some good for ITV shareholders. It's difficult to see how it would bring any benefit to viewers.

Perhaps the most surprising - and most positive - thing to say about the White Paper is that, for all the differences of emphasis that inevitably exist between broadcasters, there is a large element of consensus. All of us want a White Paper that sets a new framework for the next decade but leaves the day-to-day details to a properly empowered regulator. If the Government gets that framework right, not only will viewers get a better deal, but Britain's content creators can look forward to a brighter future beyond the UK.

webTitle: Let the leaders be candid on camera

fields.headline: Let the leaders be candid on camera
fields.standfirst: Televised election debates between Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy can energise the contest and engage the electorate Five long months lie between the Queen's Speech and the expected May election. A televised discussion will at least relieve the tedium
fields.trailText:
Televised election debates between Tony Blair, William Hague and Charles Kennedy can energise the contest and engage the electorate Five long months lie between the Queen's Speech and the expected May election. A televised discussion will at least relieve the tedium

Special report: Parliament
fields.body:
Another straw in the gathering wind. Charles Kennedy has an aversion to aircraft which is inconvenient for an MP representing highlands and islands, and disabling for a man soon to face his first election campaign as party leader. In an attempt to quell his fear of flying, the Liberal Democrat spent a recent day being swooped about in a helicopter, the idea being to condition him for the rigours of round-the-dial electioneering.

With the Government using the Queen's Speech as a jewel-encrusted starting pistol, the race has begun. May the third - or so everyone believes - is the finishing line. The result - or so everyone assumes - will be a second term for Tony Blair. Five months of huckstering on the hustings spread before us and some weary members of the commentating trade - perhaps I really mean wearisome - are already declaring themselves suffused with ennui. Since these pundits are rewarded with generous salaries to take an interest in politics, Lord knows what the voters will make of it.

The possibility exists to inject at least one novel excitement into the campaign. There is the potential to energise the contest and add an enlivening dash of unpredictability. What I have in mind might even - though about this you have to be cautious - improve the level of argument by forcing all the party leaders to raise their games above ritual abuse of each other and the English language.

Rare among advanced democracies, there has never been a televised head-to-head encounter between the party leaders during one of our general elections. Though they spar every week when parliament is sitting, it is a very British absurdity that the leaders do not debate at the most critical moment, the time of decision. This deficit in our democracy should be redeemed.

The obstacle has been simple. Previous Prime Ministers have perceived no advantage in granting that much equality to the Leader of the Opposition. The only exception is James Callaghan who wanted a debate with Margaret Thatcher in 1979 because, while Labour lagged the Tories, his personal ratings outstripped her. She turned him down.

For Blair to follow this rule - that only desperate incumbents will take the risk of debating with the challenger - would mean there was no chance of a TV debate between himself and William Hague. What makes it a prospect - a better one, I judge, than at any time before - is that the Prime Minister is ready to engage. There are, of course, counsellors around Blair who fret about the jeopardies involved, just as there are advisors around Hague nervous on behalf of the Tory leader. But at this election there are compelling reasons for both men to agree to a studio high noon.

Blair is presented with an answer to his boiling frustration with the printed media. How to get his message across to the floating millions without it being corrupted - as he would see it - by the corrosively cynical press? Election TV debates appeal as a medium through which the Prime Minister can communicate direct with the voters. That is why Number 10 agreed to this week's live question time on ITV.

There is also the continuing worry in the Government's highest commands about low levels of turnout. Great debates between the leaders will undoubtedly be one of the talking points and turning points of the campaign. They just might encourage more people to get out and vote.

This creates an unusual community of interest between Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition. Hague also believes that the more he is exposed directly to the people, the more they will discover qualities in the Tory leader that are obvious to him but wilfully concealed from the electorate by the media. He is also persuaded that he could make his superior debating talents - as he sees them, anyway - count against the Prime Minister.

Both men are convinced that they could use a TV debate to find the other out. The self-interested calculations of the two leaders are for once converging to produce an outcome to the general and greater good.

The outstanding difficulty is the precise nature of the debates. The broadcasters have approached this more strategically than they did during the abortive manoeuverings about a TV debate at the last election. Those negotiations took place very late, in the full heat of the fray. Competing proposals with different formats allowed the politicians to play off the broadcasters against each other.

This time, Tony Hall of the BBC, and Richard Tait and Steve Anderson on behalf of ITN and ITV, have presented a joint bid well in advance.

The offer is to screen two TV debates involving the three leaders in election primetime on Sunday evenings. No one can precisely know, but an audience of 10 million per programme is not impossible. At least five million viewers is surely guaranteed. David Dimbleby is to chair the BBC debate. To strike a perfect balance, Jonathan Dimbleby is to chair the ITV debate. Last time, the politicians were given the opportunity to haggle the idea to death. So, in my view, it is sensible of the broadcasters to have broadly told the parties to take it or leave it.

Though the politicians have yet to make any formal response, much of the feedback is encouraging. At a Westminster lunch a few weeks ago, Alastair Campbell publicly declared that Blair was up for it. If the Prime Minister now retreats from this commitment he will look embarrassingly chicken. Kennedy should be pretty delighted with any terms which allow the Liberal Democrats to get a decent word edgeways into the contest.

The trouble is coming from the Conservatives. Not so much from Hague, who is a personal enthusiast for TV debates, but among those of his advisors who fear for their leader's safety in mouth-to-mouth combat with the other two. The Tories, in combination with Rupert Murdoch's Sky, have suggested an alternative format of three programmes featuring two leaders in different permutations. There are some obvious flaws in this device. The masses may book a ringside sofa for Blair versus Hague, but there won't be anything like the same crowd for Hague-Kennedy and Kennedy-Blair. There will also be a hole in each programme. When tax, say, comes up for argument, only two thirds of the points of views on the subject will be articulated in each debate. The Conservatives' biggest mistake was to propose this format themselves, which made it instantly unlikely that the other two parties would ever sign up.

The Tories have a legitimate worry. In a three-cornered fight, Blair and Kennedy will combine against Hague. The Tory leader worries he might be gang-banged. The BBC and ITV propose that the leaders will be able to cross-question each other - that, after all, is the point - but only one-to-one. This ought to be reassurance enough for the Conservatives. They surely wouldn't want us to conclude that William Hague is afraid of Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy.

I can't tell you that TV debates between the leaders will be an exercise in Socratic dialogue. Each team will feed their champ on sound-bites with which to chew up the other guy. There will be too much inevitable attention paid to which leader wore the darker blusher and who had the sweatier lip.

But here is a chance - I put it no more immodestly - that the leaders will engage with each other in a way which brings the arguments between them to serious life. If one more person who would otherwise have sat the election out makes a visit to the polling station, then the TV debates will have earntk their money. The public is interested; the broadcasters are ready. The politicians must be willing.

fields.headline: Clear and present dangers
fields.standfirst: Dodgy machinery, hazardous chemicals, obstacles all over the place_Yes, it's the typical office, writes  Caroline Palmer
fields.trailText: One of the largest payouts Unison achieved for its members last year was £600,000 awarded to Alison Hockaday. But getting it - as compensation for injuries at work which resulted in her right leg being amputated below the knee had taken a 13-year legal battle.
fields.body:
One of the largest payouts Unison achieved for its members last year was £600,000 awarded to Alison Hockaday. But getting it - as compensation for injuries at work which resulted in her right leg being amputated below the knee had taken a 13-year legal battle.

Her horrific injuries, and the even more horrific consequences, were not the result of being mangled in some heavy industrial machinery but of slipping over. First she slid on wet leaves on the entrance steps to the hospital where she worked as an occupational therapy assistant, and twisted her knee. More than three years later, her injury was exacerbated when she slipped on a wet vinyl floor in the hospital and fractured her right ankle.

This extreme case is one of the huge number of injuries in the workplace suffered by employees in theoretically safe white-collar jobs. In the parlance of the health and safety professionals, 'slips, trips and falls' are the single largest cause of major injuries at work. In 1998-99, more than 34,500 non-fatal injuries caused by a slip, trip or fall on the same level were reported to the enforcing authorities. The Health & Safety Executive estimates that the cost to employers every year is more than £300 million and the overall cost to society is put at between £810m and £840m a year.

The HSE figures show that thousands of working days are lost every year because of accidents in the office. For instance, more than 2,000 injuries involving at least three lost working days in offices were reported to the enforcing authorities during 1997-98 alone.

Trailing wires across walkways, or the boxes of stationery left next to the photocopier that catch unawares anyone hurrying past, may seem a minor irritation, but these kinds of hazards can cause terrible accidents.

Westminster City Council in London has frequently seen the effects. The council's patch includes a very broad range of offices - from flagship headquarters to very small offices packed into multi-occupancy buildings. For the year to the end of last March, health and safety officers received 630 accident reports from employees, of which an estimated third were in the office sector.

David Wildey, a senior health and safety officer with the council, said: 'People forget, when they look at the statistics for the large numbers of slips, trips and falls that happen each year, just how serious they can be. For instance, we had a situation of a lady in her mid-fifties who tripped over a box in a gangway, fell awkwardly and struck the corner of a filing cabinet with her face, damaging her cheekbone and the corner of her eye socket. She never returned to work.

'In another incident, a word processor operator, also in her early fifties, caught her foot in the cabling to her workstation, fell awkwardly and shattered her arm in three places. She also was never able to return to work.'

But the cases seen by health and safety officers in local authorities may be the tip of the iceberg. Although employers are required by law to report a wide range of accidents at work to the authorities (a free HSE leaflet gives details of incidents which are reportable), not all of them do.

In fact there are wide-ranging legal requirements on employers relating to health and safety that are not always followed. The British Safety Council, in its free booklet 'Health and Safety in the Office', says: 'Unlike very specific sets of legislation which cover the safe use of chemicals and workplace machinery, there is no single set of regulations covering health and safety in the office. However, the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999 require employers to assess general health and safety risks in office environments, including the dangers posed by slips and trips, using chemicals and carrying out manual handling tasks.'

But are employers actually assessing risk? According to a study of the regulations that specifically refer to the safe use of computer equipment at work (the DSE Regulations), carried out for the HSE by the Institute of Occupational Medicine in 1997, only 39 per cent of organisations questioned had undertaken risk assessments of computer workstations.

The study also found that a third of employers, particularly those running small firms, were unaware of the regulations. Through the experience of its members, Unison is only too aware of this level of ignorance, in some cases wilful. 'What we campaign vigorously on is for employers to carry out proper risk assessment in the workplace,' said Unison spokesperson Anne Mitchell. 'It is their duty to look for potential problem areas. But what tends to happen is by the time it gets to that stage it is too late.'

'We hear it all the time: it's only after someone has had an accident that something is done about a potential hazard that has been there for ages. We recently won a payout of £5,200 for an office worker who had a filing cabinet fall on him, injuring his foot and hip. And in another recent case a woman was paid £35,000 after injuring her back after being asked to lift items that were too heavy for her.' In total, Unison won £38m in compensation for its members for personal injuries. 'People may look at this figure and the amount of individual payouts and say that is an awful lot of money,' added Mitchell. But in every case the injured party says that they would much rather have their health back than any amount of money.'

Apart from the dangers of trips and slips, there are other accidents waiting to happen in an office. The British Safety Council points out that while offices are normally thought to be much quieter than factories, the continuing ringing of phones and faxes, along with the noise of people talking and typing, can sometimes cause stress and increase the chances of accidents.

There are also hazardous chemicals about - in the form of toners for photocopiers, as well as basic cleaning products. Therefore, under the Control of Substances Hazardous to Health (COSHH) Regulations 1999, employers are required to assess the risk of exposure to chemicals.

If an accident does occur at work, get in touch with the company first-aider or appointed person. For offices with fewer than 50 employees there may only be an untrained appointed person. In companies with more than 50 employees, the law states that there should be at least one trained first-aider able to deal with an emergency.

To reduce the chances of an accident happening in your office in the first place, the British Safety Council advises: 'Just taking the time to look around an office and noting things as simple as stray electrical cables or open filing cabinets can stop an accident taking place.'

Where there are problems that an employer refuses to deal with, many hundreds of employees each year complain to the health and safety officers of their local authority, often anonymously. 'In these cases,' said Westminster City Council's David Wildey, 'maintaining the anonymity of the reporter is paramount. We would usually visit the premises under the guise of a "planned" inspection. We have to be particularly careful where it is a small employer, that the complainant isn't too obvious.'

Health & Safety Executive information line: 08701 545500. Website: www.open.gov.uk/hse/hsehome.htm

Sit down, switch on, shut up

10 things to look out for

 Make sure employer has a health and safety policy and someone with authority to enforce it. (Too often the task is given to the manager's PA, who hasn't the power to make sure things are done.)

 Is there proper consultation on health and safety with employees?

 Does the employer regularly inspect the workplace?

 Are there regular safety drills and clearly marked exits?

 Check that employer has carried out a thorough risk assessment of the workplace.

 Are gangways kept clear?

 Is there adequate working space?

 Is the lighting adequate and suitable for the task?

 Is ventilation adequate?

 Does the employer have a smoking policy?

Source: David Wildey, Westminster City Council

webTitle: What can I do about my boss's gay jokes?

fields.headline: What can I do about my boss's gay jokes?
fields.trailText: I am a gay man working in a factory. Although most of the other men here have no problem with this, the boss of my section seems nervous and makes the occasional, rather offensive joke. What can I do?
fields.body:
I am a gay man working in a factory. Although most of the other men here have no problem with this, the boss of my section seems nervous and makes the occasional, rather offensive joke. What can I do?

Your employer should be very concerned if they knew. It is illegal to treat people differently because of their sex, and case law is developing to the effect that workers should not be discriminated against because of their sexual orientation, either.

To win a case, a worker would need to prove loss. You may feel that your boss's attitude was a factor in your being passed over for promotion. Or, if you were fired, you could argue that you were picked on for being gay. Either way, you could claim loss of earnings and damages for hurt feelings. You may not win - the case law is still rather fluid - but you would have a chance.

This may all seem a dramatic leap to make because someone makes offensive jokes. But a talk with your personnel department may encourage them to train managers in equal opportunities. They may be shocked to learn that damages for sex discrimination are unlimited.

Legal advice from Hammond Suddards Edge.

webTitle: How to steer Britain on the wrong track

fields.headline: How to steer Britain on the wrong track
fields.standfirst: Too many experts missed the signals at danger, writes  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: Suppose as a management anti-Christ you wanted to wreck an industry for life. What would you do? Easy - you'd start by making prices the highest in the world. Then you'd fragment the product lines and pricing structures, making them as hard to figure out as possible. To distance yourself still further from your customers, you'd encourage them to buy the product through a callcentre rather than over the counter.
fields.body:
Suppose as a management anti-Christ you wanted to wreck an industry for life. What would you do? Easy - you'd start by making prices the highest in the world. Then you'd fragment the product lines and pricing structures, making them as hard to figure out as possible. To distance yourself still further from your customers, you'd encourage them to buy the product through a callcentre rather than over the counter.

In management terms, you'd kick out all the old-line, industry-trained managers and appoint accountants who'd sell the family silver, hive off the operating companies and manage the rump of the business for decline. You'd manage by arbitrary targets and competing incentives while making sure that no one knew where accountabilities lay. This would ensure quality problems and chronic product unavailability.

And when things went dramatically wrong (as how could they not?) you'd interfere at the drop of a hat while denying any responsibility for the outcome. What, me?

In the circumstances, the most astonishing thing about the British railway system (for that is our subject) is not today's headless-chicken behaviour. It is that, despite all the best efforts of governments and managers to fight them off, passenger numbers have grown by 30 per cent and revenues by 50 per cent since privatisation. Extraordinarily, this is a growth industry. (Imagine what it would have been like if trains ran on time, fares were cheap, and you could buy any ticket easily at the station.)

As recent studies have shown, investment in rail is economically and socially beneficial. Plucking defeat from the jaws of such favourable circumstance is truly heroic - something that, alas, only British management could have achieved.

In this mother of all British muddles, the chaos is fractal - at whatever level and under whatever degree of magnification it is viewed, from station booking office to Westminster, from ticket prices to multibillion investment programme, the pattern of incompetence and incoherence is repeated. Today's panic and journey times - in some cases longer than those of a century ago - say it all: it's as if 100 years of management practice and railway development never happened.

All UK management's worst traits - short-termism, penny-pinching and a dismal inability to think in system terms - are reflected in the rail shambles, for which successive governments must bear a large part of the blame.

In the Sixties and Seventies, when every other European country was investing in rail as an essential part of the national infrastructure, the UK was cutting back. As well as reducing the network to its present creaking state, this ensured that the British supply industry, which built the rail infrastructure of half the Commonwealth, now barely exists. Rolling stock and know-how have to be imported from Italy, France and Canada, countries slugging it out in the burgeoning market for high-speed rail networks developing in Australia, Asia and even the US.

As late as the mid-Nineties, the Treasury was still getting it wrong. Ignoring Department of Transport projections, it privatised the industry on the assumption that rail travel would continue to decline - as wrong and arrogant a forecast as for the Dome, but in reverse and with far worse consequences.

Growth made nonsense of Railtrack's incentives, which were structured so that most post-privatisation 'investment' has gone on maintenance rather than network expansion. 'Railtrack was privatised in 1996 with a weak financial structure which gave it little or no incentive to invest,' regulator Tom Winsor said last month. 'That was a poor birthright for an industry which needed to deliver so much so soon.' Bringing it up to the standards of the continent will now take £55 billion and 10 to 20 years.

It's true British Rail was one of the original producer-dominated industries. But by the mid-Nineties the industry was getting it right. A 1995 reorganisation, in which responsibility was devolved to individual lines, promoted a 20 per cent increase in productivity and the beginnings of the rail revival.

That new enthusiasm (not to mention £2bn of legal and other costs) was tossed away by privatisation, at least in the form it took. The waste was compounded by the costs of coordinating what had been torn apart. Perhaps most damaging has been the Government's ubiquitous and iniquitous technique of management by targets.

Targets are fine if they are realistically related to capacity and the means of improving it. Where they aren't (operating companies can't improve Railtrack's performance and vice versa) they simply drive people to cheat by managing the one thing they can control: the numbers, rather than the convenience of passengers. This actually works against performance improvement: as individuals compete to maximise their own position, the inevitable result is suboptimisation of the system as a whole.

The result, astoundingly, is a system which doesn't fit or work at any level - like a demented jigsaw assembled with pieces from unrelated boxes. Only this condition can account for the current collective 'nervous breakdown' (as Sir Alastair Morton tellingly described it) in which speed restrictions increase the chance of accidents and turn more passengers off the trains; or the appointment as Railtrack's new boss of a finance man who has just one year's rail experience.

Meanwhile, for the Government the railways are an enduring nightmare and the worst of all worlds - a privatised disaster for which it has responsibility and no control. In the public mind, rail still ought to be a public service: as Lord Hattersley notes, it has made public ownership a popular concept for the first time in 50 years.

It is a supreme irony that what could be an election-winner is, for the present Labour Government, the solution that dares not speak its name.

But nor does the Government seem to have an alternative. That's not surprising: neither for Whitehall nor for UK industry generally is management a core competence. In April this year, the departments of transport and education jointly launched a Council for Excellence in Management and Leadership, whose first job will be 'to identify gaps and barriers which inhibit the development of sufficient excellent managers and leaders'.

Along with Rover and the England football team, the rail industry showcases them all. It should be the first case study. Ministers and civil servants should be obliged to sit in the front row of the class.
